DOC.HEADLINE: TAIWAN INVESTORS REMAIN CONFIDENT IN MALAYSIA
DOC.DATELINE: Kuala Lumpur, Dec. 1 (CNA) (By C.P. Chen and Lilian Wu)

TEXT.P: Despite the financial crisis that recently swept through Southeast Asia, Taiwan businessmen in Malaysia remain confident of the economic prospects in that country, Chen Kun-huang, president of Taiwan Business Association in Malaysia, said Sunday.
Chen noted that as of 1996, Taiwan businessmen had invested US$8 billion in the country, second only to the Japanese among foreign investors in Malaysia.
He said that most of the more than 2,000 Taiwan firms in Malaysia are manufacturers of electronics and electric products for export, and that they have largely been unscathed by the financial crisis.

He said Taiwan businessmen remain confident in Malaysia's economic prospects. They are not considering a withdrawal of their investments, and some are actually planning to expand operations, especially since their export products have become more competitive after the devaluation of the Malaysian currency.

Nevertheless, Taiwan investment in Malaysia has slowed in the past two years. A total of US$310 million in new investments was pumped in last year, while the figure for the first eight months of 1997 was only US$200 million.
It is noteworthy that most of the new investments have centered in the high-technology field, rather than in labor-intensive industries as in the past.

DOC.HEADLINE: PRESIDENT LEE'S APPROVAL RATING DROPS TO NEW LOW: POLL

TEXT.P: President Lee Teng-hui, who concurrently serves as chairman of the ruling Kuomintang (KMT), has seen his approval rating plummet to a record low of 39 percent following the KMT's latest election rout, according to a poll conducted by the United Daily News (UDN).

The telephone poll of 889 adults taken on Nov. 30 also found that the percentage of respondents dissatisfied with Lee's performance jumped to an all-time high of 46 percent, outpacing his support rate by 7 percent.

Lee's popularity rate peaked at 75 percent in December 1996 and fell to the previous low of 47 percent in May this year when popular former Justice Minister Ma Ying-jeou resigned from his post as a minister-without-portfolio. Lee's average approval rating in the 22 UDN polls conducted during the past one and half years was 58 percent.
The latest UDN survey showed that Premier Vincent Siew's approval rating also declined to 52 percent from 60 percent recorded in a similar poll conducted a month ago.

Although the opposition Democratic Progressive Party (DPP) won big in the weekend nationwide mayoral and magistrate elections, its political star Taipei Mayor Chen Shui-bian, who had campaigned vigorously for DPP candidates, did not see a dramatic surge in his popularity in the latest UDN opinion poll.

Chen's approval rating remained at 61 percent, the same as that registered in pre-election surveys. On the other hand, the number of those dissatisfied with Chen's performance rose slightly to 19 percent from an average of 17 percent recorded in previous polls.

Nevertheless, up to 75 percent of the respondents to the Nov. 30 UDN survey acknowledged that Chen had contributed much to help DPP candidates win in the elections; only 7 percent said Chen didn't make any contribution to the DPP's landslide win; and 18 percent declined to answer the question.

The survey also found that the respondents were divided over the necessity to reshuffle the Cabinet following the local elections. The proposal drew an equal number of opponents and proponents, both accounting for 32 percent of the total; while 35 percent said they do not have any opinion about the issue.
If the Cabinet were to be reshuffled, 50 percent said DPP members should be invited into the new Cabinet, but 20 percent objected to that proposal.
Meanwhile, a China Times opinion survey, also conducted on Nov. 30, showed that 60 percent of the respondents were satisfied with the outcome of the weekend elections.

Most of those interviewed said they could accept the fact that the pro-(Taiwan) independence DPP won the top executive posts in 12 cities and counties around the island, according to the China Times telephone poll of 768 adult residents.

About 60 percent attributed the KMT's unprecedented electoral setback either to voter dissatisfaction with the poor performance of incumbent KMT local government chiefs or to its intraparty squabbling and disunity. Several incumbent KMT mayors or magistrates were accused of having links with underworld gangs or of involvement in corruption scandals.

Fifteen percent of the respondents said the KMT's failure to nominate suitable or qualified candidates was to blame for its embarrassing defeat; and about 7 percent said the KMT should improve its campaign strategies.

Although more than half of local governments will soon be controlled by the opposition party, 25 percent of those interviewed said they believe relations between the central and local governments will improve in the future; 26 percent said there will be little change; but 18 percent said they expect rifts between central and local governments to worsen.

As to the impact of the election results on future relations across the Taiwan Strait, 34 percent said they don't think the DPP victory will affect cross-strait ties; 15 percent forecast relations between the two sides will deteriorate; while 13 percent said ties between Taipei and Beijing will improve.

Meanwhile, 33 percent of those interviewed said they are elated by the DPP's big win in the local elections; 26 percent said they do not have any special feelings about either the DPP win or the KMT defeat; while 23 percent said they worry about Taiwan's political development in the wake of the weekend polls.

DOC.HEADLINE: KMT CENTRAL COMMITTEE PLENARY MEETING URGED

TEXT.P: In the wake of the major setback for the ruling Kuomintang (KMT) in Saturday's mayor and county chief elections, several members of the party's Central Committee have called for an interim plenary meeting to examine the causes of the defeat.

Wei Yung, chairman of the Vanguard Found, and Lee Ching-an, a Taipei City councilor, said in a seminar on Sunday that they will ask party leaders to convene an interim plenary meeting of the Central Committee as soon as possible and that they are planning to set up a group to promote reforms within the party.

Wei said a meeting should be held to forward the opinions of all Central Committee members to ranking authorities, as the KMT's huge loss in Saturday's elections represents a clear warning signal to the party.

The main opposition Democratic Progressive Party scored victories in 12 of the 23 cities and counties in the elections, nearly doubling its current total of city mayor and county magistrate seats, while the number held by the KMT dropped from 15 to eight.

Wei went on to say that he had exchanged opinions with Lee and they both agreed to submit a petition asking the party to look into the roots of the crisis if their call goes unheeded by the party leadership.

Wei said it is important to hold a plenary Central Committee meeting now at a time when the KMT is facing a challenge to reform itself. He added that he will invite other committee members to set up a panel devoted to revitalizing the party.

The group, he pointed out, will focus on charting a new KMT policy direction, adjusting intraparty mechanisms, studying the party's election strategies and improving its effectiveness in the Legislative Yuan.
The political analyst said the KMT should seriously consider implementing a system of primary elections to select party candidates for electoral contests.

For her part, Lee asked KMT Chairman Lee Teng-hui to put forward a timetable and an outline for the reforms and to call a Central Committee meeting immediately in view of next year's legislative elections and upcoming balloting for the mayors of Taipei and Kaohsiung.

DOC.HEADLINE: PEOPLE KILL DOGS AS RABIES SPREAD IN KALIMANTAN

TEXT.P: Fear of rabies has prompted the Dayak people in remote areas of West Kotawaringin regency of Pangkalan Bun, Central Kalimantan, to kill their dogs despite their reliance on the animals for years.

Known locally as "kudu" dogs in the Dayak region -- which covers Nanga Kalin, Namuah and Melata villages of Bulik subdistrict -- the animals have been killed by the local people since October when rabies began to spread in the area.
The Dayak people, compared to other ethnic groups in Indonesia, ironically treat their dogs highly and consider them to be part of their families, going as far as sharing their beds with them.
The Dayaks, however, have declared kudus as enemies lately out of fear of the fatal rabies.
Guntur, aged 50, who is a community leader of Melata village, said his people were left with no choice but to kill the dogs they see roaming the village.

"We fear further disaster, so we decided to kill our dogs despite our love for them," he was quoted by Antara news agency as saying, adding that the decision was unanimously made by the community as a last ditch attempt to protect themselves from rabies.
"Our dogs have become wild and vicious. Their tails fold down stiffly with their saliva foaming. They also hide in dark places now," said Guntur.
Apek, aged 33, however, expressed hope that local animal institutions as well as the health office will extend help to the people to calm their fears.
He objected to the idea of killing the dogs.
"Dogs have been useful to families. They help hunt wild boars for food," he said.
"My two dogs, which were killed recently, had brought me hundreds of wild boars and other animals and help me feed my family," said Apek.

DOC.HEADLINE: AUSSIE MEDIA SEES INCREASED CROSS-STRAIT TENSION AFTER DPP POLL WIN

TEXT.P: The overwhelming victory in Taiwan's local elections by the Democratic Progressive Party is expected to bring increased tension between Taipei and Beijing because of the DPP's pro-independence views, according to leading Australian media sources.

In a five-column headline "KMT loss in polls may sting Beijing," mass-circulation newspaper The Sydney Morning Herald reported that the shock triumph of the opposition party in Saturday's local government polls is a blow to the ruling Kuomintang and a sign that increased friction with Beijing may lie ahead

The daily quoted political analysts as saying that the strong support for the DPP would be closely monitored in Beijing. The opposition party supports eventual independence for Taiwan although its policy on ties with mainland China is generally vague.
Many senior DPP officials openly advocate independence and strongly dispute China's historical claim to sovereignty over the island.
Beijing has refused to rule out the use of force to rein in the island if Taiwan declares independence.

Another leading newspaper, The Australian, also devoted a five-column article, headlined "Poll shock fuels Taiwan push for statehood," in which the daily quoted DPP Chairman Hsu Hsin-liang as saying that: "As of today, the DPP has become a vital factor in deciding Taiwan's political future that no country, including China, can ignore."
It also quoted DPP Secretary-General Chiu I-jen as vowing that the opposition would push ahead with its plan to turn Taiwan into an independent state.

The daily quoted Professor Andy Chang Wu-yueh, director of the Institute for China Studies at Tamkang University, as saying that: "Beijing will be worried that Taiwan's political map has been redrawn in favor of the pro-independence DPP, but may also welcome the blow to Lee's (Teng-hui) prestige and expect the KMT to offer a more positive attitude toward China."

In the mayoral elections on Nov. 29, the DPP won 12 of the 23 city and county executive posts, up from its previous six, while the ruling Kuomintang won only eight posts, down from its previous 15. Another three mayoral posts went to independent candidates.
That means more than 70 percent of Taiwan's 22 million citizens will be under DPP local administrations, according to Australian media reports.

The Australian Financial Review, the leading business newspaper in Australia, also reported that the DPP's "demolition of the formerly invincible Kuomintang in local elections should ensure that Taipei's charismatic Mayor Chen Shui-bian [will] ... become Taiwan's first opposition president."

"Such an electoral rout is a personal humiliation for the president, Mr. Lee Teng-hui, who, along with other top government heavyweights, such as Vice President Lien Chan and Provincial Governor James Soong, campaigned strongly on behalf of Kuomintang candidates," the daily reported from Taipei.

DOC.HEADLINE: PESTICIDE USE INCREASES IN SAUDI ARABIA

TEXT.P: The use of pesticides is increasing due to the speedy urbanization taking place in Saudi Arabia, a Saudi expert said.

In 1996, Saudi Arabia imported US$40.26 million worth of pesticides compared to US$36.8 million in 1995. The increase in the use of toxic substances to kill pests in the country is quite contrary to the present trend of environment-friendly integrated pest management worldwide, pointed out Mousaid Shieshakly.

"Demands to decrease wide-range use of pesticides in the human environment and to apply formulations with as little toxins as possible have continuously increased recently in other parts of the world," the expert added.

DOC.HEADLINE: WTO TO SET SETTLEMENT PANEL ON US-JAPAN APPLE ROW

TEXT.P: The dispute settlement body of the Geneva-based World Trade Organization (WTO) has decided to set a panel to resolve a dispute between the United States and Japan over trade in apples, trade officials said Sunday.
The dispute settlement panel of the global trade referee will begin a nine-month examination after the WTO picks its members, they pointed out.

The United States maintains that Japan's agricultural quarantine system poses non-native barriers to US-grown apple imports, and requested last month that the WTO form the panel of experts on the matter.
Japan imports two types of apples from the United States and Washington has requested that the number be increased by five varieties starting next January.
Washington has argued that Japanese requirements for a check for each variety of apples constitutes a nontariff barrier.
Japan insists the quarantine system cannot be simplified, saying the efficacy of the fumigation treatment of apples by US farmers should be checked for each variety of apple.
Japan says such checks are necessary to prevent pests that may be in US-grown apples from proliferating in Japanese apple-growing districts, trade officials said.

DOC.HEADLINE: SCHOLARS FRET OVER DPP VICTORY, WHILE BUSINESSMEN DON'T

TEXT.P: Professor Ma Chi-hua of National Chengchi University sees the dismal failure of the ruling Kuomintang (KMT) and the victory of the opposition Democratic Progressive Party (DPP) in the just-concluded local elections for heads of 23 cities and counties as "disappointing."

Ma said although he personally is not thrilled with the KMT's recent performances, the outcome of the local contests is disastrous, because at least the ruling party's platform does not advocate Taiwan independence.
Conversely, the DPP has vowed to pursue the island's independence from mainland China, a development Beijing has vowed to oppose by force.

Ma expressed fear that a domino effect may be triggered by the Nov. 29 KMT collapse, heralding a DPP rise to power through next year's legislative elections and the mayoral contests in Taipei and Kaohsiung, as well as presidential polls still two years away.
The KMT lost seven of its 15 seats in the local elections to the DPP which grabbed 12 seats, up five from its showing in the last such elections in 1993.

Prof. Kuo Wu-ping, also from National Chengchi University (NCU), who sees the onset of the "Yeltsin effect" in Taiwan, suggested that KMT Chairman Lee Teng-hui pay equal attention to revitalizing the KMT and to carrying out national political reforms. Kuo said this would prevent Lee from following the footsteps of Russia's President Boris Yeltsin, who accomplished political reform in that country, but at the cost of his party's and his own political future.

Kao An-pang, an NCU professor in economics, said conflicts between the central and local administrations over control of government assets and distribution of financial resources will become increasingly tense, which in turn will give rise to pressure for legislation on resource allocations islandwide.
Meanwhile, most of the island's business leaders are playing a different tune.
Kao Chin-yen, chairman of the Chinese National Federation of Industries, said the DPP's victory in the local elections will have little impact on the overall domestic investment climate.
The contests for top offices in 23 cities and counties around the country are not significant as the legislative and presidential elections, he noted.

Cheng Ming-chang, chairman of the Taipei CEO Association, attributed the DPP's victory to its pluralistic nomination system, as well as to the fact that it has downplayed the sensitive issue of cross-strait relations, even though the party platform advocates Taiwan's independence.

If the victorious DPP candidates fail to keep their campaign promises or prove unable to help improve their constituents' welfare, they will be promptly booted from office, he said, adding: "The voters are as sharp as a tack."

DOC.HEADLINE: CENTRAL-LOCAL GOVERNMENT INTERACTION TO BE STRENGTHENED

TEXT.P: The Cabinet will work out new measures to provide for closer interaction between the central and local governments in the wake of the weekend mayoral and magistrate elections, a senior official said on Monday.

Interaction between levels of government has become a new focus of attention after the opposition Democratic Progressive Party (DPP) won the top executive post in 12 cities and counties around the island in the just-concluded polls.

The Cabinet official said the DPP is still not the ruling party even though 70 percent of the Republic of China's 21.3 million people will come under DPP's jurisdiction at the local level after the newly elected mayors and county chiefs are sworn later this month.

"We are satisfied with DPP Chairman Hsu Hsin-liang's promise that DPP-ruled constituencies will not confront the central government to cause social anxiety or instability," said the official, who preferred anonymity.

Taipei Mayor Chen Shui-bian, a DPP political star who campaigned vigorously for DPP candidates in the latest local elections, has also denied that he would organize an association of DPP mayors and magistrates to challenge the central government.
The official said he hopes the DPP politicians will honor their promises with deeds.

For its part, the official said, the Cabinet will work out a package of measures in the near future to reinforce consultations and interaction between central and local governments with a view to upgrade administrative efficiency and accelerate various community development projects.

DOC.HEADLINE: CABINET, KMT RESHUFFLE IN THE OFFING

TEXT.P: Due to dramatic political changes brought by the outcome of local elections last week, the government is expected to move forward the timing of a partial Cabinet reshuffle, high-ranking Executive Yuan officials said Monday.
They said the move is inevitable in view of the new political map drawn after Saturday's islandwide polls for city and county chiefs.
The ruling Kuomintang managed to hold on to only eight of the 23 posts up for grabs, while the opposition Democratic Progressive Party won 12 seats, and the remaining three went to independents.

It is understood that Premier Vincent Siew, who kept most of the previous Cabinet intact when he assumed the premiership on Sept. 1, has already reviewed a plan for the new Cabinet composition. The lineup will undergo "not a few" changes, and the new ministers are expected to bring a fresh atmosphere to the central government.

Meanwhile, as KMT Secretary-General Wu Poh-hsiung has insisted upon resigning to take the responsibility for the party's stunning defeat in the elections, the KMT leadership will also undergo changes.

Siew has already exchanged views with President Lee Teng-hui, Vice President Lien Chan and Wu on the extent of the Cabinet reshuffle, and a preliminary consensus has been reached, the high-ranking officials said.
They said that after the KMT leadership positions have been filled, the Executive Yuan will begin the partial Cabinet reshuffle, the timing of which could come in "one or two weeks."

As for the new faces in the Cabinet, the officials said that as Siew attaches great importance on teamwork, the ideal ministers will be individuals who are enthusiastic, noncontroversial. and able to work well and coordinate with others, the officials said.

They also said that to deal with the post-election political situation as well as to prepare for legislative polls and the balloting for Taipei and Kaohsiung mayors next year, the government will not rule out recruiting more nonpartisan personnel. But inviting DPP members to serve on the new Cabinet will be out of the question for the time being for reasons of political pragmatism.
Chan Chih-hsien, director-general of the Department of the Health (DOH), is the only minister without party affiliation in the present Cabinet lineup.

DOC.HEADLINE: TAIPEI STOCKS NOSEDIVE

TEXT.P: The Taiwan Stock Exchange took a nosedive of 5.1 percent on Monday, dragging down a broad range of issues, with the weighted index plummeting 396.55 points to 7,400.64.
Market sources attributed the frantic sell-off to the surprising defeat of the ruling Kuomintang in islandwide local elections over the weekend.

P.K. Chiang, chairman of the Cabinet-level Council for Economic Planning and Development (CEPD), called for cool-headedness from the investors, saying it is natural for the stock market to reflect election results, but that the fall will be only a temporary phenomenon as Taiwan's economy is fundamentally healthy.
Despite the weekend setback for the ruling KMT, he continued, Premier Vincent Siew will continue to push for programs to revitalize the economy, stabilize public order, and raise standards of living.
In an average trading day, losers overwhelmed gainers 431 to 16, while 13 other issues remained unchanged.

Banking shares topped the list of losers, plunging 6.3 percent, followed by electrical engineering issues' 5.5 percent drop, cement and construction shares' 4.4 percent fall, and textiles issues' 3.8 percent decline.
Market turnover amounted to NT$94.3 billion (US$2.94 billion) on the exchange of 1.68 billion shares.
Among the most heavily traded stocks were Acer, Mitac International, TSMC, Ritek, UME, A.S.E., Elitegroup, and China Steel.

DOC.HEADLINE: BEIJING'S ATTITUDE TOWARD TAIWAN UNCHANGED
DOC.DATELINE: Beijing, Dec. 1 (CNA) (By Wang Hsin-chung & Eva Chen)

TEXT.P: Mainland China's attitude toward Taiwan regarding bilateral relations remains the same following the resounding victory of the opposition Democratic Progressive Party (DPP) in local mayor and county chief elections on Saturday, observed officials of various mainland organizations relating to Taiwan affairs.

There are two central tenets in Beijing's attitude toward Taipei, both of which remain unchanged, said deputy director of the Taiwan Studies Institute of the Chinese Academy of Social Sciences Yu Keli, on Sunday: anticipating Taipei's response to the "eight principles" of Jiang Zemin, General Secretary of the Chinese Communist Party; and the concept that both sides of the Taiwan Strait should enter the process of negotiation as soon as possible.
The DPP's first major victory over the ruling Kuomintang (KMT) has created speculation as to whether Beijing will adjust its stance toward Taiwan.

Now that the local elections have come to an end, Yu said, the issue of how to make a breakthrough in relations, which is deemed a most important issue by the Beijing authorities, might attract even more attention in various circles.

Yu stressed that while Beijing does not want political talks alone, it feels that because protocol always gets obstructed by political factors, political dialogue is "necessary" and "beneficial" to the progress of protocol affairs.

DOC.HEADLINE: KMT'S COPYCAT STRATEGY BACKFIRES IN TAIWAN POLLS

TEXT.P: The blurring of party lines -- in which Taiwan's ruling Kuomintang (KMT) is widely seen as adopting the platform of the opposition Democratic Progressive Party (DPP) -- has been blamed for the KMT's massive defeat in local polls on Saturday.

The Singapore-based Straits Times on Monday quoted analysts as reporting in a dispatch from Taipei that while the KMT officially favors unification with mainland China, it has moved in recent years towards a more centrist position of maintaining the status quo, the report said.

Taipei has rejected Beijing's offer for unification under its "one China" formula, maintaining that Taiwan and the mainland are now under separate rule and that unification can only take place under democratic conditions.

At the same time, the DPP had been playing down its pro-independence stance in recent elections in a bid to woo more mainstream voters, saying that there is no need for Taiwan to declare independence because the island already enjoys de facto independence, the report said.

The KMT is also seen to be cooperating with the DPP on some major policies originally proposed by the DPP -- such as recent constitutional reforms which allow for the dismantling of the Taiwan Provincial Government, said Professor Hu Fu of the National Taiwan University (NTU) political science department in an interview on Saturday night after the poll results were announced.
"Voters simply cannot differentiate their policies anymore," he was quoted as commenting.

The blurring of party lines had worked to the disadvantage of the KMT at a time of widespread public dissatisfaction over its inability to maintain law and order, prompting voters to elect the DPP's "fresh faces" for a change, as Hu put it.
Professor Lu Ya-li, also of NTU, noted during a seminar on Sunday that Taiwan's urban population did not support the ruling party in this election because of the law-and-order issue, the report said.

"Chen Chin-hsing was the DPP's biggest campaign aide," he was quoted as saying, referring to the major suspect in a high-profile murder case who turned himself in last month after taking hostage a South African diplomat's family.
"In the end, he was caught not by the police, but rather, it was he himself who wanted to be caught."
Taiwan's influential local factions had also turned their backs on the ruling party because they had been offended by the KMT's crackdown on underworld figures linked to them, Hu said.
At the same time, some party members had felt alienated by the central leadership's move to streamline the provincial government, seeing it as a betrayal of party tradition, he said.

The provincial dismantling became an issue that rekindled the reunification-versus-independence debate in Taiwan as the move was interpreted by some as tantamount to declaring that Taiwan was no longer a province of China, the report said.
NTU's Professor Chang Lin-cheng pointed out that the expected provincial freeze had made the county and city head positions more sought after than ever.
A large number of maverick candidates standing without party support had in effect reduced the KMT vote, the report also noted.

DOC.HEADLINE: DPP CHAIRMAN TO VISIT US, SOUTH KOREA

TEXT.P: Riding on the wave of the opposition Democratic Progressive Party's (DPPs) victory in Saturday's local mayor and county chief elections, Hsu Hsin-lian, DPP chairman, will visit the United States this weekend, according to official party sources.
Hsu, accompanied by Sisy Chen, director of the DPP's Publicity Department and Parris Chang, DPP representative to the United States, will leave Taiwan on Saturday for the weeklong visit.
The delegation is scheduled to meet Richard Bush, chairman of the American Institute in Taiwan and other US government officials.

Hsu's first stop will be in New York City, where he is to speak to overseas Chinese there about how the DPP has transformed itself so successfully in recent years, culminating in its winning 12 of the seats up for grabs last week.
He will also hold a press conference at the National Press Club in Washington, D.C. to promote the experience of the largest opposition party in Taiwan.
During his stay in the US, Hsu is also expected to call on several think tanks, including the American Enterprise Institute, the Atlantic Council and the Heritage Foundation, as well as US senators.

Hsu is expected to return to Taiwan on Dec. 14, before traveling to South Korea to observe that country's presidential election on Dec. 18. South Korean presidential candidate Kim Dae Jung is an old friend of Hsu's.

DOC.HEADLINE: TAIPEI MAYOR DENIES HE'LL ORGANIZE `GREEN ALLIANCE'

TEXT.P: Taipei Mayor Chen Shui-bian, who has been credited for helping his opposition Democratic Progressive Party (DPP) win big in the weekend local elections, on Monday denied media reports that he is to organize a "green alliance" of DPP mayors and magistrates to confront the Kuomintang (KMT)-controlled central government.
The term "green" has been coined widely in Taiwan to indicate DPP sympathies and refers to the green-and-white of the DPP's party colors.

Chen pointed out that the outcome of the weekend mayoral and county chief elections reflects the latest public opinion. "Although our party won the top executive post in 12 cities and counties around the island, we (local administrations) don't intend to besiege the central government," he stressed.
"Now is not the time to think about confrontation," Chen said, adding that different levels of government should work hand-in-hand for the well-being of all the people on the island.
"City and county governments should support and coordinate with the central government to carry out various community development and welfare projects," Chen noted.

As the central government will deal directly with city and county governments following the "marginalization" of the Taiwan Provincial Government late next year, Chen said the cabinet should start to delegate more power to local governments.

"Relations between levels of government should be adjusted and the central government should allow local governments to have a bigger say or authority in personnel, financial, educational and police administration," the outspoken mayor said.

Moreover, Chen said, partisan considerations should be set aside when handling central-local government relations. "Even where different party affiliations exist, local and central government officials should cooperate closely to boost overall national and public interest."

Chen further said local DPP government chiefs should not isolate themselves from the central government, while the KMT-dominated central government should not ignore or overlook the existence or interests of DPP-administered constituencies.

The DPP headquarters will meet with all newly elected DPP mayors and county chiefs over the next few days to discuss joint administrative strategies and working guidelines. Chen said he will be more than willing to attend the meetings to share his three years of experience in administering the Taipei municipal government.

Until Saturday's resounding success, the DPP, with only six cities and counties under its control, has concentrated more on parliamentary politics at the central level than on local political issues at the grassroots level.

Chen, who has made no secret of his intention to seek reelection in next year's mayoral election, said the DPP's latest electoral victory is no guarantee of victory in the 1998 legislative elections, the mayoral elections for Taipei and Kaohsiung municipalities, or for the 2000 presidential elections. "The DPP should redouble its efforts to reach out to the people and continue to exercise caution and prudence in working out its strategies for those elections."

Commenting on the dramatic plunge on the Taiwan stock market following Saturday's election results, Chen said he believes the drop was only the result of psychological factors. "The downward trend will be short-lived. I don't think the DPP's win signals the advent of a bear market here," he added.

DOC.HEADLINE: CENTRAL, LOCAL GOVERNMENTS WILL WORK TOGETHER: WANG

TEXT.P: Economic Affairs Minister Wang Chih-kang said on Monday that his ministry will increase communication with local government chiefs to boost economic development at local and national levels.
Wang expressed the belief that his ministry and local governments, although cut from different political cloth, will be able to work together toward this goal.

Taiwan's major opposition Democratic Progressive Party (DPP) managed to win 12 out of 23 constituencies in Saturday's mayoral and county chief elections, dramatically changing the nation's political picture at the local level.

Wang said it is normal in any democratic society for political parties to experience election gains or losses, noting that Saturday's elections are viewed by the international community as an indication that democracy has truly come of age in Taiwan.

As one of the Economic Ministry's major tasks is to create a healthy and stable investment climate for investors, Wang said his ministry will further strengthen communication with the newly elected local chiefs in the 12 DPP-controlled cities and counties to promote national economic development.

Meanwhile, Finance Minister Paul Chiu, when questioned on the impact of the DPP's stunning victory on the ministry's current allocation of government expenditure and revenues, told local newspapers that his ministry will continue to carry out its operations in accordance with set ROC policy.

He said that future allocation of revenues between the central and local governments will be decided after the revision of the current Law Governing the Allocation of Government Revenues and Expenditures is approved by the Legislative Yuan, adding that his ministry will soon begin work on the revision.

Meanwhile, the mass-circulation China Times reported on Monday that the Ministry of the Interior will accelerate its pace in drafting the Self-governance Law for Counties and Cities, as the power of city mayors and county magistrates will be significantly enhanced after the Taiwan Provincial Government is abolished.
The proposed law will give city and county chiefs greater power in personnel management, while local councils will have greater legislative power, according to the newspaper.

DOC.HEADLINE: THAI KING APPRECIATES DEDICATION OF ROC AGRO-TECH CENTER
DOC.DATELINE: Chiangmai, northern Thailand, Dec. 1 (CNA) (By Kuo Fang-chih & Debbie Kuo)

TEXT.P: Thai Prince Bhisatej Rajani on Monday expressed his country's appreciation to the Republic of China government for the dedication of a Taiwan agricultural technical training center in rural Chiangmai as a gift marking the 50th anniversary of the coronation of Thailand's King Bhumibol Adulyadej.

On behalf of his father the king, Bhisatej accepted the dedication of the agro-tech center built by the ROC government which he lauded as a token of friendship between the people of Taiwan and Thailand.

According to Dr. Sung-ching Hsieh, deputy secretary general of the International Cooperation and Development Fund of the ROC, the center, built at a cost of NT$10 million (US$312,500), is an extension of a 27-year Taiwan commitment to Thailand to help turn land formerly given over to opium cultivation into forestry and orchards.

The center, located at the heart of a 100-hectare farm tract in Chiangmai's Fang District, is a white, European-style two-story building with a meeting hall, a library, and dormitory facilities. Members of the ROC agro-tech mission in northern Thailand and three agricultural experts also reside in the center.
The first training course offered by the center began on Monday to 50 Thai attendants, including several university professors.
The Taiwan agro-tech mission first came to Thailand in 1970 at the invitation of King Bhumibol as part of a force designed to back up the nation's agricultural development.

DOC.HEADLINE: AUSTRALIA TO BOOST DEFENSE SPENDING DUE TO ASIAN UNCERTAINTY

TEXT.P: Australia is expected to dramatically boost its defense spending to upgrade its air and naval strike capabilities to cope with the uncertainty in East Asia.

Military sources disclosed that nearly A$6 billion would be spent on new medium-range missiles and sensors for combat aircraft, air-to-air refueling to increase the range of the F-111 aircraft and FA-18 and airborne early warning and control aircraft to improve surveillance and guidance in order to upgrade the combat readiness for the Royal Australian Air Force.
In addition, the spending would also cover extensive overhauls and strike and self-defense upgrades of the naval fleet, the sources said.

They said the decision to strengthen maritime power comes amid concerns by strategic planners that future conflicts may be more demanding because of a growth in regional military power spurred by stronger Asian economies.

Australia's foreign policy white paper noted that on a table of East Asian economies, Australia has gone from second to fourth place in a decade and will slip to sixth in terms of military power by 2010.
Currently, there is no apparent threat to Australia. But defense planners are alarmed by the greater strategic unpredictability and regional capabilities following military build-ups in the region.

Military analysts said there is uncertainty in East Asia, with the Korean peninsula, the Taiwan Strait and the South China Sea remaining as possible flashpoints, although there has been a recent easing of tensions between the two sides of the Taiwan Strait since the 1996 missile shooting exercises by mainland China off Taiwan's coast.

DOC.HEADLINE: AUSTRALIA ONE OF WORLD'S HIGHEST-TAXED COUNTRIES

TEXT.P: Australia's tax rates are among the highest in the world, grouped along with Ireland, Japan and Canada, according to the National Tax and Accountants Association.

The Daily Telegraph in Sydney reported on Monday that the personal income tax and indirect tax for an Australian citizen whose annual income is A$38,355 would be 68.7 percent of his or her total earnings, second only to Ireland's 69 percent.
Personal income tax in Japan is 65 percent plus a three percent general and service tax, bringing the total to 68 percent.
Germany imposes personal income tax of 53 percent plus a value-added tax of 15 percent, while Canada imposes personal income tax of 53.19 percent plus seven percent general and service tax.
The association said the average Australian has to work 175 days a year to pay the taxman -- more than double the figure of 30 years ago.

DOC.HEADLINE: ROC'S 1ST MIRAGE SQUADRON COMMISSIONED

TEXT.P: The Republic of China on Monday commissioned its first squadron of French-built Mirage 2000-5 jet fighters at northern Taiwan's Hsinchu air base.

Air Force Commander-in-Chief Gen. Huang Hsien-yung personally presided over the commissioning ceremony. He reviewed the new warplanes and presented awards to all those who had a hand in taking delivery of the planes and outfitting them with the latest in high-tech weaponry, trained pilots and ground crew.

Speaking at the ceremony, Huang described the procedure which resulted in the deployment of the Mirage squadron within the short period of seven months as "an outstanding achievement, indicating that we have conducted prudent and comprehensive planning and groundwork."

"The commissioning of the Mirage squadron will beef up our air defense capability significantly," Huang said, but he added that the pilots and ground crew still require further intense training to enhance their combat preparedness.

The ROC has ordered 60 Mirage 2000-5s from France under its second-generation military build-up plan aimed at establishing an elite deterrent force in the face of the mounting military threat from mainland China.

To date, more than 30 Mirages have been delivered to Taiwan. The squadron commissioned on Monday comprises 20 aircraft, including eight twin and 12 single-seaters, but only 18 of them were on display at the ceremony. Each plane is armed with four MICA missiles and two Magic II missiles.

DOC.HEADLINE: DPP-RULED CONSTITUENCIES WILL NOT CONFRONT CENTRAL GOVERNMENT: HSU

TEXT.P: The opposition Democratic Progressive Party (DPP) will not use its clout at the local administration level to confront the Kuomintang (KMT)-controlled central government, DPP Chairman Hsu Hsin-liang said on Monday.
"The DPP is unlikely to organize its mayors and magistrates to confront the KMT-dominated central government because such action would cause social anxiety or instability," Hsu stressed.

The pro-(Taiwan) independence DPP won the top executive post in 12 of the 23 cities and counties up for grabs around the island in Saturday's local mayoral and county chief elections, while the KMT won only eight. The remaining three went to independent candidates.

When the newly elected mayors and magistrates assume office on Dec. 20, more than 70 percent of the Republic of China's 21.3 million population will find themselves under the DPP's jurisdiction at the local level. Against this new political backdrop, the future of central-local government relations has come under intense scrutiny.

In an apparent attempt to allay public misgiving, Hsu said the DPP's efforts to win the control of local governments is absolutely not to topple the KMT-controlled central government. "The voters cast their ballots for our candidates, not in order to create social instability but to create an efficient, caring new system of local government," he pointed out.

Hsu further said major political parties should strengthen consultations and cooperation to accelerate Taiwan's development in various fields. "We'll compete with the KMT with better public policy and welfare services. We don't want political confrontation."
Hsu said the DPP hopes to negotiate with the KMT for delegating more powers to local governments, particularly a greater say in financial, personnel and police administration.
Hsu said all DPP-ruled constituencies will give top priority to educational reforms, improving social order and upgrading welfare services.
The DPP headquarters will also set up an anti-corruption commission to investigate charges of corruption and any other irregularity involving DPP local government chiefs, Hsu said.

He further pointed out that the DPP didn't have an anti-commerce complex. "We'll come up with a white paper on our industrial development policy in the near future to explain our plans for promoting development of various industries in DPP-ruled constituencies."

Hsu went on to say that the DPP has consistently called for development of peaceful, reciprocal and mutually beneficial relations across the Taiwan Strait. "It's an erraneous perception that the DPP's rise to power would strain cross-strait relations," Hsu said, adding that if necessary, he is willing to visit mainland China.

DOC.HEADLINE: RESHUFFLE OF PLA COMMANDERS BEGINS: REPORT

TEXT.P: Lt. Gen. Guo Boxiong of mainland China's People's Liberation Army has replaced Gen. Liu Jingsong as commander of the Lanzou Military Region, according to a news report from Lanzhou, Gansu Province.

Guo's assumption of the new post on Nov. 26 indicates that a new reshuffle of high-ranking commanders has begun, the report said. His new assignment came after the Communist Party of China (CPC) held its 15th National Congress in September.
Guo, former deputy commander of the Beijing Military Region, left for Xinjiang on Nov. 27 to inspect troops there, the report said.
There are seven military regions in mainland China. The Lanzou Military Region commands troops in Xinjiang, Qinghai, Gansu, Ningxia, and Shaanxi provinces.
Guo was elected member of the CPC Central Committee at the 15th National Congress. (by Ed Hsieh)

DOC.HEADLINE: BEIJING URGED TO PROTECT FREEDOM OF DEMONSTRATION

TEXT.P: A mainland Chinese dissident Monday urged Beijing leaders to enact laws to protect citizens' freedom of demonstration.

In an open letter to Hong Kong's Information Center of Human Rights and Democratic Movement in China, Qin Yongmin said mainland Chinese President Jiang Zemin should ask the legislature to enact laws to ensure the citizens' rights to stage demonstrations and allow laid-off workers to protest in public.
The dissident made the call after Jiang said Friday in Canada that mainland China's constitution provides for freedom of assembly, speech, and demonstration.

Qin was sentenced to eight years in prison for participating in the 1979 Xidan Pro-democracy activities in Beijing and publishing pro-democracy materials in 1981. He was arrested again and sentenced to two years in labor camp in 1993 for drafting a document entitled "Peace Charter." (by Ed Hsieh)

DOC.HEADLINE: MAC: DPP VICTORY NOT TO AFFECT POLICY TOWARDS MAINLAND CHINA

TEXT.P: A spokesman for the Mainland Affairs Council (MAC) of the Executive Yuan, said Monday that the major opposition Democratic Progressive Party's landslide victory in the local elections on Saturday will not affect the government's policy towards mainland China.
Hseu Ke-sheng, MAC vice chairman and spokesman, also said that the victory will not affect cross-strait relations.
The DPP won 12 seats out of 23 seats in Saturday's elections of city mayors and county magistrates.
Hseu said that the policy was made by the government, and therefore should not be affected by any political party. (by Ed Hsieh)

DOC.HEADLINE: DPP OFFERS EXPLANATION FOR PLUNGE OF LOCAL BOURSE

TEXT.P: The opposition Democratic Progressive Party (DPP) held a press conference Monday afternoon to stress that the plunge of the local bourse that day was not the result of the big victory the DPP scored in the just-concluded local elections.

Sisy Chen, director of the DPP's publicity department, said that the dismal showing of the ruling Kuomintang (KMT) in the mayoral and magistrate elections prompted KMT-invested enterprises to withdraw their investments from the stock market, leading to a near 400-point fall in the local bourse.

DPP Chairman Hsu Hsin-liang stressed that his party has no intention to organize an alliance of DPP mayors and magistrates that would confront the KMT-controlled central government, causing political and social instability.

In Saturday's voting, the DPP took 12 of the 23 mayoral and county seats up for grabs, putting 72 percent of Taiwan's population under its jurisdiction. The KMT suffered a setback by obtaining only eight seats. The remaining three seats went to independents.

Hsu said that the DPP understands stable political development is crucial to the island's economy. He attributed the dramatic fall of the local bourse Monday to short-term psychological factors caused by his party's surprise victory as well as downward trends in international stock markets.

Hsu also denied that the DPP has an "anti-business" complex. The DPP will soon host an economic meeting to which business leaders will be invited to discuss the further development of Taiwan's economy in various fields, he added.

Relations between the central and local governments need to be adjusted, especially with the marginalization of the Taiwan Provincial Government, Hsu said, noting that how to allocate revenue between the central and local governments is a question urgently requiring a solution.

Asked if the victory by the pro-independence DPP might heighten tensions between the two sides of the Taiwan Strait, Hsu responded by saying that the DPP has always asserted that Taiwan should deal with mainland China "reasonably and peacefully."

DOC.HEADLINE: CHINESE BUSINESSES, SCHOOLS IN MANILA TO CLOSE TUESDAY IN PROTEST

TEXT.P: Chinese businessmen in Manila and its suburbs will close their businesses and schools all of Tuesday to protest the recent killing of a Chinese-Filipino trader by suspected kidnappers, police said Monday.

Col. Avelino Razon, Manila's police chief, said the Chinese community in Manila and nearby suburbs will hold a "day of mourning" Tuesday to mark the funeral of Gordon Tan, a trader who was shot dead Nov. 25 when he fought back against suspected kidnappers in the northern province of Bulacan.
The shop and school closures will be in protest against a spate of kidnappings.
"But Tan was not kidnapped in Manila," Razon complained, stressing that kidnappings occur "not only in Manila."
Razon, however, said he will deploy more policemen in the Chinatowns in Binondo and Quiapo to deter kidnappers from abducting rich Chinese businessmen and their scions.
Police records show that between January and October 1997 there were 124 cases of kidnapping for ransom involving 193 victims nationwide. Most of the cases took place in Manila.

DOC.HEADLINE: OIL DIALOGUE URGED BETWEEN CONSUMERS-PRODUCERS

TEXT.P: To maintain oil price stability, it is necessary to intensify the prevailing dialogue between producers and consumers, Indonesian President Suharto said on Monday.

In a speech to participants at the 103rd Meeting of the Conference of the Organization of the Petroleum Exporting Countries (OPEC) which took place on Nov. 26-Dec.1, Suharto suggested that OPEC members stop fighting each other to capture the market.

Suharto pointed out that even though OPEC is an organization of oil-producing countries, it is unavoidable that due attention should be paid to issues related to the environment. The oil technology being used must be completely environment-oriented, he said.
"I fully support the idea of developing an OPEC cooperation in oil technology through the Petroleum Technological Cooperation Agency," he said.

In a report to Suharto earlier in the day, Minister of Mines and Energy J.B. Sudjana, who is also the conference president, said that the conference has agreed to increase the ceiling on OPEC member-countries to 27.5 million barrels per day.
The Next Ordinary Meeting of the Conference will be convened in Vienna, Austria, on June 24, 1998.

DOC.HEADLINE: WORLD OIL PRICES SEEN NOT TO DROP

TEXT.P: World oil prices will not plunge even though the Organization of Petroleum Exporting Countries (OPEC) raised export quotas to 27.5 million barrels a day from 25.03 million barrels, an expert said.

"I do not think the price of oil will drop," Soebroto, a former secretary general of OPEC, was quoted by the Antara news agency as saying here Monday after a meeting between Indonesian President Suharto and OPEC participants.
The new quota, which will be effective from Jan. 1, 1998, is still below the 28 million barrels a day of production during October 1997.
In October, the price of oil ranged around US$20 a barrel.
"If oil prices drop, OPEC will hold a special meeting and discuss its oil production," he said.
Large oil producers, he said, such as Saudi Arabia, Kuwait and the United Arab Emirates, will adhere to the new quota.
The increase of OPEC's quota is an improvement for the organization, Soebroto said, explaining, "OPEC will not cede the increase in oil demand to non-OPEC producers."
One consideration for setting up the new oil quota is to meet the 1.86 million barrels a day of increased demand in the world market.
OPEC wants to be the leader in the oil market, he said.
On the topic of Indonesia's quota of 1.46 million barrels a day, Soebroto said that the country has the ability to fulfill it.
"We can meet the quota and it is expected to help Indonesia in overcoming the monetary crisis because it can (now) increase its oil export," he said.
Soebroto said that oil producing countries are still trying to develop the technology for new oil products that would be friendlier to the environment.

DOC.HEADLINE: FAILURE OF FINANCIAL TALKS COULD HURT MARKETS: WTO HEAD

TEXT.P: Renato Ruggiero, director-general of the Geneva-based World Trade Organization (WTO), said a failure of talks to liberalize the global financial services industry by this month's deadline could hurt international markets.

"It will be something very damaging," Ruggiero said. "If we miss this opportunity the markets will not appreciate it, and the reaction of the market could be negative. And that is something we really don't need."

The WTO has set a Dec. 12 deadline for completion of the new agreement. Yet, reeling from Asia's unfolding financial crisis, several Asian countries are dragging their feet on new offers for removing obstacles to trade in financial services.

"I'm worried, really, because time is going on," Ruggiero said. "We know that governments are working on offers, but the offers have not yet arrived in Geneva. We are moving on, but we are not yet there."

The United States refused to join a stopgap accord reached two years ago at the WTO, saying others were giving too little in return for access to its financial services market, the largest in the world. So far, only 33 of 46 signatories have made new offers.

DOC.HEADLINE: US DOLLAR UP

TEXT.P: The US dollar rose NT$0.058 against the New Taiwan dollar on the Taipei foreign exchange market Monday, closing at NT$32.110.
The greenback opened at 32.050 and was traded between 32.010 and 32.428.
Interbank US dollar trading reached US$353.50 million.

DOC.HEADLINE: ALTHOUGH DOWN AGAINST GREENBACK, NT DOLLAR SURGES IN REAL VALUE

TEXT.P: Although down against the US dollar, the New Taiwan dollar is surging in real terms even with the Asian financial crisis continuing in the region, said renowned Japanese economist Richard Koo.

Koo, chief economist at the Japan-based Nomura Securities Co., said in an exclusive interview with CNA on Nov. 26 that the NT dollar's devaluation against the greenback has to do with the US dollar increasing in strength rather than the Taiwan currency weakening.
Given that the NT dollar fell relatively little against the greenback compared to the declines of other major currencies around the world, its value is actually growing, he said.
Koo made the comments to CNA during a visit to Kaohsiung, where he had been invited to deliver a speech on the economy to the local Japanese community.

He said he believes the depreciation will help Taiwan keep its competitive edge against its Southeast Asian rivals, although he noted the island exports a different level of products than countries in that region.

When the Thai baht crashed in July, this triggered financial problems throughout Southeast Asia, largely because of the linkage between the region's currencies and the yen, which has been in a downward trend since 1985 because of the slack Japanese economy, he said.
Koo, however, said he sees no need for Hong Kong to cut the value of its currency, which was rumored would give up its peg to the US dollar amid the backdrop of a strengthening greenback.

Although several Asian countries -- such as the Philippines, Thailand and South Korea -- have called on the International Monetary Fund (IMF) to bail them out of their financial troubles, Koo predicted the crisis will not go away anytime soon.

He didn't back the initiatives by Taiwan and Japan to establish an Asian fund to help states in the region ward off future economic crises, saying Tokyo should use what, if any, extra funds it has to address its own financial issues first, and that Taiwan, which is not a member of the IMF and therefore would not be able to turn to it for help, should set aside money for its own possible crisis.

DOC.HEADLINE: COMPULSORY DNA SAMPLING FOR SUSPECTS IN SEX CRIMES PASSES COMMITTEE

TEXT.P: Those suspected in sex-related crimes could be required to provide blood samples in order to record their DNA profiles, if a bill that cleared a Legislative Yuan committee on Monday becomes law.

Recognizing that DNA profiles are of great help in identifying culprits in sex-related crimes, the Interior and Justice Committee passed the Compulsory DNA Sampling for Sex Offenders bill following several hours of discussion.

The bill, proposed by legislator Chu Hui-liang of the New Party, would allow courts or prosecutors to summon suspects in sex-related crimes for DNA sampling and to arrest and force those who resist to comply with the rule.

The Interior Ministry would take the responsibility for establishing the databank of DNA files. Such files could be provided to police departments, prosecutors, courts or military courts upon request.
Each DNA file would be kept for at least 10 years after the death of the person to whom it applies.

DOC.HEADLINE: KMT OFFICIALS HUDDLE TO SEARCH CAUSES OF ELECTORAL DEFEAT

TEXT.P: Officials of the ruling Kuomintang met Monday to discuss the causes of the party's surprising defeat in Saturday's elections, in which it lost 7 of the 15 seats it had held at the head of city and county governments.

KMT Secretary-General Wu Poh-hsiung, who tendered his resignation Saturday to assume responsibility for the party's poorest performance ever in local elections, declared at the meeting that he will let his successor decide on the avalanche of letters of resignation by ranking party officials that hit his desk after Saturday's vote-counts came in.
Wu's resignation is expected to be approved Wednesday in a regular meeting of the KMT Central Standing Committee, the party's policy making body.
Wu encouraged his fellow party workers not to lose confidence in the KMT but rather to stand up and meet whatever challenges the future might have in store for the 100-year-old party.

Admitting that he himself was stunned by the disastrous defeat, Wu urged those at the meeting -- mainly the KMT party chiefs of cities and counties around the island -- to point out shortcomings of the party's campaign strategy, including its method of naming candidates and how the party's messages were conveyed to voters.
He also asked them to pay attention to the criticism of the KMT from the mass media and academies.
A thorough review of the party's pre-election opinion polls, some of which were blamed as misleading, will be carried out to assess their effectiveness, said Wu.

However, unpopular policies of the central government, which is still controlled by the KMT and often a target of opposition politicians, are off-limits in the party's review, said Wu, not attempting to shift the blame and steering clear of offending those who run the government.

Even though the KMT lost almost half of the local administration seats it had held, Wu reminded his coworkers not to forget to thank the 3.2 million voters who did support the party. He also lauded the party officials who vigorously campaigned in Taoyuan and Kaohsiung counties, where KMT candidates posed serious threats to the incumbents of the Democratic Progressive Party and only lost by small margins.
The outgoing secretary-general encouraged his coworkers to learn from the defeat and prepare for next year's national and local legislative elections.

Meanwhile, President Lee Teng-hui, who also serves as KMT chairman, met with Premier Vincent Siew and KMT Vice Chairman and ROC Vice President Lien Chan on Monday afternoon at the Presidential Office for two hours, presumably on the new political situation that the KMT defeat established.

After the meeting, Lien met in his office with another KMT elder, Hsu Shui-teh, the president of Examination Yuan and a former KMT secretary-general, probably to consult on the reshuffle of the party hierarchy.

DOC.HEADLINE: TWO RESCUED MAINLAND FISHERMEN RETURN HOME

TEXT.P: Two mainland Chinese fishermen who were rescued off the Republic of China's frontline island of Kinmen late last month were sent back to their hometown on Tuesday.
Kang Youbo and Li Jiabo were rescued by ROC troops stationed on Kinmen on Nov. 27 after their fishing boat, Minlungyu No. 2708, struck a rock formation near the island and capsized.
Kang, 40, sustained several injuries as a result of the accident. He has fully recovered after receiving medical treatment under the arrangement of the Kinmen garrison command.
Kang said prior to his departure for home that he was grateful for the care and hospitality extended to him and his colleague during their stay in Kinmen.

The duo went home via a ferry boat leased by the Kinmen liaison office of the ROC Red Cross Society. The boat left a Kinmen wharf at around 8:30 a.m. and arrived in Xiamen, Fujian Province, at 9:00 a.m.

Hsu Nai-jung, director of the preparatory office for the Kinmen Red Cross Society, accompanied the two mainland fishermen on their homecoming voyage. Hsu made a brief stopover at the Xiamen port to complete some handover formalities with Li Minzhu, deputy secretary-general of the Xiamen Red Cross Society.

As the ROC still bans direct transport links with mainland China, the Red Cross Society originally planned to send the duo to the center line of the Taiwan Strait, where a mainland boat was to take them home. Due to rough seas and bad weather, the Red Cross Society decided to send them directly to Xiamen for safety considerations.

An earlier case of what has been termed "humanitarian direct sailing" between the two sides of the strait was witnessed on Nov. 26, when seven mainland fishermen who had completed jail terms following convictions for smuggling were repatriated in a similar manner.
