DOC.HEADLINE: MIDDLE-AGED UNSKILLED WORKERS HAVE HIGHEST UNEMPLOYMENT RATE

TEXT.P: Middle-aged unskilled workers have become the top concern in solving the nation's unemployment problem, the Council for Economic Planning and Development (CEPD) said Tuesday.
CEPD officials made the remarks after they reviewed a plan put into practice a year ago to address the supply and demand imbalance in the local job market.

The officials said the high rate of unemployment among persons with advanced academic backgrounds has improved. But at the same time, the unemployment woes of middle-aged unskilled workers have become noticeably more acute.
The CEPD devised a strategy to tackle rising joblessness after seeing a steady rise of unemployment in the latter half of 1995.

In reviewing the results and future prospects of the plan, CEPD officials found that the original problems have largely been alleviated. However a new set of difficulties has appeared over the past several months.

They found that persons aged 50-54 registered an unemployment rate of 1.74 percent in the first nine months of this year, or up 0.67 percentage points from 1.07 percent in the same period last year. The increase rate was the highest among all age groups.

The statistics released by the CEPD showed that the closure or overseas relocation of businesses in labor-intensive industries as well as the importation of foreign laborers has posed increased threats to the job security of middle-aged unskilled workers.

They said middle-aged laborers tend to enjoy stable employment, but if they happen to lose their jobs, they are likely than workers in other age groups to experience difficulties in securing new employment.

The Labor Standards Law stipulates that persons who reach the age of 55 and have stayed in the same working place for over 15 years, or persons who have stayed in the same working place for over 25 years regardless of age, are entitled to retire and to receive a pension. The CEPD officials said many employers are reluctant to hire middle-aged workers because they want to avoid paying the pensions.

The CEPD has proposed that the Council of Labor Affairs revise the law so that laborers will receive pension payments in proportion to the number of years they have served at the time they resign or retire. In this way, officials said, middle-aged laborers will have the same employment opportunities as their younger counterparts.

DOC.HEADLINE: DPP TO UNVEIL POLICIES ON INDUSTRY, CROSS-STRAIT TIES

TEXT.P: In an apparent attempt to allay public misgiving over its attitudes toward industrial development and relations across the Taiwan Strait following its resounding win in local elections, the opposition Democratic Progressive Party (DPP) said on Tuesday it will unveil its polices on those issues early next year.

DPP Secretary-General Chiu Yi-jen said the party will sponsor a "business magnates meeting" in February, which will bring together DPP local government chiefs and senior business executives to exchange views on the development of various manufacturing and service industries in DPP-ruled cities and counties.
Following the meeting, Chiu said, the DPP will issue a white paper detailing its policy on industrial development.
In the past, the DPP was widely seen to harbor an anti-commerce sentiment as several DPP-ruled constituencies often shut doors on some energy-consuming or highly polluting industries.

"It is an erroneous perception," Chiu said, adding that the DPP does not oppose industrial development or normal business activities. "We don't welcome polluting industries mainly out of considerations of environmental protection. We absolutely do not have an anti-commerce complex," he added.
Meanwhile, Chiu said, the DPP will call a meeting after the Chinese New Year holiday to forge an intraparty consensus on cross-strait relations.
Chiu said the DPP, which has advocated Taiwan independence, will deal with cross-strait issues in a peaceful, rational manner.
Chiu admitted that DPP members remain divided over many major cross-strait issues, including whether Taiwan should start to negotiate with mainland China for direct trade, transport and mail links.
While DPP Chairman Hsu Hsin-liang supports an early start on cross-strait discussions for the "three links," Chiu said he personally sees no hurry to start negotiations with Beijing.

Recalling the history of negotiations between the ruling Kuomintang and the Chinese Communist Party before the fall of the Chinese mainland to communist hands in 1949, Chiu said negotiations with Beijing are highly risky and tricky. "The three direct links are Taiwan's last bargaining chips. We should handle the issue very prudently."

With the DPP gaining the mandate to rule more than half of the cities and counties around Taiwan, Chiu said the party's social and political responsibility has increased significantly. "Even though our members remain divided over the issue, our party still has to make efforts to forge an internal consensus and formulate a comprehensive and coherent policy on cross-strait relations," he added.

DOC.HEADLINE: PETROLEUM PRICE HIKE IN THE OFFING

TEXT.P: The state-owned Chinese Petroleum Corp. (CPC) will raise petroleum prices to reflect increased costs of purchasing imported crude in the wake of the sharp devaluation of the New Taiwan dollar, CPC President Pang Wen-yen announced Tuesday.
But Pang said the size of the petroleum price hike and whether the increase will be made in stages or in a single move, will be decided after careful evaluation.

CPC officials said the cost for crude purchases was US$19.48 per barrel in November, up from US$18.16 per barrel in October, causing the CPC to fall short of its targeted profits by NT$2.4 billion (US$73.84 million) last month.

They said the CPC incurs additional costs in purchasing crude of about NT$1.5 billion (US$461.53 million) per month for every one New Taiwan dollar decrease in value vis-a-vis the US dollar. The CPC also fell short of its estimated surplus by nearly NT$600 million in October because of the devalued local currency, which began its slide after mid-October.

They said that if the CPC seeks to raise petroleum prices by more than 3 percent, it must first consult an advisory committee on energy and electricity rates under the Ministry of Economic Affairs. However, if the price hike is set at below 3 percent, the CPC can take the action on its own accord.

DOC.HEADLINE: EIGHT-POINT PROPOSAL STILL HOLDS GOOD: JIANG ZEMIN
DOC.DATELINE: Ottawa, Dec. 2 (CNA) (By Chang Sheng-chao & Eva Chen)

TEXT.P: Mainland Chinese President Jiang Zemin said that the eight-point proposal he introduced in 1995 to set forth the basic principles of the Chinese Communist Party for resolving the Taiwan issue still holds good.
Jiang made the remark on Nov. 29 in an interview with Canada's Globe and Mail. An excerpt of the 50-minite interview appeared in the daily on Monday.

The Globe and Mail asked Jiang whether too much time has been wasted in realizing the reunification of the two sides of the Taiwan Strait at a time when more and more people in Taiwan think of themselves as Taiwanese rather than as Chinese.

In response, Jiang noted that the Taiwan issue has always been a very sensitive problem. However, he said, it is something over which there is a firm and positive resolve to bring to conclusion, adding that it is also a Chinese internal matter.

"Our policy toward Taiwan is peaceful reunification -- one country, two systems. I believe that without military interference of foreign countries, Taiwan will be reunified with the motherland eventually. The eight-point proposal I introduced in January 1995 to promote the reunification of both sides is still effective today," Jiang stressed.

The statement is a reassertion of points made in his address delivered at the opening ceremony of the Asia-Pacific Economic Cooperation (APEC) forum held in late November in Vancouver, Canada. Jiang was quoted as saying at the APEC gathering that he believes the Taiwan issue will be eventually resolved.

DOC.HEADLINE: SHARE PRICES SURGE ON TAIEX

TEXT.P: Share prices rebounded on the Taiwan Stock Exchange Tuesday, with the weighted index, the market's key barometer, increasing 278.89 points to finish at 7679.53.
The bourse opened at the day's low of 7455.51 and experienced a high of 7679.53.
Gainers outnumbered losers 437 to 14, with 19 remaining unchanged. In all, 2.17 billion shares changed hands on a market turnover of NT$119.06 billion (US$3.69 billion).

Plastic and chemical stocks rose the most at 5.8 percent, followed by textile issues at 5.0 percent; construction stocks at 4.6 percent; electrical engineering issues at 4.4 percent; cement shares at 4.3 percent; paper and pulp stocks at 4.0 percent; foodstuff issues at 3.5 percent; and financial stocks at 2.1 percent.

DOC.HEADLINE: SOME 5,890 LPG-FUELED TAXIES IN TAIPEI

TEXT.P: The number of taxies in Taipei fueled by liquefied petroleum gas (LPG) has reached some 5,890, accounting for 14.72 percent of the city's 40,000 registered cabs.

The municipal Transportation Bureau and Cabinet-level Environmental Protection Administration (EPA) in March 1995 jointly pushed for a program that promotes the conversion of gasoline-powered taxies into LPG-propelled vehicles as part of efforts to check deteriorating air quality in the city.

Cheng Chai-liang, a departmental director in the Transportation Bureau, on Tuesday cited the advantages of using LPG, saying that in addition to its relative low-polluting qualities, LPG is priced at NT$11 (US$0.34) per liter, much cheaper than non-leaded gasoline which currently sells at about NT$17 (US$0.53) per liter. The taxi drivers using LPG-fueled motor vehicles can save between NT$4,000 and NT$6,000 in fuel costs per month.

To encourage the conversion of taxies, each cab driver can apply for a subsidy of between NT$40,000 and NT$45,000 provided by the bureau and the EPA, Cheng said, adding that the subsidy can cover the entire conversion cost.

Cheng, however, admitted that in addition to promoting the conversion of motor vehicles, the bureau should also make more effort to build LPG service stations. As there is only one LPG station in Taipei, which can serve only some 1,000 vehicles a day, drivers invariably have to wait in long lines for refueling, he noted.

The LPG station, operated by the Chinese Petroleum Corp. (CPC), has recently completed expansion of the facility, Cheng said, adding that the city government has approved a private-invested LPG filling station, which is scheduled to be completed in four to six months.

Cheng said that the bureau plans to build another three LPG stations, in the northern, central and southern parts of Taipei. But a number of problems have to be solved before construction can begin, he added.

DOC.HEADLINE: MULTIMEDIA INDUSTRY TAIWAN'S RISING STAR OF 21ST CENTURY

TEXT.P: The National Information Infrastructure (NII) task force under the Executive Yuan has decided to promote the multimedia sector as Taiwan's rising star for next century, estimating that the industry's output will reach about US$10 billion in 1999 and rise to account for 5 percent of the world's total by 2002.
The decision was made on Monday at an NII meeting in which the ad hoc group approved the launch of a three-year promotional program to develop Taiwan's information highway.

The program, expected to be approved by the Executive Yuan soon, calls for a total investment of NT$42.7 billion, with the government channeling in NT$18.6 billion, while Chunghwa Telecom Co., Ltd. will contribute the remaining NT$24.1 billion.

The Ministry of Economic Affairs, which will be in charge of the trans-century project, will invest NT$8.2 billion under the plan in an effort to build Taiwan into a research, development and distribution center for the multimedia industry in the Asia-Pacific region.
As the multimedia industry covers a wide range of fields, NII officials said, the Economics Ministry will join forces with the private sector to develop the project.

Meanwhile, the Council for Economic Planning and Development, as well as the Ministry of Transportation and Communications and the Ministry of Finance, will work out incentives in June and December 1988, respectively, to help boost development of the multimedia sector.

NII convener Yang Shih-chien, currently a minister without portfolio, said Taiwan, with its already solid base in the information industry, should grab the opportunity to develop itself into a multimedia power, as the sector has been seen as the locomotive behind the world's economic development in the future.

Major world bodies, such as the Asia-Pacific Economic Cooperation forum, World Trade Organization and Organization for Economic Cooperation and Development, have all targeted the multimedia industry as the focus of future development, according to Yang.

In addition to managing to transforming Taiwan into a regional multimedia network hub and a world Chinese-language data bank, Yang said the NII task force hopes to boost the number of Internet users in Taiwan to 3 million over the next three years and have all elementary and high schools on line in five years to reach the goal of providing one out of every 20 students with access to a multimedia computer.
Statistics compiled by the Institute of the Information Industry show that the number of Taiwan's Internet users stood at around 1.5 million as of the end of October.

DOC.HEADLINE: CANADA TO CUT GAS EMISSIONS BY 3 PERCENT FROM 1990 LEVEL

TEXT.P: The Canadian government announced Monday that it will reduce the country's greenhouse gas emissions by three percent from 1990 levels by the year 2010.
Ottawa also said it will set a domestic target for the stabilization of the release of greenhouse gases by 2007. It will announce the target at the Kyoto conference on climate change.
"Now is the time for the government to show leadership," stated Christine Stewart, Canada's minister of the environment.

But what she called "leadership" was termed "incompetence" by the opposition. And the province of Alberta, which produces and sells energy, called it "betrayal" -- all because the federal target went beyond the agreement between the federal and provincial governments, and because Ottawa did not spell out how that target could be achieved or how much it would cost Canadians.
Federal officials said the measures will be worked out after an international treaty is signed in Kyoto, Japan.
Opposition leader Preston Manning called this "completely irresponsible."

"It failed to identify the impacts side of the economics, sectoral or regional, and it's got no implementation plan and no idea how it's going to pay for what it's committed itself to," the Reform Party leader pointed out.
Manning accused the Liberal government of pulling its position out of a hat and urged it not to sign a deal binding Canada to reduce emissions.
Alberta's Energy Minister Steve West said, "They've betrayed the process (of federal and provincial discussion on reducing gas emission)." He promised to fight the "unilateral decision" by Ottawa.

Stewart said climate change is one of the most significant environmental challenges facing Canadians, as it could lead to higher temperatures, more frequent and longer lasting droughts in some areas, floods in others, melting permafrost and more frequent severe weather events.
Representatives from more than 150 countries opened a conference Monday in Kyoto with the goal of negotiating a worldwide treaty to limit emissions of greenhouse gases.
Such gases are transparent to incoming radiation from the sun, but they prevent that radiation from being reflected back into space, the way a greenhouse traps the sun's heat for plants.
An estimated six billion tonnes of greenhouse gases are being pumped into the atmosphere annually, mainly through the burning of fossil fuels such as coal, oil and gasoline.

Most scientists predict that the result will be a gradual rise in the average temperature of the Earth's atmosphere, but there's a lot of uncertainty about how specific regions of the world will be affected.

DOC.HEADLINE: OVER 30,000 TAIWAN STUDENTS IN US UNIVERSITIES
DOC.DATELINE: Washington, Dec. 2 (CNA) (By N.K. Han and Lilian Wu)

TEXT.P: There are 30,487 Taiwan students studying in US universities this year, down 6.8 percent from 1996, making them the fifth largest group of foreign students in the United States, US statistics show.
Students from Japan pursuing post-secondary educations in the United States outnumber, at 46,292, the students from any other foreign country, a position they have held for three consecutive years.

Some 42,503 students from mainland China are studying in the United States this year, trailing only those from Japan. South Korean students rank third at 37,130 and Indian students are fourth at 30,641.
Following students from Taiwan are those who come from Canada (22,984), Malaysia (14,527), Thailand (13,481), Indonesia (12,461) and Hong Kong (10,942).
In terms of region, there are 260,743 students this year from Asia, far surpassing the 68,315 from Europe and 49,592 from Latin America.
California attracted 57,011 foreign students last year, more than any other US state. New York and Texas ranked second and third, respectively.

The number of foreign students in the United States grew by only 0.9 percent in 1996, the seventh consecutive year of slow growth, attributed to Britain, Australia and Canada having taken up aggressive approaches to woo students to their own universities.

DOC.HEADLINE: US CABINET MEMBER TO ADDRESS JOINT US-ROC BUSINESS CONFERENCE

TEXT.P: The Clinton administration has decided to send Cabinet member Janet Yellen to address the 21st annual joint business conference of the US-ROC (Taiwan) and ROC-USA Business Councils, opening Tuesday in San Diego, California.

The US-ROC (Taiwan) Business Council announced Monday that Yellen, chair of the US Council of Economic Advisers, will deliver a keynote speech at the conference. This will be the fourth consecutive year since 1994 that the Clinton administration has sent a Cabinet member or a Cabinet-level official to the annual conference.
"Dr. Yellen's presence adds significantly to the economic and financial emphasis of the conference this year," the US-ROC (Taiwan) Business Council said in a news release.

Stephen Chen, representative of the Taipei Economic and Cultural Representative Office in the United States, also welcomed the announcement. He said the decision shows that the Clinton administration attaches great importance to the annual business meeting between the United States and the ROC.

Yellen, who earned her Ph.D. in economics from Yale University in 1971, was appointed by President Bill Clinton to her current position in February this year. Before that she served on the Board of Governors of the US Federal Reserve System.
During 1977-78 she worked with the board as an economist specializing on issues of international trade and finance, including stabilization of international currency exchange rates.
Other prominent speakers at the conference will include California Gov. Pete Wilson, US Senators Frank Murkowski and John D. Rockefeller, and Michael Bloomberg of Bloomberg Financial Markets.

The ROC delegation headed by Jeffrey Koo, chairman of the ROC-USA Business Council, includes Council for Economic Planning and Development Chairman P.K. Chiang, Minister of Economic Affairs C.K. Wang, Central Bank of China Governor Y.D. Sheu, and more than 200 business leaders from Taiwan.

DOC.HEADLINE: AUSTRALIA'S RECORD FOREIGN DEBT SENDS CURRENCY DOWNWARD

TEXT.P: Driven up by a rising current account deficit and the recent depreciation of its currency, Australia's net foreign debt hit a record high of A$217 billion (US$147 billion) in the third quarter of this year.
The Australian Bureau of Statistics reported that the current account deficit between July and September this year expanded over second quarter levels by 55 percent to hit A$4.6 billion.

The country's net foreign debt jumped about 4 percent to a record A$217 billion during the third quarter, caused largely by the recent 9 percent depreciation of the Australian dollar against the US currency.
The Australian dollar on Monday dropped to as low as 67.67 US cents before closing at 67.88 US cents.
Economists believed the currency would breach a barrier of 65 US cents soon and possibly head towards 60 US cents in the next few months.

The signs of deterioration in Australia's trade and debt positions crystallized growing financial market concerns about the combined impact of a slump in Australian exports due to the Asian economic crisis and a surge in imports as the country's economy gathers pace, they said.

Australia's economic indicators show that its economy is picking up because the impact of the Asian crisis needs some time to be felt in this country. Economists said the crisis could affect Australia next year.
This year, Australia's gross domestic product is expected to grow 3.75 percent.

DOC.HEADLINE: AUSSIE FM SEES RISING DEFENSE SPENDING IN ASIA DESPITE ECONOMIC CRISIS

TEXT.P: Defense expenditures in Asia are expected to rise despite the recent economic crisis because of potential flashpoints in the Korean Peninsula, Taiwan Strait and South China Sea, Australia's Foreign Minister Alexander Downer said.

In a speech at the National Press Club on Monday, Downer noted an increase in defense spending across the region prompted by economic growth and an array of "pressure points" that could lead to open conflict.

"None is greater in my view than the Korean Peninsula, and I look forward to these four-party talks [among the United States, mainland China, and North and South Korea] on Dec. 9 being a good start to easing the tension on the Korean Peninsula," he said.

"But the fact is the level of tension there is still very great and should not be underestimated. There has, of course, been tension between China and Taiwan. There are still competing claims in the South China Sea. So this is not a part of the world without its tensions," he added.

He said regional defense expenditures would continue to grow for the "foreseeable future" despite the recent economic turmoil in Southeast Asia, which has forced many countries to cut back on large capital projects.
Australian Defense Minister Ian McLachlan has asked the government to raise budgeting in order to upgrade the Australian Defense Force's air and naval strike and self-defense capabilities.

DOC.HEADLINE: CHINA'S LI RUIHUAN TO VISIT AUSTRALIA

TEXT.P: Mainland China's Li Ruihuan, chairman of the National People's Political Consultative Conference and a member of the Politburo Standing Committee, is scheduled to visit Australia from Dec. 14-20.
He will become the most senior mainland Chinese official to visit Australia since bilateral ties between Canberra and Beijing improved earlier this year.

Australia strained its ties with the People's Republic of China in 1996 due to a series of incidents, including its support for the US dispatch of two aircraft carrier groups to the Taiwan Strait following military provocations directed at Taiwan by Beijing, the sending of a senior Australian minister to Taipei, and the visit of the Dalai Lama to Australia.

But Australia improved its ties with mainland China through visits by Prime Minister John Howard, Deputy Prime Minister Tim Fischer and Foreign Minister Alexander Downer to Beijing, as well as through a trip by Chinese mainland Vice Premier Zhu Rongji to Australia, earlier this year.
In announcing Li's visit, Fischer said the trip would cap a year of "significant advances" in a relationship marked by a series of acrimonious differences a year ago.

"Australia's ties with China have continued to grow and diversify into new areas to the great benefit of both countries and Mr. Li's visit will further strengthen our already very good relationship," Fischer said.

Li, who ranks fourth in the Chinese leadership hierarchy, is expected to meet Howard and a number of senior federal and state ministers during his visit, which will take him to Victoria, New South Wales and Queensland.
Australia switched its diplomatic recognition from Taipei to Beijing in late 1972 and this year marks the 25th anniversary of ties between the two governments.
Mainland China's Zhu Rongji, who ranks fifth in the Chinese Communist hierarchy, visited Australia in May this year.
Two-way trade between Australia and the mainland totaled about A$8 billion last year and the figure is expected increase in coming years because of rising investment projects between the two sides.

DOC.HEADLINE: ECONOMICS EXPERT TO SPEAK AT JOINT BUSINESS COUNCIL CONFERENCE

TEXT.P: Janet Yellen, chair of the Council of Economic Advisers, will speak at the 21st Annual Joint Business Conference of the US-ROC and ROC-USA Business Council to be held in San Diego, California, on Dec. 1-4, the US-ROC (Taiwan) Business Council announced Monday.

Yellen was appointed to her position by US President Bill Clinton in February 1997. Before that she served on the Board of Governors of the Federal Reserve. She has written extensively on macroeconomic issues, but has focused on unemployment, international trade balance and East European economic reform in her most recent works.
The US-ROC Business Council said that Yellen's presence adds significantly to the economic and financial emphasis of the conference this year.

Taiwan has sent a delegation to the Conference, including Council for Economic Planning and Development Chairman P.K. Chiang, Minister of Economic Affairs C.K. Wang, Deputy Minister of Finance Yen Ching-chang, and the chairmen or presidents of 20 leading banks in Taiwan, plus a large number of other CEO's and senior government and business leaders.

Other prominent speakers include California Gov. Pete Wilson, US Senators Frank Murkowski and John D. Rockfeller, Michael Bloomberg of Bloomberg Financial Markets, former Bank of America Chairman Richard Rosenberg, US-ROC Business Council Chairman William Clark, and Dr. Jeffrey Koo, chairman of Chinatrust Commercial Bank and also chairman of the ROC-USA Business Council.
Over 500 high-level ROC and US business leaders are expected to convene for this year's conference, which has adopted the theme "US-Taiwan Relations: New Game, New Rules, New Opportunities."

The broad range of seminar topics includes: telecommunications, banking, finance and investment, information technology, biomedical technology, transportation and aviation, power and energy, environmental protection, business relations with Canada and Mexico, engineering and construction, defense, chemicals, and agricultural products and food processing.

DOC.HEADLINE: AUSTRALIA TO OUTLAW BRIBERY OF FOREIGN OFFICIALS

TEXT.P: Australia on Monday announced a ban designed to outlaw Australian multinational companies and their employees from bribing foreign officials in an attempt to win contracts.

In announcing the tough policy, Justice Minister Amanda Vanstone, in a statement faxed to the CNA, said: "The government intends to prohibit bribery of foreign officials by Australian companies or individuals.

"The move to prohibit bribery of foreign officials supplements moves by the government in May to deny tax deductibility for bribes paid to foreign officials. The prohibition forms part of the government's response to the OECD Ministerial Council agreement in May on measures to combat bribery in international business transactions," she said.

"Bribery raises business costs, creates uncertainty and distorts international trade and investment. Legislation to implement the government's intentions to prohibit bribery of foreign officials is now being prepared," she said.

"For an offense to occur, however, part of the conduct must occur in Australia. The OECD has set April 1, 1998, as the target date for the introduction of this legislation," she said. "The Australian government intends to meet this target date. However, passage of the legislation will be dependent on other OECD countries seeking to introduce similar legislation. Business groups and nongovernment organizations will be consulted further on the details of the proposed legislation," she added.

Analysts said Australian companies and employees are forced to follow the practice of bribing foreign officials, including those in developing countries such as mainland China, Vietnam, Indonesia and Thailand, in order to win business contracts. Otherwise, other foreign companies from the United States and Europe would beat Australian firms if they fail to follow suit, they said.

DOC.HEADLINE: OVERSEAS BUSINESS GROUPS EYE DARWIN-ALICE SPRINGS RAIL PROJECT

TEXT.P: Several business and engineering groups from mainland China, Hong Kong, the United States and Australia have expressed their interest to build the A$1.2 billion, 1440-km railway linking Darwin and Alice Springs.
Deadlines for expressions of interest in the rail project closed Monday, according to the Northern Territory government.

Earlier, the business group from Taiwan's ruling political party, the Kuomintang, had indicated a willingness to invest in the project. However, it failed to formally express this intention prior to the deadline.

US engineering and construction group Brown & Root, which took over the large Australian engineering group Kinhill Company in July this year, is one of the leading bidders in the Darwin-Alice Springs railway, a spokesman for the Northern Territory government said.

He said a powerful consortium from Asia with key members from Hong Kong telecommunications and transport giant Hutchison Whampoa Ltd. and a mainland Chinese shipping group, the China Ocean Shipping Co. (COSCO), has also registered for the bidding of the project.
The state-owned COSCO is the world's fourth largest shipping company.

Another group to join the bidding is Northlink Rail Consortium, which include Australian corporate heavyweights Thiess Contractors, the Commonwealth Bank of Australia and BHP Engineering. It also announced it would be lodging an expression of interest.
The Darwin-based Australia Asia Railway Corporation (AARC) said the number of bidders would not be disclosed until certain procedural matters were undertaken.
AARC chief executive Paul Tyrrell said the company will decide a short list of bidders by the end of January and those parties would then have about five months to prepare detailed bids.
The successful bidder is expected to be chosen by August or September 1998, he said.

DOC.HEADLINE: US CONGRATULATES TAIWAN ON SUCCESSFUL ELECTIONS

TEXT.P: The US government Monday extended congratulations to the people of Taiwan for holding successful mayoral and county magistrate elections last weekend.
In a readout to the press, the US Department of State termed the elections "another step in the impressive democratic transformation of Taiwan over the past decade."
"We also congratulate all candidates who won and have earned the trust of the voters to serve in these important local offices," the State Department said.
Asked to comment on possible implications of the election results, the department said, "These were local elections contested on local personalities and issues."

In the Nov. 29 elections, the ruling Kuomintang (KMT) suffered a major setback. Although its candidates received 42.1 percent of the popular vote -- slightly less than the 43.3 percent for the candidates from the opposition Democratic Progressive Party -- the KMT retained only eight of the 23 cities and counties contested, much less than the 12 cities and counties captured by the opposition Democratic Progressive Party (DPP). The remaining three went to independent candidates.

An official at the State Department contacted by CNA declined to speculate on how the election results might affect the triangular relationship among the United States, Taiwan and mainland China. He also would not comment on whether the elections might have a significant influence on Taiwan's internal party politics.

On whether the United States would step up its contacts with the DPP, the official said the United States, through the American Institute in Taiwan, has maintained contacts with a variety of people from all of walks of life in Taiwan and will continue to do so.

DOC.HEADLINE: MOFA CONCERNED ABOUT BURGLARIES AT AIT STAFFERS' HOMES

TEXT.P: The residences of four staff members of the de facto American embassy in Taipei were broken into last weekend, a Ministry of Foreign Affairs (MOFA) official said on Tuesday.

"Mrs. Lauren Moriarty, acting director-general of the Taipei office of the American Institute in Taiwan (AIT), informed the Foreign Ministry of the incidents on Monday," ministry spokesman Roy Wu told a news conference.
Wu said the ministry is concerned about the series of incidents and will convey AIT staff members' requests to local police authorities.

"Minister of Foreign Affairs Jason Hu has expressed grave concern about the incidents and has ordered John Feng, director of the ministry's Protocol Department, to contact police authorities and urge them to actively investigate the case," Wu said.

Shen Lu-hsun, director of the ministry's North American Affairs Department, had met with Moriarty to express his concern about the break-ins and exchange views on how to improve security at residences of foreign officials stationed here, Wu said.

He stated that one of the AIT staff members had incurred property losses at the hands of the intruder or intruders, while the three others reported only that the windows and doors to their residences had been damaged. The houses are all located on the scenic Yangmingshan in suburban Taipei.
Wu declined to disclose details about the losses and damages sustained by the AIT officials, saying, "I must respect their privacy."

Wu said the Foreign Ministry will make further contacts with the AIT to learn more about the incidents and will demand that police authorities intensify protective measures to ensure the safety of its staff members.

According to local media reports, the burglarized house belongs to Daryl Johnson, director-general of the AIT Taipei office. As Johnson is currently not in Taipei, the reports said, the amount of financial losses remains unclear.
AIT was founded by American authorities in 1979 to handle exchanges with the Republic of China in the absence of diplomatic ties.

The Foreign Ministry has shown much concern about the series of burglary cases because the incidents could further hurt the ROC's image. On Nov. 18, a wanted fugitive broke into the home of South African military attache Col. McGill Alexander and took his entire family hostage. Though the incident was peacefully resolved after a 24-hour standoff between police and the fugitive, the safety of expatriates here has since become a major concern. Police authorities have pledged to improve protective measures for diplomats and other expatriates.

DOC.HEADLINE: CHANG REFUSES TO CONFIRM HIS ASSIGNMENT AS KMT SECRETARY GENERAL

TEXT.P: Vice Premier John Chang on Monday refused to confirm that he is to take over as secretary general of the ruling Kuomintang (KMT) following the party's rout in the local elections.

Chang said that he hadn't received any notice about the reported assignment to replace Wu Poh-hsiung, who resigned on Saturday after the KMT for the first time lost its majority in local government seats.

If local press reports turn out to be true, Chang said, he would let the mass media know, adding that it would be an "honor" to him and a "responsibility" if the party wants him to serve as its new secretary general.

The KMT's top decision-making body, the central standing committee, will have a regularly scheduled meeting on Wednesday in which it is expected to approve Wu's resignation as well as the appointment of Wu's successor.

Commenting on local reports about Chang's appointment, Wu said that Chang, who is known as capable and enjoys a good reputation, would be the proper person to fill the vacancy left by his resignation.
Chang, 56, served as KMT overseas affairs director, overseas Chinese affairs commission minister and foreign minister before being appointed vice premier in September.

DOC.HEADLINE: DPP VICTORY SAID TO AFFECT CROSS-STRAIT RELATIONS

TEXT.P: Li Guoqiang, member of the National Committee of the communist Chinese People's Political Consultative Conference, said here Tuesday that the result of Saturday's local elections in Taiwan "will certainly affect cross-strait relations."
In the elections of 23 city mayors and county magistrates, the pro-independence Democratic Progressive Party (DPP) won 12 seats, while the ruling Kuomintang (KMT) obtained only eight.

In an interview with CNA, Li said that the election result indicated the decline of the KMT after 50 years of ruling in Taiwan, and that the situational change has made the relations between Taiwan and mainland China more complicated.
He predicted that facing the new situation, Beijing will become more emphatic about its "one China" principle.

Li said the major opposition party's victory may enhance the advocacy of Taiwan independence on the one hand, but will give Beijing a chance to play the KMT and DPP off against each other on the other hand. (by Chang Chien/Ed Hsieh)

DOC.HEADLINE: BEIJING SAID WILLING TO KEEP IN TOUCH WITH DPP

TEXT.P: Zhang Mingqing, press officer of the Taiwan Affairs Office of the mainland Chinese State Council, said here Tuesday that Beijing always welcomes the opportunities to keep in touch with Taiwan's political parties.

Zhang, who are here attending a seminar on journalism, said in an interview with CNA that Beijing will consider keeping in touch with the Democratic Progressive Party (DPP), if the major opposition party will promote cross-strait relations and work toward national unification.
It would not be possible for Beijing to promote relations with the DPP. if it continues to uphold its "pro-Taiwan independence" stance.
The DPP won a landslide victory Saturday by winning 12 seats out of 23 in Taiwan's local elections of city mayors and county magistrates.

The victory of DPP does not represent Taiwan people's support for independence, Zhang said, adding that "Taiwan independence" was not one of the DPP's main campaign appeals in the elections on Saturday. (by Chang Chien/Ed Hsieh)

DOC.HEADLINE: US DOLLAR UP IN TAIPEI

TEXT.P: The US dollar rose NT$0.09 on the Taiwan foreign exchange market Tuesday, closing at NT$32.2.
The US dollar opened at the day's low of NT$32.151 and had a high of NT$32.400. Interbank US dollar transactions totaled US$354 million.
Dealers attributed the New Taiwan dollar's fall to the weakness of the Korean won and the Japanese yen, which once dropped to 1,285 and 128 against the US dollar respectively, Tuesday.
They said that the NT dollar may fluctuate between 31.5 and 32.5 against the greenback in the short term.

DOC.HEADLINE: TAIWAN HAS WORLD'S SEVENTH FREEST ECONOMY: RESEARCH

TEXT.P: The Republic of China on Taiwan has the seventh freest economy in the world, on a par with Britain's and Luxembourg's, according to the latest world economic assessment compiled by the Heritage Foundation and the Wall Street Journal.
According to the 1998 Index of Economic Freedom, Taiwan also has the fourth freest economic system in the Pacific Rim, behind only Hong Kong, Singapore and New Zealand.

The index, co-authored by the Heritage Foundation's Kim Holmes and Bryan Johnson and the Wall Street Journal's Melanie Kirkpatrick, assessed 156 economies around the globe in 10 economic and financial areas to judge their freedom.

The 10 areas included the banking system, foreign investment, currency, tariffs, foreign trade, government system, salary structure and inflation, economic and financial laws, rights of property and black-market activities.

On Taiwan's economy, the compilers said the convention of the National Development Conference in late 1996 has helped raise the island's competitiveness in world markets and strengthened its ability to attract foreign capital.
The welfare programs called for by opposition parties, however, may undermine Taiwan's sustainable growth, the authors said.

Despite Hong Kong's handover from Britain to mainland China, the former colony kept its rating as the world's freest economy for the fourth consecutive year, mainly due to the district authorities' adherence to the pre-established hands-off policy, they pointed out.
Hong Kong scored 1.25 points in the 1998 Index of Economic Freedom, on a scale in which 1.0 is the "freest."
Taiwan received 1.95 points. Among the 10 areas assessed, Taiwan's foreign investment and banking system received 3 points, underscoring the two sectors' need for further liberalization.
The index showed that the economies of Hong Kong, Singapore, Bahrain, New Zealand and Switzerland in that order are the five freest in the world.
The US economy was declared the globe's sixth freest, while Australia and Japan tied at 12th, and South Korea came in 24th.
Mainland China fell in 120th place, down among countries that allow relatively little freedom in economic activities, such as Albania, the Congo, Bangladesh and Croatia, the index showed.

DOC.HEADLINE: PRESIDENT LEE RECEIVES SAINT CHRISTOPHER AND NEVIS GOVERNOR GENERAL

TEXT.P: President Lee Teng-hui on Tuesday received visiting Governor General of Saint Christopher and Nevis Cuthbert M. Sebastian and extended a sincere welcome to him.
Lee told Sebastian that the ROC would like to develop closer cooperation with the Caribbean island state and to step up civil exchanges between the two countries.
Expressing his admiration for Saint Christopher's beautiful natural scenery, Lee urged the country to beef up its campaign to attract Taiwan tourists and boost its tourism industry.
Sebastian, who arrived here last Friday for a week-long official visit, expressed his gratitude to Lee for ROC aid to Saint Christopher and vowed to improve ties between the two countries.

Sebastian was accompanied to the meeting at the Presidential Office by Foreign Minister Jason Hu, ROC Ambassador to Saint Christopher and Nevis Katharine S. Y. Chang and Secretary General of the National Security Council Ding Mou-shih.
Saint Christopher and Nevis, an island of 261.6 square kilometers with a population of 49,000, is one of about 30 states which maintain diplomatic ties with the Republic of China.

DOC.HEADLINE: STRAITS TIMES COMMENTS ON TAIWAN ELECTIONS

TEXT.P: It is far better for Taiwan to continue to flourish by preserving the status quo, The Straits Times commented in its editorial Tuesday.

The editorial, titled "Sign of the times in Taiwan," points out that in Saturday's local elections in Taiwan neither the pro-reunification New Party nor the year-old Taiwan Independence Party, formed by defectors from the Democratic Progressive Party (DPP) dissatisfied by what they see as DPP caution over the issue of independence, won any seats.

The rout suffered by these two parties, situated at opposite ends of the spectrum on the question of Taiwan's unification with mainland China, suggests that "Taiwanese are opposed to extreme positions on the subject," says the editorial.
"Most of them prefer the status quo to either independence or reunion with the mainland, at least in the near term," it asserts.

The editorial said that the voters' rejection of the ruling Kuomintang had many reasons, from the island's deteriorating law-and-order situation and the constitutional reforms, to the maneuverings of candidates and others at the local level.
But there is no doubt that many Taiwanese have chosen the DPP and what it stands for over the KMT, it says.

For this result, it adds, the KMT has only itself to blame. The Straits Times says that the KMT tried to adopt the DPP's platform, alienating in the process those who saw this as betraying its own traditions.

However, in hedging its position on independence, the KMT failed to dislodge the DPP from the political space the opposition party created by making the island's political future a core issue, comments the editorial.
"Neither one nor the other, the KMT has paid the price of inhabiting a halfway house," it says. "Just under half, as the local election results show."

These are, of course, local elections. However, the political mood they reveal will have a bearing on the outcome of the parliamentary polls due to be held next year and the presidential election in 2000, asserts the editorial.
The key question is what the DPP is going to do with the local mandate it received last week, it says.
The party has been playing down its pro-independence stance of late, arguing that it is unnecessary for Taiwan to declare independence because it enjoys de facto independence already.
However, the editorial notes, in the aftermath of last week's victory, "the DPP has vowed to push ahead with its pro-independence stand."
"We will continue pursuing the goal of turning Taiwan into an independent state," DPP Secretary-General Chiu I-jen was quoted as saying bluntly.
That would be inadvisable, to say the least, opines the daily.
"The prospects of the island splitting strike at the heart of China's integrity," it says.
"Beijing, to which a single China is non-negotiable, has left no one in any doubt that it will intervene militarily to prevent the prospects from becoming reality," the editorial cautions.
Armed conflict would have a cataclysmic effect in Northeast Asia and affect the stability of a far wider region as well, it adds.

Asian countries that have a stake in peace in the Taiwan Strait would hope that no party in the island would force issues to that point, asserts the editorial, hoping instead that as the DPP becomes more powerful, it will moderate and not radicalize its position on independence.
"It is far better for Taiwan to continue to flourish by preserving the status quo," the editorial says.
"Independence might or might not be a daydream, but it can certainly turn into a nightmare," it warns.

DOC.HEADLINE: KMT REQUIRES `DEEP SCRUTINY': PRESIDENT LEE

TEXT.P: President Lee Teng-hui said on Tuesday that his ruling Kuomintang (KMT) needs to do some deep soul-searching and self-examination following the party's recent election rout.
Lee, who concurrently serves as KMT chairman, made the remarks during a meeting with a delegation of overseas Chinese community leaders from the United States.

It was also the first time since last Saturday that the president had publicly talked about the just-concluded mayoral and magistrate elections, in which the KMT suffered a significant setback, winning only eight of the 23 top local government executive posts up for grabs.

Lee said the outcome indicates that democracy has taken firm root in Taiwan. "Although the KMT has lost control of several cities and counties, we should respect the choice of the electorate," he said, adding that the KMT should carefully scrutinize the reasons behind its defeat at the hands of the opposition Democratic Progressive Party and independent candidates.

Turning to the country's current challenges, Lee said the Republic of China must give top priority to three tasks in order to ensure its survival and sustained development: consolidating its democratic system, upgrading national competitiveness and forging rapprochement with mainland China.

Lee said the ROC has now existed for 86 years. "We should never forsake our sovereignty," he said, adding that the ROC should endeavor to dispel the unrealistic perception in the international community that "one China" is tantamount to the "People's Republic of China."
Pointing out that Chinese culture has been revitalized in Taiwan, Lee said Taiwan's experience can provide inspiration for mainland China in its future development.

He urged overseas Chinese community leaders to remain confident in the ROC's political and economic strength. "I believe China will eventually be reunified under the principles of freedom, democracy and prosperity," he said.

DOC.HEADLINE: NEW MARINE CORPS FORCES PUT INTO SERVICE

TEXT.P: A squadron of landing tanks and an amphibious reconnaissance and search squadron of the Marine Corps of the Republic of China Navy was put into service Tuesday.

The ceremony to commission the two modern squadrons, which were formed under the Navy's new program "to cut the number of commanding officers and strengthen the combat force," was officiated by Adm. Wu Shih-wen, commander-in-chief of the Navy, at the Tsuoyin naval base in southern Taiwan.
The Marine Corps' amphibious frogmen and tank troops showed their formidable combat strength and high spirits at the ceremony.

Wu said at the ceremony that the two squadrons are the first rapid striking forces formed under the new program. The Navy is building a modern naval force with modern military equipment, high quality personnel, and an effective commanding system, he added.
Under the program, the Marine Corps will be reduced from 20,000 to 15,000 men, but its combat strengthen will greatly increase, he added.

The squadron of landing tanks was developed from the Marine Corps' landing tank battalion, while the amphibious reconnaissance and search squadron was from the marine Corps' amphibious reconnaissance and search battalion. Both of the battalions had brilliant combat records. (by Ed Hsieh)

DOC.HEADLINE: CROSS-STRAIT TIES SHOW SIGNS OF THAWING: KOO

TEXT.P: After more than two years of standstill, relations across the Taiwan Strait have finally shown signs of thawing, Straits Exchange Foundation (SEF) Chairman C. F. Koo said on Tuesday.
Among others, Koo said, the deputy secretaries of SEF and the Beijing-based Relations Across the Taiwan Strait (ARATS) have resumed exchanges of visits.

"I'm convinced that even higher-level exchanges between the two organizations are expected to take place in the not too distant future," said the Republic of China's top negotiator with mainalnd China.
SEF and ARATS are semi-official intermediary bodies founded by their respective governments to handle cross-strait exchanges in the absence of official ties.

Koo said stable cross-strait relations are critical to the well-being of the people on both sides of the strait. Before China is reunified, Koo said, the two sides should respect each other. "I earnestly hope that cross-strait dialogue can be resumed soon."
Koo made the remarks while receiving a group of officials of the Cabinet-level Mainland Affairs Council (MAC), which charts the ROC's policy toward the mainland and oversees SEF operations.
MAC Chairman Chang King-yuh paid a visit to the SEF head office Tuesday morning in the company several MAC departmental chiefs.

This was Chang's second visit to the SEF office since he assumed office in February 1996. Chang said communications and interchanges between the MAC and SEF have been very smooth. "So i do not need to make frequent visits to SEF," he noted.
SEF Secretary-General Chiao Jen-ho briefed Chang and other MAC officials on SEF operations.
Senior MAC and SEF officials, including Koo, Chang and Chiao, then held a closed-door meeting.

Local media reports said senior officials of the two organizations might have exchanged views on strategy for future cross-strait talks since ARATS Chairman Wang Daohan reportedly has called for the holding of a meeting between Chiao and his ARATS counterpart, Tang Shubei, to pave the way for Koo's possible visit to the mainland.

DOC.HEADLINE: MOF VOWS TO SEEK MOST FAVORABLE FRAMEWORK FOR TAIPEI-PRETORIA TIES

TEXT.P: The Ministry of Foreign Affairs vowed on Tuesday to seek the best possible arrangement for unofficial ties between Taipei and Pretoria after the South Africa shifts its diplomatic recognition to Beijing at the beginning of next year.

Roy Wu, a spokesman for the ministry, said that Taipei has conducted three rounds of high-level talks and eight rounds of working-level talks with Pretoria on a new framework for bilateral ties. Most issues have already been resolved, while those which remain are to be hammered out during further negotiations.

Wu's remarks came one day after South Africa Foreign Minister Alfred Nzo said in Pretoria that the talks had snagged on Taipei's insistence on maintaining ties at the consular level, and on being allowed to use its national emblem and official name.
Noting that each side has made its stance clear to the other, Wu said the MOFA is seeking to defend ROC national interests by developing the best possible framework for new ties.

DOC.HEADLINE: LEE CALLS FOR COOL HEADS AFTER ELECTION SETBACK

TEXT.P: President Lee Teng-hui on Tuesday called for cool heads among Kuomintang (KMT) members and for a period of soul-searching in the wake of the ruling party's wholesale rout in Taiwan's Nov. 29 local elections.

During a reception for delegates of overseas Chinese communities in the United States, Lee also said that the Republic of China government will never budge on its sovereignty stance, adding that Taipei will continue to seek to expose the lies that Beijing has spread in the international community that "one China" refers only to the People's Republic of China.

Commenting on the just-concluded local elections, Lee said that although the rival parties engaged in a heated contest, the elections were carried out smoothly and rationally, underscoring a perfect example of democratic politics.
Lee said that as KMT chairman and member, he hopes that all party-members will exercise calmness and rationality while carrying out the post-election self-examination.

He said he believes that all failures and mistakes occur for a reason, adding that the party's dismal failure over the weekend, in which the KMT lost seven of its 15 seats at the executive level of local government, demands deep, across-the-board scrutiny.

He urged all KMT members to try their best to dig to the root of the problems behind the failure in order to ready themselves for the next round of challenges, referring to the mayoral elections for Taipei and Kaohsiung cities and the legislative elections scheduled for 1998, as well as the presidential election which will take place in 2000.

DOC.HEADLINE: OIL PRICE HIKE WILL HAVE LIMITED IMPACT ON INFLATION: DGBAS

TEXT.P: An imminent hike in oil prices, probably around 7 percent in mid-December, will fuel the island's inflation by a mere 0.3-0.4 percentage points, the Directorate General of Budget, Accounting & Statistics (DGBAS) predicted on Tuesday.

Since oil consumption makes up only about 2.2 percent of average household expenditure in Taiwan, even if petroleum prices were to be raised by 10 percent, and the ensuing impact on the manufacture sector taken into account, it is estimated that the consumer's price index (CPI) would edge up only 0.43 percentage points, while the wholesale price index (WPI) would increase by 0.53 percentage points, DGBAS officials noted.

If electricity prices remain unchanged and the New Taiwan dollar retains its strength, a 10-percent oil price hike will exert even less impact on CPI and WPI growth, estimated to be only about 0.36 percentage points and 0.46 percentage points, respectively, they pointed out.

The state-owned Chinese Petroleum Corp. announced on Tuesday that it will raise petroleum prices, probably by 7 percent, in the middle of this month as a reflection of the increased cost of imported crude in the wake of the recent sharp depreciation of the local currency.

The DGBAS officials refused to speculate on next year's inflation rate increase, since it remains unknown how Taiwan's currency, which has been affected by Southeast Asia's currency turbulence, will change. The agency predicted in November that Taiwan's annual inflation growth will be controlled at about 3.12 percent in 1998.

DOC.HEADLINE: PHILIPPINES A `VICTIM OF ASIAN TURMOIL'

TEXT.P: The Philippines has been more victim than culprit in the Asian financial drama. Its economy was structurally sound, and its banking system was in good shape, according to reports of the Geneva-based World Trade Organization (WTO) on Tuesday.

In an upbeat assessment of the current outlook, although forecasts for economic growth in 1997-98 have been scaled down by a percentage point or more since the onset of the crisis, they are still within a range of 5.5 - 6.5 percent, the WTO report said.

Inflation might be slightly higher than recent rates of around 5 percent, but prices for basic foodstuffs remain stable. Exports are up by about a quarter on last year's levels, and inward investment continues at a strong pace.

President Fidel Ramos expects the privatization program to continue, in spite of the sharp fall in share prices. The sale of the National Power Corporation, the country's largest company, is under active discussion, the WTO report said.
"Before the end of the first quarter of 1998 we should have some real action going so far as this privatization is concerned," Ramos was quoted as saying.

"Much of the anxiety about East Asia today has to do with issues of transparency, openness, prudence and responsible management -- all of which are the natural outcomes of managing and governing in a democratic way," he added.

DOC.HEADLINE: DPP TO CONSIDER DIALOGUE WITH BEIJING

TEXT.P: Riding the wave of its resounding victory in Taiwan's local elections last weekend, the opposition Democratic Progressive Party (DPP) said on Tuesday that it will consider opening dialogue with Beijing.

The DPP, which won 12 out of the 23 seats up for grabs in the elections for county magistrates and city mayors on Nov. 29, was responding to calls made recently by officials of Beijing's Taiwan Affairs Office for the DPP to help develop cross-strait relations. Beijing in the past has refused contact with the DPP because of the party's advocacy of Taiwan independence.

Yen Wan-chin, director of the DPP's Department of China Affairs, said that his party will definitely not accept any preconditions set by Beijing for entering into dialogue, referring to Beijing's demand that the DPP first renounce its pro-independence stance to pave the way for talks.

Describing the DPP's policy on cross-strait ties "more practical than Beijing's," Yen said that acquiescing to the Beijing demand would be tantamount to the DPP asking Beijing to abandon its "one China" principle.

He said that since Beijing now regards the DPP as important, it needs to review its strategy in dealing with the DPP. "It would be unwise for Beijing to set any prerequisite because this would only serve to block the proposed dialogue between the two sides," he added.

Yen said that the DPP might seek to open dialogue not only with Beijing's policy-making agencies for Taiwan affairs and think-tanks, but also with relevant mainland government and party institutes at both the central and local levels.

Throwing his support behind a call by the ROC's Mainland Affairs Council (MAC) for all political parties to establish a consensus on mainland policy, Yen asked the MAC to increase communication with his party in this regard.

He also pointed out Beijing's proposal that the suspended cross-strait talks be resumed step by step -- beginning with the reopening of dialogue between Taiwan's Straits Exchange Foundation (SEF) and the mainland's Association for Relations Across the Taiwan Strait (ARATS) -- is acceptable to the DPP.

Beijing unilaterally suspended SEF-ARATS talks following ROC President Lee Teng-hui's landmark visit to the United States in the summer of 1995 as a gesture against what it said was a trip aimed at promoting Taiwan independence, an allegation which has been frequently and emphatically denied by the ROC government.
The SEF and ARATS are intermediary organizations set up by Taipei and Beijing respectively to handle cross-strait exchanges in the absence of formal contacts between the two sides.

DOC.HEADLINE: AWSJ TO BE PRINTED IN TAIWAN
DOC.DATELINE: Taipei, Dec. 2 (CNA) (By Flor Wang & Maubo Chang)

TEXT.P: In a great step forward for the ROC in realizing the island's goal of becoming a regional media center, the Asian Wall Street Journal is launching its first printing in Taipei, the seventh site in Asia for the international financial newspaper.

In a speech delivered at a luncheon attended by some 200 government official and dignitaries marking the start of Taiwan's first printing operation of an international daily, ROC President Lee Teng-hui said he admired the foresight of Dow Jones & Company, the paper's owner, in selecting the ROC as a base for further expansion.

Describing himself as a regular reader of the journal, the president lauded the newspaper's insistence on cautious objectivity, accuracy, impartiality, and "its conscientious attitude in presenting its analyse," thereby allowing its readers to analyze issues comprehensively.

These factors help the paper command an influential readership which includes many government and business leaders and policy-makers, and have been instrumental in building it's vast influence in Asia, said Lee.

Noting that the media industry in ROC is becoming a new force for social progress, the president said the island is completing a comprehensive review of relevant laws and regulations, with the aim of attracting more international media to expand their operations into the ROC.

At the luncheon, Karen Elliott House, president of the international affairs division of the Dow Jones group, hailed Lee as the man "who personifies the dramatic change and progress" of the ROC, and the man "who transformed his country into a democracy."

Citing the journal's editorial philosophy of "free men and free markets," House said she admired Taiwan's "commitment to free markets and free men," and expressed gratitude to Lee and his government for welcoming the journal to Taipei.

According to an AWSJ executive, the newspaper's daily circulation in Taiwan is currently about 2,500, a figure which is expected to rise to between 5,000 and 6,000 now that the daily is printed here instead of being delivered from Hong Kong.

DOC.HEADLINE: ROC DONATES FIVE CHOPPERS TO PANAMA
DOC.DATELINE: Panama City, Dec. 2 (CNA) (By Eduardo Chen and Sofia Wu)

TEXT.P: The Republic of China on Tuesday donated five UHIH helicopters to the Panamanian government to help beef up its anti-crime capability.

ROC Ambassador Jason C. Yuan presented the five choppers to Panamanian Minister of Government and Justice Raul Montenegro at a ceremony held at an apron belonging to the Panamanian airborne police corps. The presentation was witnessed by more than 30 senior Panamanian officials and ROC embassy staff members.

Speaking on the occasion, Yuan said the ROC government has donated the helicopters in an attempt to help Panama reinforce its crime-fighting ability to better protect its people's physical and property safety.
Yuan also lauded the Panamanian government for its achievements in improving social order and reducing the crime rate in the past few years under the leadership of President Ernesto Perez Balladares.

For his part, Montenegro expressed his gratitude for the ROC's donation on behalf of the Panamanian government and people. "With these helicopters, our crime-fighting capability will be enhanced significantly," he added.
Each UHIH helicopter can carry 12 people.
