DOC.HEADLINE: TAIWAN IS FIFTH LARGEST IMPORTER OF US FARM PRODUCE
DOC.DATELINE: Washington, Dec. 2 (CNA) (By Herman Pan & Deborah Kuo)

TEXT.P: Taiwan purchased US$2.58 billion worth of agricultural commodities from the United States between Oct. 1, 1996 and Sept. 30, 1997, making it the fifth largest buyer of American farm products in fiscal year 1997, up one notch from the previous year, the US Department of Agriculture (DOA) reported Tuesday.
Taiwan imported about 1.5 times more of these products than mainland China, which took in about US$1.78 billion worth of American agricultural commodities during the same year.
Mainland China was the seventh largest buyer of American agricultural commodities in FY 1997, down two notches from FY 1996, according to DOA tallies.

The tallies also showed that the top 10 world buyers of American agricultural commodities in FY 1997 were Japan, Canada, Mexico, South Korea, Taiwan, the Netherlands, mainland China, Hong Kong, Germany, and Britain, in that order.

In FY 1997, the United States exported US$57.26 billion worth of agricultural commodities, down 4.2 percent from the previous year. North America, Japan and the European Union, in that order, were the three major export areas.

Taiwan was also the fifth largest buyer of American agricultural, fishery and forest products as a whole in FY 1997, the same tallies indicated. A total of US$2.77 billion worth of such products were shipped to Taiwan during the past fiscal year, about US$90 million more than those delivered to mainland China.
Meanwhile, Taiwan exported a relatively much smaller US$164.5 million worth of agricultural products to the United States in FY 1997, making it America's 32nd largest supplier of such products.
As a result, the United States enjoyed an enviable surplus of US$2.42 billion with Taiwan in this sector during the period.

DOC.HEADLINE: LAWMAKERS NIP IMPORTS OF 38,000 ALIEN WORKERS

TEXT.P: The public notification of the import of 38,000 foreign laborers by the Cabinet-level Council of Labor Affairs (CLA), originally scheduled for November, was suspended as a result of a boycott by a dozen legislators, CLA Chairman Hsu Chieh-kuei said Wednesday.

According to Hsu, Taiwan's top official in charge of labor affairs, the lawmakers opposed the further introduction of laborers from abroad into Taiwan on the grounds that the number of crimes committed by this special group of expatriates has continued to rise. They asked for a wholesale halt to such import, he added.

The quota of 38,000 is not an addition to the originally approved number of foreign laborers, Hsu noted, saying that instead these slots are available now because domestic applicants did not fill the original quota or sometimes had their individual quotas revoked because of improper usage.
Hsu would not speculate on how soon the CLA will give the green light to entry of the 38,000 alien workers, only saying that he will continue to communicate with the legislators on this concern.

Since 1989, when the government first began the introduction of foreign laborers to Taiwan to help ease the ever-increasing labor shortage, 327,443 foreigners have been approved to come to the island as of the end of October.
During the period, 251,127 laborers, mainly from Southeast Asian countries, actually arrived in Taiwan to work in various sectors, including home service, manufacturing and construction.
Meanwhile, their period of single stay has been extended from two to three years since May of this year.
So far the number of runaways or those who overstay their visas totals about 20,000, creating a headache for the government.

DOC.HEADLINE: ROC IMPORTS OF US ALCOHOLIC DRINKS UP FIVEFOLD IN SEVEN YEARS
DOC.DATELINE: Washington, Dec. 2 (CNA) (By Herman Pan & Deborah Kuo)

TEXT.P: Taiwan is the fourth largest market of wine and beer from the United States, a position it has reached because the island's imports of US alcoholic beverages have grown 530 percent over the last seven years, sources from the US Department of Agriculture (USDA) reported Tuesday.

In fiscal year 1997 (Oct. 1, 1996-Sept. 30, 1997), Taiwan imported US$46.83 million worth of US alcoholic beverages, including wine and beer, up 27.8 percent over the year-earlier level, making the island America's fourth largest overseas buyer, said USDA officials.

According to USDA tallies, the top 10 overseas markets of US-brewed wine and beer in FY 1997 were Britain, Canada, Japan, Taiwan, Hong Kong, Paraguay, Germany, Brazil, Mexico and Switzerland, in that order.
In FY 1997, the United States exported US$717.61 million worth of wine and beer products, with 6.5 percent of the exports heading for Taiwan, the officials noted.

Meanwhile, the department said 95 percent of the imported alcoholic beverages consumed in America came from Europe, with products from France, the Netherlands and Italy dominating some 50 percent of the total.

The top 10 alcoholic beverage suppliers to the United States in FY 1997 were France, the Netherlands, Italy, Mexico, Canada, Germany, Chile, Australia, Britain and Spain, in that order, said the department.

DOC.HEADLINE: NO TIMETABLE FOR RESUMPTION OF CROSS-STRAIT TALKS: TAO

TEXT.P: There is no timetable for the resumption of talks between Beijing's Association for Relations Across the Taiwan Strait (ARATS) and the Taipei-based Straits Exchange Foundation (SEF), remarked an official of the Taiwan Affairs Office (TAO) of the mainland Chinese State Council.
Chang Minqing, chief of the TAO's information bureau, said Tuesday that if Taipei's attitude and response are both active and serious, the bilateral talks will probably resume next spring.
Chang made the remarks at a seminar held in Hong Kong on information about Hong Kong, Macau, mainland China and Taiwan.
In regard to whether there is a chance for both sides of the strait to resume bilateral talks in the near future, the mainland official was quoted as saying "it depends on Taiwan's response."

Beijing's stance is to formally end hostilities under the principle of one China through political negotiations, Chang reiterated, adding that mainland Chinese President Jiang Zemin introduced the proposal on Jan. 30, 1995 and reasserted it at the 15th National Congress of the Chinese Communist Party, but that Taiwan "has not responded seriously yet."
Meetings of ARATS and SEF officials have now resumed and been upgraded, following their suspension in the summer of 1995, noted Chang.

As to a meeting between SEF Chairman Koo Chen-fu and his ARATS counterpart, Wang Daohan, Chang stressed that this would require a great many preparations and that cross-strait contacts should therefore be built up gradually.

DOC.HEADLINE: US SCHOLARS COMMENT ON TAIWAN ELECTIONS
DOC.DATELINE: New York, Dec. 2 (CNA) (By David Wang and Flor Wang)

TEXT.P: A long-time Taiwan observer and China expert said on Tuesday that Taiwan's recent mayoral and county magistrate election was a "genuine democratic election," which truly reflects public opinion.

However, Andrew Nathan, professor of the East Asian Study Institute at Colombia University, told the local press that the chances are slim that the opposition Democratic Progressive Party (DPP) will declare Taiwan independent, even if the pro-independence party assumes power in the central government.

The DPP scored a landslide victory in Taiwan's mayoral and county chief election on November 29, winning control in 12 out of a total of 23 constituencies in the race and changing dramatically Taiwan's political picture at the local level.

According to Nathan, the people of Taiwan prefer to maintain the status-quo across the Taiwan Strait and the DPP must take this into account should it ever become the ruling party. Since most of Taiwan's population are unwilling to unify with mainland China or declare independence, the DPP must forge its policy based on public opinion, he added.

He said the US position on the issue of cross-strait negotiations has undergone a subtle change since the October meeting between US President Bill Clinton and mainland China's President Jiang Zemin in Washington.

Richard Bush, chairman of the Washington-based American Institute in Taiwan, reiterated to ranking ROC authorities during a visit to Taiwan in the wake of the Clinton-Jiang summit, that the US government will stand firm on the "three communiques" signed between Washington and Beijing and stressed that Washington will not recognize Taiwan sovereignty or establish diplomatic relations with Taiwan should the country declare independence.
Nathan also opined that Beijing should increase contacts with the DPP in order to gain a comprehensive understanding of the DPP's stance on the issue of Taiwan independence.

James Seymour, a senior researcher at the East Asian Study Institute, said the election is a reflection of Taiwan's sound political structure and its energetic bi-partisan system. He noted, however, that the election results should not have much effect on Taiwan's overall political situation, as they only affected government at the local level.

Although the DPP achieved a major victory, Seymour said it is unlikely that the opposition party will be able to assume power of the central government in the short term, making it unnecessary to worry about at present the question of whether the DPP will declare Taiwan independent should it become the ruling party.

He expressed the belief that the DPP will not impulsively declare Taiwan independent, even it does win power in the central government, in order to avoid unnecessary trouble for the people on both sides of the Taiwan Strait.

DOC.HEADLINE: 'PEOPLE POWER' BRINGS ABOUT INT'L LAND MINE TREATY

TEXT.P: Canada's Foreign Affairs Minister Lloyd Axworthy opened an international conference on land mines in Ottawa Tuesday, calling it a triumph of "people power" on the international stage.
Besides signing a historic treaty banning the deadly devices, participants from more than 100 countries will work on the details of getting rid of them.

The drive to ban land mines was originally launched by volunteers and non-governmental agencies. Canada took up the cause last year, telling its diplomats to help push other governments to sign the deal.
Some important powers don't support the treaty. Among the hold-outs are the United States, mainland China, India, Pakistan, Israel and Russia. They are major producers and users of land mines.

Many still see the accord as a major first step toward eliminating mines. The accord will ban the stockpile, export, production and use of anti-personnel mines. It will also set a timetable for the removal of mines already in the ground.
It's estimated that over 100 million land mines are strewn in 70 countries throughout the world.
The Ottawa initiative gained steam in October, when the Nobel Peace Prize was awarded to the International Campaign to Ban Land mines and its leader Jody Williams.
Only last week, Japan and Poland came aboard. On Tuesday, Venezuela, the Vatican and Bulgaria were added to the list.
Canada is spending C$3.7 million (US$2.6 million) to roll out the red carpet for the delegates from 148 countries, including airfare and accommodation for many.
"It is on the subject of land mines that Canada's leadership has made its most resounding contribution to humankind this decade," said Kofi Annan, secretary general of the United Nations.
"Without Canada, we would not be going to the signing of the treaty," Annan added.

DOC.HEADLINE: AUSSIE WHEAT EXPORTS SEEN BEING HIT BY UNTIMELY RAINS, HEAT WAVE

TEXT.P: Australia expects lower wheat exports in fiscal 1997-98 because of untimely rains and hot spells that will hurt the quality of the produce, according to the Australian Bureau of Agriculture and Research Economics (ABARE).
The ABARE has slightly upgraded its overall wheat harvest forecast to 17.9 million tonnes for the 1997-98 wheat crop but it has warned of widespread quality problems in that crop.
The bureau said only 11.7 million tonnes of wheat -- or less than two thirds of the expected crop -- will be fit for export in 1997-98, the poorest result for three years.
The Australian Wheat Board, however, is more optimistic than the bureau, predicting that almost 13 million tonnes of wheat could be exported, including to mainland China and Taiwan.
The board's merchandising manager Phillip Pyle said much of the lower quality grain could still be sold overseas at a discount price.
Rains in early November generally came too late to benefit crops and instead had a detrimental impact on grain formation and harvesting activity, the ABARE said.
The situation was compounded by the extremely hot weather late in November, which could also significantly reduce yields in the southern, late harvesting areas, it added.

DOC.HEADLINE: KMT DEFEAT HAS PROFOUND IMPLICATIONS FOR REGIONAL PEACE: DAILY

TEXT.P: The Globe and Mail carried a Taipei-datelined report on Tuesday saying that the defeat of the ruling Kuomintang in the latest election in the Republic of China "has profound implications for peace in the region."

The report, by the International Herald Tribune, said the KMT could well lose next year's parliamentary election and it is now possible that Taipei's popular mayor Chen Shui-bian will replace Lee Teng-hui as president in 2000.

Beijing will now wait to see if a Democratic Progressive Party candidate becomes president in 2000 and wholly abandons the mantra of reunification and moves Taiwan toward the "ultimate flash point, independence," according to the report.

DOC.HEADLINE: POLICE TO REINFORCE PROTECTIVE MEASURES FOR EXPATRIATES

TEXT.P: Police are to step up protective measures for expatriates in the metropolitan Taipei area from Thursday, amid mounting criminal activities which target foreign diplomats and business people, the country's top police administrator said on Wednesday.

"Grassroots police officers will intensify patrols around foreign embassies, representative offices, corporations and expatriate residential communities," said Ting Yuan-chin, director general of the National Police Administration (NPA).

Intensified protective measures will first be implemented in Taipei City and Taipei County, where many foreign offices are located and where the largest number of expatriates are resident, Ting said, adding that similar measures will gradually be expanded to cover other cities and counties around the island.

Ting made the remarks during a visit to the central city of Taichung, where he presented awards to police officers responsible for solving the recent murder of a schoolteacher and for cracking a recent firearms smuggling operation.
Ting also exchanged views with criminal investigators responsible for probing the murder of an American housewife which took place in Taichung on April 15.
Tina Holden died from repeated blows to the back of her head during a suspected burglary at her home in an upscale community in Taichung.
Tina's husband, Lenny Holden, appealed to Ting on Tuesday for a speedy solution to the brutal murder case.
Holden, the Asia general manager for the Converse sporting goods company, said he is disappointed by the ineffectiveness of local police in solving the crime.

"Seven months later, they are still saying that they are checking fingerprints," Holden told a news conference after meeting with Ting, adding: "It seems to me they have not energetically and aggressively pursued leads, such as missing artwork, jewelry and foreign currencies."

Holden, who had lived with his wife and two small children in Taiwan for two-and-a-half years, said police have even failed to keep him informed of their progress, as they had promised to do at the outset.
In response to Holden's appeal, Ting again instructed the Taichung police office to do its utmost to bring the perpetrators to justice as soon as possible.

However, Taichung police said they have in fact devoted a great deal of energy to investigating the case over the past seven months. Forensic experts have examined more than 60 fingerprints and a number of ex-convicts suspected of involvement in the case have been questioned. However, no major breakthrough has so far been achieved due to a lack of eyewitnesses as well as limited information about the pre-murder situation. Investigators said they still do not have a complete list of missing articles.

The safety of expatriates was thrust even more forcefully into the spotlight after the island's most-wanted criminal -- Chen Chin-hsing -- broke into the home of South African military attache Col. McGill Alexander and took his entire family hostage on Nov. 18. The incident was peacefully resolved after a 24-hour standoff between police and the fugitive, although Alexander and his eldest daughter were shot and wounded by Chen.

In the latest reported incident, the residence of the de facto American ambassador to the Republic of China, Daryl Johnson, was burglarized last weekend, and the homes of three of his colleagues at the Taipei office of the American Institute in Taiwan (AIT) were also broken into, apparently on the same day. AIT was founded by American authorities in 1979 to handle exchanges with the ROC in the absence of diplomatic ties.

The burglary of Johnson's home has sounded alarm bells to police because it is the first such case in recent memory, and occurred despite round-the-clock police protection which is mandatory for foreign embassies, representative offices and the residences of the top personnel of those offices.

According to NPA tallies, a total of 46 criminal cases, involving 52 foreign victims, were reported in the first six months of this year, most of which involved Americans and Japanese. Burglary, which accounted for 30 cases, was the most common crime reported, while murder, with only three reported cases, was much rarer.

DOC.HEADLINE: SHARE PRICES SURGE ON TAIEX

TEXT.P: Share prices surged on the Taiwan Stock Exchange Wednesday, with the weighted index, the market's key barometer, increasing 222.98 points to finish at 7902.51.
The bourse opened at the day's low of 7651.68 and experienced a high of 7904.16.
Gainers outnumbered losers 423 to 26, with 29 remaining unchanged. In all, 3.09 billion shares changed hands on a market turnover of NT$136.62 billion (US$4.27 billion).

Paper and pulp stocks rose the most at 6.8 percent, followed by textile issues at 5.5 percent; construction shares at 5.4 percent; cement stocks at 4.5 percent; plastic and chemical issues at 4.3 percent; foodstuff shares at 3.7 percent; financial shares at 2.0 percent; and electrical engineering at 1.6 percent.

DOC.HEADLINE: QUEENS IS EPICENTER OF NEW YORK CITY IMMIGRANT GROWTH

TEXT.P: Half of the households in Queens Borough of New York City are now headed by someone born in a foreign country, according to a New York University study that shows Queens remains the epicenter of a massive influx of immigrants into New York City.

The study also found that Hispanics now outnumber blacks as the second largest racial/ethnic group in Queens and citywide. The city's white population, though still the largest, continued to decline, especially in Queens, while Asians are growing at the fastest pace.
The report, released Monday by the Taub Urban Research Center, analyzed data collected by the US Census Bureau for the New York City Department of Housing Preservation and Development in 1996.

The report cited Queens as having the highest number of city households headed by foreign-born people in 1996. Nearly 350,000 Queens households, or almost half of the total in the borough, were headed by a foreign-born person. Brooklyn had the second highest number, with more than 40 percent of households headed by a foreign-born individual.
According to the report, Queens' population was 39.1 percent white, 23.9 percent Hispanic, 20.5 percent black and 18.6 percent Asian in 1966.

For Queens, the percentages are a significant change for whites, who in 1990 represented 48.2 percent of the borough's population. At that time, blacks accounted for 20.3 percent, Asians 12.4 percent and Hispanics 19.1 percent.

Citywide, the 1996 figures were 38.5 percent white, 26.6 percent Hispanic, 26.2 percent black and 8.7 percent Asian. That compared with 1990 figures of 43.3 percent white, 24.5 percent Hispanic, 25.4 percent black and 6.7 percent Asian.
Asians increased at the fast rate, growing in Queens from 240,672 in 1990 to 402,373 in 1996. Citywide, their population grew from 489,851 in 1990 to 744,837 in 1996.
Mitchell Moss, the center's director and one of the report's three authors, believes there is no connection between the increase in immigrants and the drop in white residents.

"White professionals benefit because immigrants provide the support services they require," Moss said. "You see it in the dry cleaners, green grocers, the health care workers and the phenomenal growth of manicure salons."

DOC.HEADLINE: ASIA'S WOES MAY HELP US ECONOMY

TEXT.P: Economic analysts said Asia's monetary crisis will mean a stronger US dollar, fewer US exports to the region and more imports from it, followed by slower US growth and less inflation than otherwise would have occurred, hence benefiting the US Federal Reserve Board's work helping secure the US economy, according to the Journal of Commerce on Tuesday.

The analysts said there's no question that such a scenario -- in which Asia's woes help the US economy -- is highly probable, even inevitable, for the next six months or more. The dampening effect on the US economy will also be sufficient to forestall Federal Reserve action to boost interest rates in a preemptive strike against inflation.

They also said that, for dealing with the crisis, the United States and the European Union may take a step or two this week at an EU-US summit toward harmonizing their related policies, starting a kind of government-to-government cooperation US and EU business leaders are strongly urging.

DOC.HEADLINE: CEPD CHAIRMAN ADDRESSES US-ROC BUSINESS CONFERENCE

TEXT.P: The Republic of China government is taking decisive action to push forward the APROC plan and government re-engineering. These major initiatives will bring laws and regulations up to date, improve efficiency, and strongly enhance the investment environment, according to P.K. Chiang, chairman of the Council for Economic Planning and Development (CEPD).

"The performance of the ROC economy amid the widespread financial turmoil stands as testament that Taiwan is a place where investors may still come with confidence to seek high profits at low risk," Chiang said in San Diego on Tuesday at the plenary session of the 21st Joint Business Conference of the ROC-USA Economic Council and US-ROC Business Council.

In his speech entitled "ROC Economic Prospects Amid Global Financial Turmoil," Chiang said: "We will press ahead with financial liberalization while continuing to strengthen financial supervision to ensure the soundness of financial environment.

"As economic and trade ties between our countries grow constantly broader and deeper, we would like to call upon your support for early completion of the bilateral talks on ROC accession to the World Trade Organization (WTO). We are sure that our entry to the WTO will substantially benefit us both, giving rise to rich new opportunities for US-ROC business."

Chiang said: "The agricultural sector should be given special consideration in the process of trade liberalization. A healthy agricultural sector in Taiwan will help the stabilization of our society, which will better serve US interests; The delay of our accession to the WTO prevents the US business community to enjoy the benefits of our market."

He went on: "Trade liberalization is an ongoing process. We can work together to solve remaining issues in bilateral or multilateral form even after our WTO accession; accession is one of the most important policies to my country." He also asked the US delegates to convey to their government the Republic of China's determination to build up a better and more open economy and to conclude bilateral negotiations as soon as possible.

Addressing the recent financial turmoil in Southeast and East Asia, he said: "The effects of the currency crisis have been felt not only in the financial markets of the ROC, Singapore, Hong Kong and South Korea, but also in stock markets around the world. The Impact of the financial turmoil on the ROC's economy remains moderate, due to our sound economic fundamentals and our steady pursuit of economic liberalization."

DOC.HEADLINE: CURRENCY CRISIS PROMPTS BEIJING TO SPEED UP ECONOMIC REFORMS

TEXT.P: Mainland China will use the opportunity provided by the currency crisis to improve its economic efficiency and to "accelerate the pace of economic reforms," mainland Chinese Vice-Premier Li Lanqing said Tuesday.
Beijing will not devalue the renminbi, Li said, calling this step unnecessary as long as the mainland government's policies are pro-investment and pro-business.

He said that the currency crisis had proven Beijing right in pursuing a gradual, step-by-step economic reform program, but added that mainland China would continue to press ahead with reforms and the opening up of its economy to foreign investment.

Li made the points when Singapore's Senior Minister Lee Kuan Yew called on him Tuesday at the Great Hall of the People in Beijing, The Straits Times reported Wednesday in a dispatch filed from Suzhou.
The report quoted a Singapore spokesman as saying that their 45-minute talk focused on the impact of the regional currency crisis.

Lee lamented the harm the crisis had done to a number of Asian economies and said it was fortunate mainland China had been spared the fate of countries like South Korea because its currency, the renminbi, is not fully convertible.
The mainland Chinese currency enjoys current account convertibility; capital account convertibility has been deferred for several years.
Turning to the crisis' impact on investments, he stressed the importance of maintaining investors' confidence in the region.
During the talks, Lee also commended mainland Chinese economic progress as "praiseworthy," with visible advancements each time he visits, the report said.
Lee's last visit to mainland China was in September last year.

On the economic task facing mainland China, the mainland Chinese vice-premier noted that it is "unprecedented," as it involves a massive transformation of the economy. The two key issues, he noted, are getting management talent and technology into mainland China.

Turning to the 15th Communist Party Congress held in September this year, he told Lee that its most significant outcome was the affirmation of Deng Xiaoping's reformist ideology as the current guiding philosophy, the report said.
He said the congress' final report is a document of consensus, prepared only after getting the views of all participants.
The task ahead is to consolidate achievements and speed up reforms, he added, reiterating that mainland China will remain pro-investment.

Lee, who is in mainland China to renew ties with leaders there and to update himself on Singapore's mainland Chinese investments, arrived in Suzhou late Tuesday to tour the Singapore-Suzhou Industrial Park and other facilities in Suzhou Wednesday.
The highlight of Lee's 12-day visit to mainland China will be calls on President Jiang Zemin and Vice-Premier Zhu Rongji next Monday, the report said.

DOC.HEADLINE: AUSTRALIA OPPOSED TO DIMINUTION OF US INFLUENCE IN ASIA

TEXT.P: Australia will spend A$5 billion (US$3.4 billion) to increase its military firepower to deal with any emerging enemy beyond its shores and Canberra is unwilling to see mainland China's growing power if it means the diminution of the US strategic influence in Asia, according to an Australian strategic review.

Releasing the first defense strategic review Tuesday, Defense Minister Ian McLachlan said Australia would rely on a ring of electronic early-warning intelligence, including "spy planes" to identify any threat long before a potential invader could reach the Australian coast.
He said the Royal Australian Air Force's strike planes and the Royal Australian Navy's vessels, equipped with substantially increased weaponry, would be sent to deal with any such threat.

The A$5 billion will be used to buy up to seven airborne early warning and control aircraft, new helicopter-launched strike missiles, new weapons for the navy's frontline warships and the upgrade of F1-11 bombers to ensure they remain the main strike weapon until the year 2020.
Medium-range missiles for the F1-11 bombers and air-to-air refueling to extend the combat range of the Air Force's 71 FA-18 fighters to maintain air defense superiority are also on the drawing board.

McLachlan said in the past two decades Australia's security interest was far more tightly focused on the immediate region -- Southeast Asia, the southwest Pacific and the eastern reaches of the Indian Ocean.
"We cannot allow our thinking to be influenced by artificial boundaries. This strategic review re-emphasizes the importance of northeast Asia to our own security," he said.
The review warns of a "significant danger" of war breaking out on the Korean peninsula despite the "clear possibility" of the two Koreas reunifying within the medium term.
McLachlan said the reunification itself could have the potential to create "strategic tensions" in northeast Asia that would need to be carefully managed.
He played down any "inevitability" about Australian forces being drawn into a conflict in the region.
But he said mainland China was not perceived as a military threat, notwithstanding its central role in a number of potential hot spots such as the Taiwan Strait and South China Sea.

On Beijing's regional ambitions, the strategic review adopts a cautious approach. It describes the growth of mainland Chinese power as an important new factor in the strategic equation and adds the caveat that "it is not yet clear how that power will be accommodated within the regional community."

"It would not be in Australia's interests for China's growing power to result in a diminution of the US strategic influence or to stimulate damaging strategic competition between China and other regional powers," the review says.
"Such competition is not inevitable because the regional strategic balance need not be a zero-sum game. But there are some -- in China and elsewhere -- who are inclined to see it that way," it adds.
McLachlan said another significant factor in Australia's security is the impossibility of quarantining the rest of the Asian region from tension in northeast Asia.
"Today, tensions in northeast Asia -- for example on the Korean peninsula -- have flow-on effects in Southeast Asia much more directly than was the case in the 1970s and 1980s," he said.

DOC.HEADLINE: TAIWAN'S FUTURE SHOULD BE RESOLVED PEACEFULLY: US

TEXT.P: The US government Tuesday reiterated its long-standing position that the issue of Taiwan's future should be resolved peacefully between the two sides of the Taiwan Strait.

At a regular press briefing, James Rubin, spokesman for the US Department of State, was asked whether the US government would view the use of force by mainland China against Taiwan as justified if Taiwan should declare independence. Earlier Tuesday a spokesman for mainland China's Foreign Ministry reportedly threatened that Beijing would resort to force if Taiwan should seek separation from the Chinese mainland.
In reply, Rubin pointed out that the US position has not changed. He reiterated that the United States does not support Taiwan independence or "one Taiwan, one China."
"What we do support is the resolution of this issue peacefully," he said.

Pressed further to explain if the use of force by Beijing to prevent Taiwan independence would be justified, Rubin said, "What we do support ... is the resolution of this issue peacefully; therefore, we don't support the use of force."

The Republic of China on Taiwan insists that, contrary to what Beijing says, it is an independent sovereign country. The nation was founded in 1912. Its government moved to Taiwan in 1949 after the Chinese mainland fell into the hands of the Chinese Communists in a civil war. The ROC has since been in effective control of Taiwan, Penghu (the Pescadores) and the two offshore islands of Kinmen and Matsu -- territories that have never been ruled by the Communists.

In talks between Taiwan and mainland China during past years, both sides have agreed that there is only one China and that either side is free to make its own interpretation of what that means. Beijing claims that Taiwan is "a province of the People's Republic of China" and favors a "one country, two systems" approach -- a formula being practiced in Hong Kong -- as the way to resolve Taiwan's future.

However, the government in Taipei insists that Taipei and Beijing are two equal political entities and has favored "one country, two governments" -- a proposal rejected by Beijing. The ROC government has dismissed the idea of "one country, two systems" as unworkable and has stated repeatedly that Taiwan and mainland China can be reunited only when both sides of the Taiwan Strait are free, democratic and prosperous.

DOC.HEADLINE: ROC SIGNS TOURIST PACTS WITH SIX CENTRAL AMERICAN COUNTRIES

TEXT.P: The Republic of China on Wednesday signed tourist cooperation agreements with six Central American countries -- Guatemala, El Salvador, Honduras, Nicaragua, Costa Rica and Panama.
The accords were inked in Taipei by Minister of Transportation and Communications Tsay Jaw-yang and the heads of the tourism promotion organizations of the six countries.

Speaking on the occasion, Tsay said the pacts are part of the ROC government's efforts to deliver promises made by President Lee Teng-hui during his four-country Latin American visit in September to boost cooperation with the region in various fields.

Tsay said Central America is one of the best travel destinations in the world because of the region's beautiful natural scenery and rich cultural heritage. "With intensified promotional efforts from relevant countries, tourist exchanges between the ROC and the region will increase significantly in the years ahead," he noted.

Under the newly signed agreements, the signatories agreed to offer flexible visa services on a reciprocal basis, exchange tourism-related information, cooperate in marketing and offer incentives to encourage investment in the development of tourist resources and facilities.
The signatories also agreed to upgrade the quality of flight services and sponsor seminars to work out attractive tour packages.
The agreements will remain valid for five years, and, if necessary, can be extended for another five years.

With the assistance of the ROC's Tourism Bureau, local travel agencies organized a fact-finding visit to Central America earlier this year, following which they worked out three suitable tour packages.

However, local travel agents remain doubtful as to how many Taiwan tourists those travel packages will actually be able to attract, since several barriers to expanding tourist exchanges with the region remain, including geographic distance, language barriers and expensive travel bills, as well as the fact that most Central American countries have no budget allocations for promotional programs.

According to travel sources, ROC nationals make an average of 2,000 visits to Central American countries a year, with business people, elected representatives and members of special social groups forming the largest group of visitors.

At present, only Costa Rica offers landing visas for ROC passport-holders. Travel sources said Costa Rica, Guatemala, El Salvador, Honduras and Nicaragua are considering issuing "joint travel cards" to prospective visitors, whereby holders of such cards will be able to visit all five countries without having to apply separately for permission to enter each one.

The ROC has already signed aviation agreements with Panama and Costa Rica, but to date, only Taiwan's EVA Airways operates two weekly scheduled flights between Taiwan and Panama because of the low economic value of the route.
Under the ROC's open-sky agreement with the United States, Tsay said, Taiwan carriers can also cooperate with American airlines to open the Central American travel market.

DOC.HEADLINE: ROC-US TRADE SATISFACTORY: JEFFREY KOO

TEXT.P: For the first eight months of this year, the Republic of China's trade with the United States was quite satisfactory. There should be many more opportunities for American businesses to participate in ROC government projects on a fair, competitive basis, Jeffrey Koo, chairman of the ROC-USA Economic Council, said in San Diego, California, Tuesday.

Speaking at the plenary session of 21st Annual Joint Conference of the ROC-USA Economic Council and the USA-ROC Business Council, Koo said: "For the first eight months of this year, our trade with the United States was quite satisfactory, the total two-way trade being US$34.05 billion, an increase of 9.3 percent over the same period in 1996. Our total export to the United States was US$18.83 billion, an increase of 7.1 percent. Our total import from the United States was US$15.23 billion, an increase of 12.2 percent. The trade balance in our favor was US$3.6 billion, a decrease of 10.1 percent.

"We believe this health trend in our bilateral business relations will be kept up in the coming years. The policy of our new Cabinet will emphasize on transparency in the government, privatization of state enterprises and a BOT approach in many infrastructure projects. There should be many more opportunities for American businesses to participate in our government projects on a fair, competitive basis."
Koo acknowledged that in recent years there has been a rush of many countries for investment in mainland China.

"From 1979 to 1996, cumulative foreign investment in mainland China totaled US$175.5 billion. In 1996 alone, total foreign investment in mainland China was US$41.7 billion, of which US$21.3 billion, or 50.95 percent came from Hong Kong and Macau; US$3.7 billion, or 8.82 percent from Japan; US$3.5 billion, or 8.33 percent, from Taiwan, US$3.4 billion, or 8.25 percent from Singapore; US$1.4 billion or 3.25 percent, from South Korea; and US$1.3 billion, or 3.12 percent, from Britain," he said.

Koo, however, added: "Because of inefficiency and corruption in the government, it is not very easy to run a profitable business operation on mainland China. Indeed, a significant number of foreign investments in (mainland) China have ended badly.

"Now that our cross-strait relations with mainland China seem to be on the mend, there should be increased business relationships between two sides. There should be many good opportunities for American industries, especially high-tech industries, to use Taiwan as a regional operations center for expansion of business to mainland China, as well as to other Asian markets. They can not only avoid unnecessary risks (through) indirect investment in mainland China, but also take advantage of the trained manpower and much more favorable investment climate in Taiwan."

He continued: "Taiwan's economy in the current year is fairly encouraging. The forecasts for our GDP growth in 1997 range from 6.2 percent to 6.7 percent, as compared with 5.71 percent in 1996. The driving force for the growth is an over 10 percent growth in private sector investment.

"Construction of infrastructure projects, which fell way behind schedule, has gradually caught up with targets. Domestic consumption has considerably increased as a result of the bullish stock market and a mild upturn of the prices of real properties in the first three quarters of the year. The CPI increased by less that 2 percent, and the unemployment rate remains at about 3 percent.

"All real economic indicators, including industrial production export growth and private sector investment, show signs of steady improvement. The upswing of the economy is expected to continue into the next year (at) a moderate pace. The forecast for 1988 is a GDP growth rate of no less than 6.5 percent.
"The financial sector fared quite well for the first seven months of the year. The stock market registered robust growths, and the money supply also went up to the Central Bank's target level."

Although he noted that the financial crises in ASEAN countries and South Korea have had an impact on Taiwan's financial market, he said: "Taiwan's economy is on a more solid foundation than the ASEAN countries.

"While the ASEAN countries are suffering from negative growths in exports because of competition from mainland China, we still enjoy a trade surplus. Since we have a large foreign exchange reserve, we don't have foreign debt burdens, nor do we have to rely on short-term international hot money. As our exchange rate is not pegged to the US dollar, our currency is not over-valued like the currencies in some of the ASEAN countries.
"All these factors help us withstand the impact of the Asian currency crises with considerable success."

DOC.HEADLINE: ROC ECONOMICS MINISTER ADDRESSES ROC-US BUSINESS CONFERENCE

TEXT.P: "Although we are faced with many challenges brought on by changes in both the domestic and international economies, these challenges can also be viewed as opportunities to break out of the current bottleneck in our economic development," ROC Minister of Economic Affairs Wang Chih-kang said in San Diego on Tuesday.

Addressing the plenary session of the 21st Joint Conference of ROC-USA Economic Council and the US-ROC Business Council, Wang went on: "The next few years will be critical to our efforts to bring our economic development to its full potential. This period will provide an unmatched opportunity for developing and implementing constructive solutions to the problems that face us. At the same time, we must bear in mind that in an increasingly interdependent world, no country can remain prosperous and stable unless people everywhere enjoy similar benefits.

"Looking to the 21st century, we will actively seek cooperation with international enterprises to develop the ROC into an Asia-Pacific Regional Operations Center. We hope that by building on our existing strong and vibrant foundation, we will be able to join the ranks of fully developed countries by the year 2000. We also hope that by that time, we will have met the following objectives:
-- A gross national product of US$440 billion.
-- A total production value of US$300 billion for the manufacturing sector.
-- A total export and import volume that exceeds US$300 billion.
-- A per capita GNP that exceeds US$20,000."

He said: "We recognize these are ambitious goals, but we believe they are within our reach. I am proud to say, in the case of Taiwan, that our reach is consistently oriented to the future and toward goals that will create more prosperity for our people. We look forward to working with our many American partners in pursuing these aims and in identifying new directions for our economy. The ROC and the US have successfully explored many areas for cooperation in the past. I am confident that this will be no less true in the future."

In his speech, Wang also noted: "Generally speaking, our economic performance in 1997 has been promising in spite of the recent financial turmoil brought on by currency crises in Southeast Asia. Further expansion of the global economy should ensure that our export growth remains buoyant. With work on major infrastructure projects proceeding at an accelerated pace, as well as the effect of the various measures that have been taken to spur investment, our economy is expected to grow at a rate of about 6.17 percent."

He also listed the promotion of liberalization, improvement of the basic infrastructure, enhancement of administrative efficiency, upgrading of local industries and heightening of the ROC's competitiveness as current challenges to the ROC's economic development.

DOC.HEADLINE: 1997 SET TO BE SINGAPORE'S HOTTEST YEAR

TEXT.P: 1997 is set to be Singapore's hottest year ever, or at least since weather records started being kept here in 1929.
The Singapore Meteorological Service said Tuesday that this year's annual mean temperature is likely to be 28.2 degrees Celsius.
For the last 36 years, the mean was 26.8 C.
1997 will also be the first year that Singapore's mean temperature exceeds 28 C, a rise of three degrees from about three decades ago, when the average temperature hit 25.2 C one year.

A spokesman for the Meteorological Service said that actually four of the five warmest years on record have all been in this decade, including the year the mean temperature hit the previous high of 27.6 C.
He pointed out that a lack of rain, and clouds induced by El Nino are driving temperatures here up.
And it is not just Singapore that is feeling the heat, the spokesman said.

Britain's Meteorological Office said last Thursday that the earth's temperature is set to hit its highest level this year since global records began in 1860, with the average temperature 0.43 degrees Celsius higher than the 1960 to 1991 average.

The El Nino phenomenon is caused by a warming in southern Pacific waters. It occurs with varying strength every two to seven years, lasts up to 18 months and affects weather patterns all over the world.
It last hit Singapore in 1994. This year, it contributed to the haze which affected the entire region.
The Meteorological Service spokesman said that the dry weather conditions are expected to last into the first half of next year as El Nino will peak around April before tapering off.
A return to near normal weather conditions is expected only in the second half of next year, he added.
While light northeast monsoon winds have begun to be felt, the total rainfall during the monsoon months (late November to the following March) is still expected to be below normal.
This has been the case for the last 11 months, which saw monthly rainfall at more than 80 percent below normal levels in four months: January, March, July and September.

DOC.HEADLINE: CLINTON SENDS LETTER TO US-TAIWAN BUSINESS CONFERENCE

TEXT.P: US President Bill Clinton has sent a letter to participants in the 21st annual joint business conference here of the ROC-USA Economic Council and US-ROC Business Council, commending them for their efforts to promote closer and expanding trade and business ties between the United States and Taiwan.

Clinton wrote: "The theme of your conference, 'Charting a New Course for US-Taiwan Business: New Game, New Rules, New opportunities,' reflects your awareness of the growing business opportunities for US companies as Taiwan liberalizes its trading regime, privatizes state enterprises and develops as a center for business in the Asia-Pacific region. We strongly support a greater role for American firms in Taiwan's development to help reduce our trade deficit and to stimulate ever closer economic and business ties.

"During my four visits to Taiwan, I saw for myself the economic miracle and democratic evolution that have occurred there -- important developments that have contributed to Taiwan's growing role in the international community. As you know, I have just returned from the very successful APEC Leaders Meeting in Vancouver, where we made further progress toward our shared vision of free trade in the Asia-Pacific region. Taiwan played a vital part in that meeting and is deeply involved in negotiations designed to overcome the final obstacles to entry into the World Trade Organization as a developed economy.

"As you meet to discuss past accomplishments and plan for the challenges of the coming year, I commend you for your efforts to promote closer and expanding trade and business ties between our two peoples. You are helping to build a brighter future for us all."

DOC.HEADLINE: JOHN CHANG VOWS TO REBUILD CONFIDENCE IN KMT

TEXT.P: John Chang, ROC vice premier and secretary general-designate of the ruling Kuomintang (KMT), on Wednesday vowed to rebuild public confidence in the party after its major setback in last week's local election of city mayors and county magistrates.

Chang made the remarks during a press conference after the KMT Central Standing Committee approved him to replace Wu Poh-hsiung, the outgoing secretary general who tendered his resignation on Saturday to take responsibility for the party's stunning election losses.
The KMT managed to win only eight out of 23 seats up for grabs, while the opposition Democratic Progressive Party (DPP) took 12 seats and the remaining three went to independent candidates.
Chang said that the party needs to rebuild confidence, stressing that the "fundamentals of the party are still good."

Chang also said that a period of party soul-searching is needed in the wake of the defeat, but emphasized that now is not the time for criticism or finger-pointing. Demands from some quarters that KMT Chairman Lee Teng-hui step down will not change the difficult plight the party is in, he pointed out.

Looking ahead, Chang said that the KMT is determined to walk out of the shadow of Saturday's humiliating defeat, and will actively prepare for next year's legislative elections, while at the same time injecting new blood into the grand old party.
He said that the KMT must present itself as a young, vibrant and hopeful party.

Vowing to mingle with the public to hear the true voice of the people, Chang said the party will be seeking to provide more services to women, youth, and minority groups, as well as continuing to push for party-to-party diplomacy.
He placed special emphasis on KMT efforts to attract Taiwan's youth, who he said have gradually turned their backs on the KMT in recent years in favor of other parties.
Chang, 55, who is to formally take over his new position on Friday, has previously served as the director general of the KMT's Department of Overseas Affairs and as ROC Minister of Foreign Affairs.

DOC.HEADLINE: KUEISHAN ISLET TO BE PARTIALLY OPENED FOR SIGHTSEEING

TEXT.P: The Ministry of National Defense has tentatively agreed to partially open the offshore Kueishan Islet for sightseeing trips, Ilan County Government sources said on Thursday.

The Defense Ministry demanded that the new opening measure should not affect the Republic of China's national security and that only a limited number of tourists be allowed to land on the scenic islet at designated locations during specified periods of time, the sources said.

The islet, also known as Turtle Mountain Islet for its turtle-shaped appearance, is located in the Pacific Ocean just nine nautical miles north of Toucheng Township, Ilan County, on Taiwan's northeast coast.

The highly protected islet is replete with natural scenery and resources, according to previous field surveys. Ecologists said the islet has more than 300 kinds of plants and a wide variety of birds. Its surrounding waters are also a fertile fishing ground. Even more special is that the islet has two rare inland lakes.
The islet was designated a military-controlled area in 1977, and troops have been stationed there ever since. Civilians have not been permitted to visit without permission from military authorities.

For years, the Ilan County Government has pushed the armed forces to open the islet for sightseeing purpose. In line with the government's liberalization policy, the Defense Ministry has recently agreed to allow visitors under certain conditions.

The Ilan County Government has formed a special task force to work out a comprehensive tourism resources development plan. Members of the team are scheduled to make an inspection visit to the Kueishan Islet in the near future.

According to a study by Professor Chung Wen-ching of Tunghai University, the islet can be opened to ecologists and students for research purposes. In addition, Chung said, a limited number of sightseers can also be allowed to make short-term visits to the islet.

The Ilan County Government said it plans to permit only two yachts, carrying a combined total of about 200 people, to tour the islet daily in the initial stage to avoid damaging its natural environment or affecting national security.

Legend has it that the Kueishan Islet was first inhabited during the reign of Emperor Hsienfeng in the Ching Dynasty (1644-1911). In 1888, Christian priest Mackay toured the islet and confirmed that there was a Han Chinese village there. The islet was put under the jurisdiction of the Ilan County Government following the end of Japanese colonial rule in 1945. Civilian residents were all relocated to Toucheng Township in 1977 when the military took control of the islet.

DOC.HEADLINE: TRADITIONAL RENAL REMEDY SAID TO SLOW OSTEOPOROSIS
DOC.DATELINE: Taichung, central Taiwan, Dec. 3 (CNA) (By Deborah Kuo)

TEXT.P: Osteoporosis, a progressive deterioration of bone mass that often accompanies old age, has been found by researchers at China Medical College (CMC) to be closely related to kidney vacuity syndrome, or kidney deficiency.

Detecting the close relationship of the two conditions through a series of clinical tests, doctors at CMC Hospital began to administer a newly developed kidney supplement to osteoporosis patients. They were amazed to find that the rate of bone-mass deterioration among patients was significantly slowed within a half-year after treatment began.

According to Chen Ya-ying, an internal medicine specialist at CMC Hospital, the kidney supplement, a compound of traditional kidney remedies and extracts designed to strengthen bone mass and bone structure, has been clinically proven effective in slowing osteoporosis, particularly among post-menopausal women aged over 50.

After taking the supplement for about six months, patients suffering from such afflictions as back pain, stiffness in the waist, weak knees and fatigue, showed considerable improvement. And it was also found that the loss of bone mass had slowed significantly, Chen noted.

Sophisticated meauring devices indicated that bone-mass density among patients who had taken the supplement for only six months had dropped 0.8 percent, as compared with an average annual drop of 2 percent to 6 percent among post-menopausal women in general, she said.

Chen said the supplement, currently administered in tablet form, is especially recommended for serious osteoporosis patients, breast cancer patients, women who suffer multiple kidney vacuity syndromes, and post-menopausal women who are unable to take estrogen, a widely used hormone that helps to maintain bone mass.

The supplement is also recommended to the general public, both men and women, since bone mass density of ordinary people begins to deteriorate by an average of 0.75 percent annually after they reach the age of 35 or 40, she added.

DOC.HEADLINE: FOUR WORKERS DIE IN BLAZE, INCLUDING THREE FILIPINOS

TEXT.P: Police on Thursday were investigating the cause of a fire which killed four female workers, including three Filipinos, at a plant in the Nantzu Export Processing Zone (NEPZ) in Kaohsiung, southern Taiwan, Wednesday night.

The four workers were identified as Chen Fu-mei, a native of Taiwan, and Mary Ann Bartocome, Filipina Mampata and Jahei Abello, all from the Philippines. The women were employees of Lite-On Automotive Corp.

Police said that more than 20 night-shift workers were on duty Wednesday evening at a facility owned by Lite-On, which specializes in manufacturing vehicle security systems and cruise control mechanisms. At around 8:10 p.m. the smell of smoke was detected and workers spotted flames on the third floor of the three-story building.

Lite-On officials said the 15-year company had 230 employees, among which 48 were Filipinos. Chen, who was working on the first floor of the facility, was apparently overcome by smoke inhalation while attempting to notify fellow employees on the second and third floors about the fire.

Firefighters put out the fire at 9:57 p.m. Lite-On officials estimated property losses at about NT$30 million (US$923,076). The plant will be unable to resume operations for a short period of time, they added.
The blaze was the most serious fire in several years at the NEPZ, which had celebrated its 31st anniversary on Wednesday.

Meanwhile, the Manila Economic and Cultural Office in Taipei said Thursday that it is still waiting for the final police report on the investigation into the cause of the fire before issuing a statement or filing a request for compensation on behalf of families of the deceased Filipino workers.

DOC.HEADLINE: US POLICY TOWARD TAIWAN TO REMAIN UNCHANGED: AIT CHAIRMAN
DOC.DATELINE: San Diego, Dec. 3 (CNA) (By Philip Liu and Sofia Wu)

TEXT.P: The US policy toward Taiwan will remain unchanged in the wake of a recent summit meeting between President Bill Clinton and mainland Chinese President Jiang Zemin, the top US liaison officer with Taiwan said here on Wednesday.

Speaking at a seminar on Taipei-Washington-Beijing trade and economic relations, American Institute in Taiwan (AIT) Chairman Richard Bush said the United States looks forward to establishing a constructive strategic partnership with mainland China.
However, Bush stressed, it is a long-term goal, not an existing reality.
He further explained that a strategic partnership is not tantamount to an alliance, not to mention a military alliance.
The partnership will only provide for foreign policy cooperation, Bush said. For example, the US must cooperate with mainland China in the four-way Korean Peninsula negotiations.
Anyway, Bush said, the proposed strategic partnership will be constructive and won't target any country.

Bush said President Clinton had taken advantage of his meeting with the top mainland leader to reaffirm his administration's "one China" policy under which the US will not support Taiwan independence. Clinton also called for an early resumption of dialogue across the Taiwan Strait to resolve their disputes peacefully and maintain stability in the region.
Bush said the Clinton administration has fully considered Taiwan's interests in its engagement with mainland China.
He further said the US government has made many efforts to let its Taiwan friends understand that there has been no change in the US policy toward Taiwan.

Turning to Taiwan's bid to join the World Trade Organization (WTO), Bush said the Clinton administration welcomes ROC Economics Minister Wang Chih-kang's planned visit to Washington, D.C., early next month for a new round WTO talks with relevant American officials. The US is one of the three WTO members which have yet to finalize bilateral talks with the Republic of China on its WTO accession terms.
Bush is currently in San Diego to attend the annual joint conference of the ROC-USA Economic Council and the US-ROC (Taiwan) Business Council being held here.
AIT was founded by American authorities in 1979 to handle relations with Taiwan in the absence of formal diplomatic ties.

DOC.HEADLINE: MAINLAND CHINA WILL BE MORE HEEDFUL OF DPP: SCHOLAR

TEXT.P: Mainland Chinese authorities, who have cast a watchful eye upon the Democratic Progressive Party (DPP) since its inception, will be more heedful of the pro-(Taiwan) independence party's conduct in the future, a mainland scholar said on Thursday.

Xin Qi, a fellow with the Beijing-based Peace and Development Research Center, said the Communist leadership will pay more attention to the DPP, now that its political strength has been greatly enhanced following a landslide victory in the Nov. 29 local elections across Taiwan. "But that does not mean mainland China's opposition to Taiwan independence will be changed," he noted.

In a commentary carried in Thursday's edition of the Hong Kong-based Wen Wei Po, Xin said the DPP's rising political power in Taiwan will by no means weaken Beijing's sovereignty claim over Taiwan or shake its determination to seek peaceful reunification between the two sides of the Taiwan Strait.

Xin, a cross-strait affairs expert who has visited Taiwan many times for academic research, said the Beijing authorities have kept themselves well informed of Taiwan's political environment, and they are well prepared to meet any circumstances arising across the Taiwan Strait.

In the article, headlined "It takes time for the DPP to become a ruling party," Xin said Beijing has noted the DPP's willingness to communicate with mainland Chinese authorities, its intention to work out a pragmatic mainland affairs policy, and its ambition to carve out a new explanation of its Taiwan independence platform.
Beijing cannot afford to ignore the DPP, in the hope that cross-strait relations will develop in a stable and peaceful manner, and that the goal of reunification can eventually be reached, Xin noted.
"The last thing we want to see is that the residents of Taiwan are subjected to a catastrophe resulting from causes that we all know very well," he concluded.

DOC.HEADLINE: TAIEX DELEGATION VISITING US
DOC.DATELINE: New York, Dec. 3 (CNA) (By J.J. Huang and Lilian Wu)

TEXT.P: With an ever-increasing influx of investors into the local stock market, a three-member delegation from the Taiwan Stock Exchange (Taiex) is currently in the United States to study measures in force to protect stockholders there.

Chen Li-ching, deputy director of the Taiex Trading Department, said here that Taiex has instituted a NT$1.03 billion (US$31.69 million) fund to protect investors in the local bourse. However, there are currently no laws in effect to ensure legal protection to stockholders.

She noted that Premier Vincent Siew formed a task force on financial reforms shortly after taking his post on Sept. 1, and that assuring the rights of investors through the implementation of relevant laws has been one of the top priorities for his Cabinet.

The Taiex delegation has visited the offices of Merrill Lynch & Co. and the New York Stock Exchange in recent days. It will fly next to Washington, DC, to visit the Securities Investor Protection Corp. (SIPC) on Thursday.

SIPC, founded in 1970, regularly monitors the financial situation of listed and over-the-counter companies. When symptoms of insolvency regarding a particular company are detected, the SIPC will request relevant information through the Securities Exchange Commission (SEC). If all indications point to a financial crisis, it will ask local courts to liquidate the company in question.
In such cases, small investors will be given first priority in the allocation of the failed company's assets.
The Taiex delegation will return to Taipei on Friday to report on its findings.
In the future, Taiex may send groups on similar missions to other financial hubs such as London and Tokyo, Chen said.

DOC.HEADLINE: KMT PERSONNEL CHANGES TO BE COMPLETED IN 2 WEEKS

TEXT.P: Tsai Pi-huang, director-general of the Kuomintang's Department of Cultural Affairs, said Thursday that personnel changes within the party should be completed in two weeks.
Tsai said that he has offered his resignation to KMT Secretary-General-designate John Chang, who will officially take over the post Friday.
Tsai said that "this would be the best time to go," though his departure will be up to his superiors.

The ruling KMT suffered a stunning defeat in Saturday's mayoral and county chief elections. The KMT only managed to take eight seats, while the opposition Democratic Progressive Party won 12 of the 23 posts up for grabs. The remaining three went to independent candidates.
Amid soul-searching by the KMT in the wake of Saturday's setback, the party's campaign strategy has come under particular fire from KMT members

Tsai admitted that the party's campaign lacked an effective strategy, saying that he tried to focus 90 percent of the campaign on the performance of the KMT, and the remaining 10 percent on attacking candidates from other parties. He said that because the media played up the 10 percent, the public was not fully attuned to the performance of the KMT.
Tsai said that he has expressed his intention to take a long leave or assume a different position, and stressed that he will fight for the KMT in whatever post.
Faced with such a major defeat at the polls, Tsai said that the KMT's most urgent task is to regain the voters' confidence in the party.

DOC.HEADLINE: OPPOSITION LAWMAKERS DIVIDED OVER CABINET RESHUFFLE

TEXT.P: Taiwan's two major opposition parties are divided over whether the Cabinet should be reshuffled after the ruling Kuomintang suffered a major setback in last weekend's nationwide mayoral and magistrate elections.
While the pro-(Taiwan) independence Democratic Progressive Party (DPP) sees no need for a Cabinet reshuffle, the pro-(China) unification New Party wants an immediate shakeup.

Lin Yu-fang, New Party whip in the Legislative Yuan, said he was disappointed by Premier Vincent Siew's announcement on Wednesday that he will not consider any personnel changes until a comprehensive year-end evaluation of each Cabinet member's performance is completed.

Lin said the KMT's embarrassing defeat in last Saturday's local elections for government chiefs was an unmistakable sign that the electorate is dissatisfied with the overall performance of Siew's Cabinet.

"Since local voters have used their ballots to signify their assessment of the Cabinet performance, I see no reason for Siew to hesitate in making a personnel reshuffle," the outspoken lawmaker stressed.

The KMT won only eight of the 23 top local government posts up for grabs in last Saturday's elections, while the DPP garnered 12 mayoral and county magistrate posts and the three remaining seats went to independents.

In addition to the election returns, Lin said, Siew can also refer to a series of recent public opinion polls to determine whether the performances of various government departments have met public expectations.
"For the well-being of all people, the New Party legislative caucus demands the premier make a major Cabinet reshuffle immediately," Lin insisted.
He also listed several criteria for Siew's reference in choosing new Cabinet members: accountability, professionalism and youthfulness.

Commenting on press reports that former Interior Minister Lin Feng-cheng may succeed John Chang as vice premier, Lin urged Siew to forsake such an idea. He pointed out that Lin Feng-cheng had stepped down from his post only a few months ago, in large part because law enforcement agencies under his ministry had failed to solve several high-profile criminal cases.

He said Justice Minister Liao Cheng-hao would be a much more suitable person to fill the position to be vacated by Chang, who has been tapped to replace Wu Poh-hsiung as KMT secretary-general. "Liao has spared no efforts to fight crime since assuming his post in 1996," Lin said.

On the other hand, Chen Ting-nan, DPP whip in the legislature, said the KMT's latest election rout had nothing to do with the government's administrative system. "My observation is that KMT Chairman Lee Teng-hui's obstinacy, intraparty infighting and lax party discipline were to blame for the party's defeat," Chen asserted.

"It is the KMT itself, not the Cabinet, that should undergo an internal reshuffle or restructuring," Chen said, adding that KMT party workers should not try to evade responsibility by blaming Cabinet ministers for the party's election flop.

Chen further pointed out that the DPP owned much of its electoral victory to the KMT's intraparty rifts. "DPP candidates would not have won in five cities or counties if rivaling factions within the KMT had not presented their own candidates in those constituencies," he observed, adding that the number of total ballots the DPP garnered in the elections increased only slightly more than 1 percent as compared with the similiar elections held four years ago.

Chen said the DPP headquarters should do its utmost to assist all newly elected DPP mayors and magistrates to overcome various difficulties and work out innovative strategies to resolve such chronic thorny problems as garbage disposal, traffic congestion and mounting violent crime. "Otherwise, the DPP would suffer setbacks in a series of elections to be held in the coming years."

DOC.HEADLINE: US DOLLAR DROPS

TEXT.P: The US dollar dipped NT$0.321 against the New Taiwan dollar on the Taipei foreign exchange market on Thursday, closing at NT$31.9.
The greenback opened at 32.151 and was traded between 31.67 and 32.155.
Interbank US dollar trading reached US$730 million.

DOC.HEADLINE: SHARE PRICES ROSE ON TAIEX

TEXT.P: Share prices skyrocketed on the Taiwan Stock Exchange on Thursday, with the weighted index, the market's key barometer, surging 147.62 points to close at 8,050.13.
The bourse opened at 8,003.87 and experienced a low of 7,919.4 and a high of 8,060.28.
Gainers outnumbered losers 357 to 43, with 78 stocks remaining unchanged. In all, 3.58 billion shares changed hands on a market turnover of NT$158.24 billion (US$4.9 billion).

Paper-making issues increased the most at 4.2 percent, followed by electrical engineering stocks at 3.5 percent, textile shares at 2.9 percent, foodstuff stocks at 1.8 percent, financial issues at 0.9 percent, and plastic/chemical shares and construction stocks at 0.8 percent, respectively.
Cement issues remained unchanged.

The 10 listed companies with the largest turnovers were Ever Fortune, Hualon-Teijran, China Steel, ACER, First Steamship, Pao Shiang Ind., China Petrochemical Dep. Corp., Far East Textile, and Pacific Electric Wire.

DOC.HEADLINE: TAIWAN'S FIVE-DAY WORKWEEK SYSTEM TO BE POSTPONED

TEXT.P: The proposed five-day workweek system, which the Republic of China government had proposed to fully implement by the year 2000, is likely to be postponed.

The legislative Committee for Organic Laws has passed an amendment to the governmental employees' services law, establishing a legal basis for the planned system. However, no exact date for full implementation of that practice was set in the amended law as a result of opposition to an earlier target date of Jan. 1, 2001.
One of the opposing voices was sounded by Schive Chi, vice chairman of the Council for Economic Planning and Development (CEPD), which has been charged with developing the five-day workweek system.

He explained that his council originally planned to put the system into full effect by the end of the year 2000, when Taiwan's per capita gross national product (GNP) is expected to reach US$20,000 from the current US$13,000. Attainment of that income level is regarded by the CEPD as a proper juncture for the island to allow employees two days off each workweek.
Nevertheless, the official said, it is now impossible to keep that timeframe as the eruption of the Southeast Asian financial crises in July has undermined the nation's economic progress.

The financial storm was not merely attributable to the New Taiwan dollar's depreciation, but also slowed down Taiwan's economic growth, which, according to the latest CEPD assessment, can now only be expected to reach 5.5 percent yearly. Thus, Taiwan's per capita GNP is unlikely to rise to US$20,000 by 2000, Schive said.
The CEPD estimates that Taiwan will probably only register a per capita GNP of approximately US$16,000 by Jan. 1, 2001, Schive noted.

The economics expert said he believes the government should work to implement the planned five-day workweek system on a gradual basis, with workers being given a day of rest on alternating Saturdays. He cited the case of Japan, a highly developed economy wherein it took 11 years to completely put the practice into effect.

To ensure that the island's economic growth continues on a stable track, Schive said he prefers to maintain the partial five-day workweek until Taiwan reaches the level of US$20,000 per capita GNP, irrespective of the original target date for full implementation of the system.

DOC.HEADLINE: ROC DOESN'T HOLD BACK FOREIGN BUSINESSES FROM M'LAND INVESTMENT

TEXT.P: The Republic of China's representative in the United States reassured businessmen Wednesday that the ROC's policies do not prevent foreign businesses in Taiwan from taking full advantage of opportunities arising in the mainland Chinese market.

"Our 'no haste, be patient' policy is directed only toward Taiwan businesses that might be considering investing very substantial amounts of capital in strategically important industries on the Chinese mainland. The policy is not a sanction against all Taiwan investment on the mainland. Rather, it is an effort to reduce the risks incurred by that investment," Stephen Chen, ROC Representative to the US, said while speaking at a seminar on US-ROC-mainland China economic and business relations.
"It is hard to be good trading partners when one side reserves the option of using violence against the other whenever it sees fit.

"When it comes to mainland China, we are compelled to put national security ahead of trade and investment on our list of priorities. Such vigilance would not be necessary if the PRC renounced the use of force against us and acknowledged our sovereign status in the international community. Until it does, we must judiciously manage our trade and investment with the mainland, so that the PRC cannot gain critical leverage over our economy, our well-being or our destiny."

Chen said that the government had "no choice but to take action" when it noticed that 40 percent of outward investment by Taiwan businesses in recent years had been directed toward mainland China and that the size of each investment project was growing larger and larger.

"This new policy is aimed not at preventing investment in the mainland but at monitoring and regulating it so that it better reflects the economic and political risks involved," he explained, noting that while the government discourages Taiwan businesses from investing heavily in infrastructure and heavy industry on the mainland, it places no restrictions on small and medium-sized investments.

"So far the policy seems to be working. While the total value of Taiwan investment in mainland China fell slightly between January and June of this year, the number of investments actually increased by 22 percent. In effect, Taiwan businesses are investing in mainland China at nearly the same rate as before, but their investments are more diffuse and thus less risky. In other words, we are avoiding putting all of our eggs into one basket."

Chen continued: "My government still believes that the major hurdle to greater interaction and eventual reunification between Taiwan and the mainland is the difference between the political systems and the ways of life of the two sides. Only by narrowing such differences can the two sides naturally reach reunification based on democracy, liberty and prosperity.

"The ROC government has been consistent in its mainland policy, with a strong desire to construct peaceful and stable cross-strait relations through exchanges and negotiations. This is why we are hoping for an early resumption of dialogue through private sector counterparts."

The US-ROC-mainland China Economic and Business Relations Seminar is one of 12 seminars of the 21st joint conference of the ROC-USA Economic Council and USA-ROC Business Council being held at the Hyatt Regency Hotel in San Diego. Speakers at the seminar also include Richard Bush, chairman and managing director of the American Institute in Taiwan.

DOC.HEADLINE: TAIWAN ACTIVELY TAKING PART IN WORLD DE-MINING MOVE
DOC.DATELINE: Ottawa, Dec. 3 (CNA) (By S.C. Chang & Debbie Kuo)

TEXT.P: Taiwan is welcome to take part in the Ottawa Process II, the non-governmental activities following this week's signing of a world convention against land mines by 125 governments, relevant Canadian officials said on Wednesday.

Although Taiwan may not have an opportunity to become a signatory of "The Convention on the Prohibition of the Use, Stockpiling, Production and Transfer of Anti-Personnel Mines and on Their Destruction," the officials said, pointing to unspecified political reasons, the island can contribute to related efforts, including by helping Cambodia and Afghanistan restore their economies and be swept clean of mines, and by aiding victims of the devices.

Delegates of two private organizations from Taiwan -- the Eden Social Welfare Foundation and the Anti-Land Mine Network of Taiwan -- are currently in Ottawa, waiting to take part in the non-governmental land mine action forum slated to kick off on Friday.

Lin Chin-chuan, head of the Eden Social Welfare Foundation, said his group began its efforts related to the world's land mines last year. The foundation launched a fund-raising drive in March, successfully collecting enough money to purchase 1,000 wheelchairs, which have already been distributed to mine victims in Afghanistan and Cambodia, he noted.
Lin, himself a wheelchair user, said his organization plans to raise enough funds next year to purchase 10,000 more wheelchairs, and that he will announce the plan in person to the Ottawa gathering.
Lin said he hopes that other Asian nations and areas will organize their own anti-mine societies to contribute their efforts in the region.

Meanwhile, he told CNA that his initiative to hold an international conference in Taiwan has received a favorable response from the delegates of many countries, including Belgium, Canada and Mozambique.

DOC.HEADLINE: ROC-JAPAN ECONOMIC CONFAB OPENS IN TOKYO
DOC.DATELINE: Tokyo, Dec. 4 (CNA) (By Mike Chang and Sofia Wu)

TEXT.P: The 22nd trade and economic cooperation conference between the Republic of China and Japan opened in Tokyo on Thursday, with the widening trade gap between the two countries as a major topic.

Addressing the opening session, Leijiro Hattori, chairman of the Japanese Interchange Association (JIA), said he admires the ROC government's proper measures in coping with the recent Asian financial crisis.
Hattori said two-way trade between the ROC and Japan totaled US$33.8 billion in the first 10 months of this year, down 1.3 percent from the same period of last year.

Due to a foot-and-mouth disease (FMD) epidemic that hit Taiwan's hog ranches in mid-March and a slowdown in the Japanese computer market, Taiwan's exports to Japan plunged 13.4 percent in the 10-month period, while Japan's shipments to Taiwan still managed to post a 4.8 percent gain.
Judging from the current trend, Hattori said, the total amount of this year's ROC-Japanese trade will be almost same as last year's.

Meanwhile, Hattori said Japanese enterprises invested a total of US$708.8 million in the January-October period, marking a nearly 80 percent year-on-year rise. The amount was also the highest since 1990.
Hattori said Japan will continue to promote trade and economic cooperation with the ROC in the years ahead.

For his part, Lin Chin-ching, chairman of the ROC's East Asian Relations Association (EARA), said he is delighted to see bilateral commercial exchanges continue to grow even after the two countries suspended formal diplomatic ties in 1972.
However, Lin expressed his regret over the fact that Japan still would not send ministerial-level officials to attend the annual bilateral economic conference.
Lin also expressed concern about Taiwan's swelling trade deficit with Japan, reaching US$14.05 billion in the January-October period.

Japan has banned imports of pork from FMD-stricken Taiwan since March, resulting in a substantial drop in the island's agricultural exports to Japan this year. Moreover, Japan's overall economic slowdown and a hike in its consumption tax have further hindered ROC exports to that country.
