Taiwan's trade deficit with Japan registered a 23 percent jump in the 10-month period, and the total imbalance could reach a record US$17 billion by year's end, Lin noted.

He said the issue has become a major concern in Taiwan. "We hope Japan will pay more heed to the issue and help the ROC expand its exports to the Japanese market by offering preferential tariff rates and lifting its import ban on Taiwan pork."
Lin also urged Japanese companies to invest more in Taiwan's capital- and technology-intensive industries for mutual benefits.

Lin headed a 19-member delegation of EARA and ROC government officials to attend the two-day meeting. In addition to JIA officials, several section chiefs and their deputies from Japan's Ministry of Foreign Affairs, Ministry of International Trade and Industry and Ministry of Agriculture were also present at Thursday's meeting. The agenda includes about 30 topics.
EARA and JIA are founded by their respective governments to handle bilateral exchanges in the absence of official ties.

DOC.HEADLINE: TAIWAN'S TOYOTA AGENT TO RECALL US-MADE 1997 CAMRYS

TEXT.P: Hotai Motor Co., the Taiwan importer of cars made by Japan's Toyota Motor Corp., announced Thursday that it has decided to recall all 7,096 US-made 1997 Toyota Camrys on the island due to a problem with the ignition lock.
The lock, technically the key interlock solenoid, sometimes allows the ignition key to be removed even when the car is not in park, according to a recent wire service report.

If left in neutral, the car can coast. If it is in drive or reverse, it can lurch upon starting, the report indicated, saying that all 280,000 1997 Toyota Camrys manufactured in the United States will be recalled.
A Hotai spokesman said that letters on the recall will be sent to local consumers on Dec. 18, while work on replacing the faulty devices with good ones will not start until Dec. 22.

The spokesman noted that although not all 1997 Camrys -- which were built between June 29, 1996 and July 31, 1997 -- have a defective ignition lock, his company still decided on a complete recall in order to assure safety.
Toyota said 27 customers had reported faulty locks and that these devices had resulted in six minor accidents but no injuries, according to the report.

DOC.HEADLINE: BRITISH GOVERNMENT EXPRESSES REGRET OVER ROC STUDENT MURDER
DOC.DATELINE: London, Dec. 3 (CNA) (By Nelson Chung and Sofia Wu)

TEXT.P: The British Foreign and Commonwealth Office (FCO) on Wednesday expressed regret over the murder in the northern English city of Manchester last month of a student from Taiwan.

David Coates, director of the FCO's Far Eastern and Pacific Department, also asked the ROC's representative office in London to convey condolences to the parents of Chang Chun-yu, 29, a doctoral candidate at Manchester University's Sciences and Engineering Institute, who was robbed and killed on the night of Nov. 22.
Coates said the FCO has demanded that the Manchester local authorities handle all the affairs relating to the murder in the proper manner.
In addition, Coates said, Manchester University has decided to confer a posthumous doctoral degree upon Chang and to set up a foundation in his memory.
The ROC representative office in Britain said it will keep a close watch on follow-up developments and will offer all the necessary assistance to Chang's family.

Manchester police authorities said all four suspects involved in the case have been arrested and charged with robbery and murder. Chang's body will be returned to his family in six weeks' time, in accordance with British law.

Although British law permits the victims of violent crime or their family members to demand compensation from the attackers, the four defendants are all described as penniless, which means it may be difficult for Chang's parents to obtain compensation from them.

A British fund for the victims of violent crime has already agreed to pay compensation of ten thousand pounds sterling to Chang's family, while the ROC representative office said it has decided to hire a lawyer to seek a higher amount.

DOC.HEADLINE: DIETARY GUIDELINES SAID CONFUSED AND CONTRADICTORY

TEXT.P: Dietary guidelines published around the world are confused, contradictory and may even be bad for many people, according to a new survey by the Associates for Research Into the Science of Enjoyment (ARISE) in Sydney.

The guidelines by the food faddists -- people dedicated to the elimination of fat and all other nasties from their diets -- are seemingly taking over the world and making people miserable, according to the survey.

The survey, published by mass-circulation newspaper The Australian on Thursday, showed the guidelines highlight some absurd differences between the recommendations on food and wine consumption in 21 countries.

The survey asks how Americans can be allowed seven to 14 eggs a week, yet Italians are told to have only two or three. And why is it safe for French and Italian women to consume more alcohol than Australian men?

The research shows Australian dietary standards recommend men consume a maximum of 20 standard drinks a week. This is more than the United States, Finland and Sweden, but far less than Denmark (25 drinks), Italy (28 drinks) and France (42 drinks).
Consumption levels for women are lower in all countries but authorities in France believe women can safely consume 25 standard drinks a week, five more than Australian men.

When it comes to eggs, the World Health Organization allows 10 eggs a week, the Australian Heart Foundation and official U.S. dietary guidelines recommend seven, but authorities in Germany suggest three or less.

The survey shows that salt is another ingredient that stimulates disagreement, with Germans recommending a maximum of 10 grams a day, the United States and the UK six grams, and Australia just 2.3 grams.

Dr. Dale Atrens of the University of Sydney said the scientific and medical communities were guilty of overstating the importance of diet to health and making people feel guilty over a glass of wine or a chocolate. "We are moving to this post-modern age of living in fear of some of the things which are really fun and good for us," he said. "We have become frightened of our own appetites," he added.

DOC.HEADLINE: AUSTRALIA SEES STRONG GDP GROWTH OFFSET BY ASIAN ECONOMIC CRISIS

TEXT.P: Australia's economy has picked up vigorously, with growth at an annualized rate of 6 percent in the six months to September, but Federal Treasurer Peter Costello admitted the strong recovery will be clipped by the recent economic crisis in Asia, particularly South Korea.

But worries over a slowdown in Australian exports to Asia, particularly to its second largest trading partner -- Korea -- sent the Australian currency down to 4-year lows because many believed Asian countries would reduce their imports from the country.
The Australian dollar on Wednesday closed at 67.51 US cents, down 0.20 US cents from Tuesday's closing level.
The gross domestic product grew by a faster than expected 1.5 percent in the third quarter of 1997, lifting the annual growth to 3.6 percent from 3.1 percent in the second quarter.

Economists said Australia's GDP growth during the past six months was 5.9 percent -- the fastest since 1993 -- and they believed the Reserve Bank of Australia would have to put on hold any official interest rate cuts in light of such high growth.
Costello said the strong showing would help the government to achieve its GDP growth target of 3.75 percent in fiscal 1997-98, which ends in June next year.
But he warned that the Australian economy could be affected by the recent Asian economic crisis in the next fiscal year starting July 1998.

"There will be an effect, particularly as a consequence of Korea," he said. "Korea is a very serious situation. A downturn in South Korea will have a more significant effect on Australian exports," he added.

Korea is the second largest trading partner for Australia, buying about A$7.1 billion worth of coal, iron ore, natural liquefied gas, and other products from Down Under between July 1996 and June 1997.

Costello attributed the strong growth to successive interest rate cuts between July 1996 and July 1997 during which the Reserve Bank of Australia reduced its official rate to 5 percent from 7.5 percent.
He said the growth lift reflected the delayed impact of cuts to interest rates by the central bank.
"The (interest rate) cuts in 1996 were, I think, just starting to come on stream at the end of 1997 and will be felt more so in 1998," he said.
Economists said whether the Australian GDP can grow beyond 4 percent in fiscal 1998-99 depends on how the recent Asian crisis will eventually affect Australia.

DOC.HEADLINE: US COMMERCE OFFICIAL SUPPORTS CONTINUED COOPERATION WITH TAIWAN

TEXT.P: Peter Hale, the United States acting deputy assistant secretary of commerce, said Wednesday that Taiwan has been at the forefront of Asia's phenomenal economic growth, which has created vast opportunities for US firms.

Speaking at the 21st Annual US-ROC Business Council and ROC-USA Economic Council, Hale said "in recognition of Taiwan's trade and commercial strength, the United States has actively supported Taiwan's participation in multilateral economic forums."

"In the early 1980s," he continued, "the United States helped Taiwan to continue its membership in the Asian Development Bank. In 1991, we helped Taiwan enter APEC, together with China and Hong Kong. Since 1992, we have been working for Taiwan's accession into the World Trade Organization."

On opportunities for trade and investment, Hale pointed out that Taiwan's successful transition to a more mature, competitive economy from the manufacture of simpler, labor-intensive goods to the production of more sophisticated capital- and technology-intensive goods has created a booming consumer and industrial market for a full range of goods and services.

"In its quest to reposition itself as a potential regional center for multinational business operations, Taiwan authorities have taken a number of steps to improve the investment climate, especially for service industries. Most ownership restrictions in the securities trading, insurance and banking industries for example have been removed. In its negotiations to enter the WTO as a developed economy, Taiwan has committed to bringing its trade and investment regimes into full compliance with international standards."

He said, "one of the key elements of our bilateral commercial relationship with Taiwan is the interest of US companies in participating in its extensive infrastructure development effort. With over US$100 billion in project expenditures anticipated over the next decade, US firms are eager to enter this market."

"Taiwan's efforts to privatize a number of sectors, most notably power generation and telecommunications, have also created potential opportunities for American companies. US firms have been selected to participate in seven independent power projects, although obtaining financing has been something of a problem. In the telecom area, consortia including US companies won four of the eight mobile phone licenses announced in January of this year.

"A number of our market access concerns with Taiwan, including in the agricultural area, are being handled through the process of WTO accession. The full range of trade issues has been under discussion: tariffs, nontariff measures, services, agriculture, intellectual property issues, investment measures, technical barriers to trade, government procurement and civil aircraft."

He also said, "Our two peoples continue to enjoy a long and prosperous association, I commend the U.S.-ROC and ROC-USA Business Councils for providing this invaluable forum for dialogue and commerce. Our mutual commitment to trade and international entrepreneurship has enabled both of us to benefit.

"I can assure you that the United States wants to continue our commercial engagement with Taiwan as it moves forward economically. Our firms stand ready with their world-class experience to assist Taiwan in achieving its economic goals."

DOC.HEADLINE: "MEET THE PRESS" HOST GETS CONTRACT EXTENSION

TEXT.P: Tim Russert will host NBC's "Meet the Press," which recently won the November sweeps crown for Sunday "issue shows" for the first time in 17 years, through the year 2004.

The 47-year-old Russert, who had a year remaining on his contract with the Peacock Network, has inked a new seven-year pact, giving the newsman an annual salary of seven figures, including bonuses and stock options, according to sources.
By 2004, Russert will have anchored "Meet the Press" for 13 years, longer than anyone in the history of the program.
"Meet the Press" has been on a roll. Since Russert took over in 1991, ratings have grown 50 percent, while the competitors' ratings have fallen.
The Sunday morning show generates US$25 million in profits for NBC, up from less than US$1 million in 1991.

DOC.HEADLINE: KEDO AND N. KOREA RESUME TALKS

TEXT.P: The Korean Peninsula Energy Development Organization (KEDO) and North Korea resumed talks in New York on Wednesday in search of a protocol concerning quality assurance and warranties in connection with the light-water reactor (LWR) project through which KEDO will supply two nuclear reactors to Pyongyang.
The talks, being held at the headquarters of KEDO in New York, are a continuation of an earlier round of discussions on this protocol which took place in North Korea last Nov. 4-11.
During the first round of discussions, both sides made progress and conducted their meetings in a businesslike and professional manner, an official of the KEDO said.
The LWR project has been in construction since last August when it officially broke ground for site preparation in Kumho, South Hamgyong Province, on the east coast of North Korea.

The KEDO delegation to the protocol talks consists of members of the organization's secretariat and representatives from KEDO's executive board member countries, including the United States, Japan, South Korea and the European Union.
KEDO was founded in 1995 for implementing most of the "Agreed Framework" signed by the United States and North Korea in 1994.

The Agreed Framework addresses international concerns about nuclear activities in North Korea. If implemented, it will assure both North Korea's full compliance on its safeguards agreement with the International Atomic Energy Agency and the complete dismantlement of those aspects of North Korea's nuclear program, including reprocessing-related facilities, that have undermined the viability of the international nuclear nonproliferation regime and the stability of the Asia-Pacific region.

DOC.HEADLINE: NEW JIANG, SAME OLD JINGLE

TEXT.P: Although mainland Chinese President Jiang Zemin has tried his best to burnish his image in the Western world, a Canadian journalist who "had the luck" to interview him last week says: "Don't be fooled."
Marcus Gee, international affairs columnist for The Globe and Mail, and two other colleagues were the first Canadian journalists ever to interview Jiang.

Gee, writing in the Wednesday edition of the Mail, said although Jiang has learned to flash a little leg while overseas, he remains "a doctrinaire Communist politician whose spoken views have not been changed a whit by his encounters with placard-waving Canadian protesters or noisy Canadian journalists."

Despite ardent courting by Western leaders, Canada's Prime Minister Jean Chretien in the lead, Beijing's tough line on political dissent has barely wavered since Jiang assumed the presidency in 1993, Gee emphasized. Thousands of mainland Chinese still languish behind bars for their political beliefs, he noted.

He pointed out that although life for most Chinese on the mainland is better, and freer, than it has been since 1949, "their government still denies them the most basic rights." "It struck me as we interviewed Mr. Jiang that no Chinese journalist (who was around) would be allowed to ask him even the polite questions we put to him," Gee added.

He saw a bit of communist sophistry worthy of Leonid Brezhnev when Jiang told an Ottawa press conference that mainland China's constitution already guarantees freedom of assembly, speech and demonstration. Like Brezhnev before him, Gee said, Jiang quickly added that those rights don't give people license to "create chaos."

In the views of Beijing's leaders, stability without democracy is better than democracy without stability. What they fail to see is that "the two are linked," Gee commented. His reason: A government that rests on the consensus of the governed is far more stable, in the end, than one that rests on the power of the gun.

The 1989 crackdown at Tiananmen Square only bottled up the dangerous discontents of mainland Chinese society, he pointed out. If Beijing keeps them bottled up, without any democratic release valve, it is far more likely that the mainland will return to chaos that all Chinese rightly fear, Gee said.
"Despite his cuddlier image," he concluded, "the new Jiang seems no closer to understand that than the old."

DOC.HEADLINE: TAIWAN TOURIST IN CRITICAL CONDITION

TEXT.P: A Taiwan tourist is in critical condition following falling into the sea just off the coast of Australia, the Ministry of Foreign Affairs (MOFA) said Thursday.
Officials with the ministry said that Yeh Hsiu-feng was with a 20-member group from Kaohsiung that was traveling to Cairns, in the northeast of Queensland.
The accident took place Tuesday when Yeh and the rest of her group were touring the Great Barrier Reef. She was rushed to a nearby hospital.
Yeh's brother left for Australia late Wednesday, the officials said.
The MOFA is providing all necessary assistance to Yeh's family, and will check on further details about the mishap, they said.

DOC.HEADLINE: BILATERAL TAIWAN-EUROPE TRADE RISING

TEXT.P: Two-way trade between Taiwan and Europe amounted to US$32.3 billion in the first 10 months of this year, according to statistics released on Thursday by the Board of Foreign Trade (BOFT).

According to the tallies, Taiwan exports to Europe rose by about 10 percent to US$14.9 billion in the January-October period, while European imports to Taiwan grew at a similar rate to US$17.4 billion in the same period, leaving Taiwan with a trade deficit of US$2.5 billion.

Germany has become Taiwan's top trading partner in Europe this year, accounting for about 20 percent of Taiwan's total two-way trade with the region, the statistics indicate. Holland, France, Britain and Italy, in that order, followed Germany in terms of bilateral trade volume.
Together, these countries were Taiwan's major export markets, as well as being Taiwan's main European source of imports, according to the tallies.

The statistics also show that Taiwan posted the largest growth rate -- 34 percent -- in exports to Ireland in the same 10-month period. The island's out-bound shipments to Britain and Portugal also grew by 15 percent and 14 percent, respectively, while the growth ratios posted with Holland, Denmark, Finland and Luxembourg all surpassed 10 percent.
Taiwan imports of machinery, electronics equipment, integrated circuits and mobile phones from Europe have all registered major growth since the beginning of the year.

DOC.HEADLINE: ROC STEPS UP FISHERY COOPERATION WITH PANAMA

TEXT.P: Jason C. Yuan, ambassador of the Republic of China, Wednesday presented a new fishermen-training ship to Panama on behalf of his government.
The 64-feet-long ship, equipped with modern fishing facilities, is able to accommodate 16 crew for 20 days in each training operation.

Taiwan and Panama signed a fishery technical cooperation agreement in 1974. Since then, Taiwan has helped Panama develop 18 fishing grounds, and train more than 2,000 fishermen with another training ship from Taiwan, which has just been discarded after 22 years of use.

The new ship was accepted by Panamanian Minister of Industry and Commerce Raul Arango on behalf of his government in a ceremony witnessed by President Ernesto Perez Balladares and other Panamanian officials.
The new 64-ton training boat was designed to train fishermen to catch high-value fish in the ocean. (by Edward Chen/Ed Hsieh)

DOC.HEADLINE: MAINLAND MEDIA UNDERGOING CHANGES DESPITE GOV'T CONTROL

TEXT.P: The news media of mainland China have been undergoing substantial changes in content and format since Beijing launched reform programs in 1979, although the government still controls the media with a heavy hand.
More than 90 journalists from the Chinese mainland, Hong Kong, Macao, and Taiwan have participated in a four-day seminar on journalism here, which ended Thursday.

In mainland China, it is still the responsibility of all mass media to report "positive news." Reporting "negative news," such as social violence or irregularities, may bring them trouble, not to mention criticism of the government and government officials, according to a mainland Chinese participant in the seminar.
He told CNA that, in mainland China, freedom of the press is totally overwhelmed by "media's social responsibility" and "national interests."
Despite tight government controls, the mass media of mainland China have grown substantially since 1978, he said.

The number of newspapers in mainland China increased from 186 in 1980 to 2,163 in 1997; radio stations increased from 93 in 1978 to 1,244 in 1996, and TV stations from 32 in 1978 to 872 in 1996. Their advertising revenue also jumped 580 percent from 1992 to 1996, according to the materials distributed at the seminar. But no exact amount of the ad revenue was given.
Financially, the news media had to completely rely on government subsidies before, and now advertising revenue has become one of the major financial resources of them, he added.
He pointed out that ideological materials and government propaganda have long made the contents of news media very boring, and the audience abhor them.
In order to woo the audience with a purpose to increase circulation and advertising income, the news media have gradually changed the content and format.

Take the newspaper for example, to the "positive news" they added economic news and many other news of human interest. In addition to regular issues, many of them publish various kinds of supplements. New formats have also been introduced in order to make their newspaper less prosaic, he said.
TV news always enjoy high rating, because it is the major source of information to the mainlanders, he added.
The mainland participant also said that Taiwan's news media are abusing their freedom of the press, causing damages to national image and to the whole society. (by Jorge Liu/Ed Hsieh)

DOC.HEADLINE: EVA AIR TO OPEN KAOHSIUNG-JAKARTA ROUTE

TEXT.P: EVA Airways Corporation announced on Wednesday that it will open twice-weekly direct passenger and cargo flights between Kaohsiung and the Indonesian city of Jakarta, beginning on Jan. 1, 1998, a local newspaper reported on Thursday.

The United Daily News, reported that according to EVA Air sources, the direct Kaohsiung-Jakarta flights of four hours and 45 minutes will better serve Jakarta-bound passengers from southern Taiwan, who will no longer have to travel via Chiang Kai-shek International Airport in northern Taiwan.
According to the newspaper, EVA Air will use Boeing 767-200 wide-bodied jets to fly the route every Tuesday and Thursday.

DOC.HEADLINE: HORMONE TREATMENT SHOWS RECOVERY OF LOST BONE MASS

TEXT.P: Hormone treatments given to transsexuals are revealing valuable medical information about the long-term effects of hormone replacement therapy (HRT) on women after menopause.
Studies on Singapore's transsexuals have helped to show that HRT results in replacing some of the loss in bone mass that usually occurs after menopause, something no other study has shown so far.
This was disclosed Wednesday in a lecture at the opening of the Ninth Congress of the ASEAN Federation of Endocrine Societies in Singapore.

Professor Victor Goh of the National University of Singapore talked about his study on 80 female transsexuals who had none or less than the recommended amount of hormones for about one to eight years after their sex change operations, in which their ovaries or testes were removed.
As a result, some had lost as much as 35 percent of their bone mass.

But when male hormone replacement therapy was restarted, he found that all were able to regain some of their bone mass by an average of 7 percent, and in one case, by as much as 15 percent, after about one and a half years.
The study was published this year in the international journal Maturitas.
Goh said that the studies using transsexuals had implications for both menopausal women and men with little or no testosterone.
After their sex-change operations, male and female transsexuals do not secrete any more sex hormones. They can be considered as being in a surgically-induced menopausal state, he said.
He also discussed the usefulness of the transsexual model in studying the direct effects of male and female hormones on cholesterol levels.

In another study published in the same journal last year, Goh confirmed what other studies have implied: that male hormones can raise the level of bad cholesterol, or LDL, and lower the level of good cholesterol, or HDL.

He found in a study of about 40 female transsexuals that after a year of male hormone therapy, their LDL levels were raised and HDL levels lowered. In a related study, he also found that the HDL levels went up and the LDL levels dropped in about 30 male transsexuals on long-term female hormone therapy.

DOC.HEADLINE: CHEN CHIN-HSING FACES FOUR DEATH SENTENCES

TEXT.P: Chen Chin-hsing, one of the country's most notorious criminals, is facing four death sentences, one life sentence and one jail term of 57 years for his role in a series of violent crimes that sent shock waves through Taiwan society earlier this year.

A prosecutor at Panchiao Prosecutors' Office said on Thursday that following an exhaustive investigation into Chen's alleged criminal activities, he has been indicted for abduction, murder, rape, robbery, infringement of personal freedom and interference with police duties.

Prosecutor Shih Liang-po said that the prosecutors' office is demanding four death penalties for Chen's alleged involvement in four abductions and murders, including the kidnap-murder of high school student Pai Hsiao-yen in April; the murder of plastic surgeon Fen Pao-fan, his wife and a nurse at Fen's clinic in October; the abduction of Taipei County councilor Tsai Ming-tung for a ransom of NT$5 million in June; and the kidnapping of businessman Chen Chau-yang for a ransom of NT$4 million in August.

For Chen's holding hostage the family of South African military attache Col. McGill Alexander in November, the first case of its kind in Taiwan, the prosecutors' office is seeking a life sentence, said Shih.

Chen is also being held responsible for at least 18 rape cases reported in Taipei over the course of the six months he was on the run after Pai's kidnap and murder, Shih said, adding that the rape cases, along with possession of firearms and attacks on police, have prompted the prosecutors' office to demand an additional jail term of 57 years.

DOC.HEADLINE: TAIPEI IS A SAFE PLACE TO LIVE: ENVOY

TEXT.P: Paraguayan Ambassador to the Republic of China Ceferino Adrian Valdez Peralta has said that he considers Taiwan still to be a safe place to live, despite recent crimes in Taipei involving foreign diplomats.
Generally speaking, Valdez said, Taipei is quite secure compared with other metropolises in the world.
He said that in Taipei, people wearing expensive jewelry can walk on the street without fear of being robbed, adding that his children walk to school and his wife jogs alone daily, without any fear.

The Paraguayan ambassador said he thinks the ROC government is doing all it can to protect foreign diplomats and foreigners in Taiwan, adding that the Taipei police have done a good job in providing protection for the Paraguayan Embassy and his family.

Meanwhile, Ting Yuan-chin, director general of the National Police Administration, said the police have strengthened their security services for diplomats in Taiwan. Security for foreign embassies, representative offices and the residences of their chief executives have also been reinforced, he said.

The taking hostage of the South African military attache and his family last month in their home by notorious kidnap-murderer Chen Chin-hsing, and recent burglaries of the homes of several officials of the Taipei office of the American Institute in Taiwan have worried many foreign diplomats, who say the security situation in Taiwan has worsened in recent months.

DOC.HEADLINE: DPP LEADERS' COMMENT TROBLES FOREIGN INVESTORS

TEXT.P: Two leaders of the major opposition Democratic Progressive Party (DPP) recently made remarks that troubled foreign investors in Taiwan.

DPP President Hsu Hsin-liang and Liao Yung-lai, magistrate-elect of Taichung County, said in a recent TV interview that the investment plan of Bayer Taiwan Co. to produce chemicals near Taichung Harbour in central Taiwan is subject to "national referendum." Bayer is a well-known German producer of chemical and other products.

The DPP, which won a landslide victory in last Saturday's local election and favored to win national elections in the next three years by some analysts, has advocated for adding a "national referendum" article to the Constitution.

The European Commerce Association in Taipei issued a statement Thursday, saying that the unprecedented demand has troubled many foreign investors, and that the government should clarify its policy on foreign investment in Taiwan, because the remarks of the DPP leaders have made foreign investors doubtful about the transparency of the policy.
A member of the association said the DPP's proposal to subject foreign investment plans to national referendum may scare away many foreign investors. (by Ed Hsieh)

DOC.HEADLINE: EGYPT AND QATAR NORMALIZE TIES

TEXT.P: Relations between Qatar and Egypt have returned to normal after Saudi Arabia's King Fahd, President Hosni Mubarak of Egypt and Sheikh Hamad bin Khalifah Al-Thani, the Emir of Qatar, held a meeting on Wednesday in Riyadh.
"The meeting, which was held in a cordial atmosphere, paved the way for reconciliation between Qatar and Egypt," a statement issued after the talks said.
Hamad and Mubarak expressed their appreciation for the successful efforts made by Fahd to reconcile the two countries.
The Qatari emir expressed his regrets over his country's sour relations with Egypt and thanked Fahd for taking the initiative to settle the dispute.

DOC.HEADLINE: BEIJING CONFIRMS TARIFF EXEMPTIONS

TEXT.P: Mainland China has confirmed that it will extend tariff exemptions on capital goods imports for some foreign-funded businesses, a measure intended to encourage flagging foreign investment, according to reports from the Geneva-based World Trade Organization (WTO) on Thursday.
The State Council, mainland China's cabinet, has decided to allow duty-free imports on capital goods and equipment for foreign-funded projects approved before March 31 last year, the WTO report said.
The exemptions will cover imports of equipment and materials considered part of an enterprise's investment.

The government in Beijing canceled the system of tariff exemptions from April last year, prompting strong opposition from foreign businesses in mainland China which faced as much as 40 percent increases in the cost of importing machinery and equipment.

The grace period for foreign-funded projects valued at less than US$30 million was to lapse at the end of this year and projects worth more than US$30 million were to receive the special treatment until the end of 1998.
Contracted foreign investment fell 38.8 percent in the first nine months of 1997 to US$34.2 billion, while actual foreign investment has grown, but at a slower pace than last year.
In the same January-September period, a total of 15,067 foreign investment projects were approved, down 19.9 percent compared with the year-earlier period.

The mainland Chinese government will reintroduce the tax breaks for foreign companies importing capital goods into the country, placing particular emphasis on high technology businesses, the WTO report added.

DOC.HEADLINE: GIO HEAD LEAVES FOR US VISIT

TEXT.P: Director-General of the Government Information Office David Lee left Taipei Thursday for New York on a week-long visit in the United States.
Lee told reporters at the Chiang Kai-shek International Airport that he was invited by the New York-based Asia Society and the Washington-based American Enterprise Institute to give a speech there.

He said he will also call at major US mass media, such as the New York times, Washington Post, the Wall Street Journal, the Times magazine, the Newsweek Magazine as well as be interviewed by the CNN and CBS to explain the ROC's foreign policy, its ties with the mainland China and the latest political situations in Taiwan.
Lee is slated to return on Dec. 11.

DOC.HEADLINE: NUMBER OF ABUSED CHILDREN ON RISE

TEXT.P: The Chinese Children's Fund announced on Thursday that it has handled a total of 5,151 cases involving abused children aged from newly born to 14 years over the past seven years, according to a report in Thursday's edition of the United Evening News.

The newspaper quoted a fund spokesman as saying that the number of abused children in Taiwan has been rapidly increasing in recent years, with the figure rising from 425 cases in 1990 to 967 cases in 1996.

According to the fund, 43.3 percent of the 5,151 abused children were seriously neglected by their parents, adversely affecting their mental and physical development and leading many to turn to a life of crime or vagrancy.
Some 40 percent suffered serious physical abuse and torture, including being burned by cigarettes, forced to eat excrement, or being beaten into unconsciousness or even to death, it added.

The most alarming finding, according to the fund, is the rapid increase in the number of cases of sexual abuse against children, adding that while it received reports of 40 cases of sexual abuse against children in 1990, the figure more than doubled, to reach around 100 last year.
Most of the cases were of children being violated by their fathers or male relatives, while some were raped by strangers on the street after running away from home, according to the report.

DOC.HEADLINE: TAIPEI CITY MAYOR DENIES HE WILL VISIT BEIJING

TEXT.P: Taipei City mayor Chen Shui-bian on Thursday denied that he is planning to visit Beijing in the wake of his Democratic Progressive Party (DPP)'s election victory in last Saturday's mayoral and county chief elections, when the party won more than half of the seats up for grabs.

The DPP mayor said that he will go to Beijing only if Beijing recognizes his status as Taipei City mayor, and only after the DPP has worked out a common front on mainland policy, adding also that of course the visit must be legal in terms of Taiwan law.

However, Chen said that the pro-independence DPP will neither shun the issue of mainland policy nor risk the lives and property of the people of the island by engaging with mainland China in an imprudent manner.

DOC.HEADLINE: 'SURVIVAL' TOPS ALL PRIORITIES IN CROSS-STRAIT RELATIONS: HUANG

TEXT.P: Ensuring the Republic of China's sustainable existence and continued development is the top priority in cross-strait relations, said Huang Kun-huei, secretary-general to the president, on Friday.

Huang, in a discussion held on the eve of the National Unification Council (NUC) conference, outlined the government's stance on cross-strait relations, saying that the ROC shall first seek to consolidate and secure its current position before further liberalizing its mainland policies.
Huang said Beijing has long schemed to "pressure the Taiwan government through the private sector," and "constrict Taiwan's political maneuverability through trade and commerce."

Beijing has also adopted a two-pronged approach toward Taiwan -- presenting a guise of goodwill to Taiwan residents, particularly the business community, on one hand, and stifling every pragmatic initiative within the international community on the other, Huang pointed out.

He stressed that in formulating mainland policy, the government cannot cater solely to the needs of particular groups, it must also uphold the interests of national security and the overall public welfare.
Until Beijing alters its fundamental attitude toward Taiwan, Huang noted, it is vitally important for the island to maintain its "no haste, be patient" policy toward mainland China.

Byron Weng, a member of the NUC Research Committee and a professor at the Chinese University of Hong Kong, proposed that authorities from the two sides of the Taiwan Strait jointly establish an official "Chinese Cross-Strait Joint Council" to promote mutual exchanges and cooperation.

Weng's proposal, however, was not favorably received by several of the committee members, who said the creation of such a body is premature and that the overall environment is not favorable at the present time.

Those members, who sided with Huang on the desirability of continuing the "no haste, be patient" approach, suggested the government define that policy more clearly so as to forge a greater consensus among the public.

DOC.HEADLINE: DPP DELEGATION TO LEAVE FOR US VISIT

TEXT.P: A high-profile delegation of the opposition Democratic Progressive Party (DPP) will leave for the United States on Saturday for a publicity tour.
The delegation will be headed by the party's outspoken chairman, Hsu Hsin-liang, and comprises several heavyweight party officials.
The visit has long been planned, but has drawn increased attention following the party's resounding win in last weekend's nationwide mayoral and county magistrate elections.
The delegation will visit New York, Washington, D.C. and Los Angeles to publicize the party's basic stances on major Taiwan-related issues.

During its stay in Washington, D.C. on Dec. 8-9, the group will meet with senior officials of the American Institute in Taiwan (AIT), which was founded by American authorities in 1979 to handle relations with the Republic of China in the absence of formal diplomatic ties.
AIT Chairman Richard Bush is expected to arrange for Hsu to meet with officials of the US State Department, the White House and the Defense Department. The levels of those officials remain unclear.

Local media quoted DPP sources as saying that the DPP delegates will exchange views with US officials on Taiwan's latest general political situation. They will also explain the party's stance on relations across the Taiwan Strait.
The sources said Hsu may meet with Stanley Roth, assistant secretary for East Asian & Pacific affairs, and other senior US officials in charge of East Asian affairs.
Meanwhile, Legislator Parris Chang, also a member of the delegation, will deliver a speech at Georgetown University on the pro-(Taiwan) independence party's blueprint for the future of Taiwan.

While in Washington, the delegation will also meet with senior executives of several noted American think tanks, and give a news conference at the Foreign Press Club. In addition, the group will take part in a call-in forum at the DPP's US East Coast Headquarters.
The delegation will also visit South Korea and Japan before its return to Taipei in the latter half of this month.
On the eve of the delegation's departure, several DPP lawmakers urged Hsu to exercise caution and self-restraint in his words and deeds during his US visit.
The lawmakers, including Shen Fu-hsiung, Lee Ying-yuan, Yen Chin-fu, Tsai Ming-hsien and Lin Tze-fu, made the appeal at a joint news conference held at the Legislative Yuan.

Hsu is known to support a "bold westward expedition" policy toward mainland China, which advocates further liberalization of investment on the mainland and opening of direct trade, mail and transport links across the Taiwan Strait.
The five DPP lawmakers urged the party chairman to abide by five principles, or "two wants and three no's," whenever touching upon cross-strait issues during his upcoming US visit.
They reminded Hsu that in the eyes of the Chinese Communists, Taiwan is a "renegade province," and that the People's Republic of China is a one-party, totalitarian country.

They also demanded that Hsu's remarks concerning cross-strait relations should avoid giving the international community the erroneous impression that cross-strait issues are exclusively Chinese internal matters.

The legislators further stressed that "China-related" statements made by any DPP members during the visit should only reflect their personal views and should not be interpreted as representing the party's formal stance.

Shen, a medical doctor turned lawmaker, said cross-strait relations are crucial to Taiwan's survival. "All local political parties should deal with the issue prudently," Shen said, adding that the DPP should first forge an internal consensus on the issue before taking any concrete steps to contact the Chinese Communist Party.
Shen further said the DPP should not rashly begin to conduct any party-to-party talks with the Chinese Communist Party before a specialized and informal dialogue mechanism is established.

DOC.HEADLINE: TAIWAN SAILOR STABBED TO DEATH IN SOUTH AFRICA

TEXT.P: A Taiwan sailor was killed by a drunken man on the streets of Cape Town, South Africa, the Republic of China Ministry of Foreign Affairs (MOFA) said Friday, adding that the suspect has turned himself in to South African police, who are handling the case.

The sailor, identified as Cheng Jung-chun, was the first mate on the "Hao Yi No. 212" fishing boat, which is currently anchored in the Cape Town harbor. Cheng reportedly left the vessel with a group of friends on Wednesday night.

In the early hours of Thursday morning, Cheng got into a heated argument on the street with a drunken local man, who stabbed and seriously wounded the Taiwan sailor. Cheng later died of his injuries after being rushed to a local hospital.

MOFA spokesman Y.Y. Wu told the press in Taipei that his ministry has received a report on the incident from the ROC's Consulate-General in Cape Town, adding that the consulate has been in contact with relevant South African law enforcement authorities on the status of the investigation.
Wu said the consulate-general will provide any assistance within its means to help Cheng's family members handle matters arising from his death.

He noted that Cheng's sister had been touring South Africa at the time of the unfortunate incident and that she hopes to be able to return to Taiwan with the sailor's cremated remains after all necessary procedures have been completed.

DOC.HEADLINE: LEGISLATOR CALLS FOR VIGILANCE AGAINST COMMUNIST INFILTRATION

TEXT.P: The Chinese communist regime has never ended the work of its secret agents in and against Taiwan even though private exchanges across the Taiwan Strait have been substantially liberalized, a legislator representing the Taiwan Independence Party (TAIP) said on Friday.

Speaking at a routine meeting of the national affairs forum held at the Legislative Yuan, Legislator Chen Wen-hui (TAIP-Miaoli) called for concerted efforts by the government and the private sector to ward off further Chinese communist infiltration.

Chen quoted two local dailies as reporting that more than 70 officers of mainland China's People's Liberation Army (PLA), some ranked as high as major-general, have snuck into Taiwan over the last two years to collect intelligence and conduct subversive activities.

PLA agents have infiltrated Taiwan through a myriad of means, including by disguising themselves as stowaways on fishing boats, mainlanders visiting relatives in Taiwan, or specialists and pundits coming to the island for cultural exchange programs, Chen said.

Mainland intelligence authorities have also set up a workshop for underworld figures who flee Taiwan for mainland China and irresponsible Taiwan businessmen and immigrants to turn them into mainland agents, Chen reported, noting that such turncoats can speak the Taiwanese dialect and not act like outsiders in Taiwan.

Taking the Hsinchu Science-based Industrial Park as an example, Chen noted that the flagship of Taiwan's high technology sector has been visited frequently by visitors from abroad, among them many from mainland China.

He urged companies in the park to beef up their security measures so as to prevent high-tech know-how and commercial secrets from being stolen, which he said could in turn jeopardize Taiwan's overall high-tech development in the future.

DOC.HEADLINE: SHARE PRICES UP ON TAIEX

TEXT.P: Share prices surged vigorously on the Taiwan Stock Exchange on Friday, with the weighted index, the market's key barometer, rising 116.74 points to close at 8,166.87.
The bourse opened at 8,175.19, and experienced a low of 8,121.9 and a high of 8,280.65.
Gainers outnumbered losers 346 to 94, with 39 stocks remaining unchanged. In all, 4.33 billion shares changed hands on a market turnover of NT$197.78 billion (US$6.18 billion).

Cement issues soared the most at 3.2 percent, followed by plastic and chemical stocks at 3 percent, textile shares at 2.6 percent, foodstuff stocks at 2.2 percent, construction issues at 1.6 percent, financial shares at 1.5 percent, electrical engineering stocks at 0.7 percent, and paper-making issues at 0.1 percent.

The 10 listed companies with the largest turnover were Hualon-Teijran, China Petrochemical Dep., Pacific Electric Wire, BES Engineering Corp., Winbond Electronics, United Micro Electronics, Walsin Lihwa, Taita Chemical, Yageo Corp., and A.S.E..

DOC.HEADLINE: CLA TO SUGGEST OPENING LABOR MARKET TO M'LANDERS AT PROPER TIME

TEXT.P: Hsu Chieh-kuei, chairman of the Council of Labor Affairs (CLA) of the Executive Yuan, remarked Friday that he supports opening Taiwan's labor market to mainland Chinese workers and will suggest this move at the proper time for the consent of the Mainland Affairs Council (MAC), a formal administrative agency under the supervision of the premier.
Hsu made the remark when he met with directors and supervisors of the General Chamber of Commerce (GCC) during a seminar between the CLA and GCC on a draft plan on laborers' pension regulations.
Some of the representatives of business enterprises proposed at the meeting that foreign labor not be restricted to originate in Southeast Asian countries but be expanded to include mainlanders.

Hsu was quoted as saying that he has not been opposed to the idea of introducing mainland labor into Taiwan, noting that since both sides of the Taiwan Strait use the same language, communication between both sides would be relatively easy. However, since the issue involves Taipei's policy toward Beijing, any such move should first acquire the consent of the MAC, stressed Hsu, adding that as soon as the MAC agrees, the CLA will undertake the plan accordingly.
Hsu indicated further that the CLA will suggest that the MAC open Taiwan's labor market to mainland workers when the time is right.

DOC.HEADLINE: PREMIER VICENT SIEW AUTHORS ARTICLE IN LSO ANGELES TIMES

TEXT.P: Premier Vincent Siew of the Republic of China said in an article published by Los Angeles Times Thursday that the people on Taiwan have worked hard for 50 years to avoid being put under communist rule, and that their rejection of communism should not be interpreted as an advocacy for "Taiwan independence."

Siew said in the article that "under the leadership of President Lee Teng-hui, we have successfully carried out a process of internal democratic reform. Today, we have developed into a fully liberated, vital open society."

Siew said "Today, Taiwan is the second largest source of external investment on the Chinese mainland. Every year residents of Taiwan make more than a million trips to the mainland for business and other purposes. Taipei and Beijing have already held 17 rounds of semi-official talks and signed several agreements."
"Unfortunately, what we have done in goodwill has only met with military intimidation, diplomatic suppression, and threatening invective from Beijing."

"The government and the 21 million people on Taiwan have labored hard for the past 50 years so as not to be absorbed into a communist system under the Hong Kong model," Siew said, adding that "Our rejection of the communist system is in no way tantamount to the advocacy of so-called 'Taiwan independence' or the establishment of 'two Chinas.'" "We simply prefer democracy and peaceful means of reunification," he stressed.
"China's reunification can be peacefully achieved only if both sides face the reality of a 'divided China' and embark on discussions on equal footing."

"In the long run, only a China unified under a democratic and open political system and integrated with the world is likely to bring happiness to its people and peace to its East Asian neighborhood," Siew added.

DOC.HEADLINE: CHICKEN EMBRYO HEARTS MAY PROVIDE HOPE FOR HEART ATTACK VICTIMS

TEXT.P: Chicken embryo hearts are likely to prove instrumental in enabling heart attack victims to avoid the need for transplants if pioneering Australian research is successful, according to mass-circulation newspaper The Australian on Friday.

The daily reported that, following a heart attack, human cells are destroyed and do not regenerate. But researchers at the Griffith University in Brisbane say they are hoping their work can eventually trigger a process whereby heart cells are reproduced.
They are looking at cell formations in the hearts of chicken embryos and seeking to isolate a gene which could help produce more cells.
They said the technique has far-reaching ramifications for heart attack victims who either require heart transplants, or in less serious cases, have to carry on with the permanent damage.

Dr. Wayne Murrell, the head of the research team, was quoted as saying that the genes in question will be located in the hearts of chicken embryos and mouse embryos before tests are performed on humans.
He said once the genes involved in the development of a chicken's heart have been isolated, they will be tested for their ability to direct other chicken cells to become heart cells.
"We have developed a molecular biology technique for identifying genes that are turned on when cells in the chicken embryo become heart cells," Murrell said.
"By developing an understanding of this molecular process, we could then use genes involved in the original process to manipulate other cells in a patient to form new heart cells," he added.

DOC.HEADLINE: ROC ECONOMICS OFFICIAL CHARTS STRATEGY FOR TAIWAN FIRMS IN US MARKET

TEXT.P: To compete favorably in the US market, Taiwan should consider three strategies, Republic of China Vice Minister of Economic Affairs Lin Yi-fu said at a joint conference of ROC-USA and USA-ROC Business Councils in San Diego on Thursday.

"In order for the ROC to compete favorably in the US market, there is a need for us to consider three strategies. We can increase investment within NAFTA, engage in strategic alliances with American firms, or else enter into a free trade zone with the US. We can of course do the first two while waiting for the third possibility to take shape," Lin noted.

He cited the example of a one Taiwan company which has taken advantage of the opportunities afforded by NAFTA. The Tuntex Group, a major industrial conglomerate, is planning to invest approximately US$600 million in Mexico, Lin said, adding that it has invited other major firms in the ROC's petrochemical and textile industries to join the project.
The Joint Conference of ROC-USA Economic Council and USA-ROC Business Council was held in San Diego, California, from Dec. 1-4.

DOC.HEADLINE: AUSTRALIA SUPPORTS RECRUITMENT OF SOLDIERS TO BUST STEVEDORE UNION

TEXT.P: The Australian government has expressed support for privately owned companies which are training Australian soldiers in Dubai to work as stevedores in an effort to break the maritime union's monopoly on the supply of wharf labor.

Defense Minister Ian McLachlan on Thursday told Parliament that 19 soldiers are being trained as waterfront workers in Dubai and said the government would support them as long as they are not breaking the law.

Defense sources told reporters the 19 soldiers had been granted approval by their commanders because they are on leave, in a country approved by the Defense Department, for training ahead of retirement at a later date.
Recruit organizer Mike Wells said the soldiers had been hired to work for an Asian company, but he said he would also be happy to provide wharf workers for Australian companies.

DOC.HEADLINE: GAMBLING SEEN CAUSING MORE BANKRUPTCIES IN AUSTRALIA

TEXT.P: Gambling is increasingly driving Australians broke, with a rise of over 50 percent in gambling-related bankruptcies in 1996-97, according to a new survey.
The survey by accounting house Deloitte Touche Tohmatsu shows bankruptcies due mainly to gambling have moved into the top 10 contributing factors in some instances.
The survey shows bankruptcies due to "gambling or speculation" rose 56 percent in 1996-97 financial year, compared with a 26 percent rise for all other bankruptcies.
A Deloitte spokesman said while the figures were coming off a low base -- up from 255 to 398 in a total of 21,830 cases -- a definite upward trend was appearing.
He said New South Wales residents were more likely to experience financial problems from gambling than were Queenslanders and Victorians.
"Gambling is a thing to watch," he said.

"While these figures are still low, there is an increasing upward trend. These figures could well underestimate the real problem because many people are embarrassed to admit gambling as a problem," he added.
"A high percentage of the 32 percent increase in nonbusiness bankruptcies relate to those who are unemployed or not earning an income," he said.
In 1997 alone, two large casino complexes were opened in Melbourne and Sydney and they are described as the biggest gambling dens in the Southern Hemisphere.
Altogether there is at least one casino in each major city in Australia, making a total of about 14 nationwide.
"Gambling was already a problem similar to those associated with alcohol and addiction," said Lucy Limbers of the St. Vincent de Paul Society.

"It is contributing factor to homelessness and family breakdown which we witness in the problems we deal with in our family refuges and homeless men's refuges. There is definitely a causal link and an increase in our workload," she added.

DOC.HEADLINE: SINGAPORE SIGNS ACCORD FOR RSAF TO TRAIN IN CANADA

TEXT.P: Singapore and Canada have signed a Memorandum of Understanding (MOU) allowing the Republic of Singapore Air Force (RSAF) to deploy aircraft, equipment and personnel to Canadian air bases for training, according to the Singapore Ministry of Defense.
The MOU also allows RSAF fighter, transport and artillery detachments to take part in multilateral exercises held in Canada.
Singapore's Air Force chief, Maj. Gen. Goh Yong Siang, and his Canadian counterpart, Lt. Gen. A.M. DeQuetteville, signed the MOU in Cold Lake, Alberta, Canada, on Tuesday, the Defense Ministry said.

It pointed out that the mutually beneficial arrangement with Canada is part of the RSAF's continuing efforts to expand its overseas training to help alleviate airspace constraints in Singapore and to gain experience from exercises with established air forces.

DOC.HEADLINE: SLOW GROWTH EXPECTED FOR REGION'S AIR TRAFFIC

TEXT.P: The ongoing currency and economic turmoil in Asia will slow the growth of air traffic and affect the purchase of new aircraft in the region, warned Dr. Cheong Choong Kong, deputy chairman and chief executive officer of Singapore Airlines.

But the devaluation of Asian currencies, which accompanied the crisis, has made these countries more competitive and attractive to tourists. It has boosted the region's exports and increased air cargo volumes, he told aerospace experts at Pulau Langkawi, Malaysia on Thursday.

Cheong was quoted as saying at the Langkawi International Maritime and Aerospace Exhibition: "Businesses and consumers are now poorer. Some are poorer and wiser, some simply poorer. Either way, it's reasonable to assume that there will be some slowdown in traffic growth in the immediate future, especially in intraregional travel."

But he was optimistic that the slowdown will be short in duration, and that growth would remain solid by international standards. This is because Asia, with its rising living standards and expanding international trade, will still be one of the fastest-growing aviation markets in the world, he said.

Cheong, however, acknowledged that the economic crisis would have an impact on purchases of new aircraft, particularly those by airlines which were cash-strapped, or were government-supported and had to compete with other national priorities for funding.
He said that airlines might turn to more cost-effective ways of acquiring new aircraft, such as leasing.

Another area which could suffer because of government cutbacks was investment in airport infrastructure. It was estimated last year that Asian countries would spend about US$150 billion on new or upgraded airports over the next 20 years.
Cheong said he hopes these projects will not fall prey to spending cuts because of the regional economic difficulties.

DOC.HEADLINE: ROCKETTES TO STAY AT RADIO CITY MUSIC HALL

TEXT.P: In a deal that secures the Rockettes and the Radio City Christmas Spectacular as fixtures on Manhattan's holiday calendar, Tishman Speyer Properties said Wednesday that it had leased Radio City Music Hall to the Cablevision Systems Corporation, which plans to renovate the famed Art Deco theater and use it for televised performances.
The agreement puts an end to speculation that the Rockettes and the Christmas pageant would be moved or put out of business.
Cablevision, which is also a co-owner of Madison Square Garden, said it planned to spend $25 million renovating the 65-year-old concert hall.

By agreeing to purchase rights to the Rockettes, a troupe that first performed as the Missouri Rockets in St. Louis before opening the Radio City Music Hall in 1932, Cablevision is giving new life to one of New York City's more enduring entertainment institutions. While the troupe is sometimes viewed by New Yorkers as an anachronism, the Rockettes continue to draw large crowds of tourists every holiday season.
Although precise terms were not disclosed, executives involved in the transaction said Cablevision had signed a 25-year lease on the hall for about $13 million a year.

James Dolan, the chief executive officer of Cablevision, said Wednesday that the transaction would provide opportunities to expand the company's broadcasting operations. In a partnership with NBC, the company already owns several cable networks, including American Movie Classics and Bravo, and holds a controlling interest in Madison Square Garden, the Knicks basketball team and the Rangers hockey franchise.

He said the television studio that the company planned to install in Radio City would be capable of broadcasting advanced high-definition television programs and would make the hall's stage a venue for more television programming.
