DOC.HEADLINE: PENGHU BANS SHELL FISHING TO SAVE CORAL

TEXT.P: The local government on Penghu (the Pescadores) on Friday announced a wholesale ban on the gathering of lithophaga, a saltwater shellfish, in an effort to save rift coral.

Lithophaga, a great delicacy in seafood restaurants both on the offshore islands of Penghu as well as on Taiwan, use rift coral as their habitat, sheltering themselves in the natural protection of coral trees, according to Chen Chao-lun, a researcher at Academia Sinica's Institute of Zoology.
The dark tea-colored shellfish exude a certain chemical similar to an acid to enable them to penetrate the skeleton of the rift coral and affix themselves there, Chen said.
In order to harvest lithophaga, Penghu shellfish gatherers smash the upper parts of the coral skeletons to reach the delicacy.

With demand increasing as a result of booming tourism on Penghu and seafood restaurants in Taiwan, harvesting of lithophaga has increased, resulting in catastrophic damage to coral, which is quickly diminishing in waters off Taiwan, according to Chen.

According to the ROC Coral Reef Association, the Taiwan area's coral population -- including rift coral, which grows mainly in shallow waters, and jewelry coral, which mostly lives in ocean waters between 600 and 3,000 meters deep -- is facing unprecedented damage as a result of myriad reasons, including over-fishing and environmental pollution.
If the trend isn't reversed, the association warned, the coral in waters near Taiwan will face extinction in 20 years.

DOC.HEADLINE: CROSS-STRAIT TRANSPORTATION SEMINAR TO OPEN IN TAIPEI

TEXT.P: Representatives from the shipping sectors of both Taiwan and mainland China will join in a seminar scheduled to open here Monday to discuss issues on transportation management, harbor management and norms and policies related to shipping matters.

According to the Ministry of Transportation and Communications (MOTC), the upcoming two-day seminar's participants will include members of mainland China's intermediary Association for Relations Across the Taiwan Strait and the mainland Ministry of Communications.
The meeting is expected to address practical matters related to business, an MOTC official said.

He added that a request for opening more mainland Chinese harbors for indirect shipping activities between Taiwan and the mainland is expected to be raised in the cross-strait seminar. Currently, mainland authorities only allow the mainland ports of Fuzhou and Xiamen to conduct cross-strait shipping matters.

DOC.HEADLINE: GOVERNMENT TO EASE TRADE EXCHANGES WITH OUTER MONGOLIA

TEXT.P: The Mongolian and Tibetan Affairs Commission (MTAC) on Friday agreed "in principle" to ease restriction on trade between Taiwan and Mongolia.

MTAC Chairman Kao Koong-lian said that in the future Taiwan businessmen need only apply for ordinary import permits for bringing in goods from Mongolia, and will no longer be bound by regulations governing imports from mainland China.

MTAC officials said the move was made out of pragmatic considerations, adding that the government will continue to regard Mongolia as a part of the national territory of the Republic of China politically, but will henceforth differentiate that area from the rest of the Chinese mainland in economic affairs.

The barriers governing imports from Mongolia will be significantly lowered, while investment proposals in Mongolia will be reviewed on a case-by-case basis, the officials said. They pointed out that the scale and range of such investments do not presently pose many impediments to local businessmen anyway, because of the low-level of Taiwan investment in Mongolia.
The MTAC convened a meeting with Taiwan entrepreneurs in early November, during which the businessmen urged the government to ease restrictions on trade exchange with Mongolia.
To gain more trade opportunities for Taiwan businessmen and to promote bilateral exchanges, the MTAC favored a less-restrictive trade policy toward Mongolia, commission officials said.
The officials added that they will not rule out signing a trade investment guarantee agreement with authorities in Ulan Bator to further protect the interests of Taiwan businessmen.

Kao noted that outer Mongolia has implemented a series of reforms since 1990, and that it has made tremendous progress in implementing political democracy and a free market economy, putting it in stark contrast with mainland China.

For several decades, the ROC government has considered Mongolia to be part of its national territory as a region of mainland China. Accordingly, economic activities with Mongolia by Taiwan businessmen have been regulated under the Statue Governing the Relations Between the People of the Taiwan Area and the Mainland Area, which was implemented on Sept. 18, 1992.

DOC.HEADLINE: GOVERNMENT SUPPORTS BAYER INVESTMENT PROJECT

TEXT.P: Vice Economic Affairs Minister Yiin Chii-ming said Friday that Bayer Taiwan Co. has applied to invest in Taiwan according to the law and that the government will give it full support.

Yiin was responding to remarks by Taichung County Magistrate-elect Liao Yung-lai, who made a campaign pledge to conduct a referendum to decide the fate of a proposed investment in a petrochemical plant in Taichung Harbor by the German conglomerate.
Liao's words have caused great concern at the European Council of Commerce and Trade, which has asked the government to explicitly express its stance.
Yiin said Bayer has applied to invest in the nation, and that the government supports any firm that invests in Taiwan according to the law here.

He said that there is no legal basis for the referendum. If the result of a referendum were to decide the fate of an investment project, this would set a bad example and damage the image of local government, he said.

Since businesses naturally assess risks and possible profits before making an investment, the government should provide a stable and predicable investment environment, Yiin said, adding that if a local government were to change that policy abruptly, it would hurt future foreign investment.

Bayer's NT$50 billion (US$1.53 billion) investment project in a plant in Taichung Harbor is scheduled to have a production capacity of 100,000 tons of TDI. The first stage of construction work has passed an environmental assessment, and Bayer and Taichung Harbor authorities are now discussing land rental.
An executive of Bayer said earlier in Hong Kong that the project is expected to start construction next year.

Local reports quoted Bayer President Horst Mueck as saying that the investment project has been approved by the ROC government and that he had not been told beforehand that the fate of a private investment should hinge on the result of a referendum. If Taichung County insists on such a move, Bayer will not rule out withdrawing its investment, Mueck said.

DOC.HEADLINE: KMT CHANGES GUARD

TEXT.P: The ruling Kuomintang (KMT) changed its general manager of day-to-day affairs on Friday, with John Chang, the only surviving son of the late President Chiang Ching-kuo, replacing Wu Poh-hsiung as party secretary general.
The changeover ceremony was presided over by President Lee Teng-hui, who concurrently serves as KMT chairman.
Speaking on the occasion, Lee expressed his hope that Chang will lead the party from under the shadow cast by the KMT's latest election rout and into an even brighter future for the party.

Lee praised Wu for his devoted service during his 16-month tenure as KMT secretary general. "Wu assumed his post at a time when the KMT faced rigorous challenges. With his sincerity, candidness, diligence and entrepreneurial spirit, Wu has managed to lead the party members in carrying out various KMT restructuring projects and faithfully implementing major party policies," Lee said.

"Although the KMT suffered a setback in the recent local elections, Wu's achievements in reforming the party apparatus are evident and significant," the president said, adding that he hopes Wu will continue to serve the country and the party as one of his senior advisers and as a member of the KMT's decision-making Central Standing Committee.
Lee went on to describe Chang's rich experience in party and government affairs, as well as his practical experience in electoral affairs.
"With his profound knowledge, exuberance and can-do spirit, I'm convinced that Chang will be able to lead the party in taking on all the challenges which lie ahead," he said.

In a stepping-down address, Wu said he remains a KMT stalwart, despite his departure from the secretary general post. He also apologized for his failure to help the party win more seats in last weekend's nationwide mayoral and county magistrate elections. "I earnestly hope that all party members will stand united and work vigorously for the party's resurgence," Wu said, adding that the KMT can no longer endure any intraparty schisms or factional infighting.

Speaking on the same occasion, Chang, who until Thursday served as vice premier, said KMT comrades should not be daunted by the recent election setbacks. "We should just pick ourselves up from where we fell," a spirited Chang said.

Chang, who quit his former post as minister of foreign affairs as recently as October to assume the vice premiership, said he feels honored to have the opportunity to serve as the party's secretary general. "Frankly speaking, I also feel a bit anxious because the new job also carries a heavy mantle of responsibility. I'll do my utmost to meet the party's expectations," he added.

Following the changeover ceremony, Chang immediately met with members of the media to explain his work plans. He said the KMT is a party which belongs to the people. "Although I was born in mainland China, I have lived in Taiwan for nearly 50 years," he said, adding that it's unfair to consider him unsuitable for the top KMT post simply because of his mainland origin.

Chang, who can speak Taiwanese and the Hakka dialect, said he will reach out to ordinary people to win their support for the KMT. Starting on Saturday, Chang said he will make extensive visits to constituencies around the island and on offshore islands such as Penghu, Kinmen and Matsu.

He said the KMT will reinforce its services to youth, women and under-privileged groups, as well as increasing contact with members of the middle class in order to understand their thinking, opinions and demands.

Chang also stressed the importance of interaction with opposition parties, underlined by a courtesy visit which he paid on Friday afternoon to Chiu Yi-jen, secretary general of the opposition Democratic Progressive Party, which won 12 of the 23 mayoral and magistrate posts up for grabs in last Saturday's elections.

Turning to press speculation of a party reshuffle, Chang said he will complete a shakeup of department chiefs at the KMT headquarters in one or two weeks. Local KMT branch chiefs in some cities or counties may also be reshuffled in the near future, he said.

Chang's challenges are set to begin immediately, as elections for city and county councils, as well as for township chiefs, will be held in January 1998. "I'll meet with grassroots party workers and community leaders in order to nominate the most suitable candidates and work out effective campaign strategies to win the upcoming elections," he added.

DOC.HEADLINE: TZU CHI CHAPTER IN AUSTRALIA HELPING BUSHFIRE VICTIMS

TEXT.P: Australia's chapter of the Taiwan-based Buddhidt Compassion Relief Tzu Chi Association will help those whose houses burned down because of the bushfires in a number of cities and towns in New South Wales.

Lin Hsin-yi, president of the local chapter of Tzu Chi, and other members of the Buddhist charity organization went Thursday to disaster investigation centers in Menai, a southern suburb of Sydney, to look at how they could help those left homeless by the fires that have raged since last week.
Altogether there have been almost 160 bushfires across New South Wales, 80 of them remaining uncontrolled with 20 growing more serious, influenced by strong winds and hot weather.
So far about 6,000 volunteer and professional firefighters are battling the bushfires, which have already burned down more than 400,000 hectares of forest in New South Wales.
In 1994, some 600,000 hectares of forest were destroyed and over 200 houses gutted in the same state.
So far in this year's fires, more than a dozen houses in New South Wales have been completely destroyed and scores of others partially damaged.
Two firefighters were killed this week and others suffered injuries.

Firefighters from Canberra went to New South Wales Friday to join in the rescue work, and police said between 8,000 and 10,000 volunteer and professional firefighters from other states are on standby in case the fires spread over the next three days.
Lin said he and other Tzu Chi members in Sydney would look at the seriousness of the needs of the bushfire victims so that the association could raise money to help them recover from their losses.
Lin and other Tzu Chi members dashed to the Snowy Mountains early this year when two resort hotels collapsed in a landslide, killing 19 Australians.
They provided beverages to hundreds of rescue workers and won lots of praise from Australian residents and police.

Tzu Chi established its Australian chapter in March this year, so far attracting more than 1,600 members, most of whom are immigrants from Taiwan now living in Sydney, Brisbane, Melbourne and other cities.

DOC.HEADLINE: US DOLLAR DROPS

TEXT.P: The US dollar dipped NT$0.15 against the New Taiwan dollar on the Taipei foreign exchange market on Friday, closing at NT$31.750.
The greenback opened at 31.935 and was traded between 31.740 and 31.935.
Interbank US dollar trading reached US$337 million.

DOC.HEADLINE: PETROLEUM PRICE HIKE TO HAVE LIMITED IMPACT ON CONSUMER PRICE INDEX

TEXT.P: A petroleum price hike of between 6 and 8 percent in mid-December will push up the consumer price index (CPI) by 0.3-0.4 percentage points at most, the Directorate General of Budget, Accounting & Statistics (DGBAS) said on Friday.

DGBAS department director Hsu Yiao-chang said that since oil consumption accounts for only about 2.2 percent of average household expenditure in Taiwan, even if petroleum prices are raised by 10 percent, the CPI will edge up by only 0.43 percentage points.

Hsu noted that the actual impact on the CPI caused by a petroleum price hike will probably be around 0.3-0.4 percentage points, because some business sectors will absorb the price increase themselves.

The state-run Chinese Petroleum Corp. announced on Tuesday that it will raise petroleum prices in mid-December to reflect increases in the cost of imported crude oil due to the sharp plunge of the New Taiwan dollar against the US dollar.
The CPC said that the actual size of the increase will be decided later this month, but has been initially estimated at between 6 and 8 percent.

DOC.HEADLINE: ROC GOVERNMENT COMPENSATES 42 `COMFORT WOMEN'

TEXT.P: After nearly 10 years of concerted efforts by local women's groups and socialites, Taiwan's 42 surviving "comfort women" have finally received some financial assistance from the Republic of China government.

The Ministry of Foreign Affairs on Friday paid NT$500,000 (US$15,873) to each of the women, who were forced into sexual slavery by the Japanese Imperial Army during World War II, in order to help improve their living conditions. The move became necessary because the Japanese government is still reluctant to compensate the women.

Vice Minister of Foreign Affairs Cheng Wen-hua said the ROC government will continue to push Japanese government authorities to compensate the surviving comfort women, adding that the Foreign Ministry will also urge the Japanese government to formally apologize for the sins of its predecessors.

The Taipei Women's Rescue Foundation (TWRF) said the ROC government has paid the money, totaling NT$21 million, with the object of improving the lives of the women and in order to discourage them from accepting "consolation money" offered by various private Japanese groups, which would be meaningless without an official government apology.

The foundation said that if the Japanese government makes a formal apology and compensates the comfort women in the future, each comfort woman will be expected to return NT$500,000 to the ROC national coffers.

Two former comfort women present at Friday's ceremony, both in their 70s, were moved to tears when they received their checks. "We are delighted and grateful for our government's care and generosity," they said emotionally.
One of them, identified only be her family name of Huang, said she was a lonely old woman who despised herself when TWRF workers contacted her for the first time some 10 years ago.
"I felt ashamed for being a wartime comfort woman. I never dared to tell my parents of my ordeal in Japanese military barracks in Southeast Asia during World War II," Huang said.
Ashamed of her past, she never married, and made her living by doing odd jobs.

Huang said she appreciates all the assistance TWRF workers have given to her over the past decade. "More important, they have helped me understand that it is not me, but the Japanese, who should feel ashamed for my ordeal."
Several female lawmakers, as well as executives of the Women's Rescue Foundation, were also present at Friday's ceremony.

The Japanese government set up a private Asian Women's Fund in 1995 that has offered to compensate each former comfort woman with 2 million Japanese yen for her suffering. Many of the women, including those in South Korea and the Philippines, have refused compensation unless it comes directly from the Japanese government.

DOC.HEADLINE: TAIPEI MAYOR OPPOSES COALITION CABINET WITH KMT

TEXT.P: Taipei Mayor Chen Shui-bian of the opposition Democratic Progressive Party (DPP) on Friday repeated his opposition to DPP Chairman Hsu Hsin-liang's proposal that the DPP could form a coalition government with the ruling Kuomintang (KMT).
Chen claimed that doing so would only enhance and prolong the KMT's status as the ruling party in Taiwan and stated his opposition to such a proposal.
Chen made the remarks in response to questions from reporters covering a seminar of elementary school principals from Taipei City.
The mayor said he could not believe that Hsu would make such a pessimistic suggestion so soon after the DPP's major victory in the recent mayoral and county magistrate elections.

Expressing the firm belief that the DPP will eventually become Taiwan's ruling party in the coming years, he stressed that forming a coalition government with the KMT will only hinder the DPP's efforts in this regard.

Chen called on Hsu to stop voicing such comments, in order to preserve the DPP's solidarity and morale and said that he would prefer to wait a little longer for the party to come to full power rather than forming a coalition with the KMT.
Hsu Hsin-liang said on Thursday that some outgoing DPP mayors and county chiefs would make good candidates for a coalition cabinet with the KMT.

DOC.HEADLINE: WORLD ABORIGINAL ART FESTIVAL TO BE HELD IN TAIWAN

TEXT.P: A "World Aboriginal Art and Culture Festival" will be held at the Chung Cheng Stadium in Hualien in eastern Taiwan on Dec. 7-8

Experts in aboriginal art and culture from Taiwan and 14 foreign countries will take part in the two-day festival. They include the United States, Japan, New Zealand, England, Guam, Israel, the Philippines, India, Canada, Spain, Nicaragua, Papua New Guinea, and Nauru.
An official of the " Committee of Original Residents" in Taipei said the festival is aimed at presenting aboriginal art and culture as valuable assets of mankind.
The festival is part of the "Aborigines Month" activities, which started on Nov. 15. (by Ed Hsieh)

DOC.HEADLINE: TAIWAN'S CONSUMER PRICES STABLE

TEXT.P: Hit by the New Taiwan dollar's depreciation, the general index for Taiwan's wholesale prices surged 4.06 percent to 111.01 in November from the October level, according to the Directorate General of Budget, Accounting and Statistics (DGBAS).

The new index also represents 5.28 percent growth, the highest amount since 1995, in comparison with the year-earlier-level, showed the DGBAS statistics on price fluctuations, which were released Friday. The agency attributed the high level to the surge in the prices of imported goods following the fall of the local currency.
However, the agency indicated that November's consumer price index registered 120.51, down a slight 0.26 percent from October, or 0.51 percent from the level of a year ago.
The results indicate the depreciation has yet to affect local consumer prices, the DGBAS analyzed, adding that Taiwan's consumer good prices remain stable.
As a result, the agency said the growth of consumer prices could be controlled within a range of 1.1 percent.

DOC.HEADLINE: CANADA HAS BEEN 'TOO SOFT' ON JIANG

TEXT.P: Two readers told The Globe and Mail on Friday that Canada has been too soft on mainland Chinese President Jiang Zemin during his recent visit.
Ronald R. Clark of Calgary said it is disturbing that Canada should honor the man, knowing "the government he heads is guilty of persistent, widespread and brutal abuses of people under its control."

Clark said the claim that increased trade influences Beijing to improve its human rights behavior "has no credit." He stressed that talk of "constructive engagement" and the like is a mere smoke screen, a rationalization for greed.
"That we in Canada should place our own material gain ahead of so much needless human suffering is, indeed, shameful," he concluded.
Another reader, Trevor Bartram of Toronto, criticized the Mail staff, saying they gave Jiang an easy time when he granted a rare interview with the Canadian media last Saturday.

"Too bad the only probing question in reaction to Mr. Jiang's vacuous responses was as to his dance styles. But not one of your staff chose to cross-examine Mr. Jiang on his hypocrisy as he remarked that 'the world is a colorful and diverse one' in his appeal for tolerance of the Chinese dictatorship," Bartram said.
He suggested that a question on Beijing's suppression of Tibetan culture and diversity would have been appropriate.

DOC.HEADLINE: CHANGES IN KMT RANKINGS CONFIRMED

TEXT.P: John Chang, former vice premier and the newly installed secretary general of the ruling Kuomintang (KMT), confirmed on Friday that there will be some changes in the high-ranking party positions.

Speaking at a luncheon meeting with the local press, Chang said he is still assessing possible changes in the KMT rankings, which will include directors general of the party's Departments of Cultural Affairs and Organization Affairs and the party's three vice chairmen, as well as the heads of some local headquarters.
The party's candidates for next year's mayoral elections in Taipei and Kaohsiung cities will also be decided soon, he noted.

Chang also said he will increase his contact with the general public in the future, revealing that he will visit Penghu on Saturday to inspect his party's grassroots operations on that offshore island and that he will travel to the cities of Keelung and Hsinchu a few days later.

Chang became the KMT's new secretary general on Friday, taking over the post from his predecessor Wu Poh-hsiung, who resigned to assume responsibility for the KMT's humiliating defeat in the recent mayoral and county magistrate elections at the hands of the main opposition Democratic Progressive Party.
The changeover ceremony was presided over by ROC President and KMT Chairman Lee Teng-hui.

DOC.HEADLINE: TAIWAN HAS A PLACE IN A NEW WORLD ORDER: PM SIEW

TEXT.P: The following is the full text of an article entitled "Taiwan Has a Place in a New World Order" by Republic of China Premier Vincent Siew, which appeared in Thursday's edition of the Los Angeles Times:
The Republic of China on Taiwan is evolving and ardently aspires to actively contribute to peace and stability in East Asia and the new world order of the 21st century.
As early as a decade ago, the government and people of Taiwan began making major adjustments in their actions and thinking.
Under the leadership of Lee Teng-hui, we have successfully carried out a process of internal democratic reform. Today, we have developed into a fully liberated, vital open society.

We also have decided to face the reality of "a divided China," and no longer claim to represent all of China. We believe that China should be unified in the future. However, at present and in the foreseeable future, neither Taipei nor Beijing can effectively govern all of China. Hence, there is no "one China, rather only "one divided China," of which the Republic of China is one part and the People's Republic of China the other. Neither part can thus represent the other, and neither side can represent all of China.
Finally, we believe that in this Post Cold War era, no country should be excluded from playing a part in the shaping of the new world order.

Prompted by these concepts, as early as 1991, president Lee unilaterally renounced the use of military force as a means to unify China. At the same time, he took the initiative to adopt a series of measures to expand people-to-people contacts between the two sides of the Taiwan Strait and launch semiofficial talks.

Today Taiwan is the second-largest source of external investment on the Chinese mainland. Every year residents of Taiwan make more than a million trips to the mainland for business and other purposes. Taipei and Beijing have already held 17 rounds of semiofficial talks and signed several agreements.

On many different occasions. President Lee has publicly expressed his willingness to make a "journey of peace" to the Chinese mainland. The government has also proposed many projects for bilateral cooperation, such as agricultural cooperation and an offshore transshipment center. Since the summer of 1995, we have continuously expressed our willingness to resume cross-strait talks.

Unfortunately, what we have done in goodwill has only met with military intimidation, diplomatic suppression and threatening invective from Beijing. As a member of the world community, we would certainly be pleased to participate in discussions on many major global issues such as trade, investment, human rights, crime, pollution, agriculture and telecommunications, We stand ready to offer our expertise and experience toward their solutions.
We also would be happy to see regional East Asian as well as bilateral issues resolved, but not at the expense of the legitimate rights of the 21 million people on Taiwan.

The government and the 21 million people on Taiwan have labored hard for the past 50 years so as not to be absorbed into a communist system under the Hong Kong model. Our rejection of the communist system is in no way tantamount to the advocacy of so called Taiwan independence or the establishment of "two Chinas," We simply prefer democracy and peaceful means of reunification.
China's reunification can be peacefully achieved only if both sides face the reality of a "divided China" and embark on discussions on equal footing.
In the long run, only a China unified under a democratic and open political system and integrated with the world is likely to bring happiness to its people and peace to its East Asia neighborhood.

DOC.HEADLINE: DPP DOES NOT WANT TO SEE KMT COLLAPSE: HSU

TEXT.P: Opposition Democratic Progress Party (DPP) chairman Hsu Hsin-liang said on Friday that his party doesn't wish for the collapse of the ruling Kuomintang (KMT), because only partisan politics will best serve the interests of the people of Taiwan.

Hsu, whose party scored a resounding victory in the just-concluded mayoral and county chief elections, said that it will not benefit Taiwan's democratic progress if the DPP overwhelms the other parties to become the only powerful party in Taiwan.

He said the DPP needs a healthy KMT as a competitor in the political arena, adding that a sound system of partisan politics should be established in Taiwan, with the DPP and KMT competing against each other on an equal footing in future political races.
In addition, Hsu said that the leaders of political parties should not just concentrate on pitting their forces against the other parties while neglecting the promotion of national unity.

Hsu was referring to local press reports regarding the possibility of cooperation between the DPP and the KMT, as he had earlier the week proposed a coalition cabinet formed by KMT and DPP members. A meeting between Hsu and Liu Tai-yin, who is in charge of KMT investment in various fields, following the plunge of the local bourse on Monday, also sparked speculation on such issue.

DOC.HEADLINE: HK MOVIE STAR IN CANADIAN TAX EVASION CASE

TEXT.P: Carol Cheng, affectionately known as Do Do, is in a tax fight with the Canadian government, three years after she left Canada to continue her entertainment career in Hong Kong.

The Globe and Mail reported on Friday that Canadian tax authorities claim Cheng, who lived in Canada from 1990 through 1993, owes the Canadian government C$2.6 million (US$1.8 million) in taxes on undeclared income from her "extensive activities in the Asian entertainment industry."
The Canadian government's claims apparently came as a surprise to Cheng, whose lawyer said his client has handled her financial affairs in keeping with her Canadian tax advisers.
Cheng, winner of the best actress and best supporting actress awards in the 1990 Hong Kong Film Festival, became a landed immigrant but returned to live permanently in Hong Kong in 1994.

DOC.HEADLINE: PREMIER BLAMES KMT'S ELECTION DEFEAT ON MULTIPLE NOMINATIONS

TEXT.P: Premier Vincent Siew, a member of the ruling Kuomintang (KMT) Central Standing Committee, on Thursday laid the blame for the party's election defeat on Nov. 29 on its policy of multiple nominations, which sees two KMT candidates in each of six constituencies slugging it out in public.

In a question-and-answer session after a speech to the Taipei Foreign Correspondents Club, the KMT premier blamed multiple nominations for tearing apart KMT grassroots support and playing into the hands of the opposition Democratic Progressive Party (DPP).

Multiple nominations are often the result of fierce intra-party competition for the chance to represent the KMT, in this case in the mayoral and county chief elections in which the KMT won only eight seats to the DPP's 12 out of a total of 23, the remaining three going to independent candidates.

It was the first time the premier had pointed a finger of blame at the reasons for the KMT's election debacle, and a very different view to that of another KMT heavyweight, Taiwan Provincial Governor James Soong, who blamed the defeat on the government's faulty policy-making process and its failure to act promptly on people's concerns.
Siew rejected the idea of organizing another national conference to build consensus among different political factions, saying that the time is not yet ripe for such a meeting.

He also described as "immature" the cross-strait "three direct links" -- trade, postal, and transportion -- which he said could be considered only after the island is allowed to join the World Trade Organization.

He refused to comment on a recent proposal initiated by a group of scholars for the establishment of an official "Chinese Cross-Strait Joint Council" aimed at bringing some momentum to the moribund cross-strait ties.
Instead, he called on Beijing to resume cross-strait dialogue without any preconditions.
Siew also reiterated the government's policy on mainland China, and its efforts to speed up its own streamlining.

DOC.HEADLINE: OVER 7,000 WOMEN RAPED IN LAST TEN YEARS

TEXT.P: More than 7,000 Taiwan women have reported being raped in a recent 10-year period, with adolescent girls representing the largest group of victims, according to a report from Taipei's Mackay Memorial Hospital.

Chen Ching-sung, director of the social services center at the hospital, cited an analysis based on official figures, which indicated that a total of 7,530 women were raped between 1984 and 1993, an average of more than 700 cases per year.
Teenage girls accounted for 40 percent of the total number of reported rapes, while women aged between 20 and 29 made up about 20 percent of the total, Chen said.
About 20 percent of the rapes were classed as "date rape," a figure which is rising, he noted, adding that sexual offenders are usually known to their victims.

A staffer at a Mackay emergency center dedicated to abused women lamented that many women are reluctant to undergo a physical examination immediately after being raped, which she said makes it difficult for them to provide evidence of rape if they decide to take court action. She added, however, that of those who do receive a hospital examination, about 70-80 percent will return for continued treatment to prevent pregnancy or infection by sexually transmitted diseases.

Although the hospital usually encourages rape victims to make a police report, the staffer pointed out that only 50-60 percent tend to do so, for fear of exposure. Statistics show that police authorities often fail to keep such cases confidential, causing the victims to suffer for a second time.

DOC.HEADLINE: MAINLAND CHINA URGED TO SPEED TARIFF CUTS

TEXT.P: The US and the European Union are urging mainland China to build on its latest diplomatic efforts to speed its admission to the World Trade Organization (WTO) by committing itself firmly to faster and deeper tariff cuts, according to reports from the Geneva-based world trade regulatory body on Friday.

Mainland China outlined proposals for a new approach to its WTO application to the US last week. These have been welcomed by President Bill Clinton who told mainland China's President Jiang Zemin that they provide the basis for intensified negotiations.

Sir Leon Brittan, EU trade commissioner, called Beijing's initiative a "major step forward" which showed real commitment to the long-stalled membership talks. He claimed the offer was modeled on negotiating principles which he proposed to Beijing in October.

Western officials said mainland China appears to be taking a more constructive stance in response to recent moves by the US and EU to close ranks in the negotiations, after a long period in which they were often openly at odds, according to the WTO report.

Although the full contents of Beijing's offer have not been disclosed, it is understood to center on a formula which provides for a more comprehensive and systematic approach to negotiating tariff cuts on imports of industrial products.

The formula appears intended to respond to western complaints that mainland China's previous tariff offers in the WTO talks have involved piecemeal reductions, which left many of its highest import duties intact.

EU negotiators said mainland China's proposals could have a decisive impact on its WTO application if Beijing quickly turns them into a firm and detailed timetable for sharp reductions in tariffs on a wide range of specified imports.
The US and EU are pressing mainland China to cut tariffs on many industrial products to no more than 5 percent by early next century and to phase out tariff-quotas on imports by fixed dates.

Negotiators in Geneva say successful completion of the talks also depends on mainland China agreeing to accelerate the removal of other important trade barriers, in particular in areas such as agriculture, services, distribution and subsidies.

DOC.HEADLINE: EDITORS NOTE:

TEXT.P: Premier Vincent Siew of the Republic of China said in an article published by Los Angeles Times Thursday that the people on Taiwan have worked hard for 50 years to avoid being put under communist rule, and that their rejection of communism should not be interpreted as an advocacy for "Taiwan independence."

Siew said in the article that "under the leadership of President Lee Teng-hui, we have successfully carried out a process of internal democratic reform. Today, we have developed into a fully liberated, vital open society."

Siew said "Today, Taiwan is the second largest source of external investment on the Chinese mainland. Every year residents of Taiwan make more than a million trips to the mainland for business and other purposes. Taipei and Beijing have already held 17 rounds of semi-official talks and signed several agreements."
"Unfortunately, what we have done in goodwill has only met with military intimidation, diplomatic suppression, and threatening invective from Beijing."

"The government and the 21 million people on Taiwan have labored hard for the past 50 years so as not to be absorbed into a communist system under the Hong Kong model," Siew said, adding that "Our rejection of the communist system is in no way tantamount to the advocacy of so-called 'Taiwan independence' or the establishment of 'two Chinas.'" "We simply prefer democracy and peaceful means of reunification," he stressed.
"China's reunification can be peacefully achieved only if both sides face the reality of a 'divided China' and embark on discussions on equal footing."

"In the long run, only a China unified under a democratic and open political system and integrated with the world is likely to bring happiness to its people and peace to its East Asian neighborhood," Siew added.

DOC.HEADLINE: DPP URGED TO MAP OUT ITS OWN MAINLAND POLICY

TEXT.P: Shaw Yu-ming, a researcher at the Council for National Unification, said Friday that the major opposition Democratic Progressive Party (DPP) should produce its own policy toward mainland China.

The pro-independence party won a landslide victory last Saturday in local elections, and is expected to win national elections in the next three years by some analysts. Mainland Chinese officials have said that it would not be possible for Beijing to develop good relations with the DPP, if it continues to advocate for Taiwan independence.

Shaw made the remarks after he delivered a speech on cross-strait relations at the Legislative Yuan. He told the press after the speech that the DPP should face up to mainland problems and map out its own policy toward mainland China.
The ruling Kuomintang and DPP should reach a concensus on cross-strait relations, he added. (by Ed Hsieh)

DOC.HEADLINE: HSU CLARIFIES DPP STANCE ON REFERENDUM ON BAYER INVESTMENT PROJECT

TEXT.P: Hsu Hsin-liang, chairman of the opposition Democratic Progress Party (DPP), on Friday met with executives of Bayer Taiwan Co., to clarify the party's stance on a referendum which may decide the fate of Bayer's latest investment project in central Taiwan.

Chen Chai-chung, vice president of Bayer's Taiwan office, described the meeting with Hsu and Sisy Chen, director of the DPP's publicity department, as "positive and well-intentioned," and that he feels Hsu has shown sincerity in trying to communicate with him on the issue.

Hsu told him that the DPP has no bias against Bayer's investment project and understands that the withdrawal of Bayer's investment will have an impact on further foreign investment in Taiwan, Chen said.

Liao Yung-lai, DPP magistrate-elect of Taichung County, has said in public on several occasions that Bayer's investment plan for a chemical manufacturing plant near Taichung Harbor will be subject to a referendum held in the county. Liao's remarks have aroused concern and uncertainty among foreign investors.

A statement issued by the European Council of Commerce and Trade in Taipei expressed the foreign investors' uneasiness over the DPP's unprecedented move, demanding that the government clarify its policy on foreign investment in Taiwan.

According to Chen, the DPP's publicity department is to gain a better understanding of the referendum issue proposed by Liao, and the DPP will hold a public hearing on Bayer's investment project with scholars, experts, Bayer officials and representatives from an "anti-Bayer league" taking part.

Chen said that he is still optimistic about the investment project, which has been approved by the government and has passed evaluations on its impact on the environment. However, construction work cannot start until they obtain the land lease, Chen noted.

The first stage of construction work, originally slated for last year, will take two-and-a-half years to complete, with the investment value reaching NT$10 billion (US$3.15 billion), Chen said, adding that the total investment value in the three-stage project is estimated at NT$50 billion.

DOC.HEADLINE: DPP LEADERS' DEMAND TROUBLES MORE FOREIGN INVESTORS

TEXT.P: The demand of Taiwan's major opposition party leaders to subject a German investment plan to "national referendum" has troubled American investors.

Hsu Hsin-liang, president of the Democratic Progressive Party (DPP), and Liao Yung-lai, DPP magistrate-elect of Taichung County, said in a recent TV interview that the investment plan of Bayer Taiwan Co. to produce chemicals near Taichung Harbour in central Taiwan is subject to "national referendum." Bayer is a well-known German producer of chemical and other products.

The DPP, which won a landslide victory in last Saturday's local elections and is expected to win national elections in the next three years by some analysts, has advocated for adding a "national referendum" article to the Constitution.

A spokesman for the American Chamber of Commerce in Taipei said Friday that many American investors have called his office to express their concern about the remarks of the DPP leaders, and that his office will continue to pay attention to this matter.

The European Council of Commerce and Trade in Taipei issued a statement Thursday, saying that the unprecedented demand by DPP has troubled many European investors, and that the government should clarify its policy on foreign investment in Taiwan, because the remarks of the DPP leaders have made foreign investors doubtful about the transparency of the policy. (by Ed Hsieh)

DOC.HEADLINE: TIBETAN DIRECTOR VOWS TO BOOST TIES BETWEEN TIBET AND TAIWAN

TEXT.P: Kesang Takla, director of a proposed Tibet religious foundation here, said on Saturday that her main task will be to promote Tibetan Buddhism and culture, as well as to increase mutual understanding between the people of Taiwan and Tibet.

Takla, 53, who served for more than eight years as representative to the office of the Dalai Lama in London before assuming her new job in Taiwan, arrived here in late November with her husband Phuntsok Takla and secretary Kunga Tashi.

Takla said that before she came to Taiwan, she traveled to Dharamsala, India, seat of the Tibetan government-in-exile, to meet with the Dalai Lama, Tibet's spiritual leader, to receive advice and guidance regarding her new post.
She said the Dalai Lama instructed her to promote the traditional culture of Tibet, as well as boost bilateral ties and deepen understanding between the people of Taiwan and the people of Tibet.

Asked about specific ways she intends to promote Tibetan religion and culture here, she said that in view of the keen interest in Taiwan of the preaching of the Dalai Lama when he visited Taiwan in March, she would first arrange for religious teachers to come here, adding that other activities will follow as the foundation gathers pace.

Although she has only been here for a week, Takla said she already feels keenly the friendliness and hospitality of the people here. She is currently looking for a suitable office location, to be named "The Tibet Religious Foundation of his Holiness the Dalai Lama."
The Tibetan government-in-exile has now set up offices in the United States, Britain, France, Switzerland, Hungary, Mexico, Australia, Japan, Nepal, India and South Africa, she said.
