DOC.HEADLINE: ROC TO OFFER 14-DAY VISA-FREE ENTRY FOR ITALIANS
DOC.DATELINE: Rome, Dec. 5 (CNA) (By Oscar Chung and Sofia Wu)

TEXT.P: The Republic of China is to offer 14-day visa-free entry for Italian passport-holders from Jan. 1, 1998, the ROC representative office in Italy announced on Friday.
The new measure is to reciprocate Italy's friendly move in offering "Schengen Agreement" privileges to ROC nationals, a spokesman for the representative office said.

Italy began to implement the Schengen Agreement in late October, under which visitors with a valid visa issued by any signatory can visit any of the other member-countries. In addition to Italy, seven other European countries -- France, Germany, Spain, Portugal, the Netherlands, Belgium and Luxembourg -- have also implemented the travel liberalization accord.

Although Italy maintains formal diplomatic ties with mainland China, it hasn't offered the privileges to people from the Chinese mainland or Hong Kong, which reverted to mainland rule on July 1, 1997.

The spokesman said Italian people who intend to stay in Taiwan for more than 14 days for commercial, study or any other purposes still have to apply for landing visas upon their arrival at Taiwan's Chiang Kai-shek International Airport or file visa applications with the ROC representative office in Italy.
Despite the fact that the ROC offers landing visas to Italians, the ROC representative office in Rome still received more than 1,400 applications over the past three months.
Many Italian business people hailed the ROC's new visa-free measure, saying it will facilitate their business visits to Taiwan and thus help boost bilateral trade.

The ROC representative office said the new measure is expected to help attract more Italian tourists and business people to Taiwan, although it will cause the office's revenues from visa services to decline.

DOC.HEADLINE: CROSS-STRAIT SECURITY SEMINAR TO OPEN IN NEW YORK
DOC.DATELINE: New York, Dec. 5 (CNA) (By David Wang & Elizabeth Hsu)

TEXT.P: An academic seminar on cross-Taiwan Strait security problems will be held here on Saturday.

A group under Taiwan's main opposition Democratic Progressive Party is sponsoring the one-day seminar, to which a number of experts and scholars have been invited, including Hsie Shu-yuan, an expert in defense affairs; Steven F. Miller, director of Harvard University's international security science college; and Robert Henderson, an expert in military strategy in the Canadian government.
These experts in the field of regional and national defense affairs will deliver speeches on the cross-strait security issue, which plays an important role in the maintenance of global stability.

In addition, legislators Trong Chai and Lin Cho-fu from Taiwan will also take part in the seminar, and will deliver their views on cross-strait security. Chai is a former politics professor in the United States.

DOC.HEADLINE: MAINLAND CHINESE TRADE OFFICIALS TO VISIT TAIWAN

TEXT.P: A mission from the Beijing-based China Council for the Promotion of International Trade (CCPIT) is scheduled to arrive in Taipei on Monday for a 10-day visit, sources from the China External Trade Development Council (CETRA) reported on Saturday.

The mission, to be headed by CCPIT Vice Chairman An Chengxin, is coming to the island at the invitation of CETRA. CCPIT, a private organization, and its Taiwan counterpart, CETRA, have developed cordial bilateral exchanges over the last two years.
CCPIT Chairman Guo Dongpo visited Taipei last year, when he met with CETRA officials and agreed that the two trade councils should exchange visits on a regular basis.

During their stay, the mainland Chinese trade officials will meet with their Taipei CETRA counterparts, as well as representatives of the Chinese National Federation of Industries, Tatung Co., and several other leading private enterprise.
CCPIT, mainland China's leading trade promotion organization, maintains branches in 42 provinces and cities, and heads 13 trade societies and associations in different industries around the mainland.

DOC.HEADLINE: HK ADVISOR CONFIRMS HE VISITED TAIWAN LAST MONTH
DOC.DATELINE: Hong Kong, Dec. 6 (CNA) (By Jorge Liu & Maubo Chang)

TEXT.P: Paul Yip Kwok-wah, the Hong Kong chief executive's advisor responsible for contact with Taiwan confirmed on Friday that he visited Taipei in November.
Yip stressed to CNA, however, that it was a private visit for a "reunion with friends" and had no official purpose.
"If I went there for business, how could (Taiwan's representative to Hong Kong) Cheng An-kuo stay here rather than coming along with me?" Yip asked CNA.

Local press reports had said that Yip, on the instruction of Hong Kong Chief Executive Tung Chee-hwa, met with Taiwan officials, including Chairman of the Mainland Affairs Council (MAC) Chang King-yuh, and Secretary General of the Straits Exchange Foundation Chiao Jen-ho, to discuss issues concerning both Taiwan and Hong Kong.

During the alleged meeting, the reports said, Yip had politely refused Taipei's demands for 72-hour landing-visas for Taiwan travelers, saying "it is difficult" and "the time is not yet ripe," while the MAC dodged his counter demand for cutting the red tape surrounding Hong Kong people's applications for Taiwan visas, saying "it needs thorough study."
Yip denied the allegations.

Responding to Taiwan's complaints about Hong Kong's troublesome visa application procedure for Taiwan passengers, Yip said the existing regime suits the current situation existing between mainland China and Taiwan.

"Taipei should understand that the issue hinges on the whole cross-strait situation rather than on a decision by one or two people in Hong Kong. The special administration government is not supposed to take measures which are out-of-step with the general political trend prevailing across the Taiwan Strait," Yip said.

Regarding Taiwan's demands for Hong Kong to institutionalize its contact channels with Taiwan rather than conducting contacts through a relatively low-level advisor who holds no official position in the government, Yip said he doubted an official capacity would help his work. On the contrary, he said, his unofficial status allows him free contact with Cheng and facilitates the exchange of views between Taiwan and Hong Kong.

DOC.HEADLINE: PHYSICALLY-CHALLENGED JUDGE WORKS HIS WAY UP
DOC.DATELINE: Hualien, eastern Taiwan, Dec. 6 (CNA) (By Deborah Kuo)

TEXT.P: A young law student, lame in his left leg, who was barred 14 years ago from being a judge because of his physical handicap, even though he passed Taiwan's bar examination, has today worked his way up to the position of chief justice after years of hard work and perseverance.
Chuang Ming-chang, 43, was sworn in as the chief justice of the Hualien District Court on Friday, making him the first chief justice in Taiwan who is physically challenged.
Chuang said he was happy to return to the eastern coastal city of Hualien, where he took his first public service job after passing the bar examination so many years ago.
Before being promoted to a chief justice, Chuang had served as a judge in district courts of Taoyuan and Panchiao.

Fourteen years ago, Chuang and three other handicapped men passed the annual bar examination. However, the fact that they were handicapped meant that they were discriminated against by the authorities, who refused to dispatch the four to judge-training centers.
Insisting that they were entitled to equal work opportunities under the ROC Constitution, the quartet refused to succumb to this discrimination, and fought for their rights.
After two years of appeals and fighting by the strong-willed men, the judiciary authorities finally agreed to let them join the public prosecutor apprenticeship program.

During their apprenticeships, the quartet proved that their handicaps did not affect their work, and they were later dispatched to district prosecutors offices in Hualien, Chiayi, Taoyuan and Ilan, respectively, to work as alternate public prosecutors.

Chuang, born into a farming family in rural Nantou county, central Taiwan, became a victim of infantile paralysis during his childhood. The disease affected both of his legs and he was on the verge of becoming totally crippled.
To save her son from losing the use of his legs, Chuang's mother pawned all the family's valuables in order to buy medicine.
Luckily, Chuang's right leg was spared from the disease and he was able to walk with the aid of a crutch. As medical equipment has improved over the years, Chuang's handicap is now barely noticeable.
Chuang attributed his achievements today to his mother's bravery and strong will, saying that "mother's love is the force behind my perseverance."

Chuang is a hard worker. He passed the national land administration examination in his freshman year at Fu Jen Catholic University and managed to pass the court clerk exam in his junior year, finally passing the judges exam in 1983 at the age of 28.

DOC.HEADLINE: TAIPEI LIAISON OFFICE IN HK TO OFFER SPEEDY VISA SERVICES

TEXT.P: To better serve Taiwan-bound visitors from Hong Kong and Macau, the Chung Hwa Travel Service, Taipei's de facto liaison office in Hong Kong, has decided speed up visa services beginning Jan. 1, 1998.

According to Cheng An-kuo, Taipei representative in Hong Kong and head of the Chung Hwa Travel Service, the new service will enable Hong Kong and Macau residents to obtain their entry and exit papers to and from Taiwan within one week, much faster than under the previous procedure which required three to four weeks.

Because of limited staff, the liaison office will set a daily quota on the number of applicants, Cheng noted, adding that the exact number of visas to be processed each day and the amount of the fee for the service have yet to be finalized.
Currently, the office receives about 600 to 700 applicants daily for entry and exit visas to and from Taiwan filed by Hong Kong and Macau residents, according to Cheng.

DOC.HEADLINE: RESULT OF LOCAL ELECTION NO STRAIN ON CROSS-STRAIT TIES: GIO HEAD
DOC.DATELINE: New York, Dec. 5 (CNA) (By K. C. Huang and Lilian Wu)

TEXT.P: Although the ruling Kuomintang suffered a major setback in the Nov. 29 local elections, the results should not strain relations between the two sides of the Taiwan Strait, government spokesman David Lee said in a televised interview with the Cable News Network (CNN) on Friday.

Lee, the director-general of the Government Information Office, said the victory of the pro-independence opposition Democratic Progressive Party should not be interpreted as a public referendum on the fate of the nation.

He stressed that the polls were local elections for city and county chiefs, and that the campaign issues centered on local topics. Thus, Lee said, the victory of the DPP should in no way cause raised tensions across the Taiwan Strait.
The KMT managed to win only eight of 23 seats up for grabs, while the DPP won 12, and the remaining three went to the independents.
Despite the opposition victory, Lee asserted that most people on Taiwan favor maintaining the status quo.

The four-minute interview was conducted in New York and aired Friday night to audience in Asia. After the CNN interview, Lee called on the offices of Newsweek and Time magazines, and the New York Times and Wall Street Journal newspapers.
He later spoke on current Taiwan issues at the Asia Society.

Lee left Taipei for New York on Thursday. He said the main purpose of his trip was to brief major US media on recent developments in Taiwan, including the elections last week, Taiwan's social order situation and its approach and strategy to coping with the financial crisis in Southeast Asia.

He reiterated that the local elections will have no impact on relations with Beijing because the topics at issue centered on social order, environmental protection, corruption, and the personalities and performances of the incumbent local chiefs. Lee said those matters are far removed from the questions of mainland policy and cross-strait relations.

The government spokesman said that Taiwan has been largely unaffected by the fallout stemming from the recent financial crisis which swept through Southeast Asia because of its good economic fundamentals, sound currency policy and lively stock market.

Lee said that the US media appeared to be most concerned about the implications for cross-trait relations wrought by the local election results, and were also interested in the current status of cross-strait ties.
Lee reiterated the government's desire to resume dialogue with Beijing at an early date in order to solve technical problems involving the two sides across the Taiwan Strait.
He is slated to return to Taipei Dec. 11 after a hectic week-long tour of the United States.

DOC.HEADLINE: TAIPEI MAYOR STANDS GOOD CHANCE OF REELECTION: POLL

TEXT.P: More than 60 percent of local university students believe that incumbent Taipei Mayor Chen Shui-bian will be reelected next year, according to the results of a recent opinion poll released on Saturday.

The survey of more than 1,300 university students around the island also found that Chen, a heavyweight in Taiwan's pro-independence opposition Democratic Progressive Party (DPP), is the most-favored candidate for the Taipei mayorship.

According to the survey, 61.6 percent of those interviewed said they believe Chen will be reelected Taipei mayor in 1998, while 20.6 percent said former Justice Minister Ma Ying-jeou could be elected as the city's next mayor.

Taiwan Governor James Soong (6.3 percent), newly installed Kuomintang Secretary General John Chang (1.2 percent) and New Party Secretary General Wang Chien-hsien (1.1 percent) trailed Ma as possibles in Taipei's next mayoral race.
The poll results show that Chen has successfully cultivated a "strongman" image among local university students since assuming office some three years ago.
Chen topped the questionnaire's list of 15 noted politicians from the three major local political parties in many of the personal characteristics reviewed.
In the eyes of the respondents, Chen is a man with "grit, vision, charisma and administrative know-how," according to the survey results.

The poll also shows that a majority of the respondents consider Chen as "most willing to undertake sweeping reforms, assume political responsibility, fight against evil forces and deliver campaign promises."
However, Chen lagged behind Ma, now a law professor at National Chengchi University, in four respects: clean image, amiability, steadiness and sex appeal, according to the survey.
Ma resigned from his cabinet post as a minister-without-portfolio earlier this year after declining a KMT offer to nominate him to run in next year's Taipei mayoral election.
The survey was conducted jointly by the Chinese Culture Association, the ROC Industry and Commerce Management Association and the business management department of National Chunghsing University.

Analyzing the poll results, Fan Kuang-ling, president of the Chinese Culture Association, said Ma could still be Chen's strongest potential rival in the next Taipei mayoral election should he decide to stage a political comeback, even though the Harvard-trained professor is currently out of political arena.

The survey also found that Wu Poh-hsiung, who just stepped down from the KMT secretary general post to assume responsibility for the party's defeat in last weekend's nationwide mayoral and county magistrate elections, was rated by local students as "most capable of communicating with his superior."

DOC.HEADLINE: MAC HEAD URGES BEIJING TO PROMOTE CROSS-STRAIT EXCHANGES

TEXT.P: Mainland Affairs Council (MAC) Chairman Chang King-yuh on Saturday urged Beijing to step up exchanges with Taipei based on the principles of mutual respect and equality.
Chang made the appeal during a review of cross-strait relations over the past year at a meeting of the National Unification Council on Saturday.

Chang said the disruption of regular cross-strait dialogue has damaged mutual trust, deepened the rivalry across the Taiwan Strait and delivered a major setback to beneficial exchanges between the two sides.
Beijing unilaterally suspended talks with Taipei in protest at a visit by Republic of China President Lee Teng-hui to the United States in June 1995.

Chang also said mainland China has increased its diplomatic pressure on Taiwan by using its political and economic clout to blackmail members of the international community, some of whom have even gone so far as to accuse the ROC of "provocation" in its attempts to break out of the isolation imposed by Beijing, he added.
Chang said most people in Taiwan hope that Beijing and Taipei will resume talks soon, in order to avoid a further deterioration of cross-strait relations.

Chang suggested putting political differences aside and focusing on technical problems arising from exchanges between the two shores of the Taiwan Strait. This will help create a harmonious atmosphere favorable to building a broader cross-strait consensus.

DOC.HEADLINE: BEIJING NOT TO EMPHASIZE DIFFERENCES NOR CORDIAL WITH DPP
DOC.DATELINE: Beijing, Dec. 6 (CNA) (By Wang Chung-hsin & Eva Chen)

TEXT.P: Following a brief remark on Monday about Taiwan's local elections, the Beijing-based Taiwan Affairs Office under the State Council commented on Friday about the US trip by Taiwan's Democratic Progressive Party (DPP) Chairman Hsu Hsin-liang.

Beijing's brain-trust on Taiwan affairs confessed that the response to Hsu's US trip is part of an "immunization" process whereby Beijing intends neither to emphasize its differences with the pro-(Taiwan) independence DPP, nor to meet with or be cordial to its leadership.

Since winning a majority of seats up for grabs in local elections across Taiwan late last month, the DPP has expressly stated that there is "no problem" in its relations with the Chinese mainland. However, the situation has attracted international attention, noted political observers in Beijing who are familiar with Taiwan affairs.
Therefore, the observers said, Beijing must be prudent in its remarks regarding the election outcome and its attitude toward the DPP.

In comments made on Monday, the Taiwan Affairs Office information department mentioned only "developments in cross-strait relations, and opposition to Taiwan independence." In Friday's statement, however, Beijing raised its voice in suggesting it would prevent Taiwan from declaring independence if necessary.
According to those familiar with the mentality of the Beijing leadership, such remarks are an indication Beijing is readjusting its stance in accordance with the new political environment in Taiwan.
Analysts noted that Beijing apparently does not want to convey the impression to the international community that it will tolerate the DPP's pro-independence platform.

DOC.HEADLINE: TOP AGRICULTURAL OFFICIALS REMOVED

TEXT.P: A group former and currently serving senior-level agricultural officials have been removed from office on charges of negligence stemming from the disastrous outbreak of foot-and-mouth disease that struck Taiwan hog farms in March this year.
The Judicial Yuan's Committee on the Discipline of Public Functionaries handed down the penalties on Friday, marking the harshest punishment meted out to public officeholders in recent decades.

Chiu Mau-ying, former chairman of the Council of Agriculture (COA), Taiwan's top agency in charge of agriculture, fisheries, forestry, husbandry and related affairs, was dismissed from his current post as board chairman of the Central Trust of China. He also had his right to hold public office suspended for one year.

Chiu is currently in Los Angeles attending the joint conference of the ROC-USA and USA-ROC Economic Councils. He expressed dismay upon hearing the news by telephone and said he will cut short his US trip and return to Taipei in order to learn more details surrounding the surprise development.
Liu Pei-bo, director of the Taiwan Research Institute for Animal Health, was also dismissed from his current position and had his public functionary accreditation suspended for one year.

Upon being informed of the penalty, Chen Wu-hsiung, agriculture and forestry commissioner of the Taiwan Provincial Government, who himself was on reprimand list, said the punishment dealt to Liu was "shocking and unacceptable."

Chen said that when confronted with the devastating outbreak of the foot-and-mouth epidemic, all relevant agencies, none of which had experience in handling such a crisis, had tried to prevent the spread of the disease as quickly as possible. If the officials don't deserve commendations, Chen argued, they should by no means be punished for their efforts.
Sun Ming-hsien, former COA chairman and Chiu Mau-ying's predecessor, was also reprimanded.
Shieh Kuai-lo, former director of the COA Animal Industry Department, was demoted and had his civil servant accreditation suspended for six months.

Shieh, who resigned in the wake of the epidemic and returned to his academic career, asserted that he had done his best during the outbreak which caught the entire island unprepared. He said the penalty is unfair.

DOC.HEADLINE: SHARE PRICES UP ON TAIEX

TEXT.P: Share prices surged on the Taiwan Stock Exchange on Saturday, with the weighted index, the market's key barometer, rising 76.89 points to close at 8,243.76.
Turnover of the market trading reached NT$149.92 billion (US$4.8 billion).

The 10 listed companies with the largest turnover were United Micro Electronics, China Petrochemical Dep., BES Engineering Corp., ACER, Mitac International Corp., Hualon-Teijran, Winbond Electronics, Macronix International, Mosel Vitelic Inc., and Taiwan Semiconductor Manufacturing.

DOC.HEADLINE: US DOLLAR UP

TEXT.P: The US dollar rose NT$0.025 against the New Taiwan dollar on the Taipei foreign exchange market Saturday, closing at NT$31.775.
The greenback opened at 31.799 and was traded between 31.756 and 31.825.
Interbank US dollar trading reached US$92 million.

DOC.HEADLINE: TAIWAN'S HUMAN RIGHTS STILL NEED IMPROVEMENT: CAHR REPORT

TEXT.P: Taiwan's human rights index shows signs of decline this year, with children's rights even flunking the acceptable standard, the Chinese Association for Human Rights (CAHR) reported on Saturday.

The association has consistently issued an annual survey of Taiwan's human rights conditions since 1992. Previously, the association evaluated six major indicators -- political, economic, social, educational/cultural, judicial and women's rights. This year children's rights were included in its review for the first time.
The 1997 report was based on the findings of a survey of more than 200 scholars and experts as well as 1,000 prison inmates. The association received a total of 1,335 valid replies.
According to the report, women's rights have not made any significant progress this year, and children's physical safety received the worst rating.
The report said Taiwan's children have not been well protected, facing threats of white-slaving, kidnapping or abduction. Child abuse or maltreatment is also rampant in local families.
Protection for children's educational rights and distribution of educational resources have also received poor ratings on the CAHR-devised scaling system.

Turning to women's rights, the report said social participation received the lowest rating among the six indicators gauged in this category, indicating that local women have still not been granted equal opportunities as their male counterparts to take part in social and political activities.
The rating for women's physical safety was only slightly higher than that for social participation, as several high-profile criminal cases involving female victims were reported over the past year.
Compared with the 1996 survey, women's freedom, working and educational rights have made some progress, but the marriage and family index and social participation rights registered slight drops.

The report said the Women's Rights Promotion Council under the Cabinet should work even harder to protect women's basic human rights and that the newly passed sex crime prevention law should be faithfully implemented.
Meanwhile, the report said although the overall political rights index rose modestly from last year's level, civil rights and liberty received a lower rating than 1996.
The report further said Taiwan has made progress in protection for rights of survival and land ownership as well as in restriction on death sentences.

Nevertheless, the report said there is still ample room for Taiwan to improve protection for environmental rights, labor rights, welfare services, privacy, communications rights, disaster relief and crime prevention.

DOC.HEADLINE: PRESIDENT LEE PRESIDES OVER MEETING OF NATIONAL UNIFICATION COUNCIL

TEXT.P: President Lee Teng-hui reiterated the government's steady and cautious mainland policy at a meeting of the National Unification Council (NUC), while politicians from opposition camp criticized his mainland China policies.

Lee said at the a-half-day meeting that "avoiding haste, exercising restraint, treading gingerly to attain long-lasting stability" should remain the government's guiding principles in managing cross-strait exchanges at the present stage.

"We maintain that both sides (of the Taiwan Strait) should engage in dialogue and consultations to nurture mutual confidence, enhance consensus and create a new stage for peace based on mutually beneficial cooperation."
He called for changing the informal rule that the NUC meets once annually by calling it into session twice or more in a year if necessary, an motion unanimously supported by the attendants.

President Lee reiterated calls he made in his inaugural address last year, that the two sides of the strait should "face up to reality and engage in dialogue with profound sincerity and patience in order to resolve their differences."

He said both sides of the Taiwan Strait should resume dialogue at the earliest possible time, and should start with consultations between the Taipei-based Straits Exchange Foundation and the mainland's Association for Relations Across the Taiwan Straits, which were unilaterally suspended by Peking in June 1995.

"We believe that cross-strait exchanges and consultations should not have any preconditions but should be based on respect for historical reality and the premise of securing the rights and interests of our people."
"In fact," Lee said, "the inhabitants of both sides of the strait are Chinese and therefore should enjoy similar standards of living and equal opportunities for development."

Noting that Taiwan has built a full-fledged democracy, President Lee said: "We wish that Peking will join us soon in the ranks of modern civilized society by accelerating its political reform, cultivating democracy and rule of law, following international norms and enhancing international cooperation."

He expressed hope Beijing "will be pragmatic and forward-looking in developing cross-strait relations, commit themselves to peace, renounce the use of force and through parallel participation of both sides in international organizations and activities, promote coexistence as well as mutual prosperity in the international community."
By so doing, Lee said, "the gap between both sides of the strait will be narrowed and conditions for national reunification will mature in the foreseeable future."

Although many participants chimed in to support Lee's opinion at the meeting, an opposition New Party leader, Hsu Li-nung, who is also a vice chairman of the NUC, challenged Lee's no-haste China policy, characterizing it as "against the public opinion" and urging Lee to review it.

Hsu, who just returned from a trip to the mainland China, also urged the government to deal with Beijing flexibly without regard to the three-phased limits imposed by the National Unification Guidelines.
On the other hand, two NUC members from the pro-independence Democratic Progressive Party abstained from Saturday's meeting in protest at the government's policy of pursuing national unification.

Huang Hsin-chieh, an NUC vice chairman, was absent from the meeting, while Taipei City Mayor Chen Shui-bian, who was appointed to the NUC because of his mayorship, criticized the NUC's pursuit as not based on consensus.

DOC.HEADLINE: FORTUNETELLING IS WORSHIPPING THE ISLAND

TEXT.P: "The nation's leader is elected under the mandate of heaven." Over half of the population in Taiwan is deeply convinced of that, as the occult sciences are increasing in popularity around the island.

As the Chinese society here is becoming more modernized and industrialized, local sociologists have found that oracle reading and other methods of fortunetelling, which cannot be proven by scientific theory, are nevertheless more and more popular as well, especially among well-educated members of the public.

One of those scholars is Prof. Chiu Hei-yuan, director of Academia Sinica's preparatory office for the institute of social sciences, who has studied the changes in Taiwan's fortunetelling and religious practices. He presented his findings at a two-day seminar on religion, occult, science and society, which opened in Taipei on Friday.

Conducting a survey over a ten-year period from 1985 to 1995, Chiu found that 64 percent of today's well-educated Taiwan women aged 20-35 are fond of fortunetelling. The figure marks a growth of 40 percent in comparison with the level recorded five years ago.

Chiu told the seminar that religious beliefs and fortunetelling have been deeply and widely rooted in Chinese societies after centuries of being handed down from one generation to another. Such practices provide a sense of certainty and security to people who live in an age in which they feel incapable of resolving problems on the basis of their own abilities and powers of reason.

Eager for reassurance, stability or survivability, people often turn to supernatural powers for answers. This is the main reason behind the increased popularity of fortunetelling in Taiwan, the prestigious scholar said, pointing out that the island is undergoing a dramatic change from an isolated society to an open and modern one.

Chiu's survey showed that currently popular forms of the occult and divination in Taiwan are largely based on such concepts as god and ghosts, the spirit world, ancestor worship, "qi," Chinese geomancy known as "feng shui," auspiciousness, fortunetelling, and fate.
Social behavior influenced by such concepts and beliefs was found to be on the rise during the 1985-95 period.
More than 50 percent of the surveyed believe that gods and ghosts, Heaven and Hell, do exist, and that there is a superior being in the universe, the survey indicated.

It was also revealed that 70 percent of the Taiwan public believe humans have a spirit after death; some 70 percent believe in fate; and 55 percent are convinced by that having an incompatible spouse is due to debts incurred in a former life.
In addition, the survey found that about 80 percent of the public islandwide will select an auspicious day to hold wedding parties, burial services and business openings.
Taipei Mayor Chen Shui-bian on Saturday denied local press reports that he would not seek reelection next year.
"The reports were erraneous," the outspoken mayor said, reaffirming his reelection bid.

Local media quoted ruling Kuomintang sources as speculating that Chen might not seek reelection and would instead join the race for the chairmanship of his Democratic Progressive Party (DPP) next year.
KMT sources said Chen is eyeing the DPP chairmanship with a view to imporve his prospects of becoming the party's candidate for Taiwan's next presidential election in the year 2000.

KMT sources reportedly have made such speculations mainly because the DPP bans its public office holders from seeking another elected post before having served at least half of his original tenure. If Chen is reelected Taipei mayor late next year, he would be unable to join the 2000 presidential race in accordance with current DPP regulations.

Commenting on the reports, the charismatic mayor scoffed at the KMT's intelligence gathering skills. "It's only KMT's wishful thinking that I would not seek reelection," he stressed, adding he'll seek reelection and would do his utmost in the coming year to win his bid.

"I've never said that I would seek the DPP chairmanship, nor have I dreamed to be our country's president," Chen asserted. "For the moment, the top priority for me is to fulfil my duty as the Taipei mayor."

Chen has consistently enjoyed a high approval rating in various public opinion polls over the past three years. A survey of local university students released on Saturday also showed he stands a good chance of winning reelection.

DOC.HEADLINE: ACADEMIC REPORT CARDS FORGERY GROUP BUSTED

TEXT.P: Police on Saturday raided an overseas study consulting company in Taipei on suspicion of selling bogus transcripts of academic records of an unaccredited college here to students who intended to do advanced studies abroad.

Police arrested two key suspects, identified as Huang Tai-sheng and his wife Kuo Yen-ling, and confiscated five forged transcripts of academic records of the Christianity Universal Federation College (CUFC), as well as many related documents.

The couple were accused of selling false CUFC academic report cards to local students for NT$100,000 to NT$200,000 each. The students, most of whom had poor academic records, would then use the forged CUFC report cards to apply for admission to colleges or universities abroad.
The couple told police that the false transcripts were provided by a mysterious man, identified as Ho Yen-ming whose whereabouts are still unknown.

According to the couple, Ho is about 60 years old and speaks Mandarin Chinese with a Cantonese accent. Ho was said to travel frequently between Taiwan and Hong Kong. The couple said they usually contacted Ho over telephone and did not know his ture identity. They claimed that Ho sold them each copy of false CUFC transcripts for NT$50,000.

Initial investigations also show that the couple had operated such illegal business for 16 years and made a profit of over NT$10 million. Among documents seized by ploce at the couple's company on Taipei's Jen-Ai Road were a list of 230 student applicants intending to buy bogus transcripts of academic records.

The couple said they don't know where the CUFC is located. Although the school is not accredited by the ROC's Ministry of Education, it is recognized by many schools abroad. Hundreds or thousands of local students might have used such false transcripts to obtain admissions to many overseas colleges or universities over the past 16 years.
Police said they will further investigate the case and bring to justice other accomplices.

DOC.HEADLINE: LEGISLATIVE LEADER OF TONGA VISITS TAIPEI

TEXT.P: Chief Fusitu'a, speaker and president of the Legislative Assembly of Tonga arrived in Taipei Saturday for a five-day visit.

While here, he will call on President Lee Teng-hui, Legislative Yuan President Liu Sung-pan, Judicial Yuan President Shih Chih-yang and other government officials. He will also visit several cultural and economic establishments.

DOC.HEADLINE: WORKING PARTY MEETS ON BEIJING'S WTO ACCESSION

TEXT.P: At the sixth meeting of the Geneva-based World Trade Organization (WTO) working party on the accession of mainland China on Friday, Beijing's revised services offer was examined closely.
"Members judged it to be an important document, one on the basis of which they could build the future bilateral services negotiation," said Pierre-Louis Girard, chairman of the meeting.

Overall, Girard pointed out, there was a feeling that while this offer represented a substantial improvement over Beijing's previous services offers, there was still a need for a clarification exercise so that governments and the services providers they represent could satisfactorily assess the significance and value of the offer.
On the bilateral track, Girard said the delegation from Beijing has been holding bilaterals all this week and will be continuing this process through the end of next week.
Yet, much work still remains to be done, especially in the area of services, Girard said.

No decision has yet been taken on a date for resuming the multilateral process in Geneva, however, Girard said, adding that he will consult with members of the working party and decide on the appropriate program early next year.

DOC.HEADLINE: TAIWAN TRADE FAIR TO BE HELD IN ISTANBUL

TEXT.P: A one-day Taiwan trade fair will be held in Istanbul on Dec. 15, according to Peter Huang, executive director of the Istanbul office of the Taiwan Trade Center.

At a news briefing on Friday, Huang said some 39 companies in all areas of business from the Republic of China will be participating at the trade fair which is organized by the Taiwan Trade Center, the ROC's foremost nonprofit trade promotion organization.

After peaking at US$622 million in 1993, total trade value between Taiwan and Turkey dropped to US$455.8 million for 1996, according to Huang. However, the last two years have seen a lopsided trade balance in favor of Taiwan, with the surplus nearly doubling from US$173.6 million in 1994 to US$334.1 million in 1995, and climbing to US$394.7 million last year.

Huang said that as Taiwan businessmen have been actively participating in trade shows and organizing market development activities in Turkey, two-way trade between the two countries has seen a rapid increase in the recent years. (Kuo Chuan-hsin)

DOC.HEADLINE: PM SIEW: BEIJING'S "ONE CHINA" RHETORIC MUST BE REFUTED

TEXT.P: Premier Vincent Siew said Saturday at a meeting of the National Unification Council (NUC) that it is necessary to forcefully refute Beijing's "one China" rhetoric.

The NUC was established in 1990 to provide the President with ideas and findings of researches on matters relating to national unification and cross-strait relations. Currently the NUC is headed by President Lee Teng-hui himself. Premier Siew serves as vice chairman of the council.

Siew said at the meeting that Beijing has repeatedly trumpeted its "one China" rhetoric, by saying in various occasions that "There is only one China," "The People's Republic of China is the only government representing China," and "Taiwan is part of China."
"This rhetoric is a political trick to downgrade us," Siew said, adding that "We must forcefully refute it."
He pointed out that the Republic of China has been a sovereign country since it was established in 1912. Taiwan and the Chinese mainland are now under separate rule.

Siew stressed that the development of good relations between Taiwan and mainland China will depend on whether Beijing is able to face this situation realistically and change its unreasonable policy toward Taiwan.

The government will steadfastly carry out its mainland policy and steadily establish "stable and forward-looking relationship" with mainland China with a purpose to unite the nation under the principles of democracy, freedom, and equal distribution of wealth, he added.
The NUC meeting was held Saturday morning for more than three hours at the Presidential Office. (by Ed Hsieh)

DOC.HEADLINE: TAIWAN OBU ASSETS TOTAL US$39 BILLION IN OCTOBER

TEXT.P: The assets of offshore banking units (OBUs) operating in Taiwan totaled US$39,001 million as of the end of October, up 9.8 percent from the same month of last year, according to statistics released by the Central Bank of China (CBC) Saturday.
Offshore banking is a collective term for banking that is free from domestic regulations. OBUs are only allowed to deal with each other or with foreign individuals and institutions.

The statistics showed that the OBU assets of Taiwan's domestic banks amounted to US$20,725 million as of the end of October, or 57 percent of the total, while foreign banks held the remaining 43 percent, or US$18,276 million.
In October, there were 71 OBUs operating in Taiwan, six more than a year earlier. Of the total, 38 were set up by domestic banks and 33 by foreign banks.
Loans in foreign currencies granted by all 71 OBUs on the island totaled US$11,231 million in October, the CBC said.
In October alone, the CBC noted, foreign exchange transactions by the OBUs totaled US$5,167 million.

DOC.HEADLINE: WORKSHOP ON SOUTH CHINA SEA CLOSES

TEXT.P: After three days of discussion, the eighth Workshop on Managing Potential Conflicts in the South China Sea formally concluded here on Friday after issuing a 19-point statement.
Over 100 participants from around the South China Sea attended the meeting, including representatives from Australia, Canada, Indonesia and Singapore, according to the statement.

The participants agreed that the workshop should now focus on implementation of the agreed projects and programs for cooperation, and that the participants should continue to exchange ideas and views as confidence building measures.
The workshop was opened on Dec. 3 by Foreign Minister Ali Alatas.
A general consensus was reached on the following issues:
1. Three projects are ready for implementation, namely bio-diversity, studies on tides and sea level changes, and data base and information networking for scientists.
2. One project proposal is ready for discussion, namely, a training program for ecosystem monitoring.

DOC.HEADLINE: TAIWAN NGOS HELPING PROMOTE OTTAWA'S ANTI-LANDMINE CAUSE

TEXT.P: The Eden Social Welfare Foundation of Taiwan announced on Friday that it will raise some US$1 million next year to help victims injured by landmines around the world.

Robert Lin, foundation secretary general, told a press conference that his group is also pleased to provide psychological counseling and job training programs to help disabled mine victims in other countries.

The Christian non-profit organization launched a Love Without Frontiers campaign in March this year, collecting 1,000 wheelchairs for survivors of landmine incidents in Afghanistan and Cambodia. Half of the wheelchairs have already been sent to Afghanistan, while the other 500 will soon be delivered to Cambodian victims.

Sayed Aqa, the director of Afghanistan's Mine Clearance Planning Agency (MCPA), lauded the Taiwan NGO for its efforts to help alleviate the pain of his fellow countrymen and "empower" the victims so they won't become a burden on society.

Traditional cooperation in assisting war victims in less developed countries has been North-South, but the Eden project sets a good example for South-South cooperation, Aqa pointed out. MCPA groups 36 NGOs inside and outside of Afghanistan to help the 400,000 mine victims in 2,500 villages across the country.

The Anti-landmine Network of Taiwan (ANT), another Taiwan NGO attending the Global Mine Action Forum in Ottawa, has introduced international norms of mine clearance operations to concerned parties in Taiwan.

The Republic of China government deploys mines in its frontline islands near mainland China. One week before the signing of the Ottawa treaty, Taiwan's defense authorities issued the first commercial contract in 40 years and began to clear an open mine dump on Kinmen Island, according to ANT coordinator Don-Lin Mon.

Mon said ANT, a coalition of weapons specialists and businessmen concerned with mine problems, is also coordinating campaign activities both at home and abroad calling for increased awareness of mine issues and assistance to victims.

In addition to the two Taiwan NGOs, other Taiwan groups are also doing their parts in response to Canada's anti-landmine cause. For example, the Taipei Overseas Peace Service is running three humanitarian programs in Cambodia, Thailand and Kenya to help rehabilitate mine victims.
The Buddhist Compassionate Relief Tzu-Chi Foundation and the World Vision of Taiwan also have many projects in mine-contaminated countries, providing aid to victims of wars and natural disasters.

DOC.HEADLINE: AUSTRALIA REMAINS TANGLED IN POLITICS OF CHINESE CIVIL WAR

TEXT.P: After a quarter of a century, Australia remains tangled in the politics of civil war between the Republic of China on Taiwan and the People's Republic of China on the mainland.

In a dispatch from Hong Kong, mass-circulation newspaper The Australian's correspondent Richard McGregor reported that both Beijing and Canberra are celebrating the 25th anniversary of Australia's formal recognition of the mainland government.
In an eight-column article headlined "Slow Boat to China," on Saturday, the daily said Australia has been and will continue to be squeezed in the middle of the two combatant Chinas.

The daily reported that Australia has ignored Taipei politically since recognizing Beijing as the sole ruler of "one China" in 1972. A quarter of a century later, mainland China and Taiwan are both economic giants and massive trade and investment partners.
"Technically, however, they are still at war, which makes maintaining relations with both awkward for countries such as Australia," the daily reported.

"Australia ignored Taiwan politically after recognizing Beijing as the sole ruler of 'one China' in 1972. In the 1980s, our diplomats would only visit the island unofficially from Hong Kong and meet Taiwan government contacts in neutral places such as coffee shops. Things have thawed since," the daily reported.

"Now, Australia's unofficial consulate in Taipei is headed by a senior China specialist from the Foreign Affairs Ministry, Sam Gerovich. To observe diplomatic niceties, he is there in a private capacity. An Australian minister usually visits once a year. But even with this improvement, most analysts expect the cross-straits tensions to remain for generations," the daily said.
"The worst-case scenario is war between Taiwan and China. The best is some sort of federation. In the meantime, countries such as Australia will continue to be squeezed in the middle," it added.

DOC.HEADLINE: HORMONAL GEL HAS POTENTIAL AS BIRTH CONTROL

TEXT.P: A hormonal gel is currently being developed in Australia as a potential new method of contraception.

Mass circulation newspaper The Sydney Morning Herald reported on Saturday that women in Sydney are being sought to take part in the first Australian study of the progestogen gel, which researchers hope will offer an alternative to oral contraceptives.

The daily reported that volunteers will be asked to rub 0.3 ml of gel into the skin daily, which will operate on the same principle as the "mini-pill," by releasing hormones into the blood stream which will affect the cervical mucus and the womb lining.

The study is part of an international trial, as the gel has been developed by the Population Council in New York, a non-profit body with a mandate to develop new forms of contraception, the daily said.
Dr. Edith Weisberg, director of the Sydney Center for Reproductive Health Research, said there is a need to develop alternatives as "many women don't like taking pills.
"The major advantage of these methods is that they are alternatives to the pill but they are still under women's' control," she said.
Weisberg said the gel study is preliminary work aimed at establishing optimum dosage and its effect on ovarian function. The next step will be to measure its efficacy as a contraceptive.

DOC.HEADLINE: SENATE REJECTS AUSTRALIAN PM'S NATIVE LAND TITLE BILL

TEXT.P: Australia's Prime Minister John Howard is facing a double-dissolution election after the Senate on Friday rejected his native title bill. The government now has three months to decide whether to agree with the Senate-proposed amendment on the legislation or call an election.

Howard accused the Senate of "wreaking havoc" on his native title plan and told his cabinet and back bench late Friday night that he believes the only way he could have his legislation passed is to submit it to a joint sitting of both houses of parliament after a double-dissolution election.

The key man who wreaked the havoc was Senator Brian Harradine from Tasmania because he holds the balance of the vote. He favored amendment of Howard's 10-point bill as proposed by the opposition Labor Party.
Howard has ordered a rare Saturday sitting of the House of Representatives so that he can announce his rejection of the Senate action.

The main point which was denied to the government was to deny Aborigines the right to negotiate over the terms of development on pastoral leases and on mineral and petroleum exploration, infrastructure projects and towns and cities.

In addition, the government wanted to introduce a six-year time limit for native land title claims and a tougher registration test before Aborigines can negotiate on native title claims. But the government also failed to have this passed in the Senate.

DOC.HEADLINE: AUSTRALIA'S CURRENCY, GOLD EXPORTS UNDER SIEGE

TEXT.P: Gold prices plunged to US$288.50 an ounce in New York on Thursday, threatening Australia's A$2 billion-worth of gold exports and sending its currency plummeting.

Australia, which ranks third in the world for gold production and export, will have to reduce its bullion production by about one-third in the years to come, according to the Australian Bureau of Agriculture and Resources.
The bureau had set gold production for 1997-98 at 320 tons, up from 290 tons in 1996-97.
The gold slump took its toll on the Australian currency, which closed at 67.25 US cents on Friday, down 0.08 US cents from Thursday's closing level.
Gold accounts for about eight percent of Australia's total exports.

DOC.HEADLINE: PSN APPOINTS TAIWAN'S COMSEARCH AS DISTRIBUTOR

TEXT.P: The Indonesian company PT Pasifik Satelit Nusantara (PSN) has appointed Taiwan's Comsearch as the official service provider of its Asia Cellular Satellite (ACES) products in Taiwan.
The 10-year agreement between PSN and Comsearch stipulates that Comsearch will pay an annual "airtime" fee to ACES, according to a PSN press release.

PSN is a private telecommunications service provider of the state telecommunications company PT Telkom. It leases satellite transponders and general satellite communication services in the Asia-Pacific region.
About 4.5 percent of Taiwan's population subscribes to cellular telephone services.

DOC.HEADLINE: PIG LIVER CELLS CAN CLEAN BLOOD FOR LIVER PATIENTS

TEXT.P: Dialysis may prove to be a viable alternative to liver transplants for liver patients in the future, a Japanese professor said in Singapore on Friday.

Professor Yoshito Ikada from Kyoto University's Research Center for Biomedical Engineering said that his studies have shown that pig liver cells can completely clean the blood of toxins and could possibly be used to help liver patients.

Speaking at the Ninth International Conference on Biomedical Engineering, he said that charcoal is currently used to get rid of toxins but is not so effective because it can only remove very small amounts of toxins.
It cannot get rid of substances like ammonia, he said, adding that this does not help patients with acute liver failure.

The blood of liver patients could be drawn out and cleaned in a machine using the pig liver cells, he said, adding that the process would be similar to the haemodialysis system that kidney patients use to clean their blood while they are awaiting a kidney transplant.
Ikada said that although the procedure has only been tested on dogs so far, the University of Kyoto is applying for approval to use the machine on terminally-ill liver patients next year.
If successful, liver dialysis could be a real help to liver patients, as there is a shortage of liver donors worldwide.
However, he pointed out that cleaning the blood of toxins is only one of the liver's functions. There is still no way of duplicating the liver's other functions, such as bile secretion, he added.

DOC.HEADLINE: ROC, JAPAN CONCLUDE ANNUAL ECONOMIC CONFERENCE
DOC.DATELINE: Tokyo, Dec. 6 (CNA) (By Mike Chang and Flor Wang)

TEXT.P: The Republic of China and Japan wrapped up their annual trade and economic cooperation conference on Friday, with the two sides agreeing to meet next month in Taipei to negotiate an agreement on the temporary admission of goods.

Lin Chin-ching, chairman of the ROC's East Asian Relations Association (EARA) and leader of the 29-member ROC delegation, said at a news conference following the close of the conference that officials of the two countries had discussed 34 issues of mutual concern during the two-day gathering, helping the two sides further strengthen cooperative trade relations.

The 49-member Japanese delegation was led by Leijiro Hattori, chairman of the Japanese Interchange Association (JIA), and included five officials from Japan's Foreign Ministry. It was the largest contingent to the conference in years, which Lin said was an indication that the Japanese government attached great importance to the event.
He noted that the Japanese side had also promised to seek to upgrade the status of its officials participating at future meetings.

In addition to agreeing to consider holding a third round of bilateral fishery talks and to allow the resumption of imports into Japan of cooked pork products from Taiwan, Lin said the two sides decided to conduct a second round of talks on the temporary admission of goods and on cross-border transfer of hazardous waste.

Agreement was also reached on inviting the ROC to attend a seminar on management of high-tech exports slated for February in Japan, supporting bids by both countries to sponsor working party meetings of the Asia-Pacific Economic Cooperation forum, as well as jointly holding seminars to boost bilateral technological exchanges and helping remove barriers to ROC exports into Japan, according to Lin.

The ROC's mounting trade deficit with Japan has again become a major point of concern for Taiwan people since Tokyo barred ROC pork shipments following the outbreak of foot-and-mouth disease at Taiwan hog farms in March, which resulted in a slowdown in Taiwan's exports to this country.

Taiwan suffered a negative trade balance of US$14.5 billion with Japan in the first ten months of the year and the figure is expected to rebound to the previous level of US$17 billion in 1995 from last year's US$13.8 billion.
The EARA and JIA are intermediary bodies representing the ROC and the Japanese government, respectively, in bilateral exchanges in the absence of diplomatic relations between the two countries.

DOC.HEADLINE: ECONOMIST SEES 'BIG JUMP' IN CROSS-STRAIT TIES SOON

TEXT.P: A local economist on Sunday predicted an imminent "big jump" in relations between Taiwan and the mainland as a result of Taipei's "no hurry, be patient" mainland investment policy.

Ma Kai, a research fellow with the Chung-Hua Institute for Economic Research, was among the few experts who hold an optimistic view on the consequences of the conservative mainland investment policy initiated by President Lee Teng-hui.
He noted that the currencies of the Southeast Asian countries have depreciated greatly in the wake of the financial turmoil that swept through the region recently.
As a result, mainland China has lost many of its export markets to its Southeast Asian neighbors, and much foreign capital has begun to flow out of the mainland.

That unfavorable situation, coupled with its seriously ailing state-run enterprises and bad debt problems suffered by its banks, will surely serve to tighten the mainland's money supply, prompting a devaluation of the renminbi in order to save the nation's export competitiveness.

Those measures in turn will force Southeast Asian finance officials to further depreciate their currencies to win back foreign markets, thus setting off a "currency devaluation race" with Beijing, which will see the serious bleeding of the mainland economy, Ma predicted.

As the mainland is in need of Taiwan capital to fill the vacancy left by the withdrawal of foreign capital, the "no hurry, be patient" policy, designed to slow down Taiwan's investment on the other side of the strait, will only make the mainland "more thirsty" for capital from Taiwan, he said.

Accordingly, Ma expects Beijing to extend an olive branch to Taipei in the hope of reopening the dialogue it unilaterally suspended following President Lee's visit to the United States in the summer of 1995 in what it said was a trip aimed at promoting Taiwan's independence. Taipei has repeatedly and emphatically denied Beijing's allegations.

Ma said that resumption of the cross-strait talks could likely begin with a meeting between either Chiao Jen-ho and Tang Shubei, the secretaries general of the two sides' intermediary bodies -- Taipei's Strait Exchange Foundation (SEF) and the mainland's Association for Relations Across the Taiwan Strait (ARATS) -- or between SEF Chairman C.F. Koo and ARATS Chairman Wang Daohan.

DOC.HEADLINE: FORMER AIT CHAIRMEN OPPOSE SUSPENSION OF ANNUAL TRADE CONFERENCE
DOC.DATELINE: Washington, Dec. 6 (CNA) (By Herman Pan and Flor Wang)

TEXT.P: David Dean and Natale Bellocchi, both former chairmen of the Washington-based American Institute in Taiwan (AIT), on Saturday voiced their opposition to the proposed suspension of the annual joint conference of the US-ROC (Taiwan) and ROC-USA Business Councils.

Dean, who served as the first chairman of the AIT when the institute was created to handle bilateral affairs after the Republic of China and the United States cut diplomatic relations in 1979, told CNA that he felt "shocked" and "surprised" to learn of the US side's intention to discontinue the annual conference.

Stressing that the confab had played a very important role in the 1980s by providing an unofficial channel for ROC and US officials to meet in the absence of formal contact between the two governments, Dean said David Laux and Jeffrey Koo, currently the respective heads of the US-ROC (Taiwan) Business Council and ROC-US Business Council, should consider means by which to promote the functions of the two organizations.

He suggested that instead of holding a ceremonial event each year, the two councils should sponsor theme seminars on various high-tech industries four or five times annually in order to boost the willingness to participate and the substantive gains of US attendees.

Bellocchi admitted that the importance and functions of the annual joint conference of the US-ROC (Taiwan) and ROC-USA Business Councils have significantly declined over the past few years due to more frequent exchanges of ranking officials between Taipei and Washington during the tenure of former US President George Bush. However, he insisted that the annual meeting should not be impulsively suspended.

As ranking ROC officials have been able to travel to the United States in recent years and the two countries now hold annual vice-ministerial trade meetings, Bellocchi said the joint conference of the business councils is no longer the only occasion on which officials from Taipei and Washington can meet.

However, he pointed out that from the business community's point of view, it is necessary to continue the yearly meeting as Taiwan needs more private-sector channels to reflect its importance as America's second largest market in Asia.

Bellocchi attributed the declining willingness to participate in the conference by US enterprises to lackluster support from the US government. Taiwan dispatched three ministerial-level officials to this year's annual conference held earlier this week in San Diego, California, while the Clinton administration only sent one cabinet official to the meeting, he pointed out.

DOC.HEADLINE: BEIJING RULES OUT CURRENCY DEVALUATION

TEXT.P: Beijing will not devalue its currency to boost exports, despite the recent depreciations in rival Asian manufacturing economies which threaten to undermine the competitiveness of mainland Chinese exporters, according to reports of the Geneva-based World Trade Organization (WTO) on Saturday.

In the face of the devaluation of currencies in Southeast Asian countries, mainland China will take measures to increase the competitiveness of its exports and its absorption of overseas funds, the WTO report said.

Mainland exporters have been putting discreet pressure on Beijing authorities for a devaluation to restore the competitive advantage they fear may have been lost to Southeast Asian competitors, whose devalued currencies will cut the prices of their products on international markets.

Meanwhile, domestic currency markets have seen pressure for an appreciation of the local currency, reflecting the strong demand for the renminbi in mainland China and the view of many economists that the currency has been undervalued since the beginning of 1994.
Mainland China's forecast 9.5 percent growth this year has been driven by the strong performance of the external sector and supported by the continuing growth of foreign direct investment.

However, the recent devaluations by export-oriented economies in Asia and the unraveling of the financial systems in Japan and Korea, two of the mainland's most important markets and inward investors, have raised concerns of a marked slowdown in export growth and a possible decline in foreign investment next year.

DOC.HEADLINE: TAIWAN MEDIA CRITICIZED FOR LACK OF SELF-DISCIPLINE

TEXT.P: The news media of Taiwan should observe their self-disciplinary rules, the Association for Promotion of Human Rights in Taiwan said in its "1997 Report on Human Rights in Taiwan."
The report said human rights are often infringed upon by news media in Taiwan.

The report said the news reports on recent violent crimes, such as the kidnap and murder of TV celebrity Pai Ping-ping's daughter, were pretty sensational. Kidnap cases are often reported when the victims are still in danger. The names of victims in sexual offenses are often disclosed. And the actions of police can often be seen on the TV by the fugitives.
News reporters should always bear in mind their social responsibility, rather than the commercial interests of their news media, the report added. (by Ed Hsieh)

DOC.HEADLINE: TRADE OPPORTUNITIES IN MONGOLIA TO BE PRESENTED IN TAIPEI

TEXT.P: The China Economic and Trade Development Council (CETRA) will hold a seminar on the trade opportunities and investment climates in Mongolia Tuesday in Taipei.

Mongolian economic, trade, transportation,and tourism officials and businessmen will attend the seminar to introduce Mogolia's trade opportunities and potential to develop tourism to Taiwan business leaders.
Taiwan will promote trade relations with Mongolia, and Mongolia has decided to grant Taiwan businessmen 30-day visas at the Ulaanbaatar Airport, an official of CETRA said. (by Ed Hsieh)

DOC.HEADLINE: PRES. LEE'S APPROVAL RATE DECLINES: POLL

TEXT.P: President Lee Teng-hui's approval rate has recently dropped to a new low, according to the result of a public poll.

The survey, commissioned by Kuomintang Legislative Yuan whip Chen Hung-kee and conducted by the Gallup Organization Inc., Taiwan, shows that less than 37 percent of the respondents gave their approval to the president's performance over the past year, while 49.1 percent of the polled disapproved of his job in office.

This poll also also shows that Lee, who became the ROC president following the death of President Chiang Ching-kuo in January 1988 and was elected to his own term first in 1990 and again in 1996, saw his disapproval rate overtake his approval level.
The random telephone survey was conducted on Dec. 4-5 on 1,735 adults in the Taiwan area, with 1,089 of the polled giving their answers. The survey has a margin of error of plus or minus 3 percent.
The poll also shows that fewer respondents, at 34.2 percent, approved of Vice Presdient Lien Chan's performance, while 45.4 percent said they disapproved of Lien's job.

Among other high ranking-officials, the outspoken Taiwan Governor James Soong, who has voiced his strong opposition to the central government's decision to marginalize the Taiwan Provincial Government, won the hearts of most of the respondents, with his approval rate reaching as high as 79.7 percent, and disapproval at a mere 7.6 percent.
Over half of the respondents said they approved of the performance of Premier Vincent Siew, who formed his Cabinet on Sept. 1. Those who were unsatisfied with Siew's job stood at only 10 percent.

Of Siew's Cabinet ministers, Education Minister Wu Jin, who is known for his vigorous pursuit of educational reforms, has the highest approval rate of 69.8 percent, followed by Justice Minister Liao Cheng-hao, who has demonstrated a determination to fight crime, at 64.7 percent, newly installed Foreign Affairs Minister Jason Hu, at 58.6 percent, Economic Affairs Minister Wang Chih-kang at 48 percent and Interior Minister Yeh Chin-feng at 43 percent.

The approval rates for other Cabinet members, including Transportation and Communications Minister Tsay Jaw-yang, Finance Minister Paul Chiu, Defense Minister Chiang Chung-ling, Central Bank of China Governor Y.D. Sheu, Mainland Affairs Council Chairman Chang King-yuh and Environmental Protection Administration Director-General Tsai Hsung-hsiung, ranged between 30 percent and-36 percent, with ratings for Council of Labor Affairs Chairman Hsu Chieh-kwei and Department of Health Director-General Chan Chi-shean at the bottom with 1.8 percent and 2.3 percent respectively because they are relatively less known to the public.

However, the 72 percent of the polled who said Siew should reshuffle his Cabinet, were divided on the scale of the change, with those who favored either a total, major or minor shakeup of government ministers standing at 16 percent, 30.8 percent and 25.2 percent, respectively.

Around 58 percent of the respondents said Siew should be given the full authorization to change his Cabinet lineup, in comparison to the nearly 8 percent of the respondents who said President Lee alone should decide upon the reshuffle and 11 percent who favored Lee and Siew jointly determining the change.

DOC.HEADLINE: DPP CHAIRMAN ARRIVES IN U.S.

TEXT.P: Hsu Hsin-liang, chairman of the major opposition Democratic Progressive Party, Saturday arrived in New York, the first stop in his week-long visit to the United States.
He told the press at the airport that the DPP has to win popular confidence in the party before its candidates can win presidential elections.
He also said that the future relations between his pro-independence party and communist China should be reasonable, mutually beneficial, on equal basis, and peaceful.
He is accompanied during the trip by DPP Legislator Parris H. Chang and several other officials of the party.
Hsu is scheduled to deliver speeches in Boston and New York Sunday and leave for Washington Sunday evening before going to Los Angeles Wednesday. (by Huang Jui-nan/ Ed Hsieh)

DOC.HEADLINE: MONGOLIAN INVESTMENT SEMINAR TO BE HELD IN TAIPEI

TEXT.P: In line with the government's policy to increase economic exchanges with Mongolia, the China External Trade Development Council (CETRA) will host a trade and investment seminar on Tuesday to introduce opportunities in that country to the local business community.
Ranking Mongolian officials in charge of foreign trade, tourism and transportation affairs will take part in the seminar, according to CETRA.

CETRA Secretary General Kao Yi-hsin said Mongolia is rich in tourism and mineral resources and it hopes Taiwan businesses will seek opportunities in those sectors. He added that Mongolia also has expressed willingness to cooperate with Taiwan textile makers to jointly produce garments for export to third countries.

The semi-official trade promotion organization said that the Mongolian government plans to sponsor a trade fair and tourism seminar in Ulan Bator in June 1998 and that Taiwan businessmen wishing to attend the event will be granted a 30-day visa-free stay upon arrival at the airport of Ulan Bator.
CETRA said Mongolia is a good site for investment by Taiwan's small businesses, as it has not imposed any restrictions on investment capital volume.

DOC.HEADLINE: INTERNATIONAL PROSTITUTION RING BUSTED

TEXT.P: In separate raids, police successfully busted up an international prostitution ring Sunday night, arresting 41 people, including prostitutes, operatives and drivers.

None of the prostitutes arrested were from Taiwan. They were holders of passports from Thailand, Hong Kong, Macau, mainland China, Malaysia and Singapore. They were in Taiwan on tourist visas, or on the basis of fallacious marriages with local men, according to Taipei District Prosecutor Liu Cheng-wu, who directed the crackdown.

Acting on tips received three months ago, the police decided to move Sunday night, sweeping down on 40 hotels and hostels in both Taipei City and Taipei County. Among the arrested were Tsai Teh-liang and his wife, Chen Hsiao-mei, who were apparently the operators of the prostitution ring.
Police had been tipped off that Tsai and Chen ran an underground brothel named "Lily," employing more than 100 women on their service list as well as some 60 drivers and bodyguards.
Liu said the Sunday night raids were only part of the crackdown action, adding that the international sex ring will not be thoroughly eradicated until some 110 other people have been nabbed.
Liu said he believes that the ring is supported by an underworld syndicate which runs an efficient human smuggling operation from Southeast Asia.

He said he will ask Taipei Mayor Chen Shui-bian and Taipei County Magistrate You Ching for cooperation in authorizing a crackdown on nearly 100 hostels in the greater Taipei area, which are thought to have collaborated in conducting the illicit sex trade.
According to investigators, the overseas prostitutes charged between NT$4,000 and NT$10,000 (US$125-US$312.5) for 40 minutes of their services.

Fearing that the women could bring an even more serious impact to Taiwan society besides the illicit activity, Liu ordered the arrested prostitutes to undergo health exams to determine whether they are HIV-positive or drug users.

Liu also called for revisions to existing entry-exit laws. He said lax guarantor requirements under the regulations should be revised to make it more difficult for women to remain in the country as "fake brides" or under the pretense of tourism.

In addition, Liu urged revisions to anti-prostitution laws that would enable law enforcement agencies to publicize the names of customers who frequent the brothels, saying such measures would provide a greater deterrent to the illicit activity.
To nip the source of demand is the only effective way to eradicate the supply, Liu stressed, adding that "the sex trade will wither if there is no patronage."

Liu also mentioned that he and his officers had received full cooperation from Thai police during the last three months in order to crack the cross-border ring. Cooperation from Hong Kong and mainland China counterparts, however, has not been significant, he said.

DOC.HEADLINE: NT DOLLAR HAS ROOM FOR APPRECIATION: ROC SPOKESMAN
DOC.DATELINE: Washington, Dec. 7 (CNA) (By Herman Pan and Lilian Wu)

TEXT.P: Judging from the fundamentals of Taiwan's economy, the New Taiwan dollar remains undervalued and there should be room for its appreciation, David Lee, the Republic of China government spokesman, said here Sunday.

Lee, director-general of the Government Information Office, noted that Taiwan's efforts to push for financial liberalization will make it difficult for the government to fend off international speculators. But he expressed belief that the level of the NT dollar is still too low in view of the fact that the nation's economic fundamentals are sound. The local currency ended at a rate of 31.775 against one US dollar last week.

Lee, who is on a week-long tour of the United States, said that he has been frequently asked during his visit how Taiwan has emerged unscathed from the financial crisis which swept through Southeast Asia in recent months.

He would answered that Taiwan has a sound economic policy and good fundamentals, adding that Taiwan has a foreign currency reserve of US$82 billion and a foreign debt of only US$100 million. The ratio of the foreign debt to its gross domestic product (GDP) is the second lowest in Asia.

Lee said that the economic growth of Taiwan is expected to reach 6.7 percent this year, which will not only be the highest rate since 1992, but will also be top among the four Asian tiger economies. Taiwan's trade surplus for 1997 is expected to reach US$8 billion.

Lee left Taipei for New York on Thursday. The main purpose of his trip is to brief major US media on recent developments in Taiwan, including the islandwide local elections held in late November, the social order situation, and the approaches and strategies for coping with the financial crisis in Southeast Asia.
