DOC.HEADLINE: ROC TO SPONSOR APPU ANNUAL CONFERENCE ON JAN. 14-16

TEXT.P: The National Assembly's efforts to promote parliamentary diplomacy have paid off as it has been authorized to host the 61st annual conference of the Asian-Pacific Parliamentarians' Union (APPU) next January.

The meeting will be held at the Taipei International Convention Center on Jan. 14-16 with the participation of parliamentary speakers and MPs from 24 Asia-Pacific countries and areas, including Japan, South Korea, the Philippines, Thailand, Singapore, Fiji and Guam.
The Republic of China government has attached great importance to the upcoming extravaganza as the ROC doesn't maintain formal diplomatic ties with most of the APPU member countries.

APPU is one of the few international organizations in which the ROC has managed to participate with its full national title. Mainland China has repeatedly applied to join the organization with an aim to replace the ROC, but its bid has consistently failed.
Since former Minister of Foreign Affairs Fredrick Chien assumed the post as National Assembly speaker last year, the National Assembly has actively sought the right to host an APPU annual congress.
Although Hong Kong is also an APPU member, it remains unclear whether it will send representatives to the Taipei meeting now that the territory has reverted to mainland China's rule.

Premier Vincent Siew is expected to deliver a keynote speech at the opening session of the APPU conference, and President Lee Teng-hui will meet with influential parliamentarians from all APPU member states during their stay here.
The Asia-Pacific delegates will also meet with other senior ROC officials to exchange views on promoting bilateral or regional cooperation in various fields.

The functions of the National Assembly are more limited in scope than those of the parliament or congress of a Western democracy. In the ROC, the role of parliament is jointly filled by the National Assembly and the Legislative Yuan. The Assembly's functions include amending the nation's Constitution and exercising the power of confirmation on the appointment of personnel nominated by the president.

DOC.HEADLINE: DPP NOT TO FORSAKE 'INDEPENDENCE' PLATFORM: HSU
DOC.DATELINE: New York, Dec. 7 (CNA) (By Renan Huang and Sofia Wu)

TEXT.P: Taiwan's opposition Democratic Progressive Party (DPP) will not forsake its "independence" platform because it is an important historic document, the party's chairman said here on Sunday.

Speaking at a seminar on Taiwan's latest political situation, DPP Chairman Hsu Hsin-liang said Taiwan is already a de facto independent sovereign country. "It is far more practical to protect Taiwan's current independent status than to advocate establishment of a de jure independent Taiwan republic," Hsu claimed, adding Taiwan must treasure what it already has.

Hsu said although the DPP will not revise the commitment to "promoting Taiwan independence" enshrined in the party platform, that principle will serve only as a symbol of the party's basic stance. "The practice is similar to Beijing's strategy. The constitution of the People's Republic of China clearly states that the country upholds Marxism. However, Beijing has not really implemented Marxist tenets," he argued.

While soliciting international support for its cause, Hsu said, Taiwan must exercise caution and prudence to avoid defying the general global trends. "Otherwise, we would likely witness a boomerang effect."

Hsu has been at odds with many other DPP heavyweights over policy toward mainland China. At Sunday's seminar, the outspoken DPP chairman cautiously but firmly explained why he has advocated a daring "westbound policy" of increased engagement with the mainland.

Under the framework of the World Trade Organization (WTO), Hsu said, the two sides of the Taiwan Strait cannot avoid greater across-the-board commercial exchanges in the future. "Taiwan must take preemptive actions in order to gain an upper hand in the race with Beijing."

Claiming that military confrontation is unlikely to erupt between Taiwan and the mainland under the newly emerging world order, the optimistic DPP chairman said the outcome of the cross-strait rivalry will hinge on the economic strength possessed by the two sides. "It will be a long-term confrontation, maybe lasting 50 to 100 years," he observed.

"Since Taiwan is confident in its economic clout, why shouldn't it take bold steps to boost exchanges in that area with the mainland to further beef up its economic strength despite the political standoff?" he reasoned.

Hsu also urged Taipei and Beijing authorities to learn from the ordeals Israel, Palestine and Bosnia have endured by avoiding international interference in their dispute. "The governments on both sides of the Taiwan Strait should use their wisdom to resolve their problems on their own accord," he stressed, adding that history has shown outside involvement often presents only painful options that are undesirable to the parties directly concerned.

He further pointed out that neither Taipei nor Beijing can resolve cross-strait disputes solely based on their own wishes or aspirations. "For its part, Taiwan must do its utmost to work out concrete measures that would ensure the best possible benefits for the people of Taiwan."

Hsu, accompanied by several DPP departmental chiefs, arrived in New York on Saturday, the first stop on his week-long visit to the United States aimed at publicizing the party's basic policies on major issues facing Taiwan as well as at finding out general American opinions on issues related to Taiwan.

The trip has drawn much attention here as the DPP scored a resounding win in Taiwan's local elections held on Nov. 29. The DPP won 12 of the 23 mayoral and county chief posts up for grabs in the nationwide polls, while the ruling Kuomintang garnered only eight seats and nonpartisan candidates won in three constituencies.

Hsu and his colleagues left for Washington, D.C. on Sunday evening. During his stay in the US capital, Hsu is expected to meet with senior American officials in charge of Taiwan and East Asian affairs for wide-ranging talks, most notably on the DPP's policy toward mainland China.

DOC.HEADLINE: OPEN TRADE AND INVESTMENT LEAD TO GROWTH IN MALAYSIA

TEXT.P: Malaysia's pursuit of open trade policies and its attractiveness to foreign direct investment (FDI) have led to impressive growth and continued economic transformation, trade experts here said Sunday.
Accordingly, the effects of the current financial crisis in Asia will ultimately proved less serious for Malaysia than for some other markets, they predicted.

Trade experts said that Malaysia maintains a very active industrial policy, which involves tariff and nontariff measures together with internal measures such as incentives, regulations and preferential government procurement practices.

Malaysia's recent growth has largely been based on increase in the volume of capital rather than in its efficient allocation. Total factor productivity growth has slowed, with adverse implications for resource allocation.

DOC.HEADLINE: SAUDI ARABIA REAFFIRMS SUPPORT FOR MUSLIM WORLD

TEXT.P: Saudi Arabia will continue its unwavering support to the Muslim world and will embrace any opportunity for cooperation that may strengthen the cause of Islam and Muslims around the world, Riyadh Governor Prince Salman asserted on Saturday.

He was speaking at the inauguration of the sixth session of the General Conference of Islamic, Educational, Scientific and Cultural Organization (ISESCO). The conference, which will run until Dec. 9, will conclude with the adoption of a draft Three-Year Action Plan (1998-2000) designed to propel Muslim societies forward into the 21st century.

Prince Salman called upon all Muslims to safeguard the life and property of their brethren as taught by the Prophet Muhammad. Only then, he said, can they harness the enormous resources of the Islamic faith in resolving problems faced by local societies and the world community.

DOC.HEADLINE: TAIWAN URGED TO REMAIN A MODEL OF ECONOMIC PERFORMANCE

TEXT.P: As East Asia sinks further into economic quicksand, the best way for Taiwan to assist its victimized neighbors is by "continuing to be an exemplar" of good economic and marketing policies, an expert from the Heritage Foundation said here on Monday.

At a press conference, Kim Holmes, vice chairman of the US-based Heritage Foundation, said if other governments, including that of the United States, truly want to help the nations affected by the Asian financial turmoil, they should know "what to do, and what not to do."
For example, he said, the International Monetary Fund (IMF) should have not been so hasty in offering to help revive South Korea's battered economy overnight.
Such a move will only make matters worse in the long term for that nation and for the entire Asian economic structure, Holmes noted.

Asked how Taiwan is expected to fare in the face of the East Asian upheavals, Holmes said the island has made commendable performances in monetary and property rights policies, and can play a positive role simply by retaining its reputation as a "model" player.

Holmes said Taiwan, rated the seventh in the world for level of economic freedom by a recent poll, did not remain relatively unscathed by the financial crisis without reason. "Other governments should reflect why Hong Kong and Taiwan could stay out of the upheavals while Malaysia and Indonesia did not," he added.

According to the 1998 Index of Economic Freedom compiled by the Heritage Foundation and the Wall Street Journal, the economies of Hong Kong, Singapore, Bahrain, New Zealand and Switzerland, in that order, are the five freest in the world.
The United States was declared the sixth most liberalized economy on the globe, while Taiwan ranked seventh, on a par with Britain and Luxembourg.
While Japan and Australia, labeled as "mostly free," were tied in 12th position, South Korea came in 24th.
Mainland China fell in at 120th place, down among countries that allow only limited freedom in economic activities, such as Albania, the Congo, Bangladesh and Croatia.
Economies that were rated among the least free were North Korea and Laos (both 154) and Vietnam (147), the index showed.

DOC.HEADLINE: GOV'T URGED TO BOOST MAINLAND STUDENTS' UNDERSTANDING OF TAIWAN

TEXT.P: In view of a rapidly changing world political situation, the government should strive to enhance the understanding of Taiwan among mainland China students studying overseas, two respected scholars said here Monday.

Tien Chang-lin, former chancellor of the University of California at Berkeley, and Shen Chun-shan, former president of National Tsing Hua University, said the government should seek to increase the knowledge of mainland students regarding the situation on Taiwan so that their attitudes toward cross-strait relations would not be so one-sided.

Tien noted that the number of mainland students being educated abroad has increased rapidly in recent years, and that their areas of study have expanded to the humanities, economics and technology fields. He added that many young professors at leading universities such as Harvard, UC Berkeley and Columbia are mainland Chinese.
Such a phenomenon will afford tremendous opportunities for the Republic of China's national diplomacy, he said.
For example, Taiwan students studying in the United States have contributed much to the maintenance of good relations between those two countries in the past, he said.

And today, young mainland scholars are increasingly able to speak objectively on cross-strait relations because they have a better understanding of Taiwan. But in a rapidly changing political environment, Tien said, the ROC government should take more direct measures to avail itself of the opportunities presented by this situation.

Shen also pointed out that mainland students studying overseas often identify well with Western democracy and are thus able to appreciate the democratic developments achieved in Taiwan. Accordingly, when these intellectual elites return to the mainland, they will take with them a positive image of Taiwan.
Shen also voiced concern that too many of Taiwan's young people studying abroad have been concentrated in the science and information fields, and have ignored the humanities.

In the wake of recent controversy surrounding the ROC government's proposal to accredit degrees conferred by mainland colleges and universities, Tien commented that many educational facilities there in fact have high academic standards.

Tien, who frequently travels between the United States and the mainland, said the overall academic level on the mainland does not equal Taiwan's standards. However, he added, the more prestigious mainland universities often surpass local standards.

Shen echoed his words, saying that some mainland universities are superior to the top schools here. He said that they have elite enrollment and that the mainland students are endowed with a high sense of purpose, despite having meager budgets for their education.

DOC.HEADLINE: CROSS-STRAIT TV & BROADCASTING EXCHANGE SEMINAR HELD IN TAIPEI

TEXT.P: A seminar on the exchange of TV and broadcasting information across the Taiwan Strait opened in Taipei on Monday, aimed at ushering in cooperation between the two sides in this field.
Many heads of TV and broadcast media from both mainland China and Taiwan attended the seminar to observe the 10th anniversary of the beginning of cross-strait exchanges.

Guo Baoxing, head of the mainland delegation, pointed out that although mainland China's TV and broadcasting media can follow and take part in protocol, research and public relations affairs with their counterparts from the United States and Europe, it is more important to develop these relations between the two sides of the strait, since both sides share the same cultural origins.

Since cross-strait exchanges began ten years ago, remarked Yen Jon-chang, deputy director of the ROC's Government Information Office, they have developed rapidly from nothing, to contact in many different areas, so that relations have evolved from mere interaction to that of practical exchanges.

Chang Liang-jen, deputy secretary general of the Taipei-based Straits Exchange Foundation, stressed that a bridge built across the strait through the news media would be far more significant than the establishment of direct transport links. TV and broadcasting could be termed as the most important channel for promoting understanding between the two sides, Guo added.

DOC.HEADLINE: MAINLAND CHINESE TRADE PROMOTION GROUP VISITS TAIWAN

TEXT.P: An 18-member delegation, organized by the China Council for the Promotion of International Trade in Beijing, arrived here Monday for a 10-day visit at the invitation of China External Trade Development Council (CETRA).

Led by An Chengxin, vice chairman of the council, the delegation will call at Taiwan's trade promotional organizations, including CETRA, the Chinese National Federation of Industries, and the General Chamber of Commerce of the Republic of China. It will also visit Taiwan's leading enterprises and the Kaohsiung Harbor in southern Taiwan.

The council is a civil organization with branch offices in 42 mainland Chinese cities and provinces. An Chengxin told the press upon arrival that his council hopes to promote cross-strait cooperation in commerce and trade. (by Ed Hsieh)

DOC.HEADLINE: SHARE PRICES UP ON TAIEX

TEXT.P: Share prices skyrocketed on the Taiwan Stock Exchange Monday, with the weighted index, the market's key barometer, surging 158.41 points to finish at the day's high of 8,402.17.
The bourse opened at the day's low of 8,265.36.
Losers outnumbered gainers 291 to 113, with 72 stocks remaining unchanged. In all, 3.53 billion shares changed hands on a market turnover of NT$195.71 billion (US$6.31 billion).

Paper and pulp issues rose the most at 4.7 percent, followed by electrical engineering stocks at 4 percent, foodstuff shares at 1.7 percent, financial stocks at 1.1 percent, plastic and chemical issues at 0.5 percent, construction shares at 0.3 percent, and cement and textile stocks at 0.1 percent respectively.

The 10 listed companies with the largest turnovers were United Micro Electronics, ACER, Taiwan Semiconductor Manufacturing, Mitac International, Mosel Vitelic, Ever Fortune, A.S.E., China Develop, Winbond Electronics, and Compal Electronic.

DOC.HEADLINE: US DOLLAR UP

TEXT.P: The US dollar rose NT$0.125 against the New Taiwan dollar on the Taipei foreign exchange market Monday, closing at NT$31.9.
The greenback opened at 31.93, and was traded between 31.765 and 31.949.
Interbank US dollar trading reached US$349 million.

DOC.HEADLINE: DPP'S RISE MAY COMPLICATE CHINA'S UNIFICATION (I)

TEXT.P: The rise of the Democratic Progressive Party (DPP) in Taiwan may complicate the process of reunification negotiations between the two sides of the Taiwan Strait, said an article carried in Monday's edition of The Straits Times.
The article pointed out that the landslide victory of the DPP in the recent elections for city mayors and county chiefs has made it the "most influential force at the grassroots level" in Taiwan.
The DPP is effectively running the daily affairs of 72 percent of the total population, who generate 83 percent of the national revenue.
Its solid performance paves the way for its eventual showdown with the ruling Kuomintang (KMT) in the next presidential poll, scheduled to take place in 2000, notes the article.
Taiwan has been so overwhelmed by the "unification-independence" dilemma that there is no escaping a serious political re-think, it says.
DPP chairman Hsu Hsin-liang attributed the convincing victory to the "successful transformation" of the party. Among the key ideological positions transformed was its stand towards mainland China.
The DPP is learning its lesson the long, hard way, says the article.
During the presidential election last year, it notes, the DPP campaigned for independence in an aggressive high-profile fashion. The result was disastrous.
It managed to obtain only 21 percent of the votes, the lowest in all elections since its founding.
This forced party leaders to review China policy and to adopt a more pragmatic and conciliatory approach.

For example, it says, just before the Nov. 29 elections, Hsu called openly for the establishment of "three direct links" between Taiwan and the mainland, a major reversal of the DPP's previous position. "This moderation made the party less intimidating to voters," it comments.
Conversely, it adds, President Lee Teng-hui's policy to restrict Taiwan's investment in mainland China may have been a contributory factor to the KMT rout.

It is obvious that his restrictive policy is beginning to "backfire" as it has alienated most of his ardent supporters in the business sector. They feel compelled to come out, one after another, to criticize his policy, the article notes.
One of them was Chang Yung-fa of the Evergreen Group, who is known for his past support of the president.
When Chang spoke against Lee, it left a "bad impression" of the party and a "sour taste" in the mouths of its supporters, comments the article.
So far, it points out, Beijing's reaction has been extremely cautious.

The extreme caution shows that mainland China does not appreciate fully the election's implications and the question of whether Beijing should establish contacts with the DPP, at least on an informal level, it says.

Although mainland China has been preparing for the probability that the DPP will one day become the ruling party in Taiwan, "the speedy pace at which this seemed to be taking place still surprised Beijing", comments the article.
But one thing is certain. Now that the DPP is enjoying the majority support from the people, mainland China will have to review its negotiation tactics, it asserts.
Since the early 1980s, its "united front" tactics towards Taiwan have always been based on a separation between the ruling and the ruled, which Beijing assumes have conflicting interests.

In Beijing's view, the KMT has vested interests in maintaining its ruling position and therefore is reluctant to enter into unification talks, while the general masses know there is greater benefit in reuniting with a strong mainland China, says the article.
It follows that Beijing can make use of this conflict to force the KMT into negotiations.
Thus, its standard slogan since 1979 has been: "We place our hope on the authority (of Taiwan), we also place our hope on the people (of Taiwan)."
Such a tactic might be effective if the underlying assumption is correct, the article comments. (to be continued)

DOC.HEADLINE: DPP'S RISE MAY COMPLICATE CHINA'S UNIFICATION (II)

TEXT.P: But Taiwan has changed so drastically since political reform started in the later years of former President Chiang Ching-kuo's rule that the people's desire for unification is no longer what it used to be, notes the Straits Times.
The latest election results confirm this. Voters supported a DPP which demanded independence, notwithstanding Beijing's pressure, it comments.
So, it asks, if both the "authority" and the "people" are not too keen on unification, where else can Beijing place its hopes?

It is clear that Beijing needs to overhaul its entire thinking on the DPP issue. The problem is complicated by the fact that in future, Beijing will have to deal with a political force with which it has no links at all, says the article.
If it had a choice, Beijing would prefer to deal with the more predictable KMT, than the erratic DPP, it comments.

The Chinese Communist Party (CCP) has dealt with the KMT for at least 70 years. It is familiar with its rivals, and there are many people in mainland China, Taiwan and elsewhere who have good relations with the senior members of both parties.
These people can play a mediating role during critical moments in negotiations, it notes.
Finally, it adds, there is also the practical problem of who Beijing should talk to, the fading KMT or the DPP, which is gaining greater popularity.
In dealing with sensitive political issues, Beijing has always preferred a one-to-one approach, the article notes.
Thus, the rise of the DPP may complicate the negotiation process somewhat, it comments.
The sooner Beijing and the political forces in Taiwan come to grips with this change, the faster and easier it will be for real negotiations to begin, it concludes.

DOC.HEADLINE: DPP NOT TO SELL OFF TAIWAN PEOPLE'S INTERESTS: CHEN

TEXT.P: Taipei Mayor Chen Shui-bian said on Monday that the Democratic Progressive Party's (DPP's) resounding win in the Nov. 29 mayoral and county chief elections will have a positive effect on future relations across the Taiwan Strait.

Speaking at a seminar on the development of cross-strait relations in the wake of the DPP victory, the influential DPP politician said the pro-Taiwan independence party will never "sell off" the benefits of the people of Taiwan should it become the ruling party and begin negotiations with Beijing.

Chen pointed out that the outcome of the latest elections was critical to the DPP, as it helped the party rebuild its confidence after its defeat in Taiwan's first direct presidential election in March 1996.

The DPP won 12 of the 23 mayoral and county chief posts up for grabs in the local elections, while the ruling Kuomintang (KMT) garnered only eight seats, the remaining three going to independent candidates. "The victory has helped our party shake off the pessimistic sentiments prevalent among DPP members in the aftermath of last year's presidential election in which the DPP bagged only 21 percent of the vote," Chen noted.

The outspoken mayor claimed that the DPP's latest victory indicates that the people of Taiwan are able and qualified to determine the future direction of cross-strait relations, in addition to pursuing a democratic way of life. "This will contribute to the positive development of cross-strait ties," he said.
Chen went on to say the DPP's win will also allow for the adjustment of some old-fashioned concepts which disregard Taiwan in favor of mainland China and overlook the DPP in favor of the KMT.

The mayor also said he is confident that the DPP will come to power in the not-too-distant future, and that it will be the party most likely to represent Taiwan in negotiations with the mainland. "And if our party finally negotiates with China, it will under no circumstances sacrifice the interests or benefits of the people here."

With its latest electoral win, Chen said, the DPP's social and political responsibilities have increased profoundly, as more than 75 percent of Taiwan's population will fall under the party's jurisdiction at the local level starting on Dec. 20, when all the newly elected mayors and county magistrates are to assume office.

"Against this backdrop, the DPP must become an even more mature and accountable party," Chen said, giving the assurance that the DPP "will never fool around with" the physical safety or the property of the people of Taiwan.

Nevertheless, Chen said, the DPP will not revise its pro-independence party platform. "Once we become the ruling party, we will hold a referendum on the future of Taiwan, a commitment enshrined in the DPP platform," he said, adding that the timing and the provisions of the referendum could be determined "flexibly and pragmatically."

Touching on the DPP's cross-strait policy, Chen admitted that the party has yet to forge an internal consensus in this regard. "Similar lack of consensus can also be seen within the KMT and the (other main opposition) New Party," he noted. "I hope all the three major political parties here will first forge their own intraparty consensus on the issue before seeking a nationwide consensus."

The mayor also pointed out that he personally objects to a proposal advocated by some local business leaders that Taiwan start negotiations with mainland China for direct trade, postal and transportation links. "I support the government's current `no haste, be patient' policy toward economic ties with Beijing," he said, adding that local business executives should put overall national interests above their corporate interests.

Chen again mentioned the three prerequisites necessary before he would consider a visit to the Chinese mainland. "I would visit the mainland only in my capacity as Taipei mayor, the visit would have to be permitted by the KMT-controlled central government and it would have to comply with DPP policy," he stressed.

The mayor said that if Beijing continues to deny him a permission to visit as a popularly elected mayor of Taipei, the chances of President Lee Teng-hui making a "journey of peace" to the mainland would also be very slim.

The seminar, which was sponsored by an association of local reporters covering cross-strait relations, was held at a conference room in the offices of the Straits Exchange Foundation, a semi-official body set up by ROC authorities to handle exchanges with the mainland in the absence of official ties.

DOC.HEADLINE: ACADEMIA SINICA TO REGULATE ITS PUBLICATIONS

TEXT.P: Academia Sinica, the highest-level academic body in the Republic of China, said on Monday that it will formulate comprehensive rules to regulate the publication of study results, particularly those purely based on personal narrative, by its research fellows.

Academia Sinica President Yuan T. Lee made the remarks at a news conference held after Liu Feng-han, a researcher with the academy's Institute of Modern History, published a biography of Gen. Wen Ha-hsiung, former Commander-in-Chief of the Combined Service Force, based solely on Wen's narrative.

This narrative included harsh criticisms of the personalities of former Premier Hau Pei-tsun, ruling Kuomintang Secretary General John Chang and his wife, attracting much attention from the highly sensitive local political community.

Lee, a Nobel prize laureate, said the narrative form of recording history is a reflection of the narrator's personal feelings, and should not be confused with hard facts. "The academic value of such records is not as high as the result of objective academic study," he said, adding that narration is only one of the many ways of collecting historical facts or materials.

Speaking on the same occasion, Academia Sinica Vice President Yang Kuo-shu said the publication of oral histories should be carefully regulated to avoid potential libel or invasion of privacy of "third parties."
Yang said he will conduct discussions with officials of the Institute of Modern History to work out detailed rules to regulate such publications in future.

DOC.HEADLINE: CROSS-STRAIT SHIPPING SEMINAR OPENS IN TAIPEI

TEXT.P: In a bid to promote exchanges of shipping technology between Taiwan and mainland China, the fourth cross-strait maritime research seminar opened here on Monday, attended by more than 100 officials, academics and shipping executives from the two sides of the Taiwan Strait.

T.H. Chen, president of the Taipei-based Chinese Maritime Research Institute, and Cao Zhongxi, vice chairman of mainland China's Association for Shipping Across the Taiwan Strait (ASATS) and head of the Taiwan Affairs Office under mainland China's Ministry of Communications, co-chaired the two-day symposium.

The seminar was first held in 1994 in Xiamen, a port city in mainland China's Fujian province, and has been held every year since, hosted by each side alternately. Over the course of the meetings, consensus has gradually been reached on opening partial direct shipping links across the Taiwan Strait, with actual sailings beginning in April of this year.

Chen, who also serves as president of the Yangming Marine Transport Corp., hailed the point-to-point direct shipping which has helped boost development of bilateral trade. But he stressed that Taiwan shipping companies will abide by government policy regarding the establishment of overall direct shipping links with the mainland, and called on the authorities in Beijing to allow more ports to operate direct point-to-point shipping services connecting with Taiwan's offshore transshipment center at the southern port of Kaohsiung, which became operational in April.
Delivering a speech at the seminar, Li Jian, ASATS vice secretary general, called for the early opening of direct and full shipping traffic between Taiwan and mainland China.

Li said that the lack of full direct shipping ties is a serious problem for the shipping sectors of Taiwan and the mainland and that both sides are hopeful that such ties can be established as soon as possible. He claimed that direct ties will help shippers on both sides of the Taiwan Strait to save at least US$100 million per year in transport costs as they would no longer have to travel via Hong Kong.

Under the regulations promulgated respectively by Taipei and Beijing last year, only Kaohsiung and the Fujian ports of Xiamen and Fuzhou can handle direct shipping across the Taiwan Strait at the present time. Only six foreign-registered shippers on each side of the strait have been approved to ply the routes to transport products destined for a third country or area.

Lee Mi, a professor at National Taiwan Oceanic University, said the opening of full direct cross-strait shipping is a purely economic issue, but that political interference has distorted the issue. He said that Taiwan and mainland China should forswear ideological confrontation to jointly study the issue in a rational and professional manner for the benefit of the people of both sides.

Zhou Ting-fang, director of the business management school at mainland China's Wuhan Jiaotong University of Technology, said Taiwan's reluctance to open full direct shipping links with the mainland will jeopardize economic development on both sides of the Taiwan Strait.
The actual distance across the Taiwan Strait is only about 150 nautical miles, but the voyage amounts to 620 nautical miles if vessels are required to travel via Hong Kong, Zhou pointed out.

Taiwan- and mainland-bound products from either side of the Taiwan Strait currently must first be transported to a third party, usually Hong Kong, before they are allowed to continue to their final destination, resulting in huge losses in time and transport costs for shipping agents of both sides.

Many of the professionals and shipping representatives from both sides who are participating in the seminar called on both governments to ease regulations governing cross-strait shipping in order to help shippers overcome the existing barriers.

DOC.HEADLINE: MORE FOREIGN WORKERS DESERT THEIR JOBS

TEXT.P: The Council of Labor Affairs of the Executive Yuan said Monday that the number of foreign workers who have deserted their jobs is getting bigger, and urged Taiwan employers not to hire illegal aliens.

An official of the council said that, since January 1994, more than 21,900 foreign workers have deserted their jobs and become illegal aliens, of whom 14,522 are from Thailand, 6,433 from the Philippines, 457 from Malaysia and 547 from Indonesia.
He said that currently 9,225 such illegal aliens are still unaccounted for, including 4,873 from the Philippines, 3,871 from Thailand, 448 from Indonesia, and 33 from Malaysia.
Employers of illegal aliens shall be punished by law, he warned. (by Ed Hsieh)

DOC.HEADLINE: H.K. URGED TO EASE VISA RESTRICTIONS FOR TAIWAN VISITORS

TEXT.P: The "123 Democratic Alliance" Sunday urged the Hong Kong government to ease visa requirements for three kinds of Taiwan visitors to help revive the tourism industry.
A spokesman for the alliance said at a forum Sunday that the move can welcome back many Taiwan visitors, whose number is getting smaller in recent months.

He said visa requirements shall be eased for the following Taiwan visitors: those who have visited Hong Kong before, those who want to travel to Hong Kong with a tour group, and those who hold travel permits issued by mainland China.
He also said Hong Hong's travel association should open an office in Taiwan to promote tourism and issue visas from there. (by Chang Chien/Ed Heist)

DOC.HEADLINE: FOUR PERSONS ON PLANE INJURED AMID TURBULENCE

TEXT.P: One passenger and three flight attendants were injured Sunday when their China Airlines flight bound from the Philippines to Taiwan ran into sudden turbulence.
The China Airlines CI-636 plane was hit by unexpectedly violent winds around one hour after setting off from Manila, a spokesman for the airline said here Monday.
The turbulence caught everyone off guard, shocking passengers and knocking around the flight attendants who were then serving meals to those aboard.
Amid the more than one minute of turbulence, a 60-year-old passenger leaving a restroom and three stewardesses were injured, one in the neck, the spokesman said.
Fortunately, he said, several doctors were among the passengers on board and they set about helping treat the wounded and smoothing frightened passengers.

The injured were rushed to two local hospitals as soon as the aircraft landed at Chiang Kai-shek International Airport in northern Taiwan's Taoyuan County. All four of them returned home Sunday night after receiving medical treatment, the spokesman said.

DOC.HEADLINE: STATISTICAL PERIODICAL ISSUED BY ACADEMIA SINICA LISTED IN SCI

TEXT.P: A periodical issued by the Institute of Statistical Science of the Academia Sinica, the nation's highest-level academic body, has been listed in the 1997 edition of the Science Citation Index (SCI) published by the US-based Institute for Scientific Information (ISI).
Statistica Sinica, a quarterly magazine that first appeared in 1991, is the first Asian statistical magazine to be cited in SCI as a valuable reference for scientific research.

Wei Ching-zong, director of the Institute of Statistical Science, said on Monday that the Republic of China, Japan and India have nearly the same level of statistical research. Academic institutes of statistical science in these countries were competing each other to see whose periodical would be the first to be listed in the prestigious SCI, he noted.

Statistica Sinica, which reaches readers mainly in Taiwan and the United States, carries some 90 articles a year, Wei said, adding that the institute submitted its application to the ISI this June for the periodical to be listed in SCI.
The ISI was established by Dr. Eugene Garfield in Philadelphia, Pennsylvania in 1958. Of the variety of journals the institute publishes for reference purposes, SCI is the most renowned.

SCI, one of the ISI's Citation Index series, culls tens of thousands of periodicals to select and list the world's most important and influential journals. The articles in these select periodicals are added to a databank for the reference of researchers.
The 1997 edition of SCI includes 3,300 periodicals covering 160 categories, with the journals originating in 45 countries and areas around the world.

DOC.HEADLINE: SAUDI ARABIA REAFFIRMS SUPPORT FOR MUSLIM COMMUNITIES

TEXT.P: Saudi King Fahd said Saudi Arabia will continue to provide help to Muslims worldwide.

King Fahd noted that the meeting of the Muslim World League (MWL) comes at a time when Muslims are facing many problems around the world. He said Saudi Arabia will work to develop the MWL institutions serving Islamic causes.

MWL Secretary General Dr. Abdullah bin Salih Al-Obeid said the MWL is determined to refute biased campaigns launched against Islam, confront destructive ideologies, advocate Islamic causes and extend educational, cultural and social services to Muslims.

DOC.HEADLINE: TWO NOBEL LAUREATES MAY PLAY TENNIS TOGETHER IN TAIWAN

TEXT.P: A gala tennis match bringing together two Nobel laureates might be staged in Taiwan next March when Steven Chu, the co-winner of the 1997 Nobel Prize for Physics, visits Taiwan at the invitation of Premier Vincent Siew, since he has also been invited for a game of tennis by Yuan T. Lee, winner of the 1986 Nobel Prize for Chemistry and President of Academia Sinica, Taiwan's highest-level research organization.
At a press conference on Monday to announce Chu's visit, Lee said he would like to play tennis with Chu, although he admitted that Chu is superior to him on the court.
Lee and Chu are longtime friends who admire each other's academic achievements and tennis skills.

Chu, who won this year's Nobel prize along with two others for their work to trap atoms at temperatures approaching absolute zero, will be formally awarded the prize in the Swedish capital of Stockholm on Wednesday.
After his Taipei visit, Chu is expected to also travel to Tokyo and Hong Kong, according to Lee.

DOC.HEADLINE: TAIWAN HIT BY COLD WEATHER

TEXT.P: Snow has been falling on two of Taiwan's mountains since Sunday morning, shortly after the season's first winter cold front reached the island.

The Central Weather Bureau reported here Monday that up to 12 centimeters of snow has fallen on Yushan (Jade Mountain), the highest mountain in Taiwan, while Hohuanshan, a peak near the border between Nantou County and Hualien County, has received the same amount.

Wet and chilly weather brought by the cold front has been making people shiver islandwide, the bureau said, pointing out that the average temperature in northern Taiwan on Monday dropped to 14 degrees Celsius, while the northern coastal cities of Tamsui and Keelung both registered 12.5 C.
Weathermen with the bureau forecast temperatures will further plunge Tuesday and Wednesday, when the whole island will be blanketed by the cold front.

By that time, temperatures will have fallen to lows of 10-11 C in Taiwan's northern and central areas, while the mercury will have dropped to 13-14 C in the southern region, the forecasters said, adding that warm weather is not expected to return until Saturday.

DOC.HEADLINE: ROC AIRS ITS SUPPORT FOR DRIVE AGAINST LAND MINES

TEXT.P: The Republic of China has made known to Canada its support for the drive against land mines despite being excluded from the signing of an international anti-mine convention, and two ROC civil groups have been playing active roles in the non-official international campaign to ban the anti-personnel devices, said the Ministry of Foreign Affairs on Monday.

Because it is not represented at the United Nations, the ROC was prevented from joining the pact that was signed in Ottawa, Canada by 125 countries last week, Roy Wu, a spokesman for the ministry said.

Although Canada rather than the United Nations was the organizer of the Ottawa ceremony, Canada conducted the affair under the framework of the world body and only invited UN member states to attend, he said.

Nevertheless, Taipei has conveyed to Ottawa its support for a ban on land mines, and two Taiwan-based private groups, the Eden Social Welfare Foundation and Anti-Land Mine Network of Taiwan, took part in the forum of non-governmental organizations (NGOs) held in parallel with the conference in Ottawa.
The two Taiwan groups also signed an NGO declaration aimed at pooling private groups' resources to prohibit and clear land mines as well as to help mine victims, said Wu.

He cited the ROC's efforts last year to help its ally Honduras clear itself of mines and the Eden Foundation's promise in Ottawa to raise some US$1 million to purchase 10,000 wheelchairs for those maimed by land mines as proof of the government's anti-mine efforts.
The Eden Foundation has already contributed 500 wheelchairs to mine victims in Afghanistan and Cambodia.
Wu said that the ROC is also trying to invite Jody Williams, the Nobel Prize-winning US activist who coordinated international efforts toward the signing of the treaty against mines, to visit Taiwan.

DOC.HEADLINE: NO BAD INTENTIONS BEHIND SURVEY: KMT LEGISLATOR

TEXT.P: Legislator Chen Hung-kee of the ruling Kuomintang (KMT), who on Sunday made public the results of a survey that showed President Lee Teng-hui and Vice President Lien Chan with low approval ratings, said Monday that there were no bad intentions behind his commissioning of the poll.
Chen said the results of the Gallup Poll conducted Dec. 4-5 should serve as a reminder to the KMT that it must go ahead with further reforms to meet the ever-rising expectations of the people.

The telephone survey of 1,089 adults in the wake of local elections found that less than 37 percent of the respondents said they approve of Lee's performance over the past year, while even fewer respondents, at 34.2 percent, said they approve of Lien's performance.

Chen stressed that he doesn't think it was improper to commission a survey in the wake of the local elections that brought the KMT its first-ever loss of the majority of the 23 mayoral and county magistrate seats up for grabs.

Despite the KMT's overwhelming defeat in the local elections, Chen said that the party still has a good chance to win back the support of the people. He went on to explain that the poll showed that 21.9 percent of those interviewed said that they are pro-KMT, while 13.1 percent said they are inclined to support the opposition Democratic Progress Party.

While stressing that the survey was not ill-intentioned, Chen admitted that some of the poll questions could have been better, such as the one on the vice president's performance. Chen said that it would have been better to ask the respondents to rate Lien's "performance" rather than his "administrative performance."

Meanwhile, a high-ranking official at the Presidential Office who preferred to be unnamed said the Presidential Office has paid attention to the survey but that it has no plans to explain or clarify the low approval ratings Lee and Lien received.
The official, however, said there are too many surveys in Taiwan and that some of them do not reflect the facts, adding that the companies conducting the polls should be more objective.
That the survey was conducted following the KMT's rout in the elections might be one of the reasons why Lee and Lien did not score high approval ratings, he said.

DOC.HEADLINE: NEAR MISS BETWEEN AIRPLANES REPORTED IN HONG KONG

TEXT.P: A disastrous collision between two passenger airliners was narrowly averted last Friday when a descending Air China plane pulled up rapidly to avoid hitting a China Airlines plane that was taxying on a runway at Hong Kong's Kai Tak International Airport, said a local daily Monday.

The Chinese-language Apple Daily said Air China flight 107 from Beijing reached skies above Kai Tak airport shortly before 8 p.m. Friday. But when it tried to land, its pilot found the Taipei-bound China Airlines flight 666 preparing to take off from the runway it was bound for, the daily said.
The pilot of the Air China plane immediately took emergency action to climb and managed to avoid a disaster.
After the incident, the plane landed safely on its second try. Its pilot told the shocked passengers that a plane was moving on the runway on which his plane was cleared for landing.
The pilot used the plane's public address system to apologize for the scare but said that "it was the fault of the Hong Kong control tower, which had granted me clearance to land."
A Hong Kong official told CNA on Monday, however, that the Air China flight was not cleared for landing but rather told to "prepare for landing."

Kai Tak is the world's third busiest airport, with one airplane landing or taking-off every two or three minutes. The Hong Kong government is building a new airport on Lantau Island that is slated to open in April.

DOC.HEADLINE: TAIWAN'S LAGS BEHIND M'LAND IN SERVICES TRADE

TEXT.P: Taiwan lagged behind mainland China in terms of services imports and exports in 1995, according to the latest statistics released by the World Trade Organization (WTO).

The Republic of China's Board of Foreign Trade on Monday cited the WTO figures as indicating that in 1995 Taiwan's services exports reached US$15.4 billion, placing the island 18th among surveyed economies in the world. Mainland China ranked 16th.
Taiwan also ranked beneath Hong Kong, Singapore and South Korea, which along with Taiwan are known as the "Asian tigers" because of their vigorous economic development.
The United States was the largest exporter in the services trade in 1995, the WTO statistics showed.
In terms of imports, Taiwan's services imports amounted to US$23.8 billion, or 13th in the world. Mainland China ranked 12th. Germany registered as the largest importer in this field in the world.

DOC.HEADLINE: SOUTH AFRICA BIDS FAREWELL TO ROC AMBASSADOR
DOC.DATELINE: Johannesburg, Dec. 8 (CNA) (By J. S. Chang and Flor Wang)

TEXT.P: South African Foreign Minister Alfred Nzo hosted a party on Monday to bid farewell to Loh I-cheng, outgoing ambassador of the Republic of China, in recognition of his outstanding contribution to bilateral relations between the ROC and South Africa.

Speaking at the party attended by foreign diplomatic missions stationed in Pretoria, Nzo hailed Loh's role in leading the ROC government's participation in South Africa's reform programs and in encouraging Taiwan businesses to invest in South Africa.

Bilateral ROC-South Africa trade increased from about US$800 million annually to the current level of US$1.4 billion during Loh's tenure, while Taiwan investment in this country also increased to around US$1 billion, Nzo pointed out.
For his part, Loh expressed appreciation for the assistance the South African Foreign Ministry has extended to him since November 1990 when he assumed the office.
Loh will soon return to Taiwan after completing his ambassadorial duties. While here, he also served as the head of the foreign diplomatic missions in South Africa.

Diplomatic relations between the ROC and South Africa will be terminated after Dec. 31, 1997. South African President Nelson Mandela announced in November 1996 that Pretoria would switch diplomatic recognition from Taipei to Beijing starting Jan. 1, 1998.
