DOC.HEADLINE: LIU CHAO-SHIUAN TO BE NAMED VICE PREMIER

TEXT.P: National Science Council (NSC) Chairman Liu Chao-shiuan will be appointed to serve as the nation's vice premier, the Government Information Office (GIO) confirmed Tuesday.

The GIO said Liu will concurrently remain as NSC head for the time being, with his successor in that position to be chosen when Premier Vincent Siew reshuffles his Cabinet, which is expected to occur sometime early next year.
Liu's appointment is expected to be approved by a regular meeting of the ruling Kuomintang's Central Standing Committee on Wednesday.
He will thereupon officially take over the vice premiership from John Chang, who has been appointed as the new Kuomintang secretary-general.

Liu said Wednesday that he will focus his efforts on upgrading the nation's science and technology fields. As development in these areas requires talented professionals, he said, educational reforms also will be one of the main priorities.

Liu, 55, received a bachelor of sciences degree from National Taiwan University and a doctorate in chemistry from the University of Toronto in Canada. He has served as the minister of transportation and communications and as president of National Tsing Hua University.
The versatile Liu also wrote several kung fu action novels in his youth under the pen name "Shan Kuan Ting." Many of those works are still on the market.

Sources said that Liu was chosen over a number of other candidates, including Minister Without Portfolio Lin Feng-cheng, becuase he is younger, possesses a strong scientific background, and has good connections in educational and cultural fields, all of which could be beneficial to Premier Siew's Cabinet. Liu is close to Yuan T. Lee, president of the esteemed research institute Academia Sinica, and his brother Liu Chao-han is the president of National Central University.

The sources said that in choosing his right-hand man, Siew had ruled out candidates whose background and qualifications were similar to his own, referring to the premier's specialties in financial matters, foreign policy and mainland China affairs.
Liu stood out because Siew was also very impressed by his performance when he served at the Ministry of Transportation and Communications and at the NSC, they said.
Young and energetic, Liu is credited with initiating and coordinating many projects, including the satellite launch program, during his 18-month-stint as NSC chairman.

DOC.HEADLINE: DPP MAGISTRATE-ELECT RENEWS SUPPORT FOR REFERENDUM ON BAYER PROJECT

TEXT.P: Liao Yung-lai, Democratic Progressive Party (DPP) magistrate-elect for Taichung County in central Taiwan, said on Monday that he remains committed to holding a referendum to decide the fate of a proposed project by multinational chemical and pharmaceutical giant Bayer.

Liao, who is also the leader of a citizens' alliance opposed to Bayer's first investment project in Taiwan, stressed that his anti-pollution stance should not be misinterpreted as an "anti-business" complex. Low-pollution enterprises are welcome to set up production bases in the county, he added.

Liao also expressed dissatisfaction over alleged interference by the DPP leadership in local affairs, saying that he objects to a proposal by the party headquarters that a public hearing rather than a referendum be held in Taichung County to decide if Bayer should be allowed to set up a chemical manufacturing plant near Taichung Harbor.

Both during the recent election campaign and following his victory in the polls, Liao publicly said on several occasions that Bayer's investment plan should be subject to a referendum held in the county.

His remarks have aroused concern and uncertainty among foreign investors, evidenced by a statement issued by the European Council of Commerce and Trade in Taipei earlier this month, in which it demanded that the ROC government clarify its policy on foreign investment in Taiwan.

DPP Chairman Hsu Hsin-liang and Sisy Chen, director of the DPP's publicity department, met with executives of Bayer Taiwan Co. last week to clarify the party's stance on the referendum as part of efforts to allay foreign investors' uneasiness over the DPP position.

Chen said after the meeting that the DPP has no bias against Bayer's investment project. The party headquarters would coordinate with Liao to arrange a public hearing on the proposed chemical plant with participation by scholars, experts, Bayer officials and representatives from the citizens' group opposed to the plan, she added.

An official with Bayer's public relations department said that the first stage of the investment project has passed the central government's environmental impact evaluations, but that construction work cannot start until a land lease is obtained from the Taiwan Provincial Government.

The official said that the first stage of construction work, originally slated to begin last year, is estimated to cost NT$10 billion (US$3.15 billion) and take two and a half years to complete. The total investment value of the 10-year, three-stage project is estimated at NT$50 billion.

DOC.HEADLINE: MOJ TO CALL MEETING ON JUVENILE CRIME PREVENTION

TEXT.P: With juvenile crime increasing in both frequency and degree of seriousness, the Ministry of Justice (MOJ) announced on Tuesday it will call a meeting on Dec. 17 to discuss effective measures by which to curb the problem.

The ministry said it will invite officials from the Ministry of the Interior, the Ministry of Education and other relevant government agencies to jointly work out strategies for control of juvenile crime.

"We need better tactics to implement an effective juvenile crime prevention package," an MOJ official said, adding it is worrisome that juvenile delinquents are becoming younger and that the crimes they commit are becoming more serious.
According to MOJ tallies, the number of juveniles convicted of sex-related crimes reached 302 in the first eight months of this year, up from 197 recorded for the same period of last year.

Nevertheless, the official said gambling, drug abuse, assault and burglary have remained the most common juvenile crimes for the past 10 years, accounting for 60 percent of all convictions involving minors. "It is regretful that some adults have even used contraband drugs to manipulate young people and direct them to commit crime," he added.
The official said the MOJ will cooperate with the Ministry of Education to launch a campaign to help inculcate law-abiding concepts among the nation's youth.
The MOJ will also join forces with local prosecution offices as well as charitable and religious groups to sponsor more recreational programs for juveniles, the official added.

Meanwhile, several law professors and legal experts urged law-enforcement authorities to reinforce reformatory education and correctional services for juvenile criminals and delinquents, saying such programs are far more effective in reducing juvenile crime than the imposition of stringent sentences on underage convicts.

They pointed out that reformatory education and rehabilitation form a critical part of the juvenile penal system. They suggested that the government seek assistance from religious groups and other social organizations to help juvenile prisoners cope with grievances and rid themselves of vengeful sentiments so that they can rebuild their lives after completing their jail terms.
Two National Taiwan University law professors -- Chang Kan-mei and Ho Teh-fen -- also criticized judicial authorities for the unprecedented sentences meted out to four young rapists on Monday.

The four school dropouts were given prison terms ranging from 17 to 20 years following their conviction on sexual assault and battery charges in connection with the rape of several teenage girls earlier this year.

The two professors said the sentences were too harsh, adding that the youths' parents and the entire society should likewise bear some degree of responsibility for their crimes. "Their parents should also be penalized for failing to teach their kids proper behavioral concepts," Professor Chang said.
She further pointed out that Taiwan's educational system should be reformed in order to better socialize the younger generation and reduce juvenile crime.
Professor Ho urged all relevant government agencies to make concerted efforts to reach out to young dropouts and encourage them to continue their education.

DOC.HEADLINE: WHO: 600,000 DIE OF TYPHOID ANNUALLY

TEXT.P: The World Health Organization (WHO) announced on Monday that at least 600,000 people die of typhoid every year, 70 percent to 80 percent of whom are in Asian countries.

WHO bacteriologist Bernard Ivanoff said at the opening of the 13th Typhoid Symposium in Denpasar, Bali, Monday that typhoid also infects 16 to 33 million people a year and most of them live in developing countries.

"The typhoid bacteria grows in a place where the sanitation and hygiene systems do not function well," he was quoted by Indonesia's Antara news agency as saying. He said that this bacteria usually attacks the respiratory system.
Children 8 to 9 years old are most susceptible to this disease.
Up to now, he said, there is no vaccine to prevent this disease. "Antibiotic therapy is sufficient to treat typhoid for now."
He said the number of cases of "S. typh" (typhoid bacteria), which are resistant to antibiotics, have increased since 1990.

DOC.HEADLINE: EDITORIAL FORECASTS TROUBLE AHEAD FOR SOUTHEAST ASIA

TEXT.P: The Los Angeles Times said in an editorial Monday that Southeast Asian stock markets and currencies are in deep trouble, roiling the economies of Thailand, Malaysia, Indonesia and the Philippines, once dubbed the tigers of international trade.

"Confidence is deteriorating in the ability of the four governments to manage the situation. This is a timely alert for the region. A decade of export-driven prosperity has masked domestic problems, overheated economies and eroded financial discipline. A new game plan is needed."

The daily said: "Plentiful and cheap labor fueled the economic boom, and the business sector borrowed overseas -- where interest rates were lower -- to finance their operations and investments at home. Credit was easy, and borrowed money was plowed into real estate and construction projects. But then came the inevitable -- (mainland) China. The Asian behemoth offered its own cheap and plentiful labor to attract foreign manufacturers, and the tigers found their exports slowed by stiff competition.

DOC.HEADLINE: GOLDSMITH MUSIC MANUSCRIPTS DONATED TO ACADEMY LIBRARY

TEXT.P: Composer Jerry Goldsmith's original handwritten music sketches for more than 100 motion pictures from 1957 through 1996 have been donated to the Academy of Motion Picture Arts and Sciences' Margaret Herrick Library.
The material covers the entire range of Goldsmith's film work, from "Black Patch" (Warner Brothers, 1957), his first score, through the recently released "Congo" (Paramount, 1995).

Goldsmith's more current projects, including this year's "L.A. Confidential," "Air Force One" and "The Edge," will be added to the collection two years after each is released as part of an ongoing arrangement.
Goldsmith has been nominated for Academy Awards 16 times for his music since 1962. He won the Oscar in 1976 for his original score for "The Omen" (20th Century-Fox).
The Goldsmith collection is available by appointment to qualified scholars, students and other researchers who have a special research need.

DOC.HEADLINE: SECURITIES TRANSACTION REVENUE REACHES TARGET GOAL FOR FISCAL 1998

TEXT.P: Securities transaction revenue has reached the annual targeted goal of NT$57.2 billion (US$1.78 billion) for fiscal 1998, ending next June, the Finance Ministry announced Tuesday.

Hsu Kuo-chung, director of the Finance Ministry's Department of Statistics, said that as of Monday, the securities transaction revenue since the beginning of July has totaled NT$56.89 billion, and that if Tuesday's turnover on the stock exchange surpassed NT$100 billion, the government's fiscal 1998 target for securities transaction revenue of NT$57.2 billion will be reached much earlier than planned.

Hsu said he was pleased upon being informed that the turnover on the local bourse broke NT$100 billion at around 10:00 a.m. on Tuesday, one hour after the opening of trading. The daily turnover surged to NT$219.25 billion by the end of the day's session, the highest level since July 29.

Meanwhile, Hsu said that the total tax revenue for fiscal 1998 totaled NT$532.6 billion as of the end of November, up NT$82.1 billion or 18.2 percent from the corresponding period of the previous fiscal year.

Hsu said that during the five-month period, the tax revenue collected by the central and local governments has reached 40.2 percent of the government's targeted goal, compared with the ratio of 35.7 percent achieved during the same period of fiscal 1997.

Hsu attributed the increase in tax revenue for fiscal 1998 to a jump in securities transaction revenue. As of the end of November, the securities transaction revenue saw an increase of NT$35.8 billion over the 1997 fiscal year.

DOC.HEADLINE: TAIWAN HOPES TO INTRODUCE JAPANESE TECHNOLOGY: NEWSPAPER

TEXT.P: Council for Economic Planning and Development (CEPD) Chairman P.K. Chiang of the Republic of China told the Tokyo Shimbun that Taiwan hopes to introduce more Japanese technology.

Chiang was quoted by the Japanese-language newspaper in its Tuesday edition as saying Taiwan's business conditions remain good and its economy is expected to grow by 6.7 percent for the whole of 1997.

Chiang, however, pointed out in an interview with the newspaper in Taipei that, affected by the recent Southeast Asian financial crisis and the close of Japan's Yamaichi Securities, the New Taiwan dollar has dropped by 14 percent.

Speaking of the economic relations between the two countires, Chiang said Taiwan's trade deficit with Japan is likely to amount to US$17 billion this year. He also expressed the desire to introduce more Japanese technology into Taiwan, according to the newspaper.
The CEPD chairman was quoted by the newspaper as saying that the structure of Japan's enterprises will be more stable if the Japanese government can reduce its intervention in the business sector.

In conjunction with Chiang's interview, the Tokyo Shimbun also carried a report on downtown Taipei's Kwanghua Market, a major computer and parts retail center. It attributed the market's vitality to Taiwan's progress in industrial development, its large number of young professionals in the computer industry and the industry's ability to respond quickly to new situations.
In a related development, the Taipei-based CEPD on Monday forecast Taiwan's economic growth for 1998 at 6.7 percent, as the island's overall financial and economic climate remains positive and sound.

The CEPD said that the New Taiwan dollar should rebound to the level of 29.2 against the US unit sometime next year and that the local currency will not further depreciate so long as the South Korean won stops its sharp downward spiral. Continued devaluation of the won could stir up another round of financial crises in East Asia, the council added.

According to the CEPD, Taiwan may see a slight decline in its export volume next year, although retail prices will remain stable. It estimated that the 1998 consumer price index will increase by 3.1 percent.

DOC.HEADLINE: PRESIDENT LEE RECEIVES LEGISLATIVE ASSEMBLY LEADER OF TONGA

TEXT.P: President Lee Teng-hui Tuesday received Chief Fusitu'a, speaker and president of the Legislative Assembly of Tonga, at the Presidential Office.
President Lee told Fusitu's that the relations between the two countries are very close, and that his visit will help promote the friendly relations between the two countries.

Lee also said that the Republic of China is willing to share its experience in economic development with Tonga and help Tonga promote agricultural development. Tonga has a great potential for developing agricultural and marine products processing industries, he added.
Fusitu's arrived in Taipei with his wife Saturday for a five-day visit. (by Ed Hsieh)

DOC.HEADLINE: DRUG ABUSE AMONG TAIPEI YOUNGSTERS SERIOUS: COUNCILORS

TEXT.P: Several Taipei city councilors strongly urged the Taipei City government to resolutely crack down on drugs, saying that Taipei has become the major drug center in Taiwan.

The councilors, Chen Chin-chi, Chen Yung-teh, and Chen Chin-hsiang, made the appeal at a city council meeting on Monday as they described the wide variety of available drugs and rampant abuse of the illegal substances in Taipei.
The trio listed more than 20 drugs which they said are easily available at drugstores, in addition to marijuana or ephedrine which can be obtained from other channels.
They lambasted the government for not stringently implementing its pronounced anti-drug campaign, claiming that it has become a mere slogan.

Chen Chin-chi said an investigation he conducted with his colleagues has shown that the tranquilizer Valium has become the new drug of choice among teenagers, following the craze for FM2, sometimes referred to as the "rape pill."

Valium is commonly prescribed for relief of anxiety, insomnia and muscle cramps, but in large doses, it can cause hallucinogenic effects. As it is cheap and easily available, it has become popular with the youngsters. One tablet of Valium sells for as little as NT$10 (30 US cents), while five injectable doses of the drug sell for NT$170.
The councilors said instructions on how to manufacture your own drugs available over the Internet has further exacerbated the problem.
According to their investigation conducted in five areas of Taipei, they found that the prevalence of drug use varies from age group and consumption ability.

In Tienmu, drugs such as marijuana and cannibis are most popular, while in commercial areas surrounding Tunglin Department Store, all kinds of drugs are being used. In the posh Anho residential area, marijuana and MDMA are common.
In the Y-generation hangout of Hsimenting, the cheap Valium, FM2 and amphetamine are popular, while in areas surrounding National Taiwan Normal University, the DIY drugs are prevalent.

Chen said that their investigation has shown that drug abuse is more serious than the government is willing to admit. He demanded that officials enforce laws more strictly and make it more difficult to obtain drugs in local pharmacies.
They suggested that the Taipei City Government designate 1998 as the "Anti-Drug Year" and make an all-out effort to crack down on drugs.

Meanwhile, Chen said the councilors' survey on 1,000 people in local pubs and karaoke parlors found that 18 percent of the respondents said they have tried drugs, while 54 percent of the polled said that their friends or classmates have tried drugs and that the most common source of the drugs is from their friends.

DOC.HEADLINE: PREMIER GIVES DIRECTIVES ON NATIONAL DEFENSE

TEXT.P: Premier Vincent Siew on Tuesday demanded the Ministry of National Defense (MND) collect more information and intelligence about the Asia-Pacific situation and relations across the Taiwan Strait in the wake of Hong Kong's reversion to Beijing's rule on July 1 this year.

Siew gave the directive after a senior MND official briefed him on the highlights of the 1998 National Defense Report detailing the Republic of China's national defense policy and general military situation.

In the face of delicate changes in the overall global situation and cross-strait relations, Siew said, the MND should prudently and properly use its budget to upgrade the military's combat preparedness and defense capabilities.

The premier also directed the ministry to devote adequate manpower and financial resources to research and development of key technologies for manufacturing major weaponry systems in order to ensure self-sufficiency in the defense industry.

Noting that the ROC and even the entire Asia-Pacific region face new challenges following Hong Kong's handover, Siew asked the MND to step up gathering and analysis of information concerning mainland China's political, economic and military activities for the Cabinet's reference.

Siew also urged the MND to continue carrying out its troop reduction plan aimed at establishing an elite deterrent force. Under the plan, the military ranks will be streamlined and the total number of the armed forces will be cut to 400,000 while overall combat capability will be enhanced with improved training and professionalism. The plan is scheduled to be completed by 2001.

In view of the rising domestic crime rate, Siew ordered the MND to coordinate with the Ministry of the Interior to help train civilian law-enforcement officers in order to improve their crime-fighting capabilities.

The premier further asked the MND to study the provisions of mainland China's newly enacted defense law as reference for the Cabinet to legislate Taiwan's own national defense act. The MND has drafted a national defense organic act, which is now under the Cabinet's scrutiny.

Meanwhile, Siew said renovation of dilapidated residential communities for military dependents is one of the government's major construction projects. "The redevelopment plan is expected to help speed up urban renewal and contribute to local prosperity."

Siew ordered the MND to establish a fair, open and transparent tender system for private investors to participate in those residential community reconstruction projects. "I hope the redevelopment project can be completed in less than nine years," he added.

This is the fourth time that the MND has published a National Defense Report on the country's defense policy and general military situation. The 1998 report comprises 26 chapters in five categories -- the country's security environment and military situation; national defense policy and armed forces; defense resources and management; major MND work plans; and the military servicemen and civilian people.

DOC.HEADLINE: INVESTORS IN M'LAND SHOULD FULLY EVALUATE RISKS: CHANG

TEXT.P: Chang King-yuh, chairman of the cabinet-level Mainland Affairs Council (MAC), warned on Monday afternoon that Taiwan merchants should evaluate the political and economic risks in economic and trade relations across the Taiwan Strait before investing in the Chinese mainland.

Chang made the remarks when he met with representatives of Taiwan enterprises Monday at an MAC-sponsored seminar titled "Taiwan Merchants' Time," during which he explained the government's "no haste, be patient" policy toward Taiwan businessmen's investment in the mainland.
The seminar was attended by representatives of the Taiwan Electrical and Electronic Manufacturers Association who plan to invest in the Chinese mainland.

Chang told the Taiwan investors that Beijing's "unreasonable and impractical" policies toward Taiwan are the biggest obstacles to the development of improved cross-strait economic and trade relations.

According to polls conducted by the MAC, only about 25 percent of the people on the island hold that Taiwan investment in mainland China should be liberalized, while most people advocate maintaining the government's current policy or even adopting a more cautious stance, he said.

As to "direct shipping," which is currently forbidden in line with the policy against the "three direct links," about 60 percent said that this should only be allowed under the prerequisite of "having dignity and security," while only 10 percent said they favor an unconditional opening of cross-strait shipping, Chang said.

Taiwan investments in mainland China as of September amounted to 21,000 projects with a total value of US$12 billion, according to statistics of the Investment Commission of the Ministry of Economic Affairs. The statistics further revealed that Taiwan investment in the Chinese mainland accounts for 43 percent of Taiwanese total investment abroad in the last five years.

DOC.HEADLINE: S'PORE'S MANUFACTURING GROWTH EASED TO 6.4 PERCENT IN OCT.

TEXT.P: Singapore's overall manufacturing output in October eased to 6.4 percent growth from 13.8 percent in September, according to the Singapore Economic Development Board (EDB).

The electronics industry, a central pillar of the Singapore economy, registered a lower-than-expected output growth of 4.2 percent year-on-year in October, compared to the shining 16.3 percent expansion in September.
The petrochemicals industry, however, continued to be the strongest performer with another month of triple-digit growth in October, thanks to the ramp-up of new production, the EDB said Monday.
The petroleum industry also performed well, with 13.5 percent growth in the month, while output of machinery and equipment expanded by 17.7 percent.
But pharmaceuticals output suffered a double-digit fall for the second consecutive month while plastic products output slipped 2 percent due to the electronics slowdown.
"There was lower output of personal computers and telecommunications equipment due to fewer orders from the United States and China respectively," EDB said.
In contrast, production of semiconductors, computer peripherals and printed circuit board assemblies was higher than a year ago when the electronics slowdown had started to bite.
For the first 10 months, Singapore's electronics output was just 1.6 percent higher than in the comparable period last year.
Analysts said the figures suggested the recovery in Singapore's electronics sector remained uncertain.
October's trade figures showed that export growth of disk drives fell to 4.6 percent from September's 8.8 percent.
But the analysts pointed out that there was a calendar effect due to the Indian festival of Deepavali occurring this year in October instead of in November as it did in 1996.

The Singapore government had forecast around 7 percent economic growth this year. In the first 10 months, manufacturing -- which accounts for about a quarter of Singapore's Gross Domestic Product -- grew by 3.1 percent.

DOC.HEADLINE: TAIWAN ADOPTS FLEXIBLE TRADE POLICY TOWARD MONGOLIA

TEXT.P: Taiwan has adopted pragmatic and free trade policy to facilitate promotion of trade relations with Mongolia, a high-ranking official said Tuesday at a seminar on trade opportunities in that country.

Kao Koong-lien, chairman of the Mogolian and Tibetan Affairs Commission, said that the restrictions on trade with and investment in mainland China are now not applicable to Mongolia, and that the government will help Taiwan businessmen do business and make investment in Mongolia.

A 22-member economic and trade delegation, led by Mongolian investment official Jargalsaojam, came to Taipei Saturday to attend the seminar sponsored by the China External Trade Development Council (CETRA).

Jargalsaojam said in the seminar that the Mongolian government is offering good tax incentives to encourage foreign investment in the building of infrastructures, mining, refining, manufacturing, and other sectors.
Foreign individuals and companies can also sign contracts with the Mongolian government to acquire the right to use land for 60 years. The contracts may be renewed for another 40 years, he said.

CETRA Vice Board Chairman Wu Kuang-hsiung said at the seminar that Taiwan businessmen are encouraged to seriously consider making investment and doing business in Mongolia, and that the government will help them in this regard.

Mongolia is a good place for Taiwan businessmen to make investment and seek trade opportunities, because it is rich in natural resources and beautiful scenery, another CETRA official said at the seminar. (by Ed Hsieh)

DOC.HEADLINE: ROC, JAPANESE BUSINESS LEADERS MEET IN TAIPEI

TEXT.P: A Taiwan airline executive suggested on Tuesday that the Republic of China and Japan jointly develop Ishigaki Island near Okinawa into a transit center between Taiwan and mainland China.

TransAsia Airways Chairman Lin Chia-cheng presented the proposal at the opening session of the 25th East Asian Economic Conference, which brought together more than 240 ROC and Japanese business and industry leaders to explore possible bilateral cooperative projects in various commercial and industrial fields.
Lin said Ishigaki Island is replete with tourist resources. Due to a lack of convenient transport networks, the island has not yet attracted a large number of investors.

Lin said Japan should cooperate with Taiwan to develop the scenic island into an air transit center between Taiwan and the mainland. Taiwan still bans direct transport links with the mainland. All flight and shipping services across the Taiwan Strait must be conducted via a third place.
"The program, if realized, will benefit Japan, Taiwan and the mainland," Lin claimed.

Lin pointed out that a traveler from Taiwan has to fly 1,500 kilometers to reach mainland China's Fuzhou City via Macau. The traveler needs to fly only 800 kms to reach Fuzhou if he or she transits through Ishigaki Island. As a major transit center for mainland-bound Taiwan travelers other than Hong Kong, Macau can secure at least US$300 million in profits from Taiwan annually.

The 84-member Japanese delegation to the conference is headed by Leijiro Hattori, chairman of the Japanese Interchange Association, which was founded by Japanese authorities to handle relations with Taiwan in the absence of official ties. Among the delegates are senior executives of many large Japanese companies and major trade associations.
The 164-member ROC delegation is led by C. F. Koo, honory chairman of the Chinese National Association of Industry and Commerce.

The agenda for the three-day meeting include market-opening measures and major economic trends in the ROC and Japan; the possible impact on the Asian economy of Hong Kong's reversion to Beijing's rule; the feasibility of Taiwan and Japan launching joint investment projects in third countries under the framework of the Asia-Pacific Economic Cooperation forum; and the recent financial crises in many Asian countries.

DOC.HEADLINE: US DOLLAR UP

TEXT.P: The US dollar rose NT$0.063 against the New Taiwan dollar on the Taipei foreign exchange market Tuesday, closing at NT$31.963.
The greenback opened at the day's low of 31.874, and experienced a high of 32.
Interbank US dollar trading reached US$357.5 million.

DOC.HEADLINE: SHARE PRICES DOWN ON TAIEX

TEXT.P: Share prices ended lower on the Taiwan Stock Exchange on Tuesday, with the weighted index, the market's key barometer, losing 68.68 points to finish at 8,333.49.
The bourse opened at the day's high of 8,512.61, and had a low of 8,325.23.

Losers outnumbered gainers 301 to 132, with 43 stocks remaining unchanged. In all, 3.8 billion shares changed hands on a market turnover of NT$219.26 billion (US$6.94 billion), the highest record since July 29.

Cement issues dropped the most at 2.3 percent, followed by textile stocks at 1.7 percent, construction shares at 1.5 percent, electrical engineering stocks at 1 percent, paper-making and financial issues at 0.7 percent, respectively, and plastic and chemical shares at 0.2 percent.
Foodstuff stocks rose 0.5 percent.

The 10 listed companies with the largest turnovers were United Micro Electronics, ACER, Mosel Vitelic, Taiwan Semiconductor Manufacturing, Winbond Electronics, China Steel, China Develop, Taiwan Styrene Monomer, Grand Petrochemical, and A.D.I..

DOC.HEADLINE: 'CERTAIN POWER' AFTER EARLY SEVERANCE OF ROC-RSA TIES: HU

TEXT.P: A "certain power" exerted pressure on Pretoria in early November, trying to persuade South Africa to sever its formal diplomatic relations with the Republic of China ahead of schedule, Foreign Affairs Minister Jason Hu disclosed on Tuesday.
The attempt, devised to humiliate Taipei, was aborted after ROC diplomats in South Africa made timely and concerted efforts to turn the situation around, Hu said.
South African President Nelson Mandela announced in November 1996 that Pretoria will switch diplomatic recognition from Taipei to Beijing at the end of 1997.

Taipei and Pretoria have held several rounds of working-level negotiations on future bilateral relations during the past 10 months. The two sides basically have reached a consensus and an understanding on the ending of formal ties.
Hu, however, admitted that the two sides have had major differences on certain issues during the negotiations.

For example, he said, Pretoria refused to allow the ROC to continue to be referred to by its official name and for the ROC flag to be flown in South Africa after Jan. 1, 1998, even though Taipei had made these requests "based on international practices that certain principles remain applicable under the circumstances of no diplomatic ties."

During the negotiations, Taipei also expressed that it would like to maintain its consulates general -- located in Johannesburg, Cape Town and Durban -- after the two countries cease diplomatic ties on Dec. 31.
Pretoria eventually agreed to allow the three offices to remain open under different names, said Hu.

Regarding the "certain power" that tried to undermine Taipei-Pretoria ties, Hu disclosed that a minister from the People's Republic of China headed a large-scale mainland Chinese trade and business mission to South Africa in early November.

The mainland Chinese mission, which flashed a lot of cash by placing purchasing orders worth about US$450 million and promising a similar amount in soft loans to South Africa, was reportedly aimed at getting Pretoria to advance the date of its severance of formal ties with Taipei by 50 days, he said.
Hu, meanwhile, noted that Beijing's pressure tactics weren't entirely successful. "Otherwise, the outcome would be different today," he said.
Pretoria has tried its utmost to ward off Beijing's improper interference, he said.
He also praised ROC Ambassador to South Africa Loh I-cheng and his staff for their unselfish and painstaking efforts during the final negotiations, saying that they did their best.

DOC.HEADLINE: ABDUCTED MARINE POLICE OFFICER TO BE RETURNED

TEXT.P: A Taiwan marine police officer who was abducted to mainland China by mainland fishermen nearly two months ago is scheduled to return to Taiwan on Wednesday, the Straits Exchange Foundation (SEF) reported on Tuesday.

"Chuang Chen-yao will leave (the city of) Fuzhou for Hong Kong via air tomorrow afternoon and is expected to arrive in Taipei later that evening," SEF Deputy Secretary General Lee Ching-ping told a news conference.

"Legal Service Department Director You Jui-teh left for Fuzhou this morning to accompany Chuang home," Lee said, adding that You reached agreement on Monday via phone and fax with He Zhungshen, a senior official with the Fujian Red Cross Society, on terms for Chuang's return.

According to the agreement, reached after several rounds of difficult negotiations, Taiwan will give a sum of money to certain mainland Chinese fishermen who were allegedly injured by Chuang. Lee said the fund will be called neither "compensation money" as the mainland had demanded, nor "consolation money," as Taiwan had insisted.

Lee said the undisclosed sum includes payment for medical bills incurred by the mainland fishermen. "Except for a receipt, the two sides will not sign any other agreements or documents concerning the incident," he added.

Lee also said that firearms stolen from Chuang by the fishermen will not be returned along with him. The mainland side has promised to deliver the firearms to authorities on Taiwan-held Matsu Island in the near future, when it dispatches a boat to the island to take back detained illegal mainland immigrants.

Chuang was abducted to Fuzhou, in mainland China's southeastern Fujian province, on Oct. 11 while he was performing a routine search of a mainland fishing boat caught illegally operating in ROC territorial waters near Matsu, which lies closer to the mainland than to Taiwan.

Lee said Chen Zidong, director of the Taiwan Affairs Office under the Fujian government, has promised to handle cross-strait fishing disputes more seriously in the future. "Chen, who is currently in Taiwan to attend a seminar on improving cross-strait shipping services, also agreed to restrict mainland fishermen from intruding into waters off the coasts of Taiwan and its offshore islands," Lee said.
Chen paid a visit to Lee on Tuesday morning at the SEF headquarters. The SEF is a semi-official body founded by Taiwan authorities to handle cross-strait exchanges in the absence of official ties.

DOC.HEADLINE: NO US POLICY CHANGES TOWARD TAIWAN: DPP HEAD
DOC.DATELINE: Washington, Dec. 8 (CNA) (By Herman Pan and Flor Wang)

TEXT.P: Democratic Progressive Party (DPP) Chairman Hsu Hsin-liang said on Monday that US officials have made it clear to him that there have been no changes in US policy toward Taiwan, as Washington has no intention of pushing Taiwan to hold negotiations with mainland China, nor has it worked out an addition to its "three no's policy" in its dealings with Taiwan.

Speaking at a news conference on Monday night, Hsu said US officials have explained to him that the US has simply expressed the hope that the two sides of the Taiwan Strait can resume talks as early as possible.

Hsu said the DPP has been worried that the US might have adjusted its policy toward Taiwan, ever since the US State Department stressed the Clinton Administration's "three no's policy" following the meeting between US President Bill Clinton and mainland China's President Jiang Zemin in late October.
The US's "three no's policy" is that it will not support either "two Chinas" or "one China, one Taiwan," nor will it back Taiwan independence or the island's bid to rejoin the United Nations.

Parris Chang, the DPP's representative stationed in the US, said the US side also has assured him that there is not a "fourth no policy" toward Taiwan, countering a rumor which claims that the US will not help Taiwan with its national defense if the DPP becomes the ruling party on the island. He noted that the DPP has demanded that the US provide Taiwan with military support when necessary.

In response to a question on recent remarks by President Lee Teng-hui during an interview with the Washington Post that Taiwan is already an independent, sovereign country, Hsu said Lee's comments were just a reflection of reality and that "the DPP totally agrees with Lee in this regard."

The pro-Taiwan independence party chairman said the DPP's mainland China policy is forward-thinking, but that it remains consistent in always calling for improvement in Taiwan's relations with mainland China.

Many people are concerned about Taiwan's increased economic exchanges with mainland China, Hsu said, but pointed out that economic activities simply will not be curbed by political means. He also repeated his support to the establishment of direct trade, transport and postal links across the Taiwan Strait, saying that such links will benefit both sides.
Earlier in the day, Hsu also met with Richard Bush, chairman of the Washington-based American Institute in Taiwan (AIT), to exchange opinions on issues of mutual concern.
The AIT was set up to handle bilateral exchanges with Taiwan after the two countries cut diplomatic relations in 1979.
Hsu arrived in Washington on Sunday and is scheduled to continue on to Los Angeles on Wednesday before flying back to Taiwan on Saturday.

DOC.HEADLINE: MAINLAND TRADE OFFICIAL CALLS FOR COOPERATION WITH TAIWAN

TEXT.P: An Chengxin, vice chairman of the China Council for the Promotion of International Trade in Beijing, said here Tuesday that he hopes to increase the exchanges between his council and Taiwan's China External Trade Development Council (CETRA).
For example, he said, he hopes the two organizations can cooperate in making preparations for participation in international trade exhibitions.
"We can talk about anything that may help promote our economic and trade development," he added.
The mainland Chinese trade promotion official arrived here Monday at the head of a 20-member trade delegation for a 10-day visit at the invitation of CETRA.

While here, the delegation will call at Taiwan's trade promotional organizations, including CETRA, the Chinese National Federation of Industries, and the General Chamber of Commerce of the Republic of China. It will also visit Taiwan's leading enterprises, the Hsinchu Science-based Industrial Park, and the Kaohsiung Harbor in southern Taiwan.
His council is a civil organization with branch offices in 42 mainland Chinese cities and provinces. (Ed Hsieh)

DOC.HEADLINE: PHILIPPINE NAVY ARRESTS ALLEGED M'LAND POACHERS

TEXT.P: Philippine naval officers boarded two mainland Chinese ships off the northern Philippines, arresting 34 mainland Chinese fishermen and seizing tons of illegally caught fish, the Philippine navy said Tuesday.
Cmdr. Ponciano Manalang, chief of the northern naval forces, said three navy patrol boats chased the vessels flying mainland Chinese flags early Friday morning near Inlet, Pasulin, Ilocos Norte.
Manalang said the fishermen, who will be charged this week with unlawful entry and illegal fishing, had on board 45 tons of fish illegally caught in Philippine waters.
Manalang said authorities were still waiting for an interpreter who could enable them to communicate with the fishermen.

DOC.HEADLINE: ENVIRONMENTAL PROTECTION, ECONOMIC DEVELOPMENT EQUALLY IMPORTANT

TEXT.P: A high-ranking economics official on Tuesday said that environmental protection and economic development are of equal importance and that the government should support those enterprises that have observed the government's rules on environmental impact evaluations in their investment projects.

Economics Vice Minister Yiin Chii-ming was referring to a planned investment project in central Taiwan's Taichung County by Bayer Taiwan Co. and a proposed industrial zone in Chiku in Tainan County. Both projects are facing strong opposition from some local residents.

Liao Yung-lai, Democratic Progressive Party (DPP) magistrate-elect for Taichung County, has insisted that a referendum will be held in his county to decide the fate of the Bayer project, while scuffles broke out Monday between police and some of the hundreds of Chiku residents who gathered to protest a visit to the site of the industrial zone by economics officials.

Yiin said that the first stage of Bayer's investment project has passed the government's environmental impact evaluation, while the industrial zone's possible effect on the local environment is still being studied.

Yiin said that the proposed Ping Nan Industrial Zone, which would be a base mainly for petrochemical and steel firms, is the largest industrial zone development project in Taiwan and has a total investment value reaching NT$337.7 billion (US$10.6 billion).

The industrial zone was jointly proposed by the Yiehlung Group and Tuntex Group some three years ago, but the application for an environmental impact evaluation was rejected in May 1995 on the grounds that it failed to meet the required procedures. The application was resubmitted in June this year.

The Ministry of Economic Affairs will work to help local residents and environmentalists understand the government's regulations regarding environmental impact evaluations, he said, adding that if people have questions about the regulations, the ministry and the cabinet-level Environmental Protection Administration are willing to discuss the issue further.

DOC.HEADLINE: AIDC SUCCESSFULLY COMPLETES MD-95 TAIL SECTION

TEXT.P: The first completed tail section of the MD-95 twin-engine 100-seater passenger aircraft, which is designed, built and assembled by Taiwan's Aerospace Industrial Development Corporation (AIDC), was unveiled in Taichung on Tuesday.

Introducing the new creation to the public, Economics Minister Wang Chih-kang said the project, which grew from a cooperation agreement between the AIDC and the US aircraft maker Boeing, shows that Taiwan's aerospace industry has proved its qualifications and ability to build commercial passenger aircraft.

He also pointed out that his ministry has targeted the development of the precision industry sector on the island as a priority, revealing that ministry experts have estimated that the sector could create an annual production value of over NT$300 billion (some US$9.49 billion). The aerospace industry is the key player in this sector.

The AIDC, originating from the military-run Aero-Industry Development Center which built Taiwan's locally-designed Indigenous Defense Fighter (IDF), is currently under the jurisdiction of the Ministry of Economic Affairs, but is scheduled to become fully privatized within the next three years.

In Feb. 28, 1996, the state-run corporation won the contract for designing, manufacturing and assembling the MD-95 tail section, which was developed in 1995 by McDonnell Douglas, another American airplane manufacturer incorporated by Boeing in July.
Boeing estimates that there will be a market demand for 610-1,200 MD-95s in the future.

The AIDC-built tail section will be transported to a McDonnell Douglas plant in the United States on Jan. 13, where final assembly of the aircraft will take place. The AIDC has been contracted to manufacture a total of 50 of the MD-95 tail units.

DOC.HEADLINE: DEPRECIATING KOREAN WON DEEPENS ROC DEFICIT

TEXT.P: The depreciating Korean won, which fell further against the US dollar on Tuesday, reaching a low of 1,400 won to the greenback, is widening Taiwan and South Korea's trade gap in favor of Seoul, according to officials from the Council for Economic Planning and Development (CEPD).

Should the won continue to fall, the difference in value between the New Taiwan dollar and the Korean currency will continue to widen, resulting in a greater trade imbalance between the two countries, CEPD officials noted.

Taiwan exported US$2.21 billion-worth of commodities to South Korea in the first 11 months of this year, down 9.2 percent from the year-earlier level, while importing US$4.59 billion-worth of goods from South Korea, up 20.8 percent from the same period of the previous year.
As a result, Taiwan incurred a deficit of US$2.38 billion with South Korea during the 11-month period, marking a four-year deficit high and an increase of 73.7 percent over the year-earlier level.

However, the officials were quick to point out that the deficit, even if it continues to rise, will not be a major headache for Taiwan, since South Korea has never been a significant trading partner of this country.

Two-way trade between Taiwan and South Korea, which has averaged around US$6-7 billion per year for the last few years, accounts for only about 3 percent of Taiwan's entire foreign trade, which totals about US$220 billion annually.

DOC.HEADLINE: LOCAL ELECTIONS ARE NOT A REFERENDUM ON TAIWAN INDEPENDENCE

TEXT.P: Visiting ROC Government Information Office (GIO) chief David Tawei Lee on Monday told American press executives in Washington that Taiwan's recent round of local elections should not be regarded as a referendum on Taiwan independence.
Lee made the remarks during a visit to the offices of the Washington Post and USA Today, two mass-circulation American newspapers.

Talking about Taiwan's Nov. 29 city mayor and county chief elections, Lee said the issues which arose in pre-election debates related mainly to the fields of environmental protection, social security, crime and social welfare and did not focus so much on questions regarding the ROC's political status and foreign links.

According to surveys, some 85 percent of the population of Taiwan have expressed their desire to see the island's status quo being maintained, while 60 percent have said they are in no hurry to decide their position on independence or national unification, Lee noted.

DOC.HEADLINE: DEFENSE MINISTRY COMMENT ON REPORTS OF BEIJING'S MIL. DISMANTLING

TEXT.P: A spokesman for the Ministry of National Defense said on Tuesday that he has no knowledge of reported Beijing plans to dismantle all of its major military regions apart from the Nanjing "War Region."

Local media recently reported that Beijing has decided to cut its People's Liberation Army (PLA) by 500,000 and to dismantle its major military regions after 1998 with the exception of the Nanjing War Region, which will be placed under the direct jurisdiction of the Communist Party of China's Central Military Commission (CMC).
Military spokesman Maj. Gen. Kung Fan-ting said the reported 500,000-man downsizing plan is actually part of a PLA program which has been underway since 1995.

Kung said that following the collapse of the former Soviet Union, Beijing has reached agreement with members of the Commonwealth of Independent States (CIS) on long-standing border disputes, freeing itself of the military threat from the north.

Under these circumstances, Beijing is now able to shift its military emphasis from the northern to its southeastern coastal area, as was evidenced by a CMC move in 1993 to designate the area as a "potential military flashpoint."

During last year's missile crisis in the Taiwan Strait, which saw Beijing launch test missiles into waters near Taiwan to intimidate the ROC people in the run-up to the island's first direct presidential election, the CMC went even farther, upgrading the Nanjing Military Region to the "Nanjing War Region," with Taiwan as its hypothetical enemy, Kung noted.

Kung pointed out that in addition to increasing its purchases of advanced military weapons and equipment from foreign countries, Beijing has aggressively developed the so-called four major battle skills -- landing, parachuting, urban warfare and mountain warfare -- and has established a rapid response force.

This military buildup, along with remarks by mainland China's President Jiang Zemin during his recent meeting with US President Bill Clinton that Beijing will not renounce its use of force against Taiwan, fully demonstrates that the mainland has not reduced its hostility towards Taiwan, Kung said.

He said that in the face of the military threat from Beijing, the ROC armed forces, in addition to continuing to monitor the PLA's deployment, have adopted necessary measures, including modernizing its navy and air force, to maintain its ability to deter Beijing's adventurism.

DOC.HEADLINE: US ROLE IN THE INTERNATIONAL BAIL-OUT FOR SOUTH KOREA

TEXT.P: The US$55 billion rescue package for South Korea is easily the largest in the International Monetary Fund's 50-year history, according to reports from the Geneva-based World Trade Organization (WTO) on Tuesday.

It exceeds the famous bail-outs for Mexico in the 1990s, several Latin American countries in the 1980s and the UK in the 1970s. It also comes at a time when the fund has arranged bail-outs worth US$37 billion for Indonesia and US$17 billion for Thailand, the WTO report pointed out.

It is not just the financial scale of the response that is so striking, but its geographical breadth. For the first time since the Asian crisis broke this summer, European governments are to contribute a small but symbolic amount to the package. They, along with the US, Japan, Canada and Australia, are to provide a "second line of defense," ready if needed, to supplement the main IMF loan of US$21 billion, World Bank funds of US$10 billion and an Asian Development Bank advance of US$4 billion.

Officials of the IMF and the US were anxious to play down expectations that the signing of the Korean agreement marks a turning point in the Asian financial crisis. But they are clearly hoping that such an unprecedented show of strength will surely stop the rot and begin the process of recovery.
"It was our judgment, with increasing force over the last two weeks, that it was important the Korean authorities move quickly," the WTO report quoted a senior US Treasury official as saying.

The US and the IMF certainly need this Korean mega-deal to be a success because it is the most serious test yet of the strategy for dealing with the financial crisis that continues to rage over much of Asia. For although criticism so far of the US and the IMF has been muted, there are signs of growing discontent in Washington and elsewhere with the strategy they have pursued.

The defenders of the strategy argue that it is the right one for dealing with the modern world economy -- an era of globalized capital markets, rapid technological change that enables billions of dollars to be transferred between countries at a moment's notice, and economic interdependency that makes even the once mighty US economy vulnerable to shocks from emerging markets.

The Asia crisis represents "the first 21st century financial crisis in terms of the speed at which it has been propagated" throughout the world, the WTO report quoted a senior US official as saying. "It is to be hoped that the changes we are introducing will help to produce a 21st century economy."

DOC.HEADLINE: SINGAPORE'S ECONOMY PREDICTED TO GROW 5.4 PERCENT IN 1998

TEXT.P: Economists in Singapore have forecast an average 5.4 percent growth for Singapore's economy next year.
The latest forecast remains well within the official 5 to 7 percent range, which the Singapore government has said it now plans to review.

Most of the 13 economists polled by The Straits Times newspaper on Monday said they will not revise their forecasts yet, despite the government plans for a review in light of the South Korean financial crisis, saying that their forecast already takes that crisis, as well as the other factors affecting growth, into account.
However, the forecast of 5.4 percent is lower than the 5.9 percent indicated by an earlier poll in mid-November, which was itself lower than the 7 percent forecast in October.
The forecast for this year's growth remains unchanged at 7.1 percent.

DOC.HEADLINE: ROC ENVOY BRIEFS CANADIAN CONGRESSMEN ON BILATERAL TIES

TEXT.P: Fang Chin-yen, the Republic of China's representative to Canada, hosted a dinner on Monday night in honor of members of the Canada-Taiwan Parliamentary Friendship Group, and briefed them on the prospects for bilateral ties, as well as on Taiwan's current situation and its ties with mainland China.

The 63-member group, which has recently reorganized and elected Ontario Congressman Paul Szabo as its president, is the largest bilateral group in the Canadian Congress formed to improve relations with foreign countries.
ROC Legislator Lee Yeou-chi, president of its counterpart group in Taipei, sent his congratulations to Szabo on his election.

At the dinner party, Fang described the ties between Taipei and Beijing as being paradoxically "close and distant" -- close, because both parties are eager to talk with the other, distant because they are far apart in their views of the so-called "one China" which they both claim to pursue.

Although there is only "one China," the de-facto ROC ambassador told his audience, it is an indisputable fact that China has been a divided country since 1949, with two separate governments on different sides of the Taiwan Strait.
Beijing claims that it represents the whole of China and that Taiwan is part of it, said Fang, asking: "How can cross-strait dialogue be conducted if we are already part of China?"

Demanding that Taiwan negotiate from a position of servility rather than on an equal footing with mainland China is no less than demanding "our dissolution or disappearance," said Fang, stressing that any negotiations should take place from a position of parity.

Noting that Canadian congressmen are reluctant to support publicly the idea of "a divided China ruled by two separate governments" because of Ottawa's policy of recognizing Beijing as the sole legitimate government of China, Fang prodded his audience to promote pragmatic ties with Taiwan in parallel with Canada's official relations with Beijing.

After emerging from the shadow cast by the controversial detention of seven Taiwan crewmen from the cargo ship "Maersk Dubai" on charges of throwing two Romanian stowaways overboard, Fang said Taipei and Ottawa should focus their efforts on bilateral economic and cultural exchanges.
The seven crewmen were extradited to Taiwan on March 21 to stand trial here.

DOC.HEADLINE: RUMORS ABOUT SUHARTO'S DEATH DENIED

TEXT.P: Minister and State Secretary Moerdiono has denied rumors that President Suharto has died or is hospitalized.

"Pak Harto (the president) smiled to hear those rumors. I want to deny the rumors that Pak Harto has passed away or has moved from... the presidential residence to a hospital," Antara quoted the minister as saying on Tuesday.
Moerdiono said he meets regularly with the president to report on important matters while he is "resting."

He said the president keeps abreast of important developments which occur in the country, although when asked whether the president will attend the ASEAN Informal Summit in Kuala Lumpur on Dec. 14-15, Moerdiono said: "I am sorry for not asking him about the matter."
He said the president has also asked the Monetary Council, ministers and high-ranking officials in the economic sector to continue and intensify the monetary reformation program he recently ordered.

DOC.HEADLINE: TAIWAN RANKS THIRD IN ECONOMIC RISK SURVEY

TEXT.P: Taiwan ranks third among 97 developing nations surveyed by Britain's Economist magazine in terms of investment risk, ROC economic officials said on Tuesday.

In its third quarter report on investment risk, the Economist Intelligence Unit (EIU) listed Singapore as the least risky place for investors, followed by Spain and Taiwan, respectively, said Lin Neng-jong, director for investment affairs under the Ministry of Economic Affairs.

Among the major Asian countries and areas, Hong Kong came in 7th place, South Korea in eighth, Malaysia in 14th, Thailand in 20th, mainland China in 31st, the Philippines in 33rd, Indonesia in 42nd and Vietnam in 48th.
The report rates investment risk in developing countries using the criteria of political risk, economic policy risk, economic structure and the liquidation risk, said Lin.
The economic policy risk category takes into account each country's monetary policy, financial policy, policy on foreign exchange rates, trade policy and legal policy.

Lin said that Taiwan, which has remained relatively unaffected by the current Asian financial crisis, is a hot-spot of foreign investment, with many foreign firms exploring the possibility of venturing into Taiwan.

In the first ten months of this year, Taiwan registered 549 foreign investment projects with a total investment value of US$3.48 billion, 83.22 percent more than that of same period of last year, said Lin.

DOC.HEADLINE: TAIWAN BUSINESSES URGED TO INVEST IN MONGOLIA

TEXT.P: Mongolian and Tibetan Affairs Commission Chairman Kao Koong-lian on Tuesday encouraged Taiwan businesses to invest in Mongolia, saying the Republic of China government has decided to adopt a pragmatic and flexible economic policy toward that country.

Speaking at a seminar co-sponsored by the commission and the China External Trade Development Council (CETRA) to introduce Mongolia's investment climate to the local business community, Kao expressed the hope that Mongolia and the ROC can sign agreements to strengthen bilateral trade and commerce relations and to establish regular channels of communications on trade issues.
The ROC government also welcomes Mongolia to open a trade office in Taiwan, which Kao said would give a boost to bilateral economic exchanges.

CETRA Vice President K.H. Wu said Taiwan businesses should consider investing in Mongolia, which is rich in natural and tourism resources, and that the government is willing to provide assistance to resolve difficulties for them.
Currently, there are only six Taiwan businesses operating in Mongolia. Bilateral trade between Taiwan and Mongolia has remained less than US$600,000 annually.
A 22-member trade promotion delegation composed of Mongolian officials in charge of trade, tourism and transportation affairs arrived earlier this week to take part in the seminar.
