DOC.HEADLINE: CROSS-STRAIT SEMINAR ON BROADCASTING SEEKS MORE EXCHANGES

TEXT.P: A seminar on the exchange of broadcasts across the Taiwan Strait entered its second day Tuesday in Taipei, with representatives from both Taiwan and mainland China seeking to increase such exchanges and cooperation in the field of broadcasting.
Participants from both sides agreed that the influence and potential of broadcasting have always been underestimated, but they said the field's prospects are still bright.

The broadcasting trends of the future will be narrowing the focus of individual programs in order to zero in on specific demographic and geographic groups and building strategic alliances with multimedia firms so as to get the upper hand in the face of stiff competition, they said.

Guo Baoxin, deputy director and secretary general of mainland China's TV and Broadcasting Association, remarked that radio stations in the mainland have already focused their programming more, which he said has led the number of stations there specialized in certain fields -- such as music, news or information related to transportation -- to mushroom in recent years.

Introducing new technology to systems is also important to broadcast media's future, he said. "A star in the sky, a network on the ground," a slogan widespread in the Chinese mainland, vividly depicts the significance of wedding broadcast systems with satellite and computer networks, Guo added.
Representatives of both sides are eager for the exchange of radio programs as well, he noted.

DOC.HEADLINE: CANADA URGED TO IMPROVE IMMIGRATION SERVICES IN TAIWAN

TEXT.P: Canada's immigration services in Taiwan, Hong Kong and mainland China will be discussed between MP Sophia Leung and Lucienne Robillard, minister of citizenship and immigration, when they meet Wednesday in Ottawa.

The backlog and consequent waiting period for many applicants for Canadian visas will likely be one of the issues discussed between the first Chinese-Canadian woman MP and the woman minister, Leung's aides said Tuesday.

Leung is a member of the House of Commons Standing Committee on Citizenship and Immigration. She has long shown a special concern over the high rate of refusal for students and sponsored applicants from mainland China as well as the long waiting period for Business Investment Program applicants from Taiwan. Some applicants have complained they had to wait two years before receiving a decision.

Meeting Robillard on these issues is "part of her on-going work to improve (Canada's) immigration services," the aides said. At the meeting, Leung will be joined by two leaders of the United Chinese Community Enrichment Services Society of Vancouver, who will relate to the minister examples of frustration felt by many of the group's members.

Leung is also expected to raise the issue of why the Canadian government has not set up an immigration office in Taiwan. Taiwan applicants currently have to fly to other countries for interviews, an unnecessary hardship that also delays the processing of the applications, she pointed out.
If Robillard cites budget constraints, Leung said she will argue that revenues from processing tourist and student visas in Taiwan are more than enough to maintain an immigration office there.

Other Canadian MPs have called for a 14-day visa-free treatment for Taiwan visitors to Canada, whose citizens already enjoy that privilege on trips to Taiwan. Taipei lawmakers have repeatedly asked their Ottawa counterparts to urge the Canadian government to reciprocate.

In 1996, Hong Kong, mainland China and Taiwan were the top, third and fourth-largest sources of immigrants in Canada. As many as 29,954 Hong Kong people, 17,530 mainland Chinese and 13,205 Taiwanese emigrated to Canada last year.

DOC.HEADLINE: SUZHOU INDUSTRIAL PARK PROBLEM WILL BE RESOLVED: LEE KUAN YEW

TEXT.P: Singapore Senior Minister Lee Kuan Yew has expressed confidence that the difficulties facing the Suzhou Industrial Park (SIP) will be resolved, saying mainland China's central government does not give promises lightly and will make good on what it pledges, The Straits Times reported Wednesday in a dispatch from Guangzhou.

Noting that mainland Chinese President Jiang Zemin had said that he would instruct mainland Chinese Vice Premier Li Lanqing to work with Singapore's Deputy Prime Minister Lee Hsien Loong to resolve the issue, he was quoted as saying, "I believe the problem will be resolved."
Jiang, he added, had told him during talks on Monday in Beijing that the Suzhou problem was one that could be solved.

In addition, Jiangsu Governor Zheng Silin had assured him that the views and policies of the central government must prevail over those of the provinces. "China is a big country. If the center does not prevail, how can it govern?" the governor was quoted as telling the senior minister. Lee added that once mainland China's central government focused its attention on a problem, it would work on it.

Lee was answering questions from Singapore reporters on Monday in Beijing after a dinner hosted by mainland Chinese Vice Premier Zhu Rongji, the report said. Earlier in the day, Lee had held talks with both Jiang and Zhu.

Lee's comments came four days after he had expressed dissatisfaction with the progress of the SIP, a Singapore joint venture with the mainland Chinese government to build a 70-square-kilometer modern township in the strategic city on the Yangtze River.
The Suzhou municipal government was said to be less than wholehearted in supporting the project, preferring to give priority to its own industrial park in the Suzhou New District, the report said.

Lee noted on Monday that Jiang had reaffirmed his commitment to the SIP when he met Singapore Prime Minister Goh Chok Tong in May this year. "He meant he wanted the SIP to succeed, not any other park in Suzhou, and not even any other Singapore project in China. And he meant it sincerely," Lee was quoted as saying.

He stressed that it was not only the credibility of the Singapore government that was at stake but also that of the mainland Chinese government in endorsing the SIP "at a very high level" in 1994. The SIP's top policy-making body is the Joint Steering Committee co-chaired by Li Lanqing and Lee Hsien Loong.

Noting several incidents that showed the Suzhou municipal government giving more backing to its own Suzhou New District than to the Beijing-backed SIP, Lee Kuan Yew was quoted as saying, "You are challenging the credibility and worth not just of the joint effort, but of the whole government."
These incidents included a Suzhou vice-mayor telling some German investors last month that they should put their investments in the New District and not the SIP, the report said.

Asked how what he called the "tug-of-war for investments" could be resolved, Lee was quoted as replying: "There must only be one team. Either we freeze the SIP and let the New District go, or we freeze the New District and let the SIP go.
"Why be divided? We are only wasting time and resources. Even if we don't lose as a result of the competition, which is unlikely, it'll be only half as good."

DOC.HEADLINE: S'PORE TO BECOME CNBC'S REGIONAL HEADQUARTERS

TEXT.P: Singapore will be the Asian headquarters of the new cable and satellite business news television service created by the merger of Asia Business News (ABN) and CNBC Asia.
CNBC Asia, operated by NBC, a US-based media company, will shut its Hong Kong production office as part of its merger with Dow Jones & Co Inc.'s Singapore-based ABN.
The new channel will be operated under the CNBC brand from February 2, 1998.
The merger will be mirrored in Europe, where Dow Jones European Business News and CNBC Europe will join at a cost of some 76 jobs.
The mergers will also cut about 20 jobs in the United States. Retrenched staff worldwide have been offered four months' severance pay.

In Singapore, where ABN has been headquartered since 1993, up to 10 jobs will be lost in distribution. CNBC Asia's Hong Kong operation, however, will bear the brunt of the pain with 150 layoffs, mainly in the editorial and production departments, the company said.
Dow Jones' broadcast operations and CNBC had been reported to be losing US$88 million annually, and the merger had been expected for over a year.

DOC.HEADLINE: NEGOTIATIONS OVER TAIWAN HIGH SPEED RAILWAY COMPLETED

TEXT.P: A ground-breaking ceremony for Taiwan's first high-speed railway will be held at Linkou, Taipei County on Dec. 30, the Taiwan High Speed Railway Consortium (THSRC) announced on Wednesday.
The consortium made the announcement shortly after it completed negotiations with the Bureau of the High-Speed Railway under the Ministry of Transportation and Communications (MOTC).

The two parties put the final touches on two agreements -- one on the construction and operation of the high-speed railway and the other on the development of railway stations -- on Wednesday, following many rounds of difficult negotiations.

According to the terms of the agreements, the consortium must complete construction of the 345-km Taipei-Kaohsiung high-speed railway by mid-2003. The contractor will be entitled to operate the railway for the first 35 years and to manage the railway stations along its length for the first 50 years.

The new railway is the first domestic public construction project to be open to private investors under the build-operate-transfer (BOT) formula, in which private contractors build the system and operate it for a specified period of time before transferring control to the government.
The MOTC and the THRSC are scheduled to formally sign the two accords early next year.

MOTC officials said that although the two agreements are separate, they are still connected to some extent, since if the consortium is deprived of construction/operation rights for the railway, its rights to manage the stations will also be invalidated.

The provisions also stipulate that if the MOTC delays in making land available to the consortium for construction of the railway, the contractor will not be allowed to apply for compensation, but will be able to apply for an extension of the 35-year operating period.

The agreements further say that the MOTC will reserve the right to develop three additional stations at Miaoli, Changhua and Yunlin for the time being, and that the two parties may negotiate this issue at a later date.

The THSRC, comprised of five Taiwan companies and two European firms -- GEC Alsthom S.A. and Siemens Aktiengeselschaft -- beat out the Chunghwa High-Speed Railway Consortium -- a Taiwan-Japanese joint venture -- to win the right to build the high-speed railway, which carries a price tag of about NT$441.9 billion (US$13.9 billion).

The Bureau of the High-Speed Railway said the MOTC will not refund the Chunghwa High-Speed Railway Consortium its NT$400 million tender deposit until it formally signs the BOT agreements with the THSRC early next year.

DOC.HEADLINE: SHARE PRICES SKYROCKET ON TAIEX

TEXT.P: Share prices skyrocketed on the Taiwan Stock Exchange Wednesday, with the weighted index, the market's key barometer, rising 170.06 points to finish at 8,503.55.
The bourse opened at the day's low of 8,368.16, and had a high of 8,532.25.
Gainers outnumbered losers 359 to 40, with 73 stocks remaining unchanged. In all, 3.5 billion shares changed hands on a market turnover of NT$185.12 billion (US$5.86 billion).

Financial issues increased the most at 4 percent, followed by textile stocks at 2.1 percent, foodstuff shares at 1.8 percent, cement issues and plastic and chemical stocks at 1.7 percent, respectively, construction issues at 1.6 percent, paper and pulp shares at 1.2, and electrical engineering stocks at 0.9 percent.

The 10 listed companies with the largest turnovers were ACER, United Micro Electronics, China Steel, Ever Fortune, Chuntex Electronic, Mitac International, Cathay Life Ins., China Trust Commercial Bank, Taiwan Styrene Monomer, and China Petrochemical.

DOC.HEADLINE: NO SIGN OF `BIRD FLU' IN SINGAPORE, SAYS HEALTH MINISTRY

TEXT.P: "Bird flu," which has killed two people in Hong Kong so far this year, has not been detected in either people or poultry in Singapore, the Singapore Health Ministry said on Tuesday.
Preliminary reports suggest that infection from the latest influenza strain H5N1 -- popularly known as bird flu -- is localized to Hong Kong.

Although the ministry has alerted doctors to be on the lookout for the new strain, Singaporeans need not worry about catching it, the ministry said. Travelers to Hong Kong also have little cause for alarm, it added, as it has not been medically proven that this form of flu can be transmitted.
There are only two types of flu virus that affect people -- type A and type B. H5N1 falls into the first group, but has previously been found only in birds.
In domestic poultry, it can lead to a lethal fowl plague, which decimates flocks, but last week in Hong Kong, a 54-year-old man died from the flu, and a 13-year-old girl is still in hospital.
H5N1 is also known as Hong Kong 1997, to differentiate it from a previous strain called Hong Kong flu.
It first appeared in Hong Kong in May this year, when it caused the death of a three-year-old boy. A two-year-old boy was also infected at that time, but survived.

DOC.HEADLINE: TAIWAN FOREIGN INVESTMENTS HIT HISTORIC HIGH

TEXT.P: Taiwan has attracted around US$3.48 billion-worth of foreign investment during the ten-month period from January to October, the highest record since 1952, when the government began allowing foreign investment, the Industrial Development and Investment Center under the Ministry of Economic Affairs (MOEA) said on Wednesday.

Lin Neng-jong, chief of the center, revealed that the amount represents significant growth of 83 percent over the same period of last year, attributing this growth to Taiwan's success in avoiding damage from the recent Asian financial storm.

Lin said that Taiwan has demonstrated its sound economic fundamentals in the wake of the crisis which has severely damaged the economic development of most Asian countries, including South Korea, Taiwan's key opponent in foreign trade.

Taiwan's continued sound economic health not only helps the island attract foreign funds, it also benefits Taiwan's efforts to develop the island into a high-tech manufacturing center and an operations hub in the Asia-Pacific area, Lin said.

According to a MOEA survey on the impact of the financial turmoil on Taiwan businesses, most Taiwan investors in the housing, stock and entertainment sectors in Thailand, Malaysia and Indonesia have become victims of the storm, leading to the closure of a number of enterprises in the region.

However, the survey indicates that most Taiwan investors in the nations of Southeast Asia are engaged in the processing and exporting businesses, which have been less affected by the turmoil, while some of them have even profited from income paid in US dollars or other foreign currencies which have not depreciated.

DOC.HEADLINE: INDONESIA'S ARCHERS TO JOIN WORLD CHAMPIONSHIP IN TAIWAN

TEXT.P: Indonesia's student archers are slated to participate in the Second World Archery Championship for Students in Taoyuan, Taiwan in March, according to an official of the Indonesian National Sports Committee (KONI).

Boy Dewoyanto of KONI was quoted by the Antara news agency as saying that the Indonesian University Student Sports Promotion Board was invited to send representatives to the event by Taiwan's National College of Physical Education and Sports.
KONI is grooming three archers, a man and two women, for the championship, he said.

DOC.HEADLINE: US DOLLAR UP

TEXT.P: The US dollar rose NT$0.266 on the Taiwan foreign exchange market Wednesday, finishing at NT$32.229.
The greenback opened at NT$32.000 and had a high of NT$32.239 and a low of NT$31.905. Interbank US dollar transactions totaled US$388 million. (by Bear Lee)

DOC.HEADLINE: US NEWSPAPER REPORTS GIO CHIEF TALKS
DOC.DATELINE: Washington, Dec. 9 (CNA) (By Han Nai-kuo & Elizabeth Hsu)

TEXT.P: The issue of Taiwan independence had little bearing on the island's Nov. 29 mayoral and county chief elections, David Tawei Lee, chief of the ROC Government Information Office, said on Tuesday.

Lee's remarks came during a meeting at the offices of The Washington Times, the US mass-circulation daily, in which he briefed key newspaper staff on the current economic and political situation in Taiwan.

Topics of Monday's 90-minute discussion, which appeared in Tuesday's edition of the paper, included relations between the two sides of the Taiwan Strait, the results of Taiwan's Nov. 29 city mayor and county chief elections, mainland Chinese President Jiang Zemin's US visit and the Asian financial storm.

According to the article, Lee, who is currently visiting Washington, acknowledged the ROC's ruling Kuomintang (KMT) suffered a big defeat in last month's elections, in which the Democratic Progressive Party (DPP), the island's major opposition party, won 12 of the total 23 constituencies, while the KMT took only eight constituencies and independents gained three.

However, Lee said he believes the real test of his party's hold on power will be next year's vote for national legislators, noting that if the KMT fails to win a majority in the Legislative Yuan, the ROC's highest legislative body, it may loss its ruling status.
He stressed that the result of the upcoming vote will also have an impact on Taipei's diplomatic relations and cross-strait links.

Questioned as to whether the Taiwan independence movement is more and more supported by people on Taiwan, the GIO chief said that although residents say the island's interests should come first, this doesn't mean they prefer independence to reunification with mainland China.

He cited the results of a recent islandwide poll as indicating 85 percent of the population of Taiwan want to see the island's status quo maintained and that only 10 percent said they support Taiwan independence.

Calling the DPP platform's advocacy of Taiwan independence an obvious violation of the will of the people of Taiwan, Lee said the KMT will take its rival to task over this in the 1998 legislative election.
Meanwhile, referring to Taipei-Beijing relations, Lee stressed during the Washington meeting that Taipei always keeps its door open to negotiations.

Touching on an assessment that said next spring would be the best time for the resumption of cross-strait talks, the ROC official pointed out that differences on the topics of the talks still exist, noting that his government hopes to talk about practical matters, including anti-crime issues, while Beijing wishes more for discussions on political issues, such as the definition "one China."
Cross-strait negotiations have been suspended since the summer of 1995, when Beijing unilaterally called them off to protest ROC President Lee Teng-hui's visit to the United States in June 1995.

In reply to questions as to whether Jiang's US visit has had a negative impact on the ROC-US ties, Lee told the press elite that Washington had Taipei completely briefed on the entire visit and that the US government issued assurances that it will never deviate from its existing Taiwan policies.

On the financial storm that has hit Asian economies, Lee said Taiwan has suffered less than others in the region because it enjoys sound and healthy economic fundaments. The island also has the highest economic growth among the "four tigers" in Asia, he noted.

Nevertheless, he added, with Taiwan's dependence on foreign trade for economic development, the island must keep making efforts in the promotion of worldwide economic and financial liberalization to allow fair trade competition.

DOC.HEADLINE: LIU CHAO-SHIUAN TO PROMOTE EDUCATIONAL REFORMS

TEXT.P: Newly appointed Vice Premier Liu Chao-shiuan said Wednesday the promotion of educational reforms will be the focus of his future work.
Liu also said he will coordinate with government agencies to try to solicit more budgeting for the educational, scientific and cultural fields.

Liu's appointment was approved unanimously in a regular meeting of the Kuomintang Central Standing Committee earlier on Wednesday. He formally took over the job from John Chang, who was appointed as KMT secretary-general earlier this month.

Liu, 55, received a bachelor of science degree at National Taiwan University and received a doctorate from the University of Toronto. He has served as the minister of the transportation and communications, president of the National Tsing Hua University, and chairman of the National Science Council.
Liu was reportedly handpicked by Premier Vincent Siew because of his young and fresh image, which gave him an edge over several candidates, including Minister Without Portfolio Lin Feng-chen.
Siew was also impressed with Liu's performance when he headed the Ministry of Transportation and Communications, and the National Science Council.

His strong science background and good connections in the educational and cultural fields are also considered a plus. Liu is close to Yuan T. Lee, president of Academia Sinica, the nation's most prestigious research institute, while his brother Liu Chao-han is president of National Central University.
Liu has said that the pursuit of scientific and technological development is crucial to the nation, and that educational reforms will be vital to fostering more talent in those fields.
The blueprint for turning Taiwan into a regional scientific center which he helped design when he served as the NSC chairman will be unveiled by the end of the year, he said.

DOC.HEADLINE: CROSS-STRAIT TALKS SHOULD FOCUS ON PRACTICAL ISSUES: MAC HEAD

TEXT.P: Mainland Affairs Council (MAC) Chairman Chang King-yuh said on Wednesday that if Taiwan and mainland China resume cross-strait negotiations, these talks should first address technical and functional issues such as the frequent fishery disputes which occur between the two sides.

Reporting to a Central Standing Committee meeting of the ruling Kuomintang (KMT) on the current situation across the Taiwan Strait and the means of facing new challenges in bilateral ties, Chang said Taiwan and the mainland could begin preparations for political negotiations, but predicted that the mainland will not reduce its attempts to isolate Taiwan in the international community, despite the easing of tension between the two sides.
However, he pointed out that Taiwan and mainland China still stand a good chance of reaching consensus on the political front if the mainland can recognize Taiwan as a separate political entity.

He stressed that the ROC government will stick to the policy set out in the Guidelines for National Unification and step up cross-strait exchanges, as well as forge a national consensus and devising a mechanism for negotiations as part of its efforts to promote ties with the mainland.

Commenting on the case of Chuang Chen-yao, a Taiwan marine police officer who was abducted two months ago by mainland fishermen operating illegally in ROC territorial waters, Chang expressed the hope that such cases will not happen again and repeated the ROC government's determination to safeguard Taiwan fishermen's rights and national security within ROC territorial waters.
Chuang had just been released by mainland authorities and was scheduled to return to Taipei via Hong Kong from the port city of Fuzhou in mainland China's Fujian province later in the day.

The mainland side released Chuang after the two sides finally agreed that the Taipei-based Straits Exchange Foundation would pay 140,000 renminbi (about US$17,000) in "consolation and assistance money" to the mainland fishermen involved, who were allegedly injured during the incident. The two sides also signed a "handover certificate" as part of the deal.
Chang emphasized that the government's handling of the incident is not a "precedent," but simply a "one-off" case.

Chuang was attacked and abducted by mainland fishermen on Oct. 11 near Hsichu island, part of the ROC-governed Matsu island group, while searching their fishing vessel which had been detained for illegal entry into ROC waters.

DOC.HEADLINE: COA CONFIRMS NEW CASES OF FMD

TEXT.P: The Council of Agriculture (COA) confirmed on Wednesday that new cases of foot-and-mouth disease (FMD) have been detected at three local pig ranches, casting an even darker shadow over Taiwan's already battered hog industry.

COA officials said 30 pigs at a ranch in Chupei in the northern county of Hsinchu, 49 pigs at a farm in Taichung City, and about 60 pigs at a Kaohsiung ranch in southern Taiwan, had contracted the deadly disease, and that all of them have been slaughtered.

"Local health officials have also stepped up sterilization procedures at the three ranches and the surrounding regions," the officials said, adding that the disease is not expected to develop into another epidemic because most local pigs have now been inoculated.
The officials said the FMD recurrence might be attributable to the failure of the pig farmers to conduct regular inoculations of their stock, due to a continuing drop in pork prices.

An FMD epidemic, the island's first in many decades, broke out in Taiwan in mid-March this year. Agricultural officials said that although the epidemic was brought under control by mid-May, sporadic cases are very likely to occur again in the first year following such a large-scale outbreak, pointing out that Taiwan will not be classed as FMD-free for another three or four years.
The virus found this week at the Chupei, Taichung and Kaohsiung hog ranches is same "O1" type that caused the epidemic in March, the officials added.
As the virus thrives in low temperatures, the officials said, local pig farmers should maintain a high alert during the winter season to protect their hogs from contracting the disease again.

According to COA tallies, more than 21 million shots of FMD vaccine have been administered here since March, and the island currently has only about 8.5 million pigs. Each shot is effective for about six months, but beyond that period, the possibility of the pig contracting the disease will increase again.
COA officials said they will intensify spot checks at pig farms around the island to ensure that farmers are having their pigs inoculated every six months.

The officials said the supply of FMD vaccine is not a problem at the moment, as local health authorities currently have a stock of one million doses and private companies have also imported some three million doses.

Chen Wu-hsiung, director of the Department of Agriculture and Forestry under the Taiwan Provincial Government, said hog farmers who have failed to have their pigs inoculated regularly will be fined from NT$10,000 to NT$50,000 and will not be compensated if their pigs die of the disease.

Chen said it remains uncertain whether the most recent FMD cases will discourage Japan from resuming imports of cooked pork products from Taiwan. In fact, Japan now imports cooked meat products from such FMD-stricken areas as mainland China and Thailand.
Japan originally agreed to resume imports of cooked meat products from Taiwan starting next year if Taiwan could meet Japan's quarantine and sterilization standards.

Up until March, when it imposed an across-the-board ban on Taiwan pork products, Japan was Taiwan's largest market for pork exports, accounting for more than 90 percent of the island's total outbound shipments.

DOC.HEADLINE: INTERNATIONAL DRUG TRAFFICKING RING BUSTED

TEXT.P: Three Singapore nationals and a local man have been arrested on charges of trading in contraband drugs, law-enforcement authorities said on Wednesday.
Investigators also confiscated more than two kilograms of high-grade heroin packed in 20 bricks as well as a large sum of drug money.

Agents with the Ministry of Justice Bureau of Investigation said the three Singaporeans of Chinese origin had used sailors serving on commercial vessels to smuggle drugs into Taiwan for distribution on the local market.
The trio, identified as Ho Chin Hoon, Ong See Seng and Lim Chwee Gim, allegedly have collaborated with drug trafficking rings in Thailand and Hong Kong in smuggling heroin into Taiwan.
Investigators said they had closely monitored the trio's activities since they arrived in Taipei on Dec. 5 and checked into a YMCA hostel in downtown Taipei.
On Tuesday evening, the trio met with Chang Chin-tang, a local drug dealer, at the coffee shop of the Hilton Hotel near Taipei Railway Station.
Chang gave NT$2.55 million (US$80,189) to the Singaporeans who then gave him a key, which would enable Chang to obtain the drugs.
Investigators arrested Chang as he was opening a storage box in the basement of Shinkong Mitsukoshi Department Store near Hilton Hotel to retrieve drugs.

Later that evening, law-enforcement officers also arrested the three Singapore nationals in Chungho, Taipei County, and confiscated a total of NT$4.25 million and US$13,000 in cash at their hotel rooms.
Also seized were three forged passports the trio planned to use to leave Taipei should their criminal activities be uncovered.
Investigators said the drug trafficking ring was well-organized and had managed to smuggle several dozen kilograms of heroin into Taiwan in separate installments in recent months.
Law-enforcement officers said they will further investigate the case to determine whether there are other accomplices here as well as to root out the distribution channels of the trafficking ring.

DOC.HEADLINE: IF ONLY MAINLAND CHINA WERE FREE: ROC AMBASSADOR TO HOLY SEE

TEXT.P: ROC Ambassador to the Holy See Raymond Tai expressed his wish for a free mainland China in an article carried in a US-based newspaper, saying that "if only China were free, there wouldn't be the conflicts and problems besetting Beijing-Taipei relations and Beijing-Vatican relations now."

Tai also reiterated in the article published in the Nov. 2 edition of The Washington Times that the "one country, two systems" scheme designed by the mainland China for the reunification of the two sides of the Taiwan Strait is totally unacceptable to the Republic of China.

Tai said in the article that "at present, the Vatican is the only sovereign state in Europe which recognizes our government. This gives us hope that God is on our side and that freedom will eventually prevail on the Chinese mainland."

He noted that the lack of freedom on the Chinese mainland is not the only stumbling block to a unified China. "Different political systems and ideologies have separated the two sides of the Taiwan Strait for almost half a century. Currently, while Beijing still espouses the Marxist-Leninist doctrine and one party rule -- monopoly of political power by the Chinese Communist Party (CCP), a pluralistic society with a multiparty democracy and a market economy has been thriving in Taiwan." Tai wrote.

In addressing the "Taiwan issue," he continued, Beijing adheres to the principle of "one China" and touts "one country, two systems" as the formula for China's unification. It claims that the People's Republic of China (PRC) is the "sole and legitimate" representative of the Chinese nation and that the ROC is nothing but a local government of Taiwan under the PRC's jurisdiction, the ambassador said.
Of course, this is totally unacceptable to Taipei, Tai wrote, adding that the ROC's mission is to see the restoration of freedom and democracy to the Chinese people on the mainland.

While Taipei also endorses the principle of "one China" and likewise seeks China's eventual reunification, it insists that a unified China be democratic and free. "In the meantime," he continued, "my government opposes the Hong Kong model, i.e., 'one country, two systems' and counters with the 'one country, two political entities (governments)' formula, which provides a framework of modus vivendi before reunification of China materializes."

Tai said: "Dr. Lee Teng-hui, ROC's president and the first popularly elected president in Chinese history, is a devout Christian and a firm believer in religious freedom and human rights. President Lee has made repeated proposals to the Beijing leadership that the two governments on either side of the Taiwan Strait should treat each other as equals and begin a dialogue to explore the process of peaceful reunification.

"The main responsibility of a diplomat, in my view, is to make peace. Thus convinced, I sincerely urge the new leadership in Beijing to open up completely and allowed the Chinese people to enjoy a political life akin to that of the Western democracies.

"As the world approaches the 21st century, it is imperative that both mainland China and Taiwan continue to develop in a peaceful environment. My earnest prayer, is that 'peace and solidarity' be with the Chinese people on both sides of the Taiwan Strait as mankind embarks on the third millennium."

DOC.HEADLINE: EUROPEAN CAR MAKERS FEAR ASIAN IMPORTS

TEXT.P: Competition in Europe's car market, the world's second biggest after the United States, is set to intensify if embattled Asian manufacturers redirect output originally destined for domestic buyers to Europe, according to reports of the Geneva-based World Trade Organization (WTO) Wednesday.

Louis Schweitzer, president of the European Automobile Manufacturers' Association and chairman of Renault, warned that the recent economic turmoil in Asia could hit European manufacturers in their home market, the WTO report said.

Schweitzer was quoted as saying that it was too early to tell if Asian cars would flood into Europe. He warned that any surge in exports from South Korea, Malaysia or Japan, where demand has collapsed after recent economic upheavals, would exacerbate Europe's chronic overcapacity by swamping the market and distorting prices.

Asian car production will become more sensitive, especially in France, after the expected announcement by Toyota, Japan's biggest carmaker, that it will build a new factory in the northern city of Valenciennes.
However, Schweitzer stepped back from demanding import restrictions on Asian cars. "I don't think restriction is an answer. But it may be a necessary means to obtain an opening on the other side."

Such measures might be required for Korea, where sales of foreign cars remain minimal in spite of Seoul's pledges to liberalize trade. While Korea exported almost 250,000 cars to Europe last year, the flow was less than 5,000 units in the other direction.

Europe's car makers will be debating soon whether to extend the gentleman's agreement limiting car exports from Japan to Europe, which expires in 1999. Japanese manufacturers had done better out of the 1991 deal between the European Commission and Tokyo than expected, because the European market had not grown as forecast, allowing Japanese exporters room to expand without breaching the ceiling. In the first 10 months of this year, sales by Japanese car makers were almost 12 percent above the previous level at 1.34 million.

However, Schweitzer said an extension of the gentleman's agreement was unlikely. Although some European car makers would like that, there would be political opposition. As a replacement, "a form of monitoring of developments in the Japanese and European markets would be welcome," the WTO report said.

DOC.HEADLINE: 18TH ANNIVERSARY OF 'FORMOSA MAGAZINE' INCIDENT COMMEMORATED

TEXT.P: An exhibition of documents, photos, videotapes and other articles related to Taiwan's struggle for human rights over the past 50 years opened at the 2-28 Incident Memorial Hall at Taipei's Peace Park near the Presidential Office on Wednesday, which was also World Human Rights Day.

The exhibition, dubbed "Taiwan Human Rights Show - the Judgment of Hisotry," is also being held to mark the 18th anniversary of the 1979 Formosa Magazine Incident, which was reputed by many as an important watershed in Taiwan's march toward freedom and democracy.
On display is a collection of 212 historical documents, 134 photos and 15 videotapes recording major events in Taiwan's strive for basic human rights from 1947 through 1997.

The exhibition, co-sponsored by the Taipei City Government and the Taiwan Peace Foundation, also features personal belongings or articles some well-known former political prisoners, including incumbent Taipei Mayor Chen Shui-bian and writer Po Yang, used when they were serving jail terms.
Chen, Po Yang and several other prominent ex-political prisoners cut specially installed barbed wires with iron cutters to open the show, symbolizing their fight against suppression of human rights.

Speaking on the occasion, Chen said he hopes the Kuomintang, which has ruled Taiwan for more than five decades, would lose power in the not too distant future. "That will be the best judgment of history," said the mayor, who was jailed for eight months in 1986 for publishing an anti-government magazine. AT the time, Taiwan was still ruled under martial law.

Chen said the exhibition is aimed at paying tribute to those who have contributed to Taiwan's democratization and human rights over the past five decades. "Without their sacrifice of personal freedom, youth and even lives, we wouldn't have been able to achieve what we have today," he noted.

Meanwhile, Legislator Shih Ming-teh, also chairman of the New Taiwan Research Foundation, signed an agreement with Academia Sinica's Preparatory Office for the Institute of Taiwan Hisotry on Wednesday, promising to donate a collection of historical documents and articles concerning the Formosa Magazine Incident to the institute, which will be inaugurated in the near future.

Shih, the top leader of an unauthorized street march in the southern city of Kaohsiung on Dec. 10, 1979 which later led to the tragic Formosa Magazine Incident, said his foundation will work hard over the next two years to collect first-hand data concerning the incident and will donate the collection to the institute in 1999.

The march in Kaohsiung was held to mark the inauguration of the pro-Taiwan independence Formosa Magazine. The participants, including many noted pro-democracy activists, clashed with riot police. The event ended up with the arrest of dozens of leading pro-independence and pro-democracy activists, many of whom were later given long jail terms.

Shih, who had spent nearly half of his life behind bars, said it is important to collect first-hand materials concerning the incident. "As many participants and witnesses are still alive, we can rely on their recollections or oral histories to get more facts about the event," he said.

Shih, a former chairman of the opposition Democratic Progressive Party (DPP), was jailed for more than 10 years for his role in the Formosa Magazine Incident. Many other victims of the incident and their defense lawyers have later become prominent politicians, including Taoyuan County Magistrate Annette Lu, Taichung Mayor-elect Chang Wen-ying, Taipei County Magistrate You Ching, Taipei Mayor Chen, Legislators Chang Chun-hung and Yao Chia-wen.

DOC.HEADLINE: DPP HEAD RULES OUT PLEBISCITE ON TAIWAN INDEPENDENCE
DOC.DATELINE: Washington, Dec. 9 (CNA) (By Pan Ying-chen & Maubo Chang)

TEXT.P: The pro-independence Democratic Progressive Party (DPP) will not seek a plebiscite to determine whether the people of Taiwan wish to secede from mainland China in the event it becomes the ruling party, DPP Chairman Hsu Hsing-liang said here on Wednesday.

In an apparent toning down of the party's pro-independence stance in a bid to win over international support, Hsu told an audience in a seminar at George Washington University that "no matter whether you like it or not, Taiwan's sovereignty is a historical fact which cannot be changed."
"Of course we like to see Taiwan moving from de facto independence to de jure independence, but I believe Taiwan people know that we have to be patient," said Hsu.

In a press conference organized exclusively for Chinese-language mass media reporters after the seminar, Hsu reiterated a pledge that the DPP will not declare Taiwan's independence after coming to power on the island because such a move is unnecessary. That echoed a statement made by former DPP Chairman Shih Ming-teh in Washington two years ago.
Beijing, which claims sovereignty over Taiwan, has threatened to use force against the island should it formally declare independence.

Hsu was asked whether the DPP would continue to campaign for Taiwan's membership in the United Nations and press on with efforts to arrange foreign visits for its head of state, especially when such actions, most notably a trip to the United States by ROC President Lee Teng-hui in June 1995, have touched Beijing's raw nerves.
He responded that the DPP always seeks better relations with mainland China via peaceful dialogue and increased contacts.

Touting the DPP's mainland policy as being "more advanced" than that of other political forces in Taiwan, Hsu said his party will try to promote ties with Beijing in the field of economics, with top priority being the establishment of "three links" with the mainland -- meaning direct postal, trade and transportation links.

In performing the balancing act of raising the island's international profile without offending mainland China, Hsu advocated pursuing more unofficial exchanges with other nations. He said that approach could serve the island's purposes without appearing as a provocative action designed to expand Taipei's presence on the international stage at Beijing's expense.

Parris H. Chang, the DPP's top representative in the United States who appeared with Hsu at the press conference, chimed in saying that "the DPP will act responsibly toward Beijing, and will not attempt to provoke or humiliate it and intentionally cause tensions." Chang noted that opposition local administrations now represent 71 percent of Taiwan's population after winning 12 of the 23 seats up for grabs in last month's local elections.
Hsu's delegation is slated to leave for Los Angels on Wednesday night after a three-day visit here. The group will return to Taiwan on Dec. 13.

DOC.HEADLINE: CROSS-STRAIT NEGOTIATIONS SHOULD TAKE PLACE ON EQUAL FOOTING: GIO CHIEF

TEXT.P: The Republic of China has been seeking to develop substantive relations with mainland China, but Beijing needs to remove two major obstacles to the development of such relations, Dr. David Tawei Lee, spokesman for the Republic of China government, said here on Tuesday.

In an address at a luncheon of the American Enterprise Institute, Lee, director general of the Government Information Office (GIO), said Beijing needs to renounce the use of military force against Taiwan to achieve reunification between Taiwan and the Chinese mainland. In addition, Beijing should treat the Taipei government as an equal partner at the negotiating table.

He pointed out that Taipei and Beijing have governed their respective areas of China separately for 48 years, and that "only an equality of status can accurately reflect reality and allow a constructive dialogue to begin."
Lee noted that Taiwan is now a mature democracy and that its democratically elected government has to conduct itself in accordance with the prevailing popular will.

As the results of a recent public opinion survey indicate, the majority of the voters in Taiwan either prefer the status quo or want to leave the unification issue to the future. In the process of developing bilateral relations with the mainland, the ROC government has to make sure that the security and welfare of the 21.6 million people of Taiwan is not compromised, he said.

Lee suggested that the two sides of the Taiwan Strait should resume dialogue, beginning with the discussion of functional issues of mutual concern that arise from the ongoing person-to-person exchanges between the two sides. The two sides should also try to find areas where they can cooperate, such as the economic and cultural fields. They should also take gradual steps to reduce the enormous differences between them in their standards of living and political systems, he said.

He urged Beijing to allow cross-strait relations to be restored to the level of the 1992-1995 period, when both sides agreed on the premise of "one China" but permitted each side to make its own interpretation of what that meant.

On the recent mayoral and county magistrate elections in Taiwan, Lee acknowledged that the ruling Kuomintang suffered a serious setback, capturing only eight of the 23 contested areas against the opposition Democratic Progressive Party's victories in 12 counties and cities. The other three went to independents.

However, in his view, the results of the elections have little effect on relations between Taiwan and mainland China, because they focused mainly on local issues, such as crime, the environment and social welfare, with no debate on the issue of whether Taiwan should opt for reunification or independence.

Earlier on Tuesday morning, Lee, accompanied by officials from the GIO and the Taipei Economic and Cultural Representative Office, called at the offices of the Washington Post and had a discussion with its department chiefs on various issues relating to Taiwan. (Han Nai-kuo)

DOC.HEADLINE: EAST ASIAN ECONOMIC CONFERENCE ENDS

TEXT.P: ROC and Japanese delegates agreed at a joint economic conference Wednesday that both sides have to ease restrictions to expand bilateral trade and reduce the huge bilateral trade imbalance in Japan's favor.
C.F. Koo, head of the ROC delegation, said that both sides also decided to increase cooperative efforts in a variety of areas prior to the close of 25th East Asian Economic Conference.

On bilateral trade and technology cooperation, the two sides believe that the key to increased trade will be an early recovery of the Japanese economy and the easing of restrictions to further open markets, Koo said.

If was also deemed urgent for both nations to cooperate in third areas, saying that multilateral cooperation is crucial in the face of the Asian financial crisis. If inflation is allowed to fuel trade competition, the result will be disastrous, Koo quoted the conference participants as saying.
As the number of Japanese tourists to Taiwan has seen only limited growth in recent years, the two sides agreed that it is necessary to improve tourism facilities on the island.

The participants also expressed hope that Hong Kong will continue to maintain its liberal economic system and its status as an Asian financial center under Beijing's rule, so that it can continue to contribute to overall regional economic growth.
Both sides also said the governments and the people of Taiwan and Japan should increase cooperation, invest in the Asian Pacific region, and engage in technology transfers.
The meeting gathered over 240 delegates, including senior executives from several Japanese companies and major trade associations from Taiwan and Japan.

DOC.HEADLINE: ECCT, AMCHAM CONCERNED ABOUT REFERENDUM ON BAYER INVESTMENT PLAN

TEXT.P: The European Council of Commerce and Trade (ECCT) along with the American Chamber of Commerce in Taiwan on Wednesday repeated their concern over a proposed public referendum on an investment plan by German conglomerate Bayer Taiwan Co in Taichung, central Taiwan.

An ECCT official stated that Taiwan has made substantial progress in many areas over the past year, citing the transparent bidding process for the island's first high-speed rail system and improvements in the traffic control and garbage disposal problems.
But despite those improvements, the ECCT official said calls for a public referendum on the Bayer investment project have called into question other aspects of Taiwan's investment climate.

Liao Yung-lai, the opposition Democratic Progressive Party (DPP) magistrate-elect for Taichung County, has indicated he will go ahead next month with a referendum on whether county residents favor the construction of a chemical manufacturing facility by Bayer, despite earlier approval of the project by the central government.
The European trade official claimed that such sentiment has produced great impact on domestic and foreign investment in Taiwan.

He said European investors in Taiwan's pharmaceutical industry continue to grapple with unfair regulations and pricing policies. In addition, he claimed, European pharmaceutical manufacturers have received discriminatory treatment under Taiwan tax laws.
Although the ECCT supports Taiwan's goal to turn the island into a regional operations hub, it feels that the progress of such an ambitious project is painfully slow, he said.

The American Chamber of Commerce (AmCham) also said the holding of a referendum as part of the approval process for a private investment project would be unprecedented and inconsistent with the concepts of transparency and certainty in regulatory procedures, all of which it said are essential to maintaining a viable and attractive investment climate.

AmCham President Jeffrey Williams said that Taiwan can be proud of its rapid progress toward full democracy, adding however that the referendum concept as part of the approval process for private investment project would create a significant barrier to investment and should be avoided accordingly.

The first stage of construction for the Bayer project in Taichung Harbor, originally slated to begin last year, is estimated to cost NT$10 billion (US$312.5 million) and take two and a half years to complete. The total investment of the 10-year, three-stage project is estimated at NT$50 billion.

DOC.HEADLINE: PACT ON NEW TAIPEI-PRETORIA TIES TO BE SIGNED SOON
DOC.DATELINE: Johannesburg, Dec. 10 (CNA) (By Bear Lee and Chang Jer-shong)

TEXT.P: Republic of China Foreign Minister Jason Hu will soon sign an agreement in Taipei on the framework for future relations with South Africa after official ties between the two nations are cut at the end of this year, diplomatic sources here said Wednesday.
South African President Nelson Mandela announced on Nov. 27 last year that Pretoria will shift its diplomatic recognition from Taipei to Beijing from Jan. 1, 1998.

In previous rounds of negotiations, the two nations have reached agreement on their new ties and South African Foreign Affairs Minister Alfred Nzo signed the formal pact in Pretoria a few days ago, the sources said.
Outgoing ROC Ambassador to South Africa Loh I-cheng, who is scheduled to leave Pretoria for home Friday, will bring back a copy of the agreement to be signed by Hu.
Both sides, however, have a tacit understanding not to reveal details of the pact prematurely, the sources said.

But Nzo made it clear during a recent press briefing that there will be difficulty in meeting Taipei's demand that it be allowed to use its national name, emblem and flag, and that a consular-level relationship be maintained.

Loh also told members of the overseas Chinese community here earlier that the ROC's embassy in Pretoria and consulates-general in Johannesburg, Durban and Cape Town will continue to operate under different titles.
He added that the ROC's property in South Africa will be secured and the ROC personnel stationed here will continue to enjoy diplomatic immunity and other privileges.

As to the bilateral accords on various cooperative programs which were suspended by Taipei following Pretoria's announcement of the change in relations, Loh said they will be reviewed on a case-by-case basis after the new bilateral framework is established.
He indicated that the content of the accord will be announced by the foreign affairs ministries of the two nations.

Loh hosted a dinner party at a Pretoria country golf club Tuesday to bid farewell to his friends here. Attending the party were some 200 guests, including South African Defense Minister Joe Modise, former Foreign Minister Pik Botha, the South African president's former wife Winnie Mandela, members of the foreign diplomatic corps and leaders of the Chinese community here.

DOC.HEADLINE: HSU REFUSES TO REVEAL STANCE ON BAYER PROJECT REFERENDUM

TEXT.P: Democratic Progressive Party (DPP) Chairman Hsu Hsin-liang on Tuesday refused to confirm whether he endorses holding a referendum to decide the fate of a proposed investment project by multinational chemical and pharmaceutical giant Bayer.

Hsu said that after he returns to Taipei from a week-long trip in the United States he will take responsibility for addressing the highly sensitive question of whether public referendums should be conducted to determine the fate of investment projects, an issue which has aroused concern and uncertainty among foreign investors in Taiwan.
Hsu then asked Sisy Chen, director of the DPP publicity department, to further clarify the opposition party's stance on the topic during a press conference for Chinese-language media reporters.

Chen said DPP headquarters has not held any detailed discussions regarding a proposed referendum on Bayer's first investment project in Taiwan. Liao Yung-lai, DPP magistrate-elect for Taichung County, has said he remains committed to holding such a vote to decide whether the chemical plant should be built in his county.
After Hsu's return to Taipei, party leaders will arrange a public hearing to discuss whether referendums are a desirable means of determining the fate of controversial investment projects, Chen said.

Chen noted that the first stage of Bayer's investment project had passed governmental environmental impact evaluations only two days before the DPP delegation embarked on its US mission. Three DPP-recommended experts took part in those evaluations, Chen said, adding that according to her understanding the pollution levels produced by Bayer's proposed facility should be acceptable.
Hsu and other DPP members arrived in New York on Dec. 6 for a week-long US trip. Before leaving for Taipei on Dec. 13, the delegation will make a stopover in Los Angeles.

DOC.HEADLINE: TAIWAN'S LEADING COMPUTER MONITOR FIRM TO INVEST IN ENGLAND
DOC.DATELINE: London, Dec. 9 (CNA) (By Nelson Chung & Lin Wen-fen)

TEXT.P: A Taiwan's leading computer monitor manufacturer has decided to set up its first production base outside Asia in England, the British Department of Trade and Industry announced on Tuesday.

The department said that ADI, one of the world's top 10 computer monitor manufacturers, will invest US$17 million to establish production lines in northeastern England for direct supply to major customers in Europe, including IBM and Compaq.
The annual sales turnover of ADI reached some US$960 million, with half of its sales concentrating on European market.

With three production bases in Taiwan, mainland China and Thailand, ADI has over 3,000 employees. The Taiwan company's latest investment project in England will create some 600 job opportunities there, the department noted.
The company set up a service and marketing center in England some two years ago.

DOC.HEADLINE: ABDUCTED MARINE POLICE RETURNS HOME

TEXT.P: Chuang Chen-yao, the marine police who was abducted by mainland China fishermen to the coastal city Xiamen of Fuzhou in October, returned to Taipei via Hong Kong Wednesday night.

In a press conference held at the CKS International Airport, Chuang said he was happy to be home after being under virtual house arrest for two months in the mainland. He said he had remained confident that the Republic of China government would negotiate his return.

Chuang was released after long and laborious negotiations between Taipei and Beijing and after Taipei agreed to pay a condolence fee of 140,000 renminbi (US$17,500) to mainland fishermen for losses they claimed to suffer during the confrontation that resulted in Chuang's abduction.

Chuang said that on Oct. 11, he and his colleague were conducting a check on a mainland fishing boat spotted in Matsu waters. When the Taiwan marine police boarded the boat, about 15 mainland fisherman wielding sticks, axes and bottles to attack them. Chuang was injured in the melee while his colleague jumped overboard after the fishing boat fled toward the mainland shore.
One mainland fisherman was also injured in the scuffle. The Taiwan side agreed to pay up to 140,000 renminbi in condolence money as a condition for Chuang's release.

Lee Ching-ping, deputy secretary general of the Straits Exchange Foundation (SEF), who accompanied Chuang at the press conference, expressed regret over the way in which Beijing handled the incident, saying that it had adversely affected the development of cross-strait relations.

Lee said that from 1993 to September this year, mainland fishing boats have made 548,630 illegal entries into Taiwan waters, not only endangering the safety and livelihood of fisherman and the marine ecology, but also affecting cross-strait ties.
Lee urged mainland China to effectively prevent its fishermen from entering Taiwan waters so as to create a smooth reciprocal atmosphere between the two sides of the Taiwan Strait.

SEF Legal Service Department Director You Jui-teh, who has conducted several rounds of negotiations with Beijing regarding Chuang's abduction and return, had traveled to the mainland to pick up Chuang. He said that each side maintained a different understanding of the incident, which made handling the matter exceptionally time-consuming.

While Taiwan claims that Chuang was abducted by mainland fishermen while performing his duties, the mainland has insisted that the fishermen did not enter Taiwan waters illegally, and thus their boat was not subject to inspection by Taiwan police.

Taipei believed that Chuang could be repatriated after he was fully recovered from his injuries and negotiations on compensation could be left until later, but that the mainland continued to hold him in order to facilitate its demands for compensation.

DOC.HEADLINE: ROC TO SEPARATE ECONOMICS FROM POLITICS IN DEALING WITH MONGOLIA

TEXT.P: In line with its pragmatic diplomacy, the `epublic of China will separate economic affairs from political matters in its future dealings with the Mongolian People's Republic.
Although recognized as an independent state around the world, Mongolia is still technically considered part of ROC territory, government sources explained Wednesday.

In response to increasing trade between Taiwan and Mongolia, the ROC government's Mongolian and Tibetan Affairs Commission (MTAC) is proposing that the Central Asian region be reclassified as an area distinct from other parts of mainland China in economic-related matters. At the same time, Taipei will stick to its political stance that Outer Mongolia, as it is known locally, is a part of the national territory, said the sources.

Outer Mongolia was part of Chinese territory until 1911, when it seized upon the chaos of the Chinese revolution and declared independence with the backing of Russia. Although the move was later accepted by the People's Republic of China afterward, Mongolia's independence has never been never recognized by the Republic of China.

Under the government's new draft guidelines, which were worked out jointly by the MTAC and the Mainland Affairs Council, Mongolia will be exempted from rules governing economic ties with mainland China. Henceforth, Taiwan businessmen, after obtaining permission, will be allowed to import goods from Mongolia without being subject to relatively more stringent limitations on trade imposed on transactions with mainland China.

As to investment projects in Mongolia, those will be reviewed by relevant authorities on a case-to-case basis in the absence of written statutes. Taipei may negotiate an investment protection pact with Mongolia if investments in that country by Taiwan businessmen continue to increase, said the sources.

The policy to exempt Mongolia from the rules governing trade with mainland China was initiated by MTAC Chairman Kao Koong-lian at a meeting of the ruling Kuomintang's policymaking Central Standing Committee on Oct. 15 and was ordered to be studied in detail by KMT Chairman Lee Teng-hui.
It is expected to take force after being approved by the Cabinet, said the sources.

DOC.HEADLINE: SHARE PRICES PLUNGE ON TAIEX

TEXT.P: Share prices steeply dropped on the Taiwan Stock Exchange on Thursday, with the weighted index, the market's key barometer, losing 232.97 points to finish at 8,270.58.
The bourse opened at 8,438.38, and had a high of 8,451.93 and a low of 8,250.92.
Losers outnumbered gainers 373 to 70, with 25 stocks remaining unchanged. In all, 3.38 billion shares changed hands on a market turnover of NT$175.59 billion (US$5.66 billion).

Both paper-making and electrical engineer issues plunged the most at 4.5 percent, respectively, followed by foodstuff stocks at 3.1 percent, plastic and chemical shares at 3 percent, textile issues at 2.8 percent, cement and construction issues at 1.5 percent, respectively, and financial shares at 1 percent.

United Micro Electronics, ACER, International Bills Finance, Ever Fortune, Shin Kong Life Insurance, China Bills Finance, China Life Insurance and Taiwan Semiconductor Manufacturing were the first companies with the largest turnovers.

DOC.HEADLINE: NEW ROC AMBASSADOR TO SAINT CHRISTOPHER & NEVIS TAKES OFFICE
DOC.DATELINE: New York, Dec. 10 (CNA) (By David Wang & Elizabeth Hsu)

TEXT.P: Katherine S.Y. Chang, new Republic of China ambassador to Saint Christopher and Nevis, has arrived in the East Caribbean nation, unfolding her diplomatic career as the ROC's first woman ambassador.
Chang presented her credentials to Saint Christopher and Nevis Governor General Cuthbert Sebastian in the capital of Basseterre on Monday, and held a 30-minute talk with the leader.

During the meeting, Chang told Sebastian she will base her activities on the existing framework of exchanges between the ROC and Saint Christopher and Nevis, but will also work to further promote and develop substantial relations between the two countries in the fields of agriculture, economy and culture.

Sebastian applauded the ROC's political and economic accomplishment and revealed his great personal interest in traditional Chinese acupuncture, saying he hopes his country can send doctors to Taiwan for training in the ancient but effective treatment method.

Taipei forged diplomatic relations with Basseterre in 1984, when an accord for agricultural and technical cooperation was also signed. Based on that agreement, the ROC dispatched an team of specialists to the island country, which had been ruled by Britain until 1983, to assist in developing modernized agricultural methods.
Saint Christopher and Nevis' key economic activities are in the fields of tourism, agriculture and light industry.

DOC.HEADLINE: TAIWAN DOLLAR DROPS IN WAKE OF SOUTH KOREAN WON'S FALL

TEXT.P: The South Korean won plummeted to a historic low of 1,719 against the US dollar on Thursday, which precipitated a drop in the Taiwan currency.

However, experts from the Council for Economic Planning and Development (CEPD) said they believe the won's value will soon stabilize, adding that its sudden fall is highly unlikely to touch off another round of global currency fluctuations.
The New Taiwan dollar plunged to NT$32.532 against the greenback in midday trading in foreign exchange markets on Thursday. Interbank transactions amounted to US$341 million.
Dealers attributed the NT dollar depreciation mainly to the won's seemingly unstoppable fall, which prompted local investors to buy greenbacks in large volumes.
They said the South Korean currency continues to play a key role in determining the Taiwan unit's value, revealing that it could reach a new low of NT$33 to the US dollar at some time in the future.
In the short term, however, they predicted the NT dollar will likely swing between 31.8 to 32.8 against the US currency.

DOC.HEADLINE: DPP CHAIRMAN MEETS WEI JINGSHENG
DOC.DATELINE: Washington, Dec. 10 (CNA) (By Herman Pan and Sofia Wu)

TEXT.P: Hsu Hsin-liang, chairman of Taiwan's opposition Democratic Progressive Party (DPP), paid a visit to prominent mainland Chinese political dissident Wei Jingsheng on Wednesday.
This was the first time the two famous political dissidents from opposite sides of the Taiwan Strait had met to exchange views on the development of democracy in mainland China.
Hsu is currently on a publicity tour of the United States, while Wei arrived here in mid-November after being released by mainland authorities on parole for receiving medical treatment.

During their hour-long talks, Hsu expressed tribute to Wei for his devotion to promoting democracy and human rights on the mainland. "I admire you for your courage to fight communist authorities for freedom and democracy," the leader of Taiwan's largest opposition party said.
For his part, Wei reminded the pro-(Taiwan) independence DPP not to underestimate the possibility of Beijing attacking Taiwan if the island formally declares independence.
"Beijing is waiting for Taiwan to give it an excuse to launch an attack," Wei said, adding that if the island declares independence, the communist government is unlikely to sit idle.
Mainland China's best-known dissident also urged Hsu to remain cautious in dealing with the Chinese Communists and not to be deceived by them.

Wei later told reporters that his breakfast meeting with Hsu was a happy encounter. "We talked like old friends as we have shared similar experiences of fighting for freedom and democracy," he said, adding the meeting has helped change his perception of the DPP and enhance his interest in Taiwan-related affairs, particularly the realities of Taiwan's political environment.
Hsu also described his meeting with Wei as "amicable and cordial." He also revealed that Wei has accepted his invitation to visit Taiwan at a "convenient time."
Hsu was originally scheduled to meet with an official from the US Department of Defense on Thursday, but the meeting was canceled at the last meeting for unknown reasons.

Hsu, accompanied by several DPP department chiefs, arrived in the United States last weekend to meet with local Chinese community leaders and American officials in charge of Taiwan and East Asian affairs. The group has exchanged views on a range of issues, including the DPP's policy toward mainland China and the party's development plan following its resounding win in Taiwan's latest nationwide mayoral and county chief elections.
The DPP delegation has already visited New York and will also make a stopover in Los Angeles before returning to Taipei at the end of this week.

DOC.HEADLINE: M'LAND SHIPPING OFFICIALS TO TOUR KAOHSIUNG HARBOR

TEXT.P: A mainland Chinese delegation attending a shipping seminar held in Taiwan will be given a tour of Kaohsiung Harbor next Monday by the Kaohsiung Harbor Bureau (KHB) of the Taiwan Transportation Department.
KHB officials, who have been keeping the planned tour low profile, said that it would merely be a visit to the harbor and urged people not to read too much into the event.
The mainland delegation will arrive in Kaohsiung on Dec. 15, be briefed by KHB authorities and then tour Kaohsiung Harbor on board a sightseeing boat.

Mainland China has yet to open its large port facilities -- including those in Guangzhou, Shanghai, Qingdao, Dalian and Tianjin -- to Taiwan's shipping companies. As a result, the indirect shipping business across the Taiwan Strait that was initiated in April has not been as successful as expected, the KHB authorities noted.
The KHB, however, will not set up a meeting between the mainland delegation and Taiwan shipping merchants nor arrange for the group to tour the trans-shipping service region.

The proposal for cross-strait trans-shipping service was made in May 1996. For lack of a friendly response from Beijing, however, only the mainland harbor cities of Xiamen and Fuzhou and Taiwan's Kaohsiung were opened for the trans-shipping business, a situation that has kept business turnover low.

Only some 100,000 containers having been trans-shipped since April, and shipping companies plying the cross-strait route have suffered a heavy deficit. Hence shipping merchants in Taiwan are pinning much hope on the on-going cross-strait shipping meeting being held in Taipei.

DOC.HEADLINE: MORE DOMESTIC FLIGHT SERVICES TO OPEN

TEXT.P: Taiwan is planning to open more domestic flight services to meet increased demand.

Tsai Tuei, chief of the Civil Aeronautics Administration (CAA), pointed out Thursday that local U-Land Airlines has been authorized to ply two newly-opened flight routes -- one between Hsinchu and Kaohsiung, and the other between Hsinchu and Kinmen -- at the beginning of 1998.

Great China Airlines was approved to begin flying the route between Taichung and Chiang Kai-shek (CKS) International Airport-Taichung route on January 1, 1998, revealed Tsai, who made the announcement in a legislative meeting.

As part of its effort to solve the air transportation problems, CAA will open more new domestic aviation services, he said, adding that the agency is now studying the feasibility of opening other flight routes, including CKS-Taitung, Hsinchu-Tainan, Hsinchu-Hualien and Hsinchu-Taitung, he said.
Factors affecting the routes' opening include concerns over passenger-carrying capacity, the chief explained, saying a decision on the matter should not be expected until at least February or March.

DOC.HEADLINE: CROSS-STRAIT CULTURAL, EDUCATIONAL EXCHANGES INCREASING

TEXT.P: Mainland Chinese have made more than 30,000 visits to Taiwan for cultural and educational exchanges in the past 10 years, and about 8,000,000 volumes of mainland Chinese publications entered Taiwan during the period.

According to the statistics compiled by the Mainland Affairs Council of the Executive Yuan, mainland Chinese scholars and researchers have been permitted to make 31,668 visits to Taiwan since 1987, when Taiwan began to promote civilian exchanges with mainland China. Mainland Chinese entertainers and artists have received permission to make 7,730 visits to Taiwan since then.

The statistics also indicated that as of the end of October, 235 mainland Chinese groups have been invited to visit Taiwan, including 139 performing art groups, 41 student bodies, 29 athletic teams, and 26 groups of exhibitors.
During the 10-year period, 7,916,798 volumes of publications, 46 movies, and more than 22,600 volumes of videotapes were imported into Taiwan from the Chinese mainland. (by Ed Hsieh)

DOC.HEADLINE: CONSUMER PRICES IN TAIWAN EXPECTED TO RISE NEXT YEAR

TEXT.P: The consumer prices in Taiwan will rise next year, but not high enough to cause inflation problems, according to a report issued Thursday by the Committee of Economic Research and Development of the Ministry of Economic Affairs.

The 1997 report on the committee's review and forecast of the economy said the total world trade is likely to decline mildly next year, although the world economy is still growing normally at the present time.

The report pointed out that the economy of Taiwan has been growing normally for 12 months, and that investment and production capability have also kept increasing during the period. This situation is helpful to future economic development , it said.
The financial turmoil in Northeast Asia is a most volatile factor that may affect the economic development in Taiwan, the report said.

Meanwhile, the Directorate General of Budget, Accounting, and Statistics of the Executive Yuan has forecast that the consumer prices in Taiwan will rise 3.12 percent in 1998 due to the devaluation of Taiwan currency and increases in the prices of agricultural and industrial raw materials in the world market.

Economic Minister Wang Chih-kang has ordered economic researchers to study the possible impact of the current Asian financial turmoil on the economic development in mainland China, and to map out plans to help Taiwan investors weather the financial storm that may be brewing on the Chinese mainland. (by Ed Hsieh)

DOC.HEADLINE: MAC CLOSELY WATCHES M'LAND DIPLOMATIC OFFENSIVE

TEXT.P: Mainland China has been aggressively pursuing diplomatic relations with other nations in the manner of an emerging world power, the cabinet-level Mainland Affairs Council (MAC) said Thursday.
MAC officials noted that since the start of this year mainland Chinese leaders have exchanged state visits with the heads of foreign nations more frequently than ever before.
They noted that mainland Chinese President Jiang Zemin visited Russia in April and the United States in October, followed by mainland Chinese Premier Li Peng's trip to Japan in November.

World leaders visiting mainland China this year included French President Jacques Chirac in May, Japanese Prime Minister Ryutaro Hashimoto in September and Russian President Boris Yeltsin in November.
Jiang attended the Asia Pacific Economic Cooperation forum summit meeting in Vancouver in November, and will also attend the Association of Southeast Asian Nations summit meeting this month.
The officials said the frequent overseas trips of mainland leaders indicate that Beijing has been using its newly acquired world stature to launch a series of diplomatic offensives.

They said that after mainland China took over Hong Kong in July and smoothly concluded in September the 15th Communist Party Congress, during which Jiang reportedly consolidated his leadership position, Beijing's international stature reached a new pinnacle.

MAC officials said that Beijing's aggressive diplomatic moves have put heavy pressure on Taipei, further squeezing Taipei's "pragmatic diplomacy" in the international community, adding that related developments need to be closely watched.

Looking ahead, the officials said the improvement of relations between mainland China and the United States will hinge on the practical concerns of both sides, adding that support for and opposition to the Clinton administration's policy of engagement with Beijing are roughly equal in strength.

They also said the improved Beijing-Moscow ties could be attributed to a Russian sense of insecurity over the expansion of NATO. But in the future, they added, Russia will have to rely on the West and not the mainland to complete its free-market economic reforms.

In a world predominantly headed by such powers as the United States, European Union, Japan, Russia and mainland China, they observed, mainland China is at a low rung in economic development, research standards and national defense, and also lags behind in democratic development, human rights, quality of life and ideology.

DOC.HEADLINE: GREENBACK DIPS AGAINST NT DOLLAR

TEXT.P: The US dollar dipped against the NT dollar Thursday, falling NT$0.329 to 31.90.

It opened here at NT$32.4, and rose as high as 32.68 because of heavy bidding for the greenback triggered by the plummet of the South Korean won, before pulling back to close at Thursday's low of 31.90, A total of US$505.5 million changed hands during the session.

DOC.HEADLINE: FMD-FREE PIGS TO BE MARKED WITH EAR-TAGS: COA

TEXT.P: Starting in mid-December, all healthy pigs raised in Taiwan will be marked with ear-tags to prove that they have been vaccinated against foot-and-mouth disease (FMD), the Council of Agriculture (COA) announced on Thursday.

The cabinet-level council made the announcement after discussing new anti-FMD measures with major local hog industry associations in the wake of the discovery of new FMD infections at three local pig ranches earlier this month.

Chen Pao-chi, director of the COA's Animal Industry Department, said the ear-tag measure is aimed at encouraging local pig farmers to properly and regularly vaccinate their swine in order to fend off the recurrence of an FMD epidemic on the island.
"Those who fail to abide by the regulations will be fined from NT$10,000 to NT$50,000 and will not be compensated if their pigs die of the illness," Chen stressed.

He said all 211 of the swine verified to have contracted the deadly disease in Chupei, Taichung and Kaohsiung, have already been slaughtered, adding that the areas surrounding the pig ranches have been thoroughly sterilized to contain the infection.

All the infected pigs were discovered either at wholesale markets or pig-pens, Chen said, which means none of them had been distributed to retail markets. "Local consumers need not panic over the reports of new FMD cases," he noted.

Chen said his department has directed local animal disease control offices to intensify monitoring of the 20 wholesale pig markets around the island to prevent any sick swine from entering retail markets.
The COA has also banned the movement of any swine raised within three kilometers of the three affected hog ranches, he added.

He pointed out that Taiwan has now entered a high-risk period, when an FMD epidemic is most likely to re-occur, firstly because the FMD virus usually thrives in low temperatures, and secondly because the FMD vaccine is effective for only six months. "By now, many pigs which were vaccinated between March and May need to be inoculated again," he added.

Under a massive vaccination program, a total of 21 million doses of the vaccine have been administered to local swine since an FMD epidemic, the island's first in many decades, broke out in Taiwan in mid-March this year. To curb the spread of the disease, nearly four million pigs were slaughtered from March to July.
Chen said the COA has continued to monitor FMD-control measures since July 15 when the last case of FMD infection was uncovered. Up until Dec. 6, no new cases had been reported.

All three farms where FMD-infected swine were found over the past week are small-sized ranches and usually use spoiled food to feed their pigs, Chen said, adding that this might be the source of the new infections.
Taiwan currently has only 8.5 million pigs and some four million doses of FMD vaccine in stock. Against this background, Chen said, it's unlikely that an FMD epidemic will sweep the island again.
Meanwhile, many local governments have stepped up protective measures to prevent any sick pigs from other cities or counties from entering their jurisdictions.

According to health experts, the FMD disease is only contagious among cattle, sheep, pigs and other cloven-hoofed animals. The symptoms include necrosis around the animal's mouth, feet and udders. Some afflicted animals will eventually lose their hooves before finally dying of the illness.

DOC.HEADLINE: WILL CHINA BE NEXT SOUTH KOREA?

TEXT.P: Who will be next in line for an International Monetary Fund (IMF) rescue package? "Certainly China looms, since it has all the policy problems of South Korea and Thailand, only on a grander scale and with less political legitimacy," a Canadian commentator said Wednesday.

Terence Corcoran of The Globe and Mail said the IMF's "Mr. Bean assessment of South Korea's economic condition had proved dead wrong." But such failure was not supposed to occur in the wake of the 1995 Mexican crisis, he claimed.

The IMF created a so-called "early earning system" that would allow it and the market to detect looming national economic crises. "Whatever mechanisms exist, they obviously didn't work," Corcoran pointed out.

Despite its warning system, the IMF is full of optimism toward mainland China, according to the Canadian columnist. He quoted a former IMF official as praising Beijing for having "begun to master the art of soft-landing" and adding that given the mainland's large stock of currency reserves, "it may well be that China will not need financial assistance from the fund."
Corcoran warned that the true secret of the IMF is its "ability to maintain a facade of supreme confidence and stability while it plunges from catastrophe to catastrophe."
