Even as its own policies and programs are revealed to be shams, "the IMF goes through life like a sophisticated Mr. Bean, leaving a trail of unintended consequences and escalating turmoil," he noted. In short, when the IMF sneezes, financial markets spend years cleaning up the mess, he said.

He went on to criticize the IMF's secretive way of dispensing credit, saying "it keeps a tight rein on information about its practices and policies. It's impossible to know where the billions go, how they are allocated, who benefits and who loses," he added.

Some Ottawa observers asked: If the IMF is not competent in solving national financial crises, then why not allow "regional funds," like the one proposed by Japan, to play a role in the regional economy?

DOC.HEADLINE: CA AND FUJITSU ANNOUNCE SHIPMENT OF JASMINE
DOC.DATELINE: Ottawa, Dec. 10 (CNA) (By S.C. Chang) (By Huang Kwang-chun)

TEXT.P: New York, Dec. 10 (CNA): Computer Associates International, Inc. (CA) of the United States and Fujitsu Ltd. of Japan jointly announced Wednesday the full-scale shipment of Jasmine, the first pure object solution for building next-generation business systems over Internet and client/server computing environments.
CA and Fujitsu made the announcement during a press conference held in conjunction with the Fall Internet World '97, taking place at Jacob K. Javits Center in New York.

Jasmine offers developers an object-oriented platform ideally suited for dynamic multimedia applications while delivering the integrity and practical data management required for mainstream business solution, said Charles Wang, chairman and CEO of Computer Associates.

DOC.HEADLINE: RI PRODUCERS WORRIED OVER RUBBER PRICE DROP

TEXT.P: Indonesian rubber producers are worried over a sharp drop in the rubber price in international markets to below production cost, a state-owned plantation official said here Wednesday.

"The drop was prompted by Thailand, the world's largest rubber producer, who sold it at cheaper prices and in large volumes because of the economic crisis in the country," Edward Sitorus, director of PT Perkebunan Nusantara XIII, was quoted by Antara news agency as saying.
Sitorus said the rubber price in the world market was down to US$0.70 a kilogram. "This is the lowest price of rubber I have ever seen."
Smallholders and plantations alike will benefit if the price can reach a minimum of US$1.00 per kilo.
The rubber price was US$1.5 per kilo in 1994, US$1.3 in 1995, and US$1.1 in 1996.
The commodity's market had also been weakened by the state of the domestic rubber processing industry, Sitorus said.
Normally, Sitorus said, if Indonesia had so many processing industries, it could supply the domestic market.
But in fact, the country has been depending on rubber imports, he said.
Meanwhile, Ir Basran Madry, director of plant rehabilitation and extensification at the Ministry of Agriculture, said the affected plantation area for 1996 was 14 million hectares.
Total production of plantation products from those areas amounted to 12 million tons, with about half of the total production being exported.
"National earnings from the export amounted to US$5 billion," Madry said.
Total area in 1997 amounted to 14.05 million hectares, 11.39 million hectares for smallholders and 2.67 million hectares for large plantations.

The largest area of big plantation production was oil palm (1.469 million ha), followed by rubber (543,000 ha). For smallholders, the largest area was planted with coconut (2.675 million ha) followed by rubber (2.992 million ha).

DOC.HEADLINE: ROC KEEPS 3RD TOP SPOT IN WORLD PROFITABILITY RANKING

TEXT.P: The Republic of China has retained its position as the world's third most profitable place to invest in for the next one to five years, according to the Business Risk Service (BERI).
In the BERI's latest ranking, the ROC remained tied with Japan for the third spot with the same score of 76.
In its November report, the US-based risk consultancy ranked profit opportunities for the world's 50 major countries for next year and the next five years.
Switzerland remained in the top spot with a score of 82 (same as the previous rank and score in July).
Singapore also retained its second position in the new rating with the same score of 78.

The ratings of other countries in Southeast Asia dipped because the financial crisis sparked by the free fall of the Thai baht in early July has resulted in the plunge of the baht, Indonesian rupiah and Malaysian ringgit, which shed between 30 percent and 50 percent of their value against the US dollar. The Singapore dollar fell by 12.7 percent in that period.
BERI gave Malaysia a score of 57, down from 59 in its previous report in July. Its rating slipped one notch to 19th.
Indonesia's score dropped from 46 to 44, and its rank fell from 34th to 39th.
Thailand's score dipped three points to 47, and it slipped from 28th to 29th spot. The Philippines also dropped to 39th spot, tied with Indonesia, from 37th with a score of 42.

The assessment of profit opportunity is based on ratings in three key areas: operations risk, which covers the general business environment; political risk; and remittance and repatriation, which measures the ease with which private foreign companies can transfer profits and capital abroad.
Following are the top 10 countries in BERI's latest rating, with composite scores (previous rank/score in parentheses):
1. Switzerland (1) 82 (82)
2. Singapore (2) 78 (78)
5. Netherlands (5) 74 (74)
8. United States (9) 69 (68)

DOC.HEADLINE: TROOPS CLASH WITH STUDENTS IN YOGYAKARTA

TEXT.P: Troops forcefully broke up a student rally commemorating Human Rights Day in Yogyakarta, Indonesia, on Wednesday and beat dozens of participants who refused to disperse.

Hundreds of students calling themselves the Committee of People's Action for Change exchanged harsh words with the security personnel who tried to halt the demonstration and make them return to the Gadjah Mada University campus.

After several minutes of arguing, the troops broke up the gathering, chased the protesters and forced them into waiting trucks. Several students were beaten with wooden sticks, but there were no reports of serious injuries.

Yelling slogans, the students began their march at the building of the School of Social and Political Sciences, and proceeded to the campus' main boulevard where they were intercepted by district police and troops.
The chief of the 072/Pamungkas military command of Yogyakarta, Col. Djoko Santoso, said no students had been detained. Those rounded up during the demonstration were returned to the campus.
"They have not been detained. They were returned to the campus. If they want to continue with the demonstration there, they can do so," he was quoted by the Jakarta Post as saying.

In Semarang, the 49th anniversary of the Universal Declaration of Human Rights was marked with a student rally held at the Diponegoro University campus. Chanting slogans, 80 students demanded that the government be consistent in the campaign for human rights promotion.
The students marched to the building of the Central Java provincial legislative council to deliver their petition.

DOC.HEADLINE: IS CANADA CATCHING CHINESE FLU?

TEXT.P: A Canadian daily expressed worry Wednesday that Canada's leaders, by showing "alarming insensitivity" to protesters during last month's APEC conference in Vancouver, are becoming more like their mainland Chinese counterparts.
One of the justifications for doing business with repressive regimes is that, over time, they will adopt Western values of respect for human rights, The Ottawa Citizen said in an editorial.
The risk, however, is that "in consorting with the devil, we begin to act more like him," warned the Citizen. This is just something to consider on International Human Rights Day, it added.

The daily was commenting on how the Canadian leaders reacted to anti-APEC protests in Vancouver last month. It was shocked by Canadian Prime Minister Jean Chretien's knock-off line in response to police hauling out pepper spray at protesters on the UBC campus: "For me, pepper is what I put on my plate."

Another insensitive Canadian leader was Chretien's International Trade Minister Sergio Marchi, who vaguely dismissed the Vancouver clashes as an "altercation on the university campus." This conjures up mainland China's vague reference to "an incident at Tiananmen Square," the editorial noted.

It pointed out that University of British Columbia law student Craig Jones has accused the Canadian government and police of trying to muzzle free speech. Jones recounts being arrested as he stood outside his student residence -- a space he was entitled to occupy, even under the security guidelines -- because he refused to relinquish a sign that read "Free Speech." It would be seen by passing motorcades moving such dictators as Indonesia's Suharto and mainland China's Jiang Zemin.

Earlier, four UBC student protesters were held until they signed an undertaking not to participate in any more public protests -- anywhere, at any time -- against APEC, the Citizen said. An aboriginal chief says her welcome speech to APEC leaders was canceled because it contained a reference to human rights, it added.

The Globe and Mail reported from Vancouver on Wednesday that the Prime Minister's Office and the Royal Canadian Mounted Police (RCMP) were accused of violating the constitutional rights of protesters during the APEC meeting.

"The suit is just the latest embarrassment for the federal Liberal government," the Mail said, noting that so far, the fallout from the Vancouver summit "has been mostly negative, with repeated criticisms from APEC protesters and civil libertarians" that Chretien's handlers "tried to stage-manage protests, interfered in security arrangements and censored a speaker who had been invited to attend the conference."

DOC.HEADLINE: BAYER UNDECIDED ON TAIWAN INVESTMENT

TEXT.P: Horst Mueck, chief of the Bayer Group's Taiwan branch, said on Thursday that Bayer's headquarters in Germany will have the final say on the fate of the company's NT$49.2 billion investment project in central Taichung County.

Mueck's remarks came after the Legislative Yuan on Wednesday passed the first reading of an amendment to the Self-Governance Law for Provinces and Counties, which would allow local governments to hold public referendum on major public affairs.

Mueck said Bayer Taiwan will proceed with the investment plan as scheduled until the company's headquarters makes a final decision on whether or not to withdraw the project from Taiwan, adding that the decision will depend on the results of the vote following the third reading of the amendment at the Legislative Yuan.

Bayer's plan to build a plant to produce toluene di-isocyanate near Taichung Harbor has provoked strong opposition from local residents, and county magistrate-elect Liao Yung-lai of the Democratic Progressive Party (DPP) has insisted on holding a public referendum to decide the fate of the project.

When asked about whether Bayer will conduct negotiations with the DPP or the Taichung County government on the issue, Mueck said Bayer, as a business group, will not get involved in Taiwan politics. However, he pointed out that it will be a heavy blow to Taiwan's investment climate if the Taichung County government really resorts to a public referendum to decide on the future of the plant.

Addressing a joint committee question-and-answer session in the Legislative Yuan, newly appointed Vice Premier Liu Chao-shiuan said the local government had better work out a detailed explanation to help the public gain a comprehensive understanding of the issues involved before holding public referendums on important local affairs.
He said the local government should provide a legal basis and a well-thought-out procedural system before holding a referendum, in order to allow the public to make a "wise decision."

P.K. Chiang, chairman of the cabinet-level Council for Economic Planning and Development (CEPD), said his council has no intention of avoiding monitoring from the local government by applying directly to the Interior Ministry for construction and usage licenses in order to push the Bayer investment project through before any referendum is held in Taichung County.
"The CEPD has no need to fend off the referendum, as a public vote of this kind has no legal basis in Taiwan," he claimed.

Chiang said the CEPD has decided to send Bayer's documents and reports of the results of its long-term communication with the local people to the Taiwan Provincial Assembly as a reference of public opinion on the issue, since the assembly requires proven "strong public support" for its passage of Bayer's case.

Meanwhile, Taipei Mayor Chen Shui-bian, also a DPP heavyweight, said neither the DPP nor the central government should interfere in the Taichung County government's plan to hold a referendum, as it is a local issue.
Holding referendums is only a means of soliciting public opinion, which he said is not a reflection of anti-business feeling and will not hinder job and investment opportunities at the local level.
Chen said the fate of the Bayer investment plan should be decided by the residents of Taichung County and called on the outside world not to judge the issue from a political point of view.

DOC.HEADLINE: ROC'S ANTI-SUBMARINE CAPABILITY CAN COVER ENTIRE TAIWAN STRAIT

TEXT.P: The Republic of China's anti-submarine capability can cover the entire Taiwan Strait, naval authorities said on Thursday.
"The ROC Navy can detect any activities by submarines in the entire Taiwan Strait," said a senior naval officer, who spoke on condition of anonymity.

The officer was commenting on a report by the Far Eastern Economic Review that the ROC Navy failed to detect a mainland China's Russian-made K-class A-77 submarine which navigated to Southeast Asia via the Taiwan Strait in November.

The Hong Kong-based weekly said in its Dec. 18 issue that the incident indicates that there is a loophole in Taiwan's submarine combat capability. It further said mainland China has four K-class submarines, including two 636-type subs, which are more advanced and quieter than the A-77 craft.

"The foreign media report is not true," the officer said. According to the ROC's defense regulations, the officer said, the navy would immediatetly cope with any submarine that intrudes into waters east of the median line of the Taiwan Strait, but would not necessarily issue a news release on such events.
Under the ROC regulations, the navy would closely monitor submarine activities in waters west of the median of the Taiwan Strait, but may not necessarily take any countermeasures.
"We have consistently maintained the capability to detect, contact and cope with unidentified underwater targets in accordance with our anti-submarine regulations," the officer asserted.

Commenting on the Far Eastern Economic Review observation that Taiwan would be able to detect K-class submarines in its nearby waters only after all the six Lafayette-class missile frigates it has ordered from France join services, the officer argued that such comments indicate that the weekly neither understands Taiwan's anti-submarine capability nor the basic situation of its navy.
The officer said Taiwan has taken delivery of five Lafayette-class frigates, five of which have been formally commissioned.
Nevertheless, the officer said, among the ROC's warships, the six Knox-class frigates leased from the United States have the strongest anti-submarine capabilities.

DOC.HEADLINE: PROPOSED INDUSTRIAL ZONE MUST MEET ENVIRONMENTAL ASSESSMENT

TEXT.P: Economics Minister Wang Chih-kang said Thursday that if the proposed Pingnan Industrial Zone in southern Taiwan fails to pass an environmental impact assessment, the government will not allow construction to begin.

Wang said the officials from the Industrial Development Bureau and the Environmental Protection Administration are currently working with local authorities to conduct an evaluation of the environmental surroundings at the proposed site of the industrial zone in Tainan County.

Wang said that the stance of the ministry is consistent with the wishes of local people. But he added that if the proposed industrial zone is ultimately deemed environmentally sound, the public should give its full support to the development project.

However, if the assessment determines that construction of the industrial zone would produce negative consequences for the local environment, the government will not allow the project to be carried out, Wang said.

The Pingnan Industrial Zone, which would be the largest industrial development project in Taiwan, will house the island's 7th naphtha cracker, an integrated steel mill and an exclusive harbor facility.
Environmental activists and advocates of the project have clashed several times over the NT$400 billion (US$12.42 billion) investment.

Plans for the joint project between the Yieh Loong Group and the Tuntex Group were submitted to the government for review three years ago, but were rejected on grounds of improper procedures. A revised project outline was recently submitted by the investors. But environmental activists believe the development of a industrial zone in Pingnan could be detrimental to the ecology of the wetland area.

Wang also said the government understands the position taken by foreign companies after the European Council of Commerce and Trade and the American Chamber of Commerce in Taiwan expressed concern over the future of investment projects, such as the one proposed by German conglomerate Bayer in Taichung Harbor.

Wang said that a public referendum at the current juncture on the Bayer project will affect the willingness of foreign investors, and that the ministry will continue to communicate with the local government on the issue.
Taichung Magistrate-elect Liao Yung-lai has said he plans to go ahead with a public referendum next month on the fate of the Bayer investment project.

DOC.HEADLINE: WTO HEAD CONFIDENT FINANCIAL SERVICES ACCORD WILL BE REACHED

TEXT.P: Renato Ruggiero, director general of the Geneva-based World Trade Organization (WTO), has expressed confidence that the trade body will sign an accord on liberalizing financial services by the Dec. 12 deadline.
Ruggiero said the WTO has thus far received 46 offers of improved market access, adding he expects at least five others to arrive soon.

Meanwhile, Nigel Gardner, spokesman for the European Union's trade chief, Leon Brittan, said the many new offers made in recent days by members of the WTO have boosted the chances of meeting the Dec. 12 deadline on the financial services talks.
Some 60 nations now have offers on the table, he said. "We are clearly waiting for some more to come to fruition today," he said.

The WTO members have been seeking a deal on financial services for the past nine months. They aim to tackle long-standing barriers, above all in developing countries, to international competition in banking, insurance and securities.
A WTO accord also would subject national policies on financial services to binding multilateral rules and disciplines.
The United States, European Union and Japan have tabled offers that pledge liberalization beyond their commitments two years ago when the WTO first tried to reach an accord on financial services.
However, hopes for an accord this time around are seen hinging on Washington, which says it won't sign unless developing countries such as those in Southeast Asia move to open their markets further.

"No one can predict at this stage what all the elements of the imminent conclusion will be," Ruggiero said. "But it is hard to image in this final phase that all of our achievements will be allowed to slip away."
Brazil deposited an offer earlier this week, while Colombia, Indonesia, Thailand and Romania are expected to chip in soon, officials of the WTO said.

DOC.HEADLINE: THREE PERCENT PETROLEUM PRICE HIKE EXPECTED SATURDAY

TEXT.P: A petroleum price hike of 3 percent can be expected on Saturday, and consumers in Taiwan are likely to see three other price hikes by next June.

Speaking at a Legislative Yuan committee meeting, President of the state-run Chinese Petroleum Corp. (CPC) Pan Wen-yen said on Thursday that a petroleum price hike will be announced on Friday at the earliest, but that the most likely time for the announcement will be Saturday.
He said the CPC is still seeking to obtain approval from the Economics Ministry to raise the price by more than the current maximum of 3 percent.

It is within the CPC's power to raise petroleum prices by up to 3 percent, but if the increase is over 3 percent, it has to be approved by an advisory committee on energy and electricity rates under the Economics Ministry.

CPC Chairman Chen Chao-wei said the CPC has no choice but to raise prices to reflect the increased cost of purchasing imported crude oil in the wake of the sharp devaluation of the Taiwan dollar. But under pressure from the Legislative Yuan, Chen added that the CPC is likely to raise petroleum prices in stages instead of all at once.

Chen noted that based on the current foreign exchange rate of NT$31.93 to the US dollar and the international crude oil price of US$18.27 per barrel, the CPC will incur an additional NT$22 billion (US$676 million) in purchasing costs over the next seven months. With a 3 percent price hike, sales revenue will only increase by NT$5.2 billion during the seven-month period, he added, pointing out that if the CPC wants to make up its losses in purchasing costs, it will have to make four 3 percent increases by next June.

DOC.HEADLINE: MANDELA CONFERS MEDAL ON OUTGOING ROC ENVOY
DOC.DATELINE: Johannesburg, Dec. 11 (CNA) (By Bear Lee and Chang Jer-shong)

TEXT.P: On the eve of the severance of diplomatic relations between Taipei and Pretoria, South African President Nelson Mandela on Thursday conferred the Order of Good Hope, Grand Officer on the outgoing Republic of China Ambassador, Loh I-cheng.

During the ceremony, which took place at Mandela's residence in Pretoria, the president described the order as the highest honor that his government offers to foreigners who have contributed to the well-being of the people of South Africa.

He said that during his tenure, Loh has played a very important role in encouraging both the ROC government and the business sector's participation in South Africa's reconstruction and other development programs.

Mandela noted that during Loh's tenure, trade between Taiwan and South Africa increased from US$800 million to over US$1.4 billion, while Taiwan investment grew to US$1 billion. Loh has served as the ROC envoy since 1990.

He said Loh "deserves the honor" as he has made great efforts in promoting a long-lasting relationship between the people of the two nations. He also asked Loh, who is scheduled to leave for Taipei on Friday, to convey his best regards to ROC President Lee Teng-hui.
Mandela announced late last year that his government will shift its diplomatic recognition from Taipei to Beijing from Jan. 1, 1998.

Since then, negotiators from the two nations have held several rounds of talks on establishing a framework for future ties, and recently reached an accord. Details of the new framework, however, have yet to be announced.

DOC.HEADLINE: HONG KONG EXPORTS TO TAIWAN UP
DOC.DATELINE: Hong Kong, Dec. 11 (CNA) (By Stanley Cheung and Flor Wang)

TEXT.P: Hong Kong imported HK$11.8 billion-worth of Taiwan products in October, up 9.9 percent from the same month of 1996, making Taiwan its fourth-largest source of imports behind mainland China, Japan and the United States, according to statistics released on Thursday by the Hong Kong government.
The tallies also indicate that Hong Kong imports of Taiwan products topped HK$103 billion in the first 10 months of this year, an increase of 1.1 percent from the same period of 1996.

The same statistics also show that HK$2.7 billion-worth of products were transshipped through Hong Kong to Taiwan in October, up 13.6 percent from a year ago, while the figure for the January-October period amounted to HK$22.4 billion, up 11.8 percent from the corresponding period of last year.
Taiwan is Hong Kong's seventh-largest export market after mainland China, the US, Japan, Britain, Germany and Singapore in that order, the tallies point out.

DOC.HEADLINE: INDONESIA WANTS EXPANDED AGRICULTURAL COOPERATION WITH TAIWAN
DOC.DATELINE: Jakarta, Dec. 11 (CNA) (By Wu Pin-chiang and Flor Wang)

TEXT.P: Indonesian Agricultural Minister Sjarifudin Baharsjah on Thursday praised the Republic of China's successful development of its small business and agricultural sectors and expressed the desire to boost bilateral cooperation in these two fields.

Baharsjah made the remarks during the second ROC-Indonesia agricultural cooperation meeting, in which Baharsjah and his ROC counterpart, Council of Agriculture Chairman Peng Tso-kuei, signed the minutes of the conference.

Peng said the ROC agreed to cooperate with Indonesia in young farmer exchanges and to provide loans to Indonesian farmers. He added that the two sides will take part in a working party meeting slated for March next year to discuss five "vanguard exhibition programs" raised by the Indonesian side.

The ROC-Indonesia ministerial-level agricultural meeting has been held every year since July, 1995, when the two sides inked a memorandum of understanding to boost cooperation in the farming and aquaculture sectors, as well as in the development of rural areas.
The two sides have launched 10 agricultural cooperation projects over the past two years, according to Peng.

DOC.HEADLINE: CSC UNVEILS NEW CLASS OF BULK CARRIER

TEXT.P: After successfully developing two new types of bulk carrier with displacements of 165,000 tons and 149,000 tons, respectively, the state-run China Shipbuilding Corp. (CSBC) recently unveiled a new fuel-efficient bulk carrier of 80,000 tons which they hope will claim a niche in the shipping market.

Sources at the CSBC's Kaohsiung headquarters said the new ship, patterned on the design of a much smaller 45,000 ton carrier, has a length of 225 meters, a width of 27 meters, and a height of 18.7 meters. It has passed international seaworthiness tests with high scores, said the sources.

With a 13,299 horsepower engine, it reached a speed of 16 knots in a test voyage on sea with waves no bigger than three degrees, while loaded with 30,000 tons of cargo and with a clean and smooth hull.
The vessel's striking fuel-efficiency is expected to create a strong appeal on the part of shipping operators, said the CSBC sources, adding that one domestic shipping firm has already ordered two.

DOC.HEADLINE: TAIWAN TO PARTICIPATE IN WORLD EFFORTS TO CUT GREENHOUSE GASES

TEXT.P: In line with world efforts to help save the earth from catastrophic global warming, Taiwan will work out plans to cut greenhouse gas emissions, a technology counseling meeting sponsored by the Executive Yuan decided on Thursday.

A report issued after the meeting said that even though the ROC is neither a member of the United Nations nor a participant in the just-concluded global climate conference in the Japanese city of Kyoto, Taiwan will make efforts to cut its greenhouse gas emissions and will submit its plans to the UN by next March.

The report said that greenhouse gas emissions in Taiwan reached 149 million metric tons in 1991, 83 percent of which was carbon dioxide and 15 percent methane. Most greenhouse gases were emitted as a by-product of energy consumption, accounting for 78 percent of the total, while landfills were the main source of methane.

Taiwan's greenhouse gas emissions ranked in 27th place among 160 countries around the world and accounted for 0.5 percent of the total global emissions. It is estimated that Taiwan will see an increase in such emissions over the next 14 years, with annual growth forecast at 3.1 percent, signaling an urgent need for the government to control such emissions.

The report said that as the government has been pushing for trash recycling and the setting up of several new incinerators around the island, the emission of methane is expected to be brought under control, and government efforts should therefore focus on the control of carbon dioxide emissions.

Total carbon dioxide emission reached 170 million metric tons in 1996, an increase of 52 percent compared with the 1990 level. The figure is estimated to climb to 294 million metric tons by 2010, making Taiwan's per capita carbon dioxide emission the highest in the world.

The report proposed several emission-cutting measures such as reduction of energy consumption, trash recycling, increasing use of low-carbon or non-carbon energy, the changing of the island's industrial structure, and reforestation.

DOC.HEADLINE: CAL REACHES SETTLEMENT WITH RELATIVES OF NAGOYA CRASH VICTIMS
DOC.DATELINE: Tokyo, Dec. 11 (CNA) (By Bear Lee and Mike Chang)

TEXT.P: Taipei-based China Airlines on Thursday reached a settlement with the 77 relatives of 20 victims of a 1994 aircraft crash at central Japan's Nagoya airport over compensation payments.
CAL officials in Nagoya said the settlement, although not the first to be reached with individual victims, is the first to be reached with a group of victims' relatives.

The officials declined to reveal details of the terms of the settlement under which CAL is believed to have agreed to pay more compensation than its initial offer of 16.4 million yen (US$127,000) per victim.
The CAL Airbus-6000 crashed during landing on April 26, 1994, killing 264 of the 271 passengers and crew.
Several different groups of relatives of the victims have filed lawsuits at Japanese courts against both CAL and the European aircraft consortium Airbus Industrie, maker of the ill-fated plane.

DOC.HEADLINE: CANADIAN TRIBUNAL RULES TAIWAN DUMPING BICYCLES

TEXT.P: A Canadian court on Wednesday renewed antidumping duties on bicycle imports from Taiwan and mainland China, prompting Canada's three major manufacturers to celebrate.
"We won," exulted lawyer Geoff Kubrick, just after the Canadian International Trade Tribunal in Montreal issued its ruling.

The Canadian bike makers had argued that their industry of 1,300 employees and sales of C$300 million (US$211 million) would be in jeopardy if the five-year protection against cheap foreign bikes were allowed to expire this month.
"This guarantees the survival of the Canadian industry," claimed Kubrick, who represented the manufacturers in court.
"Now these Chinese and Taiwanese manufacturers will have to pedal their dumped bicycles somewhere else," he said in a jubilant voice.

The trade court will release the reasons for its decision in two weeks, but Kubrick believes it will note that Europe, Mexico and Argentina have anti-dumping rulings in effect against mainland Chinese and, in some cases, Taiwanese bicycles.

Bikes that cost more than C$325 (US$230) are excluded from the ruling. The three companies all have their plants in Quebec. They are industry leader Procycle, which makes many brands including CCM and Peugeot, and owns Rocky Mountain Bicycles of Delta, British Colombia.; Raleigh Industries of Oakville, Ontario, with its plant in Waterloo, Quebec; and Victoria Precision, based in Montreal.
The three supply about half of Canada's bicycles. Taiwan supplies 16 percent, mainland China 7 percent and other countries 18 percent.

DOC.HEADLINE: ANTI-DUMPING TARIFF ON BICYCLES WILL BARELY AFFECT TAIWAN

TEXT.P: A decision by the Canadian government to extend the anti-dumping tariff on Taiwan-made bicycles will have only limited impact on Taiwan's bicycle exports, the Economics Ministry said on Thursday.

An official with the ministry's Board of Foreign Trade said that the five-year anti-dumping tariff on Taiwan-made bicycles, which expired on Thursday, is to be extended according to a decision made a day earlier by the Canadian international trade court. The court will announce details of the tariff extension in two weeks, he said.

Saying that local manufacturers expected the result, the official noted that Canada is not the main outlet for Taiwan-made bicycles, pointing out that Taiwan only exported some 173,600 bicycles to Canada last year.

An official of Giant, Taiwan's leading manufacturer, said that the Canadian government's verdict didn't take local makers by surprise, adding that his company only exported some 14,000 bicycles to Canada last year, a quite small ratio compared to the one million bicycles the company exported worldwide during the same period.

He said that according to his understanding, the Canadian government will follow previous practices, in that the anti-dumping tariff will be imposed on bicycles with a unit price lower than C$325 (NT$7,475).

DOC.HEADLINE: TAIWAN TO CREATE BARRIER-FREE CLIMATE FOR INVESTORS

TEXT.P: President Lee Teng-hui said Thursday that the Republic of China will create "barrier-free climate" for investors.
He made the remark at a year-end banquet given by Economic Minister Wang Chih-kang in honor of foreign diplomats and trade officials.

Lee said the government will also lower the tax burden on investors, adjust the economic structure of the country, and take effective measures to tackle the problems facing the nation in the fields of energy, environmental protection, and technological development.
To facilitate the work of building Taiwan into a "technological island," the government welcomes technical transfer from the developed countries, he added.
Meanwhile, Economic Minister Wang told the 120 foreign dignitaries at the banquet that Taiwan has been successful in trade and economic development this year.

Exports from Taiwan totaled US$100 billion in the first 10 months of this year, a hike of five percent from a year earlier. Investment by the private sector also increased 14.1 percent during the period.
Foreign investment in Taiwan reached US$3,048 million in the 10-month period, a jump of 83.2 percent over the same period of last year, he said.
The government is taking effective measures to promote free trade, he added. (by Ed Hsieh)

DOC.HEADLINE: BETTER COMMUNICATION TOP PRIORITY ON BAYER PROJECT: CEPD HEAD

TEXT.P: P.K. Chiang, chairman of the Council for Economic Planning and Development (CEPD), on Friday said that clearing up public misgivings over an investment project in central Taiwan by the German-based conglomerate Bayer will be the council's top priority.
Chiang made the remarks after he and Liao Yung-lai, magistrate-elect of Taichung County, appeared on a local cable TV program Thursady night.

Liao, who had earlier insisted on linking the fate of the investment project to the outcome of a public referendum, seemed to soften his stance. He said that he would welcome every possible method by government agencies, including public hearings, to ease concerns over the project before initiating a county-wide vote.

Liao also said he would not insist on holding the public referendum next month as previously planned, suggesting instead that an opinion survey of Taichung County residents could be conducted before putting the matter to a vote.
Chiang said that the government's first priority at present is to ease public misgivings over the possible threat posed by Bayer's proposed chemical plant project to the local environment.

Liao said residents in Taichung have worries about the pollution levels that will be created by the Bayer facility and the potential danger to public safety. He claimed that the CEPD has failed to inform Bayer officials about such concerns, and has also neglected to clearly explain the manufacturing process associated with the chemical plant to the public.

Chiang said he would continue discuss the matter with Bayer over the next few days and would attend public hearings if necessary, stressing that the CEPD will do its utmost to improve communications among all parties involved.
Horst Mueck, chairman and president of Bayer Taiwan Co., later called on Chiang to discuss details for stepping up communications.

DOC.HEADLINE: BEIJING SAYS TAIPEI NONRESPONSIVE TO JIANG OFFER ON TALKS
DOC.DATELINE: Beijing, Dec. 12 (CNA) (By Wang Hsin-chung & Eva Chen)

TEXT.P: Taipei has not made an "active or formal" response to a call for resumption of dialogue issued by Chinese Communist Party (CCP) Secretary-General Jiang Zemin, mainland China's Foreign Ministry spokesman Tang Guoqiang remarked on Thursday.

Tang, speaking at a press conference, further emphasized that communication channels between Beijing and Taipei are not necessarily limited to the Beijing-based Association for Relations Across the Taiwan Strait (ARATS) and the Taipei-based Straits Exchange Foundation (SEF).

Tang's remarks were made in response to questions from Western reporters about Beijing's reaction to a recent call by Republic of China President Lee Teng-hui urging the resumption of cross-strait talks.

Tang said that during the 15th National Congress of the CCP in September, Jiang had suggested the resumption of dialogue across the Taiwan Strait could begin with the termination of the hostilities between the two sides. However, Tang claimed, that overture has not seen an active or formal response from the Taipei authorities.

Regarding the meaning of a "formal response," Tang said he was referring to Jiang's standing eight-point proposal, which suggested "negotiations as a first step in formally putting an end to hostilities under the one-China principle; the two sides should shoulder the responsibility of safeguarding Chinese sovereignty and territorial integrity and work out plans for future development of cross-strait ties."
As to whether such a response should be made through the ARATS and the SEF, Tang stressed that contacts do not necessarily have to proceed under established mechanisms.

DOC.HEADLINE: EVERGREEN CALLS A HALT TO AIRLINE PLAN IN PANAMA
DOC.DATELINE: Panama City, Dec. 11 (CNA) (By Edward Chen & Deborah Kuo)

TEXT.P: The Taipei-based Evergreen Group has halted plans to establish an airline company in Panama through which it had hoped to enter the Latin American air passenger market, Panamanian newspapers reported on Thursday.

According to Lin Yueh-teng, a spokesman for Evergreen Group in Panama, the establishment of Eva Panama Airway (EVAPA Airway) was temporarily suspended in consideration of fierce competition in the regional market, the news reports said.

The reports said EVA Airway, an offshoot of Evergreen Group, planned to set up an affiliate, dubbed EVAPA Airway, in Panama City, in an effort to gain a foothold on the commercial airline markets in Central and South America.
Under the plan, EVA had reportedly sought to invite Gabriel Castro, an official with Panama's National Security Council, to serve as board chairman of EVAPA Airway.

However, the reports disclosed that Evergreen decided to nix the EVAPA Airway plan to avoid possible conflict with Panama Airlines in contending for shares of the region's relatively small air services market.

DOC.HEADLINE: LEE MEETS HOLLYWOOD CELEBRITIES

TEXT.P: President Lee Teng-hui on Friday met with movie director Ang Lee, American actress Sigourney Weaver, and other film industry notables from abroad who are here to attend the 34th Taipei Golden Horse Film Festival.

Lee offered appreciation to award-winning director Ang Lee, who has gained fame in the West in recent years, for his achievements in film direction which were described as being a source of pride for all Chinese.
The president said he is very fond of Ang Lee's "Wedding Banquet," which he described as a lighthearted piece that tells a moving human-interest story.
President Lee urged director Lee, who was born and raised in Taiwan, to make a film about Taiwan to "tell the world about the island from a cultural and sentimental perspective."
Both Lee and Weaver have been invited to present awards at the Golden Horse Film Festival Awards Ceremony on Saturday evening.
Weaver, who was the leading actress in Ang Lee's latest work "Ice Storm," is also here to promote her own project "Alien: Resurrection."
Also among those in President Lee's audience Friday morning was Chinese-American Jessica Yu, who won an Oscar last year for her 35-minute documentary "Breathing Lessons."

DOC.HEADLINE: MINISTER MEETS INMATES-TURNED-WRITERS

TEXT.P: Justice Minister Liao Cheng-hao on Monday met with two inmates of Penghu Prison and the teachers who inspired them to write behind bars.

Two of the inmates presented Liao with a pre-publication copy of their book titled "Postcards from the Edge," a collection of 21 pieces of prose and verse written by the members of Penghu Prison's writing class, the first of its kind in Taiwan.
Impressed by the inmates' performances, Liao encouraged them to continue to write, which he said will help them find new lives and inspiration within themselves.

Liao also expressed gratitude to the teachers of the writing class -- who include renowned authors Ou Yin-chao, Chang Tien-wan and Shen Hua-mo, a poet -- for the love and patience they have shown the inmates.
According to Ou, many inmates shed tears upon seeing their writings appear in print, an achievement she said most of them had never even considered before.

Ou described the slim volumes as "postcard books" because they contain 21 bound postcards carrying a poem or short story by the inmates and pictures taken by five Penghu-based photographers who volunteered to help make the book more appealing.
A local publishing firm has agreed to put out the books free of charge. They will be available islandwide soon.

DOC.HEADLINE: NA DEPUTY SPEAKER IN CRITICAL CONDITION AFTER SUFFERING STROKE

TEXT.P: National Assembly (NA) Deputy Speaker Hsieh Lung-sheng suffered a serious stroke Thursday afternoon and is reported to be in a deep coma following emergency medical treatment.
The Taiwan political heavyweight was stricken as he made a mobile telephone call while traveling by car to his hometown of Tamsui.
Hsieh, 56, suddenly lost consciousness in the middle of his conversation and was rushed to the National Taiwan University Hospital in downtown Taipei.

According to hospital sources, Hsieh remained in an unconscious state with abnormal dilation of his pupils after being wheeled into the emergency room. Members of the medical team eventually got him to respond to light and sensation returned to his feet.
He was placed in an intensive care unit, although he remains in a deep coma and is kept breathing by machines.
Kao Ming-chien, head of the hospital's neurosurgery department, told the press Friday that following a 12-hour long process of observation, they found that Hsieh's condition has not deteriorated.
However, the doctor said, he is suffering from pneumonia which occurred as a result of choking due to a large amount of food in his stomach at the time of the stroke.

Kao explained that an aneurysm that resulted in serious cerebral hemorrhaging was the culprit behind the apoplexy which nearly took Hsieh's life. Nevertheless, the NA deputy speaker remains in critical condition.

Taipei political circles were shocked over the incident as Hsieh, a well-known stalwart of the ruling Kuomintang (KMT), had played a key role in the passage of KMT-guided amendments to the Republic of China Constitution earlier this year.
Hsieh was elected in 1986 to the National Assembly, which fills the role of the nation's parliament in conjunction with the Legislative Yuan. He had previously served as county representative.

With a frank, upright and generous personality, Hsieh has numerous friends in both political and business circles, which has allowed him to enjoy broad influence and a high-ranking position in the NA.
The political heavyweight has also gained the nickname "The King of Palau," due to his successful investments in that West Pacific island nation.
Hsieh also maintains a close relationship with ROC President Lee Teng-hui, who on Friday sent his Secretary-General Huang Kun-huei to the hospital to inquire about the deputy speaker's condition.

DOC.HEADLINE: CHIPS SALES ACROSS ASIA RISE, WITH EXCEPTION OF JAPAN

TEXT.P: Despite the financial turmoil in Asian countries, world semiconductors sales hit their highest mark of the year in October as sales reached nearly US$ 12 billion, an increase of 12 percent compared to the same period last year, according a Semiconductor Industry Association (SIA) report released Thursday.

The San Jose-based SIA's report was made public in the midst of predictions that the near-meltdown performance in some of Asian countries' currency and stocks markets would drag the price and demand of chips to the bottom.

"With the exception of Japan, global sales continued to build upon the momentum of a growth trend that surfaced at the end of the first quarter," said Doug Andrey, SIA director of information systems and finance. "Japan's sales, computed in US dollars, were crimped by the depreciation of the yen against dollar."

The Asia-Pacific market, excluding Japan, showed across-the-board sales gains. October sales reached US$ 2.73 billion, a 1.7 percent gain from September's total and a 21.4 percent jump from October 1996 sales.

"The Asia-Pacific market remains strong despite the recent currency crisis in Korea and other Asian countries," Andrey said. "Over the long term, demand for semiconductor products should continue to expand in all markets, including Asia-Pacific, because chips are fundamentally improving the way we live, work and communicate."

According to the Global Sales Report for October, sales rose steadily in three of the four major chip markets, with Europe showing the most dramatic month-to-month gains. Sales in the American market and the Asia-Pacific market continued to show the most dramatic year-to-year growth.
With total sales of US$11.99 billion, October was also the strongest sales month since March 1996 when sales hit US$12.11 billion.
The SIA report puts all Asia Pacific countries, excluding Japan, into one category, therefore the specific sales of chips in Taiwan is not available, a spokesman for the association said.

DOC.HEADLINE: SINGAPORE'S AEROSPACE INDUSTRY FLYING HIGH

TEXT.P: Singapore's aerospace industry revenue is expected to grow a robust 16.7 percent to S$1.84 billion this year with investments rising 18.9 percent to S$145 million.

Its output growth next year is expected to continue at a double-digit rate and new investments will at least equal this year's as the industry strives to obtain a larger share of regional and global markets, the Singapore Economic Development Board (EDB) said Thursday.
The industry's average output growth was 7.7 percent a year between 1993 and 1996.
The EDB pointed out that the strong growth resulted from the sector having capitalized on the global upturn in the aerospace industry as well as from new investments over the past three years.
This year's investments are expected to create 800 new jobs in the industry which currently employs 9,485 workers.
Of the 55 aerospace companies in Singapore, 20 were new outfits that had set up operations in the last three to four years, EDB said.

It added that the aerospace industry's output contributed just over 1 percent to Singapore's manufacturing output last year, but the value-added amount contributed by each worker came close to the manufacturing sector's national average of S$76,924 last year. This year, the value added by each worker in the aerospace industry is expected to rise 10 percent to S$84,439.

Aircraft repair and overhauls, the main contributor to the industry's output, is expected to grow 16.8 percent and account for 87.3 percent of total output this year. Seventy percent of this is generated in Asian markets.
It is understood that Singapore has more than 40 percent of Asia's aircraft repair and overhauls market.
Output of aerospace manufacturing operations is likely to account for 12.7 percent of the industry's output.

The EDB said Asia was expected to lead the growth in the world air travel market in the long term despite its economic crisis. The region was expected to receive 35 percent of global aircraft deliveries over the next 10 to 20 years.
And the Asia-Pacific region would lead worldwide growth in the aircraft repair and overhauls market over the next decade, it added.

DOC.HEADLINE: FIRES IN JAKARTA UP 60 PERCENT

TEXT.P: The incidence of fires in Jakarta increased by 60 percent this year, a fire-fighting official said.
The head of the city's fire services department, Suharso, said on Thursday a total of 1,186 fires occurred in the city this year while only 723 fires were recorded last year.
Fires this year have so far claimed the lives of 38 people.
Suharso said carelessness and electrical facilities were the most dominant causal factors in the incidents.
"Our people still underestimate possible danger of fires from things such as oil lamps, cigarette butts and old electrical instruments," he was quoted by Antara news agency as saying.
The fires in 1997 caused up to 97 billion rupiah in material losses apart from the fire at the Bank Indonesia office tower that killed 15 people on Monday.
The city fire brigade has a total of 2,557 personnel and 178 vehicular units.
Meanwhile, police on Thursday interrogated four more people as witnesses in the recent fire which gutted the top four floors of Bank Indonesia tower.
Chief of Jakarta Metropolitan Police Maj. Gen. Hamami Nata said 21 witnesses had been questioned earlier in connection with the blaze.
"But we do not rule out the possibility that they will become suspects in the event strong evidence is produced regarding their involvement with the fire," he said.
The 21 witnesses include Bank Indonesia employees, construction workers and cleaning service workers.
Meanwhile, Chief of the Indonesian Police Gen. Dibyo Widodo said the cause of the fire was still under investigation.
Chief of the Jakarta Metropolitan Police's Detective Unit Col. Gories Mere, who met Widodo on Wednesday, said the blaze started on the 24th floor.
"We are awaiting the result of a laboratory test to name suspects in the fire," Widodo said.
Police officers were seen guarding the top three floors of the 25-story building which was to be inaugurated early next year.

DOC.HEADLINE: CANADIAN CURRENCY DOWN, INTEREST RATE TO GO UP

TEXT.P: The Canadian dollar traded below seventy US cents, dropping to as low as 69.98 US cents Thursday morning before recovering to 70.11 US cents at 2:00 p.m. The drop opens the door for the Bank of Canada to raise interest rates.
It was the first time the dollar had dropped that low in nearly twelve years. Not even the late 1995 Quebec referendum brought the Canadian currency down that far.

The Canadian Imperial Bank of Commerce and Royal Bank were not waiting. They announced that mortgage rates will rise between a fifth and just over a third of a percentage point on terms ranging from one to seven years.
At both institutions, the rate for a one-year closed mortgage will be 6.10 percent, up from 5.9 percent, with a five-year term going up from 6.7 percent to 7.05 percent.
The CIBC said it had to raise the rate because of the rising cost of borrowing money on the bond market.
Current prime rate at Canada's major commercial banks was 5.5 percent. The Bank of Canada, or central bank, rate was 4 percent.

DOC.HEADLINE: US DOLLAR UP

TEXT.P: The US dollar rose NT$0.421 against the New Taiwan dollar on the Taipei foreign exchange market Friday, closing at NT$32.321.
The greenback opened at 32.46, and experienced a high of 32.599 and a low of 32.205.
Interbank US dollar trading reached US$448 million.

DOC.HEADLINE: SHARE PRICES REBOUND ON TAIEX

TEXT.P: Prompted by vigorous purchases of plastic and chemical stocks, share prices on the Taiwan Stock Exchange closed 1.5 percent higher, or 127.69 points, with the weighted price index climbing to 8,398.27 on Friday.

Dealers said investors swarmed for those shares after there were reports alleging foreign orders for plastic and chemical goods might turn to Taiwan from South Korea, where the won's serious devaluation was said to have a negative impact on their supply of the products.
The bourse opened at the day's low of 8,135.17 and rebounded to finish at the day's high of 8,398.27.
Gainers outnumbered losers 308 to 108, with 53 stocks remaining unchanged. In all, 2.96 billion shares changed hands on a market turnover of NT$154.22 billion (US$4.97 billion).

All eight stock categories enjoyed growth, with a 2.9 percent surge by plastic and chemical stocks, 2.8 percent by construction issues, 1.7 percent by electrical engineering shares, and 1.6 percent by paper and pulp issues.
Both textile and financial stocks rose 1.4 percent, while cement and foodstuff shares gained 0.5 percent respectively.

United Micro Electronics, ACER, Ever Fortune, International Bills Finance, China Petrochemical Development, Mitac International, Taiwan Styrene Monomer, Pao Shiang, Taiwan Semiconductor Manufacturing and Shin Kong Life Insurance were the companies enjoying the 10 largest turnovers.

DOC.HEADLINE: TAIWAN TO BECOME A 'BRIDGE TO ASIA': SIEW

TEXT.P: To make Taiwan a regional financial center, the government has put forth an implementation plan guided by five overriding values broadly categorized as liberalization, cooperation, efficiency, transparency and excellence, Premier Vincent Siew said Friday.

Speaking to the Conference on the Development of a Regional Financial Center in Taiwan, Siew said the government envisions a regional center "open for business," which will facilitate the free flow of capital and remove impediments to trade.

Taiwan will also endeavor to reduce trade barriers, call for cooperation among foreign and local entities, and work to build public-private partnerships, Siew told his audience. "We would like to be not only a gateway but also a bridge to Asia," he noted.

Siew said Taiwan will make every effort not only to reduce the cost of doing business in Asia but also to "maximize benefits for all stakeholders, whether they are individual parties to transactions or members of the greater community at large."

In addition, he said, the Republic of China would like to build a level playing field for business and attract as many players as possible. "To promote accessibility and accountability, the regional financial center favors transparency of transactions and free flow of information. Furthermore, the ramp to the information superhighway has been constructed," he added.
He said the government's most important goal in this plan is to build a center "synonymous with excellence," whose quality of service and supporting infrastructure will be first rate.

Capital markets have become globalized as impediments to foreign participation in the local bourse are removed, he noted. From July 1995 to August 1997, foreign capital in the local stock market grew from US$5.8 billion to US$10.9 billion. Concurrently, domestic public companies are being encouraged to issue depository receipts or corporate bonds overseas, he said.
"My government will continue to foster and promote trade by staying the course toward the greater liberalization and globalization of the Taiwan market," he added.
"We believe that a balance between competition and cooperation should be maintained with other financial markets in the region," he said.
As the economies of Hong Kong, Singapore and Shanghai flourish and the movement of capital accelerates, closer coordination and interaction are essential, Siew stressed.

DOC.HEADLINE: NO CONFLICT BETWEEN BEING TAIWANESE AND ROC NATIONAL: JOHN CHANG

TEXT.P: John Chang, secretary general of the ruling Kuomintang, said on Friday that there is no conflict between identifying yourself as Taiwanese and being a national of the Republic of China.
Chang, who was born in mainland China and brought up in Taiwan, said he believes that most Taiwanese would not deny they are ROC nationals.

A survey made public earlier this week by the cabinet-level Mainland Affairs Council showed that more than 37 percent of those interviewed described themselves as "Taiwanese," a figure that for the first time surpassed the percentage of those who said they are both "Taiwanese and Chinese" in previous similar polls.

"Our country is the Republic of China," Chang said, adding that anyone who identifies with this place can say he is Taiwanese. There is no conflict between being Taiwanese and an ROC national, he stressed.

Chang noted that when those interviewed in the survey were asked if they think of themselves as "Chinese," this could have made them think "mainland Chinese," which he said might be the reason why the number of people calling themselves Chinese was low in the poll.
Those who said they are Taiwanese would not deny that they are also ROC nationals, Chang said, adding, "If you refuse to possess an ROC passport, how could you travel around the world?"

DOC.HEADLINE: FINANCIAL AID BY INDIVIDUAL COUNTY IMPROPER: CEPD OFFICIAL

TEXT.P: Responding to a proposal by a ranking official of the ruling Kuomintang (KMT) that Taiwan provide a US$10 billion loan to help South Korea overcome its financial crisis, an official with the cabinet-level Council for Economic Planning and Development (CEPD) said on Friday that financial assistance by an individual country is inappropriate and that such acts should be conducted through regional aid-providing mechanisms.

M.F. Yeh, director of the Economic Research Department under the CEPD, said international assistance to South Korea would be better made through regional mechanisms and that the International Monetary Fund (IMF) should consider accelerating the pace of its allocation of relief funds to that county if its first batch of US$57 billion is insufficient.

In addition to the IMF, other regional organizations such as the Asia-Pacific Economic Cooperation forum and the Asian Development Bank should also offer to help South Korea cope with its financial difficulties.

Yeh's remarks came after Liu Tai-ying, chairman of the KMT's Business Management Committee, said on Thursday that the financial turbulence in South Korea is far more serious than what Taiwan has perceived and that Taiwan should take the initiative by providing a loan of US$10 billion to help South Korea recover from the current financial disaster.

If Taiwan made such a move, Liu said, it might lead Japan to provide another loan of US$30-40 billion, which, coupled with the IMF's US$57 billion, would be enough for South Korea to control the situation.

DOC.HEADLINE: SAUDI FALCON PRICES SKY-HIGH

TEXT.P: Falcons are very expensive in Saudi Arabia, where a rare white Persian falcon recently went for US$120,000 at a show in Al-Khobar.
Saudi falcon aficionado Mohammed Al-Shateeli said that even though falcons are costly, many Saudis love them very much and willing to pay high prices to own one.
At the Al-Khobar show, Al-Zinabah falcons cost a minimum of US$40,000. Honey-colored Al-Ash'al Al-Mughtar falcons sold for at least US$26,000, while red falcons went for some US$19,000.

Al-Shateeli pointed out that those unfamiliar with falcons may consider these prices exorbitant and unreasonable. But for those who love falconry, he said, money is not the consideration but rather the sheer joy of owning a prize bird.

DOC.HEADLINE: 111 NEW HIV CASES IN LAST 90 DAYS

TEXT.P: Some 111 new HIV cases were reported in Taiwan in the past three months, bringing the total number of those on the island infected with the virus that leads to AIDS to 1,654, the Department of Health (DOH) said Friday.

DOH officials said that among the new cases reported since statistics were last compiled on Sept. 10, 105 are local people, while six are expatriates, including one student, a Thai woman, two tourists, a worker and a foreign bride. By gender, 98 are males, while 13 are females.

The officials said that though the island's total number of patients under 18 years old who are HIV-positive is not so large as in other nations, the fact that 62 percent of this group became infected through sexual behavior is alarming.

Statistics show that Taiwan has so far had 33 HIV-positive people under 18, five of whom have died. Twelve of the 33 are 12 years old or younger, most of them hemophiliacs, while the remaining 21 contracted the virus from sexual behavior.
DOH officials also expressed worries about the rising number of HIV-positive women, noting the ratio between men and women patients was 19 to 1 in 1992, but that it is now at to 9 to 1.
Infections between spouses have also risen sharply. Although only one baby could be confirmed to be infected with HIV, the officials said the actual number is likely higher.

They noted that the theme of World AIDS Day is to keep children from the shadow of AIDS. Though people 18 or younger who are HIV-positive account for only about 2 percent of the total number of those with the deadly virus here, that ratio has been increasing steadily as a result of insufficient sex education among youngsters, they said.

First lady Tseng Wen-hui said on the same occasion that 99 percent of child AIDS sufferers contracted the disease from their mothers. She lauded the Republic of China's ally El Salvador, noting that even though that country does not have the economic might of the ROC, it has a shelter for young AIDS sufferers.

DOC.HEADLINE: CHINESE CANADIANS REMEMBER RAPE OF NANKING (II)
DOC.DATELINE: Taipei, Dec. 12 (CNA) (By Lilian Wu) (By S.C. Chang)

TEXT.P: Chang, who sought out survivors and scoured archives, wrote the newly published book, "The Rape of Nanking: the Forgotten Holocaust of World War II."

She suggests that "the custodian of the curtain of silence was politics." Civil war engulfed China after Japan surrendered in 1945, and neither the Nationalist nor the Communist Chinese government pressed for reparations the way Israel did from Germany, the CP noted.
The United States, eager to have Japan on side against communism, refrained from pushing the issue, Chang writes.
Right-wing leaders in Japan have called the Nanking massacre an exaggeration, a lie. But there are also Japanese who vigorously block attempts to rewrite history.

After a 32-year court battle, historian Saburo Ienaga, 84, won a partial victory in August against the Japanese Education Ministry which ordered him to revise or delete references to atrocities in a textbook he wrote.

Japan's Supreme Court ruled that the ministry acted illegally in censoring his mention of the death camp and human experiments run by a Japanese biological warfare unit in occupied northeastern China.
But the court upheld the ministry's authority to screen textbooks and an order that Ienaga remove a reference to rape in a passage that reads:
"When the Japanese army occupied Nanking, they murdered large numbers of Chinese soldiers and civilians, and many of the Japanese officers and soldiers raped Chinese women."
The ministry's rationale: troops everywhere rape women during war and Japan should not be singled out.

DOC.HEADLINE: CHINESE CANADIANS REMEMBER RAPE OF NANKING (I)

TEXT.P: Sixty years ago this weekend a fate so horrific befell the Chinese city of Nanking that its aftershocks are still being felt today, the Canadian Press (CP) reported Thursday.
On Dec. 13, 1937, after a final night of battles under clear skies and a half moon, Imperial Japanese troops poured into Nanking, China's capital at the time, the CP said in a dispatch from Toronto.
In the ensuing six weeks, the Japanese invaders unleashed a bloodbath that became known as the "Rape of Nanking," said the report.

Unarmed inhabitants were slaughtered en masse throughout the walled city. The women were raped, humiliated and butchered. Corpses lined the meandering banks of the Yangtze River and filled ponds and trenches, the CP said.
The city now called Nanjing, 300 kilometers west of Shanghai, will sound its air raid sirens Saturday and observe three minutes of silence, it said.
In Canada, it pointed out, Chinese communities from Vancouver to Toronto and elsewhere grapple with the question: To remember or not to remember?
Those who believe remembrance will collar the capacity for evil so often unleashed by war are marking the anniversary while trying to curb any anti-Japanese sentiments.

"When we organize activities of this type we are always mindful about harmony between our two communities," the CP quoted Dr. Joseph Y.K. Wong, a family physician coordinating a commemorative peace concert in Toronto.
"We always remind the Chinese community that we are doing this not because of hatred," Wong was quoted. "This is done because we don't want this horrendous part of history to happen again."
Canada's ethnic Japanese say that they, as Canadians, had nothing to do with Japan's wartime behavior and in fact suffered from it.
The National Association of Japanese Canadians joined three other groups last month in petitioning Japan to apologize for war crimes.
It shows that concern for human rights "transcends cultural boundaries," association president Randy Enomoto said from Vancouver.
"We're proud of our cultural identity too, but that does not extend to war crimes which happened in the 1930s and '40s," Enomoto said.

The Nanking death toll remains a highly charged controversy. Many estimates put it between 200,000 and 300,000, though arguments that it should be far higher or much lower are fervently put forth, according to the CP.
But survivors, witnesses, film, photographs and confessions by Japanese soldiers, and evidence at the 1946-48 Tokyo war crimes trials point to the horrors that winter.
For many, death came only after torture and mutilation. The massacre evokes comparisons with Auschwitz among the Chinese, but is nowhere near as widely known or remembered outside Asian communities.

"The Rape of Nanking did not penetrate the world consciousness in the same manner as the Holocaust or Hiroshima because the victims themselves had remained silent," writes American author Iris Chang. (MORE)

DOC.HEADLINE: CPC ANNOUNCES 2.94 PERCENT PETROLEUM PRICE HIKE

TEXT.P: The state-run Chinese Petroleum Corp. (CPC) on Friday announced a petroleum price hike of 2.94 percent to help offset losses caused by the ongoing devaluation of the Taiwan dollar.

CPC Vice President Tsai San-lung said that from Friday midnight, gasoline prices will rise by NT$0.4 (US$0.012) per liter, while diesel prices will increase by NT$0.3 per liter and fuel oil by NT$172 per kiloliter.
This is the third time the CPC has raised petroleum prices this year, following two increases in January and April.

In an attempt to ease public concerns over inflation pressure imposed by the price hike, Tsai said that the increase will only push up the consumer price index by 0.126 percent and the wholesale price index by 0.155 percent.

He said the price increase was based on the exchange rate of NT$29.5 to the US dollar and the international crude oil price of US$16.992 per barrel. If these figures can be maintained until the CPC adopts a floating petroleum price policy, scheduled for January at the earliest, the CPC will not consider raising petroleum prices again, he added.

Economics Minister Wang Chih-kang said that it is within the CPC's power to raise petroleum prices by up to 3 percent and that he has approved the increase. As it is not high enough to reflect the increased cost of purchasing imported crude oil, the CPC is expected to fall short of its targeted surplus by nearly NT$10 billion for fiscal 1998, Wang noted.

Based on a foreign exchange rate of NT$31.93 to the US dollar and an international crude oil price of US$18.27 per barrel, the CPC will incur an additional NT$22 billion in purchasing costs over the next seven months. With a nearly 3 percent increase, sales revenue will only increase by NT$5.2 billion during the seven-month period.

The CPC's targeted surplus for fiscal 1998 was set at NT$22 billion. With a NT$7 billion surplus gained between July and October, the CPC is still expected to fall short of its targeted surplus by nearly NT$10 billion.

DOC.HEADLINE: TWO MORE FRIGATES TO ENTER NAVAL SERVICE

TEXT.P: The Navy of the Republic of China will see its defensive capabilities further upgraded with the addition of two more advanced types of frigates which are to be commissioned on Tuesday.
The two frigates, called "Panchao" and "Wuchang," will be put into service immediately after being commissioned by the navy.

The "Panchao," which has been delivered by the China Shipping Corp. (CSBC) to the Tsoying naval base in southern Taiwan, is the sixth of a series of the Perry-class frigates which the CSBC began building for the Navy in 1994.

The "Panchao" high-speed patrol frigate, modeled on the US-made Perry-class frigate, is equipped with its original weapons system and two US-made S-70C anti-submarine helicopters, as well as 40 mm and 76 mm guns and locally made Hsiung Fung II anti-ship missiles.
The powerful CSBC-built Perry-class frigates now form the backbone of the ROC fleet, effectively upgrading its three-dimensional air-defense, anti-ship and anti-submarine capabilities.
The "Wuchang," the fifth of six Lafayette-class frigates which the ROC has ordered from France, is also equipped with powerful weapons and anti-submarine systems.
The Lafayette-class frigates, whose unique design and construction render them invisible to radar, are currently owned only by France, the ROC and Saudi Arabia.
The "Wuchang" arrived at the Tsoying naval base on Monday after a voyage from France which lasted for more than 40 days.

DOC.HEADLINE: TAIWAN, SOUTH AFRICA REACH AGREEMENT ON FISHING COOPERATION

TEXT.P: Taiwan and South Africa have concluded annual fishing cooperation consultations in Capetown, in which the South African authorities agreed that the annual fishing fee for each Taiwan vessel operating in their territorial waters will remain unchanged next year, according to the Council of Agriculture (COA).

COA officials said the Taiwan delegation at the negotiations was headed by Kuo Chin-lau, deputy director of the council's fisheries department, while South Africa was represented by its own fisheries officials.
According to the agreement, 26 Taiwan fishing boats will be allowed to fish in South African territorial waters next year, with the annual fee for each vessel set at US$11,500.

The COA officials said that due to heavy pressure from its local fishermen's groups, the South African delegation had intended to reduce the quota of Taiwan fishing vessels to 20, but great efforts on the part of the Taiwan delegation had persuaded the South Africans to agree to a quota of 26.
The agreement also stated that the quota for swordfish be raised from 55 to 70 metric tons, while the quota for tuna be reduced from 2,200 to 2,000 metric tons.

DOC.HEADLINE: LIEN RECEIVES FOREIGN TECHNOLOGY ADVISORS

TEXT.P: Vice President Lien Chan on Friday met a group of foreign technology experts here to attend the 18th technology meeting of the Executive Yuan, and expressed appreciation for their contributions to the Republic of China's science-technology development.

Lien said the ROC government attaches great importance to technology development and welcomes the private sector to join forces with the government to ensure Taiwan's sustained progress and upgrade the quality of life for its people.

The 12 foreign technology advisors to the ROC government briefed Lien and raised proposals on a number of ROC government-sponsored development programs, ranging from the telecommunications sector to the agricultural industry, in the face of climate changes across the world and the increasing reduction of natural and water resources.

The 12 foreign advisors, which included Ian M. Ross, Pierre Aigrain, Robert Sproull, Max Rives and Hans Baur, among others, were accompanied by Vice Premier Liu Chao Shiuan, Lin Bih-jaw, deputy secretary general of the National Security Council, and Yang Shih-chien, minister without portfolio.

DOC.HEADLINE: ABORIGINAL CONCERT STAGED IN TAIPEI

TEXT.P: An aboriginal concert which included performances by l3 dancing troupes from foreign aboriginal groups, as well as several teams from local tribes, was staged in Taipei on Friday afternoon.

At the opening of the concert organized by the Council of Aboriginal Affairs (CAA), Premier Vincent Siew welcomed the foreign minority teams, saying that the concert underlines the government's policy of promoting minority culture and art.

Saying that exchanges between the world's minorities will help build consensus among them on safeguarding their rights, the premier promised to base the government's minority policy on the principles of "respect, caring, parity and protection."
Foreign Minister Jason Hu, who also attended the event, also lauded the idea of exchanges between minority groups around the world, saying that they will deepen mutual understanding.
The concert is the climax of the International Aboriginal Culture Festival held by the CAA to mark its first anniversary.

The festival, which opened on Dec. 7 in the eastern city of Hualien, featured minority music and dance and brought together aboriginal troupes from Canada, Cook Islands, Israel, Japan, Nauru, New Zealand, Nicaragua, Papua New Guinea, Peru, the Philippines, Spain, Scotland and the United States.
The United States entered two teams in the festival, one -- the Apsaalooke dancers -- from mainland USA, the other -- the Guam Natibu Dance Company -- from Guam.

After three days' performance in Hualien, the foreign troupes, as well as their Taiwan counterparts, divided into four groups to tour and perform at aboriginal communities around the island before gathering in Taipei for Friday's concert.
They will hold a parade in Taipei on Saturday and will exhibit their artwork and craft products at the Chiang Kai-shek Memorial Hall on Saturday and Sunday.
The eight-day festival will wrap up on Sunday with a celebration in Taipei for the 1st CAA anniversary.

DOC.HEADLINE: SUHARTO CANCELS PLANS TO ATTEND ASEAN SUMMIT

TEXT.P: President Suharto has canceled plans to attend the Dec. 15 ASEAN summit in Kuala Lumpur on the advice of his doctors, State Secretary/Minister Moerdiono said on Friday.
The president has instructed Foreign Affairs Minister Ali Alatas to represent him at the informal summit, said Moerdiono.
"If the president makes another long trip, it could take a longer time for him to restore his health," he was quoted by Antara news agency as saying.
Guarding the health of the president is crucial, because there are various state activities coming up which will require him to be in top physical shape, he said.
Alatas said that during the ASEAN summit, the nine members of ASEAN will meet with their dialogue partners, Japan, mainland China and South Korea.
The foreign minister said he will deliver a message from Suharto explaining his cancellation to Malaysian Prime Minister Mahathir Mohammed.

DOC.HEADLINE: BANK DEPOSIT OF PRESIDENT LEE AND WIFE INCREASES BY NT13 MILLION

TEXT.P: Although the bank deposit shared by President Lee Teng-hui and his wife has increased by some NT$13 million (US$406,200), their assets are otherwise almost the same as one year ago, according to documents Lee and his wife have filed with the Control Yuan.

Most of the increase comes from Lee's salary and interest on the couple's bank deposit. Lee has NT$350,000 (US$10,937) in a personal account, in addition to a golf club membership card. He also shares two golf club memberships with his wife Tseng Wen-hui, while she personally owns four cards.
Golf club cards are valuable assets in Taiwan, some of which can fetch millions of NT dollars on the market.
The Lees have the same number of cards as last year.

Tseng included a sapphire with a street value of NT$850,000 (US$26,562) on her list of valuable personal possessions, while her stocks in electronic giant ACER have increased from 900,000 shares to 1,200,000, which were valued on Friday at NT$58.5 per share.

Meanwhile, Premier Vincent Siew, who took office on Sept. 1, submitted a list of assets including a bank deposit -- some of which was in US dollars -- of NT$1 million. His wife and other family members registered an accumulated bank deposit of NT$6 million. This total is about NT1.2 million more than one year ago, when Siew was serving as a legislator.
Senior government officials have until Dec. 31 to register their assets with the Control Yuan, the nation's highest-level watchdog body.

DOC.HEADLINE: DPP CHAIRMAN, TAIPEI CITY MAYOR TO VISIT JAPAN
DOC.DATELINE: Tokyo, Dec. 13 (CNA) (By Victor Lai and Lilian Wu)

TEXT.P: Hsu Hsin-liang, chairman of the Republic of China's main opposition Democratic Progressive Party (DPP), and Taipei City Mayor Chen Shui-bian, also of the DPP, will visit Japan later this month, sources said on Saturday.
In the wake of the stunning DPP victory in Taiwan's Nov. 29 mayor and county chief election, the visit of the two opposition heavyweights has aroused keen interest here.
The DPP won 12 of the 23 seats up for grabs in the local elections, while the ruling Kuomintang (KMT) managed to retain only eight, and independent candidates took the remaining three.

Hsu is expected to arrive here on Dec. 18 after concluding a visit to the United States. Details of his itinerary in Japan have yet to be announced, but it is understood that Hsu will meet with groups supporting the DPP, as well as members of the Japanese media.
Meanwhile, Chen is scheduled to arrive in Tokyo on Dec. 25 for a two-day visit to attend a Taiwan film festival party being held in Tokyo's New Otani Hotel.
Chuang Ming-yao, representative of the Taipei Economic and Cultural Representative Office In Japan, which is one of the six co-sponsors of the festival, will also attend the party.
The film festival, aimed at promoting understanding of Taiwan, will officially open on Dec. 26 and will last until Feb. 15, 1998.
Chen is slated to attend a press conference at the foreign press club on Dec. 26 to discuss the political situation in Taiwan and the prospects for cross-Taiwan Strait relations.

A foreign press club news release described Chen as the most popular politician in Taiwan, and widely believed to be a possible victor in the island's next presidential election, which will be in 2000.
