DOC.HEADLINE: SHIPPING LOW-GRADE NUCLEAR WASTE TO N. KOREA SAID 'IMPRACTICAL'

TEXT.P: The state-owned Taiwan Power Company (Taipower) plan to ship low-grade radioactive waste to North Korea is "impractical," said former chancellor of the University of California at Berkeley, Tien Chang-ling, on Saturday.
Tien said it would be better to store the waste somewhere within the nation's own borders, at least for the next twenty years.
Tien, now a technology advisor to the Executive Yuan, made the remarks in a written statement at an Executive Yuan technology advisory meeting held at the Civil Aeronautics Administration.
The meeting was presided over by Premier Vincent Siew and Vice Premier Liu Chao-shiuan.

Tien said that although it is an attractive and technically feasible proposition to ship radioactive waste overseas, it is not a "practical" idea, considering Taiwan's sensitive position in the international community.

He stressed that for the next two decades, it would be better to store low-level nuclear waste on the island while continuing to search for long-term storage and disposal sites, whether here or overseas.

Taipower and North Korea signed a contract last year allowing the company to ship up to 60,000 barrels of low-grade radioactive waste to North Korea for permanent disposal. The plan has drawn a storm of protest from South Korea and environmental activists from other countries.

DOC.HEADLINE: TAIWAN TO HOLD 16TH ROUND OF WTO TALKS WITH US

TEXT.P: Several Republic of China trade officials are scheduled to leave for the United States on Saturday to attend the 16th round of Taipei-Washington bilateral talks on Taiwan's terms for joining the World Trade Organization (WTO).

Chen Ruey-long, director general of the ROC Board of Foreign Trade (BOFT) and the head of the delegation, told the CNA that technical issues will be the major topics of the meeting, which is to open in Washington on Monday.

Differences between the two sides concerning policy reforms, such as Washington's demand for Taiwan's easing of quota restrictions on American tobacco and alcohol, pork, chicken, rice, and offal, as well as proper tariff management, will be excluded from the upcoming agenda, Chen added, revealing his hope that this round of talks will see all technical problems related to US support for Taiwan's WTO bid resolved.

ROC-US WTO bilateral talks are entering their final stages, although the most complex problems have still to be worked out, the trade official said, pointing out that the US side has showed the high priority it has given to the upcoming negotiations by appointing Assistant Trade Representative Robert Cassidy to replace David Burns, director of Asia-Pacific affairs at the Trade Representative office, to represent the US in future talks.
According to the BOFT, technical issues relating to insurance, government purchases, tariff and quota management, along with agricultural matters, will be included in Monday's agenda.

Taiwan has concluded bilateral WTO negotiations with 23 economies out of a total of 26 WTO contracting parties which have expressed concern over Taiwan's trade regime, while two-way negotiations with the US, Switzerland and the European Union as a whole are still snarled by some thorny issues.

DOC.HEADLINE: US DOLLAR UP

TEXT.P: The US dollar rose NT$0.203 against the New Taiwan dollar on the Taipei foreign exchange market Saturday, closing at NT$32.524.
The greenback opened at 32.45, and was traded between 32.402 and 32.605.
Interbank US dollar trading reached US$73.5 million.

DOC.HEADLINE: TAIWAN BIDS TO ENTER GLOBAL SEMICONDUCTOR REGULATORY BODY

TEXT.P: The ROC government has received positive responses from the United States, Japan and European Union for Taiwan's bid to enter a world regulatory body on semiconductor manufacturing, the Ministry of Foreign Affairs (MOFA) said on Saturday.

Tung Kuo-you, deputy director of the MOFA's Department of International Organizations, said that the Global Governmental Forum (GGF), the only mechanism to be comprised of the governments of major semiconductor manufacturers, aims to coordinate global semiconductor policy through government dialogues, so as to achieve production orders and avoid dumping.
The forum, founded a year ago, has four members -- the US, Japan, South Korea and the European Union.

Noting that Taiwan is the fourth-largest semiconductor producer, with production value forecast to reach US$66 billion by 2005, with a world market share of 8 percent by that time, Tung said Taiwan is actively bidding to join the organization.

He said the MOFA will bear in mind the dignity and best interests of the nation when applying to join the GGF, adding that the primary goal at the moment is to attend the second annual meeting of the forum, the date of which has yet to be decided.

DOC.HEADLINE: ROC ENVOY POSTPONES HIS RETURN FROM PRETORIA

TEXT.P: The Foreign Affairs Ministry on Saturday said that Republic of China Ambassador Loh I-chen, who was scheduled to leave Pretoria for home on Friday, will remain in his post for a little longer to "take care of important administrative affairs."
Foreign Affairs Ministry Spokesman Roy Y.Y. Wu denied that Loh has postponed his return because there has been some change in the framework of future relations between the ROC and South Africa.

South African President Nelson Mandela announced Nov. 27, 1996 that Pretoria will shift its diplomatic recognition from Taipei to Beijing from Jan. 1, 1998. Since then, negotiations have been held between officials of the two nations to develop a framework for future relations.

Quoting diplomatic sources in Pretoria, a CNA dispatch from Johannesburg reported on Wednesday that after several rounds of negotiations, Taipei and Pretoria have finally reached an agreement on their future ties, and that a formal accord will be signed by the foreign ministers of the two nations in the near future.

Under the new framework, the ROC embassy Pretoria and its consulates general in Johannesburg, Cape Town and Durban will continue to operate, but under different titles, while ROC personnel stationed in South Africa will continue to enjoy diplomatic immunity and other privileges.
"Since diplomatic negotiations involve many factors, a comprehensive agreement may only be reached at the last moment," Wu said.

As to whether Taipei will take the initiative and cut official ties with Pretoria before South Africa and mainland China sign the communique establishing diplomatic links on Dec. 28, Wu said he doesn't have any information about this, adding that the matter has to be decided by the "highest government authorities."

DOC.HEADLINE: SHARE PRICES DECLINE ON TAIEX

TEXT.P: Taiwan share prices finished 0.6 percent lower on Saturday despite the market opening in a positive atmosphere with expected profits in plastic and chemical stocks, according to local dealers.

The dealers pointed out that the decline resulted mainly from a downward adjustment of electrical engineering and banking issues, which contributed to a 54.39-point fall, with the Taiwan Stock Exchange (TAIEX) weighted price index dropping to 8,343.88.
The bourse started at 8,430.45 points, and experienced a high of 8,521.07 and a low of 8,338.16. Gainers outnumbered losers 226 to 189, with 57 listed stocks remaining unchanged.
A total of 3.38 billion shares changed hands on a market turnover of NT$154.95 billion (US$4.84 billion).

Among the eight stock categories, textiles, along with plastic and chemical shares jointly enjoyed the largest gains at 2.2 percent, while cement stocks increased 0.2 percent and cement issues soared 0.5 percent.
Electrical engineering shares registered a 1.7 percent fall, while financial stocks dropped by 1.3 percent, paper and pulp dropped by 1.2 percent, and construction issues fell 0.7 percent.

DOC.HEADLINE: MAINLAND CHINA'S CURRENCY EXPECTED TO DEPRECIATE
DOC.DATELINE: Hong Kong, Dec. 13, (CNA) (By Stanley Cheung & Eva Chen)

TEXT.P: The value of the renminbi, the currency of mainland China, will remain stable for the next couple of months, but is expected to depreciate by 5 percent in the latter half of 1998, according to the latest economic report published by the Solomon Brothers Securities Corp. of the United States.
A decrease in mainland China's exports, an increase in imports and reduced foreign investments are all listed as factors which will affect the depreciation, the report said.
The economic report also forecast that mainland China's GDP in 1998 will be 8 percent.

DOC.HEADLINE: MOEA TO MONITOR CLOSELY MAINLAND CHINA'S ECONOMIC DEVELOPMENT TREND

TEXT.P: Economic Affairs Minister Wang Chih-kang is calling for a meeting with economists and entrepreneurs next week for discussions on possible repercussions from South Korea's currency turmoil and a latent financial crisis in mainland China.
Foreign wire service reports have said that some 26 security firms in mainland China may be closed in the face of new financial instability.

With nearly 20,000 local companies maintaining operations on the mainland worth over US$20 billion, Taiwan should watch out for any possible change on the mainland to avoid being affected by any crisis which might arise there, Wang noted, pointing out, however, that should the mainland become embroiled in an economic upheaval, Taiwan will find it difficult to remain unscathed.
Wang said that the financial crisis in Northeast Asia is now being seen as the key "uncertainty" factor in deciding Taiwan's domestic economic development for next year.
He stressed that it is critically important for Taiwan to fully understand the situation and work out contingency plans to counter any possible spread of the financial crisis affecting most of Asia.

The regional turmoil which began in Thailand in July, as a result of the Thai government's de facto devaluation of the Thai baht, has forced Thailand's economic growth estimates down to 1.5 percent in 1997 from 1996's 6.4 percent. The economies of Malaysia, Indonesia and the Philippines have also taken a battering.

In South Korea, the Korean won has continued to dive in the wake of a loss of confidence which has snowballed. The amount of bad debts has skyrocketed to 2.6 trillion won and stock markets have plummeted, while many of the 26 leading enterprises in the country have closed down or announced widespread layoffs.

Taiwan has fared well over the last several months by comparison, despite the fact that the Taiwan currency has depreciated by 15 percent. Taiwan's economy posted an enviable growth of 6.93 percent in the third quarter of this year, marking a single-quarter high since the fourth quarter of 1994. It is estimated that the annual growth for 1997 will top at least 6.72 percent.

For 1998, however, the Ministry of Economic Affairs is not so optimistic, on the grounds that many Southeast Asian countries will sink further into the economic morass, while the fate of the Korean and mainland Chinese economies will also remain uncertain, Wang noted.

DOC.HEADLINE: SINGAPORE PIPS HONG KONG AT TOP BUSINESS LOCATION IN ASIA

TEXT.P: Singapore has toppled Hong Kong as the best place in Asia to do business over the next five years, according to the London-based Economic Intelligence Unit (EIU).
In a new 16-country study measuring business operating costs, both Singapore and New Zealand climbed a rung higher to overhaul Hong Kong and clinch the top two spots.
Taiwan, ranked sixth in the previous 1992-96 study, dropped one notch to seventh position in the EIU's new 1997-2001 ranking.

EIU spokesman and Business Asia editor Adam Aston was quoted as saying: "Hong Kong's fall in rank is not the result of any dramatic change in 1997. Strong growth, low taxes, property rights and free trade will remain in place."
He said the risk was that mainland China might not honor its promise to maintain Hong Kong's freedoms and government intervention was likely to become more widespread.
"In contrast, Singapore is predicted to retain its standing for the next five years with further improvements pushing up its absolute score on the index," he was quoted as saying.
The EIU study predicts that mainland China's business environment will improve slightly over the next five years.
The mainland remained on the 14th place in the new ranking.
Beijing will continue to encourage foreign investment while trying to protect domestic industries from competition, the EIU said.

It added that political risks would mar the outlook for businesses in the Chinese mainland despite continuing efforts to reform and liberalize the system gradually. This was also the case for countries such as Indonesia, Thailand and Vietnam.
Australia was ranked fourth, followed by Malaysia, Japan, Taiwan, South Korea, Thailand, the Philippines, Indonesia, India, Sri Lanka, mainland China, Vietnam and Pakistan.

The ranking is based on a comprehensive set of variables including political, macroeconomic, and foreign investment environments, market opportunities, government policies towards private enterprise and competition, trade and foreign exchange regimes, taxes, financing, labor markets and infrastructure.

DOC.HEADLINE: BANK OF CANADA MOVES UP INTEREST RATES TO 4.5 PERCENT

TEXT.P: The Bank of Canada raised its trend-setting rate to 4.5 percent from 4.0 percent as the Canadian dollar came under pressure on international markets Friday.
"Volatility in international financial markets, tied to events in Asia, has continued to affect Canadian markets," the central bank said in a statement.

"This action by the bank is designed to contribute to more settled domestic markets in which investors can focus more confidently on the strong fundamentals favoring noninflationary growth in the Canadian economy," it added.

All major banks announced that their prime lending rate would move to 6.0 percent from 5.5 percent effective Monday. Prime rate is the rate the banks use when dealing with their best corporate customers.

Two major commercial banks, the Canadian Imperial Bank of Commerce and the Royal Bank of Canada, did not wait for the central bank to move up its rate. The two hiked their mortgage rates by 20 to 35 basis points Thursday for one- to seven-year loans. A basis point is 1/100th of a percentage point.
The Canadian dollar has been under pressure on world markets for several weeks. It opened at 70.18 US cents Friday, up 0.10 US cents from Thursday's close.

DOC.HEADLINE: ECONOMIC TURMOIL SET TO DOMINATE ASEAN SUMMIT

TEXT.P: Asia's economic turmoil will dominate the talks at the informal ASEAN summit in Kuala Lumpur on Monday, when ASEAN leaders will also meet their counterparts from mainland China, Japan and South Korea in a historic conference of Asian leaders.
This was to have been a celebratory summit to commemorate ASEAN's 30th anniversary and its expansion to include Laos and Myanmar in the grouping last July.

But the financial crunch precipitated by falling currencies and stocks in the Asian tiger economies has taken the fizz out of the event, Singapore-based newspaper The Straits Times reported Friday in a dispatch from Kuala Lumpur.

Thailand, Indonesia and South Korea -- all recipients of huge bailout packages sanctioned by the International Monetary Fund (IMF) -- and Malaysia have just begun implementing austerity measures that will slow down Asia's economic growth in the next few years.
This summit of ASEAN and East Asian leaders will instead be an occasion for them to rethink their economic strategies and seek new ways to overcome their difficulties.
Mainland Chinese President Jiang Zemin is expected to restate Beijing's willingness to foster closer economic and political ties with ASEAN, the report said.
For strategic and political reasons, Chinese leaders are keen to deepen the relationship and this will be explored in the ASEAN-Chinese mainland talks on Tuesday, it added.
Singapore Prime Minister Goh Chok Tong has said that ASEAN's greatest challenge is how to meet the growing economic competition posed by a rising mainland China, it said.
Tuesday's meeting could give shape to what Chinese officials have called a "partnership of good neighborliness and mutual trust" for the new century, it noted.
Japan's Prime Minister Ryutaro Hashimoto had earlier this year called for an annual summit between Japan and ASEAN, as well as bilateral security talks with Southeast Asian countries.
Dubbed in some quarters as the Hashimoto doctrine, it envisages a leading role for Japan in Asian affairs. This concept has yet to be explored in detail, said the report.
Indonesia's President Suharto yesterday canceled plans to join the summit on doctors' advice. Foreign Minister Ali Alatas will represent him at the meeting.

Outgoing South Korean President Kim Young-sam will also not attend the meeting, as South Koreans are going to the polls on Dec. 18 to elect a new leader. He will be represented by Prime Minister Koh Kun.
The ASEAN-East Asia summit will be watched closely by Western countries, notably the United States.
Washington opposes the formation of an East Asian Economic Caucus, an idea conceived by Malaysian Prime Minister Mahathir, who is chairing the conference, the report noted.
But Japan and South Korea also demur at the thought of a pan-Asian grouping opposed by the United States, their staunch ally.
This is why the gathering is called the ASEAN-9 Plus Three summit. In any case, it is not certain whether this will become an annual event, the newspaper said.
On regional security, the main issues are likely to be Cambodia and the competing claims in the Spratly Islands.
The latter is an issue which could cause armed conflict between claimant ASEAN countries and mainland China.

ASEAN members, notably Vietnam and the Philippines, want Beijing to freeze its activities in the South China Sea and reaffirm the non-use of force to settle the rival territorial claims in the potentially mineral-rich Spratly atolls.
On Cambodia, ASEAN's primary consideration is that there should be free and fair elections next year before it can become an ASEAN member, the report said.
Cambodia's membership, which has been postponed indefinitely, will realize ASEAN founding fathers' vision of uniting all 10 Southeast Asian countries in a single entity.
ASEAN leaders will also endorse the Vision 2020 statement to chart the grouping's future direction, the report said.
On the summit sidelines, Prime Minister Goh will have bilateral meetings with Vietnam's Pham Van Khai, Myanmar's Gen. Than Shwe and mainland China's Jiang, it said.
He will also meet United Nations Secretary-General Kofi Annan, who will be in Kuala Lumpur as Malaysia's guest, it added.

DOC.HEADLINE: GARUDA SETS UP COOPERATION AGREEMENT WITH CAL

TEXT.P: Indonesia's national carrier Garuda has set up a cargo cooperation agreement with four foreign airlines, including Taiwan's China Airlines (CAL).
A Garuda spokesman said that the agreement's objective is to accommodate the high market demand, since the Indonesian flag carrier does not operate its own cargo aircraft.

"Under the terms of the cargo transportation cooperation agreement, Garuda gets a cargo capacity allocation of 35 tons using MD-11 and A-300 freighters owned by Korean Air every Monday and Thursday serving the Batam-Jakarta-Seoul route," the spokesman was quoted by the Indonesia Times as saying, while the agreement with China Airlines allows Garuda an allocation of 20 tons in CAL's A-300 freighters every Monday on the Jakarta-Taipei-Los Angeles route.
Similar deals have also been set up with a French and a Dutch carrier, the spokesman added. (Wu Pin-chiang)

DOC.HEADLINE: FAMILY DOCTOR ATTRIBUTES LIEN CHAN'S GOOD HEALTH TO GOOD HABITS

TEXT.P: A wine connoisseur, he doesn't drink during daytime and knows when to stop. He doesn't smoke, works out a lot, and follows healthy dietary rules.
That, says Lien Chan's family doctor Wang Cheng-yi, is how the vice president has retained his energy levels over the past years, even during times of stress.

In a new book by Dr. Wang, he attributes Lien's good health to his "moral culture." A considerate person with a mild disposition, Lien plays by the rules and is never slow to show his appreciation for others.

Dr. Wang, concurrently vice president of the National Taiwan University Hospital, who himself had long wondered why Lien is so energetic and high-spirited, got his answer while serving as Lien's personal physician and accompanying him on several overseas trips over the last few years.

Wang said that Lien loves fish and believes that eating fish does not lead to weight-gain. Possessed of a good appetite at all times, Lien always empties his dishes and hates to waste food. He's also a balanced eater -- consuming a larger amount of vegetables and fruit than meat, the doctor noted.

A wine connoisseur, Lien has a keen appreciation for the grape. However, he doesn't drink much, and never during the day, Wang said. Citing Lien's drinking philosophy -- "to be a good drinker, but never to get drunk" -- Wang said Lien knows when to stop with regard to alcohol.
People may not know that besides golfing, Lien maintains the habit of walking 10,000 steps each day, which is another possible source of his energy, Wang pointed out.
He swims too -- about 30 minutes at a time during weeknights -- and that allows him to enjoy good-quality sleep, Wang said.

The doctor also lauded Lien's respect for "the men who know." Particularly with regard to the health and medical fields, Lien respects the experts, listens to their opinions and follows their instructions, and that's another reason for his success in maintaining good health, Wang said.

DOC.HEADLINE: KEEPING STATUS QUO REMAINS MAINSTREAM OPINION: MAC POLL

TEXT.P: More than 80 percent of the people on Taiwan favor keeping the status quo for the time being, prior to either eventual unification with the Chinese mainland or a declaration of independence, according to a poll conducted by the Mainland Affairs Council (MAC).

Results of the poll were published on Friday by the MAC, a formal administrative agency under supervision of the Republic of China premier. It was revealed that, with regard to the situation across the Taiwan Strait, maintaining the current state of relations between the two sides is still the mainstream opinion among local people.

The poll indicates that those who advocate either quick unification with or separation from the mainland account for no more than 20 percent of the population. Hence the landslide victory of the main opposition Democratic Progressive Party in the recent local elections is by no means an indication that the strength of the independence faction is gaining ground, the MAC stressed.

Changing attitudes about the national identification of people in Taiwan are also noteworthy. Those who consider themselves as "Taiwanese" account for 36.9 percent, which is the highest level ever indicated in such polls. It is the first time that number surpassed the percentage of those who identify themselves as "Taiwanese and Chinese at the same time," which stood at 34.8 percent. It is also far more than the number of island residents who identify themselves as "Chinese," which accounted for 23.1 percent of those surveyed, the MAC officials said.

DOC.HEADLINE: TAIWAN TO STEP UP RECRUITMENT OF SCI-TECH TALENT

TEXT.P: Taiwan will attempt to recruit more professional talent in the science and technology fields from both at home and abroad, hoping to establish and staff world-class research institutes within five years, Premier Vincent Siew said on Saturday.

Speaking to a ceremony marking the conclusion of the 18th annual meeting of the Cabinet's science and technology advisory group, Siew said one of the top concerns in Taiwan's sci-tech development is how to maintain a steady input of sci-tech resources.

Another key concern is how to integrate existing resources from the academic, industrial and governmental sectors so as to acquire top-notch sci-tech manpower and key technologies -- the two necessary factors for raising Taiwan's international competitiveness, Siew pointed out.

Meanwhile, Siew noted that all the suggestions and proposals presented by the 14 overseas advisors during the six-day meeting will be adopted as important points for revising the ROC government's sci-tech white paper compiled last year, the first of its kind.
Newly appointed Vice Premier Liu Chao-shian, who himself is a technocrat, will be responsible for integrating those suggestions and proposals into a concrete implementation plan, Siew noted.

DOC.HEADLINE: MAC ADVISED TO REGULATE MAINLAND CHINESE ADS

TEXT.P: Mainland Chinese advertising in Taiwan should be regulated by law, counselors to the Mainland Affairs Council (MAC) said unanimously at a meeting Saturday.
They said that mainland Chinese advertisements have often appeared in Taiwan's news media, and that most of them contain Communist political propaganda.
Liu Teh-hsiun, director of the Legal Affairs Department of the MAC, said after the meeting that the counselors have found many of the mainland Chinese advertisements illegal.

He pointed out a recent advertisement in a Taiwan evening newspaper as an example. The headline of the ad reads, "Tong Yang City that Vigorously March Towards the 21st Century." There are two pictures of Communist officials in the ad. In addition to messages of investment opportunities in the city, the copy of the ad highlighted the "political achievements" made by Communist China in modernizing the city.
He said the counselors worried that mainland Chinese authorities are using commercial advertising to spread Communist propaganda in Taiwan. (by Ed Hsieh)

DOC.HEADLINE: ROC TO SEEK COOPERATION WITH FRANCE IN BUILDING AIRCRAFT

TEXT.P: A high-ranking Republic of China economics official on Saturday departed for France to promote a joint project involving the manufacture of parts and components for Mirage jetfighters, one of the world's most advanced combat aircraft.

Vice Economics Minister Yiin Chii-ming, who is leading a delegation to make inquiries regarding the project, revealed that his group will also seek opportunities to join France in a highly sought-after deal to develop jumbo passenger aircraft.

According to the Ministry of Economics Affairs (MOEA), in the wake of the ROC's purchase of 60 French-built Mirage 2000 jetfighters, the government hopes to forge broader cooperative relations with France in producing parts and components as well as engines for the aircraft.

In addition, the MOEA said, after South Korea's withdrawal from an international project guided by Airbus Industrie to produce A3XX jumbo jets in the wake of its recent economic woes, the ROC will seek to fill the vacancy by teaming up with France's Latecoere, the world's third largest fuselage maker, to produce fuselages for the A3XX airplanes.
The 600-seat ASXX, which enjoys the largest passenger capacity in the world, is expected to be flying by the year 2003.

Yin told the CNA that his France trip is also aimed at finding out the reasons behind South Korea's withdrawal from the A3XX project, studying whether Taiwan's aerospace industry is capable of taking charge of the contract, and determining whether participation in the project will be profitable.

DOC.HEADLINE: FLEEING TAIPEI?

TEXT.P: Nearly 200,000 Taipei residents moved out of the metropolis during the past year, with about 60,000 of them emigrating abroad, indicating a new outbound trend in Taiwan, said a Taipei city councilor.

Quoting Taipei City Population Administration Office tallies, City Councilor Teng Chia-chi said a total of 197,478 people moved out of Taipei City last year, with one-third of the total, or 61,191 people, having emigrated to foreign lands, marking record highs for both areas in recent decades.
The population of Taipei City, totaling 2.597 million at the end of last year, also hit a 10-year low as a result of the exodus, Teng noted.

Teng attributed the outflow primarily to Beijing's missile firings in waters near Taiwan in March last year. Other considerations, including uncertainty in the political environment, deteriorating social order and declining quality of living, however, were also cited as important factors pushing Taipei residents out of the city, he added.

DOC.HEADLINE: DIRECTOR PAI CHING-JUI DIES

TEXT.P: Film director Pai Ching-jui, famous for his productions in the 1970s and '80s, died of heart failure Friday night. He was 66.

Pai was meeting friends in a hotel when he suddenly collapsed. He was rushed to the Cathay General Hospital in a comatose state and showed no vital signs despite emergency treatment. He was pronounced dead at 11:23 p.m.
Pai had worked as a reporter, and studied painting and stage design in Rome. After learning to make films in Italy, he returned to Taiwan to join the Central Motion Picture Corp.

Veteran film critic Huang Jen noted that Pai was the first director from Chinese cinematic circles, in either Taiwan, Hong Kong or mainland China, to study filmmaking in Italy, the mecca of the new wave realism genre. He is credited with introducing the realistic and wholesome style that had swept the whole world to the Taiwan movie scene.
He also brought with him modern editing equipment from overseas, which contributed significantly to upgrading the technical quality of Taiwan-produced pictures.
Pai helped elevate numerous actors and actresses who worked with him to stardom, including Ke Chun-hsiung, Kuei Ya-lei, Tang Pao-yun, and Josephine Siao.
In 1968 and 1969, he won consecutive honors for best director at the Golden Horse Awards, the Taiwan equivalent of the Oscars, for his work in "Lonely Seventeen," and "The Bride and I."
Some of Pai's other most famous films include "Coldest Winter in Peking," "Home Sweet Home," "Girlfriend."
He also collaborated with directors Lee Han-hsiang, Hu King-chuan, and Lee Hsing to produce "Happiness, Anger, Sorrow and Joy," a film composed of four separate segments.

Pai became the third member of that group to depart the Taiwan movie scene within the past year, with all three succumbing to heart problems. Lee Han-hsiang was in Beijing filming the epic story of the razing of Ahfang Palace when he suffered a heart attack last Dec. 17. Hu died while undergoing coronary bypass surgery on Jan. 14.

The Golden Horse Awards ceremony is scheduled to be held at Sun Yat-sen Memorial Hall Saturday night during which a lifetime achievement award will be conferred on Lee and Hu. After learning of the unexpected passing of Pai, the Actors Guild said it will solicit the same honor for Pai.
A retrospective of Pai's films has been planned for January, film industry officials said.

The short and stocky Pai has been known for his romantic affairs. His present wife Chang Hwa, a mainland actress 38 years his junior, received approval to live in Taiwan only two years ago. The pair met when Pai was filming in the mainland.

DOC.HEADLINE: NANKING HOLOCAUST OBSERVED

TEXT.P: Sixty years ago on Dec. 13, invading Japanese troops poured into Nanking, then the capital of China, unleashing a bloodbath unprecedented in the contemporary history of mankind.
In the ensuing six weeks, more than 300,000 Chinese, mostly unarmed civilians, were slaughtered en mass after being tortured and mutilated.

The New Tungmenghui, a pro-unification political organization headed by Hsu Li-lung, former chief of the Cabinet-level Vocational Assistance Commission for Retired Servicemen, held a photo exhibition on the "Rape of Nanking" to remind people of the atrocities committed by the Japanese Imperial Army 60 years ago.

On display at the exhibition, held at the Dr. Sun Yat-sen Memorial Hall in downtown Taipei, were 80 photos showing Chinese civilians being buried alive, or being used for bayonet practice by Japanese soldiers.
Others showed naked Chinese women photographed with their Japanese rapists or, even worse, old women being sexually abused after they were raped.
Several photos depicted corpses lining the meandering banks of the Yangtze River and filling ponds and trenches.

Others bore witness to the horrific human experiments conducted by the Japanese "731 biological warfare unit," the so-called "comfort women" -- Chinese women forced to become sex slaves for Japanese soldiers, and the killing of Taiwanese by their conquerors.
Hsu said more than 30 million Chinese were killed during Japanese invasion. "We cannot forget the history although we can afford to not seek revenge," Hsu added.
"We could again fall victim to Japanese invaders simply by forgetting the lessons of history," he noted.

Meanwhile, hundreds of local residents gathered in the morning in front of the Taipei office of the Japan Interchange Association -- Tokyo's de facto embassy here, to protest against the crimes committed 60 years ago. They pelted the office building with eggs to vent their anger.

Also in Nanking (Nanjing), air raid siren was sounded and three minutes of silence were observed by the five million citizens of the city, 300 kilometers west of Shanghai, to remember the holocaust, according to foreign wire service reports.
Similar activities were also held in United States, Canada, Singapore, Australia and Japan.

DOC.HEADLINE: TAIWAN TO DISPOSE OF NUCLEAR WASTE BY ITSELF

TEXT.P: Vice Premier Liu Chao-hsiuan said Saturday that Taiwan shall find out how to dispose of low-radioactive nuclear waste by itself.

Tien Chang-ling, technological adviser to the Executive Yuan, said in a study report issued Saturday that it is not feasible to ship Taiwan's nuclear waste overseas for disposal under the current situation.
The Taiwan Power Company signed a contract with North Korea last year for disposal of its nuclear waste from nuclear power plants. South Korea has strongly protested against the arrangement.
Tien, who is former chancellor of the University of California at Berkeley, recommended to store the low-radioactive nuclear waste in Taiwan.
In response to Tien's recommendation, Liu said the Atomic Energy Council of the Executive Yuan and some other relevant government agencies shall work together to find out how to solve the problem.
"The problem shall be solved by ourselves," he said. (by Ed Hsieh)

DOC.HEADLINE: LABOR PROBLEMS INCREASING IN FUJIAN PROVINCE

TEXT.P: Conflicts between employers and employees in Fujian Province in southeast China mainland are increasing, the "Chinese Youth" newspaper reported Saturday.

The central organ publication of the Communist Youth League also reported that the conflicts have resulted in two cases of arson, killing more than 30 people in Jinjiang City in the last three months.

The report quoted local officials as saying that employers' failure to pay wages on time have caused many conflicts, and that workers may resort to arson and other violent actions to vent their anger.

Workers at a sports goods factory owned by a Taiwan investor in Fuzhou City went on strike recently because the employer announced to lower their wages in November and some of the female workers who joined in the strike have been fired, the report said.

Workers in the city have said that if employers ignore the newly enacted "Labor Law," arson attacks will be unavoidable. The report also said that in the first 11 months of this year 18 employers in Quanzhou City have escaped without paying the wages they owed. They included six Taiwan investors, 7 foreign companies, and 4 mainland Chinese private enterprises.

The report quoted local officials as saying that local authorities hesitate to enforce the labor law for fear of scaring away foreign investors, and that under such circumstances, arson attacks, such as those happened recently in Mawei and Jinjing, will occur in other places. (by Wang Hsin-chung/Ed Shay)

DOC.HEADLINE: 8 KILLED, 14 INJURED IN TWO ACCIDENTS

TEXT.P: Two separate accidents killed at least eight persons and injured 14 others in the southern Taiwan county of Kaohsiung on Saturday, police said.
Seven workers died and 12 suffered injuries at a construction site of the Taiwan Water Co. in Kanshan Township when its scaffolding collapsed abruptly.
Meanwhile, a gas explosion at the Talin Refinery Plant of the Chinese Petroleum Corp. (CPC), killed one and injured two others.

This was third major accidents for the refinery in five years. A similar explosion in 1993 prompted a large-scale protest by residents around the plant. A leakage of crude oil at Kaohsiung port in 1996 triggered another waves of protest by residents. As a result, the accidents-stricken CPC has to pay over NT$600 million (US$19 million) in compensations to residents.

The injured from the two accidents were rushed to nearby hospitals for treatment. (by Bear Lee) ENDITEM
ZCZC CEP026 12-13-97 MAGGIE CHEUNG BEST ACTRESS IN GOLDEN HORSE AWARDS
Taipei, Dec. 13 (CNA) Hong Kong actress Maggie Cheung's dream came true Saturday as she won the title of the best leading actress of this year's Golden Horse Awards.

Hong Kong Director Kuo Chan, emerged as the biggest winner at the award presentation ceremony held in Taipei Saturday night as he personally grabbed two titles -- the best director and the best original screenplay -- for his work "Made in Hong Kong".
The 34-year old Golden Horse Awards, the Taiwan version of the Oscars, honors Chinese films from Taiwan and Hong Kong.

The following is the list of the winners: Best Picture-- Comrades-Almost a Love Story Best Short Film -- Wild Sparrows Best Documentary -- Homesick Eyes Best Animation -- A Chinese Ghost Story-the Animated Film Best Director -- Kuo Chan (Made in Hong Kong) Best Original Screenplay -Kuo Chan (Made in Hong Kong) Bast Adapted Screenplay -- Raymond to (the Mad Phoenix) Best Leading Actor -- Kwan-Ho Tse (The Mad Phoenix) Best Leading Actress -- Maggie Cheung (Comrades-Almost A Love Story) Best Supporting Actor -- Jin-Hsing Chen (Love Go Go) Best Supporting Actress -- Hui-Zhen Liao (Love Go Go) Best Cinematography -- Christopher Doyle (Happy Together) Best Music Original Score -- Kitaro (The Soong Sisters) Best Music Original Song -- Chik Lam and Kuo-Lun Huang (Eighteen

DOC.HEADLINE: MAGGIE CHEUNG BEST ACTRESS IN GOLDEN HORSE AWARDS

TEXT.P: Hong Kong actress Maggie Cheung's dream came true Saturday as she won the title of the best leading actress of this year's Golden Horse Awards.

Hong Kong Director Kuo Chan, emerged as the biggest winner at the award presentation ceremony held in Taipei Saturday night as he personally grabbed two titles -- the best director and the best original screenplay -- for his work "Made in Hong Kong".

DOC.HEADLINE: CHEN DENIES VYING FOR DPP CHAIRMANSHIP

TEXT.P: Taipei City Mayor Chen Shui-bian said on Sunday that he is not considering to run for the chairmanship of the Democratic Progressive Party (DPP) and that the top priority for him now is to administrate the city well.
Chen made the remarks after attending the opening ceremony of an athletic competition of mentally retarded children held at the Chieshou Junior High School.

As to the disputes sparked within the DPP over the remarks made recently in the United States by DPP Chairman Hsu Shin-liang and Sisy Chen, director of the DPP's Propaganda Department, related to the issues of Taiwan independence and an investment plan by the German Bayer Group in central Taiwan, Chen said it is very normal that there are different opinions within a democratic political party and that there is no need for outsiders to make a tempest in a teapot.

Chen said that the most important thing for him at present is to run Taipei City and that he has no time for "daydreaming" about the DPP chairmanship, adding that the idea to run for the post "has never come to mind."
He stressed the DPP is as unified as ever and he is confident it will become Taiwan's ruling party early in the next century.

Chen revealed that he will call a meeting on Monday to report his "Taipei experience" to other DPP-affiliated city mayors and county chiefs and exchange opinions with them on issues to help upgrade administrative efficiency and the living quality of the people.

DOC.HEADLINE: FIRST WOMAN RECEIVES HONORARY DEGREE FROM INDONESIAN UNIVERSITY

TEXT.P: Political scientist Prof. Miriam Budiardjo became the first woman to receive an honorary doctorate in political science from Universitas Indonesia (UI).
In 1956, the state university for the first time conferred an honorary doctor's degree on Raden Kodyat in the field of medical science.
Miriam, 74, read out her speech titled "Accountability in Political Science" at the university's campus in Depok on Saturday in the presence of Universitas Indonesia Rector Prof. M.K. Tadjudin.
In her address, she roundly criticized a number of political institutions in Indonesia, Antara news agency reported.

DOC.HEADLINE: ISLAMIC DEVELOPMENT BANK TO FLOAT US$1.5 BILLION FUND

TEXT.P: In an effort to promote development projects in the Muslim world, the Islamic Development Bank has decided to float a US$1.5 billion Infrastructure Fund, according to a senior bank executive.

The bank will provide finances from the fund only to the private sectors of member countries for the construction of roads, buildings, telecommunication projects, electricity distribution schemes, oil and gas distribution networks as well as the development of sea ports.
The decision was made at the annual meeting of the IDB, which was held in Damascus in the last week of November, according to Enam Ahmed Chaudhury, adviser to the bank.
He said the formalities for the Infrastructure Fund will be completed soon and it should be launched early next year.

DOC.HEADLINE: ICDF-TAIWAN ALUMNI ASSOCIATION SET UP

TEXT.P: Indonesia is noted for its rich natural and human resources, while the Republic of China is strong in medium- and small-sized enterprises, according to Dr. Lu Pao-sun, representative of Taipei Economic and Trade Office.

Speaking at the inauguration ceremony of the ICDF-Taiwan Alumni Association in Indonesia on Saturday, Lu pointed out that over the years, the close cooperation between the two countries has proved to be very fruitful, and has contributed much to improving people's quality of life.
The ceremony was presided over by Utama Kajo, chairman of the association.
Lu noted that the International Cooperation Development Fund (ICDF) in Taipei has hoped to establish the association for several years.
"Alumni who have completed their short term of study in Taiwan under ICDF's arrangement are united and will be able to share experiences under this creative scheme," he said.

DOC.HEADLINE: ROC PARLIAMENTARY GROUP ENDS VISITS TO TWO AFRICAN ALLIES
DOC.DATELINE: Paris, Dec. 13 (CNA) (By M.C. Chou and Flor Wang)

TEXT.P: An 18-member group composed of Republic of China National Assembly (NA) deputies arrived here Saturday on a transit stop en route to Taipei after concluding a two-week visit to Burkina Faso and Senegal.

The nonpartisan group, led by National Assembly Speaker Fredrick Chien of the ruling Kuomintang, was the first mission of its kind ever to visit African countries as a means of paving the way for a planned visit by President Lee Teng-hui to the region next year.

NA Deputy Huang Yeng-huang of the major opposition Democratic Progressive Party and Wang Chih of the New Party said that the two African diplomatic allies attach great importance to their relations with the ROC and that they were very touched by the warm welcome extended by the peoples of the two countries.

Huang and Wang attributed the deep friendship of the peoples of Burkina Faso and Senegal with the ROC to the outstanding performance of ROC diplomatic and technical missions stationed there, saying their hard work has paid off and played a significant role in strengthening bilateral relations with the two countries.
The ROC NA deputies first paid a week-long visit to Burkina Faso, where they were received by President Blaise Comparore and met with other ranking officials.

In addition to exchanging opinions and holding seminars on issues of mutual concern with their Burkina Faso counterparts, the delegation, accompanied by ROC Ambassador Sainting Kung, also visited local farms developed with the assistance of ROC agricultural missions. More than 2,000 local farmers, waving the national flags of the two countries, lined the road and performed folk dances to welcome them.

During a six-day visit to Senegal, the delegation was received by President Abdou Diouf and signed with the Senegal parliament an amity accord, under which Senegal stated its support for the ROC's bid to join the United Nations and agreed to expand two-way exchanges and cooperation with the ROC.
Accompanied by ROC Ambassador Tou Chou-seng and Senegal parliamentary leaders, the ROC parliamentary mission also inspected the construction of a highway, which was financed by the ROC government.

DOC.HEADLINE: DPP CHAIRMAN HSU HSIN-LIANG REVEALS INTENTION TO RETIRE

TEXT.P: Hsu Hsin-liang, chairman of the major opposition Democratic Progressive Party (DPP), said Sunday that it would be all right to him if Taipei Mayor Chen Shui-bian is elected new chairman of the party.

Hsu, who is one of the leaders of the DPP's Formosa Faction, has been verbally attacked by legislators of other three factions since the DPP won a landslide victory in local elections last month. They vowed to support Chen's bid to run for the chairmanship.

Hsu, who has just come back from a week-long visit to the United States, said at a press conference that he has done his best for the party, and that he would welcome Chen or any other party leader to succeed him as chairman.
However, he said that the job of DPP chairman and that of Taipei mayor are quite different.

Meanwhile, scores of pro-Hsu activists shouted "Come on Chairman Hsu" at the site of the press conference to show their support for him. They also condemned Hsu's rivals and critics for waging "political struggle" within the party. (by Ed Hsieh)

DOC.HEADLINE: UNEMPLOYED WORKERS BEING PREVENTED FROM GOING TO BEIJING
DOC.DATELINE: Hong Kong, Dec. 14 (CNA) (By H. S. Wu)

TEXT.P: Mainland Chinese authorities have deployed more paramilitary forces to ensure that labor unrest in various parts of mainland China will not affect the capital, the South China Morning Post reported Sunday.

The report quoted mainland Chinese sources as saying Saturday that the party leadership had instructed railway offices in areas with high jobless rates to prevent large groups of workers from boarding Beijing-bound trains.

The leadership was afraid political stability would be jeopardized if large-scale demonstrations were held in the capital, they said. Areas badly hit by unemployment include the three northeastern provinces, in addition to the inland provinces of Sichuan and Henan.
Laid-off workers there have staged frequent rallies and other protest actions to demand better unemployment benefits and new jobs, according to the report.

A labor source was quoted as saying that "local railroad officials have been told that they can, if necessary, call in soldiers and paramilitary police to stop laborers from boarding trains to Beijing."
"Such actions have, on many occasions, resulted in long delays of trains bound for the capital."
The source said provincial and municipal administrations had been instructed to prevent jobless workers and their relatives from making trips to Beijing to hand in petitions to the authorities.
It is understood that heads of localities who fail to stop labor unrest from spilling out of their areas will be penalized by central authorities, the report added.

DOC.HEADLINE: BAYER PROJECT IMPORTANT TO TAIWAN'S ECONOMY: DPP CHAIRMAN

TEXT.P: Hsu Hsin-liang, chairman of Democratic Progressive Party (DPP), stressed on Sunday that while the fate of German-based Bayer Group's proposed investment project in Taichung County is important to Taiwan's continued economic development, it should not be decided solely by the local government.

At a press conference following his return from a week-long US visit late last night, Hsu said that even if Bayer's first investment project in Taiwan is put to a public vote among county residents, the DPP headquarters cannot avoid its responsibility to conduct discussions on the referendum issue.

Hsu noted that the proposed referendum on Bayer's project has aroused concern and anxiety among foreign investors, evidenced by statements issued by the European Council of Commerce and Trade (ECCT) and American Chamber of Commerce (AmCham). The DPP must also work out a comprehensive party policy toward major investment projects, he added.
Soon after its overwhelming victory in the Nov. 29 local elections, Taiwan's largest opposition party was thrown into crisis when infighting broke out over the Bayer investment project.

Attacks on Hsu and his leadership mounted when he was leading the DPP delegation on the US visit. Several DPP heavyweights made remarks critical of what they called intervention by party headquarters in local affairs, with some even declaring they will not support Hsu's re-election as the DPP chairman.

Hsu, however, said that he doesn't think the intraparty conflict over the Bayer issue is serious, adding that he is not concerned over his personal political future. It is more important to successfully transform the DPP during the remainder of his tenure, he said.

Hsu went on to say his relationship with DPP Secretary-General Chiou I-jien is quite good and he hopes it will remain so until the end of his term in the mid-1998. Chiou was reportedly ready to resign as he insisted that the DPP magistrate-elect in Taichung County should be left alone to decide whether a referendum on the Bayer project should be held.

Hsu said that if the DPP wants to replace the Kuomintang (KMT) as the nation's ruling party, it should assure the people that it has the ability to maintain economic prosperity and safeguard national security.

Asked for his comments on the possibility that Taipei Mayor Chen Shui-bian might seek to become the next DPP chairman, Hsu said he would welcome such a development. He added that Chen's leadership would be advantageous for the popular Taipei mayor personally as well as for the party.

Sisy Chen, director of the party's Publicity Department who accompanied Hsu on the US visit, said that not much time had been spent discussing the Bayer investment before they embarked on the overseas trip. However, the time has come for DPP officials to sit down and discuss the issue practically and calmly, she asserted.

If the referendum takes place, it will inevitably affect the willingness of foreign enterprises to invest in Taiwan due to the uncertainty such a precedent would create, Chen said. She added that if every major project must be affirmed through a public vote, local governments will have difficulty in pushing through major investment projects and in initiating civic construction work.

Chen also said at the press conference that in order not to aggravate tensions within the party, she will not resign from her position for the time being. But she added that was likely to transpire at the end of the year.

DOC.HEADLINE: APPROVAL DROPS FOR TAIPEI, KAOHSIUNG MAYORS, RISES FOR TAIWAN GOVERNOR

TEXT.P: Taipei Mayor Chen Shui-bian saw a 76 percent approval rating in a recent poll conducted by the United Daily News, while Kaohsiung Mayor Wu Den-yin won 59 percent approval and Taiwan Governor James Soong's popularity peaked at 82 percent.
Despite still-high popularity, Chen's approval rating slipped 8 percent compared with the level found in a similar poll conducted one year ago. Chen's approval stood at 76 percent in 1995.

Twenty-three percent of Taipei citizens interviewed in the poll taken on the eve of Chen's third anniversary in office labeled his performance "very satisfactory" and another 53 percent rated it "satisfactory," while 20 percent expressed dissatisfaction with the Taipei mayor.

The telephone poll of 1,119 adults taken on Dec. 9-11 also found that a high approval rating does not necessarily mean a high support rating, as the percentage of those who said they would support Chen's re-election stood at only 59 percent, far below the 76 percent of respondents who approved of his performance in office. Twenty percent of the polled said they would not support Chen's re-election and 18 percent did not respond.

Kaohsiung Mayor Wu saw his approval level decline when 16 percent of Kaohsiung citizens surveyed said they are very satisfied with his performance and 43 percent said they are "satisfied." The 59 percent approval rating Wu obtained this year was lower than the 64 percent garnered last year and 77 percent received in 1995.

The telephone poll of 849 adults in Kaohsiung City conducted on Dec. 12-13 found that the percentage of respondents dissatisfied with Wu's performance rose to 33 percent, from 26 percent in 1996 and 9 percent in 1995.
Conversely, Taiwan Governor Soong's popularity rate climbed to 82 percent this year, compared with 77 percent and 78 percent in 1996 and 1995, respectively.

Thirty-nine percent of those polled described Soong's performance as quite satisfactory, while 43 percent said it is satisfactory. Only 5 percent of those interviewed said they are dissatisfied with Soong's performance, down 3 percent from the similar poll last year.
The telephone poll of 981 adults around Taiwan was conducted on Dec. 11-12.

DOC.HEADLINE: FM HU TOPS OPINION POLL

TEXT.P: Foreign Minister Jason Hu was regarded as the most popular cabinet minister by local college students, according to a recent survey. The results of the survey, made public on Sunday by the ROC Chinese Culture Association, show that Hu scored the highest approval rating of 72 percent, followed by Justice Minister Liao Cheng-hao with 65 percent, Education Minister Wu Jin with 56 percent, and Premier Vincent Siew with 55 percent.

According to the survey, Hu and the other three were far ahead of other cabinet ministers. The students were asked to judge from the officials' administrative efficiency, clean image and ability to handle emergency situations.

Kao Koong-lian, chairman of the Mongolian and Tibetan Affairs Commission and Lin Cheng-chih, chairwoman of the Council for Cultural Affairs, were the two cabinet members who scored the lowest approval rating of about 27 percent each in the poll.
The association attributed the low ranking of Kao and Lin to the lack of understanding by college students of their respective organizations.

The poll also indicates that improvement of social order was a major concern of college and university students. They are also very concerned about the problems of money politics, the improvement of education and living qualities.
The survey, which was carried out from Dec. 1 to Dec. 10, polled 1,180 students from 18 colleges and universities, with a margin of error of 2.5 percent.

DOC.HEADLINE: BEIJING TO RESHUFFLE TOP MILITARY LEADERSHIP

TEXT.P: Gen. Fu Ouanyou, chief of general staff of the People's Liberation Army of mainland China, will be appointed minister of national defense soon, according to information from Beijing.
Fu, 67, will replace Gen. Chi Haotian, who will continue to serve as vice chairman of the Chinese Communist Party (CCP) Central Military Commission.

Gen. Wang Ke, director of General Logistic Department, is likely to succeed Fu as chief of general staff. If so, Wang, 66, will be replaced by Gen. Liu Jingsong, former commander of Lanzhou Military Region.

But it is also possible that Liu, 64, will become chief of general staff. Lt. Gen. Guo Boxiung, former deputy commander of Beijing Military Region, has replaced Liu as commander of Lanzhou Military Region since late November.

The military reshuffle is seen by observers as a major move by President Jiang Zemin, who is also CCP General Secretary and chairman of the CCP Central Military Commission, to consolidate his ruling power, according to the information from Beijing. (by Ed Hsieh)

DOC.HEADLINE: KOREAN-STYLE FINANCIAL WOES UNLIKELY TO OCCUR IN TAIWAN: CHIU

TEXT.P: South Korea's financial woes are unlikely to appear in Taiwan because the two countries' economic fundamentals are completely different, Minister of Finance Paul Chiu said on Monday.

Fielding questions at a Legislative Yuan committee meeting, Chiu said economists and financial experts around the world share the view that the Republic of China and South Korea have provided illustrations of two different developmental types.
The ROC government has seldom intervened in banking operations and does not rely heavily on foreign investment for the country's economic growth, Chiu noted.

Moreover, the minister said, Taiwan has continued to enjoy steady economic growth and foreign trade surplus. "Our annual economic growth rate is comparable to our money supply growth rate. This is very important in maintaining financial stability," he claimed.
Against this background, Chiu said, Taiwan's financial situation is solid and unlikely to be affected by fallout from the South Korean debacle.

Chiu pointed out that South Korean authorities have often intervened in banking operations, which have traditionally been asked to offer huge low-interest loans to a dozen or so large South Korean conglomerates or "chaebols" to support their sometimes rash global expansion plans.

Furthermore, foreign capital accounts for 12 percent of South Korea's capital formation, while its average annual economic growth rate is only about 6.7 percent. "The phenomenon leads to an overly high growth rate in its money supply, which eventually becomes a burden on the Korean economy."

Worse yet, Chiu said, South Korea has suffered deficits in its foreign trade for many years. "South Korea should have depreciated its currency long before, and its delay in doing so has resulted in its recent financial fiasco," he noted.

Chiu said Taiwan learned a bitter lesson from the collapse of Cathay Trust Co. and the financial difficulties encountered by several other trust firms between 1983 and 1984. "We have since banned investment trust companies from investing in non-banking businesses and unlisted stocks to ward off any possible financial crises," he said.

According to a Finance Ministry-proposed package of amendments to the current bank deposit insurance regulations, Chiu said, all financial institutions will be required by law to join a government-sponsored deposit insurance program to better protect the interests and rights of individual depositors. Under the current law, joining such an insurance program is not mandatory. The revised regulations will take effect after being approved by the legislature.
Chiu went on to say that the Finance Ministry and the Central Bank of China will cooperate closely in supervising bank operations in order to avoid any financial fiascoes.
