DOC.HEADLINE: MORE THAN 150 ARRESTED IN SECOND VICE CRACKDOWN

TEXT.P: More than 150 prostitutes, brothel operators and drivers were arrested by police early Monday morning, in a large-scale crackdown on international sex rings.

Liu Cheng-wu, a prosecutor with the Taipei District Prosecutors' Office who oversaw the operation, said this is the first time that police and investigative authorities have clamped down on hotels and hostels allegedly involved in the sex trade. He vowed to continue such operations until all illegal sex-related business on the island has been eradicated.

More than 500 police and investigators from both Taipei City and Taipei County were mobilized on Sunday night for the operation. They raided 84 hotels and hostels in the greater Taipei and Keelung City areas and arrested more than 150 people, most of whom were brothel owners or managers, drivers and prostitutes.

Some of the prostitutes arrested were call girls from Hong Kong, Macau, Malaysia, Singapore and Thailand, who entered Taiwan on tourist visas or were sold and cheated into prostitution in Taiwan by "snake-head" human cargo smuggling groups.

Liu said this second crackdown is aimed at deterring the efforts by Southeast Asian criminal rings to transport foreign prostitutes into Taiwan. He promised to continue the crackdown on the sex trade and vowed to seize the two major snake-heads who are suspected of being the ringleaders of a group involved in smuggling prostitutes from Thailand.

Acting on tips reached in September, police authorities launched the first round of the operation one week ago to break an international prostitution ring called "Lily," arresting 49 prostitutes and scores of drivers.

DOC.HEADLINE: CANADA'S ARMS EXPORTS TO THIRD WORLD INCREASING

TEXT.P: Canada, which claims to be a leader in peacekeeping, increased its military exports to Third World countries such as Algeria, Indonesia, mainland China, India and Turkey last year, according to an annual report on exports of military goods.

The report, released on Friday, shows that while there were no military exports to Algeria in 1995, in 1996 Canada exported C$45,442-worth of military training equipment for use in simulation exercises.
The military-backed regime in Algeria has been accused of complicity in horrific attacks on civilians.

Military exports to Indonesia -- which has waged a brutal military occupation of East Timor since 1975 -- went from zero in 1995 to C$1.7 million last year. Lloyd Axworthy, Canada's foreign minister, stressed that the exports include aviation-related equipment and aircraft parts.

Canada's military exports to mainland China, which stood at only C$7,316 in 1995, surged to C$149,941 last year, including sales of radar system components. Mainland China has also been upgrading its anti-riot police equipment since 1989.

Turkey, a NATO ally, nearly tripled its military imports from Canada, from C$2.4 million in 1995 to C$6 million last year, largely because of the sale of aircraft parts, armored personnel carrier parts and navigation systems.
The report indicates that Canada's military exports included firearms, ships for scrap, sonar, and other military equipment and parts.

Military exports to India, which has been accused of military brutality against insurgent groups, increased from C$45,110 in 1995 to $510,733 last year. Those exports included firearms, ships for scrap, sonar and bomb-disposal suits.

The export of gas mask parts and ammunition accounted for an increase in arms exports to Mexico from C$55,573 to C$304,818. Exports to Morocco, engaged in a low-intensity conflict in the Western Sahara, rose to C$232,400 from C$37,836 the year before. These exports included simulator parts for military training.
Exports to the Philippines soared from C$447,999 in 1995 to C$2.9 million last year because of the shipment of firearms, large-caliber ammunition parts, propellants and aircraft parts.

Canada's total military exports amounted to C$459 million in 1996, down marginally from the C$463 million exported in 1995. But the share of exports that went to low- and middle-income countries jumped to 14.5 percent, up from 8.6 percent the year before.

DOC.HEADLINE: JOB LOSSES MAY GENERATE ASIAN SOCIAL TENSIONS

TEXT.P: Asia's financial turmoil could lead to "catastrophic" social consequences because there are few safeguards to protect the millions of people who will lose their jobs in the coming months, according to reports of the Geneva-based International Labor Organization (ILO) on Sunday.

"Starting as the Southeast and East Asian economies do from a prolonged period of high growth, even a deceleration of growth would generate social tensions," Michel Hansenne, Director General of the ILO, was quoted as saying.

In Asia "there is typically no system of unemployment benefits or mechanism for facilitating retraining and redeployment," Hansenne was quoted as saying. "Consequently, retrenched workers will have to fend for themselves."

Job losses are mounting throughout Asia, even in countries that just months ago were experiencing labor shortages. Thai officials say as many as 1.5 million people are expected to be sacked by the end of next year. South Korean job losses will total more than 900,000 next year, according to the labor ministry there. Unemployment in Indonesia will also rise by 1 million, labor union leaders say.

The ILO regional director for Asia, Joe Thurman, said job losses in the current crisis will have an impact on a high proportion of well-paid white collar workers, noting that 6,000 of Thailand's finance workers have lost their jobs.

DOC.HEADLINE: UIGHUR SEPARATISM TRIGGERS FEAR OF DISINTEGRATION IN MAINLAND CHINA (I)

TEXT.P: Although the Uighur separatist movement is too small to be a real threat to mainland Chinese rule, it stirs a visceral fear of chaos and disintegration, a major Canadian newspaper reported on Sunday.

In a dispatch from Kashgar, northwestern China, the Toronto Star said that over the past year, militant Uighur separatists have set off several bombs in the remote northwestern province of Xinjiang, and have even slipped through the security net to strike in Beijing, it added.

The fear has grown as a national psyche developed through centuries of unrest and foreign invasions, and still defines the way mainland China sees the rest of the world, and its place in it, the report said.
In Kashgar, a desert oasis on the ancient Silk Road, Mao Zedong's statue still stands tall.
Perhaps that's because there is little else in Kashgar, beyond soldiers and apparatchiks, to remind the Uighur people that theirs is a Chinese city, the Star said.
They have a saying here: "If you want to know how big China is, you must see Xinjiang. If you want to understand what Xinjiang is, you must visit Kashgar."
Kashgar's 3.1 million people come from 13 of mainland China's minority ethnic groups, including Uzbeks, Mongols and Kazakhs. But more than 90 percent of the city's people are Uighurs.

Uighurs have a lot more in common with neighbors living across the border in countries such as Afghanistan, Kazakhstan and Tajikistan than they do with their rulers in Beijing, the report pointed out.
In the early years of communist rule, well over 90 percent of Xinjiang's people were Uighurs. But as infrastructure improved, Chinese settlers arrived by the million, it said.
The province has more than 13 million people today, only about 7 million of whom are Uighurs, it noted.
At the current rate of migration, Han Chinese will form the majority by early in the 21st century. This creates a feeling of being colonized, which makes many Uighurs angry, according to the Star.
Hao Chang Shun, Kashgar's vice commissioner, is Han Chinese and speaks Uighur. He's not a Muslim, but says, with the certainty of absolute power, that he knows a real one from a charlatan.
He brought up the matter of the Xinjiang's separatists himself, midway through his interview with the Star's Asia Bureau Chief Paul Watson, who filed the report.
"Some people want to make Xinjiang separate from China," he quoted Hao as saying. "They do exist, but they are very few. The people want unity with China and don't want to be separated."

Gulamettin Pahta, a leader of the Uighur independence movement in the US, told Watson: "We just want to live as humans. We don't want to disappear. We want equal rights and self-determination. That's it. And we don't want these Chinese stealing everything from our rich country." (more)

DOC.HEADLINE: UIGHUR SEPARATISM TRIGGERS FEAR OF DISINTEGRATION IN CHINA (II)

TEXT.P: Pahta fled Kashgar with his family and some 10,000 other Uighurs five years after the communist victory, when he was 18 years old.
Now 65, he lives in New York, where he is the founding president of the Eastern Turkistan National Research Center, one of several groups that want Uighur independence.
Pahta is old enough to remember the days when that didn't sound like such a fantasy because Xinjiang declared short-lived independence as the Republic of East Turkistan in 1945.

The chances of it ever happening again are very slim, Watson pointed out. Mainland China has far too much at stake in Xinjiang, such as gold, uranium, oil, natural gas, nuclear missiles -- and national unity, he stressed.

Pahta said, "Before the communist takeover in 1949, there were only 6.3 percent Han Chinese (in Xinjiang), according to official sources. Now they're almost 50 percent. They've become a majority in our country."

Mainland China has 55 official minority groups, and the majority Han Chinese have fought for centuries to keep them united in a stable country, especially in border regions such as Xinjiang and Tibet, Watson reported.

Xinjiang is rich in oil and natural gas, which mainland China needs a lot of as its economy takes off. By some estimates, the region has more oil than Saudi Arabia, perhaps one-third of the world's reserves.

Yet it's one of the country's most backward provinces, and the Uighur people are among the poorest of minorities, which makes industrial mainland China seem like a giant, sucking leech, the Star correspondent said.

DOC.HEADLINE: DPP CITY AND COUNTY CHIEFS SHARE EXPERIENCES

TEXT.P: Newly elected and former city and county chiefs from the opposition Democratic Progressive Party (DPP) shared their experiences in running local governments at a DPP conference held in the Taipei International Convention Center on Monday.

Some 12 newly elected DPP city and county chiefs, as well as past DPP chiefs, attended the meeting, including former Ilan County Chief Chen Tien-nan and former Changhua County Chief Chou Ching-yu, as well as high-level DPP staff.

Participants, riding on the wave of their late November local election victory, discussed enthusiastically whether to hold such meetings on a regular basis, whether to form a strategic alliance of DPP city and county chiefs, and the future of relations between local and central government.

The DPP won a stunning victory in the Nov. 29 local election, taking 12 seats of the 23 up for grabs, while the ruling Kuomintang only managed to capture eight, the other three going to independent candidates.

Addressing the opening ceremony, DPP Chairman Hsu Hsin-liang said the purpose of the conference will be to pass on and share the experience of DPP members, as well as to upgrade the role and power of local government, in the hope that cities and counties can propose a revision of the law to give more power to local governments.

The conference will also seek to build reciprocal exchanges between the central and local governments, in the hope that the Executive Yuan will give more respect to local governments and will seriously consider the idea of inviting local administrative chiefs to take part in Executive Yuan floor meetings, Hsu said.

Taipei City Mayor Chen Shui-bian said that although the experiences of various city governments are all slightly different, he said the theme of his administration has never been too far from the watchwords of "dignity, safety and development" espoused by the government.

Chen said that he is committed to permitting Taipei citizens to receive dignified service from civil servants. In the field of public safety, he stressed that he is striving to cut fires and traffic accidents to the minimum, and is continuing to crack down on video game parlors and illegal sex trade operations in residential areas.
Chen also said that he will seek the support of all Taipei's citizens to maintain the continued development of their city.
The Taipei City mayor will preside over a general discussion later in the afternoon, during which the participants will discuss how to form a strategic alliance of DPP city and county chiefs.

DOC.HEADLINE: CORE PACIFIC GROUP TO ACQUIRE YAMAICHI HK

TEXT.P: The Taipei-based Core Pacific Group (CPG) has agreed to acquire the Hong Kong operations of the failed Japanese Yamaichi Securities later this month, marking the first international merger to be made by a Taiwan stock brokerage firm.

According to a Core Pacific spokesman, CPG and the Japanese brokerage giant Yamaichi Securities forged a draft accord on the merger last week, and a formal agreement is expected to be signed in Tokyo on Dec. 19.

Under the agreement, CPG will acquire 100 percent of the share capital of Yamaichi International (HK) Ltd., which includes Yamaichi Securities (Hong Kong), Yamaichi Futures (Hong Kong), and Yamaichi International Nominees (Hong Kong), valued at more than HK$500 million, the spokesman said.
It is not believed that the collapse of Yamaichi Securities in Japan will have any negative impact on its Hong Kong affiliates, which have been operating normally.

Following the merger, CPG will retain the existing 114 staff members of the Yamaichi affiliates in Hong Kong, including the general manager of Yamaichi International Hong Kong, according to the spokesman.

Several financial conglomerates, including mainland China's International Securities, the United States' AIG, and Taiwan's Grand Cathay Securities have shown keen interest in acquiring Yamaichi's Hong Kong operations in the wake of the recent failure of the mother company, but were beaten to the punch by CPG, which offered better terms and conditions, the spokesman said.

The merger, if successful, will allow CPG the opportunity to make inroads into Hong Kong, mainland China and even Japan, fulfilling CPG founder Shen Ching-chin's dreams of expanding his Taiwan business into multinational financial operations.

Shen, who began his working life as a sailor and textiles exporter, developed skill in utilizing US quotas, and is a clever stock speculator. He founded the CPG about a decade ago and the company today is involved in stock brokerage operations, real estate development and other businesses.
The group, which claims to have assets worth about NT$150 billion (US$4.68 billion), was once included as one of the top 10 business conglomerates in Taiwan.

DOC.HEADLINE: ROC ARMED SERVICES DO NOT SUPPORT SEPARATISTS

TEXT.P: The armed services of the Republic of China definitely do not support separatists and those who advocate changing the official name of the country, Vice Minister of National Defense Wang Wen-hsieh said on Monday.

Wang's remark was made in response to questions raised by the National Defense Committee of the Legislative Yuan. He added that all ROC current territory -- Taiwan, Penghu, Kinmen and Matsu -- will be under military threat from mainland China if the ROC declares independence.

The armed services of the ROC exist based on the ROC constitution; it is the obligation of the armed services to defend the constitution, Wang noted, stressing that even if the main opposition Democratic Progressive Party (DPP) becomes the ruling party, it is unlikely they will declare Taiwan independent.

As a result of the landslide victory of the DPP in recent city mayor and county chief elections, more than 70 percent of Taiwan's population are now under the rule of the DPP at the local government level, which has led to speculation that the DPP will soon become the ruling party, thus bring up the question of the role of the ROC military in the face of such changes.
Wang, who was quoted as saying that the military should understand politics but not interfere in politics, said the armed services of the ROC will fight for the survival of the Republic of China.

With regard to the question of whether the military will be loyal to the constitution if it is revised by the DPP through referendum, Wang said that he believes that any responsible party will weigh the consequences of the survival and security of the nation prior to any revision of the constitution or change in territorial sovereignty.

DOC.HEADLINE: C-119 TRANSPORT PLANES TO BE DECOMMISSIONED

TEXT.P: After serving in the ROC Air Force for nearly four decades, the C-119 transport planes will be decommissioned on Friday, air force officials said on Monday.

The officials said a ceremony will be held on Friday at Pingtung Air Force base, the home of the US-made planes, to formally retire the aged craft. Taiwan is the only nation in the world that still uses the planes.

The air force began taking delivery of the transport planes from the United States in the late 1950s, and the transports became the backbone of the air force's transportation operations, until they were largely replaced by the C-130 Hercules in the early 1990s. The Hercules has three times the payload of the C-119.
In the C-119's heyday, the air force maintained six squadrons containing over 100 of the lumbering planes.

After the decommission ceremony, the transport planes will be dismantled and any schools or institutions that can afford transportation fees will be able to apply to have them for teaching or exhibition purposes.
Taipei City government has already obtained one of the planes, which it plans to install in the Hsinsheng Park for permanent exhibition.

DOC.HEADLINE: FIJI OPENS REP. OFFICE IN TAIPEI WITH MUCH FANFARE

TEXT.P: Visiting Fiji President Kamisese Mara personally presided over an opening ceremony for his country's representative office in Taipei on Monday.
Speaking on the occasion, Mara expressed delight that his Taipei visit has coincided with the inauguration of the Fiji trade and tourism office here.

"The event highlights the long-standing cordial friendship between our two countries," the Fiji head of state said, adding that he hopes the new office will help boost bilateral trade and tourist exchanges in the years ahead.

Noting that globalization is the wave of the 21st century, Mara said international cooperation has become ever more important. "We look forward to strengthening cooperation with the Republic of China in various fields," he added.
Mara also expressed his gratitude for all the assistance the ROC has extended to Fiji and other South Pacific island nations.

Many ROC officials and members of the diplomatic corps attended the opening ceremony. Among the well-wishers were Tzen Wen-hua, ROC vice minister of foreign affairs; John Feng, director of the Protocol Department of the Ministry of Foreign Affairs; Daryl Johnson, director general of the Taipei office of the American Institute in Taiwan; and Hugh L. Stephens, director of the Canadian Trade Office in Taipei.

Josaia Maivusaroko, who has just retired from his post as Fiji commerce and industry vice minister, will be Fiji's first representative to the ROC. Maivusaroko, who also once served at Fiji's embassy in Belgium, arrived in Taipei earlier this month to arrange for the opening of the representative office.
Fiji has no formal diplomatic ties with the ROC, but substantive relations between the two countries are traditionally cordial. Mara previously visited Taipei in 1994 and 1996.

The ministers of foreign affairs of the two countries signed a joint communique in October 1996 on mutual recognition, which is only one step short of establishing full diplomatic ties. Fiji is the third country to sign a mutual recognition communique with the ROC, after Vanuatu and Papua New Guinea.
The ROC has already set up a representative office in Fiji and has also sent agricultural and sugar industry experts to that country to assist in its economic development.

DOC.HEADLINE: ACER ANNOUNCES US$40M INVESTMENT IN WALES

TEXT.P: Acer Peripherals Inc., an offshoot of Asian computer giant the Acer Group, on Monday announced a US$40 million investment project in Wales, UK, to make television and computer monitors for the expanding European market.
The monitor manufacturing complex, to be located in a suburb of the Welsh capital of Cardiff, will create at least 1,000 jobs for the region.

In a simultaneous announcement in Cardiff to mark the multi-million dollar investment, David Rowe-Beddoe, chairman of the Welsh Development Agency, said: "The decision by such a prominent, world-class Asian company to choose Wales is a significant endorsement for the growing role Wales is playing in the international intelligent technology (IT) industry and its ongoing initiatives to create a high-tech workforce."
"Acer will be a significant boost to the local economy. It will make a significant contribution to enhancing our skills base and will be a major new customer for Welsh suppliers," Rowe-Beddoe noted.

Acer is likely to depend on a huge volume of key electronic components supplied from other companies located in South Wales. The four largest IT-accredited molding companies in Britain which are likely to compete to supply the casings for Acer's monitors are all based in the region, he added.

K.Y. Lee, president of Acer Peripherals Inc., who was also present at the ceremony in Cardiff, said: "One of the prime factors in our choice of location was the supply infrastructure within the region. We will be able to buy all key components from Welsh-based suppliers."

Increasing demand in Europe prompted Acer to look at potential locations in Holland, Scotland, the North East of England and Wales for a European manufacturing base. The Welsh Development Agency showed Acer's project team around a range of sites in North, West and South Wales before the team opted for a 50-acre site at Cardiff, which proved closest to key suppliers.

Acer made the decision also out of consideration of its need to be near major ports, since the bulk of its output will be exported to continental Europe. A perceived loyal and positive work ethic demonstrated by the Welsh workforce, and Wales' track record as a proven base for the manufacture of consumer electronics also affected Acer's decision, Lee noted.

According to Lee, Acer plans to reach full production over a five-year timetable. A small team of senior employees and engineers will be seconded to Wales in late 1998 to oversee the launch of production. Thereafter, the company is expected to recruit all of its employees from within Wales. The facility will employ approximately 200 people by the end of 1998, with the figure growing gradually to reach 1,000 in the year 2002.

DOC.HEADLINE: MORE THAN NT$500 MILLION REQUIRED TO MEND DAMAGE TO CPC REFINERY

TEXT.P: As much as NT$515 million will be needed to repair the damage caused by the explosion of an oil tank in the Talin refinery plant of the Chinese Petroleum Corporation (CPC) in southern Kaohsiung County, according to a report submitted on Monday by the Commission of National Corporations to the Ministry of Economic Affairs.

The report points out that about NT$460 million will be needed for major structural repairs to the plant, while an additional NT$55 million will be required to repair three damaged tanks and pipes, and broken windows in the control room.

The explosion, the second similar accident to occur in the CPC's Talin plant in the last five years, took place on Sunday at about 2:45 p.m., killing two workers and injuring two, while another one remains missing.
Initial investigation has revealed human error to be the most probable cause of the accident, as cigarette lighters and a bottle of wine were found at the site.
The incident has stirred up strong protests from local residents, who demanded the CPC move the plant elsewhere.

Cheng Wen-ching, vice chairman of the Commission of National Corporations, said operations of the more than 10 remaining tanks at the Talin plant have been immediately suspended for the moment, but added that they will resume operations after being checked.

He said the CPC will continue searching for the missing worker and has already delivered compensation money to the families of the two fatalities. He pointed out that the CPC is still assessing who should be held responsible for the accident.

DOC.HEADLINE: ROC TO WORK OUT STRATEGY TO MEET KYOTO PROTOCOL

TEXT.P: Premier Vincent Siew has directed relevant government agencies to work out concrete, effective measures in a comprehensive and systematic manner to help reduce Taiwan's contribution to global warming in accordance with the newly passed international agreement on cuts in greenhouse gas emissions.

Siew gave the directive after hearing reports by government officials in charge of economic affairs and environmental protection on the highlights of the treaty passed by a group of industrially advanced countries at Japan's ancient capital of Kyoto on Dec. 11 to limit emissions of gases which cause global warming.

The Kyoto Protocol calls for the United States to reduce greenhouse gas emissions to 7 percent below 1990 levels, while Europe and Japan will make cuts of 8 percent and 7 percent, respectively, below 1990 amounts. The reductions will be achieved between 2008 and 2012.

Siew said that although the Republic of China is not a signatory to the Kyoto Protocol, it is very likely to be the target of the next wave of action on greenhouse gas emission-cutting. "As an export-oriented country, the ROC is vulnerable to global trade sanctions," the premier said, adding that the ROC must begin to brace itself as early as possible for stricter world regulations on greenhouse gas emissions.

Siew demanded that all relevant government departments finalize a comprehensive package of measures by the end of next May for reducing Taiwan's greenhouse gas emissions in order to meet standards set for newly industrializing countries or developing countries.

The premier said the Ministry of Economic Affairs should review the domestic industrial structure and energy policy, while the Council of Agriculture should accelerate reforestation and reinforce forest management, and the Environmental Protection Administration (EPA) should collect first-hand information about measures adopted by Kyoto treaty signatories to cut greenhouse gas emissions.

EPA Administrator Tsai Hsun-hsiung said Taiwan must adjust its industrial structure, upgrade its energy efficiency and promote energy conservation in order to meet its target of significantly slashing greenhouse gas emissions by 2014.

Tsai said Taiwan must trim carbon dioxide emissions by 162 percent if it wants to limit its greenhouse gas emissions at its 1990 level by 2010. The island will have to reduce carbon dioxide emissions by 81 percent and 31 percent, respectively, if it wants to control greenhouse gas emissions to the 1995 and the 2000 level.

"By any standard, we have to overhaul our energy policy and industrial development strategy to meet the new anti-global warming requirements," Tsai said, adding that such adjustments will certainly have a great impact on Taiwan's future economic development.
According to an EPA report, Japan and South Korea plan to build more than 20 nuclear power plants in order to meet the Kyoto Protocol's provisions on greenhouse gas emissions.

As former Premier Lien Chan once promised that Taiwan will not build any more nuclear power plant after the completion of its controversial fourth nuclear plant, Tsai said Taiwan may have to increase the use of natural gas in power generation in order to cut carbon dioxide emissions.

Vice Premier Liu Chao-hsiuan said the cabinet will call a national energy meeting in the first half of next year to discuss possible adjustments to the country's energy policy, particularly the suitable ratios of various forms of energy in overall energy supplies.

The EPA study also shows that the petrochemical, steel and cement industries are Taiwan's top three sources of greenhouse gas emissions. To cope with the new global trend, the report suggests that the government restrict the development of industries that consume large amounts of energy and emit large amounts of greenhouse gases.

Against this background, observers said, the fates of two controversial investment projects -- Tuntex Group's plan to build a petrochemical complex and Yiehlung Group's plan to build an integrated steel mill in coastal region of Tainan County -- have become quite uncertain.

DOC.HEADLINE: US DOLLAR UP

TEXT.P: The US dollar rose NT$0.222 against the New Taiwan dollar on the Taipei foreign exchange market Monday, finishing at NT$32.746.
The greenback opened at 32.65, and was traded between 32.616 and 32.87.
Interbank US dollar trading reached US$390.5 million.

DOC.HEADLINE: ASEAN LEADERS TO TAKE ACTION TO RESTORE CONFIDENCE
DOC.DATELINE: Taipei, Dec. 15 (CNA) (By Elizabeth Hsu) (By Conrad Lu)

TEXT.P: Their crucial task is to grapple with the region's economic crisis caused by a financial crunch that has overshadowed what was to have been a commemorative summit to mark ASEAN's 30th anniversary and its expansion to nine members.

Senior ASEAN officials have spent the past two days working feverishly on a statement that could be adopted by their leaders, The Straits Times reported on Monday in a dispatch from the Malaysian capital.

In essence, the statement will call for urgent measures to stop the slide in the region's currencies, as well as for a new mechanism to complement the International Monetary Fund's role in restoring confidence and stability in Southeast Asian economies.
With much of the legwork done on what needs to be fixed, the job is now for the ASEAN leaders to endorse the proposed reforms, or better still, come up with new ideas.
This means that they have to go well beyond what their finance ministers and officials had suggested, the report said.

At the minimum, the hope is that a positive note from the ASEAN leaders will send the right signals to the financial markets and underline their resolve to overcome their economic problems with reforms and austerity measures.
ASEAN finance ministers have, among other things, recently proposed that a regional surveillance mechanism be set up to warn member economies headed for trouble.
This is a ground-breaking move that could go some way to fostering greater transparency, the lack of which has been blamed for much of the region's economic difficulties.
On Sunday night, the ASEAN leaders had a working dinner hosted by Malaysian Prime Minister Mahathir Mohammad, the report said.

Mahathir, chairman of the summit, also had a series of bilateral meetings in which the currency crisis took top billing. Among those he met were Thailand's Prime Minister Chuan Leekpai and mainland China's President Jiang Zemin.
A Thai spokesman said Mahathir and Chuan agreed that the IMF should speed up its study on currency trading and the impact of volatile funds on developing economies.
They also agreed that a global approach was needed to help Asian economies overcome their current financial difficulties.
Malaysian Foreign Minister Abdullah Badawi told a press conference on Sunday that the IMF's tough prescriptions for East Asian economies had failed to improve the situation, the report said.

"Maybe you cannot give Panadol to everybody... This, I think, is a matter of great concern. I think we would expect to see a more concerted effort by ASEAN countries to deal with the present crisis," he was quoted as saying.
Unlike Thailand, Indonesia and South Korea, Malaysia is doing its best to avoid going to the IMF for a financial lifeline, the report said.
The report also noted that the absence of Indonesia's 76-year-old President Suharto, ASEAN's most senior head of government, will be keenly felt at the summit.
Told by his doctors to rest at home, he is being represented by Indonesian Foreign Minister Ali Alatas.

The ASEAN leaders will be meeting their counterparts from mainland China, Japan and South Korea for the first time at Monday's summit, when the economic crisis and regional security will dominate the talks, the report said.

DOC.HEADLINE: TAIWAN INVESTMENT IN PANAMA REACHES US$86.7 M. THIS YEAR

TEXT.P: Taiwan investment in Panama has reached US$86.7 million this year, according to information from the Republic of China Embassy in Panama.

Thirteen Taiwan companies have made investment in Panama this year. Most of the investment projects are in the Fort Davis Export Processing Zone. A freight terminal and shipping company invested US$65 million, and a maritime shipping company invested US$5 million.
Taiwan investors have created 200 employment opportunities in the Fort Davis eport processing zone.
Taiwan companies have also made investment in Panama's Colon Free Trade Zone and some other places. (by Ed Hsieh)

DOC.HEADLINE: VICE PRESIDENT LIEN MEETS WITH NICARAGUAN OFFICIAL

TEXT.P: Vice President Lien Chan said Monday that the 21 million people on Taiwan, the Republic of China, have been deprived of representation in the United Nations and other world organizations because of their rejection of communism.
Lien made the remark when he received Enrique Paguaga Fernandez, representative of Nicaragua to the United Nations.

The vice president also said that the Republic of China is willing to work with other countries in the world for common prosperity and benefits, and that the Republic of China will be able to make greater contribution to the world community, if it is able to join world organizations and their activities.

Lien told Paguaga that the Republic of China will continue to strengthen the relations between the two countries, and cooperate with Nicaragua in economic development. He also thanked Paguaga for having made speeches in support of the Republic of China's bid to join the United Nations. (by Ed Hsieh)

DOC.HEADLINE: SA NATIONAL PARTY CRITICIZES SALE OF NUKE TECHNOLOGY TO M'LAND CHINA

TEXT.P: South Africa's major opposition National Party (NP) has condemned the reported sale of South African nuclear technology to mainland China.

NP spokesman Dr. Boy Geldenhuys said in a statement that the sale of nuclear technology to a country which is not a signatory to the Nuclear Non-Proliferation Treaty should be condemned in the strongest possible terms.
"The transaction nullifies South Africa's laudable efforts in combating the proliferation of nuclear weapons worldwide," the statement said.
It added, "The secrecy that shrouds the deal also puts a question mark behind the government's commitment to transparency."

A Sunday newspaper reported that 40 mainland Chinese scientists were working illegally in South Africa to dismantle a crucial part of South Africa's nuclear-fuel production facility and ship it back to mainland China.

DOC.HEADLINE: TAIWAN CHICKEN FARMERS URGED TO BE ALERT TO HONG KONG BIRD FLU

TEXT.P: Taiwan chicken farmers were urged on Monday to stay highly alert to possible invasion of the "bird flu" from Hong Kong which has killed two people and infected seven others, forcing the territory's poultry market to close for cleanup operations.

The Council of Agriculture (COA) made the urgent call amid reports that the deadly H5N1 influenza strain has spread from Hong Kong to Shenzhen in mainland China's Guangtong province, where hundreds of thousands of chickens have reportedly died of the epidemic.
COA officials urged local chicken farmers to monitor their poultry carefully and report swiftly to related agencies if they see signs of infection in their stock.

In addition, COA experts advised chicken farmers to separate chickens from other types of poultry such as ducks and geese, since these species may act as intermediary agents to spread the virus to chickens. Ducks and geese can carry the virus without developing symptoms, they warned.
As of Monday, there have been no reported cases of the disease in any of Taiwan's chicken farms.

DOC.HEADLINE: SHARE PRICES PLUNGE ON TAIEX

TEXT.P: Share prices closed 1.6 percent lower on the local stock market Monday, with share prices of plastic and chemical issues adjusting downward following active buying last week stimulated by unexpectedly high profit reports, according to brokers.
They added that the turnover volume in electrical shares also dropped off due to uncertainty in the market, which resulted in the downturn, despite vigorous activity when trading opened.
The Taiwan Stock Exchange (TAIEX) weighted price index plunged 102.39 points to close at the day's low of 8,241.49. Trading began at the day's high of 8,420.91.
Falling stocks outnumbered gainers 300 to 125, with 40 issues remaining unchanged.
A total of 2.84 billion shares changed hands on a market turnover of NT$121.73 billion (US$3.8 billion).
All eight stock categories experienced a fall, with foodstuff shares dropping the most at 1.8 percent.

Electrical and construction stocks both took a plunge of 1.7 percent, with a decline of 1.6 percent in plastic and chemical issues, 1.1 percent in financial stocks, 0.5 percent in paper-making shares, and 0.4 percent in textile issues.
Cement shares remained unchanged.

The companies with the 10 largest turnovers were: China Steel, Hualon-Teijran, Taiwan Styrene Monomer, Formosa Chemical and Fiber, Grand Petrochemical, Union Petrochemical, Formosa Plastic, Mosel Vitelic, and Acer.

DOC.HEADLINE: ASIAN ECONOMIES WILL RECOVER AND EMERGE STRONGER: LEE KUAN YEW

TEXT.P: Asian economies will recover and emerge stronger from the current financial turmoil, Singapore's Senior Minister Lee Kuan Yew said recently.

He pointed out that the financial turmoil in Asia does not suggest that the Asian economic model has fundamental flaws, he said in an interview published in the Dec. 4 issue of German business magazine Wirtschaftswoche.
Lee was asked during the interview whether the ongoing turmoil in Asian markets means the so-called Asian century is over before it has begun.
He dismissed the fanfare over the Asian century as "hype," but noted that it is a fact that Asia will play an important role in the new century because of mainland China's growing importance.
"China will overtake the United States in terms of GNP (Gross National Product) in the next century.
"This alone will shift the weight of the world balance from the Atlantic to the Pacific. The present crisis in Asia is not going to change this historic perspective," Lee claimed.

He added that while the turmoil reflects some common problems in Asia, such as overly-close connections between politicians and businesses, it does not indicate any fundamental flaw in Asia's economic model.
The crisis will turn dangerous only if some countries postpone measures to tackle their problems, he said.
But countries which act quickly will recover within two years, he predicted.
Asked if the "Asian miracle" will turn into an "Asian malady," Lee said: "No, it won't be that bad. But I do not want to minimize the problems either.
"What we are experiencing now has been developing for years. The old structures have not been adjusted to the new challenges."

For example, South Korea's state-directed development was correct for the country until the mid-1980s, when it was plugged into the world economy and subject to world prices and it could no longer direct developments at a national level.
As for Japan, its troubles arose from its banks and Finance Ministry not understanding early enough the impact of global financial markets on the country, he said.
On whether the Asian or Western models of development will turn out to be more successful, Lee said only time will tell, but he believes the Confucian system will survive.
He elaborated: "It is a system which focuses on man's self-improvement -- a man who takes his destiny into his own hands.
"Good families can develop only under those conditions, and from good families develop good extended families and clans and eventually good relationships between people and rulers.
"I personally believe that this Confucian system will pass the test of time."
He disagreed that family-oriented values will necessarily disappear as a society becomes more affluent.
Singapore, for example, has become richer, but family ties have remained strong, in part because the state has designed social and tax policies that have helped preserve the family unit.

On the state's role in the economy, the Senior Minister said that because Singapore is so small, the government has to manage the economy actively, as it lacks the critical mass for the market to find its own level in all respects, but added that the state has scaled back its role in some areas.

DOC.HEADLINE: BRITISH FIRM TO HELP CLEAR MINE FIELDS ON ROC-HELD KINMEN ISLAND

TEXT.P: The Ministry of National Defense has hired a British company to help remove land mines in a township on the offshore frontline island of Kinmen as part of the Republic of China's efforts to support a global campaign to ban anti-personnel land mines, military authorities said on Monday.

A group of executives from Specialist Gurkha Services UK Ltd. made an inspection tour of Hsiputou in Kinmen on Monday afternoon in preparation for clearing land mines planted in the region many decades ago. The British team, headed by Gurkha's Chairman Mark Ranson, was accompanied on the inspection tour by Col. Lee Tze-kuang, deputy director of the Engineering Service under the Army Logistics Command, and several Kinmen civilian officials.
The British firm is scheduled to start de-mining operations in the Hsiputou region before the end of this month, according to military sources.
Kinmen, which lies closer to mainland China than to Taiwan, currently has nine abandoned mine fields, with six at Hsiputou, two at Houpan and one at Shuangjushan.

The Defense Ministry has set aside a budget of NT$380 million (US$11.69 million) for removing all land mines from the nine fields over the next three fiscal years. The mine field in front of a temple dedicated to Gen. Lee Kuang-chien at Hsiputou township is the first region to be de-mined. Gurkha has won the NT$47 million de-mining contract through an open tender. The mine-clearing project is scheduled to be completed by May 20, 1998.

Gurkha is founded by retired engineering servicemen of Britain's Gurkha Corps. The company has helped clear land mines in Mozambique, Afghanistan, South Korea, Cambodia, Swaziland, Kuwait and several other countries or areas around the world.

Ranson, who visited Kinmen once before in October 1996, said mine-clearing is like conducting archeological excavations. "Security is a top concern," he stressed, adding that Kinmen's land mines are covered by thick earth and intertwined with plant roots. "We must pay much heed to ensure safety."

DOC.HEADLINE: MORE ILLEGAL IMMIGRANTS FROM MAINLAND CHINA ARRESTED IN JAPAN

TEXT.P: The number of illegal immigrants arrested in Japan has increased rapidly in recent years, and most of them are from the Chinese mainland, according to statistics released by the maritime security agency of Japan.

A total of 597 illegal immigrants have been arrested so far this year, 95 percent of whom from the Chinese mainland, the statistics showed. Of the other five percent, 22 are from Bangladesh, four from the Philippines, and 2 from South Korea.
According to the statistics, the number of arrested illegal immigrants has increased from 22 in 1990 to 209 in 1993, and 481 in 1996.
The ships smuggling illegal immigrants to Japan are equipped with satellite navigation facilities, sophisticated radio equipment, and cellular phones, Japanese police officers said.
Mainland Chinese smugglers and the criminal rings of Japan are colluding in bringing the illegal immigrants to Japan, they said. (by Chang Fang-ming/Ed Hsieh)

DOC.HEADLINE: ONE MORE TAIWAN BANK OPENING PHILIPPINE OFFICE
DOC.DATELINE: Manila, Dec. 15 (CNA) (By Sung Ting-wu & Elizabeth Hsu)

TEXT.P: The Taipei-based United World Chinese Commercial Bank will formally open its Philippine office Wednesday, according to bank officials.

A spokesman said here Monday that the unit is being set up in tune with the Republic of China government's "Go South" policy, which is aimed at encouraging Taiwan investors to expand their businesses into the Southeast Asian area.

The new facility will mostly play the role of financial consultant, before an application for upgrading the representative office to the status of a branch bank is approved, the spokesman pointed out.

According to Philippine laws, a representative office of a foreign bank, in contrast to an overseas branch, is not permitted to conduct financial operations, such as monetary transactions or loan activities.

United World Chinese Commercial Bank is the latest Taiwan-based bank, following International Commercial Bank of China, Chinatrust Commercial Bank, First Commercial Bank and Taiwan Cooperation Bank, to open a branch bank or representative office in the Philippines.

DOC.HEADLINE: SIA VOTED WORLD'S BEST AIRLINE FOR 9TH TIME

TEXT.P: Singapore Airlines (SIA) has been voted the world's best airline as well as best trans-Pacific airline by the readers of New York-based Business Traveler International magazine.
In addition, SIA has also been recognized with having the best business class and best economy class accommodations, SIA said in a statement on Sunday.
The awards were presented at a luncheon held at the Plaza Hotel in New York on Dec. 3, it said.
Business Traveler International is the only US magazine published exclusively for American executives who travel internationally.
A total of 2,000 business readers who travel extensively throughout the world were polled to produce the results of this year's survey, the ninth annual reader's survey conducted by the magazine.

SIA said it has achieved a noteworthy history with the US magazine's reader's poll. This is the ninth consecutive win for SIA for "Best Airline in the World" and the seventh consecutive win in the "Best Trans-Pacific Airline" category since the award was introduced in 1991. The award for "Best Business Class" is the second one for SIA and is complimented by a first-time win for "Best Economy Class," it added.

DOC.HEADLINE: KAOHSIUNG MAYOR RULES OUT RUNNING FOR TAIPEI CITY HEAD

TEXT.P: Kaohsiung City Mayor Wu Den-yih on Monday dismissed as "groundless" reports that he plans to run for the top job in Taipei City on the Kuomintang ticket after his current term expires in 1999.

Asking the press to refrain from wild speculation on his future options, Wu told a group of curious reporters : "I would like to make it clear that I definitely will not enter the race in Taipei City. So, please stop this kind of guessing game."
Admitting he had been urged by some supporters to run for the Taipei City mayorship, Wu firmly stated that he has absolutely no desire to do so.

Taipei Mayor Chen Shui-bian, a member of the opposition Democratic Progressive Party, has declared his intention to run for re-election. He is deemed a powerful contender by the ruling Kuomintang given his high approval rating in recent opinion polls.

DOC.HEADLINE: ANTI-DUMPING DUTIES LIFTED ON KOREAN DRAMS

TEXT.P: The European Union has lifted anti-dumping duties on South Korean-made DRAMs, the most common type of computer chip, after manufacturers reached an industry-to-industry accord on data collection, the World Trade Organization (WTO) said on Monday.
The EU may do the same for Japan if a similar agreement can be reached, according to reports from the Geneva-based global trade regulatory body.

Removing measures against both countries could end one of the EU's largest and longest-running dumping disputes, after minimum pricing undertakings were imposed on 11 Japanese manufacturers in 1990, and on three South Korean groups in 1993.

DRAMs, or dynamic random access memory chips, are the basic building block for intelligent electronic devices from video recorders to PCs. The EU market is worth some US$ 5.7 billion annually, with Japanese and Korean manufacturers accounting for 80 percent.

Anti-dumping measures were suspended for 21 months from 1995, after a rise in DRAM prices. But they were reimposed in phases between March and June this year, after a worldwide slump in chip prices, despite complaints from EU electronic goods manufacturers that this would push up their costs.

The EU industry body -- the European Electronic Component Manufacturers' Association (EECA) -- began talks in July with its Korean and Japanese counterparts on an industry-to-industry accord that would allow the duties to be lifted, but also promised swift investigation of any future dumping complaints.
EECA reached a reciprocal accord with the Korean Semiconductor Industry Association in September requiring manufacturers to collect data on cost of production and export prices.

The accord contains no minimum pricing element, and has been cleared by the European Commission's competition authorities. It is similar to a deal reached on another type of semiconductor chip, "flash" Eproms, and is seen as model for resolving dumping disputes in other sectors.

DOC.HEADLINE: EXPORT FROM TAIWAN'S EXPORT PROCESSING ZONES INCREASES

TEXT.P: Export from Taiwan's export processing zones is expected to exceed US$8,000 million this year, an official of the Export Processing Zones Administration said here Monday.

He said export from the three export processing zones of Taiwan reached US$7,226 million in the first 11 months of this year, a hike of 17 percent over a year earlier. Imports during the period totaled US$4,615 million, an increase of 27 percent over the same period of 1996. Trade surplus totaled US$2,610 million in the 11-month period.

Their surplus in trade with Hong Kong and Europe totaled US$789 million and US$246 million respectively, indicating that the policy to diversify their export markets has begun to bear fruit, the official said.

He also pointed out that electric and electronics machinery, optical products, precision machinery, and other high-tech products are their major export items, accounting for 89 percent of the total export.
The three export processing zones are located in Taichung, in central Taiwan, and Kaohsiung and Nantz, in southern Taiwan. (by Ed Hsieh)

DOC.HEADLINE: KAOHSIUNG MAYOR URGES TIMETABLE FOR REMOVAL OF CPC PLANTS

TEXT.P: Kaohsiung Mayor Wu Den-yin on Monday lambasted the Chinese Petroleum Corp. (CPC) for failing to impose strict industrial safety measures on its facilities, demanding the state-run corporation set a timetable for removing its two refineries in the city.

Wu said that in the past two years, a total of 16 CPC-related industrial accidents have occurred, killing and injuring dozens of its employees and members of the public. This proves the CPC's lack of ability and sincerity in strengthening safety measures and in preventing the recurrence of similar accidents, he added.

The latest incident came on Saturday when an oil tank at the CPC refinery in Kaohsiung's Talin district exploded, killing two workers and injuring two others, while one worker remains missing. It was the second such explosion at the same location within five years, and residents around the Talin plant have threatened to besiege the compound until the CPC meets their demand to relocate the facility.

Wu said that two CPC refineries, the one in Talin and another in the Tsoying district, have not only brought environmental pollution problems to Kaohsiung City, but also have seriously endangered the lives of its residents.

The CPC has long used Kaohsiung as its production base, but with its headquarters in Taipei, the company did not pay any taxes to the Kaohsiung City Government until three years ago, Wu pointed out. "The CPC owes Kaohsiung residents too much," he asserted.

Wu said that when construction began on the nation's fifth naphtha cracker in Tsoying seven years ago, the CPC promised to remove the refinery within 25 years. Several years have since passed, Wu noted, but the CPC has not announced any plans about the removal.

While urging the CPC to raise industrial safety standards to better protect the lives of its employees and of Kaohsiung residents, Wu also demanded that the company set a timetable for removal of both the Tsoying and Talin plants as soon as possible.

DOC.HEADLINE: LEVEL OF ROC TIES WITH S. AFRICA SAID TO BE HIGHER THAN WITH US, JAPAN

TEXT.P: South African Ambassador to the ROC H.E. Cornelius van Niekerk Scholts said on Monday that Pretoria is set to reveal its arrangement for continuing unofficial ties with Taipei after it shifts diplomatic recognition to Beijing at the beginning of next year.

Refusing to elaborate, the last Pretoria envoy to Taipei said in response to reporters' questions that the new framework will allow decades-old bilateral relations, especially the close economic ties, to continue after Jan. 1, 1998, in the absence of official recognition.
South African President Nelson Mandela announced on Nov. 27, 1996, that Pretoria would switch its diplomatic loyalty to Beijing at the end of 1997.

Taipei has conducted three rounds of high-level talks and eight rounds of working-level negotiations with Pretoria since that announcement in an attempt to forge a new framework for bilateral relations, but no outcome has been announced.

South African Foreign Minister Alfred Nzo said in Pretoria on Dec. 1 that the talks had stalled over Taipei's demands to retain its consulates and to continue using its official national name after 1998.

Meanwhile, opposition Democratic Progressive Party Legislator Parris Chang said Monday that although the agreement with Pretoria may not accommodate all Taipei's demands, relations will nonetheless be on a higher level than those afforded under similar arrangements reached with Washington and Tokyo. He added that the ROC-South African framework is certain to trigger protests from Beijing.

Chang also revealed that South Africa will use the term "liaison office" to describe its representative office in Taipei, while the ROC will employ the name "Taipei," rather than "Taiwan," in the title of its representative office in Pretoria.

DOC.HEADLINE: MOI LOOSENS QUOTA ON MAINLANDERS SEEKING RESIDENCY

TEXT.P: The government-imposed quota on the number of mainland Chinese who are married to people from Taiwan and have applied for residency here on that basis will be expanded to 2,200 persons annually from the current limit of 1,800 per year.
According to the Ministry of the Interior (MOI), the new quota will be adopted next year.

The MOI explained that the relaxed regulation was approved as a result of a calculated 0.995 percent population growth for Taiwan and the fact that an average of 21,268 persons each year are emigrating abroad.

However, despite the increased quota, mainland Chinese spouses who are now filing marriage-based applications for Taiwan residency will have to wait until July 2005 for approval as nearly 17,000 persons are already on the waiting list, the ministry indicated.

DOC.HEADLINE: DEFENSE MINISTER PLEDGES LOYALTY OF ARMED FORCES TO NATION

TEXT.P: "There should be no question of the armed forces' loyalty to the country and to the government," no matter who is at the helm, Defense Minister Chiang Chung-ling said at the Legislature on Monday.
However, Chiang said: "The 'country' refers to the Republic of China, and the 'government' refers to the government of the Republic of China."
The minister's comment came in a response to an interpellation by Lin Che-fu, a legislator of the independence-minded opposition Democratic Progressive Party.

The DPP, which swept to an overwhelming victory in November's local elections, is setting its eyes on the legislative elections next year and is eager to replace the Kuomintang, which has ruled the island since 1949, in forming the nation's next government.

While denying allegations by the opposition that the KMT uses the armed forces to consolidate its grip on power, the defense minister, himself a KMT member, cautioned in the same breath against any ambitions harbored by some DPP members to declare independence.
Chiang said that the armed forces do not care which party rules the country, so long they are defending the Republic of China, rather than a so-called "Taiwan Independent State" or any other entity.

Chiang dismissed Lin's question as to how the armed forces would respond if the nation's Constitution were altered and the country renamed, saying only: "I would answer the question only after the Constitution is changed."

DOC.HEADLINE: ALCOHOL CITED AS FACTOR IN BRITONS' DEATH

TEXT.P: The two Britons who died in a car crash in Taipei on Saturday were not wearing seat belts, and that could be a main reason for their deaths, local police said on Monday.

In addition, Douglas Clay, the driver of the vehicle at the time the car slammed into a concreat divider at high speed, had a blood alcohol level in excess of the legal limit of 0.025 percent, the police said.
Clay died from a massive brain hemorrhage after being taken to a local hospital. Philip Craig, the front seat passenger and one of four occupants in the car, died in the hospital the next day.
Two other passengers riding in the back seat, Stephen Farrand, also a Briton, and a Chinese woman named Liu Li-fang, were released from the hospital after treatment.

DOC.HEADLINE: TAIWAN PROVINCIAL GOVERNMENT AGREES TO LEASE LAND TO BAYER

TEXT.P: German-based Bayer Group took one step closer to beginning construction on its project in Taichung County when the Taiwan Provincial Government on Monday agreed to lease land for the multinational's first investment in Taiwan.
The lease agreement, however, must be approved by the Taiwan Provincial Assembly, which is scheduled to close its current session on Friday.
In an apparent attempt to make approval by the assembly possible before the week's end, the Taiwan Provincial Government rushed through authorization of the contract during an administrative meeting.

Provincial government spokesman Hwang Yi-chiou said after the meeting that the Taiwan Provincial Assembly had earlier asked that the land lease agreement meet three conditions: that a careful study be made of the environmental impact of the project, that the terms of the contract be fair, and that consent for the project be given by residents living near the proposed investment site in the Taichung Harbor area.

Hwang said that on the sensitive issue of local consent, Bayer had submitted a copy of over three thousand signatures by harbor area residents in support of the project, proving that the petrochemical giant has kept up good communications with the public.

Under the contract, the Taiwan Provincial Government will lease 90 hectares of its land in the Taichung Harbor area to Bayer Group for a period of 50 years for the purpose of constructing chemical plants. Bayer has the right to ask for an extension of another 50 years after expiry of the lease.

The rental rate will be 5 percent of the government-set land value plus royalties charged for the use of the land. The rent, calculated on annual basis, at current land prices would be about NT$154 per square meter, that is, NT$100 million for the 90-hectare construction base.

Even if the Taiwan Provincial Assembly approves the land lease, the fate of the Bayer project is still full of uncertainty as it may face a referendum to be held in the county, an unprecedented occurrence in Taiwan.

The Democratic Progressive Party magistrate-elect in Taichung County, Liao Yuan-lia, has said that if county residents continue to have misgivings stemming from environmental concerns over the Bayer project, he will put the issue to a countywide public vote.

DOC.HEADLINE: URGENT NEED FOR TAIWAN TO CUT GREENHOUSE GASES: SIEW

TEXT.P: In line with world efforts to help save the earth from catastrophic global warming, Taiwan should work out plans to cut greenhouse gas emissions, Premier Vincent Siew said on Monday.

After being briefed by the Environmental Protection Administration (EPA) on the conclusions of the global climate conference held in Japan last week, Siew instructed the EPA to submit emissions-cutting measures by May.

Siew said that the Environmental Protection Administration, the Economics Ministry, the Council for Economic Planning and Development and the Agricultural Commission should work together to set reasonable reduction level in greenhouse gases.

The EPA's report said that greenhouse gas emissions in Taiwan reached 149 million metric tons in 1991, 83 percent of which was carbon dioxide and 15 percent methane. Most greenhouse gases were emitted as a by-product of energy consumption, accounting for 78 percent of the total, while landfills were the main source of methane.

Taiwan's greenhouse gas emissions ranked in 27th place among 160 countries around the world and accounted for 0.5 percent of the total global emissions. It is estimated that Taiwan will see an increase in such emissions over the next 14 years, with annual growth forecast at 3.1 percent, signaling an urgent need for the government to control such emissions.

The report proposed several emission-cutting measures such as reduction of energy consumption, trash recycling, increasing use of low-carbon or non-carbon energy, the changing of the island's industrial structure and reforestation.

DOC.HEADLINE: DPP DELEGATION LEAVES FOR NORTHEAST ASIA VISIT

TEXT.P: A delegation of politicians from the opposition Democratic Progressive Party (DPP) left for Seoul on Tuesday to observe the South Korean presidential election scheduled for Thursday.
The delegation, headed by DPP Chairman Hsu Hsin-liang, will also visit Japan following its South Korea visit.

Hsu's Seoul visit has drawn much attention as he is an old friend of Kim Dae-jung, the leading opposition candidate in the current South Korean presidential race. Kim, 72, recently said he would promote nonpolitical exchanges with the Republic of China if he wins the election.

Kim is a spiritual leader of South Korean political dissent. Both Kim and Hsu have been jailed and forced to live in exile for many years due to their pro-democracy stances. This is Kim's fourth bid for the presidency. He currently leads the field of candidates in opinion polls.

Hsu said prior to his departure that he and his DPP colleagues will visit campaign headquarters of the three top contenders in the South Korean presidential race -- Kim Dae-jung of the opposition National Congress for New Politics; Lee Hoi-chang of the majority Hannara or Grand National Party; and Rhee In-je of the New People's Party.
"We will attend campaign forums of the three main candidates to hear their speeches as well as meet with other South Korean politicians, scholars and experts," Hsu said.

Members of the DPP delegation include Sisy Chen, director of the DPP's publicity department; Legislators Wang To, Lin Feng-hsi and Tsai Huang-lang; National Assembly Deputy Chang Chuan-tien; and Taiwan Provincial Assemblyman Chou Hui-ying.

The DPP delegation is scheduled to fly to Japan on Friday, where the group will meet with several influential figures in the Japanese political arena. Hsu would not reveal the identities of the Japanese politicians the delegation plans to meet.
Meanwhile, Taipei Mayor Chen Shui-bian, another DPP heavyweight, is also expected to visit Japan in the near future.

Japanese sources said political circles in Tokyo have attached great importance to Hsu's and Chen's visits as the pro-Taiwan independence DPP scored a resounding win in the ROC's recent elections for local government chiefs. After all of the newly elected city mayors and county magistrates have taken office on Dec. 20, more than 70 percent of Taiwan's 21.3 million people will be under DPP jurisdiction at the local level.
