DOC.HEADLINE: MOFA CONCERNED ABOUT SAFETY OF ROC DIPLOMATS IN SOUTH AFRICA
DOC.DATELINE: Taipei, Dec. 16 (CNA) (By J.H. Chang and Lilian Wu)

TEXT.P: The Ministry of Foreign Affairs (MOFA) has asked the South African government to step up protection of ROC diplomats and their families after an ROC diplomat was injured in a robbery in Johannesburg, MOFA spokesman Roy Wu said Tuesday morning.
Wu said the ministry has asked Loh I-cheng, ROC ambassador to South Africa, to convey Taipei's concern to the South African Foreign Ministry.
Timothy Yang, director of MOFA's Department of African Affairs, will visit Nicky Scholtz, South African ambassador to the ROC over the matter Tuesday or Wednesday, Wu said.

Feng Tai, ROC consul-general in Johannesburg, was attending a party in honor of Ambassador Loh hosted by Chen Yuan-yen, president of a Taiwanese association in southern Africa, at Chen's residence in Johannesburg Sunday night when the assault took place.

Loh and his wife left early at about 8:00 p.m. Feng and seven others continued chatting in the living room when three men suddenly broke in at around 8:48 p.m., armed with pistols and an AK-47 automatic rifle.
Feng and other quests were forced to hand over their money and valuables. The robbers hit Feng and another guest, surnamed Lin, on the head with the butt of the rifle.
The assailants fled after one of them forced Chen upstairs to open a safe and was injured by a shotgun blast fired by Chen's son.

Feng and Lin were rushed to a nearby hospital where Feng received five stitches in his head. Lin was in good condition after treatment. Another woman guest also suffered injuries after she was kicked several times.
Feng appealed through the local media for all Taiwan businessmen and overseas Chinese to be more vigilant of their safety in Johannesburg.
Police in Johannesburg said that five men were involved in the robbery, including the three who broke into Chen's house and two others who kept watch outside the residence.
Two suspects from Zimbabwe have been arrested, while a manhunt is under way for the other three men.

DOC.HEADLINE: CPC TAKES MEASURES TO INCREASE WORKPLACE SAFETY

TEXT.P: The Chinese Petroleum Corporation (CPC) on Monday called an interim meeting of directors and supervisors, wherein it was decided to set up a task force and launch a campaign to increase workplace safety in the wake of an explosion at its Talin refinery in southern Kaohsiung County on Sunday.
CPC Chairman Chen Chao-wei said the state-run unit must thoroughly overhaul its operations and practices to rebuild its image and reputation after a strings of accidents in recent years.

He added that CPC department chiefs, starting immediately, will not receive overtime pay and that this year's annual performance bonuses allocated for workers at the Talin plant will be deducted as part of the compensation money for victims of the accident.
This is the first time that the CPC workers' yearly bonuses will be used as compensation funds.

It was also decided in the meeting that a "workplace safety task force" will be established to improve the safety standards of CPC operations and to review the company's contractor system in a bid to fully implement its workplace safety requirements.
Meanwhile, the CPC is scheduled to release a namelist of personnel at the Talin refinery who were found to be negligent in their duties.
An initial investigation has shown that human error is probably the cause of the accident, which killed three workers and injured two.
The explosion stirred up strong protests from local residents, who demanded the CPC suspend operations at the Talin plant and move it elsewhere.

Cheng Wen-ching, vice chairman of the Commission of National Corporations under the Ministry of Economic Affairs, said it would be hard for the CPC to relocate the plant due to difficulties in acquiring land lots.

Although operations of the more than 10 remaining tanks at the Talin plant have been temporarily suspended in order to carry out inspections, Chen said a complete suspension of operations at the plant is also difficult, as that will have a big impact on the supply of petroleum products in the domestic market.
The Talin plant produces up to 40 percent of Taiwan's unleaded petroleum and fuel oil, according to Cheng.

DOC.HEADLINE: TRAFFIC ACCIDENTS INVOLVING FOREIGNERS INCREASE

TEXT.P: The number of traffic accidents involving foreign nationals has increased significantly in recent years as more and more expatriates have come to Taiwan for business, sightseeing, work and study, the Ministry of Transportation and Communications (MOTC) said on Tuesday.
According to ministry tallies, about 2 million foreign nationals visit Taiwan annually and the number of foreigners residing on the island exceeds 200,000.
The statistics also show that the total number of expatriate-related traffic accidents increased 89.7 percent between 1995 and 1996.
The MOTC recently conducted an opinion survey of foreign businesspersons with an aim to understand their views on Taiwan's traffic problems.
More than 90 percent of those surveyed said they have difficulties finding English-language editions of publications detailing traffic rules, instructions or related information.
Many respondents said they have to rely on radio or television programs to understand Taiwan's traffic regulations and general road conditions.

About 66 percent said they have a "fair" understanding of Taiwan's traffic rules, and more than half of the respondents said their knowledge about local traffic regulations mainly comes from their friends.

Asked about their opinions concerning Taiwan's traffic environment, 84 percent said sidewalks in all major cities around the island are inconvenient because they are often occupied by cars, motorcycles or bicycles. Moreover, many sidewalks are blocked by public facilities or other barriers and many of the walkways are in need of repair.

Many expatriates also criticized rampant violations of traffic rules by local drivers, saying reckless changes of traffic lanes, speeding, drunk driving and disobeying traffic signals are all too common on Taiwan's highways and city streets.

Only 30 percent of the respondents said Taiwan's mass transportation systems are convenient, and a mere 10.2 percent said they frequently take city buses or use mass rapid transit systems and other means of public transportation.

Although many foreigners praise convenient taxi services here, quite a few also complain that taxi drivers often purposely take detours or demand additional fares. Some respondents said many taxi drivers fail to abide by traffic regulations.
MOTC officials said relevant government agencies should publish foreign-language editions of local traffic rules for the convenience of foreign visitors and residents.
The officials also suggested that special classes be added to vocational training programs for foreign laborers to help them understand Taiwan's traffic regulations and special conditions.

The officials further said traffic violators should be subject to higher fines and that those who violate articles of the Criminal Code should also be penalized through court proceedings as a deterrent to repeat offenses.

DOC.HEADLINE: S. AFRICAN PLANT SOLD TO MAINLAND CHINA SAID REDUNDANT FOR YEARS

TEXT.P: A plant at the Pelindaba nuclear facilities west of Pretoria, which was recently sold to mainland China, has been redundant for a number of years, according to the Atomic Energy Corporation (AEC) of South Africa on Monday.

The high-technology plant was used to make the zirconium tubes that sheath the fuel for nuclear reactors. The AEC said in a statement "it became politically possible and cheaper to source the product from abroad."

The sale was approved on July 18 this year following an international tendering process, the AEC said, adding that clearance was received from the South African Council for the Non-Proliferation of Weapons of Mass Destruction.

"Apart from three items for which no clearance has yet been received, the sale of the plant has been approved to Pacific Development Services (based in South Africa), who will in turn on-sell to the China Nuclear Energy Industry Corporation of Beijing," the statement said. Pacific Development Services had arranged a team of engineers, scientists and technicians to dismantle the plant and erect it again in mainland China. The AEC said the sale of the plant did not include the transfer of any technology to any party.

Built in the 1960s, Pelindaba was intended to supply South Africa with nuclear fuel. According to the opposition National Party, the facilities built six atom bombs which were destroyed shortly before the 1994 general elections.

DOC.HEADLINE: HUGE NATURAL GAS FIELD FOUND IN IRIAN JAYA

TEXT.P: A huge field of natural gas, believed to be the biggest in Indonesia, has been found in Bamberai village, Fak-Fak district, Irian Jaya Province.

The field was the first to be discovered in Fak-Fak district by PT ARCO, a contractor of the state oil and gas company Pertamina, since it started exploring the area in 1996, Antara news agency quoted district head Suparlan Pasambuna as saying over the weekend.
Pasambuna said the find is expected to attract more foreign investors to exploit the district's natural resources, which include oil and natural gas.
He said research studies conducted by both Indonesian and foreign geologists show that the district is also rich in other minerals.
PT Freeport Indonesia has launched gold explorations in Kaimana subdistrict, while PT British Gas has launched gas explorations in other areas of the district, he added.

DOC.HEADLINE: CANADA EXTENDS IMMIGRANT INVESTOR PROGRAM FOR ONE YEAR

TEXT.P: The Canadian government announced Monday the extension of its immigrant investor program for one more year, until Dec. 31, 1998.

Lucienne Robillard, minister of citizenship and immigration, said the amendments to the regulations will extend her authority to approve new provincial government funds and extend offering periods for existing provincial government funds.

The current rules governing the approval and operation of provincial government funds will continue to apply. Minimum investment amounts, holding periods and the tier system for investment will remain the same.
This amendment does not apply to Quebec, which operates its own investor program under the terms of a 1991 agreement with Ottawa.
The program allows wealthy investors to obtain entry to Canada as landed immigrants if they make a minimum investment. It was introduced 10 years ago by the Conservative government of Brian Mulroney.
Many Taiwanese have become Canadian immigrants or citizens through this program. In 1996, a total of 781 Taiwanese applied for landed immigrant status as investors, down from 833 in 1995.

The most common investment is in provincial-approved mutual funds designed to serve immigrants. The minimum investment required is C$350,000 in Alberta, British Columbia, Ontario and Quebec, and C$250,000 in the other provinces.

The program has drawn criticism that some of the money invested has been a front to obtain a visa. In addition, immigrants have complained of being bilked by investment funds that qualified under the program but were not run professionally.
Robillard increased the minimum investment by C$100,000 last March and tightened regulations to restore confidence in the program.

DOC.HEADLINE: TAIWAN TRADE EXHIBITION HELD IN ISTANBUL

TEXT.P: A one-day Taiwan trade exhibition, promoting electrical home appliances, auto parts, accessories, leather goods, gift items and computers, was held in Istanbul on Monday.
Some 38 companies of Taiwan participated in the exhibition organized by the Taiwan Trade Center.
After peaking at US$622 million in 1993, total trade between Taiwan and Turkey dropped to US$455.8 million in 1996.
Taiwan businessmen have actively participated in various trade shows and market development programs in Turkey to promote trade, an official of the Taiwan Trade Center said.

DOC.HEADLINE: RUPIAH CONTINUES FREE FALL

TEXT.P: The Indonesian rupiah and local stock prices continued their uncontrolled free falls Monday.
The rupiah, which opened at 4,900/5,100 against the US dollar in the spot market, fell almost 16 points to a record low of 5,800 against the US currency and closed at 5,600/5,900.
Stock prices on the Jakarta Stock Exchange lost 7.2 percent, with the composite index closing down 26.317 points at 339.536.
The weakening rupiah sent a negative sentiment to stock trading on the Jakarta Stock Exchange, which saw a 7.2 percent drop in its composite index.
Trading turnover totaled 524.78 million shares valued at 407.18 billion rupiah (US$71.4 million).

DOC.HEADLINE: NAVY COMMISSIONS TWO FRIGATES

TEXT.P: The Navy commissioned two frigates Tuesday at a base in southern Taiwan to enhance its defense capability in the Taiwan Strait.

Naval Commander-in-Chief Admiral Wu Shih-wen presided over the inauguration ceremony for the frigates Ban Chao and Wu Chang on Tuesday morning. Over 400 guests, including Yu Cheng-nan, chairman of the China Shipbuilding Corp., representatives from France and the ROC Navy attended the event.

Wu noted that Ban Chao was the sixth of a series of vessels modeled on US-made Perry-class warships. China Shipbuilding Corp. started construction of the vessel in May 1994, and conducted a series of rigorous tests after its completion.

The high-speed vessel is equipped with modern weaponry systems, two anti-submarine helicopters, artillery and locally developed Hsiungfeng anti-ship missiles. It possesses anti-aircraft, cruise and anti-submarine capability. The frigate also can conduct interception, anti-blockade, escort and other operations.

The Wu Chang is the fifth of six Lafayette-class frigates purchased from France to be delivered. The French-made warship arrived in Taiwan on Dec. 8. It is also equipped with anti-submarine and combat weapons systems, and has the advantages of low-noise propulsion and a "stealth" design to evade detection by enemy forces.
Wu said the two frigates will immediately be included in a series of combat training exercises so that naval personnel can familiarize themselves with the ships' state-of-the-art features.

Taiwan stuck a deal with a deal with France in 1991 to purchase six Lafayette-class frigates at a cost of US$2.8 billion. Four of the vessels have already arrived and been commissioned. The last of the group is due to arrive here very soon.
With the introduction into service of the new ships, the Navy will gradually phase out its aging fleet of destroyers.

DOC.HEADLINE: BEIJING NARROWING ROOM FOR FUTURE CROSS-STRAIT NEGOTIATIONS: MAC

TEXT.P: The Taipei-based Mainland Affairs Council (MAC) said that Beijing has further narrowed the room for future cross-strait negotiations while continuing to insist that such talks be conducted under the "one China" principle.

MAC, a formal administrative agency under supervision of the ROC Cabinet, made the claim after comparing an eight-point proposal announced by mainland Chinese President Jiang Zemin in January 1995 with the contents of a political report he delivered to the 15th National Congress of the Chinese Communist Party (CCP) held last September. Jiang is concurrently the CCP general secretary.

In his report to the CCP congress, Jiang said: "Under the prerequisite of 'one China,' any issue can be discussed, and any comment and proposal, if it is helpful to the reunification of the motherland, can be put forward."

According to MAC officials, that statement had already been contained in his previous eight-point proposal. However, the earlier version had held that all issues could be discussed under the "one China" principle, "including those of concern to the Taiwan authorities."
As a result, the MAC officials analyzed, Beijing has narrowed the space for conducting cross-strait talks, while continuing to insist upon the "one China" principle as a basis for discussions.

In Jiang's report at the CCP congress, two preconditions were set: the "one China" principle must be observed, and the subject matter of cross-strait talks must be limited to topics "helpful to the reunification of motherland," the MAC officials noted.

Such developments once again underscore Beijing's unilateral approach to setting an agenda for talks, the officials stressed. They also said Beijing has now apparently narrowed of the scope of any such negotiations down to only those issues seen as useful to bringing about reunification on its own terms.

DOC.HEADLINE: TURNING TAIWAN INTO INVESTOR HAVEN SAID HELPFUL TO CROSS-STRAIT TIES

TEXT.P: If Taiwan can become a haven for foreign investors as a "Switzerland of the East," such a development would provide a tremendous boost to cross-strait relations.

Those remarks were made on Tuesday at a seminar on cross-strait relations sponsored by the ROC Elite Women's League. The participants consisted of outstanding figures from political and economic circles, women's groups and the business sector.

Huang Yao-yu, director of the Kuomintang's Department of Mainland Operations, said the determining factors affecting cross-strait relations come from forces in both the mainland and Taiwan, as well from as the international community.
He said the top priority for the ROC will be its basic survival and continued development, while mainland China will seek preserve its territorial integrity and national sovereignty.
He said that if the two sides of the Taiwan Strait could find common ground in pursuit of their interests, it would help foster a more stable environment for cross-strait relations.

Chu Chao-ling, a researcher at Academia Sinica, said that women have contributed much to building peaceful, stable, and mutually beneficial cross-strait exchanges. In order to make a fresh start in the coming millennium, she said, the government must map out a new framework for medium- and long-term development of cross-strait ties.

Professor Bian Yu-yuan of National Taiwan University spoke from an economic approach, saying that, in comparison with the mainland, Taiwan excels in business management, marketing and manufacturing. But she criticized the approach toward the mainland taken by Taiwan's political leadership due to the influence of conservative forces and a lack of confidence.

She said that under its financial liberalization policies, Taiwan has the ability to develop itself into a "Switzerland of the East" or a global business center. The island could also become a bridgehead for multinational enterprises seeking to make inroads to mainland markets. Bian said such developments will help foster improved cross-strait ties.

Entrepreneur Lee Tzu-chia said that the problems of land acquisition and labor shortages have forced many local businesses to go overseas. At the same time, she noted, the multinational Bayer Group's investment project in central Taiwan has raised controversy.

Such phenomenon seem to indicate that Taiwan has forgotten that its economy is built upon trade, Lee said. Only if the island can develop itself into an attractive location for foreign investors can it force the mainland to pay due attention and respect to its existence.
From the perspectives of economic relations, population size and internationalization, Taiwan also needs the mainland to achieve sustained development, Lee said.

DOC.HEADLINE: ROC-US WTO TALKS ACHIEVE MAJOR BREAKTHROUGHS
DOC.DATELINE: Washington, Dec. 15 (CNA) (By Herman Pan and Sofia Wu)

TEXT.P: Major breakthroughs have been achieved in negotiations between the Republic of China and the United States concerning terms for Taiwan to join the World Trade Organization (WTO), delegates from both sides said on Monday.

The two countries began the 16th round of WTO talks in the US capital city on Monday, with Chen Ruey-long, director-general of the Board of Foreign Trade, and David Burns, a senior adviser to the US Trade Representative, heading their respective delegations.
During the first day of negotiations, the two sides resolved many disputes over issues related to further liberalization of Taiwan's trade regime, government procurements and service market opening.
"The meeting proceeded smoothly in an amicable atmosphere and we have achieved breakthroughs on some technical issues," Chen said at the end of the first-day consultations.

According to Chen, Taiwan has agreed to open its market to foreign-made motorcycles with 150cc engines or larger two years after it joins the WTO and to finalize necessary reforms of its commercial port construction surcharge collection system within 15 months following its formal entry to the Geneva-based world trade regulatory body.

Taiwan has also promised to scrap a regulation requiring coal importers to simultaneously purchase Taiwan-produced coal and to sign an international commercial aircraft agreement immediately after its WTO accession.

Touching on the opening of service markets, Chen said the US is generally satisfied with Taiwan's fast-paced deregulation of its telecommunications market. Meanwhile, the ROC has promised to revise its insurance law after entering the WTO to allow foreign mutual insurance companies with net worth of NT$2 billion (US$61.35 million) to open branches in Taiwan.

Concerning the government procurements deregulation, Chen said the ROC has agreed to open two major categories of products -- electric engineering and transportation equipment, such as rail cars -- to foreign bidders two years after its WTO entry. Chen said the Cabinet's Public Construction Commission has set up a special committee to handle disputes over the implementation of government purchase contracts. At the request of foreign contractors, the committee will help settle such disputes through the administrative system.

Chen said the two sides will discuss issues concerning Taiwan's tariff reduction schedule, management of tariff-quota system and farm trade-related problems on Tuesday. "If all goes well, this round of talks will end on Wednesday as scheduled," he added.

Chen further said certain policy-related issues, such as quotas, tariff rates and management concerning imports of alcohol, tobacco, pork, chicken meat, rice and animal intestines, will be tackled in the next round of talks scheduled for February.

Minister of Economic Affairs Wang Chih-kang will personally head the ROC delegation to the February round of WTO talks with the US to be held in Washington, D.C., Chen said. "We hope these thorny policy-related issues can be resolved through ministerial-level consultations," he noted.

Prior to Monday's meeting, the ROC delegation paid a courtesy call on Assistant US Trade Representative Robert Cassidy. During the talks, Chen said, both sides have expressed a common desire to conclude bilateral WTO consultations at an early date.
The United States is one of the three WTO members which have yet to finalize bilateral WTO talks with the ROC. The other two are the European Union and Switzerland.

DOC.HEADLINE: ASEAN UNVEILS GRAND VISION 2020 PLAN

TEXT.P: The Association of Southeast Asian Nations (ASEAN) on Monday unveiled its grand vision for the next millennium: a clean and green region where the economies of each member state are integrated even more closely.

Vision 2020 would see a free flow of professionals and other services between countries, governments consulting each other in financial and macroeconomic policies and joint efforts to make ASEAN a leading producer of food, agricultural and forestry products.
Also envisioned is a regional power grid and a Trans-ASEAN Gas and Water Pipeline, The Straits Times reported Tuesday in a dispatch from Kuala Lumpur.

Singapore Prime Minister Goh Chok Tong on Monday hailed the Vision 2020 statement, saying: "Although it may get less attention in the media than the currency crisis, it actually contains many bold ideas for ASEAN integration."
He noted that member countries had agreed to come out with an action agenda to implement the plan quickly. The agenda will be endorsed at the formal ASEAN summit to be held in Vietnam next year.
A key component of the vision statement is titled "ASEAN 2020: Partnership in Dynamic Development."
The leaders have pledged to move towards closer economic integration and to narrow the gap in levels of development among member countries.
They also pledged to:
-- fully implement the ASEAN Free Trade Area;
-- realize the ASEAN Investment Area by 2010 and a free flow of investments by 2020;
-- promote a modern and competitive small and medium enterprises sector in the region;
-- promote the opening up of the financial sector and work closer in money and capital market, tax, insurance and customs matters;
-- and, develop a harmonized trans-ASEAN transportation network and link the planned information highways and multimedia corridors.

The Vision 2020 statement also outlined its goal of being "A Community of Caring Societies." It envisioned a region wherein hunger, malnutrition and poverty would no longer be basic problems and wherein strong families would tend to their children, youth, women and elderly.
The leaders also want a set of agreed rules of behavior to evolve in dealing with drug trafficking, environmental pollution and cross-border crime.

DOC.HEADLINE: AFTA TO BE IMPLEMENTED AHEAD OF 2003 DEADLINE

TEXT.P: The ASEAN Free Trade Area (AFTA) will be implemented earlier than the 2003 deadline to boost trade among regional economies hit by currency crisis.

The leaders of nine ASEAN countries meeting in Kuala Lumpur agreed Monday that they should increase trade among themselves as a way of overcoming "the unprecedented devaluation of their currencies," The Straits Times reported Tuesday in a dispatch from Kuala Lumpur.
They said in a joint statement that "intra-ASEAN trade could not only continue as before but could even be expanded so long as prices remained competitive."

Singapore Prime Minister Goh Chok Tong said in Kuala Lumpur on Monday it was significant that the ASEAN leaders agreed to accelerate the implementation of AFTA and called for greater intra-ASEAN trade and investment, the report by the Singapore-based daily said.
Officials from ASEAN member countries have been asked to study the possibility of establishing methods of payment that can assist each other in conserving foreign exchange holdings.
To boost intraregional trade, the leaders agreed that the implementation of AFTA and the ASEAN Investment Area be accelerated, the report said.
The AFTA agreement aims to achieve free trade in the region no later than the year 2003 in the six core ASEAN countries of Singapore, Indonesia, Thailand, the Philippines, Malaysia and Brunei.
The ASEAN Investment Area is aimed at helping the region compete for foreign investment with large countries like India and mainland China.
Malaysian Prime Minister Mahathir Mohamad said Monday that the decision to increase intra-ASEAN trade is not a form of protectionism, the report said.
He was quoted as saying: "It's not regional nationalism. It's purely because we don't have foreign exchange to buy from outside the region."

Asked if this move would send a wrong signal, he was quoted as replying: "We are responding to a situation beyond our control. When we had money, we bought from outside. We are not forming a trade bloc. This is not regionalism, blocism or whatever."

Rodolfo Severino, Philippine undersecretary for foreign affairs, said that the earlier implementation of AFTA will certainly stimulate growth in the region and would be a signal to the private sector to look at the intra-ASEAN market more closely, the report said.

The ASEAN heads of government also discussed the progress of the Mekong Basin Development Cooperation. They agreed that the proposed plan for the trans-Asian railway from Singapore to Kunming in the Chinese mainland be implemented on a consortium basis involving all ASEAN countries, the report said.
The United States, Japan and countries in Europe will also be invited to help build the railway, it added.

Leaders from the nine member countries also agreed to establish an ASEAN Foundation to develop exchange programs in the area of human resources. A memorandum of understanding on the setting up the foundation was signed Monday by foreign ministers of the member countries.
The nine member countries have pledged to contribute between US$100,000 and US$1 million to the foundation, the report said. Malaysia will give M$1.5 million, it added.

DOC.HEADLINE: SHARE PRICES DOWN ON TAIEX

TEXT.P: Share prices ended 0.6 percent lower on the local stock market Tuesday, as uncertainty remained in effect and investors reduced their holdings, dealers said.
The Taiwan Stock Exchange (TAIEX) weighted price index lost 47.84 points to close at 8,193.65, after trading began at the day's high of 8,341.35.
Losers outnumbered gainers 258 to 133, with 70 shares remaining unchanged.
A total of 2.31 billion shares changed hands on a market turnover of NT$107.69 billion (US$3.37 billion).

Among eight stock categories, electrical engineering shares suffered the biggest fall with a 1.2 percent decline, followed by a 0.7 percent drop in textile stocks, 0.6 percent fall in financial issues, and 0.3 percent decline in both cement stocks and plastic and chemical shares.
Foodstuff and paper-making issues appeared as gainers, each with a 0.5 percent increase, while construction shares posted a rise of 0.4 percent.

The companies with the 10 largest turnovers were: Ever Fortune, Taiwan Styrene Monomer, China Steel, ACER, Formosa Chemical & Fiber, Hualon-Teijran, United Micro Electronics, Union Petrochemical, Wan Yu Paper, and Tainan Spinning.

DOC.HEADLINE: BAYER'S CASE DEPENDS ON PROVINCIAL ASSEMBLY: SOONG

TEXT.P: Taiwan Provincial Governor James Soong said on Tuesday that the Taiwan Provincial Assembly will have the final say on the fate of a NT$49 billion investment plan by Germany's Bayer Group in central Taichung County.

Soong said the Taiwan Provincial Government, in conjunction with central government policy and expert opinion, has approved Bayer's application to lease a plot of provincial government-owned land near Taichung Harbor for construction of the projected plant.

As the investment plan is of major importance to the central government, Soong said it is natural that the provincial government will provide support and cooperation for the case, but added that the Taiwan Provincial Assembly, the central government and the Taichung County authorities will have the final say on the issue.

He expressed the hope that the Taiwan Provincial Assembly, as a organ which reflects public opinion, can strike a balance between the issues of economic development and environmental protection, because its decision on the Bayer case will not only have an impact on Taiwan's economic development, but also on Taiwan's promise to cooperate with the international community.

Soong also expressed his disapproval of the insistence of the Democratic Progressive Party (DPP's) Liao Yung-lai, the newly elected Taichung County magistrate, on holding a public referendum to decide the fate of the Bayer investment plan.
"If every issue must be decided by a referendum, then what are public opinion organizations for?" he asked, pointing out that holding a referendum is not the only means of assessing public opinion.

Bayer's plan to build a plant to produce toluene di-isocyanate near Taichung Harbor has encountered strong opposition from local residents who fear that the plant will cause heavy pollution, and Liao has insisted on holding a public referendum to decide whether or not Bayer can continue with the project.
The Taiwan Provincial Assembly is scheduled to screen the investment project later this week.

DOC.HEADLINE: TAIWAN DOLLAR REACHES TEN-YEAR LOW

TEXT.P: The US dollar rose NT$0.074 against the New Taiwan dollar on the Taipei foreign exchange market on Tuesday, closing at NT$32.82 and marking a 10-year low for the Taiwan currency unit.
Local dealers said the fact that most East Asian countries are still suffering from currency devaluations is the principal reason for the drop in Taiwan's currency.

Meanwhile, an assessment revealing that South Korea is unable to halt the devaluation of the won is also partly to blame for the NT dollar's decline, the dealers said, adding that the coming days might see the local currency fall even further, to NT$33 against the US dollar.
The greenback opened at 32.74, and was traded between 32.689 and 32.95. Interbank US dollar trading reached US$424 million.

DOC.HEADLINE: DECEASED TYCOON WAITS ON ICE WHILE FAMILY FIGHTS OVER CASH

TEXT.P: Deceased fruit tycoon Chen Cha-mou, who died on Aug. 9, 1993, has still not received a proper burial or cremation, it was discovered recently.

Chen, who reportedly left a multi-billion dollar estate, has been kept on ice at his home in Chinchou Street in downtown Taipei for four years and four months as a result of discrepancies among his children over the burial site, as well as a dispute over the distribution of his wealth.

During a city council plenary session on Tuesday, Taipei city councilors Lin Jui-tu and Kang Shui-mu inquired to city government authorities in charge of funeral and burial affairs whether or not Chen's offspring have violated any regulations by neglecting their late father's remains for so many years.

Wu Er-min, director of the Taipei City Funeral and Burial Affairs Department, said that according to existing statutes, Chen's children have not violated any regulations, adding that officials can at best advise the Chen family to handle the burial as quickly as possible.
He also suggested that the city government revise relevant burial regulations, in order to prevent similar situations from developing in the future.

Chen has not been buried because his eldest and third sons disagree over the site of their father's burial. The eldest insists that the old man be buried along with their mother on Yangmingshan in suburban Taipei, while the third son claims that he must be buried on Mt. Kuanyin, near the Tamsui River, saying that only by resting there will the old man bless his offspring.
Meanwhile, the family, including three sons, two daughters and several daughters-in-law have been engaged in a dog-fight over his legacy from within one year of his death.

Members of the family have filed several lawsuits against each other since the second year of Chen's death. The suits involve the disappearance of stocks and securities worth several billion NT dollars, and the disappearance of time deposit certificates and cash worth over NT$1 billion earned from the sale of 12 tracts of land in suburban Taipei.

DOC.HEADLINE: MOST MAINLAND-BASED TAIWAN FIRMS WISH TO SHIFT OPERATIONS: POLL

TEXT.P: More than half of Taiwan businesses with operations in mainland China would like the ROC government to help them shift their operations to other countries, according to a report published on Tuesday in the mass-circulation evening newspaper the China Times Express.

The report, citing the results of a survey carried out by the Taipei Managers and Executives Association, shows that 54.2 percent of Taiwan businesses currently operating on the mainland would like the government to help them transfer their operations to other countries and that they would also like to see it help set up banks on the mainland and train professional talent to be stationed there.

M.C. Chen, chairman of the association, was quoted by the report as attributing the results of the survey to the increasing lack of confidence of Taiwan firms in mainland China's investment climate since Hong Kong's return to Beijing rule in July.

As Southeast Asia sinks further into the financial morass, Chen suggested that Taiwan businesses slow down their investment on the mainland and consider shifting their operations to other countries, especially because the mainland Chinese renminbi and the Hong Kong dollar are facing strong pressure of devaluation, which will result in greater business risk and financial demands, according to the report.

Chen was cited as pointing out that although Taiwan and mainland China are likely to resume talks next year, the two sides remain divided on several issues of major concern, casting a shadow over the business community's hope that cross-strait economic exchanges will soon start warming up.

DOC.HEADLINE: GREECE ASKS ITALY TO HELP HANDLE VISA SERVICES FOR ROC NATIONALS
DOC.DATELINE: Rome, Dec. 15 (CNA) (By Oscar Chung and Sofia Wu)

TEXT.P: The Italian Ministry of Foreign Affairs said on Monday it is studying the feasibility of handling visa-related services in Taipei for Republic of China nationals intending to visit Greece.
"Greece has expressed its hope that our representative office in Taipei would help handle visa services for ROC nationals to save their time," an Italian Foreign Ministry official said.
As such a request involves many technical problems, the official said, relevant Italian authorities are still mulling the issue.

Greece currently offers landing visas to ROC nationals. However, the country has decided to stop issuing landing visas after it begins to implement the Schengen Agreement on Jan. 1, 1998. For the convenience of ROC passport holders, Greece has approached Italy for assistance in issuing Schengen visas to Greece-bound ROC travelers.
According to the Schengen Agreement, a person who has obtained a visa from any of the Schengen signatories can travel to any other member country.

An official with the ROC's representative office in Rome said Greece's move to seek Italian assistance is a good-will gesture to the ROC. "It will be far more convenient for ROC nationals to apply for visas to Greece in Taipei than at the airport of Athens," he noted, adding it usually takes at least three hours or even seven hours to get a landing visa at the Athens International Airport.

The Italian representative office in Taipei currently receives more than 120,000 visa applications from ROC nationals a year. That means the office has to process 600 applications on every work day. It remains unclear whether the Italian office has enough manpower to help Greece handle visa applications from prospective ROC visitors.

DOC.HEADLINE: MILITARY MEANS CANNOT RESOLVE CROSS-STRAIT ISSUE: LIEN

TEXT.P: Mainland China's show of force in the Taiwan Strait in the run-up to the Republic of China's first direct presidential election last year was a great mistake, Vice President Lien Chan said in an exclusive interview with CNA on Tuesday.
Noting that cross-strait competition involves a choice of way of life and related political, social and economic systems, Lien said military means cannot resolve cross-strait issues.

"It was regretful that mainland China conducted missile tests and menacing war games in waters near Taiwan in the run-up to the ROC's historic presidential election on March 23, 1996," the vice president said.

Lien said he earnestly hopes the two sides of the Taiwan Strait will work together to create a peaceful environment for the cultivation of rapprochement and the avoidance of any possible conflicts in the region.
Lien, who finished his concurrent duty as premier in late August, said the ROC's current military policy is to establish an effective deterrent force to safeguard its national security.
"We have adopted a strategy for effective deterrence and have no intention of employing military means to resolve cross-strait issues," the scholar-turned politician stressed.

Lien went on to say that mainland China has continued to increase its military budget and beef up its combat capability in recent years. "Mainland China's military build-up has exerted pressure on many neighboring countries, and this was a major factor that prompted Japan and the United States to amend their defense cooperation guidelines in order to revamp their security alliance," he observed.

Touching on the maintenance of peace and stability in the Asia-Pacific region, Lien said a collective mechanism should be established in the region to safeguard regional security, peace and prosperity.

Lien further said the best collective security arrangement would be one which includes all the countries of the Asia-Pacific under a framework which is not targeted at any particular hypothetical enemy.

DOC.HEADLINE: TAIWAN YOUTH CORPS TO SERVE IN FOREIGN COUNTRIES

TEXT.P: The youth corps of Taiwan will leave for Swaziland, Malawi, Costa Rica, Honduras, and other countries in March to provide services under the sponsorship of Kaohsiung-based International Cooperation and Development Foundation.
The China Youth Corps' branch office in Kaohsiung will recruit college graduates for the service program on behalf of the foundation.

An official of the foundation said college graduates, who are able to speak either English or Spanish and have experience in teaching Chinese, teaching computer science, promoting the business of small-and-medium enterprises, improving farm life, or job training, are welcome to join the youth service program.
The youth corps of Taiwan is similar to the Peace Corps of the United States in the nature of their service, the foundation official said. (by Ed Hsieh)

DOC.HEADLINE: TAIWAN'S FOREIGN TRADE CONTINUES TO GROW

TEXT.P: Taiwan's foreign trade continued to grow substantially in the first 11 months of this year, with export amounting to US$111.57 billion and import to US$103.84 billion, according to statistics released by the Ministry of Finance.
Trade surplus totaled US$7.73 billion in the period, a reduction of 38 percent from a year earlier, the statistics showed.
Taiwan's export and import trade are expected to expand next year, because of the devaluation of Taiwan currency and increases in domestic demand, said an official of the ministry.

Taiwan's surplus in trade with Hong Kong reached US$24.08 billion during the 11-month period, an increase of US$1.63 billion over a year ago. The surplus with the United States totaled US$6.08 billion, a reduction of US$90 million from the first 11 months of 1996.
However, during the 11-month period Taiwan suffered a deficit of US$15.57 billion in trade with Japan, an increase of US$2.87 billion from a year earlier.

Export from Taiwan in November amounted to US$11.41 billion, a hike of 11 percent over the same month of last year. Import totaled US$10.15 billion, an increase of 12.8 percent. Trade surplus in the month totaled US$1.26 billion, a reduction of 1.2 percent from the same month of last year.

Export in November exceeded the US$11 billion mark for the first time, indicating that the devaluation of the Taiwan currency has helped sharpen the competition edge of the country in the world market, the official said. (by Ed Hsieh)

DOC.HEADLINE: JUSTICE MINISTER PLEDGES TO PROTECT OFFICIALS FROM GANGSTERS

TEXT.P: ROC Minister of Justice Liao Cheng-hao is shocked and angered at reports that government officials in eastern Taiwan's Hualien County have been threatened by underground elements for carrying out their legal duties.
Liao said here on Tuesday that he has personally instructed law enforcement officials in Hualien to protect government officials exercising their powers without fear or favor.

Local news reports on Monday said that Tu Li-hua, director of the Agriculture Bureau and Chen Chin-li, acting director of the Environmental Protection Bureau, both under the Hualien County Government, have been threatened for imposing fines on individuals who have been illegally dumping waste soil in a local harbor.
Liao said that his ministry is taking the threats seriously and pledged to safeguard government employees' exercising their power according to the law.

To meet pledges he made during a trip to Hualien in August that the government will do its utmost to protect the county -- the only Taiwan county reported to be free of underground influence at that time -- the minister said that local prosecutors have been instructed to act in conjunction with the police to protect Tu and Chen, who happen to be man and wife, and try to track down the gangsters who issued the threats.

DOC.HEADLINE: ACTIVE SHORT-WING TRADING ON TAIWAN STOCK MARKET

TEXT.P: Short-wing trading on the Taiwan stock market appeared quiet vigorous over the past 11 months compared with the performance of the major international markets' stock dealings over the same period.

According to the latest official statistics, Taiwan saw each share change hands an average of 3.36 times in the local market during the period from January to November, 1.12 times more than the year-earlier level.
This figure is also higher than those of most major stock markets worldwide, officials of the Directorate General of Budget, Accounting and Statistics (DGBAS) said on Tuesday.

In terms of turnover, the DGBAS statistics show that a total of NT$34 trillion (about US$1.06 trillion) turnover volume emerged in the Taiwan stock exchange in the January-November period, marking a 1.9-times increase in comparison with the year-earlier level.
Over-the-counter turnover hit NT$2.2 trillion (US$68.75 billion) during the 11-month period, 5.6 times more than last year.

DOC.HEADLINE: TAIWAN'S SHORTEST ADULT WANTS TO MEET PRESIDENT

TEXT.P: She stands 78 centimeters high, weighs 28 kilograms, and she is currently the shortest adult in Taiwan.
Tsai Mei-ling, 33, a native of Chingshui, Taichung County, is reported by the Taiwan Museum of the Guinness World of Records to be the shortest adult in Taiwan.
Tsai's younger sister, Tsai Shu-hui, 31, is also a dwarf, but at 86 cm, is taller than her sister.
According to their mother and their doctors, there is no history of dwarfism in the Tsai family and the sisters are victims of a brittle-bone condition caused by their inability to absorb calcium.
Tsai Mei-ling, whose condition prevents her from walking or standing, sits on a low armchair on which she carries out all her daily routines, including eating and bathing.

Despite her handicap, she is a carefree girl and an industrious worker. At the age of nine, Tsai went to work in a textile factory where she stayed for 15 years until the factory relocated to mainland China.

Tsai has two greatest wishes. One is to meet President Lee Teng-hui in person, so she can tell the president how the handicapped fare in Taiwan, and the other is to have an automated wheelchair so she can have more freedom of movement.

Tsai is not the shortest woman in the world. That title currently belongs to Madge Bester, who is only 65 centimeters tall. Bester, 34, a South African national, is currently resident at the Taiwan Museum of the Guinness World of Records on a six-month visiting program.
The museum, located in downtown Taichung City, is one of seven Guinness museums around the world.

DOC.HEADLINE: TAIWAN TO BECOME ASIA'S SILICON VALLEY IN THREE YEARS: CEPD

TEXT.P: Output from Taiwan's information technology (IT) industry is expected to make up 40 percent of the island's overall production in three years, making the Republic of China the "Silicon Valley" of Asia, the Cabinet-level Council for Economic Planning and Development (CEPD) reported on Tuesday.

With its IT industry continuing to flourish, CEPD officials said, Taiwan will join the ranks of the developed countries by the beginning of the 21st century, dubbed the "century of information revolution."

In October alone, Taiwan received export orders for IT products worth US$1.88 million, marking a single-month record in electronics sales in Taiwan. As of the end of October, nine of Taiwan's IT products ranked first place in production value in the world.
CEPD officials attributed the Taiwan IT industry's outstanding performance to the efficient vertical and horizontal sharing of labor among the up- mid- and down-stream sectors of the industry.
In 1996, the information and electronic industry contributed 34.1 percent of Taiwan's overall industrial production, and that figure is expected to shoot up to 40 percent in 2000.

The workforce in the IT industry, which is capital- and technology-intensive, has seen an annual growth rate of 3.4 percent since 1992, as compared with an average of -5 percent in the textiles industry, which is labor-intensive, CEPD officials noted.

With the Hsinchu Science-based Industrial Park, which is currently Taiwan's "Silicon Valley," in the north, the start of construction of the Tainan Science-based Industrial Park in the south, and plans to begin development of a third science park in Miaoli, central Taiwan in 1999, Taiwan's ambition of becoming a sci-tech island is gradually materializing, the officials added.

DOC.HEADLINE: SOUTH AFRICAN DIPLOMAT GIVES BIBLE AND XMAS GIFTS TO FORMER CAPTOR

TEXT.P: The outgoing South African Military Attache and his wife visited their former captor at a local court on Tuesday, where they presented him with a Bible and other Christmas gifts.
Anne and McGill Alexander met with Chen Chin-hsing at the Panchiao District Court. They encouraged Chen to seek God's forgiveness and to turn over a new leaf.
Anne, McGill, their two children and a baby in their care were taken hostage by Chen in their Taipei residence on Nov. 18.
Chen, a notorious fugitive wanted for multiple killings, rapes and kidnappings, held police at bay and demanded the airing of his grievances through the mass media.
McGill and his elder daughter were shot and wounded by Chen during the ordeal, which ended the next day when Chen surrendered to police.
McGill, who is expected to leave Taipei after Pretoria closes its ROC embassy by the end of the month, bade farewell to Chen, for whom the prosecutor is seeking four death sentences.
Chen, wearing leg irons, met with the Alexanders at the office of the president of the Panchiao District Court, where the Alexanders offered their blessings to Chen through an interpreter.

Chen, who showed no emotion during the meeting, was remanded in custody after the meeting, while the Alexanders gave an informal, unsigned deposition to the prosecutor, who was eager to get the Alexanders' testimony before their departure from Taiwan.
As a diplomat, McGill falls outside ROC jurisdiction and is not supposed to answer local subpoenas. However, he agreed to give a personal account of the kidnapping drama to the court.
The prosecutor said the deposition corroborated Chen's claims that he didn't intend to hurt the Alexanders.

DOC.HEADLINE: LIEN SEES RESUMPTION OF CROSS-STRAIT DIALOGUE NEXT YEAR (I)

TEXT.P: Vice President Lien Chan said on Tuesday that he foresees the resumption of cross-strait dialogue sometime next year.
In an exclusive interview with CNA at his office, Lien said that he believes Beijing is now ready for the dialogue with Taipei it suspended in the summer of 1995.
"I am confident that we will resume the long-awaited talks next year," said the vice president, who relinquished his concurrent office as premier on September 1. He did not set a time.

Beijing suspended scheduled talks between its Association for Relations across the Taiwasn Strait (ARATS) and Taiwan's Straits Exchange Foundation (SEF) in the summer of 1995 to vent its anger at President Lee Teng-hui's landmark visit to the United States.
He said the talks should focus mainly on technical issues arising from the increasing unofficial exchanges across the Taiwan Strait.
"However," Lien said, "non-technical (political) issues can also be pondered."

With important internal issues settled, Beijing is now able to shift more of its attention to relations with Taiwan, repeatedly calling on Taipei to enter into "political negotaitions." Chief among the questions were Beijing's takeover of Hong Kong on July 1, the 15th Chinese Communist Party National Congress and President Jiang Zemin's visit to the United States in October.

On reginal security, Lien said Beijing's massive military buildup, as evidenced by its huge defense spending, has been viewed with grave concern by its neighbors, Japan in particular. Tokyo has countered with a new set of defense guidelines, under which Japan is obliged to provide military facilities and necessary noncombat assistance for the United States to cope with contingencies in Asia.
The revised US-Japan mutual defense arrangements came after Beijing conducted war games and test-fired missiles into the Taiwan Strait in 1996.

In the face of the new threat, Lien said, the Republic of China on Taiwan has improved its deterrent forces to effectively curb Beijing's possible military adventurism, but he prefers a new collective security system to safeguard peace in the region.

Lien stressed that the SEF and ARATS should use the existing channels of dialogue, although the "level" of talks should be upgraded step by step. "We do not wish to open new channels of dialogue," he said, "and we cannot expect high-level meetings (as proposed by Beijing) to solve the long-standing, thorny issues at one time."
"War cannot solve the cross-strait issue," Lien pointed out. "The issue is one of differences in political and economic systems as well as ways of life," he said.

"It was also a big mistake for Beijing to conduct war games and launch missiles in an attempt to intimidate the people of Taiwan in the run-up to the country's first popular presidential election in March last year," Lien pointed out.

The vice president said that he will continue to travel abroad. "It's very natural for government leaders to go abroad to promote friendship and understanding with friendly countries," he pointed out.
"Beijing's allegations that such trips are aimed at promoting either `two Chinas' or `one China, one Taiwan' are totally groundless," he said.
During the past few years, Lien paid visits to Austria, Hungary, the Czech Republic, the Dominican Republic, Ukraine, Nicaragua, the Vatican, Ireland and Iceland. (more)

DOC.HEADLINE: LIEN SEES RESUMPTION OF DIALOGUE (II)

TEXT.P: Commenting on communist China's moves to press South Africa for an earlier-than-scheduled severance of ties with the Republic of China on Taiwan, Lien said it fully reflects nothing but Beijing's bigoted narrow-mindedness, making it impossible for the two sides of the Taiwan Strait to achieve what he termed a "win-win" situation in the near future. Taipei does not see its diplomacy vis-a-vis Beijing as a "zero sum" game. Lien believes both sides are capable of winning in the diplomatic arena.

South African President Nelson Mandela announced on Nov. 27 last year that Pretoria will shift its diplomatic recognition from Taipei to Beijing from Jan. 1, 1998. Taipei and Pretoria have since conducted several rounds of negotiations to work out a framework for future bilateral ties.
Lien flatly ruled out the possibility that the Republic of China on Taiwan might take the initiative and sever ties with South Africa before Dec. 31.

Taiwan is safe from the financial turmoil which has embroiled many newly industrialized economies in Asia, including Thailand, Indonesia and South Korea, Lien declared. The island's economic fundamentals are sound: it has no foreign debts, holds foreign exchange reserves of well over US$85 billion, with its national economy growing more than five per cent per annum.
He attributed Taiwan's success to the enforcement of sound government policies over the past years.

Lien said that Taipei is willing to provide relief for its financially stricken neighbors. But, he added, the relief must be arranged by world organizations, like the International Monetary Fund and the Asian Development Bank, rather than on a nation-to-nation basis.

He took to task Liao Yung-lai, Taichung magistrate-elect of the Democratic Progressive Party (DPP), for calling a referendum to decide the fate of an approved NT$49 billion (US$1.5 billion) investment project by Germany's Bayer conglomerate in that county.
Such a move, Lien said, will confuse foreign investors and gravely hinder investment from aboard, which is of very great importance to the island.

Defending Taipei's "go-slow" mainland investment policy, Lien said it aims only to limit high-tech projects worth over NT$50 million (US$1.53 million) each. "In fact, we are actively promoting cross-strait economic exchanges on a step-by-step basis," he declared.

He also predicted a sharp depreciation of the renminpi next summer. Asia's liquidation crisis and a decline in foreign investment will force Beijing to depreciate its currency, he said. "Taiwan investors," he cautioned, "should seek to purchase currencies other than the renminpi as a hedge."

On the possibility that he may run with Taiwan Governor James Soong on the same ticket in the 2000 presidential election, Lien said it is too early to talk about the question now. Many changes may occur in the next two years to make any talk to that possibility futile at present, he added.

DOC.HEADLINE: LAW AMENDED TO STOP AIRPLANE SIT-INS

TEXT.P: The use of on-board sit-ins as a form of protest by air passengers against perceived maltreatment by airlines has been misused to such an extent that the Taiwan legislature has amended relevant laws to impose restrictions against this type of behavior.

The Legislative Yuan on Tuesday passed the third reading of an amendment to the Civil Aeronautic Law which stipulates that the Civil Aeronautics Administration (CAA) should help settle passenger disputes.
Accordingly, the institution will form a commission based on the new law to take charge of managing complaints related to flight delays.
The amended law also rules that if a sit-in protest occurs despite official mediation, law enforcement personnel stationed at the airport can be mobilized to ensure passengers disembark.

The reformed law also specifies a ceiling for compensation, pointing out that the amount of compensation airlines should be held liable for relating to mistakes resulting in delays should be tied to ticket prices.
Civil aviation businesses on the island welcomed the amendment, and pledged their willingness to deal with passenger complaints through communication rather than through legal procedures.
In recent years, there have been many instances of Taiwan air travelers refusing to disembark from commercial flights because of delays or perceived poor service.

The most series of incidents occurred in February, when heavy fog disrupted flight schedules at Chiang Kai-shek International Airport in northern Taoyuan County. Several sit-ins occurred, prompting the authorities to take legislative steps to resolve a problem which was harming Taiwan's international image.

The amended regulations also state that any passenger who makes bomb threats or who otherwise makes false reports which might affect flight safety, will face a maximum jail term of three years, or a maximum fine of NT$1 million (US$31,250).
Any passenger whose behavior actually endangers flight safety, will face a jail term of 3-10 years.

DOC.HEADLINE: ROC-INDONESIAN ENERGY MEETING TO BE HELD

TEXT.P: The annual ministerial-level energy meeting between the Republic of China and Indonesia is scheduled to open here on Dec. 22, the Ministry of Economic Affairs (MOEA) said on Tuesday.
ROC Economics Minister Wang Chih-kang and Indonesian Energy Minister I.B. Sudjana will jointly preside over the opening ceremony.

A 28-member ROC delegation composed of officials from the MOEA, the Ministry of Foreign Affairs, the Atomic Energy Council, and the state-run Chinese Petroleum Corp. and Taiwan Power Company (Taipower) will take part in the meeting with a 23-member Indonesian delegation to discuss issues related to the development of electrical power, coal mines and natural gas resources.

Taipower and its Indonesian counterpart are slated to sign a memorandum of understanding on bilateral exchanges of personnel, management information and energy development programs during the meeting.

The annual conference has been held alternately in Taiwan and Indonesia since 1990, providing a regular channel of dialogue for the two countries to hold bilateral consultations on energy development and related issues.

Taiwan maintains close economic relations with Indonesia, an official with the Atomic Energy Council said, pointing out that Taiwan imported 7.6 million barrels of crude oil from that country in 1996 and that the figure for the first nine months of this year has already amounted to 8.8 million barrels, up 48 percent from the same period of 1996.
