DOC.HEADLINE: TAIWAN TO JOIN AIRBUS NEW PLANE DEVELOPMENT PROJECTS

TEXT.P: South Korea's recent financial crisis has brought a new opportunity to Taiwan's fledgling aerospace industry, as a major French commercial aircraft manufacturer has decided to cooperate with Taiwan instead of cash-hungry South Korea to develop new aircraft models.

Latecoere Co., France's third-largest commercial airliner manufacturer, signed a memorandum of understanding with the Republic of China's Ministry of Economic Affairs (MOEA) on Tuesday expressing its intention to form strategic alliances with Taiwan firms for the joint development of new passenger planes.

The preliminary cooperative agreement was signed at Latecoere headquarters in the southern French city of Toulouse on Tuesday when an ROC delegation, headed by Vice Economics Minister Yin Chi-ming, visited the company.

Under the accord, Taiwan's state-run Aerospace Industry Development Corp. (AIDC) will join forces with Latecoere in participating in Airbus Industrie Group's new commercial aircraft development project.

Airbus, the world's second-largest commercial airliner manufacturer after Boeing Co., and its subsidiaries such as AIR and ATR, are planning to develop A340-500 and A340-600 wide-body jumbo jets as well as several new models of regional jets.

Latecoere is one of Airbus' major contractors, specializing in producing fuselages. It originally planned to cooperate with major South Korean aerospace firms in the new Airbus development projects, but the outbreak of a financial crisis in South Korea early this year has left many of its large conglomerates or chaebols plagued by a dire shortage of cash. Against this backdrop, Latecoere decided to switch to Taiwan to seek possible joint-venture partners.

Yin said Taiwan so far only has experience in cooperating with American aerospace companies. "By cooperating with Latecoere, we'll be able to gain easier access to Europe's aerospace technology," he noted.

Latecoere is also the European Union's first commercial aircraft manufacturer to form cooperative ties with Taiwan. "The partnership is expected to help open new markets for our aerospace makers," said David Chu, director of the MOEA's Committee for Aviation and Space Industry Development (CASID), who is accompanying Yin in France.

Meanwhile, the CASID has also signed a preliminary industrial cooperation pact with the Matra Group's defense industry division. The accord was inked by Yin and Matra Chairman C.O. Thomas at Matra headquarters on Monday.

Under the terms of the accord, Matra promises to transfer to private Taiwan companies technical know-how needed to produce spare parts and components for Mirage 2000-5 jet fighters in order to help upgrade Taiwan's aerospace technology.

Yin said Matra is quite strong in the fields of remote control, space communications and automated technology. Some 30 percent of the Mirage fighter's core parts and components are supplied by Matra. "Matra has finally agreed to cooperate with Taiwan companies in manufacturing Mirage parts and components only after many years of difficult negotiations," Yin said.
Taiwan has ordered 60 Mirage 2000-5s from France as part of its efforts to beef up its air defense capabilities. More than 10 Mirages have already been delivered.

Another French Mirage contractor, CSF Group, which provides avionics systems, has also expressed interest in developing cooperative ties with Taiwan firms. If a cooperative deal is struck, Yin said, CSF will be able to provide Taiwan with expertise for repair and maintenance of remote control devices, radar, aviation guidance equipment and other electronics parts.
However, Yin added: "Further discussion is needed before the two sides can finalize an accord."

DOC.HEADLINE: HONG KONG'S TUNG CHEE HWA MOVES OFFICE
DOC.DATELINE: Hong Kong, Dec. 17 (CNA) (By Wu Shean-shen & Eva Chen)

TEXT.P: Tung Chee Hwa, chief executive of the Hong Kong Special Administrative Region (HKSAR) of mainland China, on Tuesday formally began working at his new office located in the HKSAR's government headquarters complex.
His old office was located in the Asia-Pacific Financial Center, and Tung remarked that working with other civil servants in the new office will raise work efficiency.
Tung's 900 square-foot office, which he shares with more than 40 working staff, occupies what used to be the offices of Hong Kong's former chief secretary and financial secretary.
The HKSAR security department is in the process of constructing a three-meter-high iron security fence around the building and this is expected to be finished by the end of this month.

DOC.HEADLINE: SHARE PRICES RISE ON TAIEX

TEXT.P: Share prices closed 1.7 percent higher on the local stock market on Wednesday, a rise attributed by stock brokers to profitable banking incentives.

The dealers indicated that the government's move to lower bank reserves, speed up the opening of new types of trust funds, and drop the current ceiling of bank investments in the stock market inspired opportunists to step up purchases.
The Taiwan Stock Exchange (TAIEX) weighted price index rebounded to the trading day's high of 8,347.2 points, showing bright growth of 153.55 points.
The bourse opened at 8,297.69, dropping at one point to a low of 8,241.69.
Gainers surpassed losers 364 to 59, with 49 shares unchanged.
A total of 2.46 billion shares changed hands on a market turnover of NT$113.49 billion (US$3.55 billion).
Eight major stock categories all enjoyed gains, with the largest rise -- 3.9 percent -- in paper and pulp issues.

Banking shares posted a gain of 3.5 percent, while textile stocks followed with 1.7 percent growth, foodstuff issues with 1.5 percent, cement shares with 1.4 percent, plastic and chemical issues with 1.2 percent, electrical engineering stocks with 1.1 percent, and construction issues with 0.8 percent.

The companies with the 10 largest turnovers were: Ever Fortune; BES Engineering, Shin Kong Life Insurance, Chang Hwa Bank, Taiwan Semiconductor Manufacturing, Formosa Plastic, RITEK, ACER, Cathay Life Ins., and Formosa Chemical and Fiber.

DOC.HEADLINE: HONG KONG TYCOON DETAINED ON BRIBERY CHARGES

TEXT.P: Hong Kong business tycoon Lim Por-yen was detained Wednesday morning by the Taipei District Prosecutors' Office on charges of bribery.

Lim, chairman of Asia Television (ATV) and Lai Sun Development of Hong Kong, was taken into custody on charges of bribing Taipei county government officials with offers of some NT$300 million (US$9.3 million).

Lim was arrested on Tuesday at Chiang Kai-shek international airport where he was departing for Hong Kong after visiting Taipei for several days, during which he attended the Golden Horse movie awards presentation ceremony on Saturday.

According to chief prosecutor Hsueh Wei-ping, evidence shows that Lim offered some NT$300 million to Taipei county government officials so that his Sanshia-based Dollar Textile manufacturing company -- occupying a tract of several hectares -- could be rezoned to be included in an area earmarked for development for a proposed National Taipei University.

Hsueh pointed out that Chuang Yu-kun, director of the Taipei County Land Administration Bureau, who was detained earlier this month for involvement in another land rezoning scandal, received about NT$100 million from Lim for helping to rezone Lim's factory from cheap industrial land into commercial and residential land.
The other NT$200 million, according to Hsueh, was believed to have been distributed to at least three other county officials, also as bribes for the rezoning project.

In addition to illegal rezoning, Chuang and the Taipei County officials were also accused by prosecutors of excessively assessing Lim's land and factory facilities, enabling him to receive several billion NT dollars in cash compensation from the government under a land acquisition program for the university development plan.
The National Taipei University development plan has been on the drawing board for eight years, held up by land acquisition problems and disputes over land acquisition compensation.

The university, to be located on a tract of 55 hectares in Sanshia in the south of Taipei County, is expected to generate business opportunities worth NT$1.2 billion per year in the Sanshia, Shulin and Tucheng regions after it is completed.
The octogenarian Lim is also believed to have bigger wealth other than the reported multi-billion dollar assets in his Lai Sun Group and three other Hong Kong listed companies.
Beginning with garment factories in Hong Kong in the 1950s, Lim expanded his operations to the real estate business in the 1970s. In the 1980s, he bought out ATV, to become an entertainment tycoon.

Lim has operated at least two weaving plants, including Dollar Textile, in Taiwan. But the plants ceased production in recent years after Lim relocated their manufacturing facilities to mainland China.

DOC.HEADLINE: AIDS PATIENTS LEGALLY PROHIBITED FROM DONATING BLOOD

TEXT.P: Taiwan carriers of the AIDS-causing HIV virus will be legally prohibited from donating blood in order to protect the health of people who receive blood transfusions, according to the newly-passed AIDS Prevention Law.

The revised AIDS Prevention Law, which cleared the legislature floor on Tuesday, stipulates that HIV carriers or AIDS patients who make blood donations in an attempt to have their blood checked, will face jail terms of up to seven years as punishment for disregarding the health and safety of others, even if the tainted blood has not been administered.

Despite the fact that the non-profit Chunghua Blood Foundation has repeatedly announced that AIDS patients and HIV carriers are forbidden to donate blood, some people in this group have continued to give blood to blood centers, risking the health of other, otherwise healthy people, a foundation official said.

AIDS patients and HIV carriers are also prohibited from having sex or sharing syringes and needles with other people without telling the truth about their deadly disease. Those caught doing so will also risk up to seven years behind bars.

The revised AIDS Prevention Law stipulates that the state-run Central Health Insurance Bureau will be responsible for checkups and treatment of the island's AIDS patients and that deceased AIDS victims will have to be cremated instead of buried. It also states that AIDS patients should receive equal treatment to healthy people, and that they are entitled to equal opportunities in schooling, medical care, and employment.

Meanwhile, AIDS screening work conducted by seven medical centers islandwide last year found that 2 percent, or 25 out of 938 people in the group categorized as being at high-risk of contracting the disease were confirmed to have been unknowingly infected. The high-risk group included homosexuals, heterosexuals, drug abusers, family members of AIDS patients, prostitutes, and medical personnel.
Among the group, heterosexuals were found to be most at risk of contracting AIDS, as some 95 percent of the newly-diagnosed AIDS patients were heterosexuals.

DOC.HEADLINE: ROC-SWEDISH TIES GROWING STEADILY

TEXT.P: Substantive relations between the Republic of China and Sweden have continued to grow steadily over the past decade, the de facto ROC ambassador to the Scandinavian country said on Wednesday.

Lu Ping-yen, head of the Taipei Mission in Sweden, told a Legislative Yuan committee meeting that although the Swedish authorities are generally friendly toward Taiwan, there is still much the ROC can do to reinforce bilateral ties.

As many Swedish companies are scrambling to enter the vast mainland Chinese market, Lu said, Taiwan must step up efforts to reinforce trade and economic cooperation with Sweden by increasing its investments there.

In the face of mainland China's aggressive diplomatic offensive, Lu said he hopes more Taiwan business people will travel to Sweden to explore trade and joint-venture opportunities to help cement two-way ties.

Lu, who returned to Taipei earlier this week for home consultations, said commercial, cultural and tourist exchanges between the ROC and Sweden have grown steadily since the two countries exchanged representative offices several years ago. Sweden has been directly issuing visas in Taipei to prospective ROC visitors since November 1993.
Four Swedish parliamentary delegations have visited Taiwan over the past year, and three ROC Legislative Yuan missions also paid visits to Sweden this summer, Lu said.

Moreover, the Swedish parliament formally set up a pro-Taiwan task force on Nov. 26, comprised of more than 60 Swedish parliamentarians. Lu said pro-Taiwan Swedish lawmakers have so far introduced five bills aimed at boosting cooperation with Taiwan in various fields.

Lu said the ROC and Sweden have held 13 economic cooperation conferences and five transportation-related meetings over the past few years. High-ranking economic officials have also exchanged frequent visits.

Bilateral trade between Taiwan and Sweden amounted to US$1.2 billion in 1996, with Taiwan incurring a trade deficit of about US$400 million. Major Taiwan exports to Sweden included computers and peripherals, communications equipment, bolts and screws, and bicycles, while automobiles, paper products, telecommunications equipment, machinery and steel products formed the bulk of Swedish exports to Taiwan. Lu said ROC-Swedish trade is expected to grow by 9 percent this year.

Sweden has maintained full diplomatic ties with mainland China since May 1950. Their trade volume surpassed ROC-Swedish trade for the first time in 1992. By 1996, their annual trade had already hit US$1.78 billion, with Sweden posting a surplus of about US$900 million.

Sweden joined the European Union (EU) on Jan. 1, 1995 and it became a non-permanent member of the United Nations Security Council (UNSC) in January this year. "As a result, Sweden has to consider overall EU external policy and its relations with mainland China, a UNSC permanent member, in formulating its policy toward Taiwan," Lu said, adding that such considerations have been major hindrances to upgrading the status of the ROC's representative office in that country.

For all the difficulties, Lu said, the Taipei mission in Sweden will continue to do its utmost to expand contacts with Sweden's private and public sectors to solicit their support for the ROC's bid to take part in major international organizations and activities. "We'll also invite more Swedish politicians, academics, journalists, business leaders and social celebrities to visit Taiwan to enhance their understanding of the ROC's general situation and its national cause and basic policy," he added.

DOC.HEADLINE: TAIWAN GOODS PRICES WILL NOT SKYROCKET

TEXT.P: Despite anticipated pressure on goods prices following Taiwan's currency devaluation against the US dollar, prices on the island are not expected to jump precipitously, an economic official said on Wednesday.

P.K. Chiang, chairman for the Council for Economic Planning and Development (CEPD), made the remarks while reporting on the impact of the global financial turmoil on Taiwan's economic development at a meeting of the ruling Kuomintang's policy-making Central Standing Committee.
He said that the New Taiwan dollar has been found to have been over-devalued, according to a series of assessments of the CEPD and many professional economic institutes.

If the Taiwan unit remains in the range of 30-31 to the greenback, Chiang noted, local prices will not jump by more than 3 percent next year, due to factors such as the NT dollar gains against Southeast Asian currencies and the South Korean won.

International crude oil prices are expected to show only a moderate increase in 1998, while an estimated rise in the productivity of local manufacturers, and over-production in the nations of Southeast Asia will also help Taiwan maintain stable prices, the CEPD leader pointed out.

Meanwhile, according to a CEPD survey of 100 large companies in the manufacturing sector on the island, the number of businesses suffering a decline in foreign orders in November was 18 percent higher than those enjoying increasing orders.

Local manufacturers likely to suffer shrinking orders registered 21 percent more than those expecting to enjoy gains, the early-December survey showed, indicating that general exports from Taiwan are expected to face a slow-down in development.

However, the survey also showed that around 85 percent of the businesses polled believe the recent financial storm will not force any changes in Taiwan's planned domestic investment projects for 1998, seeming to suggest that the financial crisis has had only a minor impact on the country's manufacturing sector.

DOC.HEADLINE: ARATS DENIES CHAIRMAN'S RESIGNATION

TEXT.P: A ranking official of the Beijing-based Association for Relations Across the Taiwan Strait (ARATS) denied on Tuesday that ARATS Chairman Wang Daohan, mainland China's top negotiator with Taiwan, resigned from his post in mid-November.
ARATS Vice Chairman Tang Shubei told the Taiwan press in a telephone interview that "he has never heard of such a thing," and that "Wang remains in very good shape."
Tang's remarks came after a Hong Kong-based magazine reported in its latest edition which hit newsstands on Tuesday that Wang had tendered his resignation on Nov. 24 for health reasons.

The report said Wang had come under strong criticism from ranking Beijing officials for remarks on the controversial "one China issue" which he allegedly made to Hsu Li-nung, chairman of the New Tungmenhui, a Taiwan-based pro-unification political group, during a Nov. 16 meeting in Shanghai.

Wang had been reported earlier as telling Hsu in the meeting that "one China" is a unified entity comprising the two sides of the Taiwan Strait, a different slant on Beijing's normal stance on the subject.

Tang denied the reports and said that although conditions are not yet ripe for the two sides of the Taiwan Strait to resume talks, the mainland Chinese side is preparing to conduct preparatory consultations with Taiwan in order to open bilateral negotiations on political issues under the framework set up by the ARATS and its Taiwan counterpart -- the Straits Exchange Foundation (SEF).
He stressed that the structure of bilateral negotiations remains unchanged and added that mainland China has never changed its stance and attitude toward the disputed "one China issue."

The SEF and ARATS are the semiofficial organizations authorized by Taipei and Beijing, respectively, to handle bilateral exchanges in the absence of government-to-government contacts between the two sides.
Regular SEF-ARATS talks were unilaterally suspended by Beijing after ROC President Lee Teng-hui paid a visit to the United States in 1995.
SEF Chairman Koo Chen-fu met his mainland counterpart Wang for the first time in 1993 in Singapore.

DOC.HEADLINE: TAIWAN STOCK MARKET REGARDED AS PROFITABLE
DOC.DATELINE: New York, Dec. 16 (CNA) (By Jennifer Huang and Elizabeth Hsu)

TEXT.P: Latest survey results reveal that most of the world's key institutions involved in stock investment posted optimistic expectations of the Taiwan stock market's performance for 1998, estimating a 43 percent growth in turnover for the upcoming year.

The survey was jointly conducted by the Tempest counseling company and Britain's Reuters news agency, which surveyed more than 200 international fund management companies worldwide between September and November on the prospects for 31 stock markets in various emerging economies.

The results released on Wednesday reveal that Taiwan stock trading is enjoying the fastest growth in Asia, with rewards from investments in the island's stock market ranking fourth among emerging economies worldwide and top among the countries of the Asia-Pacific region.

DOC.HEADLINE: PRESIDENT CALLS FOR TIMELY MEASURES TO WARD OFF FINANCIAL CRISIS

TEXT.P: President Lee Teng-hui on Wednesday urged relevant government agencies to study the causes of the recent financial crises in many Asian countries and work out precautionary measures to fend off the occurrence of any similar fiasco in Taiwan.

President Lee gave the directives in his capacity as chairman of the ruling Kuomintang (KMT) after hearing a report on the latest international financial trends and Taiwan's economic outlook by P.K. Chiang, chairman of the Council for Economic Planning and Development (CEPD), at a weekly meeting of the KMT Central Standing Committee.
Lee said the government's economic and financial departments have so far performed well in coping with the recent region-wide financial storm.
"The government has managed to respect the market mechanism while maintaining domestic financial stability amid the regional financial turbulence," Lee said.

The president, who has a doctorate in agricultural economy, suggested that domestic financial authorities take even more active measures to maintain a mature, healthy economic climate that will ensure steady economic growth.

If necessary, Lee said, the Central Bank of China should consider further lowering of the bank reserve requirements, while the Ministry of Finance can ease restrictions on stock investment by local banks and accelerate screening of applications for establishing mutual funds to invest in the local bourse. "These measures will help stabilize the local securities market and sustain our economic growth," he noted.
Chiang said at the KMT meeting that Taiwan's economic growth rate will be able to exceed 6 percent next year, despite the financial turmoil in the rest of the region.
"Our 1998 economic growth rate is expected to fall between 6.3 and 6.7 percent," Chiang forecast optimistically, adding that his forecast is based on a combination of factors.

For one thing, Chiang said, several large private and public investment projects, including construction of a high-speed railway and a high-tech industrial park in southern Taiwan, will be launched next year, which will be a driving force to bolster Taiwan's economic growth.

Other factors which will contribute to Taiwan's economic growth include a continued rise in labor productivity, stable wages and an anticipated drop in labor costs, Chiang noted, adding that the government's strenuous efforts to improve the investment climate will also help stimulate private investment.

Chiang said the Asian financial storm has so far only had a limited adverse impact on Taiwan's economy, even though the depreciation of the New Taiwan dollar has triggered rises in local interest rates and the wholesale price index.

The cabinet's chief economic planner warned that the competitiveness of local petrochemical, food processing and steel industries may be somewhat weakened by the recent financial storm. "Nevertheless, the impact will remain limited," he stressed.

Chiang further said the depreciation of the NT dollar against the US dollar is not expected to fuel strong inflationary pressure because of stable international crude oil prices and over-production of some raw materials in Southeast Asia.

Except for the United States, Taiwan's major import sources also include Japan, South Korea and Southeast Asian countries. The NT dollar has appreciated significantly against the South Korean won and the currencies of several Southeast Asian countries, while its parity rate with the Japanese yen remains almost unchanged. "All these factors will help minimize the adverse effects of the NT dollar's devaluation against the greenback," Chiang explained.

DOC.HEADLINE: GLOBAL TRADE IN GOODS UP 5 %

TEXT.P: World trade in goods grew by 5 percent in volume terms last year, slightly below the average for the five previous years, but appears to have accelerated again in 1997, according to reports from the Geneva-based World Trade Organization (WTO) on Tuesday.
Giving his annual overview of developments in the international trade system to WTO members, Renato Ruggiero, WTO director general, said that 1997 was a good year for trade.
Although he gave no estimates, he said both world trade and output were likely to be higher this year than in 1996, when they rose by 5 percent and 2.5 percent, respectively.

However, Ruggiero warned that East Asia's financial crisis could lead to an expansion of exports from the region and a slowing in import demand in the coming year. He urged other WTO members to show understanding and appealed to East Asian governments not to reverse economic liberalization which, he said, could inhibit longer-term recovery prospects.

According to the WTO, 1997 has already seen a narrowing of regional differences in economic performance, with slower though still strong growth in East Asia, continuing rapid growth in Latin America, and stronger economic activity in western and eastern Europe compared with 1996.

The overall improvement in economic performance will spill over into improved real export growth for 1997, the WTO said, although the value of exports may grow more slowly because of the continued appreciation of the dollar.

In 1996, dollar appreciation and lower prices for some commodities and semi-manufactured goods lowered the growth by value of world merchandise trade to only 4 percent. Nevertheless, the total value of exports topped the US$5,000 billion mark for the first time, at US$5,120 billion.

Exports of commercial services grew by 5 percent in value terms last year to reach US$1,260 billion. This was well down from the 14 percent growth recorded in 1995, although much of the difference is accounted for by the rise in the dollar.
Commercial services trade rose particularly fast in Latin America and Asia, up by 8 percent last year, the WTO report said.

DOC.HEADLINE: AIT CHIEF MEETS JUSTICE MINISTER ON COOPERATION IN FIGHTING CRIME

TEXT.P: Daryl Johnson, director-general of the Taipei office of the American Institute in Taiwan (AIT), paid a visit to Minister of Justice Liao Cheng-hao on Wednesday to exchange views on cooperation in fighting crime.

This was the first time the de facto American embassy in Taipei has contacted the Republic of China's Ministry of Justice to discuss possible cooperative measures in cracking down on crime, including drug trafficking and money laundering.

AIT spokesperson Susan Stahl confirmed that Johnson met with Liao at the ministry on Wednesday morning to discuss matters of mutual interest. She stressed, however, that their talks did not touch on the issue of local property scandals which have been widely reported in recent days.
According to media sources, a US Federal Bureau of Investigation agent stationed at the American Embassy in Japan was also present at the Johnson-Liao meeting.
The reports said Johnson had exchanged views with Liao on how to strengthen bilateral anti-crime operations in the absence of formal diplomatic ties between Taipei and Washington.
During the talks, Liao reportedly expressed the ROC government's desire to sign an agreement to facilitate joint crime-fighting operations.

As the meeting took place one day after a noted Hong Kong business tycoon was detained by ROC law-enforcement authorities for alleged involvement in a corruption scandal stemming from a land deal in Taipei County, local media said Liao and Johnson might have discussed possible cooperation in investigating illegal money laundering.

Liao had told local reporters that law-enforcement authorities will carefully trace the flow of money connected with a land scandal related to a long-talked-about plan to establish a National Taipei University in Sanhsia, Taipei County.

DOC.HEADLINE: HONG KONG BOURSE SAID TO STABILIZE IN SIX MONTHS

TEXT.P: The slide of the Hong Kong stock market is a short-term phenomenon, and the territory's bourse should be back on track within six months, participants in a seminar said Wednesday.

That view was expressed by a group of scholars and experts from Taiwan and Hong Kong as well as government officials from the Central Bank of China, Ministry of Finance and the Council for Economic Planning and Development, during a seminar on the implication of financial turmoil on the stability and prosperity of Hong Kong.

William Li, director of the Mainland Affairs Council (MAC) Department of Hong Kong and Macao Affairs, said there was also a consensus among the participants that mainland China's currency will not be devalued in the short term. The seminar was sponsored by the MAC.

Li said the meeting examined the factors which caused the recent slide of the Hong Kong bourse, the future direction of that stock market, the effect of the Asian financial turmoil on Hong Kong's role as an international financial hub, and the overall economic implications of pegging of the Hong Kong dollar to the US dollar.

Li pointed out that after the reversion of Hong Kong to mainland Chinese rule last July, the Hang Seng index had risen to 16,000, which he said was a departure from the fundamentals, and that the recent slide merely reflected a correction of that trend.
Thus, analysts predicted that if the territory's economic base remains sound, the stock market in Hong Kong will be back on a steady course within six months.

The participants believed that the pegging of Hong Kong's currency to the US dollar has contributed significantly to financial stability in the Hong Kong Special Administrative Region (SAR). If the SAR government abandons such linkage and allows a devaluation of the HK dollar, they said that would stimulate exports on a limited basis, but would also trigger import-induced inflation and increase the foreign debt burden.

Li said the participants also believed that the exchange rate of the mainland currency will not be readjusted in the short term. They predicted that Beijing will maintain stringent foreign exchange controls and continue to register huge trade surpluses.
As the mainland's outstanding foreign debt is more than US$130 billion, a currency devaluation could seriously hamper its future economic development, Li noted.

DOC.HEADLINE: CLINTON ASSESSES CROSS-STRAIT SITUATION IN YEAREND REVIEW

TEXT.P: US President Bill Clinton said Tuesday that the United States has not changed its position on the security of Taiwan and would view any resolution of the Taiwan issue by force with the "greatest possible concern."

In response to questions on relations between Taiwan and mainland China at his "year-in-review" press conference at the State Department, Clinton pointed out that the whole framework of America's relations with mainland China is embodied in the three joint communiques between Washington and Beijing.
Within that framework, he said, the United States recognizes "one China," while Beijing makes a commitment to a peaceful resolution of the issues between Taiwan and mainland China.
"And we have always said that we would view a departure from that with the gravest possible concern," Clinton said.

Asked to assess whether Taiwan and mainland China are moving in the direction of resuming dialogue, as he suggested at a press conference after his Oct. 29 summit with communist Chinese leader Jiang Zemin, Clinton replied, "I would urge them to get together to keep working on it as soon as possible."
He said, "Both places are doing too well now -- economically and otherwise -- to risk their prosperity and their process on a fight that need not occur and should not happen."
Clinton declined to comment on whether too much time had elapsed before the resumption of talks between Taiwan and mainland China, saying he said he did not know enough to make a judgment.

DOC.HEADLINE: RESEARCHERS ACHIEVE BREAKTHROUGH IN MOLECULAR CARDIOLOGY

TEXT.P: The human heart became significantly less mysterious on Tuesday when Canadian and Chinese researchers published an 80-to-90 percent complete catalogue of all the genes contained in the cardiovascular system, The Globe and Mail reported on Wednesday.

Roughly 9,000 of the genes had never been described before in any organ -- a significant addition to what scientists believe are the 75,000 to 100,000 genes that regulate the human body's development and functions, the daily said.
In terms of long-term medical significance, American scientists say the work is a "milestone in the development of a new science called molecular cardiology," according to the report.

A companion piece to the main thesis states: "In essence, although this database has presented us with the advantages of a dictionary of molecules, our scientific aspirations are to use this to create great novels, i.e., to use these molecules to answer critical problems in cardio-vascular biology and medicine."
The report said the researchers "used their database to pinpoint 100 genes that their initial surveys suggest are involved in congestive heart failure."
The paper was co-authored by David Hwang and Adam Dempsey. Hwang, a graduate student at the University of Toronto, said only 10 of these genes have previously been linked to heart failure.

Moreover, while the ordering or the relative importance of these genes is still unknown, simply finding a "gene complex" creates its own variety of heretofore unknown scientific issues, the report added.

The newspaper called the Toronto group's findings "a technological tour de force," adding that they also represent the fruits of an unusual collaboration in which institutions in both China and Hong Kong gave research grants to support basic science in Canada.
The publication of the paper in open scientific literature is also being praised for its altruism, especially since a Toronto company contributed C$1 million to the research project.

As one scientist said: "At a time when most comprehensive tissue and disease-related databases remain in the private domain of biotechnology and pharmaceutical firms, it is particularly admirable that a database of this size has been introduced into the public domain."

DOC.HEADLINE: ECONOMICAL OFFICER ENCOURAGES VENTURES INTO SOUTH KOREA

TEXT.P: Financial crisis griped South Korea brings about a wonderful opportunity for Taiwan firms to get that country's technology know-how and marketing skill in semiconductor, automobile parts and railroad cars maintenance, but better do so only after Feb. 21 when Seoul swears in a new president, said an economic official here Wednesday.

Listing semiconductor, auto parts and railroad car maintenance as the three categories most worthwhile to invest for Taiwan firms, Chen Min-hsiang, a Board of Foreign Trade official told reporters that Taiwan imported more than NT$70 billion (US$2.12 billion) worth of auto parts from South Korea thus far this year, and has bought from South Korea NT$600 million (US$18.18 million) -worth of railroad cars which still need the regular maintenance of its manufacturers.
As to South Korea's semiconductor industry, it ranks third in the world said Chen who has just returned on Monday from a fact-finding trip to Seoul.

In light of the South Korea's financial crisis which has seen its currency devalued by more than 50 percent, Chen encouraged Taiwan investors to venture into the Korea markets which is starved of hard currency necessary to meet its short-term debts.

The crisis takes a heavy toll on South Korea's business. Five huge trade firms have declared bankruptcies on top of some 1,400 small and medium sized business firms that have gone out of business. The number of South Korean banks with the authority to negotiate has been cut down from 30 to four, all of them were overseas-based, according to Chen.

As the financial woe is not troublesome enough, political uncertainty ahead of Thursday's presidential elections deepen the crisis with different candidates prescribing different remedies for the country's tattering economy, said Chen.
He suggested local businessmen who are interested in acquiring South Korea firms throwing in their money only after a new president takes office and set out his economy policy.

DOC.HEADLINE: KMT ANNOUNCES PERSONNEL RESHUFFLE

TEXT.P: The ruling Kuomintang on Wednesday announced a major personnel reshuffle aimed at streamlining its party apparatus in the aftermath of its embarrassing defeat in the Nov. 29 nationwide mayoral and county magistrate elections.

The reshuffle involved four departments at the KMT headquarters -- the organization affairs department, the secretariat, the cultural affairs department and the Sun Yat-sen Institution on Policy Research and Development.
The party's decision-making Central Standing Committee (CSC) approved the personnel reshuffle at its weekly meeting chaired by President Lee Teng-hui, who concurrently serves as KMT chairman.
Lee lauded the reshuffle, including the appointment of a woman as the party's spokesperson, which he described as "bold and daring."
"All four newly appointed KMT department chiefs are top-notch party workers. I'm confident that they will be able to fulfill their duties," Lee said at the CSC meeting.

KMT Secretary-General John Chang, who assumed his post earlier this month, said he personally initiated the new lineup after extensive consultations with party elders as well as grassroots party workers.
Chang said there will be another round of personnel changes following the Jan. 20 elections for township chiefs and city and county councilors.
Most prominent among the latest personnel changes was the replacement of the party's official spokesperson or director of the cultural affairs department.

Huamg Li-ching, 42, who currently serves as deputy director of the KMT women's affairs department and head of the party's Taoyuan branch, will succeed Tsai Pi-huang as the KMT's spokesperson and director of the cultural affairs department.
Huang, a graduate of the Central Police College, will be the 103-year-old party's first female spokesperson.
Tsai, who has been criticized for his sometimes loose remarks, will replace Chuang Hui-yi as director-general of the Sun Yat-sen Institution on Policy Research and Department.
Meanwhile, Chen Chun-chan, a law-enforcement officer turned legislator, will replace Hsu Wen-chih as director of the organizational affairs.

Shi Hwei-yow, a former chairman of the Cabinet-level Mainland Affairs Council and a legal expert, will assume the post as the director-general of the party's secretariat. Shi lost his bid for the magistrate post in his native Nantou County in the Nov. 29 local elections.

DOC.HEADLINE: LATE 'BANANA KING' CHEN CHA-MOU REMAINS UNBURIED

TEXT.P: Four years after the death of billionaire Chen Cha-mou, his remains have yet to be interred because of disputes among his children over the burial site and rights to his inheritance, Taipei City Councilor Lin Juei-tu said Wednesday.
Lin visited Chen's former mansion in Yangmingshan, suburban Taipei, where his coffin has laid for over four years.
Lin said the body of Chen, who made his fortune selling bananas to Japan and has been dubbed the "Taiwan banana king," has been embalmed and the coffin is sealed, thus there is no hygiene problem.
But he urged Chen's children to fulfill their filial duty so that their father can be put to final rest.

A governess said that since Chen's death on Aug. 9, 1993, his body has laid in the old mansion, adding that she and a butler light incense for him every day. "None of Chen's children lives here," she said.

Lin said Chen Ching-chung, Chen's third son, has insisted that his father be buried together with his grandmother and mother at a family graveyard in Yangmingshan, saying that the "feng shui," or geomantic qualities, of the location are most suitable.
But Chen Chien-chung, Chen's eldest son, said his father had hoped to be buried on Kuangyin Mountain, but died without declaring so in a will.
After Chen's death, his children also squabbled over their rightful share of the inheritance, and the case has gone to court.

Councilor Lin, who wants to help resolve the problem after it recently came to light through media reports, said the nation's Civil Code stipulates that, in circumstances as those in Chen's case, the children of the deceased must share responsibility for handling the remains.
A Taipei City official in charge of funeral-related affairs said there is presently no legal provision to force a burial, and thus he can do nothing about the matter.
Lin said that as it will take too long to review relevant statutes, he plans to ask Vice President Lien Chan, whose daughter is married to Chen's grandson, to intervene in sorting out the matter.

DOC.HEADLINE: HONDURAN VICE PRESIDENT TO VISIT TAIWAN

TEXT.P: Honduran Vice President Walter Lopez Reyes will arrive in Taipei on Saturday for a six-day visit, according to the Ministry of Foreign Affairs.

During his stay in Taiwan, Ropez will meet with ROC officials and preside over the opening of the Honduras Golf Charity Invitational on Dec. 23, a fund-raising activity aimed at helping poor and handicapped children in the Central American country.

James Tao, head of the Honorary Consulate-General of Honduras in Taipei and chairman of the ROC-Honduras Cultural, Economic and Trade Association, said on Wednesday that the golf tournament is jointly sponsored by his organization and the ROC Golf Association.
Tao said the proceeds raised at the charity event will be donated to a social welfare foundation run by the wife of Honduran President Carlos Roberto Reina.
Ropez is scheduled to depart on Dec. 25.

DOC.HEADLINE: MAINLAND CHINA WILL NOT DEVALUE CURRENCY TO MAINTAIN GROWTH

TEXT.P: Mainland China will boost domestic demand by increasing spending on infrastructural development, rather than devalue its currency to spur exports, in order to maintain economic growth in the face of the current Asian financial crisis, a leading Asian analyst said.

Daryl Ho, regional economist of the Hong Kong-based Jardine Fleming Group, said this was because mainland economic planners can control only fixed capital formation, The Straits Times reported Wednesday in a dispatch from Beijing.
He ruled out domestic consumption as an engine of growth, citing levels of massive unemployment. Consumer spending is expected to achieve only single-digit growth in the short term.
He said that over the longer term, however, measures have to be taken to stimulate such consumption because it will be difficult to sustain investment spending.
Mainland China will finance the infrastructural spending through its huge pool of domestic savings, he added.

He pointed out that a slowdown in investments from South Korea and Japan, reeling under the crisis, will not have a major impact on mainland China's foreign investments, as 70 percent of it comes from Hong Kong and Taiwan.
Foreign investments, affected by tax changes last year, were already declining before the crisis erupted, he noted.

The South Korean meltdown has made mainland China's economic planners painfully aware of its similarities to its East Asian neighbor, in particular the cozy relations between the government and business enterprises.

The analyst said he expected Beijing to speed up reforms, especially in the banking system. Reforms which are needed include granting loans based on commercial considerations rather than officials' whims.
"Whether that can in fact be achieved is a different question," he was quoted as commenting.

In addition, officials will be more conservative now about making the mainland currency fully convertible. For instance, it is unlikely that they will merge the country's domestic and foreign stocks in the next two to three years.
He said he does not expect mainland China to devalue the renminbi as it will still enjoy a large balance of payments surplus next year, despite reduced exports and investment inflows.
Overall, as exports contribute 10 percent to 15 percent to the economy, Beijing will focus on the remaining 85 percent and boost domestic demand, he commented.
He predicted that mainland China's economy will grow by 9 percent in 1997 and 8 percent in 1998.

DOC.HEADLINE: LIAO SETS CONDITIONS FOR DELAYING OR SUSPENDING REFERENDUM

TEXT.P: The Democratic Progressive Party (DPP) magistrate-elect in Taichung County, Liao Yung-lai, said on Wednesday that if two conditions are met, a proposed referendum on German-based Bayer Group's investment project in his county could be delayed or suspended.

After a meeting with Chiang Pin-kung, chairman of the Council for Economic Planning and Development, Liao said that if a review of the project by a special task force favors the company's environmental safeguards, and if approval of a lease for construction of chemical plants under the plan is not rushed through the Taiwan Provincial Assembly this week, he will not insist on putting the issue to a public vote.

Liao stressed that he will take responsibility in forming a task force of chemical experts to gain a better understanding into and conduct a thorough examination of Bayer's first investment in Taiwan. If the investigation finds Bayer's planned operations are unlikely to produce excessive levels of pollution or pose a threat to public safety, Liao said he will not hesitate to also explain those facts to his constituents.

However, before such steps are taken, Liao said, he hopes the provincial assembly will delay screening the Taiwan Provincial Government-approved contract under which provincial-owned land in the Taichung Harbor area will be leased to Bayer Group for a period of 50 years for the purpose of constructing chemical plants.
The assembly, which is scheduled to close its current session on Friday, has the final say on the fate of the land lease agreement.

Liao said he and Chiang both agree that the Bayer's NT$49 billion investment project is important to the continued economic development of Taiwan as well as Taichung County. But as many local residents continue to have misgivings over the project, more efforts should be made to communicate with the public, he added.

Chiang said he believes his meeting with Liao was helpful to finding workable solutions to the dispute. Asked if Bayer will consider withdrawing the investment proposal if the land lease is not obtained by year's end, Chiang said he will attempt to persuade the multinational giant not to make such a decision so hastily.

Since so much time has already been put into planning the project, Bayer should give the provincial assembly more time to discuss the matter and, in the meantime, keep good communications with the residents of Taichung County, Chiang added.

DOC.HEADLINE: CANCER-STRICKEN LEGISLATOR TO HELP ORGANIZE CHARITY CONCERT

TEXT.P: Legislator Lu Shiu-i may be near the end of his life, but he hopes other lung cancer patients may benefit from his final endeavors.
Lu has handed a brochure promoting a charity concert to each visitor at his bedside recently, earnestly inviting them to attend the event.
Though weakened by lung cancer, the legislator wants others to have healthy lungs, Lee Yuan-chih, a doctor at the National Taiwan University Hospital said.
Lee, who also serves as the chairman of a lung transplant foundation, said that Lu has controlled his condition reasonably well over the past two years.

Lu took the initiative for organizing the fundraiser in September, saying that the White Heron Foundation, chaired by his pianist wife Chen Yu-hsiu, wanted to raise money for lung cancer patients at its annual concert. The legislator said he hoped to help others who needed lung transplant operations.
However, doctors soon found that Lu's cancer had spread to the brain.
Yet, the onslaught of the cancer has not dampened the enthusiasm of Lu, who has been one of the most outspoken advocates for public interests in the Legislative Yuan.
Lee said he cannot but admire Lu, although he feels pity because, in the terminal stages of cancer, Lu is no longer suitable to receive a lung transplant.
Lee also lamented the fact that Lu's efforts may not even raise enough for one lung transplant operation, estimated to cost up to NT$3 million (US$92,3076).
The charity concert will be held at Dec. 28 at the National Concert Hall.

DOC.HEADLINE: MORE FOREIGN DOMESTIC WORKERS TO BE ALLOWED

TEXT.P: Taiwan is to bring in 2,100 more foreign domestic helpers while scaling down the number of alien laborers, according to a new policy currently under study.

Chang Chang-chi, vice chairman of the Council of Labor Affairs, said in a briefing to a Cabinet panel Wednesday that a poll conducted by the council had found more than 19,000 Taiwan households urgently need domestic helpers, or 2,100 more than the ceiling of 16,900 provided under the current regulations.
Local sanitariums, nursing homes and other facilities which are seriously understaffed will be open to licensed foreign caregivers under the new plan, Chang said.

Meanwhile the number of foreign laborers employed in the construction and manufacturing industries, presently standing at 4,378 and 159,970 respectively, will be frozen and eventually reduced after current contracts expire in order to make room for local workers in those sectors.
Under the council's new plan, the quota of foreign laborers for these two sectors will be lowered by 5 percent from current levels.

However, contractors for major investment projects, those with a capitalization of more than NT$200 million (US$6.06 million), will be allowed to import foreign labor without being subject to the limitation.

Service industry businesses, including financial institutions and insurance companies, which are eager to hire managerial staff from overseas, will remain off-limits to foreign white-collar workers, in order to provide incentives to local professionals in these sectors.

In order to rid the island of dead-end and environmentally unfriendly industries, enterprises in those areas will be prevented from using cheaper overseas foreign labor to cling to life, according to the new plan.
The policy is expected to be finalized and take effect early next year, Chang said.

DOC.HEADLINE: SIEW MEETS WITH ARGENTINE CONGRESSMEN

TEXT.P: Premier Vincent Siew on Wednesday told Fernando Omar Salim, head of a four-member parliamentary delegation from Argentina, that he hopes the ROC and that South American country can strengthen bilateral economic and cultural relations.

Siew said that as relations between Taiwan and Argentina in trade, fisheries, investment and cultural exchanges have become closer in recent years, Taipei hopes that Buenos Aires will take the US-enacted Taiwan Relations Act as a model to enact legislation that will provide a legal framework for the future conduct of bilateral relations.

Siew said that after Taiwan and Argentina concluded their trade talks on terms for Taiwan's entry into the World Trade Organization (WTO) in September, the two sides should push for closer economic relations. The holding of regular meetings attended by high-ranking economic officials of the two countries will provide great impetus to such cooperation, Siew added.

Salim agreed with Siew that the two countries should seek to promote bilateral economic and cultural cooperation, adding that this is also line with Argentina President Carlos Menem's plans to forge closer cooperation with other countries around the world.
Salim and the three other members of the Chamber of Deputies arrived in Taiwan on Sunday for a six-day visit. They are scheduled to depart on Friday.

DOC.HEADLINE: ASEAN PLEDGES TO SPEED UP TARIFF CUTS

TEXT.P: The Association of Southeast Asian Nations (ASEAN), a powerful group of nine developing countries, agreed to accelerate the reduction of regional tariffs to combat their economic crisis, an influential European newspaper reported Wednesday.

The ASEAN member countries had decided at a summit meeting to import more from their member countries because sharp depreciation of several currencies against the US dollar had made regional goods cheaper, the Financial Times said.

"We do not have the foreign exchange to buy from outside the region," the Financial Times quoted Dr. Mahathir Mohamad, Malaysian prime minister, as saying. He insisted the agreement did not mean that ASEAN was turning into an exclusive trade bloc.

ASEAN, which comprises Malaysia, Thailand, Indonesia, Singapore, the Philippines, Vietnam, Burma, Laos and Brunei, has set a target of bringing tariffs down to less than 5 percent by 2003 on almost all items traded within the group. Imports from outside ASEAN are subject to different, generally higher, duties.

Officials said it was possible the 2003 deadline could be brought forward but they added this was an issue for economic ministers to decide at a later date. Mahathir indicated that ASEAN's drive to buy more from within the region could be extended to include purchases from mainland China, Japan and South Korea for certain items.

The leaders of mainland China, South Korea and Japan are also attending ASEAN's informal summit, which was called to celebrate the 30th anniversary of the Southeast Asian group. It is the first time the leaders of Asia's most powerful nations have met without US participation.

DOC.HEADLINE: ROAD CRASHES IN SAUDI ARABIA CAUSE LOSSES WORTH US$2.6 BILLION

TEXT.P: Traffic accidents are causing more than 30,000 injuries and between 4,000 and 8,000 fatalities annually in Saudi Arabia, involving financial losses worth over US$2.66 billion.
The statistics were disclosed by Dr. Ali Saeed Al-Ghamdi, chairman of the information committee for an upcoming traffic safety conference, which will be inaugurated on Saturday.

An earlier symposium revealed that the number of persons involved in traffic accidents in Saudi Arabia during the 12-year period between 1984 and 1996 stood at 91,854, representing 7 percent of the total number of road casualties.

Traffic accidents are the main cause of the surge in mortality rates in Saudi Arabia and other Gulf states. According to Dr. Abdul Jaleel Al-Seif, director-general of medical services in the Ministry of Interior, children constituted 20 percent of the road casualties reported.

DOC.HEADLINE: DRUG TRAFFICKERS NABBED

TEXT.P: Police have arrested four suspects on charges of smuggling heroin from Thailand.
Police were tipped in August that a drug smuggling ring operating in Taichung, central Taiwan, had lured jobless men to sneak in drugs from Thailand.
After tracking the suspects for months, police were able to arrest Tsai Cheng-chou, 27, and Chen Shu-ming, 23, on Wednesday night as they returned to CKS International Airport from Thailand.
An X-ray machine found eight heroin balls, with a total weight of 200 grams, hidden in condoms which Tsai and Chen had swallowed to avoid detection.

Police also rounded up Han Ching-hsiang, 36, and Ou Chun-hsiung, 21, who paid NT$50,000 (US$1,538) each to Tsai and Chen to procure the drugs in Thailand from an ROC national surnamed Kao, a fugitive who is wanted in connection with other criminal cases in Taiwan. Han and Ou planned to sell the heroin locally for profit.
Police are closely monitoring a rising trend whereby drug traffickers conceal the contraband in condoms, which they either swallow or insert into their anal cavities.
