DOC.HEADLINE: IRANIAN SWINDLING RING BUSTED

TEXT.P: Police have busted an Iranian swindling ring in Taipei and arrested three key suspects, the foreign affairs department under the National Police Administration (NPA) announced on Thursday.

Since their arrival on Dec. 12, NPA officials said, the three Iranians have stolen more than NT$100,000 (US$3,076.92) from a dozen local shops by pretending to convert their US dollar holdings into New Taiwan dollars.

The trio, identified as Fereyboun, his wife Lailla and friend Motpaba, were caught red-handed on Wednesday evening when they were stealing some NT$36,000 from a cashbox at a convenience store in downtown Taipei. The trio took a baby girl with them in an attempt to distract the shopkeepers.

NPA officials said the group arrived at the store driving a rented car. Fereyboun first approached a shopkeeper asking to convert a greenback note into local currency. His accomplices then approached the cashbox and stole the money while the shopkeeper was busy talking with Fereyboun.

Police said the trio have used this method to steal money from at least 10 local stores, including a Japanese food restaurant, a bowling alley, motorcycle shops and several convenience stores. The Iranians usually used the pretext of converting US cash into NT dollars, but they sometimes asked to change a NT$1,000 bill into smaller denominations. In some cases, they even asked shopowners to give them bills bearing serial numbers starting with a specific English letter.
NPA officials urged local shopkeepers to remain alert when approached by foreigners or strangers seeking to convert currency in order to prevent financial losses.

The NPA's foreign affairs department set up a special task force in November to shadow suspicious visitors from the Middle East as there have been signs that criminal rings from the region have resumed activities in Taiwan since this summer, law-enforcement authorities said.

DOC.HEADLINE: FUJITSU PURCHASES TAIWAN COMPUTER PRODUCTS

TEXT.P: A Japanese computer conglomerate was in Taiwan on Thursday to seek local suppliers for monitors, as well as computer parts and components.

A delegation formed by Fujitsu Peripherals Ltd. (FPE), part of the Fujitsu Group, which is listed among the world's top three information technology companies, is currently holding a trade workshop here.

During the two-day event, the delegation is expected to place a large number of orders with local computer makers for 15- and 17-inch monitors, along with parts and components for 15-inch monitors equipped with liquid crystal display (LCD), according to officials of the China External Trade Development Council (CETRA).
The semi-official institution has been attempting to introduce foreign buyers to Taiwan, seek trade opportunities and open markets for local enterprises.

To further promote Taiwan products to the world, CETRA has implemented what it calls an "International Sourcing Center" plan, hoping to develop the island into a resource center for complete product ranges, especially in the computer and info-tech fields.

Under the project, CETRA provides foreign businesses with data and information on Taiwan enterprises. It is also sponsoring a series of trade workshops, such as the current one which attracted the Fujitsu Group subsidiary to Taiwan in search of suppliers.

Fujitsu Peripherals, founded in 1984, currently employs around 800 personnel to manufacture computer monitors, LCD projection devices, printers and motherboards. Its 1996 turnover reached 50 billion Japanese yen, 60 percent of which came from sales of monitors, according to CETRA.
In order to accommodate rapidly expanding production, the Japanese manufacturer is seeking to increase purchases from suppliers in Taiwan.
Around 90 computer-related local businesses, including Sampo, Taiwan Semiconductor Manufacturing and Acer Peripheral Inc., are taking part in the workshop to bid for orders.

DOC.HEADLINE: WEI JINGSHENG TO VISIT FRANCE IN EARLY 1998
DOC.DATELINE: Paris, Dec. 18 (CNA) (By Tzou Ming-jhie & Eva Chen)

TEXT.P: Wei Jingsheng, mainland China's most famous dissident, has accepted an invitation to visit France on Jan. 14, l998, according to the French National Assembly.

The legislative body passed a resolution introduced by a liberal congressman to formally invite Wei to France so that he can relate to the sympathetic French people his story of sacrifice and struggle for human rights and democracy in mainland China, reports from the assembly said.
Wei will also be asked about present human rights conditions in the mainland and the possibilities for improvement, as well as about future prospects for the democratic movement there.
After spending 18 years in prison for his advocacy of human rights and democracy in the Chinese mainland, Wei was released on "medical parole" on Nov. 16 and went to the United States.

Since his release, Wei has been received as a mentor within the exiled Chinese pro-democratic movement. It is expected that his visit to France will be conducive to unifying the factious Chinese dissident groups in Europe. In addition, it will be helpful in gaining sympathy and support from European countries and in speeding up Beijing's liberalization process.

DOC.HEADLINE: SHARE PRICES DOWN ON TAIEX

TEXT.P: Share prices slipped 1.1 percent on the Taiwan stock market Thursday, as technology sector investors sold their shareholdings.
Stock brokers attributed the drop to investors' attempt to avoid losses after weak performances by electrical engineering shares.

The Taiwan Stock Exchange (TAIEX) weighted price index declined 92.15 points to close at the day's low of 8,255.05. The bourse started at 8,361.9, and reached a high of 8,380.72 before reversing directions.
Losers outnumbered gainers 239 to 167, with 63 shares unchanged.
A total of 2.84 billion shares changed hands on a market turnover of NT$133.18 billion (US$4.16 billion).

Among eight major stock categories, electrical engineering issues fell the sharpest at 2 percent, followed by financial shares at 1.6 percent, paper and pulp issues at 1.1 percent, textile stocks at 0.4 percent, and plastic and chemical shares at 0.3 percent.
Construction stocks registered a gain of 0.7 percent, while cement issues edged up by 0.6 percent, and foodstuff shares charted a modest 0.3 percent rise.

The 10 companies with the largest turnover were: International Bills Finance, Union Petrochemical, Ever Fortune, Taiwan Styrene Monomer, Taiwan Semiconductor Manufacturing, Chang Hwa Bank, Formosa Chemical and Fiber, United Micro Electronics, BES Engineering, and China Trust Commercial Bank.

DOC.HEADLINE: BAYER SAYS LAND-LEASE AGREEMENT CRUCIAL TO INVESTMENT PROJECT

TEXT.P: The German-based Bayer Group will withdraw plans for its investment project in central Taiwan if the Taiwan Provincial Government fails to approve a land-lease agreement, a representative for Bayer said Thursday.
Company spokesman Chen Chia-chung made the statement at a public hearing on the controversial project convened by the opposition New Party caucus in the Taiwan Provincial Assembly.

The assembly is due to review a Taiwan Provincial Government-approved contract under which provincial-owned land in the Taichung Harbor area will be leased to the multinational chemical giant for a period of 50 years for the purpose of constructing a chemical plant.

Chen said that Horst Mueck, chairman and president of Bayer Taiwan Co., "has his back to the wall now," and that if Bayer fails even to procure land for the facility, it can hardly talk about future investment plans, much less actual construction work for the project.

Sung Ai-ke, New Party assemblyman who convened the public hearing, questioned why Bayer ha d not sought to communicate with the provincial assembly earlier, but is now attempting to pressure the lawmaking body.

Chou Shih-chang of the ruling Kuomintang said the dispute surrounding Bayer's investment project has arisen from a campaign in Taichung County to hold a referendum to decide the fate of the NT$49 billion (US$1.5 billion) project.
Chou said it is not fair for provincial assembly to shoulder the entire responsibility for the outcome of the matter.

Tsao Chi-hung of the opposition Democratic Progressive Party said his party would not be influenced by what he called threats from Bayer to cancel the project on the eve of the decision on the land-leasing contract.
The assembly, which is scheduled to close its current session on Friday, will have the final say on the land-lease contract.

After meeting with P.K. Chiang, chairman of the Council for Economic Planning and Development (CEPD), on Wednesday night, Taichung County Magistrate-elect Liao Yung-lai of the DPP said that he will not insist on putting the issue to a public vote if a task force okays Bayer's environmental safeguard proposals, and if approval of the leasing agreement is not rammed through the assembly.

DOC.HEADLINE: PRESIDENT LEE RECEIVES U.S. REP. EDDIE JOHNSON

TEXT.P: President Lee Teng-hui said Thursday that the Republic of China highly values its traditional friendship with the United States and hopes to strengthen the relations between the two countries.

President Lee made the remarks when he received U.S. Rep. Eddie Bernice Johnson (D-TX) at his office. He also told her that the ROC government is trying to improve the balance of trade between the two countries, and looking for U.S. support for its early admission to the World Trade Organization (WTO).

During the meeting, Johnson praised Taiwan for its smooth handling of the recent financial crisis in Asia, and stressed American people's friendship and support for the people on Taiwan. (by Ed Hsieh)

DOC.HEADLINE: INVESTMENT WILLINGNESS NOT AFFECTED BY FINANCIAL CRISIS: POLL

TEXT.P: The recent Asian financial crisis has not affected local manufacturers' investment willingness, the Council for Economic Planning and Development (CEPD) reported on Thursday.

The Cabinet-level council conducted a telephone poll of senior executives from 100 large local manufacturing companies early this month with a view to understand the impact of the regionwide financial storm on trade and investment activities.
Eighty-four percent of those interviewed said they will not change their domestic investment plans set to be launched next year as a result of the recent Asian financial turbulence.

Only 8 percent indicated they may scale back future domestic investments because of the economic difficulties. However, roughly the same number of respondents said they plan to increase domestic investment in the coming years.
"The survey results indicate that the Asian financial crisis has not weakened local manufacturers' confidence in the domestic investment climate," a CEPD official noted.
According to the poll, investors in heavy industries are less likely to revise plans than are their counterparts in light industries.

The same survey also found that about one-third of the respondents expect export orders to decrease over the next three months (December through February 1998). As a result, these manufacturers said they plan to lower export prices in order to upgrade competitiveness in the world market.

According to the survey results, 34 percent forecast that they would receive fewer export orders in the coming three months; 53 percent said they believe orders will remain almost the same; while 13 percent said they expect orders to increase during the December-February period.
Most noteworthy was that 35 percent of companies with Southeast Asia as their main export markets foresee a decrease in export orders, while none of them expects a surge in new orders.

An even higher 38 percent of companies with Hong Kong (including mainland China) as their major export outlet predicted that orders for the next three months will decline, while 12 percent said they believe new orders will continue to rise.

CEPD officials said the figures indicate that, under the cloud of regional financial disturbances, local manufacturers are not optimistic about prospects for exports to Southeast Asia and Hong Kong for the first half of next year.

Some local manufacturers foresee a slowdown in mainland China's exports for the next year because the mainland currency has appreciated significantly against major Southeast Asian currencies, which could undermine the competitiveness of mainland products and thus cut mainland China's demand for intermediary materials from Taiwan.

Against this backdrop, more than half of those surveyed, particularly those eyeing Hong Kong and European markets, have decided to cut export prices in order to maintain their market presence. Hong Kong is a major conduit for indirect trade across the Taiwan Strait as Taiwan still bans direct trade, postal and transportation links with mainland China.

DOC.HEADLINE: AIR CANADA JET GOES OFF RUNWAY, INJURING 25 PASSENGERS

TEXT.P: An Air Canada passenger jet went off the runway at the Fredericton Airport in New Brunswick Tuesday night, injuring 25 passengers.
A hospital official said Wednesday there were no life-threatening injuries in the crash of the Air Canada regional jet.

About two dozen people suffered cuts, bruises and broken bones when Air Canada flight 646 from Toronto crashed on landing. Twenty-five people were taken to the emergency room at the Dr. Everett Chambers Hospital.
The DC-9 passenger jet hit some trees while attempting to land at the Fredericton airport near midnight. Fog was reported at the time.
The plane came to rest among trees, about a kilometer from the terminal. There were no air traffic controllers on duty at the recently downsized airport.
Canada's Transport Safety Commission is investigating the incident.

DOC.HEADLINE: HK TYCOON'S RIGHT-HAND MAN ASKED TO CLARIFY ROLE IN LAND SCANDAL

TEXT.P: The Taipei Prosecutor's Office has asked a close associate of Hong Kong business tycoon Lim Por Yen to come forward and clarify his role in a local land rezoning scandal.

Chief Prosecutor Hsueh Wei-ping said the man, surnamed Ho, had brokered a deal to bribe Taipei County administrators so that land housing Lim's Sanhsia-based Dollar Textile Manufacturing Co. could be rezoned to be included in an area earmarked for development as part of a proposed National Taipei University.
Lim, the 83-year-old chairman of Asian Television (ATV) and Lai Sun Development of Hong Kong, was arrested Wednesday morning by the Taipei District Prosecutor's Office on charges of bribery.

Lim had been detained on Tuesday at CKS International Airport as he was returning to Hong Kong after visiting Taipei. During his stay in Taiwan, Lim attended the Golden Horse film industry awards ceremony on Saturday.

Hsueh said Ho had bribed Chuan Yu-kun, director of the Taipei County Land Administration Bureau, into making a fraudulent assessment of the value of Lim's land and factory facilities. That enabled Lim to receive several billion NT dollars in compensation from the government under a land acquisition program for the university development plan in Sanhsia, Taipei County. Investigators are also looking into charges of illegal money laundering in connection with the scam.
The university plan has been on the drawing board for eight years, held up by land acquisition problems and disputes over compensation to landowners.
Hsueh urged Ho, who is presently in Hong Kong, to come to Taiwan as soon as possible to answer investigators' questions.
In view of Ho's suspected role in the case, Hsueh said he will not rule out seeking means to persuade other individuals involved in the scandal to cooperate with the prosecutor's office.

DOC.HEADLINE: DPP CHAIRMAN MEETS SOUTH KOREAN PRESIDENTIAL CANDIDATE

TEXT.P: Kim Dae-jung, the leading opposition candidate in the current South Korean presidential race, said on Thursday that if he wins the election, he plans to take steps to improve relations between South Korea and Taiwan.

Kim, 72, made the statement when he met with Hsu Hsin-liang, chairman of Taiwan's opposition Democratic Progressive Party (DPP), who arrived here earlier this week to observe campaign activities in the run-up to the Dec. 18 South Korean presidential election.
Kim and Hsu are old friends. During their talks, Kim lauded Taiwan for its vibrant small- and medium-sized enterprises (SMEs), solid economic development and smooth democratic reforms.

The spiritual leader of South Korean political dissent said now-jailed former President Roh Tae-woo had committed a mistake when he cut diplomatic relations with the Republic of China on Taiwan in 1992.

Kim said South Korea has much to learn from Taiwan's SME developmental experience. In South Korea, he said, political forces have often intervened in economic activities. The South Korean government has wasted many national resources by giving favors to the country's dozen or so large conglomerates, or chaebols, while neglecting the development of SMEs, he claimed.
Kim said if he is elected, he will overhaul South Korea's development strategy and promote simultaneous and parallel economic and political reforms.
Kim said although South Korea has undergone fast-paced democratization at the central level, its democratization at the local level only began two years ago.
In contrast, Kim said, Taiwan has long implemented democratic elections at local levels, laying a solid foundation for its overall political development.

Nevertheless, Kim, who has been jailed and forced to live in exile for many years due to his pro-democracy stance, said Taiwan would become a mature democracy only after its opposition party comes to power.

Later on Thursday, Hsu met with another opposition South Korean presidential candidate, Rhee In-je of the New People's Party, for wide-ranging talks. He also paid a visit to a senior official of South Korea's ruling Grand National Party in the afternoon.

Hsu, accompanied by several senior DPP officials, arrived in Seoul on Tuesday. The DPP delegation will leave for Japan on Friday, where the group will meet with several influential Japanese politicians.

DOC.HEADLINE: US DOLLAR DOWN

TEXT.P: The US dollar dipped NT$0.32 against the New Taiwan dollar on the Taipei foreign exchange market on Thursday, finishing at NT$32.2.
The greenback opened at 32.378, and was traded between 32.15 and 32.56.
Interbank US dollar trading reached US$380 million.

DOC.HEADLINE: 16TH ROUND OF ROC-US WTO TALKS ENDS WITH SATISFACTORY RESULTS
DOC.DATELINE: Washington, Dec. 17 (CNA) (By Herman Pan and Sofia Wu)

TEXT.P: The 16th round of negotiations between the Republic of China and the United States over terms for Taiwan to join the World Trade Organization (WTO) concluded on Wednesday with satisfactory results.

"The two-and-half-day talks have achieved major breakthroughs on many topics related to protocal issues, government procurements and insurance market opening," said Chen Ruey-long, head of the ROC delegation.

Chen, also director-general of the Board of Foreign Trade, told a news conference at the end of meeting that the two sides still need consultations on certain policy-related issues, such as staging of tariff reduction for a number of sensitive agricultural and industrial products and opening of professional services.

"We'll discuss unsolved thorny issues via fax and hope to work out mutually acceptable measures before the end of next January," Chen said, adding that if all technical issues can be settled by then, ROC Economics Minister Wang Chih-kang will travel to Washington, D. C. next February to seek major breakthroughs on policy-related issues, particularly those related to tariff-quota administration on imports of such sensitive products as rice, alcohol, tobacco, pork, chicken meat and animal intestines.

During his February visit, Wang is expected to meet with the US Trade Representative to push for an early conculsion of the bilateral WTO talks to facilitate Taiwan's entry to the Geneva-based world trade regulatory body.
Chen outlined the concrete results achieved at the 16th round of talks as follows:
-- On government procurement-related issues, Taiwan has agreed to open more industrial products to foreign bidders two years after its WTO entry.
-- Taiwan will revise its insurance law after entering the WTO to allow foreign mutual insurance companies with net worth of more than NT$2 billion (US$61.35 million) to open branches in Taiwan.

-- Taiwan will open its markets to foreign-made motorcycles with 150 cc engines or larger two eyars after its WTO accession and to finalize necessary reforms of its commercial port construction surcharge collection system within 15 months following its WTO entry.

--Taiwan has also promised to scrap a regulation requiring coal importers to simultaneously purchase Taiwan-produced coal and to sign an international commercial aircraft agreement immediately after it joins the WTO.

Chen said staging of tariff reduction for certain sensitive agricultural and industrial products remains the greatest obstacle in ROC-US WTO talks. The United States demanded that Taiwan gradually lower its tariff rates on a number of agricultural and industrial products to WTO standards by 2004 and that tariff cuts for most of those products should be completed by 2002. Taiwan has difficulties meeting such deadlines, Chen noted.
The US is one of the three WTO members that have yet to finalize bilateral accession terms negotiations with the ROC. The other two are the 15-member European Union and Switzerland.

DOC.HEADLINE: TAIWAN ON ALERT FOR BIRD FLU

TEXT.P: Officials and experts in health, agriculture, police administration, customs and quarantine affairs from all over the nation gathered on Thursday to try to figure out a way of preventing an epidemic of the "bird flu" which has afflicted Hong Kong.

The Council of Agriculture (COA) under the Executive Yuan, which convened the meeting, emphasized that the island should be alert to "bird flu," although the epidemic, caused by the H5N1 influenza strain which originally appeared in chickens, has not been conclusively proven to be harmful to humans.
According to the latest foreign wire reports from Hong Kong, there are currently nine suspected or confirmed cases of "bird flu" in humans, two of which have been fatal.

The H5N1 virus has never been reported in Taiwan, but despite this, the COA still urged Taiwan people who plan to visit Hong Kong in the near future to be especially careful with regard to sanitation, while the National Quarantine Service (NQS) has posted large posters at Chiang Kai-shek International Airport in Taoyuan, warning visitors to Hong Kong to avoid contact with poultry.

The NQS posters also advise tourists in Hong Kong to try to avoid spending too much time in public places. Anyone who feels sick or uncomfortable, or who is suffering from "flu-like symptoms," should see a doctor immediately, the signs say.

The so-called H5N1 strain, known to experts since 1961, is spread through airborne droplets, like a normal flu. Experts worldwide so far remain in doubt as to whether the virus can spread from person to person.

DOC.HEADLINE: NO REASON FOR SINGAPORE DOLLAR TO WEAKEN, SAYS MAS

TEXT.P: The Monetary Authority of Singapore (MAS), Singapore's de facto central bank, said on Wednesday that Singapore's economic fundamentals are strong and it sees no reason for the Singapore dollar to weaken.

In a written reply to press queries, the MAS said it intervenes in the foreign exchange market from time to time to iron out short-term fluctuations and that it does not publicize its exchange rate operations.
"As Singapore's economic fundamentals remain sound, we see no reason that the Singapore dollar should weaken," it said.
The Singapore dollar firmed at below 1.68 to the US dollar on Wednesday, partly because of talk that the MAS had intervened in the market.
This followed a slump in the currency to a more-than six-year low of 1.7047 on Tuesday.

The Singapore dollar has lost nearly 7 percent against the US dollar in the last three trading days as players have sold it down on the perception it needs to weaken further for Singapore's exports to remain competitive regionally.

DOC.HEADLINE: LAOTIAN PRIME MINISTER VISITS PHILIPPINES

TEXT.P: Philippine President Fidel Ramos on Thursday officially welcomed Laotian Prime Minister Khamtay Siphandone who is on a two-day official visit to the Philippines.

Following the official welcome, Siphandone paid a courtesy call on Ramos, while the two first ladies also met to exchange views on the environment, women's roles in national societies, livelihood training, and agriculture and forestry.
Ramos and Siphandone then went to Rizal Park for traditional wreath-laying ceremonies at the monument of Philippine national hero Jose Rizal.
The Laotian prime minister and his wife were guests of honor later in the evening at a banquet hosted by the president.

DOC.HEADLINE: INDONESIA ENJOYS US$7.7 BILLION FOREIGN TRADE SURPLUS

TEXT.P: Indonesia enjoyed a foreign trade surplus of US$7.7 billion in the January-November period this year, Industry and Trade Minister Tunky Ariwibowo said here on Wednesday.
He said the value of the country's exports in the period reached US$39.5 billion and its imports US$31.8 billion.
The value of non-oil exports was recorded at US$30.8 billion, the minister said after reporting the status of the country's trade balance to President Suharto.
Tunky said that, compared to the same period of last year, the value of imports was down by 0.5 percent. He added, however, that most of the imports were non-oil products valued at US$28.8 billion.
He said the surplus of US$1.9 billion in non-oil trade was recorded at only US$1.5 billion.
He said he had previously hoped non-oil exports this year could reach US$42 billion.

Tunky said he had reported to the president that the price of cooking oil had gone up in the last few months because producers had preferred to export the commodity rather than sell it at home following the increasing price of crude palm oil (CPO).
In view of that situation, the government decided that 75 percent of the country's CPO production had to be reserved for domestic demand, with the other 25 percent being allowed for export.
Tunky said producers would provide 350,000 tons of CPO equivalent of cooking oil although the monthly domestic demand is only 150,000 to 200,000 tons.

He said the government also planned to impose an additional tax on CPO exports, adding that the tax schedule would be made known to the public after he had discussed the matter with the finance minister.

DOC.HEADLINE: ROC AMBASSADOR TO DOMINICA PRESENTS CREDENTIALS
DOC.DATELINE: Panama City, Dec. 17 (CNA) (By Edward Chen and Flor Wang)

TEXT.P: Katherine S.Y. Chang, the new Republic of China Ambassador to the Commonwealth of Dominica, on Tuesday presented her credentials to Dominica President Crispin Sorhanindo.

Expressing her appreciation for Dominica's support of the ROC in the international community, Chang vowed to further strengthen bilateral relations, as the two countries share the same aspirations for democracy, freedom, justice and human rights. She also conveyed ROC President Lee Teng-hui's greetings to Sorhanindo.

For his part, Sorhanindo thanked the ROC for the wide-ranging assistance the nation has extended to Dominica and praised the outstanding performance of the ROC agricultural missions stationed in his country. He also asked Chang to convey his greetings to Lee.

On Tuesday night, Chang hosted a dinner party at a local hotel which was attended by more than 100 guests, including Dominica Prime Minister Edison James, cabinet members, parliamentary members of both the ruling and opposition parties, and representatives of foreign diplomatic missions.

In an interview with a local television station on Tuesday night, Chang criticized Beijing's attempts to hamper the ROC's relations with its diplomatic allies in the Caribbean, pointing out that the ROC's substantive assistance to Dominica in its infrastructure and agricultural development is a far cry from Beijing's checkbook diplomacy.
She repeated her promise to take measures to cement bilateral cooperative ties and thanked the support the Dominica government and its people have provided to the ROC.
Chang, the ROC's first female ambassador, returned to her residence in nearby Saint Christopher and Nevis on Wednesday.

DOC.HEADLINE: ROC AMBASSADOR TO GRENADA PRESENTS CREDENTIALS

TEXT.P: ROC ambassador to Grenada Lin Yung-lo on Wednesday presented his credentials to Grenada governor Sir Daniel Williams and conveyed best personal regards to Williams on behalf of ROC President Lee Teng-hui.
Lin said that since the ROC and Grenada established diplomatic relations in 1989, bilateral cooperation has expanded into political, economic, agricultural and cultural fields.

Most of all, the people and governments of the ROC and Grenada share the same beliefs in democracy, freedom, international justice and human rights. Over the past years, the two countries have cooperated on issues of mutual concern as part of efforts to contribute to the international community.
Lin pledged to boost the ROC's ties with the Caribbean country on the foundation of the already-close cooperative relations and friendship.
Williams welcomed Lin to Grenada, adding that he was especially pleased to hear Lin say that he will do his best to pursue closer bilateral relations.
Williams said that the ROC and Grenada have maintained good relations since the two countries established diplomatic relations.
The governor expressed the hope that the two countries will spread peace and friendship to the world and help every member of the international community lead a peaceful and happy life.
Prior to his meeting with Williams, Lin visited Grenada Foreign Minister Raphael Fletcher and presented a copy of his credentials to him.

Lin also met with Grenada Prime Minister Keith Mitchell, the chief of the foreign diplomatic corps stationed in Grenada, and Venezuelan ambassador to Grenada Teofilo Labrador, as well as chief of the opposition party, George Brazan.

DOC.HEADLINE: ROC HOPES RELATIONS WITH S. KOREA WILL IMPROVE

TEXT.P: The Republic of China hopes the relations between Taipei and Seoul will begin to improve after South Korea's presidential election, Spokesman Roy Wu of the Ministry of Foreign Affairs said Thursday.
South Korean voters went to the polls to elect their president Thursday.
Wu said the severance of diplomatic relations between the two countries in August, 1992 has caused a great damage to the government and people of the two countries.

The two countries enjoyed mutually beneficial relations before the unfortunate disruption of formal relations, Wu said, adding that the Republic of China hopes the relations between the two countries will begin to improve after the South Korean presidential election.
The outlook for Taipei-Seoul relations will good and beautiful, he said, if the relations are based on the principles of mutual respect, sincerity, and goodwill. (by Ed Hsieh)

DOC.HEADLINE: TAIWAN SETS 1998 ECONOMIC GROWTH AT 6.7 PERCENT

TEXT.P: Premier Vincent Siew Thursday agreed to preliminarily set the country's 1998 economic growth rate at 6.7 percent, as proposed by the Council for Economic Development (CEPD).
Siew said he agreed to the proposal after hearing a briefing made by CEPD Chairman Chiang Pin-kung on the council's 1998 plan for national development.

Taiwan's economy has grown 6.7 percent in 1997, while consumer price index has risen only 1.1 percent. To help maintain the record of high economic growth and low inflation, the CEPD proposed to preliminarily set next year's goal for economic growth at 6.7 percent.

Siew said after the briefing that the current financial turmoil in Asia will inevitably affect world trade and the financial market next year. He urged all relevant government agencies to map out plans to weather the financial storm, so that the economy of the country will continue to grow as planned next year.
Under the CEPD plan, Taiwan's economy will grow 6.4 to 6.7 percent and the consumer prices will increase no more than 3 percent in 1998. (by Ed Hsieh)

DOC.HEADLINE: WTO PREDICTS GLOBAL GROWTH IN TRADE OF SEVEN PERCENT FOR 1997

TEXT.P: The Geneva-based World Trade Organization (WTO) predicted on Thursday that global growth in trade will be around 7 percent in real terms for 1997.

In the new "WTO Annual Report 1997," the world trade body stated that world trade and output growth are expected to accelerate in comparison to 1996. The report's early assessment of trade in 1997 is based on economic indicators available at the time of writing in August 1997.
Events during the fall are not captured in the assessment. Nevertheless, it appears that the 7 percent figure remains broadly in line with expectations.

The effects of developments in Asian financial markets will become apparent in data for 1998. Regarding the Southeast Asian region, the report maintains that, while recent developments in the financial sector in a number of these countries will continue to pose policy challenges in the months ahead, most of the economies concerned are expected to grow at rates above the world average in 1997.

The WTO annual report highlights some of the major trends in trade policy during 1997. For example, on Feb. 15, 69 governments agreed to wide-ranging liberalization measures in basic telecommunications services.
On March 26, forty governments agreed to cut customs duties on information technology products, beginning on July 1, 1997, with the aim of eliminating all duties on these products by 2000.

International trade in information technology products amounts to some US$600 billion annually, while domestic and international revenue generated in the basic telecommunications sector is roughly the same amount.

In its review of developments in world trade in 1996, the report provides a more detailed analysis, confirming and expanding on the findings of the WTO secretariat's preliminary assessment published in April 1997.
The report examines in greater depth trade flows by region and product, intra-trade of regional integration agreements, and trends in commercial services trade.
World trade slowed down markedly in real and nominal terms in 1996.
Real merchandise exports grew by 5 percent -- much less than in the two preceding years -- but remained above the sluggish growth rates of the early 1990s.
There was also a general slowdown by region, with only Africa on the export side and Latin America on the import side recording higher growth in 1996 than in 1995.
The analysis is supported by a full volume of trade statistics and charts.

DOC.HEADLINE: ROTARY INTERNATIONAL TO CHECK NAME CHANGE ISSUE

TEXT.P: Rotary International President Glen W. Kinross said on Thursday that he was unaware of the name change of Taiwan's official designation registered in the organization and pointed out that the world body, devoted to promoting goodwill and peace, would not interfere in political issues.
Kinross stressed that Rotary International has not come under pressure from Beijing, as, in compliance with the organization's charter, only democratic countries are entitled to host Rotary chapters.

According to C.K. Huang, former chairman of the Rotary Club in Taipei, the name change issue which arose during a September gathering of Asian-Pacific Rotary members in Bangkok aroused strong protests from Rotarians from Taiwan. The ROC chapter's designation was changed from "Taiwan in ROC," into "Taiwan China" at the meeting, Huang said.

Rafael G. Hechanova, one of the 19 board members of Rotary International, said he will raise the issue at the organization's next board meeting to allow relevant personnel to fully understand the seriousness of the matter.

Glen, who arrived here on Wednesday for a week-long visit, also praised the remarkable performance of Taiwan Rotarians, who have raised more than US$1 million in funds, one of the top-ten largest amounts among Rotary Clubs worldwide, for Rotary International programs to help the poor around the world.

As an organization committed to helping abused children and poor people around the world, Glen said Rotary International has constructed 1,500 buildings for the poor in Asia and that its efforts to eliminate poliomyelitis has paid off, as the epidemic has been eradicated almost everywhere, except for some countries in Africa and in Pakistan.
He urged greater efforts from the 1.2 million Rotarians worldwide to help prevent children from becoming victims of sexual abuse and violence.
Accompanied by local Rotarians, Glen also visited a park in downtown Taipei which was built with a US$500,000 donation from Taiwan Rotarians.

DOC.HEADLINE: COMMITTEE DELAYS DECISION ON BAYER'S LAND-LEASE CONTRACT

TEXT.P: A committee of the Taiwan Provincial Assembly delayed making a decision on the controversial Bayer investment project on Thursday, instead referring the German chemical giant's land-lease contract to an ad hoc panel for further study.

The transportation committee of the assembly instructed a panel which has been set up exclusively for the project to consult public opinion more thoroughly and review Bayer's environmental protection measures before reporting back to the committee.

The committee, which has the options of either approving the contract and sending it to the full floor for final approval by the assembly, or turning it down, chose to withhold its decision pending more careful consideration, while about one thousand anti-Bayer activists demonstrated outside the assembly building.
The latest twist in the controversy makes it very unlikely that the land-lease contract will receive a green light before the end of the year, since the assembly is to recess on Friday.

Bayer Taiwan Chairman Horst Mueck, whose company has threatened to withdraw the project unless granted the lease before the end of the year, said he regretted the committee's decision, adding that he will inform the firm's German headquarters of the new development and await further instructions.
Meanwhile, P.K. Chiang, Chairman of the Council for Economic Planning and Development, urged Mueck to postpone any hasty decision and give the island another chance.

The architect of Taiwan's policy aimed at transforming the island into a regional operations hub expressed his worry that a divestment by Bayer on the island will undermine the operational hub project.

Government Information Office chief David Tawei Lee also urged Bayer to continue to make its case vigorously to the public and not to scrap it too hastily. He also promised that the central government will try to persuade the ad hoc panel of the Taiwan Provincial Assembly to give the plan a fair review.

Although welcomed by the central government, Bayer's plan to build a NT$50 billion chemical plant in Taichung County on land rented from the provincial government, is opposed by local conservationists and residents who claim the firm wants to bring in obsolete and potentially dangerous technology.
The future of the plant plunged deeper into uncertainty when a anti-Bayer activist and a member of the opposition Democratic Progressive Party was elected county magistrate on Nov. 29.

Liao Yung-lai, who grabbed the county's top job on a promise of putting the project to a referendum, has set the central government's teeth on edge by pledging to block construction of the plant if the voters veto the project in the upcoming referendum.
He and his supporters also called on the Provincial Assemblymen to reject the firm's request for a lease.

DOC.HEADLINE: FITTING TRIBUTE TO A BRAVE FIREFIGHTER

TEXT.P: The family of one of the victims of a gas explosion which has claimed the lives of 14 people since the accident occurred in September in the southern city of Kaohsiung, has decided to use part of their compensation to buy an ambulance and donate it to the Kaohsiung Fire Department.

Hwang Juei-lin, 30, a firefighter, was seriously injured when he and his colleagues, who were first at the scene of the explosion, were trying to control the flames following the huge gas explosion Subsequent blasts caught Hwang off-guard, causing him to suffer burns to 95 percent of his body.

Hwang was rushed to the 806th Army Hospital for treatment, where doctors amputated his legs to save his life. His condition remained stable until Tuesday night, when he suddenly succumbed to complications from his injuries.

The explosion on Sept. 13 occurred when workers from the China Petroleum Corp. (CPC) were attempting to move a gas pipe as part of a road-widening project. The careless workers failed to check if the pipe had been purged of gas before cutting it, leading to a series of three huge explosions. Three people were killed outright, while 22 were hospitalized.

His mother said Hwang, who she adopted when he was only 40 days old following his parents' divorce, got along quite well with his two older sisters and two younger sisters. She described Hwang as always ready to help others.

As a firefighter, Hwang was used to being first at the scene of accidents to rescue people. When a fire broke out at a restaurant in Taichung, central Taiwan, in February 1995, Hwang was among the first firefighters to reach the scene. He succeeded in rescuing a number of people from the fire, which took the lives of 64 customers who were dining in celebration of Valentine's Day.

Hwang asked for a transfer to Kaohsiung City one year ago to be closer to his long-time girlfriend, who lives in the southern city. They had been together for 13 years and had planned to get married in October in a mass wedding held by the Kaohsiung government, his mother said.

For the past three months, Hwang's fiancee has been on a leave of absence from her company, a department store in Kaohsiung, in order to go to the hospital every day to accompany and take care of him.

Hwang's mother said that although the family has yet to receive the NT$13 million compensation promised by the CPC, they have decided to buy an ambulance at a cost of NT$3 million, which they will name "Juei Lin," in memory of her brave son.
She said the ambulance will be donated to the Kaohsiung Fire Department on Dec. 29, coinciding with the day of Hwang's funeral.

DOC.HEADLINE: VIETNAM AGREES TO DISCUSS TRADE PACTS WITH TAIWAN

TEXT.P: Vietnam has agreed to start negotiations with Taiwan on avoidance of double taxation and commercial arbitration to boost bilateral trade, Vice Economics Minister Chang Chang-pang said on Thursday.
Chang, who has just returned from a trip to Vietnam, said that he met with Vietnam Premier Phan Van Khai, who also agreed to send an official delegation to Taiwan.

Chang described Phan as being surprised by Taiwan's ability to withstand the current Asian financial crisis which has seen many of its neighbors, including South Korea, devalue their currencies and turn to the International Monetary Fund to try to weather the storm.
Chang attributed the island's smooth avoidance of the financial turmoil to its sound economy, tiny foreign debt and huge reserves of foreign capital.

Professing keen interest in Taiwan's thriving small- and medium-sized enterprises, and its successful science-based industrial parks, Phan accepted Chang's invitation to send a fact-finding team to Taiwan in the near future, said Chang.

Noting that Vietnam's restrictive business regulations force many Taiwan businessmen to invest there through local front-men, Chang said this is an issue that will be high on the agenda of forthcoming bilateral negotiations.

DOC.HEADLINE: ROC CONGRATULATES KIM DAE-JUNG ON WINNING ELECTION

TEXT.P: The Republic of China government on Friday congratulated veteran South Korean opposition leader Kim Dae-jung on his election as the next head of state of his country.

"We congratulate Kim on his electoral victory," Roy Wu, spokesman for the Ministry of Foreign Affairs, said, adding that the ROC looks forward to reinforcing relations with Kim's administration based on the principles of equality and reciprocity.
Wu said the termination of long-standing formal diplomatic ties between the ROC and South Korea in August 1992 was an "unfortunate historical event."
"Even though it was Seoul, not Taipei, that should be held responsible for the breakoff, the ROC still attaches great importance to its relations with South Korea," Wu said.
Since the two countries are close neighbors and share a long-term friendship, Wu said he sees no reason the ROC and South Korea cannot continue to maintain reciprocal cordial relations.

"We hope the new South Korean government will learn from historical lessons, treasure its traditional friendship with the ROC and take positive forward-looking measures to normalize bilateral relations with sincerity, good will and mutual respect," Wu urged, adding that by so doing, both countries will benefit and regional stability and prosperity will also be further guaranteed.

Taipei-Seoul relations have remained at a low ebb since South Korea switched its diplomatic recognition to Beijing in August 1992. In retaliation, the ROC cut direct air links with South Korea shortly thereafter. Direct flights between the two countries have not yet been resumed.
Kim, 73, head of the National Congress for New Politics, won Thursday's South Korean presidential election by capturing slightly more than 40 percent of the vote.

The spiritual leader of South Korean political dissent said recently that if he won his presidential bid, he planned to take concrete steps to improve relations with Taiwan and substantially increase bilateral nonpolitical exchanges.
