DOC.HEADLINE: TAIWAN RATED AS FREE COUNTRY BY FREEDOM HOUSE
DOC.DATELINE: Washington, Dec. 18 (CNA) (By Edward Han & Elizabeth Hsu)

TEXT.P: Taiwan is listed as one of the world's 81 free countries by the US-based Freedom House in its 1997 global survey on the status of democracy, individual liberties and political rights.

The privately funded organization on Thursday released the annual survey, which divides the nations of the world into three categories -- free, partly free, and not free -- based on a set of criteria which rates 191 countries and 60 territories according to their degree of respect for political rights and civil liberties.

In the evaluation, a scale of one to seven is used to evaluate the democratic conditions in each of the countries and territories, with a score of between one and 2.5 constituting the "free" category to indicate an overall respect for civil and political rights.

Scores in the three to five range are given to those entities considered "partly free," which indicates the presence of widespread corruption, legal injustice, racial conflict or civil war that serves to curtail the level of civil and political rights.

The nations and territories receiving a score of between 5.5 and seven are labeled as "not free" and citizens in those areas enjoy almost no degree of democracy under repressive governments or tyrannical leaderships that deprive citizens of their most basic rights.

Mainland China, although enjoying a fast-developing economy over the past few years, is rated "not free," receiving the lowest possible score of seven. There are a total of 53 countries in that category.

Taiwan, listed along with the mainland as an "independent country," is ranked in the "free" category, an indication that its efforts toward promoting individual freedoms, political democracy and social equality have born fruit.

As for Hong Kong, it is categorized as a "territory" under Beijing's rule and is considered "partly free." The survey found the former British colony has witnessed less freedom since Beijing took control of its sovereignty in July.
Another mainland territory -- Tibet -- is rated by Freedom House as one of the world's five least free areas.
Under Beijing's rule, the Freedom House survey found that Tibetans, who have different lifestyles and customs from the Chinese, are granted few civil liberties, not to mention political rights.
Freedom House is a nonprofit organization dedicated to promoting democratic values around the world.

DOC.HEADLINE: US DOLLAR UP

TEXT.P: The US dollar rose NT$0.111 against the New Taiwan dollar on the Taipei foreign exchange market Friday, finishing at NT$32.311.
The greenback opened at 32.498, and was traded between 32.305 and 32.55.
Interbank US dollar trading reached US$233.5 million.

DOC.HEADLINE: AUSTRALIA'S POPULATION EXCEEDS 18.5 MILLION

TEXT.P: Australia's population has increased by 1.2 percent in fiscal 1996-97 to more than 18.5 million from the previous year, but the average age of Australians has also risen, according to the Australian Bureau of Statistics (ABS).
The ABS figures show the average Australian is now 34.3 years old, compared to an average age of 28.6 years in 1977.
The number of Australian women over 85 has increased by 7 percent in the past 12 months -- five times the growth rate for the general population, according to the ABS.

The ABS reported that there are now 216,100 people aged over 85, compared to 87,900 about 20 years ago, a rise of 146 percent. The gender gap also widens -- there are twice as many women over 85 as there are men.

DOC.HEADLINE: FINANCIAL CRISES MAY BE LOOMING IN MAINLAND CHINA: REPORT

TEXT.P: Beijing is facing three major economic problems, and its currency is under growing pressure to depreciate, according to a research report made by the Committee of Economic Research and Development of the Ministry of Economic Affairs (MOEA).

The report, released Friday at a symposium in Taipei on how to deal with the financial situations in South Korea and mainland China, said the renminbi is now under growing pressure to depreciate, because the circulation of the currency has increased by more than 50 percent since Beijing changed its foreign exchange regulations in 1994, and because mainland China is facing three major economic problems.
It is however hard to tell at the present time whether a serious financial crisis will surface soon in mainland China, the report said.

It pointed out that the recent drastic devaluation of Southeast Asian currencies may blunt mainland China's competitive edge in the world markets, and the lowering of tariffs in October on 4,874 items of commodities by 26 percent will certainly encourage mainland Chinese imports. Mainland China's trade surplus may plummet as a result.
Foreign investment in mainland China is expected to reduce next year because of the financial and stock market turmoils in many Asian countries, bringing another economic problem to mainland China.
Mainland China's shaky financial structure could also cause a serious problem when the financial crisis in Asia is getting worse, the report added. (by Ed Hsieh)

DOC.HEADLINE: SPECIAL TEAM SEEN NEEDED TO SETTLE CRISIS IN INDONESIA

TEXT.P: Leading businessman Bambang Trihatmodjo on Thursday called for the establishment of a special team of professionals to help the government tackle the economic crisis currently facing the nation.

Bambang, who is President Suharto's second son, told reporters on the sidelines of a People's Consultative Assembly (MPR) meeting that such a team was needed to follow up on the president's general economic policies.
He also called on his father to include players from the private sector along with government officials.
"I really hope Pak Harto (Suharto) will set up a special team to handle the crisis," he was quoted by the Jakarta Post as saying.
He said that the reason for the team was the current cabinet ministers' reportedly slow response and poor initiative in handling the crisis.

"That's the reason why I suggested the establishment of the special team," said Bambang, who was also hit by the crisis when a bank he partially owned, Bank Andromeda, was closed down by the government on Nov. 1.
Indonesia's economic turmoil took a turn for the worse last week and earlier this week when rumors spread that Suharto had died and that a coup attempt was brewing.

DOC.HEADLINE: ROC-PANAMANIAN TIES REMAIN SOLID: MOFA

TEXT.P: Relations between the Republic of China and Panama will remain solid even after the Central American country signed an agreement with mainland China to upgrade the status of its representative office in Hong Kong, a senior official with the Ministry of Foreign Affairs said on Friday.

Huang Lung-yuan, director of the ministry's Central and South American Affairs Department, said Panamanian President Ernesto Perez Balladarez reassured Taipei of his country's firm commitment to the ROC only last week.

According to Huang, Balladarez had asked Panama's Labor and Social Welfare Minister Mitchell Doens and Housing Affairs Minister Francisco Sanchez Cadenas to convey a message to that effect to the ROC when the two Panamanian officials visited Taiwan earlier this month.
"Balladarez has directed the two ministers to assure us that friendly relations between Panama and the ROC will remain unchanged," Huang told a news conference.

Foreign wire service reports said Panama and mainland China signed an accord at the United Nations headquarters in New York on Wednesday to upgrade Panama's provisional economic and trade office in Hong Kong to a formal office.

The pact was signed by Ambassador Leonardo Kam, Panama's permanent representative to the UN Office in Geneva, and Qin Huasun, mainland China's permanent representative to the United Nations, the reports said.

Commenting on that development, Huang said the change in the designation or status of Panama's representative office in Hong Kong will by no means affect long-term cordial relations between the ROC and Panama.

Panama was forced to close its consul general in Hong Kong on July 1 this year when Beijing took control of the territory. With Beijing's consent, Panama set up a provisional economic and trade office in Hong Kong to handle commercial and shipping affairs following Hong Kong's handover.

DOC.HEADLINE: SHARE PRICES DROP ON TAIEX

TEXT.P: Share prices plunged 2 percent on the local stock market Friday with major issues falling across the board, dealers said.
The brokers pointed out that technology-related shares were dumped as investors remained pessimistic toward the performance of electrical engineering stocks on the market.

The bearish sentiment also dragged down other issues, they added, which in resulted the Taiwan Stock Exchange (TAIEX) weighted price index plunging 161.47 points to close at the day's low of 8,092.58.
The bourse opened at 8,205.83, and reached a high of 8,305.83 before reversing directions.
Losers overwhelmed gainers 368 to 71, with 31 shares unchanged.
A total of 3.27 billion shares changed hands on a market turnover of NT$162.3 billion (US$5.07 billion).
All eight major stock categories encountered losses, with electrical engineering issues falling the sharpest at 4.5 percent.

Construction shares followed with a 3.6 percent plunge, ahead of the 3.3 percent drop posted by plastic and chemical stocks, 2.9 percent by textile issues, 2.1 percent by foodstuff shares and 2 percent by cement stocks, while paper-making and banking issues both charted a 1.7 percent decline.

The 10 companies with the largest turnover were: China Trust Commercial Bank, Chang Hwa Bank, Dah An Bank, International Bills Finance, United Micro Electronics, Taiwan Semiconductor Manufacturing, Grand Bank, BES Engineering, China Life Insurance, and ACER.

DOC.HEADLINE: RULES OF EXCHANGE BETWEEN TAIWAN AND HONG KONG AFTER 1997: MAC

TEXT.P: With the long anticipated year of 1997 now coming to an end, what of the regulations concerning exchanges between the people of Taiwan and Hong Kong?

Since its handover to Beijing's rule on July 1, 1997, Hong Kong has been regarded by the government of the Republic of China as a special region separate from other parts of the Chinese mainland. Exchanges between people of Taiwan and residents of Hong Kong are regulated in accordance with the Statute on Relations with Hong Kong and Macao, the Taipei-based Department of Hong Kong and Macao Affairs of the Mainland Affairs Council (MAC) remarked on Thursday.

According to officials of the department, "Hong Kong residents" refers to those persons who are permanent residents of Hong Kong and who do not hold passports issued by the government of Great Britain or any other country besides the Hong Kong government.

As to whether ROC citizens and civil servants can visit Hong Kong after 1997, officials of the Hong Kong and Macao Affairs Department said persons entering Hong Kong will follow normal regulations and will not be subject to special restrictions, while residents of Hong Kong entering Taiwan must have approval from the ROC authorities.

Due to changes in the legal and political status of Hong Kong and Macao after 1997 and 1999, respectively, the ROC government has made a series of parallel adjustments in its policy toward those two territories.

The fundamental principle behind the new statute was that as long as the two territories retain a high degree of autonomy, the ROC government will regard them as special regions separate from the rest of the Chinese mainland.

Officials of the Hong Kong and Macao Affairs Department took an additional step in stating that, as Hong Kong residents are no longer considered overseas Chinese after July 1, 1997, the ROC government will no longer issue identification certificates to residents of the territory. However, for Hong Kong residents who hold overseas Chinese identification papers issued by the ROC government before July 1997, the certificates will remain valid.

After July 1997, the ROC government stopped issuing passports to Hong Kong residents. But persons who possess passports obtained before the territory's change of status can renew the documents through regular procedures, the officials stressed.

DOC.HEADLINE: ROC ENVOY FORESEES THAW IN TIES WITH SOUTH KOREA
DOC.DATELINE: Seoul, Dec. 19 (CNA) (By Y.C. Chiang and Sofia Wu)

TEXT.P: The Republic of China's de facto ambassador to South Korea said on Friday that he foresees a thaw in Taipei-Seoul relations following the inauguration of newly elected South Korean President Kim Dae-jung next spring.

Lin Tsun-hsien, head of the Taipei Mission in Korea, which represents ROC interests in South Korea in the absence of formal diplomatic ties, made the optimistic forecast after the veteran South Korean opposition leader won Thursday's presidential election for the National Congress for New Politics.
Lin said the ROC representative office had maintained close contacts with the three main contenders -- Kim Dae-jung, Lee Hoi-chang and Rhee In-je -- in the run-up to the election.

He further pointed out that Kim Dae-jung's associate, Kim Jong-pil, chairman of another opposition party, the United Liberal Democrats (ULD), has been very friendly toward the ROC. The two opposition parties cooperated to defeat the majority ruling Grand National Party in the latest presidential race.

Kim Jong-pil, a veteran rightist politician who once served as prime minister during the presidency of the late Park Chung-hee, played a crucial role in helping Kim Dae-jung win his fourth bid for the presidency.

Lin said Kim Jong-pil is the most friendly toward Taiwan among the leaders of the various South Korean political parties. He has consistently attended the annual ROC Double Ten National Day reception sponsored by the Taipei representative office in Seoul. He is also the only prominent South Korean politician who has not yet visited Beijing.

Lin said he earnestly hopes that the inauguration of the Kim Dae-jung administration will open a new chapter in ROC-South Korean relations, which have remained at a low ebb since Seoul switched diplomatic recognition from Taipei to Beijing in August 1992.
Touching on the possibility of resuming direct air links between Taipei and Seoul, Lin said there is no timetable for the resumption of direct flight services.

Taiwan cut direct air links with South Korea shortly after Seoul established formal diplomatic ties with Beijing. Over the past five years, South Korea has repeatedly expressed its desire to resume such links.

Lin said the ROC is willing to discuss the issue with South Korea based on the principles of equality and reciprocity. "In the process of negotiation, we hope South Korea will respect our sovereignty and national dignity," he stressed.

Lin also confirmed that all three major South Korean presidential candidates had approached his office to explore the possibility of the ROC offering loans to cash-hungry South Korea, but pointed out that as the ROC and South Korea currently have no diplomatic ties, the two sides have yet to formally discuss the issue.

Liu Tai-ying, the chief financier of the ROC's ruling Kuomintang, suggested after a recent fact-finding trip to South Korea that the ROC offer US$10 billion in loans to South Korea to help it weather its current financial crisis.

Lin said if the ROC really wants to assist South Korea after the inauguration of the new South Korean government, aid could be given in the form of investment in its capital market or industries in addition to offering loans. South Korea has opened its capital markets to foreign investors, and foreign nationals can now hold up to a 50 percent stake in Korean companies.

On the development of relations with North Korea, Lin said South Korea basically does not object to foreign countries' engagement with Pyongyang, so long as such developments do not disrupt South Korea's national security and the stability of the Korean peninsula.

While engaging North Korea, Lin said the ROC has consistently abided by the principles that engagement should be in Taiwan's national interests, should not affect the ROC's international image, and should not jeopardize regional stability and peace in Northeast Asia.

DOC.HEADLINE: BAYER SUSPENDS INVESTMENT PROJECT IN TAIWAN (I)

TEXT.P: Bayer Taiwan announced on Friday that it will suspend a project to invest in a petrochemical plant in central Taiwan, saying it will now pursue contingency plans to build the plant in the United States.
Bayer said in a statement Friday that it was disappointed that "after 24 months of intense negotiations on our investment project in Taiwan," talks on the project will be suspended immediately.

It said that despite the fact that an environmental impact assessment has been finalized, the Taiwan Provincial Assembly has decided not to review the land-leasing agreement with Bayer or to set a clear time frame for the finalization of the approval process.

The provincial assembly on Thursday decided not to review the lease agreement until its next session. The agreement would lease land in the Taichung Harbor area to Bayer for a period of 50 years for the purpose of constructing the chemical plant.

Bayer said it was deeply disappointed over the aborted project, especially after its intensive efforts to convince authorities on Taiwan as well as the local public of the project's benefits. Alternate plans to locate the plant in Baytown, Texas, will now be pursued.

But Horst Mueck, chairman and president of Bayer Taiwan, said that though the project has been suspended, the present investment and operations of Taiwan Bayer, as an independent company, will not be affected.

Mueck said the suspension only means the company will cease efforts on that particular project. As to whether there is any chance of its revival, he stressed that decision will be up to Bayer headquarters in Germany.

Bayer Taiwan spokesman Chen Chia-chung said the company lost about US$10 million because of its abandonment of the proposed project. He added that the local company was instructed to suspend the proposal because authorities on Taiwan had not given a clear time frame for beginning the project, which Bayer deemed unacceptable.
Meanwhile, government officials and business leaders here expressed shock over Bayer's announcement, saying it has dealt a heavy blow to the image of Taiwan.

Economic Affairs Minister Wang Chih-kang said although Taiwan has been rated by the London-based Economist magazine as the third best area for investment stability, the island's efforts in that regard could go down the drain with the withdrawal of Bayer's project.

To avoid a domino effect upon other ongoing investment projects, Wang said, he will begin communication with 21 cities and counties around the island starting next month, and at the same time will continue to solicit foreign investment.
But Wang also said that the Bayer case has set a bad example, noting that it will fuel the uncertainty about investment in Taiwan and will put a damper on the local investment climate as well.

He said that businessmen are concerned over the future of Taiwan's industrial development. The economics minister pointed out that the Democratic Progressive Party (DPP) has always claimed it is not opposed to business, and stated that it is high time for the opposition party to match its words with deeds. (to be continued)

DOC.HEADLINE: BAYER PROJECT(II)

TEXT.P: Business leaders echoed Wang's words by saying that the case will deal a blow to the local investment environment, and they blasted the government for failure to exercise its authority.

Wang You-chang, chairman of the General Chamber of Commerce of the ROC, said that the case has damaged the image of Taiwan. He lamented that the project, which has been in the pipeline for so long, could be reversed in a single day because of the newly elected Taichung County magistrate, referring to Liao Yung-lai of the DPP, who had vowed to hold a public referendum to decide to fate of the project.

Chu Chih-yang, chairman of the Council for Industrial and Commercial Development, said the government should put itself in Bayer's shoes, asserting that Taiwan businessmen would also decline to go overseas if they had to pass a public vote by the local people.

Kao Chin-yen, chairman of the Chinese National Federation of Industries, said the government should care more about overseas investment to insure that foreign investor do not have to worry about other such impediments.

Lin Min-ling, speaker of the Taichung County Council, regretted Bayer's decision, saying that irreparable damage has been made and that the credibility of Taichung and even of Taiwan has been compromised.
Meanwhile, efforts to salvage Bayer's NT$49 billion (US$1.5 billion) investment project continued on Friday, despite the company's announcement.
P.K. Chiang, chairman of the Council for Economic Planning and Development (CEPD), called on the Premier Vincent Siew to report on the handling of the case.

Chiang said he has talked with Liu Ping-wei, speaker of the Taiwan Provincial Assembly, over the phone on Friday, hoping that the assembly will pass a conditional resolution to provide a final opportunity to keep the project in Taiwan.
Chiang said Bayer had told him that if the assembly could pass a conditional resolution, the company headquarters would still be willing to proceed with the project.
However, as the assembly closed its current session on Friday morning without making any solid promise, Bayer was left in limbo, according to Chiang.
Chiang said the CEPD, which is responsible for pushing through the project, will not abandon its efforts on the project until the final moment.

The assembly's decision not to review the land-lease agreement was considered the last straw for Bayer, following calls earlier in the month for a public vote on the project, which also came as an unexpected development for the German chemical giant.

DOC.HEADLINE: AIR FORCE DECOMMISSIONS AGING C-119 TRANSPORTS

TEXT.P: The Republic of China Air Force on Friday formally decommissioned its C-119 transport aircraft which have been in service for 43 years, an air force spokesman said.

The ROC established its first squadron of C-119s, better known as "the Flying Boxcar" in November, 1954, taking over many of the craft left behind by the US troops who moved out of Taiwan at that time.

The air force began to phase out its C-119 fleet after 1981, when it started to become difficult to obtain spare parts and components, eventually leaving Squadron No. 103, based at Pingtung airport, as the last unit in the world using the lumbering planes.

The spokesman said that the four C-119s of Squadron No. 103 are still in good shape and that one of them will carry out its last mission on Saturday when it flies to the Hsinchu airbase, where it will be delivered to a technology college in northern Taiwan for education purposes.

The spokesman said that during its years of service, the fleet successfully carried out two very important missions: transporting back to Taiwan, without the backup of in-air refueling or satellite\radar guidance, former ROC army troops trapped in the border area between Thailand and Laos in 1961; and airlifting relief goods to flood victims in the Philippines in 1972.
The spokesman said that the C-130 Hercules transport aircraft now forms the backbone of the air force's transport fleet.

The air force currently has 17 of the huge planes following the loss of one in a crash on Oct. 10, and is expected to take delivery of another four which were ordered last year at a cost of US$50 million apiece.

He said the air force is also considering purchasing either Indonesian-produced CN-235 planes or a new type of transport aircraft manufactured by the Lockheed Martin Company of the US to fill the gap left by the C-119s.

DOC.HEADLINE: LEE HSIEN LOONG APPOINTED MAS CHAIRMAN

TEXT.P: Singapore's Deputy Prime Minister Lee Hsien Loong has been appointed Chairman of the Monetary Authority of Singapore (MAS) with effect from January 1, 1998, the Singapore Prime Minister's Office announced on Friday.
He will assume the MAS chairmanship concurrently to replace Dr. Richard Hu who will continue to be Minister for Finance.

Lee Ek Tieng was appointed Deputy Chairman of the MAS, Singapore's de facto central bank, with effect from January 1, 1998, the announcement said. He will continue as head of the civil service and permanent secretary of the prime minister's office.

Koh Yong Guan, permanent secretary, Ministry of Health, and second permanent secretary, Ministry of Finance, was appointed managing director of MAS, also with effect from January 1, 1998. He will keep his Health Ministry post but relinquish his Ministry of Finance position.
All three appointments will be for a two-year term, the announcement said.

DOC.HEADLINE: ENGLISH WILL BE LESS IMPORTANT IN 50 YEARS

TEXT.P: English will decline in importance in the next century, but it will still remain the world's most influential language in 2050, American linguist David Graddol predicts.
It will still be the only language which is usable in every part of the world, but languages such as Chinese, Hindi and Spanish will compete in influence with it in their respective regions, he said.

Graddol has developed a model to forecast the spread of languages around the world in the British Council's publication "The Future of English?" He presented his findings at the Fourth International Conference on World English held in Singapore on Friday.

Explaining how his forecast model worked, he said it uses United Nations demographic projections for each country, calculates the proportion of people in the country who now speak each language, and makes some forecasts about the future.
Based on these estimates, Chinese will be spoken by the largest number of people in the world, with Hindi/Urdu and Spanish coming next.
Following are the top 10 languages in 2050, as forecast by Graddol:
Native speakers (millions) Young native speakers
(aged 15 to 24)
1. Chinese 1,384 Chinese 166
2. Hindi, Urdu 556 Hindi, Urdu 74
3. English 508 Arabic 72
4. Spanish 486 English 65
5. Arabic 482 Spanish 63
6. Portuguese 248 Portuguese 33
7. Bengali 229 Bengali 32
8. Russian 132 Russian 15
9. Japanese 108 Japanese 11 10. German 91 Malay 11
But as the number of speakers alone does not determine how influential a language will be, other economic and social indicators are also used.
For example, Chinese was spoken as a first language by the most number of people in the world in 1996, with over one billion native speakers.
English had only 372 million first-language speakers, but was more influential in the world of ideas and the global economy, because of its "economic strength," Graddol noted.

In his models, he derived a crude index of "economic strength" by assigning a proportion of Gross Domestic Product and trade in each country to different languages according to the pattern of language use in each country.
Because of the economic might of the United States today, English tops the league in all of these categories, with German, French and Japanese following in sequence.
English also retains its premier position if social indicators such as literacy rates and education provisions are factored in.
The following chart shows the global influence of the world's major languages at present:
1. English 100 (index of 100 represents the
position of English in 1995)
2. German 42
3. French 33
4. Japanese 32
5. Spanish 31
6. Chinese 22
7. Arabic 8
8. Portuguese 5
9. Malay 4 10. Russian 3
Graddol predicted that the development of technology and globalization will decrease the influence of English, rather than increase it.

He said an increasing amount of content will be produced in local languages. "Already, on the Internet, you can use your web browser in a variety of languages, you can translate web documents with a click of the mouse.
"On satellite television, more programs are being beamed in local languages," he added.
At the same time, English will continue to be a useful "neutral broker" and be used by foreigners who share no common language, he said.

"The future is going to be more plural. It won't be an either-or situation. People will be more multi-lingual, and different languages within each region are going to become more important," he concluded.

DOC.HEADLINE: INTERIOR MINISTRY INVESTIGATING MYSTERIOUS CULT ACTIVITIES

TEXT.P: The Ministry of the Interior said on Friday that its religious affairs department will investigate activities of the so-called "God Saves the Earth Flying Saucer Foudnation," which has not formally registered with the ministry.
"We'll deal with the case in accordance with the law if the mysterious cult is found to have any activities violating the Criminal Code or other domestic regulations," said a ministry official.
According to media reports, about 120 Republic of China nationals have traveled to the United States in preparation for mass suicide in Garland, Texas next March.
Commenting on the reports, the ministry official said although the constitution provides for religious freedom, religious activities should not violate existing laws and regulations.
The official said the ministry has asked county and city governments to help probe mysterious cult activities.

Foreign Ministry spokesman Roy Wu confirmed that the ROC's representative offices in Los Angeles and San Francisco had recently helped a family of four, who had joined the mysterious cult, the God Saves the Earth Flying Saucer Foundation, return to Taiwan.

The family, including a couple and their two children, went to the US together with other members of the cult to attend cult activities. As the couple's father, identified only by his surname "Chou," worried about their safety, he asked the Foreign Ministry to assist in advising his offspring to return home.
Wu said many other cult members are believed to still stay in the US. As the ministry didn't have a list of cult members, it's not easy to trace their whereabouts.
Wu said the ministry has requested the US Federal Bureau of Investigation and police authorities to help investigate the cult's activities and ensure the safety of cult members from Taiwan.
Wu said minisitry officials stationed in Los Angeles, San Francisco and Houston will offer all necessary assistance to cult members if they want to return to Taiwan.
Meanwhile, the Criminal Investigation Bureau said it will contact Chou and his family in order to learn more about the cult's activities.

Chou, who runs a convenience store in Homei township in the central Changhua County, said his son and daughter-in-law were not happy after their return. "They would brief the public on the cult's doctrine and activities after they regained calm," he said.
Chou's daughter and her family, also members of the cult, have not yet returned to Taiwan.

According to media reports, the cult has recruited some 200 members in the past few years. Many of the members have said they wanted to seek peace in the United States, compalining about rising crime and declining moral standards in Taiwan.
A key member of the cult was quoted as saying that mainland China would invade Taiwan in 1999 so the members would seek salvation from God in a farm in Garland near Dallas, Texas next March.

The members who have traveled to the US reportedly included more than 20 children because the cult encourages entire families to kill themselves so that their bodies could be picked up by flying saucers.

According to a report by the Hsinchu County Police Headquarters, the cult once applied for accreditation with the Interior Ministry under the name of the ROC Soul Research Association. The Interior Ministry said it will check whether the two groups have any correlation.

DOC.HEADLINE: TAIWAN CULT MEMBERS EMIGRATE TO US FOR GOD'S BLESSING
DOC.DATELINE: Houston, Dec. 18 (CNA) (By P.C. Hu & Elizabeth Hsu)

TEXT.P: "How it is possible for us to conduct a collective suicide as we have all chosen to leave Taiwan for the same reason -- to escape from an expected disaster which will occur in 1999?" a member of the so-called "Truth Cult" said here on Thursday.

The cult member from Taiwan, surnamed Wu, made the remarks in an interview with CNA to explain the cult's belief and rebut a report alleging that the members are planning to kill themselves to seek eternal life.
Wu said their organization has different beliefs from another cult which claims that "God" or "super intelligent beings" will pick up the remains of the believers in flying saucers.

Recent newspaper reports from Taiwan indicated that over 100 members of the so-called "God Saves the Earth Flying Saucer Foundation" have left for Dallas, Texas, where they are said to be planning to commit mass suicide so that their bodies can be picked up by UFOs.
Over the past two years, approximately 200 Taiwan people have been recruited by the US-based cult, the reports said.

Wu, who holds a doctorate, told CNA that he, like the other members of Truth, joined the cult because they believe they can find peace and safety in the United States. They are looking for life here, not death.
However, the cult member acknowledged that he still expects to go to heaven, a place without disaster and hardship, under God's guidance.
The Truth Cult is currently supervised by a Chinese man, identified as Chen Heng-ming, who has predicted that the world will end in 1999, while Taiwan will be destroyed one year earlier, in 1998.

Accordingly, Chen has asked his Taiwan followers to emigrate to the US, which he describes as the last pure land in the world. The cult leader also pointed out that Garland, near Dallas, where Wu and the other Truth members from Taiwan are living, is blessed with luck.

DOC.HEADLINE: PM SIEW: ROC NEEDS U.S. SUPPORT FOR ITS BID TO JOIN WTO

TEXT.P: Premier Vincent Siew said Friday that the Republic of China desires U.S. support for its bid to join the World Trade Organization.
Siew made the remark when he met with U.S. Rep. Eddie Bernice Johnson (D-TX).

"The United States is our most important trade partner," he said, adding that "We hope to finish the consultation with the United States on the terms for us to join the World Trade Organization as soon as possible."
Siew pointed out that the United States exports more to Taiwan than to mainland China, and that, in term of per capita import, Taiwan is virtually the biggest importer of American products in Asia.
Besides economic development, Taiwan has also made great achievements in democratization and promotion of human rights, he added. (by Ed Hsieh)

DOC.HEADLINE: BEIJING URGED TO REOPEN CHANNELS OF CONSULTATION WITH TAIPEI

TEXT.P: The Mainland Affairs Council (MAC) of the Executive Yuan Friday urged mainland China to reopen the channel of consultation with Taiwan.
Beijing unilaterally closed down the consultation channel after President Lee Teng-hui's visit to his alma mater in the United States in the summer of 1995 angered Beijing leaders.

Soon after that, the Association for Relations Across the Taiwan Strait (ARATS), an unofficial intermediary organization set up in Beijing in 1991 to handle cross-strait exchanges in the absence of formal relations, sent a message on June 16, 1995 to its counterpart in Taipei, the Strait Exchange Foundation (SEF), saying that "We will keep in touch with you again at an appropriate time in the future."

MAC spokesman Hseu Ke-sheng said Friday in a regular press conference that both parties have the responsibility to keep the "institutionalized" channel of consultation open, as the establishment of the channel was agreed upon by the two parties after careful negotiations.

To facilitate the work to fight cross-strait smuggling, drug trafficking, and other crimes, and to resolve other problems caused by increased civilian exchanges, it is necessary to reopen the consultation channel, he said.
He urged Beijing to honor the promise given in the above message and begin consultations on matters of mutual concern. (by Ed Hsieh)

DOC.HEADLINE: FORECAST PUTS CONSUMER PRICE INDEX GROWTH AT 3 PERCENT NEXT YEAR

TEXT.P: In an economy forecast for next year, a local research institute has put the growth of the consumer price index (CPI) at 3.34 percent, and predicts that the New Taiwan dollar will weather the current financial storm to surge to an average of 30.14 to the US dollar.

The Chung-Hua Institute for Economic Research, a non-profit civil think-tank, attributed the CPI's relative low growth of 1.4 percent in 1997 to a bumper harvest and the foot-and-mouth disease (FMD) epidemic which swept the island's swine population early this year.

The institute said the epidemic, which prompted many countries to ban pork imports from Taiwan, diverted Taiwan's huge stocks of pork destined for export to the domestic market, helping to curb CPI growth.
However, the institute pointed out, it also provided a relatively lower base against which next year's inflation will be measured, and this may result in a correspondingly higher CPI growth rate.

That factor, combined with the devaluation of the local currency, the impact of which is expected to be felt next year in the form of import price hikes, is estimated to drive up the CPI by 3.34 percent.
Putting aside the unpredictability of the local bourse, the institute estimated that private spending will grow by 6.59 percent, against the 7.65 percent figure recorded for 1997.

That estimate was based on the launch of the new five-day work week next year and the NT dollar's stronger buying power against the currencies of Southeast Asian nations, despite rising prices which might dampen consumers' willingness to spend.
Private sector investment will continue this year's trend by growing by 12.11 percent.

Taiwan's exports are expected to post a meager gain of 8.25 percent next year because its competitive advantage gained through NT dollar devaluation will be eroded by further depreciation of Southeast Asian currencies, said the institute.

Imports of military equipment will keep expanding at 7.33 percent, against 13.18 percent recorded this year, a reduction caused more by the broadening of its calculating base than any actual cuts in military expenditure, said the institute.

DOC.HEADLINE: AUSTRALIA TO HELP MAINLAND CHINA WITH MARKET REFORMS

TEXT.P: Australia has pledged to launch a A$20 million program to help mainland China develop its market economy by sending public sector experts to Beijing and other mainland cities.
The program was announced by Prime Minister John Howard when he greeted mainland China's Vice Premier Li Ruihuan in a reception in Sydney earlier this week.
Howard said the Australian experts will help mainland China undertake developments in finance, taxation, enterprise reform, social security and public sector administration systems under the program.
Li, who ranks fourth in the Beijing leadership, is the most senior mainland Chinese official to visit Australia.

Bilateral ties between the two countries in 1996 were strained by a series of incidents, including Australia's support of the US deployment of two aircraft carriers to Taiwan during a mainland Chinese missile shooting practice off the island, the sending of a senior Australian minister to Taipei, the visit of the Dalai Lama to Australia and the renewal of a defense and military pact between Australia and the US

Ties improved with the first official visit of Prime Minister John Howard to Beijing in late March this year, followed by trips to mainland China by Deputy Prime Minister Tim Fischer, Foreign Minister Alexander Downer and other senior Australian ministers.
Australia switched diplomatic ties to mainland China from Taiwan in late 1972, But Canberra still maintains unofficial relations, including trade, culture and sports, with Taipei.
Mainland China is facing a serious problem in its state enterprise sector due to its mounting debts and inefficiency, and is trying to privatize its state-owned firms.
But the state enterprises, numbering more than 300,000 and employing over 100 million people, are a very hard nut to crack.
The Australian government will send its public sector specialists to advise mainland China on ways of tackling the problems.

During the meeting, Howard and Li spoke of political differences between Australia and mainland China, but they said they preferred to set aside the differences and work on economic cooperation so that both countries can benefit.
"It is not always bad to have differences because it is the differences... that render necessary exchanges and cooperation," Li said.

DOC.HEADLINE: TAIWAN STANDS FIRM ON UNIFICATION PRINCIPLES: MAC HEAD
DOC.DATELINE: Paris, Dec. 18 (CNA) (By M.C. Chou and Flor Wang)

TEXT.P: The Republic of China government stands firm on its mainland policy of promoting the unification of China, and any accusation by the international community that it is seeking to hamper China's unification is unfair, Chang King-yuh, chairman of the cabinet-level Mainland Affairs Council (MAC), said here on Thursday.

The ROC government has stuck to and will continue sticking to the three phases set out by the Guidelines for National Unification to achieve eventual unification with mainland China, Chang said, adding that this has been and will continue to be Taiwan's stance on the issue, despite the recent victory of the major opposition Democratic Progressive Party in local elections on Nov. 29.

Chang made the remarks at a meeting with members of the local press and academics while responding to questions on the current state of relations across the Taiwan Strait and potential developments between the two sides.

Chang said that since the ROC government lifted a ban on cross-strait travel in 1987, it has always actively advocated cross-strait exchanges, pointing out that the mainland is the one which is trying to jeopardize harmonious cross-strait ties, as Beijing has spared no efforts in trying to block bilateral activities and isolate Taiwan in the international community.

Answering question from a reporter from Agence France-Presse on the impact of the meeting between US President Bill Clinton and mainland Chinese President Jiang Zemin in late October, Chang repeated that the ROC government will not interfere in US dealings with mainland China and that the US should maintain parallel relations with Taiwan and not sacrifice the interests of Taiwan's 21 million people while seeking to improve ties with the mainland.

He added that the US assured the ROC government that no secret agreement was reached in the Clinton-Jiang meeting and that Washington has repeated its call that the two sides of the Taiwan Strait should resolve their disputes through peaceful means.

Responding to the question on Taiwan's increased trade reliance on the mainland Chinese market, Chang said the ROC is a free country which will not fully ban Taiwan businesses from investing on the mainland, but added that it must impose some restrictions to forestall any potential investment risks.

He went on to say that it will be hard for the two sides of the Taiwan Strait to achieve economic integration if mainland China continues to hinder Taiwan's efforts to take part in international activities and refuses to renounce the use of force against Taiwan.
Despite mainland China's efforts to blockade the island, Chang said Taiwan is still willing to help the mainland develop its economy and upgrade its standards of living.
On the "one China, two systems" issue, Chang said the ROC government will never accept Beijing's formula for unification.

Citing Hong Kong as an example, Chang said the former British colony has experienced a setback in its democratic and legal systems, as well as a noticeable reduction in the number of tourist arrivals, since its reversion to Beijing's rule in July under the "one China, two systems" scheme.

He said that Taiwan and the mainland can only create a "win-win" situation when Beijing recognizes the reality that the two sides are two separate political entities and treats Taiwan on an equal footing based on mutual trust and reciprocity.

Chang, who arrived here from Madrid on Wednesday after concluding the annual national development council meeting with Taiwan academics and experts residing in Europe which took place there, is scheduled to proceed to Brussels on Friday and next to Bonn, to explain the ROC's mainland policy to the local press and political sectors there.

DOC.HEADLINE: GERMAN TRADE OFFICE REGRETS SUSPENSION OF BAYER PROJECT

TEXT.P: The German Trade Office in Taipei on Friday expressed regret over the German-based Bayer Group's decision to suspend its first proposed investment project in Taiwan.

Gunther Tetzner, director of economic affairs of the German Trade Office in Taipei, said his office believes the multinational chemical giant's decision to suspend the project was based on careful consideration and study and that they understand and respect Bayer's decision.

Tetzner said Bayer's decision to suspend its proposed project to set up a chemical production base in Taichung County, central Taiwan, will inevitably cause concern and uncertainty among foreign investors, but added that the degree of impact on foreign investors' willingness to invest in Taiwan remains to be seen.

Although Bayer's decision should not be interpreted as a result of Taiwan's investment climate getting worse for foreign investors, the German Trade Office in Taipei still regrets the abandonment of the NT$49 billion investment project, he added.

Horst Mueck, chairman and president of Bayer Taiwan, announced earlier in the day that as the multinational had failed to obtain the land required for the construction of its proposed plant in Taichung County, the investment project will be suspended immediately.

The European Council of Commerce and Trade (ECCT), which issued a statement earlier this month expressing its worry that the new Taichung County chief-elect insisted on linking the fate of Bayer's project with a proposed referendum in his county, refused to make any further comment on the issue.
ECCT Secretary General Richard Tangye said on Friday that the council has already made its stance on the issue very clear and it would be improper to make any comment at this time.

On learning of Bayer's announcement, the Democratic Progressive Party's magistrate-elect for Taichung County Liao Yung-lia expressed the hope that Bayer won't get discouraged by the setback, adding that Bayer is welcome to locate in Taichung County if the project it introduces is non-pollutant and safe.

Liao, who opposed the Bayer project on the grounds that it would have brought excessive levels of pollution and might have posed a threat to public safety, asserted that the central government should take part of the responsibility for Bayer's suspension of the investment project.

He said that even though the project had passed the central government's environmental impact assessment, the local residents had no faith that the government would have the ability to monitor the chemical plant. In past years, the government has disappointed his constituents many times by failing to control or deal with pollution problems in the county, he added.

DOC.HEADLINE: NO SALARY CUTS FOR INDONESIAN GOVERNMENT WORKERS

TEXT.P: Indonesia will not cut the salaries of its government employees as have Thailand and Malaysia, because this will not ease the monetary crisis, State Minister for Administrative Reforms T.B. Silalahi said on Friday.
"What is best for other countries may not be good for us," Silalahi was quoted by Antara as telling a seminar on administrative studies at the State Administrative Institute.
Indonesia has been actively promoting the welfare of its government employees, in an effort to improve their performance, he said.
"How could we cut their salaries in this situation?" he asked, adding that government employees in Thailand and Malaysia are more prosperous than their Indonesian counterparts.
Silalahi said the best way to face the monetary crisis is to tighten the budget, for instance by limiting expenditures for travels and private parties.

DOC.HEADLINE: ASIAN CRISIS HITS AUSTRALIA'S ECONOMIC RECOVERY

TEXT.P: Asia's financial crisis will hit Australian economic recovery this year and reduce the country's gross domestic product by half a percentage point in the following year, although the government can still achieve a budget surplus in its first term (from March 1996 to early 1999).
In a mid-year economic and fiscal outlook report, Federal Treasurer Peter Costello described the crisis as "the biggest financial meltdown we have seen in our lifetime in the region."
He said the Asian crisis will limit Australia's GDP growth to 3.75 percent in fiscal 1997-98 and knock about 0.5 percent off its GDP growth to 3.25 percent in 1998-99.
He predicted the crisis will almost halve Australia's export growth this year from 7 to only 4 percent.

"We are in the midst of major external challenges at the moment. If it had not been for Asia, both this year and next year would have seen substantially stronger growth than we are now forecasting," he said.

"If not for the impact of developments in East Asia, the continuation of the momentum in domestic growth achieved in 1997-98 would have likely led to significantly stronger growth in 1998-99," he said.
Earlier this year, the government forecast the GDP would grow by 4 percent or even higher.
The report also forecast that stronger economic activity in Australia, combined with softer export growth, will see the current account deficit increase substantially over the next two years.

DOC.HEADLINE: ALL SINGAPORE AIRLINES FLIGHTS TO BE SMOKE-FREE

TEXT.P: Singapore Airlines (SIA) announced on Friday that all SIA flights worldwide will be smoke-free from February 1, 1998, fulfilling its commitment towards providing smoke-free services.
SIA's efforts were recognized in 1995, when the World Health Organization awarded SIA the World No-Tobacco Day medal and citation for that year.
Currently, SIA operates over 1,000 services each week, of which more than 90 percent are already smoke-free.
The exceptions are non-stop flights originating or terminating in Japan. From Feb. 1, 1998, these flights will also be non-smoking services, SIA said.

It said the daily Singapore-Tokyo-Los Angeles service went smoke-free in October 1994, by which time SIA had already phased out smoking on all services except those to Japan. At the beginning of last month, SIA's Singapore-Taipei-Tokyo and Singapore-Taipei-Osaka services followed suit, it added.

SIA first introduced smoke-free travel on shuttle flights between Singapore and Kuala Lumpur in April 1988, and in December 1993 SIA became the world's first airline to offer a smoke-free service between the United Kingdom and Australia, SIA said.

DOC.HEADLINE: MULTINATIONALS MAINTAIN FAITH IN ASIA

TEXT.P: Most US and European multinational companies with sales or factories in Asia have shrugged off the recent currency turmoil and are committed to the region and their investment goals, according to reports from the Geneva-based World Trade Organization (WTO) on Friday.

A survey by Renaissance Technomic, the US management consultants, of the regional managing directors of 35 large multinationals found that, while one-third considered the region to be less attractive since the currency crisis, 79 percent were not planning to change their strategy, the WTO report said.

The findings are in contrast to a survey in 1994 of large companies exposed to Mexico in the wake of the peso's devaluation. Steven Ganster, managing director of Renaissance's Asian consultancy, was quoted as saying: "With Mexico, more companies said: `We have to cut our overheads, sales forces and operating costs to minimize the damage.'"

The survey of companies operating in Asia, including ICI, BASF and Hoechst from Europe, and General Motors, Tenneco and Dow Chemical of the US, found that only around 15 percent were left significantly worse off because of the regional crisis. This group included companies such as Whirlpool of the US, which have no local plants and whose only exposure to the region is as importers of their own products manufactured elsewhere.

Manufacturers with local plants felt the devalued currencies offered opportunities to integrate their operations further through the buyout of dealers or distributors or the purchase of greater stakes in joint venture partners. A small group felt themselves in a stronger position post-crisis.

Some 14 percent foresaw stronger sales in 1998 and the same proportion expected increased rates of return. The beneficiaries were mainly exporters from the region who expected that the devalued currencies would lead to increased shipments, offsetting tighter margins.

Some 60 percent of the executives questioned believed the currency instability would last until the end of 1998 or beyond, with Thailand expected to undergo the longest period of instability. Most believed it would take three to four years for the region to recover to pre-crisis levels.

DOC.HEADLINE: CANADA'S SAGGING TRADE SURPLUS SAID SIGN OF ASIAN FLU

TEXT.P: Canada's trade surplus took a tumble in October, prompting suspicion this might be a signal of what the financial turmoil in Asia could mean to the North American country's economy.

Government statistics released Thursday show that Canada's exports slipped 0.6 percent to C$25.07 billion (US$17.8 billion) in October because of a slide in the exports of resource commodities such as forestry and energy products.

Meanwhile, Canada's imports grew by 2.7 percent to C$24.5 billion, with gains in every product sector except energy. As a result, Canada's trade surplus slipped in October to a 4-year low at C$581 million.
The October surplus was down from C$1.37 billion in September. And for the first 10 months of 1997, the surplus was C$19.37 billion compared with C$35.46 billion for the same period of 1996.

Statistics Canada and most economists attribute the shrunken surplus to a healthy economy that has resumed its taste for imports. But some economists are adding the Asian crisis to their list of explanations.
Sherry Cooper, chief economist at Nesbitt Burns, said the damage to resource exports was an early sign of what Asia's problems could mean to the Canadian economy.

"Export prospects are hardly encouraging, given the hit to commodity-related shipments from the Asian flu, and the fact that Canadian manufacturers are already operating at around full capacity (87.5 percent operating rate)," she noted.
Sal Guatieri, senior economist at the Bank of Montreal, said the Canadian dollar's appreciation against many Asian currencies had made goods from this country expensive in those markets.

Randall Powley, economist at Scotiabank, said what happened to the resource shipments was understandable given the Asian situation. But he was puzzled that industrial goods would fall 2.7 percent in October after a rise of 1.1 percent in September.

DOC.HEADLINE: INDONESIA'S TYCOONS URGED TO RESTRAIN DOLLAR BUYING

TEXT.P: Four organizations under the patronage of Indonesian Development Cadres (KPI) have urged Indonesian conglomerates to withdraw their private accounts from overseas banks and to restrain their US dollar purchases.
The four organizations, GAKPI, WPI, GPPI and MPI, submitted their petition to the People's Consultative Assembly Working Body Chairman Poedjono Pranyoto here Thursday.
Afifah Elansary, representing the organizations, also asked the Indonesian people to strengthen their trust in the rupiah currency.
"Our nationalism is calling on us, particularly the tycoons, to withdraw our private accounts to the country," he was quoted by Antara news agency as saying.
KPI Chairman H.M. Muas said that the country needed quicker reactions to overcome the worsening monetary turmoil.
"So, they (conglomerates) have to immediately withdraw their private savings from overseas banks."
Muas added that his organization would launch a nationwide "love the rupiah" movement.
On the impact of the recent liquidation of 16 insolvent banks, KPI called on the businessmen not to lay off their employees since it would increase the unemployment rate.

KPI also supports the economic reform conducted by the government and the government's efforts to fight against corruption, collusion, power abuse and other unethical practices to create a cleaner government, Muas said.
The organization also expressed support for the nomination of Indonesian President Suharto for another term.

DOC.HEADLINE: DPP CHAIRMAN REGRETS ABANDONMENT OF BAYER PROJECT
DOC.DATELINE: Tokyo, Dec. 19 (CNA) (By Chang Fang-min & Lin Wen-fen)

TEXT.P: Hsu Hsin-liang, chairman of Taiwan's main opposition Democratic Progressive Party (DPP), said on Friday that he felt regret and sorrow over the suspension of German-based Bayer Group's first investment project in Taiwan.

Hsu made the remarks while answering questions from reporters upon his arrival at Narita Airport in Tokyo. Hsu is leading a six-member DPP delegation on a foreign mission, which has already taken them to South Korea before arriving in Japan for a four-day visit.

Hsu said that Bayer executives in Taiwan once told him that if the multinational chemical giant failed to obtain the land-lease in central Taiwan for the construction of a proposed chemical plant by Dec. 29 (Friday), Bayer would consider relocating the investment project to the United States.

Asked if Bayer's setback will be seen as being a result of an "anti-business" complex on the part of the DPP, Hsu said that DPP headquarters is quite concerned about the NT$49 billion investment and will do its best to communicate with the local government on the issue.

Bayer's investment project in Taichung County, central Taiwan, had faced strong opposition from some local residents on the grounds that it would have produced excessive levels of pollution and would have posed a threat to public safety. The DPP's magistrate-elect in Taichung County, Liao Yung-lai, had insisted on imposing a referendum on the Bayer project to decide its fate.

Based on the fact that the project passed a central government environmental impact assessment, Taiwan Provincial Government approved a land lease earlier this week which allows the provincial government to lease 90 hectares of land in the Taichung Harbor area to Bayer for a period of 50 years. The Taiwan Provincial Assembly, which had the final say on the fate of the contract, however, refused to grant its approval.

Hsu said that he hopes the dispute over the project can be resolved through communication, adding that once he completes his Japan visit and returns to Taiwan, he will contact Liao, as well as Bayer Taiwan, to discuss the issue.

DOC.HEADLINE: CHINA AIRLINES TAKES DELIVERY OF NEW PLANE

TEXT.P: Taiwan's China Airlines (CAL) took delivery of a new passenger aircraft on Friday. The Boeing 747-400 is CAL's ninth and the 50th plane to join the company's fleet. It's purchase also makes the air carrier the island's largest in terms of fleet size.
The airline said another 13 new aircraft are expected to join the fleet next year, including three more Boeing 747-400s, two A300-600Rs and eight 737-800s, in addition to a used 747-400 cargo plane.
Setting a revenue target of NT$90 billion (US$2.72 billion) by 2003, the company said that by that time, its fleet will have expanded to 70 aircraft.

DOC.HEADLINE: FIRST TWIN-LOBE LUNG TRANSPLANT CARRIED OUT IN KAOHSIUNG

TEXT.P: The Kaohsiung Veterans General Hospital in southern Taiwan announced on Friday that surgeons there in November successfully performed Taiwan's first-ever two-lobe lung transplant operation.

The team, led by H.C. Hsu, director of the hospital's thoracic department, spent more than nine hours transplanting a pair of healthy lungs into Lai Lee-chih, a 34-year-old computer programmer belonging to the Rukai aboriginal tribe.

Lai, who had suffered from chronic bronchitis and asthma from his early youth, was sent to the Kaohsiung Veterans General Hospital for treatment, where it was discovered that his lungs were functioning at only about 16 percent of the capacity of a healthy person's. Hospital authorities began to consider a lung transplant because Lai's life was threatened by his condition, which was deteriorating.
Lai had to wait for nine months until October, when a pair of lungs donated by the 37-year-old victim of a car accident became available and were found to have compatible blood and cell type.

One month later, Lai currently remains in stable condition, despite having been treated for complications in the hospital's intensive care unit. Lai has now been transferred to a normal ward and is expected to be able to leave the hospital in one week.

A spokesman for the Kaohsiung Veterans General Hospital said that although the hospital has carried out eight lung transplants, six of which have been successful, it was the first time a twin-lobe transplant had been performed.

DOC.HEADLINE: PRESIDENT LEE PRESIDES OVER HIGH-LEVEL ECONOMIC CONFERENCE

TEXT.P: Although Taiwan has been relatively unaffected by the financial woes sweeping much of the region, President Lee Teng-hui on Friday called on his senior economics officials to guard against any turmoil and to ensure the smooth development of Taiwan's economy.

After being briefed at an urgently convened economic conference on the current economic situation, the president lauded the fact that the country's sound economic fundamentals have shielded it from the regional economic crisis.
Given the increasing integrity of the economies in the region, however, the president urged his economics staff to monitor closely the unfolding of the crisis, and brace for future challenges.

The conference brought together Vice President Lien Chan, Premier Vincent Siew, Secretary General to President Huang Kun-huei, Secretary General of National Security Council Ding Mou-shih, Economics Minister Wang Chih-kang, Chairman of the Council for Economic Planning and Development P.K. Chiang, and Governor of the Central Bank of China Sheu Yuang-dong.

Those attending were told that the crisis gripping Southeast Asia stems from the collapse of the so-called "bubble economy," deficits in current accounts, heavy foreign debts, small foreign reserves, over-reliance on the inflow of foreign capital and rigid foreign exchange rates.

On the other hand, Taiwan's capability to withstand the crisis is based on its steady macro-economy, surplus in its current account, few foreign debts, a gradual process of opening up its markets to foreign investment, and a sound financial system.

The participants, from Lien Chan down, also credited the island's smooth avoidance of economic turmoil to President Lee Teng-hui's "avoid haste, exercise restraint, tread gingerly to attain long-lasting stability" policy toward mainland China, which they said should remain the island's guiding principle in dealing with the mainland.

DOC.HEADLINE: PREMIER SIEW CALLS ON BAYER TO WAIT

TEXT.P: Premier Vincent Siew on Friday called on the German-based Bayer Group to have second thoughts on its decision to suspend its proposed multi-billion dollar investment project in Taiwan.

Siew expressed the hope that the international chemical and pharmaceutical giant will go ahead with its investment project in Taichung County, adding that Bayer should not make any crucial decision until the screening of a land lease by the Taiwan Provincial Assembly.

Based on the fact that the project passed a central government environmental impact assessment, The Taiwan Provincial Government earlier this week approved a land lease which allows the provincial government to lease 90 hectares of land in the Taichung Harbor area to Bayer for a period of 50 years.

However, the Taiwan Provincial Assembly, which has the final say on the fate of the land lease, refused to review the contract in its current session which ended on Friday, saying that a task force formed in the assembly needs more time to gain a better understanding of public opinion of the project.

Siew said that he has already ordered P.K. Chiang, chairman of the Council for Economic Planning and Development (CEPD) to contact Bayer and try to persuade the multinational not to give up the project. Chiang will also urge the Taiwan Provincial Assembly to complete and make public the report on the project in due course, Siew added.

While calling on the people of Taiwan to treasure their hard-earned economic achievement, Siew noted that if Taiwan wants to maintain its high economic growth rate next year amid the financial turmoil in the rest of Asia, it must strengthen its investment incentives to attract more local and foreign investment.

Siew stressed that the protection of the environment and the development of industries are equally important for a country and that the two things should not necessarily conflict with each other. Taiwan won't develop its economy at the expense of the environment, he added.

DOC.HEADLINE: STOCK OPENS HIGHER

TEXT.P: Share prices on the Taiwan Stock Exchange (TAIEX) opened higher Saturday, with the weighted price index rising 57.45 points to 8,150 soon after the opening of trading.
Exchange turnover reached NT$7.54 billion (US$235.63 million).

DOC.HEADLINE: TAIWAN NATIONAL KILLED IN SILKAIR AIRLINE CRASH

TEXT.P: A Taiwan national is among the 104 victims aboard a Singaporean SilkAir flight on Friday which crashed on the Indonesian island of Sumatra, a Republic of China Foreign Affairs Ministry spokesman confirmed here on Saturday morning.
Roy Y.Y. Wu told CNA that the ROC national has been identified as Hwang Li-ming.
Two of the victim's family members have already left for Singapore, according to the Taipei office of Singapore Airlines Ltd. (SIA) owner of the regional SilkAir airline.
The airline said the grieving relatives have refused to grant press interviews and have asked the company not to disclose news concerning Hwang's case.

The ill-fated SilkAir flight MI185 came down in a swampy area near the city of Palembang in Sumatra on its way to Singapore from Jakarta. All 104 passengers, including the seven-member crew of the Boeing 737-300 aircraft are feared dead, Indonesia's state Antara news agency reported.

DOC.HEADLINE: IMF SEES LOWEST ECONOMIC GROWTH FOR NIE'S IN 1998
DOC.DATELINE: Washington, Dec. 19 (CNA) (By Bear Lee & Herman Pan)

TEXT.P: Asia's newly industrialized economies (NIEs) will see average economic growth decline to a 14-year low of 3.6 percent in 1998 as a result of the ongoing financial turmoil that has embroiled many of the nations in the region, according to the International Monetary Fund (IMF).

In a response to CNA queries, a spokesman for the IMF's economic research department said that the 1997 average growth for NIEs -- Taiwan, South Korea, Singapore and Hong Kong -- will reach 6.2 percent, 0.3 percentage points higher than an earlier IMF forecast, due to better-than-expected performances from Taiwan and South Korea.
He said that Taiwan's economy is expected to grow 6.7 percent this year, next only to Vietnam (9 percent), the Chinese mainland (8.8 percent), and Malaysia (7 percent).

With the impact of the financial crisis looming, the IMF has made a downward adjustment of the 1997 economic growth forecast for Hong Kong and Singapore, to 5.3 percent and 6.2 percent, respectively, while raising that of South Korea, which didn't suffer until recently, to 6.2 percent, due to its strong exports.
For 1998, the spokesman said, the growth rates for Hong Kong and South Korea will decline to 4.1 percent and 2.5 percent respectively.

He said that the 2.5 percent growth forecast for South Korea may be "too optimistic" as Seoul has accepted the IMF's bailout packages to undertake structural economic reforms, which is expected to largely reduce domestic demand, making it impossible for South Korea to maintain high economic growth.

According to IMF estimates, the Asian financial crisis will pull down average world economic growth by 0.8 percentage points. In terms of grouping, ASEAN (Association of Southeast Asian Nations) countries will suffer most, with economic growth trimmed by 3.7 percentage points, followed by the NIEs, by 2.4 percentage points and industrialized countries, by 2 percentage points.
The spokesman also denied allegations by many economists that mainland China's renminbi is under great pressure for devaluation in the wake of the currency crises in its neighboring countries.

He said that it's true that mainland China may lose some of its export markets to other countries that have had their currencies devalued, but it would not be so difficult as has been speculated for mainland authorities to defend the renminbi, since mainland China maintains both strong economic growth and a huge current account surplus of up to 3 percent of its gross domestic product.

DOC.HEADLINE: US DOLLAR UP

TEXT.P: The US dollar grew NT$0.063 against the New Taiwan dollar on the Taipei foreign exchange market Saturday, closing at NT$32.374.
The greenback opened at 32.331, and was traded between 32.31 and 32.395.
Interbank US dollar trading reached US$36.5 million.

DOC.HEADLINE: SHARE PRICES UP ON TAIEX

TEXT.P: Share prices finished 0.8 percent higher on the local stock market Saturday, as stock-buying rebounded following a two-day recession.
The Taiwan Stock Exchange (TAIEX) weighted price index rose 61.69 points to 8,154.27.
The bourse opened at 8,150.03, and experienced a high of 8,167.68 and a low of 8,085.49.
Gainers outnumbered losers 239 to 143, with 79 shares unchanged.
A total of 1.59 billion shares changed hands on a market turnover of NT$79.96 billion (US$2.5 billion).

Electrical engineering stocks posted a 2 percent gain, plastic and chemical issues soared 0.9 percent, foodstuff shares edged up by 0.5 percent, and construction stocks charted a modest 0.4 percent rise.
Cement shares decreased 0.4 percent, textile stocks slipped down by 0.2 percent, and paper-making issues moved down 0.1 percent.

The 10 companies with the largest turnover were: ICBC; Taiwan Styrene Monomer; ACER; Da An Bank; United Micro Electronics; Union Petrochemical; Chang Hwa Bank; Grand Commercial Bank; Yieh Phui Enterprise; and Taiwan Semiconductor Manufacturing.

DOC.HEADLINE: US YET TO ACCEPT TAIWAN PROPOSAL ON AUTO EXPORTS IN WTO TALKS
DOC.DATELINE: Washington, Dec. 19 (CNA) (By Herman Pan and Lilian Wu)

TEXT.P: The United States has yet to accept a proposal by the Republic of China on cutting the tariffs on auto exports to Taiwan, US officials said on Friday following the 16th round of bilateral negotiations on Taiwan's terms for entry into the World Trade Organization (WTO) which ended here on Wednesday.
The officials said that the US will communicate with its auto manufacturers before giving the ROC an answer on the issue.
During the latest talks, Taiwan made a new proposal on auto imports, offering that cars below 2000cc will continue to have a tariff of 25 percent.

Tariffs for cars larger than 2000cc will be cut in two stages. The rate will be cut to 35 percent in the first five years of Taiwan's WTO membership, and further reduced to 30 percent beginning in the sixth year.

US officials denied that the new proposal has been accepted, saying that they will continue to communicate with Chrysler, Ford and General Motors, in the hope that the problem can be resolved before the end of next January.
Taiwan also offered to lift differential tariffs on compact cars beyond a certain quota nine years after WTO entry, imposing instead a single 20 percent tariff.

The ROC delegation, headed by Chen Ruey-long, director general of the Board of Foreign Trade, is still visiting various industrial groups in the US to solicit support for Taiwan's WTO bid. It is scheduled to fly back to Taiwan on Friday.
Minister of Economic Affairs Wang Chih-kang will head the ROC delegation to the next round of WTO talks with the US, slated to be held in Washington in February.
