DOC.HEADLINE: AUSSIE UNIVERSITIES ATTRACTING MORE FOREIGN STUDENTS

TEXT.P: Australian universities are attracting more foreign students from Asia and elsewhere, defying predictions of a backlash triggered by Independent Member of Parliament Pauline Hanson, the racist, bigoted former fish-and-chip seller who is a champion of anti-Asian immigration.

IDP Education Australia, which is responsible for selling Australian universities abroad, reported that the number of foreign students from Asia and elsewhere has increased 22 percent in the past 12 months.
Despite this positive result, IDP Education on Friday warned that the recent Asian financial crisis could threaten enrollments for next year.
A recent survey by IDP Education shows the number of foreign students jumped to 75,500 in August this year from 61,800 for the same period last year.
More than 50 percent of the total number came from Malaysia, Singapore, Hong Kong and Indonesia, with the rest coming from Taiwan, mainland China and other countries.
Australia's education exports are worth A$3 billion a year and the race debate sparked by Hanson's anti-Asian remarks in September, 1996 posed a serious threat.

However, reassurances by senior Australian politicians from across the political spectrum, who branded her as an unrepresentative, jingoistic moron, have minimized Hanson's damage to Australia's educational industry.

DOC.HEADLINE: ASIAN HIGH-ROLLERS ROCK AUSTRALIA'S BIGGEST CASINO

TEXT.P: The Melbourne-based Crown Casino, the biggest gambling den in the Southern Hemisphere, has lost A$40 million in the past five months because high-rollers from Asia have enjoyed an unprecedented winning streak in the past six weeks, company chairman Lloyd Williams said.
The massive losses have forced the casino to make rights issue of A$146 million through its banks to give it much-needed cash and reduce its gearing.
But the Australian Securities Commission and the Australian Stock Exchange have launched investigations into Crown's operations and its worsening financial situation.
The news sparked a plunge of 21 Australian cents in the Crown share price to a record low of 63 Australian cents, on a Friday turnover of 11.6 million shares.
The losses are largely the result of massive payouts to high rollers from Asia. The cost of operating its premium player market has also forced the company to make the rights issue.
Crown chairman Williams said the casino has lost A$55 million in the past six weeks alone to high-rollers from Asia.
"They (Crown Casino) are bleeding," one shocked institutional investor told reporters.

Consolidated Press Holdings, owned by Australia's richest man, Kerry Packer, has agreed to take up any shortfall, which is expected to boost Packer's stake in the casino to 22 percent from the current seven percent.
Crown Casino has set up offices in Taipei, Hong Kong, Bangkok, Singapore, Kuala Lumpur and Jakarta to attract high-rollers from these places.

DOC.HEADLINE: MOFA FOLLOWS CULT ACTIVITIES OF TAIWAN RESIDENTS IN US

TEXT.P: The Ministry of Foreign Affairs (MOFA) is keeping tabs on the movement in the United States of 53 Taiwan residents from 12 families who are allegedly involved with a religious cult.

Shen Lu-hsiun, director of MOFA's Department of North American Affairs, made the remarks following reports that the cult members had left Taiwan for Dallas, Texas, where they are said to be planning to commit mass suicide so that their bodies can be picked up by space ships in March next year.

Taipei City Councilor Chin Hui-chu said she received several requests for help from family members of the 53 residents who feared for their safety after hearing of the cult's involvement with a so-called "God Saves the Earth Flying Saucer Foundation."
Chin called on the MOFA on Saturday to ask for the ministry's assistance in ensuring the cult members' safety.
Shen said that local police in Texas and related US government agencies are also closely watching the situation.

Shen said the ministry is fully aware of the activities of the 53 Taiwan residents, adding that the ROC representative office in Dallas had also contacted them by telephone and was informed that "there is no intention to commit mass suicide."
He said that the cult has so far engaged in no criminal activities, and that US authorities can only monitor developments closely at the present time.
But Shen said that if the cult members are found to have been forced to remain in the United States against their will, US law enforcement officials will intervene.

Local news reports said that the "Truth Cult" is led by Chen Heng-ming, 43, who quit his teaching job at a college in Tainan, southern Taiwan, last February, in order to pursue advanced studies in the United States.
Chen registered the organization with the Ministry of the Interior two years ago under the name "ROC Soul Research Association," claiming to have 80 followers.

According to the families of the followers, the cult members believe that Jesus Christ will return to Earth in July 1999. The cult reportedly practices the traditional Chinese healing art of "chi gong" to treat illnesses, and the followers have apparently donated large sums of cash as well as automobiles to the cult.
The ROC Bureau of Investigation is looking into whether any laws were broken by the cult in soliciting money or in the conduct of other operations.

DOC.HEADLINE: SINGAPORE'S TOTAL TRADE GROWS BY 10.4 PERCENT IN NOVEMBER

TEXT.P: Singapore's total trade at current prices in November 1997 continued to grow by 10.4 percent compared to November last year, with exports and imports increasing by 10.5 percent and 10.3 percent, respectively, the Singapore Trade Development Board (TDB) announced on Saturday.
The total value of November's trade amounted to S$32,829 million, with exports totaling S$16,049 million and imports at S$16,780 million, it said.
In real terms (at 1990 prices), the total value of trade in November amounted to S$37,982 million, indicating a growth of 10.2 percent over the same month last year.
Exports totaled S$19,259 million, while imports stood at S$18,723 million, according to figures compiled by the TDB.
Non-oil domestic exports expanded by 11.9 percent, while re-exports registered a growth of 13.2 percent.
Domestic oil exports, however, continued to decline by 10 percent in November.
Re-exports grew by 11.8 percent in November, due mainly to increased shipments of electronics products to the European Union (EU), Hong Kong and the United States.
Non-oil imports recorded a moderate increase of 5.9 percent in November, the TDB said.

DOC.HEADLINE: TAIWAN MISSION TO VISIT S. KOREA AND SE ASIA

TEXT.P: A group of Taiwan trade promoters and economic officials will visit South Korea and some Southeast Asian countries next month to study the changing investment climates in those countries.

Economic Minister Wang Chih-kang said Saturday that the mission will include officials of the China External Trade Development Council, the Industrial Development and Investment Center of the Economic Affair Ministry, and the Industrial Development Bureau of the ministry. Their purpose is to find out how the financial turmoils in Asia are affecting the business and investment climates of those countries, so as to help Taiwan investors adjust themselves to the new situations.
He pointed out that some Taiwan investors in mainland China are considering moving their investments to Southeast Asia for fear of a sudden devaluation of the renminbi and other kind of risks.

The Taipei Business Managers' Association also reported recently that many Taiwan investors in mainland China have asked the association for help, because they want to move their investments to somewhere else.

Meanwhile, Wang said the renminbi is not going to depreciate in the near future, because government control of foreign exchange in mainland China is tight, but it is hard to predict what will happen to the currency in the long term. The later it devalues, the greater risk it will bring, he added. (by Ed Hsieh)

DOC.HEADLINE: ROC-INDONESIA ENERGY CONFERENCE TO OPEN IN TAIPEI

TEXT.P: The Republic of China-Indonesia Ministerial Energy Conference will open here Monday, with participants set to discuss exchanges in energy resources development.

ROC Economics Minister Wang Chih-kang and Indonesia's Minister of Mining and Energy I.B. Sudjana will jointly preside over the meeting, in which a cooperative program between Taiwan and the Southeast Asian country for developing electric power is expected to be worked out.

Electric power and coal, natural gas and recycled resources are three major topics to be discussed at the conference by representatives from government agencies and economic institutes as well as executives from petroleum and power companies from the two sides, according to an official with the Ministry of Economic Affairs (MOEA).

He noted that issues related to personnel and information exchange along with technical cooperation in power generating will also be addressed at the conference, which has been held on an annual basis since 1990.
The yearly energy meeting has contributed significantly to promoting exchanges of power-related resources between Taiwan and Indonesia, the MOEA said.
According to MOEA statistics, the ROC imported a total of 8.76 million barrels of crude oil from Indonesia in the first nine months of this year, up 48 percent from the year-earlier level.

DOC.HEADLINE: LEE TENG-HUI SAYS HE WILL RETIRE AFTER TENURE EXPIRES
DOC.DATELINE: Tokyo, Dec. 20 (CNA) (By Victor Lai and Bear Lee)

TEXT.P: Republic of China President Lee Teng-hui said on Friday that he will retire after his current tenure expires two and a half years from now.

"I would be glad and feel lucky if history regards me as a person who contributed greatly to promoting Taiwan's democratization and who loves Taiwan and Chinese people," he said in an interview with the Tokyo-based Sankai Shimbun newspaper.
Asked whether he has designated an heir apparent, Lee said it is up to the people of the nation to decide his successor, as the ROC is now a fully democratic nation.

He said that during his one and a half years in office, he has realized most of his campaign promises, as Taiwan's economy has become healthier, party politics have taken root and national security has been safeguarded.
Lee won a resounding victory in Taiwan's first direct presidential election last March.
During the three-hour interview with visiting Japanese reporters, Lee answered a series of questions covering a wide range of political, economic and national security issues.
He said that Taipei is willing to resume suspended bilateral cross-strait negotiations with mainland China, as long as no preconditions are set.

The president pointed out that Taipei insists on the unification of China under the principles of freedom, democracy and equal distribution of wealth and that it will be very difficult to achieve the goal of national unification until mainland China can adopt a multi-party democratic system.

On Beijing's live missile tests in the waters of the Taiwan Strait carried out to intimidate the people of Taiwan in the runup to the country's first presidential election, Lee said the provocation by Beijing caused grave concern among neighboring countries and the incident ended only after the United States sent two aircraft carrier battle groups to the area, fully illustrating Beijing's tendency to "bully the weak and fear the strong."

As to the "intended ambiguity" in the revised US-Japan defense guidelines which don't clearly define Taiwan in the area subject to joint US-Japan military action in case of contingencies, Lee said that the ambiguity is understandable and shows that the US attaches importance to Taiwan's security.

He noted that the improved US relations with mainland China have had no direct negative impact on its ties with Taiwan so far, but he said Beijing is very likely to press US President Bill Clinton to limit US support for Taiwan when he visits the mainland next year.

Lee also pledged to promote substantial relations with friendly countries, especially with the US and Japan, and said he hopes the Japanese government will reciprocate by allowing higher-ranking officials, to at least the vice minister level, to visit Taipei.

The president also clarified remarks he made recently during two separate interviews with the US media that "Taiwan is a sovereign, independent country," saying the remarks don't signify any change in the government's stance on the issue. They simply referred to the reality that the ROC, now on Taiwan, has always been an independent state, ever since its establishment in 1912.

DOC.HEADLINE: SINGAPORE PM OFFERS SYMPATHY TO CRASH VICTIM FAMILIES

TEXT.P: Singapore Prime Minister Goh Chok Tong on Saturday offered his "deepest sympathies" to the families of passengers on board the ill-fated SilkAir aircraft which crashed near Palembang, Indonesia on Friday evening and said that the Singapore authorities are providing every assistance and support to them.
He said in a statement at noon that he was "dismayed" when Communications Minister Mah Bow Tan informed him that a SilkAir aircraft returning from Jakarta to Singapore had gone missing.
"We feared the worst but hoped for the best," he said.
"I am greatly distressed that our fears have been confirmed -- the aircraft had crashed.
"I am told that no survivors have been found so far. This is a tragic accident.
"I offer my deepest sympathies to the affected families. This is a difficult time for them and I wish them strength and fortitude," he said.

Goh said the Singapore government has joined the Indonesian authorities in mounting a full search and rescue operation. "We are grateful to the Indonesian authorities for their prompt response and continuing efforts," he added.

Mah said at a hastily called press conference that the government has formed an ad hoc investigation committee to probe the actual cause of the crash -- the first ever accident for Singapore Airlines and its affiliate SilkAir.
All 104 passengers and crew on board SilkAir's newest B737-300 aircraft are believed to have been killed in the crash.

Reports from Indonesia said that by noon Saturday, some 38 bodies had been identified and two heavy pieces of the body of the crashed aircraft had been recovered, although the "black box" flight data recorder has yet to be found.

DOC.HEADLINE: SOUTH AFRICAN DIPLOMAT GIVEN WARM FAREWELL PARTY

TEXT.P: The family of a South African diplomat which was suddenly cast into the national spotlight after being taken hostage by Taiwan's most wanted fugitive last month, was given a warm farewell party at an elementary school here Saturday.

McGill Alexander, military attache of South African embassy to the ROC, said that he would like to return to Taiwan if given the opportunity. He expressed his appreciation for all the support given to the family after the hostage incident.
The Alexanders are due to return to South Africa early next year after Taipei and Pretoria sever diplomatic ties after Dec. 31, 1997.
The farewell party, sponsored by local King Car Education Foundation, was held at the Chienan Elementary School.
The family arrived at the school to a song of welcome. After an exchange of gifts, the family donned traditional Chinese attire presented by the foundation.

Huang Yu-lan, president of Chienan school, also presented an honorary student certificate to Christine, the diplomat's 12-year-old daughter whose courage in the hostage crisis captured the hearts of Taiwan residents.
Alexander, speaking to about 1,000 students and faculty members, said that the family will never forget the warmth and support they received during and after the hostage incident.

Although he, his wife and two daughters experienced a family's worst nightmare, Alexander said, words could not convey their appreciation for the many letters, phone calls and fax messages of support from total strangers received after the ordeal.
The South African diplomat also said among all the "fair and good memories, the warmth and hospitality of Taiwan people are the most difficult to forget."
He also expressed his confidence about the future of the ROC, saying that the people here are diligent and hard working, seemly never in need of sleep.
The 90-minute farewell party closed with the Alexanders singing a farewell song with about 1,000 students and faculty members of the Chienan elementary school.

Alexander, his wife and two daughters were held at gunpoint in their home on Nov. 18 by fugitive Chen Chin-hsing, wanted for the brutal kidnap and murder of the daughter of local TV celebrity Pai Ping-ping and other notorious cases. Alexander and his elder daughter Melanie were shot and wounded during the 24-hour standoff, while his wife and younger daughter Christine were eventually released unharmed. The family became familiar to Taiwan residents after local TV stations provided live coverage of the entire incident.

DOC.HEADLINE: STATE COUNCIL OF MAINLAND CHINA TO UNDERGO MAJOR RESHUFFLE

TEXT.P: The State Council of mainland China will undergo a major reshuffle in March with Zhu Rongji replacing Li Peng as Premier, according to information from Beijing.

Li Lanqing will succeed Zhu Rongji as Vice Premier, while Liu Huaqiu is likely to succeed Qian Qichen as minister of foreign affairs. Qian will continue to serve as vice premier. There are four vice premiers in the state council.

Gen. Fu Quanyou, chief of general staff of the People's Liberation Army, will replace Gen. Chi Haotian as minister of national defense. Chi will continue to serve as vice chairman of the Chinese Communist Party Central Military Commission.

The State Economic and Trade Commission and the Ministry of Foreign Trade and Economic Cooperation will be combined into a new economic and trade organization, which will be headed by Minister Wu Yi of the foreign trade and economic cooperation ministry.

The information from Beijing also indicated that the officials who will remain in their posts after the reshuffle include Minister of Public Security Tao Siju, Minister of State Security Jia Chunwang, Minister of Finance Liu Zhongli, Minister of Justice Xiao Yang, and President of People's Bank of China Dai Xianglong. (by Ed Hsieh)

DOC.HEADLINE: CULT LEADER URGED TO LET FOLLOWERS RETURN TO TAIWAN
DOC.DATELINE: Taipei, Dec. 21 (CNA) (By T.C. Hu and Flor Wang)

TEXT.P: Taipei City Councilor Chin Hui-chu on Sunday urged Chen Heng-ming, a cult leader from Taiwan with a group of followers now staying in the United States, to let cult members return to Taiwan in March if flying saucers do not appear to take them to heaven by then.

Chin, who said her office has received 16 letters for help in recent days from families of some of Chen's followers, called on Chen in a news conference to explain the situation to the public, guarantee the safety of his followers in the United States and allow them to return to Taiwan in March.

More than 100 followers, including 20 children, of the mysterious cult called "God Saves the Earth By Flying Saucer Foundation," recently left for Garland, near Dallas, Texas, to seek peace and wait for flying saucers to take them to heaven on March 31. The cult members believe that Taiwan will destroyed in 1998, followed by the rest of the world in 1999, and that Garland is a land blessed by God.

Chin also urged Taipei Mayor Chen Shui-bian to help resolve the matter, as many of the cult members are Taipei residents. Since Taipei is a sister city of Dallas, Chen should find channels through that relationship to help the government bring the followers back to Taiwan, she said.
Y.C. Luo, deputy director-general of the Taipei Economic and Cultural Office in Houston, on Saturday visited about 50 cult members in Garland on behalf of the Republic of China government.
Luo said those believers from Taiwan now lead a very peaceful and normal life in Garland and that their activities there should be respected, as all of them entered the United States legally.
Some of cult members complained about reports by the Taiwan press that they plan to commit mass suicide so their bodies can be transported to heaven by flying saucers.

They said they came to the United States with Chen voluntarily to escape the "millennium catastrophe" and that they are not controlled by anybody and do not intend to kill themselves en masse. Such reports appearing in the Taiwan media are "ridiculous" and "absurd," they added.

They also expressed the desire to stay in the United States to wait for the arrival of God and flying saucers to take them to heaven on March 31 and said they will return to Taiwan if God does not appear by then.

DOC.HEADLINE: MAC CHAIRMAN SEES AMPLE ROOM FOR CROSS-STRAIT RELATIONS

TEXT.P: There is ample room for mainland China and Taiwan to develop relations on the basis of mutual respect, equality, and goodwill, Chang King-Yuh, chairman of the Mainland Affairs Council of the Executive Yuan, said here Saturday.

Chang, who arrived here Friday for a two-day visit, told a group of overseas Chinese leaders in Brussels that relations between the two sides of the Taiwan Strait have improved considerably in the past decade, and that Taiwan has been trying to promote various kinds of exchanges with the mainland for mutual benefits.

But, he said, Beijing's efforts to isolate Taiwan in the world community, and its reluctance to abandon the option of using force against Taiwan and to recognize the existence of the Republic of China, have hindered the development of the relations.
He said that only on the basis of mutual respect, equality, and goodwill can cross-strait relations improve normally. (by Tang Ping-chun\Ed Hsieh)

DOC.HEADLINE: GCC SUMMIT BEGINS IN KUWAIT

TEXT.P: Leaders of the six-member Gulf Cooperation Council (GCC) arrived Kuwait on Saturday for a three-day annual summit to take up a number of topics related to strengthening economic, defense and security cooperation.

GCC Secretary-General Jameel Al-Hujeilan said the leaders will discuss two projects "aimed at strengthening military cooperation." Military sources have said Sweden's Ericsson company has been chosen to install a secure communications link-up for the GCC, while Hughes Space and Communications International of the United States is to build a regional early-warning system.
This is the 18th summit of GCC leaders since the regional body was formed in 1981.

DOC.HEADLINE: MYSTERY OVER SILKAIR PLANE CRASH REMAINS

TEXT.P: Reports about the explosion of SilkAir flight MI-185 before it crashed into the Musi River, 35 miles north of Palembang, Indonesia, on Friday afternoon could not be confirmed, and mystery over the crash remained as search and rescue operations resumed early Saturday morning.

On Friday, there were numerous reports from the crash site quoting Indonesian villagers and fishermen as claiming that they had heard one or two explosions before the plane plunged into the river, followed by another loud bang.

"The first two explosions in the air jolted me, then I saw the plane go down into the river right before my eyes," The Straits Times quoted a 60-year-old Indonesian farmer, named Damsik, as describing what he saw.
Several other eyewitnesses also reported hearing explosions before the 10-month-old Boeing 737-300 plunged into the waters off the sparsely populated fishing village, according to the report.

DOC.HEADLINE: NO BODIES FOUND IN SEARCH FOR SILKAIR CRASH VICTIMS

TEXT.P: An underwater search for the bodies of last Friday's SilkAir crash victims near Palembang in Indonesia continued as of 2:00 p.m. Saturday but failed to produce any bodies, police said.
Police divers conducting the search only found pieces of flesh, skin, intestines or hair, Lt. Col Syafei Aksal, chief of the South Sumatra marine police, said.
The effort to recover the victims' bodies would continue until evening, he added.
Eight divers from special marine police units were deployed to find the bodies of the crash victims.
The ill-fated SilkAir plane crashed into the Musi riverbed at the village of Makarti Jaya in Sungsang district, South Sumatra, on Friday afternoon.
The site of the crash is remote and difficult to reach by land, the second assistant to the district administrative secretary, M. Yamin, told Antara on Saturday.
The site is about 70 kilometers north of Palembang and can be reached only by boat on the Musi River, he said.

DOC.HEADLINE: CHINA AIRLINES AIMS FOR US$28 MILLION FROM INDONESIAN OPERATIONS

TEXT.P: Jacobus Hsieh, general manager of the Indonesian branch of China Airlines (CAL), has predicted that the CAL will have US$28 million in revenue this year from its operations in that country.

"We are very optimistic to be able to reap US$14 million from passengers and another US$14 million from cargo services," he Indonesian Observer quoted Hsieh as saying in an interview appearing in the newspaper on Saturday.

In the interview, Hsieh told the Observer's Rudijanto that CAL has already been involved in co-share flights with Garuda Indonesia in cargo transport for two years. Under this co-share flight scheme, Garuda has 30 tons of cargo in each freighter aircraft operated by China Airlines.
"Both China Airlines and Garuda Indonesia have agreed to increase the level of co-shared flights," Hsieh said.
According to Hsieh, China Airlines' load factor is quite encouraging.

DOC.HEADLINE: DPP CHAIRMAN TO HOLD PRESS CONFERENCE IN JAPAN

TEXT.P: Hsu Hsin-liang, chairman of Taiwan's major opposition Democratic Progressive Party (DPP), will hold a press conference here Monday at the request of foreign wire service reporters, an official of the party said.

Sisy Chen, head of the DPP's Information and Publicity Department, said that, in the press conference, Hsu is expected to urge the International Monetary Fund (IMF) to allow Taiwan to attend its meeting on Asian financial crisis. Taiwan has been excluded from IMF activities since it was dismissed by the United Nations in 1972 in favor of communist China.
A certain expert of the World Bank has accused Taiwan of trying to cause a second round of financial trouble for Asia by purposely allowing its currency to devaluate, Chen pointed out.
"If we have that kind of ability, then the IMF should allow us to help resolve the financial problems of Asia," Chen said.
Hsu and several other DPP officials are visiting Japan after observing presidential elections in South Korea Thursday. (by Y.Y. Chen\Ed Hsieh)

DOC.HEADLINE: MANILA MAYOR TO RUN FOR PRESIDENT

TEXT.P: Manila Mayor Alfredo Lim formally launched on Saturday afternoon his bid for the presidency on the eve of his 68th birthday.
Lim announced his candidacy at the Mehan Garden, near City Hall.

In a press conference at City Hall following the launching ceremonies, Lim repeatedly refused to reveal his choice for a vice presidential running mate. Reporters suggested it could be former Cebu Governor Lito Osmena, but he would not confirm nor deny that speculation.

In a prepared statement, Lim said, "The country needs at this time a decisive, no-nonsense president who can get things done ... with the courage and integrity to do justice to every man ... one who will not just uphold and enforce the law but also effectively address the problem of mass poverty.
"My vision of the new Philippines is a country where our families can live in safety and peace, where our businesses can thrive and create jobs, where every citizen can make an honest living.
"I believe in government providing leadership for social reforms and a stable set of policies that inspires confidence in the private sector."

DOC.HEADLINE: EARLY TARIFF CUTS ON AGRICULTURAL PRODUCTS STILL UNDECIDED: WANG

TEXT.P: Economics Minister Wang Chih-kang said on Sunday that Taiwan has not decided whether to make concessions on a timetable for the reduction of tariffs on agricultural products as part of its efforts to enter the World Trade Organization (WTO).

The United Daily News reported in its Sunday edition that in order to push through early admission to the world trade regulatory body by next May, Taiwan will agree to a US demand to lower tariff rates on agricultural products ahead of schedule.

Wang did not confirm or deny the report, saying only that no decision has been made by his ministry regarding an accelerated timetable for tariff cuts on agricultural products. His ministry will consult the Council of Agriculture on the sensitive issue to ensure that the interests of local farmers will not be ignored, Wang stressed.

The report said that Taiwan had previously insisted that the tariff cuts be completed within three years after Taiwan's WTO admission. But in an attempt to conclude trade talks with the United States on terms for Taiwan's early membership in the trade watchdog body, authorities here plan to implement tariff reductions on some agricultural products prior to its WTO accession, and that reductions on some agricultural products will be finalized by 2000 instead of 2002, as originally proposed.

Tariffs on agricultural products remain the greatest obstacle in the Taiwan-US trade talks. The US officials had demanded that across-the-board tariff cuts on agricultural and industrial products be completed by 2002, while Taiwan suggested that the timetable for cuts on some 160 agricultural goods, including beef, pork and fish products, be pushed back to 2004. US negotiators rejected the proposal and further demanded that tariff reductions on 60 agricultural items be finalized by 2000.

The local news report said that to avoid bringing any negative impact upon the ruling Kuomintang (KMT) in local elections to be held in January, the Economic Ministry has decided to delay the next round of trade talks with the United States on agricultural products and policy-related issues from January to February.
The United States is one of three WTO members that have not concluded negotiations with Taiwan on terms for its entry to the WTO. The other two are the 15-member European Union and Switzerland.

DOC.HEADLINE: ASEAN TO FIGHT TERRORISM AND CRIME

TEXT.P: In a show of solidarity and unity, member countries of the Association of Southeast Asian Nations (ASEAN) agreed Saturday to put more teeth to the ASEAN campaign against terrorism, drug trafficking, money laundering, arms smuggling, credit card fraud, fake travel documents and other transnational crimes.

The ministers gave their approval to a joint declaration which was discussed by the interior and home affairs ministers of host Philippines and ASEAN member countries at the Ministerial Meeting on Transnational Crime, presided over by Philippine Interior and Local Government Secretary Robert Barbers at the Manila Hotel.
The declaration capped the three-day meeting, the first concerted effort by ASEAN against transnational crime.
Under the joint declaration, ASEAN member countries vowed to cooperate at a regional level in combating transnational crimes.
It also proposed further discussions on a regionwide extradition treaty as a means of strengthening the campaign against transnational crime.

The declaration mandates the convening of a high-level experts group to develop the "ASEAN Plan of Action on Transnational Crimes," an institutional framework for ASEAN cooperation and a feasibility study on the establishment of an "ASEAN Center Against Transnational Crimes."

DOC.HEADLINE: MEETING ON SOUTH CHINA SEA SLATED FOR TUESDAY

TEXT.P: An interministerial-level meeting on the South China Sea is scheduled to be held on Tuesday with an aim to work out pragmatic measures to stress the Republic of China's sovereignty over the disputed waters.

According to the Interior Ministry, in addition to reviewing the results of the first South China Sea meeting held in Taipei in 1993, officials from several government agencies will discuss a consensus reached earlier in a nonpartisan negotiation that the ROC government will temporarily put aside its "sovereignty over the special historical waters," and find practical means of reinforcing the ROC's sovereignty over the disputed waters claimed by a number of countries in the region.

The Interior Ministry said that to temporarily put aside the ROC's sovereignty claims to the territorial waters does not mean not to claim the sovereignty forever. Rather, it hopes to resolve the highly sensitive and complex dispute with practical measures.

Officials with the Interior Ministry said the government's decision to adopt a pragmatic approach toward the issue is expected to help it gain a seat in future international conferences on the South China Sea.

The Tuesday meeting on the South China Sea will be chaired by Interior Minister Yeh Ching-feng and attended by officials from the ministries of foreign affairs, national defense and economic affairs, as well as the Mainland Affairs Council, the Council of Agriculture and the Environmental Protection Administration.
The South China Sea, believed to be potentially rich in oil, is also claimed in whole or in part by mainland China, the Philippines, Malaysia, Vietnam, and Brunei.

DOC.HEADLINE: FARMERS' INTERESTS SHOULD NOT BE SACRIFICED IN WTO TALKS: OFFICIALS

TEXT.P: Agricultural officials said on Sunday that the government should not seek to join the World Trade Organization (WTO) by sacrificing the interests of local farmers.

Officials of the Cabinet-level Council of Agriculture (COA) said they cannot support concessions on a timetable for the reduction of tariffs on agricultural products as part of efforts to conclude trade talks with the United States on terms for Taiwan's entry into the world trade regulatory body.

The United Daily News reported in its Sunday edition that in order to remove the greatest obstacle in the Taiwan-US trade talks -- differences on the timetable for tariff cuts on agricultural products, authorities here plan to concede to US demands by lowering tariff rates on some agricultural products prior to its WTO accession.
Taiwan had previously insisted that the across-the-board tariff cuts on agricultural products be completed within three years after Taiwan's WTO admission.

COA officials said that the opening of the rice market to all foreign competition after its WTO admission will have the greatest impact on Taiwan's agricultural sector. The government should not make any further concessions on the rice import policy or on tariff reductions on other agricultural products, they added.

Taiwan has agreed to a rice import policy modeled after Japan's, under which Taiwan will allow the import of rice amounting to 4 percent of its national rice consumption in the first year after its WTO admission. The import quota will increase annually by 0.8 percent in the subsequent five-year period, whereupon the import quota would represent 8 percent of its total rice consumption.
Taiwan and US trade officials, however, still have differences over the allocation of the rice quota and access of imported rice to the local market.

DOC.HEADLINE: CHEN SHUI-BIAN FAVORED PRESIDENTIAL CANDIDATE BY UNIVERSITY STUDENTS

TEXT.P: Taipei Mayor Chen Shui-bian is seen as the most ideal candidate for the 2000 presidential election among university students in Taiwan, according to a survey made public on Sunday.

The poll, conducted by the National Cultural Congress, found that Mayor Chen of the Democratic Progressive Party (DPP) won a 35.1 percent support rating as the nation's next president, followed by Taiwan Provincial Governor James Soong (25.7 percent) and former Minister Without Portfolio Ma Ying-jeou (11 percent). The combined support rating for the three surpassed 70 percent.

Others named by the university students as ideal presidential candidates in descending order of popularity are former New Party Legislator Wang Chien-shien, ruling Kuomintang Secretary-General John Chang, the DPP candidate for the last presidential election Peng Ming-min, current ROC President Lee Teng-hui, Premier Vincent Siew, Kaohsiung Mayor Wu Den-yih, Vice President Lien Chan and former DPP Legislator Hsieh Chang-ting.

Ma Ying-jeou of the Kuomintang is seen as the most popular candidate for vice president among the 1,087 university students interviewed around the island, with a support rating of 22.9 percent, while Taipei Mayor Chen garnered 12.3 percent support for that office, Hsieh Chang-ting obtained 9.2 percent and James Soong won 9 percent.

The other favorite vice presidential candidates are John Chang, senior presidential advisor Wu Poh-hsiung, Kaohsiung Mayor Wu Den-yih, Academia Sinica President Yuan T. Lee, DPP Publicity Department Director Sisy Chen and Premier Vincent Siew. Sisy Chen is the only female appearing on the list of 10 top candidates for either president or vice president.

For the students, the most perfect match for presidential and vice presidential running mates without regard to the candidates' party affiliation are James Soong and Ma Ying-jeou (9 percent), followed by Chen Shui-bian and Ma Ying-jeou (8.3 percent), and Chen Shui-bian and Hsieh Chang-ting (7.4 percent).

DOC.HEADLINE: CROSS-STRAIT DIALOGUE CHANNELS SHOULD REMAIN OPEN: FANG LIZHI

TEXT.P: Fang Lizhi, one of the most prominent mainland Chinese dissidents living in the United States, said on Saturday that Taiwan and mainland China should keep their channels of dialogue open for bilateral communication, according to a report by the China Times Express on Sunday.

Fang, who was visiting Taiwan to attend an astronomical workshop sponsored by Academia Sinica, Taiwan's highest research institute, made the remarks in an interview with the mass-circulation evening newspaper.
Fang, who was exiled from mainland China for advocating democracy there, said the most important thing for Taiwan at present is to strengthen itself, as Chinese communists only believe in force.

Fang suggested the Taiwan authorities acquire sufficient knowledge and understanding of the Chinese communists in order to improve their policy toward mainland China, since "the Chinese Communist Party has hardly changed in the past few decades."
Fang proposed Taiwan adopt a flexible mainland policy and maintain communication channels with mainland China in order to forestall any emergency cases.

"Unification will not take place soon and cross-strait communication channels must be kept open, " Fang said, adding that the missile crisis over the Taiwan Strait in March 1996 was caused by lack of such channels.
"If the two sides maintain positive exchanges, the chances of war are slim," he noted.

Although Beijing's "one China, two systems" unification scheme is theoretically feasible, Fang said, it is hard to put it into practice on the long-term if the systems of the two sides are different."
Citing Hong Kong as example, he said signs have indicated that "the Hong Kong media have begun to exercise self restraints by not criticizing the decisions made by Beijing."

Regarding the recent election defeat of the ruling Kuomintang at the hands of the opposition Democratic Progressive Party, Fang said "there is noting to worry about, as it is natural in a democratic society."

DOC.HEADLINE: `NO HASTE, BE PATIENT' POLICY PAYS OFF

TEXT.P: Communist Chinese statistics released over the weekend show that Taiwan's "no haste, be patient" policy on investment in mainland China has paid off, as investment across the Taiwan Strait saw a significant drop in the first three quarters of this year.

According to statistics released by mainland China's Ministry of Foreign Trade and Economic Cooperation (MFTEC), Taiwan's business people committed themselves to pouring US$2.01 billion into the mainland for investing in 2,181 projects between January and September of this year.
The amount marked a 54 percent year-on-year decline, while the number of projects receiving investment from Taiwan fell 9.1 percent from the same period of last year.
The tallies also show that the average amount invested in each investment project was about US$920,000, down nearly 50 percent from an average of US$1.83 million recorded for the same period of 1996.

Wang Hui, deputy director of the MFTEC's Department of Taiwan, Hong Kong and Macau Affairs, said the decrease can be partly attributed to Taiwan's "no haste, be patient" policy, which bans Taiwan companies from investing in mainland China's infrastructure construction projects, such as power plants, airports and highways.
Another reason for the dwindling Taiwan investment was adjustments in mainland China's taxation policy, which have cut tax privileges to foreign investors, including those from Taiwan, Wang noted.

Taiwan began to implement the "no haste, be patient" policy on cross-strait investment in 1996 as mainland China continued its efforts to block Taiwan's presence in the international community and declined to resume institutionalized cross-strait dialogue.

According to official mainland statistics, Taiwan companies to date have committed to investing a total of US$37.37 billion in the mainland for 37,652 projects as of the end of September. Of the committed amount, US$17.57 billion has actually been remitted, making Taiwan the third largest foreign capital supplier to mainland China after Hong Kong and Japan.
In terms of investment commitment, Taiwan ranked sixth, trailing Hong Kong, the Virgin Islands, the United States, Singapore and Japan.
