DOC.HEADLINE: AIRLINES TO CASH IN ON FIVE-DAY WORK SCHEME

TEXT.P: Taiwan's airline industry is gearing up to cash in on the five-day work scheme expected to be partially implemented at the beginning of next year, adjusting their fleets and flight destinations in order to draw potential customers, business sources have said.

As the new work schedule is expected to create an additional one million potential weekend holidaymakers, flights to neighboring countries such as Japan and Southeast Asian countries will become more popular, the sources said, adding that about 30 destinations will be added next year to the current flight service network of major domestic carriers serving international routes.

Destinations in countries and areas such as Guam, Indonesia, Macao, Palau and Saipan, which offer visa-free or landing-visa privileges to tourists from Taiwan, will become more competitive in their drive to draw Taiwan visitors, the sources forecast.

A spokesman for China Airlines (CAL), Taiwan's largest carrier, said CAL's fleet will be expanded to 57 airplanes from the current 50 units and the number of flights to Japan and Indonesia will be increased.

Starting on Jan. 1, 1998, CAL will increase its five weekly Taipei-Bali flights to seven, while Taiwan-Okinawa flights will be increased from 12 to 14 each week, and Taipei-Nagoya flights will be increased by 40 percent, according to the spokesman.

The spokesman predicted that the number of Japan-bound Taiwan tourists will continue to rise following the implementation of the five-day work week early next year and revealed that CAL will increase its charter services to Kagoshima, Nagasaki, Hiroshima and Sapporo in Japan, while flights to Penang and Ipo in Malaysia and those to Chiang Mai in northern Thailand will also be increased.

EVA Airways Corp. (EVA AIR), CAL's major rival, said the new work schedule has prompted it to plan the launch of a number of three-day package tours to Japan and Southeast Asia for individual travelers.

According to EVA AIR, the company will significantly increase its flight services to cities on the northern Japanese island of Hokkaido, while it will also increase its international flights departing from Kaohsiung, to better serve residents in southern Taiwan.

DOC.HEADLINE: TALKS ON POLITICAL AGENDA ACROSS TAIWAN STRAIT SAID PREMATURE

TEXT.P: Although people here have great expectations for the resumption of cross-Taiwan Strait talks, an official of the ROC's Straits Exchange Foundation (SEF) said over the weekend that he does not believe the two sides of the Taiwan Strait can reach agreement on a political agenda at present.

During a seminar which took place on Sunday on cross-strait relations and Taiwan's future, SEF Vice Chairman Chiao Jen-ho said that talks on a political agenda at the moment would be premature because of the current lack of mutual trust between both sides.

Chiao blamed Beijing for the stalled cross-strait relations, adding that Taiwan has become very pragmatic in its mainland policy since its initial opposition to contact with the mainland. He cited as an example the fact that mainland China now receives nearly 2 million visits by people from Taiwan every year.

In contrast, he noted, mainland China lacks sincerity in handling cross-strait relations, and refuses to forego the "one China" principle, which sees Taiwan as a part of the People's Republic of China.
He said that Beijing's insistence that the Republic of China met its demise in 1949, when the communists took over the mainland, has hampered the development of cross-strait relations.
Chiao stressed that although nobody wants a war across the Taiwan Strait, an ingratiating attitude toward Beijing will not help promote cross-trait ties.
He said that the ROC sees "separate rule" on both sides of the Taiwan Strait as a fact now, and that the ultimate goal is to pursue a unified China.

DOC.HEADLINE: DRUG TRAFFICKING RING BUSTED

TEXT.P: Law-enforcement officers busted a drug trafficking ring in the southern Taiwan city of Kaohsiung on Sunday, arresting three key suspects and confiscating 78 kilograms of amphetamine with a street value of some NT$56 million (US$1.72 million).
The Investigation Bureau under the Ministry of Justice (MJIB) said on Monday that the drugs had been smuggled from mainland China.
The three detained suspects were identified as Hsin Chen-sheng, 48; Hsu Chung-hsing, 25; and Yang Chin-po, 49. All three are ROC nationals.
The trio were caught red-handed in a busy hypermarket parking lot in Kaohsiung's bustling business district at around 6:00 p.m. Sunday, while Hsin and Hsu were striking a deal with Yang.
Law-enforcement officers uncovered the 78 kg of amphetamine in a van parked nearby.
Initial investigations show that the ring had often conducted trade deals in crowded business districts, using the presence of shoppers or pedestrians to distract attention.

Just two weeks ago, the ring allegedly pulled off an amphetamine sale to local drug dealers at another retail market in downtown Kaohsiung. To date, an estimated 300 kg of amphetamine, worth more than NT$400 million at street prices, is believed to have flowed into the underground drug market through this channel.
Investigators said they will trace the source of the drugs and probe whether there are additional accomplices involved.

A task force made up of MJIB branches in Kaohsiung, Pingtung and Changhua, as well as relevant police offices and the coast guard intelligence department had been shadowing the ringleaders for more than a year prior to the arrests.
The task force found that Hsin had set up an amphetamine processing plant in mainland China and has successfully smuggled a large quantity of the drug to Taiwan via fishing boats.
Acting on information that the ring had stored a large quantity of amphetamines in the Talo hypermarket parking lot, law-enforcement officers raided the site on Sunday evening.
MJIB Director Wang Rong-jou traveled to Kaohsiung on Monday to preside over a ceremony during which MJIB agents involved in Sunday's operations were cited.
Speaking at the ceremony, Wang said 75 percent of contraband drugs seized in Taiwan originated in mainland China, usually entering Taiwan via fishing boats or arriving by air via Burma and Thailand.
Wang said mainland Chinese authorities should cooperate with Taiwan in cracking down on the trafficking in illegal drugs.

"In future cross-strait talks, anti-drug trafficking should be a priority topic," Wang said, adding that he is convinced mainland China would be willing to cooperate with Taiwan in wiping out the illegal drug trade. "Mainland China will be the victim if it fails to take immediate action to eradicate such business."

Wang said drug dealers or traffickers continue to refine and improve their trading methods, and now often either conduct deals in bustling marketplaces or store drugs in safety deposit boxes at department stores. "Law-enforcement officers must hammer out suitable strategies to cope with the new challenges," he added.

DOC.HEADLINE: MAINLAND CHINA'S ECONOMY AFFECTED BY ASIAN FINANCIAL TURMOIL: ZHU
DOC.DATELINE: Tokyo, Dec. 22 (CNA) (By Victor Lai & Eva Chen)

TEXT.P: Mainland Chinese vice premier Zhu Rongji remarked at an economic conference held in mid-December that mainland China's exports and foreign investment will decrease and its economic growth rate will fall below 8 percent as a result of Asia's monetary crisis, according to Japan's mass-circulation Yomiuri Shimbun newspaper on Sunday.

If the mainland's 1998 economic growth rate scores less than 8 percent, it will be the lowest growth since 1991, which will affect the mainland's average growth rate target of 8 percent for the ninth five-year economic plan (1996-2000), the newspaper noted.
According to the paper, the main topics discussed by Zhu at the meeting were:

-- Although most Asian countries have been swept by the latest currency crisis, Beijing won't let its renminbi depreciate, while the value of Hong Kong's currency will be pegged to the US dollar in order to ensure Hong Kong's survival.
-- Both mainland export and foreign investment in 1998 will decrease; the influence of foreign investment on the mainland's economy will be weakened and the growth rate will be reduced accordingly.

The mainland's economy in the latter half of 1997 regressed slightly, revealed the Yomiuri, describing this as a result of long term tight monetary policy and price cutting on consumer goods, causing increases in bankruptcies among enterprises and leading to higher unemployment.
The paper disclosed that price cutting on retail prices lasted for two consecutive months last October and November, while unemployment rose to 5,000,000, according to official mainland statistics.
Meanwhile, foreign investment in the first 10 months of this year amounted to US$39.9 billion, a decrease of 35 percent compared with the same period of last year.

DOC.HEADLINE: EVA PILOTS' DEATH LINKED TO CARBON MONOXIDE POISON

TEXT.P: An initial autopsy carried out Monday on the bodies of two Venezuelan pilots working for EVA Airlines who were found dead on Saturday showed that the two might have died of carbon monoxide poisoning. Cesar Alberto Reuda and Marco Tulio Cegarra, were found dead on the 13th floor of the EVA Airlines dormitory building in Luchu Village, in northern Taiwan's Taoyuan County.
EVA officials began to suspect something amiss when captain Reuda failed to report to the EVA office at CKS airport on Saturday morning when he was due to pilot an EVA BR-67 plane to London.

Airline officials went with police to the dormitory, where they found the bodies of the two men in their apartment. Reuda was lying in bed with bubbles around the corners of his mouth, while Cegarra was lying on the sofa in the living room.

There were no signs of forcible entry and the gas stove was off, although the windows were shut tight and the air conditioners were on. There were no signs of a scuffle and neither man had sustained any noticeable wounds. Their personal property was also intact.
Police found half-consumed instant noodles and several bottles of pills for treating respiratory illness in the apartment.

Taoyuan Prosecutor's Office said the coroner's initial finding was death from excessive inhalation of carbon monoxide, but added that further tests will be needed to fully establish the cause of death.
Reuda's brother, who was the only family member present at the autopsy, was reported as being extremely distressed, and declined to comment. Other family members of the two will arrive soon.

EVA officials said that Rueda, 43, had a record of 4,714 flying hours. Cegarra, 47, had 11,005 flying hours. Both men had received a clean bill of health during their most recent physical examinations.

DOC.HEADLINE: TAIWAN TOURIST ARRIVALS IN KYUSHU DECLINING
DOC.DATELINE: Tokyo, Dec. 22 (CNA) (By Mike Chang and Flor Wang)

TEXT.P: Tourist arrivals from Taiwan in Fukuoka on the southern Japanese island of Kyushu has declined rapidly over the past few months as a result of stricter screening by the Japanese Transport Ministry of applications for temporary flights by Taiwan-based carriers, Japan's economic daily Nihon Kaizei Shimbun reported in its Monday edition.
The measure has resulted in a drop in Taiwan tourist arrivals in Fukuoka in September and October, the newspaper reported.

Taiwan tourist arrivals in Fukuoka dropped by 1 percent in September compared to the same month of last year, while the figure for October decreased by 3 percent on an annual basis, according to the report.
Foreign visitor arrivals by air or sea in Kyushu have been recorded at around 363,000 since the beginning of 1996 until recently, 30 percent of which have been tourists from Taiwan, it noted.

It added that the decline in tourist arrivals from Taiwan has caused grave concern among local tourism businesses in that it may have a negative impact on the local tourism industry, especially with the approaching Chinese New Year holiday, a high season for Taiwan tourists visiting Japan.

Officials with the Japanese Transport Ministry pointed out that the ministry decided to impose stricter approval for temporary flights by Taiwan-based airlines because they questioned the need for Taiwan carriers to operate temporary flights all year round when their regular flights are not always fully-loaded.

China Airlines and EVA Airways Corp., Taiwan's two largest carriers, were each approved to run 20 provisional flights to Fukuoka on a monthly basis from January to October, but the number declined to just one and two in September and October, respectively, although it rose to five and 10 for November and December.

Sources familiar with the Taiwan airline industry said Taiwan tourists prefer to depart for Fukuoka in the morning, which is why the Taiwan carriers use provisional charter flights. Most regular flights leave Taipei in the evening, they noted.

DOC.HEADLINE: ASEAN MINISTERIAL MEETING ON HAZE OPENS DEC. 22

TEXT.P: The Association of Southeast Asian Nations (ASEAN) environment ministers will meet in Singapore on Monday to discuss the problem of haze caused by the smoke emanating from the hundreds of wildfires that have affected much of the Southeast Asian region this year.
Singapore's Minister for the Environment and Minister for Health, Yeo Cheow Tong, who proposed the ministerial meeting on the haze, will chair the two-day meeting.

Apart from reviewing the current haze problem, the ASEAN ministers are expected to deliberate on a Regional Haze Action Plan that will set out policies and measures to prevent a recurrence of such problems, according to the Singapore Ministry of the Environment.

DOC.HEADLINE: BEIJING WANTS TO BOOST IMPORTS IN 1998

TEXT.P: Beijing plans to boost imports next year to narrow its mounting trade surplus and deflect trade friction, according to reports from the Geneva-based World Trade Organization (WTO) on Sunday.
Mainland China will continue to try to expand exports next year, although it will also seek to reduce its excessively large surplus by encouraging imports, the WTO report said.
Mainland China posted a trade surplus of US$40.23 billion in the first 11 months of this year compared with a surplus of US$13.93 billion in the same period of 1996.
The surplus for November alone was US$4.65 billion.
Some foreign and local economists have said export growth will slow next year due to competition from Southeast Asia.
Mainland officials have in the past said they are concerned over the rapid rise in the surplus and that measures will be taken to encourage more balanced trade.
The mainland will further adjust its imports and encourage imports of high-technology products next year, the WTO report said.
It gave no details, but the report said Beijing is preparing to restore waivers of duties on imports of high technology equipment.
Mainland China on October 1 cut import tariffs on a range of products to pave the way for entry into the WTO.
The report also said Beijing will encourage domestic banks to provide mortgage loans to individual home buyers next year to reduce the amount of unsold housing on the domestic market.

The report also repeated previous policy statements that Beijing will maintain what it calls its "appropriately tight" monetary policy in 1998, while speeding up reforms in the struggling state sector and taking measures to reduce unemployment.

DOC.HEADLINE: DAUGHTER OF INDONESIAN PRESIDENT `OPPOSES' HER FATHER'S REELECTION

TEXT.P: President Suharto's eldest daughter, Siti Hardiyanti Rukmana, said on Saturday that she would prefer if her father were not reelected so that he can spend more time with her family.
"I am speaking honestly here, and only Allah knows," Mbak Tutut, as she is popularly known, was quoted by the Jakarta Post as saying to thousands of students at Semarang's Diponegoro University.
"If you ask me... my answer is: I personally don't want him to be president again because he never has time for his family."
"For years now, he has had only a little time for us," said Hardiyanti.

Hardiyanti is a leader of the ruling Golkar group which has officially declared its intention to renominate Suharto to his seventh consecutive Assembly (MPR) which will convene next March to elect a president and vice president and endorse the 1998/2003 State Policy Guidelines.

Responding to a student's query about Suharto's health, she said: "He's healthy now. Please Allah, may he be able to finish the duties that the people have mandated to him until next March. May he be given the strength to carry on."
"As for the future, we leave everything to the people and God, this is not yet the time to talk about the next president," she said. "The MPR assembly hasn't even begun. Let's wait and see."

DOC.HEADLINE: FUSELAGE SECTION OF SILKAIR PLANE STILL MISSING

TEXT.P: Indonesia's Transportation Minister Haryanto Dharnutirto on Sunday admitted that a search and rescue team had failed to find the fuselage section of the SilkAir Boeing 737-300 which crashed on Friday into the Musi River in the Sungsang district of South Sumatra.
He was quoted by Antara as saying the team had only found a section of the airplane wreckage.
As no progress has been made so far, the minister said a navy mine sweeper has been deployed to help in the search and was expected to begin operations on Monday morning.
The minister said he has ordered the national search and rescue body to continue the search for a large piece of the fuselage section.
Officials of SilkAir, the regional arm of Singapore Airlines, are said to be mystified at the crash of the 10-month-old jet in good weather, on a routine flight and with an experienced pilot.
There were no distress calls and radio contact was lost only a few minutes before the reported time of the crash.
Eyewitnesses said they heard two explosions before the ill-fated jetliner plunged into the Musi River.

DOC.HEADLINE: AIDS CASES INCREASE DRAMATICALLY IN MAINLAND CHINA
DOC.DATELINE: Hong Kong, Dec. 22 (CNA) (By Wu Shean-shen & Eva Chen)

TEXT.P: Since the first diagnosed case of AIDS in mainland China in 1985, Beijing has tried to tightly control the spread of the disease.
Despite these efforts, however, the number of AIDS patients has increased dramatically, with mainland public health officials claiming on Sunday that the figure has reached 200,000.
Controlling the spread of AIDS is now of unprecedented urgency in mainland China, experts warned.

Among new AIDS cases reported last year, 68 percent were illegal drug users infected through intravenous injections, about 20 percent through transfusions of contaminated blood, and about 6 percent through sexual activity.
In the first nine months of 1997, an additional 2,237 AIDS cases were reported, most of which were drug addicts, accounting for 77.5 percent.

DOC.HEADLINE: SHARE PRICES DOWN ON TAIEX

TEXT.P: Share prices closed 0.6 percent lower on the local stock market on Monday as early buying slowed following a decision by the International Monetary Fund to downwardly adjust global growth forecasts, dealers said.
The prestigious financial institution cut its 1998 global growth forecast from 4.3 to 3.5 percent over the weekend to reflect weak economies in Southeast Asian nations hit by a financial storm.
Speculation that the adverse conditions will linger for an extended period of time affecting stock-buying in the market, the brokers analyzed.
The Taiwan Stock Exchange (TAIEX) weighted price index slipped 50.24 points to close at 8,104.03, while the bourse opened at 8,223.69.
The market experienced a high of 8,226.14, and had a low of 8,096.99.
Losers outnumbered gainers 237 to 175, with 61 shares unchanged.
A total of 1.82 billion shares changed hands on a market turnover of NT$83.96 billion (US$2.6 billion).

Among eight major stock categories, electrical engineering shares fell 1.9 percent, while paper and pulp issues followed with a 1.1 percent loss, plastic and chemical stocks with a 1.0 percent drop, and construction shares with a 0.1 percent decline.
Foodstuff issues rose 0.7 percent, cement shares edged up by 0.6 percent, and textile stocks charted a modest 0.2 percent rise.
Financial shares remained unchanged.

The 10 companies with the largest turnover were: Picvue Electronics, ACER, Chang Hwa Bank, Grand Commercial Bank, Yieh Phui Enterprise, ADI, ICBC, Taiwan Styrene Monomer, United Micro Electronics, and China Life Insurance.

DOC.HEADLINE: US DOLLAR UP

TEXT.P: The US dollar rose NT$0.229 against the New Taiwan dollar on the Taipei foreign exchange market Monday, closing at NT$32.603.
The greenback opened at the day's low of 32.378, and had a high of 32.62.
Interbank US dollar trading reached US$257.5 million.

DOC.HEADLINE: 'LILY' INTERNATIONAL SEX RING DISBANDS

TEXT.P: Following a series of large-scale crackdowns by Taiwan's law-enforcement authorities, a high-profile international sex ring has terminated its illicit operations here, a Taipei prosecutor said on Monday.
Taipei District Prosecutor Liu Cheng-wu said the Taipei County Police Headquarters recently received the passports of many detained foreign prostitutes belonging to the "Lily" sex ring.
"We believe that the passports were mailed to the police bureau by operators of the Lily-associated human smuggling ring as an acknowledgment of the crackdown," Liu said.
By so doing, Liu said, the ring might be making a gesture to inform law-enforcement authorities of its disbanding and to appeal for a halt of further police investigations or raids.
Liu said this was the first time that a large criminal ring has disbanded itself following crackdowns by law-enforcement authorities.

Liu, who is reputed for his integrity and devotion to fighting corruption and the sex trade, said he will continue to direct officers to investigate the case and bring to justice all those involved in the illicit human smuggling and sex peddling operations.

Liu said Taipei County police have been tipped off that the Lily group and the human smuggling operatives connected with the ring had sent back to their home countries a number of foreign prostitutes who have not yet been taken into custody.

"This indicates that the recent crackdown on hostels, restaurants, individual sex brokers or underground brothel operators who colluded with the Lily sex ring have paid off, and that the ringleaders realize their illicit activities are finished," Liu explained.

After Lily operators threatened to kill Liu's family members, Liu vowed to topple the ring within four months. Otherwise, he said he would resign from his post. "I'm very happy to learn that our anti-sex trade operations have brought about good results," the widely respected prosecutor said.

Police investigations show that the Lily ring had recruited foreign women to work as prostitutes through an underworld syndicate which ran an efficient human smuggling operation from Southeast Asia. The human smuggling ring forced those women to serve as prostitutes by confiscating their passports upon their arrival in Taiwan. Police estimated that more than 120 women from Thailand, Malaysia, Singapore, mainland China, Macau and Hong Kong had been forced into the sex trade by the syndicate.
The foreign prostitutes entered Taiwan on tourist visas, or on the basis of fallacious marriages with local men.
In separate raids, law-enforcement officers had managed to arrest nearly 200 people involved in the Lily operation, including prostitutes, brothel operators, sex brokers, drivers and bodyguards.

Liu said law-enforcement authorities began to investigate the criminal activities three months ago. In the process, he said, Thai police have offered much assistance, while cooperation from mainland and Hong Kong authorities was not significant.

DOC.HEADLINE: VALUE OF NOVEMBER FOREIGN ORDERS TOPS US$10 BILLION

TEXT.P: Orders placed by foreign companies with Taiwan businesses and manufacturers in November were worth US$10.3 billion, the ninth consecutive month the US$10 billion mark was broken, the Ministry of Economics Affairs (MOEA) reported on Monday.

Chang Yao-tsung, director-general of the MOEA's Statistics Department, said orders from the United States hit US$3.2 billion in November, up 14.3 percent, or US$400 million, from the same month of 1996.

Affected by the breakout of foot and mouth disease at local hog farms in March and by a stronger Taiwan dollar against the Japanese yen in recent months, the value of Japanese orders placed with local companies in November dropped by an annual rate of 24 percent to US$980 million, the first monthly drop below the US$1 billion level since 1995.

Due to a sluggish information industry in Japan, Japanese orders for Taiwan-made information industry and telecommunications products fell by US$70 million in value, while orders for local plant and animal products declined by US$150 million, a noticeable fall of 79 percent from the same month of 1996, Chang elaborated.

In addition, orders from Hong Kong slid by 3.6 percent, or US$70 million, on an annual basis in November, mainly because of a lackluster demand for textile products in the mainland Chinese market, Chang added.

DOC.HEADLINE: TAIWAN AND TIBET SEEN CONTINUING FRICTION IN AUSSIE-CHINESE TIES

TEXT.P: Australia and mainland China are celebrating their 25th anniversary of formal relations this month and yet Taiwan, Tibet and human rights issues are expected to remain the focus of friction between the two countries.

In its Friday editorial headlined "Building on 25 years of China links," mass circulation newspaper The Australian says: "Today, there is no dispute that the relationship with China is of fundamental importance to Australia. As a trade partner in Asia, China ranks behind only Japan and South Korea. It is a growing source of investment, migrants, students and tourists for Australia and there can be no doubt of its strategic weight and cultural influence."

But the editorial warns: "That is not to say everything is rosy in Australia-China ties. Taiwan, Tibet, human rights issues and the treatment of Australian citizens who fall foul of the Chinese authorities will ensure that some friction remains.

"We should not step back from this. Australia has clearly accepted the principle of 'one China' and does not formally recognize Taiwan. But that does not and should not stop Australia from seeking to maximize its commercial ties with Taiwan," the editorial says.

"Likewise, Australian citizens are used to expressing their opinions freely about what they perceive are injustices in other countries. Freedom of speech on issues such as Tibet or China's treatment of dissidents is part of Australian democracy," it adds.

In another article on Friday headlined "Fear, greed teach us to live with exotic giant" the daily's foreign editor Greg Sheridan says that throughout Australia's history, mainland China has loomed as "the other -- mysterious, exotic, sometimes threatening, sometimes enticing."
"Fear and opportunity have been the two contending, indeed oscillating, motifs in Australia's view of China," he says.

He points out that in the 1990s, there have been periodic disagreements over Hong Kong and mainland China's human rights practices. And Sheridan believes the future of ties between Beijing and Canberra is "unclear."

"There is an influential American view that the Chinese have embarked on a long-term strategy to rid the region of the American military. If that is so, it will ultimately bring China into diplomatic conflict with Australia, as Australia is one of the chief forces anchoring the United States in the region," he adds.

DOC.HEADLINE: US EXPERT PREDICTS 'BIG BUST' FOR MAINLAND ECONOMY

TEXT.P: While Japan is struggling over implementing its "big bang" following the recent economic crisis in Asia, a leading US economics expert has predicted that the next country to experience a bust will be mainland China.
The prediction is made by Prof. Christopher Lingle of the Weatherhead School of Management of Case Western Reserve University in Cleveland, who is currently a visiting scholar in Australia.
In an article published by the Australian Financial Review on Monday, Lingle predicted "China's bubble will blow up in the face of over one billion people."
"While Japan continues to struggle over implementing its 'big bang,' look out for the shock effects of China's 'big bust,'" he warned.
He said the weakest link in the mainland's ability to maintain continued economic progress is the lack of transparency within its financial institutions.

"Avoiding the openness demanded by private investors in bond markets, banks can be obliged to grant loans to meet political ends and so neglect appropriate risk assessment in their lending decisions. These funds may be for subsidies to support industry policy or to reward political cronies," he said.
"Additionally, the Bank of China suffers from a complete lack of independence, and it has never carried out the oversight role of a modern central bank," he pointed out.
He said of the nearly 300,000 state-owned enterprises in the Chinese mainland, roughly 75 percent are effectively bankrupt and are kept afloat only by loans from state banks.

"With or without dramatic reform, China's banking sector faces severe problems in dealing with a ratio of 20 percent to 30 percent of bad loans to assets. However, this figure may mushroom dramatically once property prices and rentals begin to fall in response to the overbuilding in many of China's largest cities," he predicted.
"There is no easy way to sort out the impending financial crisis," Lingle added.

DOC.HEADLINE: AUSSIE RESOURCES FIRMS FACING BLEAKEST YEAR

TEXT.P: Hit by falling prices globally and the recent economic crisis in Asia, Australian resources companies are facing their bleakest Christmas since early 1980s and are now starting to issue warnings that 1998 could even be worse.

The warning was issued by John Prescott, chief executive of Broken Hill Proprietary, Ltd., Australia's largest conglomerate, who revealed that the Asian crisis had cost the company A$17 million in the second quarter of fiscal 1997-98.
He said most of the lost revenue came mainly from reduced steel sales to Asia, including Japan, South Korea, Taiwan and Southeast Asia.
Copper, aluminum, nickel and zinc prices have plunged to new lows as the world commodity crisis deepens.
The falling prices have affected many Australian producers and exporters as their profits plunged sharply, according to resource analysts.

To make the matter worse, Australian gold producers are suffering because of the gold market crash while coal producers are sharing the same fate because they have to reduce prices to compete with major rivals from South Africa, the United States and Canada, the analysts said.
They said the impact would continue in 1998 because they believed the economic crisis in Asia will not be over and that it will take years to recover from such financial turmoil.

The International Monetary Fund has already scaled down its forecast of world economic growth in 1998 to 3.5 percent from its earlier forecast of 4.1 percent, mainly due to the economic crisis in Asia.
Analysts predicted the falling prices of commodities -- which are the backbone of Australia's exports -- will have a considerable impact upon the nation's economic growth.
Federal Treasurer Peter Costello has already predicted that Australia's gross domestic product will grow at about 3.25 percent in fiscal 1998-99, compared to an estimated 3.75 percent in 1997-98.

DOC.HEADLINE: PRESIDENT LEE URGES BEIJING TO RESUME DIALOGUE WITH TAIWAN

TEXT.P: President Lee Teng-hui said here Monday that Beijing should resume dialogue with Taiwan without preconditions.

Speaking at an annual meeting of the Association for the Promotion of National Unification and Development, Lee said the Republic of China government has been promoting civilian exchanges with mainland China in accordance with the "Guidelines for National Unification," hoping to turn cross-strait relations into a new page of peaceful competition.
However, in spite of this, Beijing continued its efforts to isolate Taiwan in the international community and even unilaterally closed down the channel of consultation with Taiwan, he pointed out.

Lee said, in order to break the bottleneck of cross-strait relations, Beijing has to recognize that the two sides of the Taiwan Strait are now under separate rule, abandon its unrealistic ideological warfare against Taiwan, and reopen the channel of consultation with Taiwan without any preconditions.
Lee said the Republic of China government will continue to promote democratization and economic development, strengthen national security, and improve its foreign relations. (by Ed Hsieh)

DOC.HEADLINE: CETRA TO INCREASE OVERSEAS BRANCHES

TEXT.P: Taiwan's major trade promotion organization, the China External Trade Development Council (CETRA), will have three more overseas branches, an official of the council said Monday.
He said the council's Taiwan Trade Center in Warsaw, Poland, will become operational on Jan. 1. It's offices in Tegucigalpa, Honduras, and Asuncion, Paraguay will open later next year.

He also said that CETRA is unable to establish a branch office in mainland China at the present time, but it will collect trade information for Taiwan companies through the trade promotion organization of mainland China. (by Ed Hsieh)

DOC.HEADLINE: CHIAYI COUNTY BECKONING BAYER

TEXT.P: Chiayi County in southern Taiwan will welcome Bayer's investment project with open arms after the German chemical giant announced that it will suspend the project to locate in Taichung, central Taiwan.
Lee Ya-ching, Chiayi County magistrate, said that if the Central Government's environmental assessment of Bayer is up to international standards, he will welcome Bayer wholeheartedly.

Lee said that for the welfare of the people of Chiayi County, he would welcome Bayer to invest in Chiayi. He said the best site for the plant would be at the Auku Industrial Zone, which he said has already cleared 347 hectares out of a proposed 1,031 hectares.
Meanwhile, Bayer Taiwan said that it has taken the initiative by contacting Lee to learn more about his ideas.

Chen Chia-chung, a Bayer Taiwan spokesman, said that any decision on whether to construct the NT$50 billion plant in Chiayi will be up to Bayer headquarters in Germany, but added that the idea may not be feasible.
Chen said that while Bayer Taiwan has suspended all its efforts on the project, it appreciates Lee's offer, and will convey the message to Bayer headquarters for a final decision.

Bayer suspended its two-year investment project after hitting snags over residents' and environmentalists' opposition, a public referendum suggested by Taichung magistrate Liao Yung-lai and problems over land-lease approval in the Taiwan Provincial Assembly.
The land-lease agreement would give Bayer a lease period of 50 years on the provincial government-owned land in the vicinity of Taichung Harbor.

However, Bayer officials said the company has not completely given up its plan to set up its plant in Taiwan, saying that it chose Taiwan as the best site for the toluene di-isocyanate (TDI) plant because of the lucrative Asian market.

Chen said that since the plant will target exports to Asian countries, it has to be located at a harbor, and as no suitable land is available for lease around Keelung and Kaohsiung, the island's other two deep-water ports, Taichung was the only alternative.
Economics Minister Wang Chih-kang said that if Chiayi can meet Bayer's conditions, the government will throw its support behind Lee's offer.

Lee said the only impediment for Bayer to develop the project in Chiayi would be the lack of a deep-water harbor, because that was not included in the planning of the industrial zone in the first place.
In addition, the industrial zone is required to establish a 246-hectare wild bird sanctuary, which was an original condition for permission to turn the original farmland into an industrial zone.

Bayer announced late last week that it was suspending the investment project at Taichung harbor after the Taiwan Provincial Assembly decided to ask a task force to learn more about public opinion in the county and the reliability of Bayer's environmental protection facilities in its review of the land-lease agreement.

Huang Yi-chiao, spokesman for the Taiwan Provincial Government, said that Bayer has put a lot of time and effort into its investment project in Taichung Harbor, and it is questionable whether the company will be prepared to change the site of the project at such short notice.

DOC.HEADLINE: TAIWAN AND NEW ZEALAND FORGE FAIR COMPETITION PACT

TEXT.P: Taiwan and New Zealand have formally signed an agreement to take joint measures in stemming trade practices which are seen as unhealthy to fair competition.
The pact was endorsed last Thursday by the Republic of China's Fair Trade Commission (FTC) and New Zealand's Commercial Council in the New Zealand capital of Wellington.

FTC Chairman Chao Yang-ching told local press here on Monday that the cooperative efforts envisioned under the agreement will not only provide for joint monitoring of market openness and fair trade, but will also will help to strengthen Taipei-Wellington trade and economic ties.

Chao added that the accord also reflects Taiwan's efforts in promoting trade liberalization, which he said is clearly the global trend as most of the world's economies are currently in a process of removing tariff barriers.

Citing the examples of the World Trade Organization, the Organization for Economic Cooperation and Development, and the Asia-Pacific Economic Cooperation forum, Chao pointed out that most major international economic groups are devoting their energies to working out sound competition policies and devising relevant laws to construct a fair and equitable global trade environment.
New Zealand is currently Taiwan's sixth largest trade partner and has agreed to support Taipei's bid for membership in the World Trade Organization.

Chao said that Taiwan and New Zealand are highly complementary in trade and economic structure. Taiwan imports dairy products, frozen beef and lumber from that South Pacific country, while exporting information products, television sets and sports equipment.
Close trade and economic exchanges between the two countries are beneficial to their continued economic development, the FTC leader said.

DOC.HEADLINE: OCAC OFFICIAL: WEI JINGSHENG IS WELCOME TO VISIT TAIWAN

TEXT.P: The Republic of China government will be glad to see mainland Chinese dissident Wei Jingsheng visit Taiwan, Ming Chun-hwa, vice minister of the Overseas Chinese Affairs Commission, said here Sunday.

Wei was sentenced to 15 years in prison in 1979 and another 14 years in 1995 for advocating democracy in mainland China, and was released on medical parole and expelled to the United States in mid-November.
He was warmly received by overseas Chinese when he visited here during the weekend.
Ming, who came here Thursday to attend a meeting of the Chinese Benevolent Association in San Francisco, said he was very glad that Wei was so warmly greeted by overseas Chinese in the city.
Ming also expressed his gratitude to the overseas Chinese residing in the United States for their unswerving support for the Republic of China. (by Neil Lu/ Ed Hsieh)

DOC.HEADLINE: ROC SEEKS TO JOIN CENTRAL AMERICAN GROUP: FOREIGN MINISTRY

TEXT.P: The Ministry of Economic Affairs said on Monday that the Republic of China will seek to join the System for Integration of Central America (SICA), but hopes its membership status will be similar to that of the Dominican Republic.

Vice Foreign Minister Francisco Ou said at a meeting of the Foreign and Overseas Chinese Affairs Committee of the Legislative Yuan that his ministry has exchanged views with the SICA Secretariat on the procedure and timing for the ROC's entry into the regional body.

Answering questions by members of the committee, which is reviewing a joint communique signed in September by President Lee Teng-hui and leaders of six Central American countries during Lee's four-nation Latin American visit, Ou asserted that joining the SICA is of both political and economic significance for the ROC.

Ou said that during Lee's trip, the ROC had expressed keen interest in joining SICA, a regional organization comprising Costa Rica, El Salvador, Honduras, Guatemala, Nicaragua and Belize which aims to promote a common market and integrated community.

That desire was reiterated in a joint communique adopted upon the conclusion of the unprecedented summit between President Lee and leaders of six Central American allies, who lauded the ROC intention to join SICA.

Ou said that the ultimate goal of SICA, which seeks to form a regional trade and political grouping modeled upon the European Union, is to connect itself with the market created by the North American Free Trade Agreement. At a time when the ROC faces difficulties in being admitted to international organizations, membership in SICA will serve the nation's political as well as economic interests, he added.

Legislator Parris Chang of the Democratic Progressive Party (DPP) demanded at the committee meeting that the government provide full information regarding the rights as well as the obligations entailed by the ROC's participation in SICA.

DOC.HEADLINE: US THREATENS SANCTIONS ON MALAYSIAN INSURANCE SECTOR

TEXT.P: The United States, apparently dissatisfied with Malaysia's offer on financial services at the World Trade Organization (WTO), plans to take action if an American insurance company is forced to sell its equity holding in that country, according to reports from the world trade body on Monday.

Insurance giant American International Group Inc. (AIG) had fought Malaysia's proposal at the Geneva-based WTO to cap foreign ownership at 51 percent. It wants to be allowed to hold up to 100 percent.
The US trade sanctions would be applied on Malaysia in the event Kuala Lumpur's offer takes effect as scheduled in March 1999, the WTO report said.

The WTO report did not spell out what kind of sanctions would be imposed on Malaysia, but said that the US would continue to "work out with Malaysia in an amicable way" means to resolve the differences.

The WTO agreement, reached in Geneva on Dec. 13 and endorsed by 102 countries, opens the banking, insurance and securities market. It will cover about US$18 trillion in global securities assets, US$38 trillion in bank lending and nearly US$2.5 trillion in insurance premiums.
The agreement is scheduled to be ratified by the end of January 1999 and go into force by March that year.

DOC.HEADLINE: ATTENTION EDITORS: CNA WILL SUSPEND ITS CEP SERVICE ON DEC. 25
TAIWAN SECOND LARGEST SOURCE OF VISITORS TO HONG KONG

TEXT.P: Taiwan visitors made some 138,000 visits to Hong Kong during the first 11 months of the year, making Taiwan the former British colony's second largest source of foreign visitors.
The statistics made public by the Hong Kong Travel Association, however, found that the number of tourist arrivals from Taiwan decreased by 27,000 or 16.6 percent from the same period of last year.

The largest visitor group comes from mainland China, with the number of trips made by mainlanders accumulating to 196,000 during the 11-month period. The figure represented a slight increase of 1.8 percent on the year-earlier level.

Japan is Hong Kong's third largest source of visitors, but it accounts for the largest drop in the number of arrivals to the territory. Travelers from Japan stood at 86,000 between January and November this year, plummeting nearly 60 percent from the 211,000 visitors recorded over the same 11-month period in 1996.

Between January and November, tourist arrivals from Southeast Asian countries totaled 104,000, declining 24.3 percent on an annual basis. Visitors from Europe and the Middle East numbered 90,000, down 23 percent, while visitors from the United States also slipped 2.8 percent to 66,000.

International travelers in Hong Kong have declined significantly over the past 11 months. The total number of foreign visitors between January and November was 792,000, down 22 percent from the more than 1 million registered a year ago.

DOC.HEADLINE: PERSONNEL SHORTAGE CASTS SHADOW OVER LOCAL INFORMATION INDUSTRY

TEXT.P: Despite ranking third in the world with a total output estimated to reach US$60 billion by 2000, Taiwan's information industry is facing a growth bottleneck because of a shortage of high-level personnel, an analyst said here Monday.

Lin Chen-pang, director for business information at the nonprofit Institute for Information Industry (III), told a symposium that Taiwan's information technology sector, with an output of US$35.7 billion in 1997, tops the list of domestic industries and ranks third in the world after the United States and Japan.

Although Taiwan is touted as an "information kingdom" in terms of computer manufacturing, Lin pointed out that the island lags far behind other advanced countries in computer applications, a situation which blunts the competitive edge of the local information industry and holds back its ability to catch up with the two front-runners.

A shortage of mid-level and senior managerial personnel, the inability to globalize markets and difficulties in obtaining sufficient financing, all loom large as obstacles to the information industry's further development, Lin said.

He warned that without adequately addressing those problems, Taiwan could be overtaken by South Korea and Singapore in the next few years, with little hope of ever catching up to the United States and Japan.

Lin said Taiwan's information industry is expected to post an output of US$60.1 billion by the year 2000, but even that figure will not match the estimated output of the two global leaders at the turn of the century.

According to Lin's analysis, Asia will dominate the global telecommunications market jointly with North America and Europe by 2000, despite the current financial crisis which has plagued most of Southeast Asia and bodes a slowdown of capital inflow to this continent.

DOC.HEADLINE: ROC-INDONESIA ENERGY MEETING OPENS

TEXT.P: The eighth ROC-Indonesia Ministerial Joint Energy Meeting, co-chaired by ROC Economics Minister Wang Chih-kang and Indonesian Minister of Mining and Energy I.B. Sudjana, opened here Monday.

Wang said at the opening ceremony that he hopes the meeting will be upgraded to a ministerial-level conference encompassing all aspects of economic activity between the two countries, which he said would also help to enhance substantive Taipei-Jakarta relations in other areas.

Three major topics -- electric power and coal, natural gas and recycled resources -- are to be discussed by representatives from relevant government agencies and economic institutes, as well as executives of petroleum and power companies from Taiwan and Indonesia.

During the annual meeting, the state-funded Taiwan Power Company is also planning to sign with its Indonesian counterpart a letter of intent on technical cooperation in power resources development, as well as memoranda on personnel and information exchange and the opening of workshops involving the two sides' power-generating departments.

Wang noted that in order to conform with international trends, issues related to the liberalization and privatization of the energy industry will also be included in the yearly conference, which has played an important role in promoting exchanges of power-related resources between Taiwan and Indonesia.

He pointed out that liberalization and privatization had been listed as priority tasks for 1998 in expanding fair trade practices among contracting members of the Asia-Pacific Economic Cooperation (APEC) forum at the grouping's recently concluded ministerial meeting in Vancouver, Canada.

The ROC economics minister said both Taiwan and Indonesia have been committed to energy liberalization and that the two sides are expected to "fully and profitably" exchange their experiences in that effort during the meeting.

Indonesia has for many years been a major supplier of energy resources to the ROC. Taiwan imports of crude oil from that Southeast Asian country amounted to more than 7.57 million barrels last year, accounting for 3.3 percent of Taiwan's total crude oil imports, Wang said.

He also pointed out that between January and September this year, ROC crude imports from Indonesia surged to more than 8.76 million barrels. This represents a jump of 48 percent over the 5.91 million barrels imported during the same period of last year, Wang added.

DOC.HEADLINE: DPP SUPPORTS STATUS QUO FOR TAIWAN
DOC.DATELINE: Tokyo, Dec. 22 (CNA) (By Chang Fang-min & Maubo Chang)

TEXT.P: Declaring that Taiwan is already a sovereign state, the visiting head of Taiwan's opposition Democratic Progressive Party, Hsu Hsin-liang, asserted here Monday that his party supports the status quo for the island.

In a bid to allay international concerns over his party's advocacy of Taiwan independence, Hsu said that maintaining the island's status quo -- even if it is not easy in light of the current international political situation -- means nothing less than keeping its independence.

Hsu, who arrived at the head of a six-member DPP delegation, repeated at a press conference a statement made earlier in the United States that his party is no less concerned than any other political party on Taiwan about the island's security. He said the DPP would never jeopardize Taiwan by irresponsible political adventures, referring to an official declaration of Taiwan's independence from mainland China which would be certain to infuriate Beijing.

Admitting that it is not the view of the DPP establishment, Hsu reiterated his personal advocacy of direct trade, transportation and postal links between Taiwan and mainland China. He said the establishment of such links would benefit both sides.
Taiwan authorities are holding out against implementing the so-called "three links" as leverage to press Beijing into renouncing the use of force against the island.
There have recently been private contacts between DPP legislators and Beijing officials, but no formal meeting has ever taken place, Hsu said.

Noting that Taiwan has emerged relatively unscathed from the current financial crisis sweeping across Southeast Asia, Hsu urged the International Monetary Fund (IMF) to seriously considered Taiwan's bid for membership. He said this will allow the island to actively contribute its resources to the IMF rescue package.

Although Taiwan might be limited in its political stature on the international stage, Hsu said, it is a giant in terms of economic strength, and economic approaches could be vital campaign issues for various Taiwan political parties in the future.

In a gentle jab at Taiwan authorities' insistence upon setting up a regional crisis-management mechanism separate from the IMF, Hsu said it will only drive a wedge between the Western nations and Asia.

He regretted that the multinational chemical giant Bayer has withdrawn a multi-billion dollar investment plan from Taiwan because of the opposition of conservationists and a DPP magistrate, saying it cast a shadow on Taiwan's economic prospects and heightens a false perception that the DPP is anti-industry.
The leader of Taiwan's major opposition party held out hope that a balance between economic development and environmental protection will be achieved through full public discussion.

Hsu said the DPP's overwhelming victory in November's local elections raised the possibility that the ruling Kuomintang will lose its majority in the Legislature in general elections next year, and that a coalition government is more likely than ever to emerge because no party will be able to command a legislative majority.
Hsu and his delegation flew in on Friday from Seoul after observing South Korea's presidential elections. He did not disclose when he will return to Taipei.

DOC.HEADLINE: ACER TOPS 10 LEADING COMPANIES IN TAIWAN FOR 1997

TEXT.P: Computer maker Acer took the first position among Taiwan's top 10 leading companies in 1997 for the third consecutive year in an annual survey made by Hong Kong-based Far Eastern Economic Review.

Other technology companies also excelled in the rating published in the latest edition of the weekly economic magazine. Taiwan Semiconductor jumped four places to second in the top 10, while United Microelectronics advanced three places to sixth.

Formosa Plastics remained in third position. Evergreen Marine slip two notches to fourth, while EVA Airways dropped five places to ninth. A newcomer to the top 10 this year was Cathay Life insurance at 10th.

The top 10 leading companies in Taiwan in descending order are Acer, Taiwan Semiconductor, Formosa Plastics, Evergreen Marine, President Enterprises, United Microelectronics, Nan Ya Plastics, China Steel, EVA Airways, and Cathay Life Insurance.

The survey, which polled nearly 6,000 business executives from around Asia, assessed companies on overall performance and on five areas of excellence: high quality service and products, innovation in responding to customers, long-term management vision, financial soundness, and exemplary qualities to be emulated by other companies.

In the category of "high-quality service and products," Compaq Manufacturing jumped to first spot from the 20th ranking the notebook computer maker received in last year's survey. The other top four in the category are Taiwan Semiconductor, Acer, EVA Airways and United Microelectronics.

In terms of "innovation in responding to customers," China Steel soared to the top of the list from 27th position last year, while Compaq Manufacturing advanced to fifth from 11th. Acer slipped from first place in last year's survey to second, United Microelectronics took third and President Enterprises ranked fourth.
In the category of "long-term management vision," Acer kept its top ranking, followed by EVA Airways, Taiwan Semiconductor, President Enterprises, and Formosa Chemical and Fiber.
Formosa Plastics topped others on assessment of "financial soundness," followed by China Trust, Taiwan Power Company, Asia Cement and Taiwan Cement.
In the category of "company that others try to emulate," the top five are Taiwan Semiconductor, Formosa Chemical and Fiber, Acer, EVA Airways, and President Enterprises.

DOC.HEADLINE: TIMETABLE FOR UNIFICATION NOT BENEFICIAL: MAC OFFICIAL

TEXT.P: Wu Chia-an, vice chairman of the Cabinet-level Mainland Affairs Council (MAC), said on Monday that setting up a timetable for China's unification is not beneficial for future development of cross-strait ties.

Wu made the remarks while answering questions at the Legislative Yuan about a Hong Kong media report that Zhang Wannian, vice chairman of the Central Military Commission of the Chinese Communist Party (CCP) called for setting the year of 2020 as the deadline to resolve the "Taiwan question" in a recent party meeting.
Wu said he was not surprised at the report, as Liu Huaqing, who served in the same post two years ago, also raised an identical proposal.

However, Wu said that the issue remains a matter of dispute within the CCP and pointed out that, according to his knowledge, mainland authorities remain basically opposed to setting a timetable for eventual unification with Taiwan.

In the 1980s, former mainland Chinese paramount leader Deng Xiaoping also claimed that he would achieve China's unification before the end of the decade, but his dream remained unfulfilled at the time of his death in February 1997, Wu added.
A fixed timetable will not necessarily help bring about unification, Wu said, claiming that it could serve to create tensions within the CCP and between the two sides of the Taiwan Strait.

He went on to say that the best way to ease tensions across the Taiwan Strait is to resume regular bilateral talks, adding that Taiwan and the mainland are likely to reopen such talks in May or June if the two sides can first reach a consensus on which topics to discuss.
