DOC.HEADLINE: SHARE PRICES DOWN ON TAIEX

TEXT.P: Share prices closed 0.8 percent lower on the local stock market on Tuesday as buying slowed as a result of a sharp fall in the value of the South Korean currency, dealers said.

The brokers pointed out that the South Korean temporarily broke the 2,000-mark against the US dollar Tuesday morning. They said the optimism of local investors faded over worries that South Korea's financial crisis will spread to neighboring countries, including Taiwan.
The Taiwan Stock Exchange (TAIEX) weighted price index lost 65.72 points to finish at the day's low of 8,038.31.
The bourse opened at 8,223.69.
Losers overwhelmed gainers 323 to 82, with 62 shares unchanged.
A total of 1.76 billion shares changed hands on a market turnover of NT$83.86 billion (US$2.62 billion).

Banking shares registered the largest fall of 1.9 percent among eight major stock categories, while paper and pulp issues followed with a 1.2 percent drop. Plastics, chemical and textile shares all registered a 1.1 percent loss, both cement and construction issues saw a 0.7 percent decline, and technology stocks charted a 0.1 percent decrease.
Foodstuff issues posted a modest 0.2 percent gain.

The 10 companies with the largest turnover were: Picvue Electronics, Tong Lung Metal Industry, Taiwan Styrene Monomer, ADI, Dah An Bank, Chang Hwa Bank, ACER, Formosa Plastic, Union Petrochemical, and Mosel Vitelic.

DOC.HEADLINE: ROC HAS NEVER VIOLATED NUCLEAR AGREEMENT: OFFICIAL
DOC.DATELINE: San Francisco, Dec. 22 (CNA) (By Neil Lu and Sofia Wu)

TEXT.P: The Republic of China has never violated the provisions of an agreement with the Vienna-based International Atomic Energy Agency (IAEA) on the application of nuclear energy, an ROC official stationed here said on Monday.

"Although the ROC is not an IAEA member, it has consistently abided by the provisions of the ROC-IAEA-USA Agreement for the Application of Safeguards signed in the early 1970s," said Chou Jen-chang, head of the science division of the ROC representative office in San Francisco.

Chou, a former director of the nuclear energy research institute under the ROC's military-run Chungshan Institute of Science and Technology (CIST), made the remarks after an article carried in the current issue of the Bulletin of Atomic Scientists urged Taiwan to make public details of its past nuclear bomb development programs.

The article, co-authored by David Albright, president of the private US-based Institute for Science and International Security, and an associate, Corey Gay, said Taiwan seemed to have dropped active bomb-building efforts after a top official in charge of the program defected to the United States in 1988.

Col. Chang Hsien-yi, then deputy director of the CIST's nuclear energy research institute, stole vital documentation, evidence with which Washington forced Taipei to scrap its atomic bomb development plan.
Chou was Chang's superior when he left Taiwan and took refuge in the United States in the late 1980s. For years, Chou, a retired naval captain, has kept silent on the incident.
As Albright's article again called public attention to the incident, Chou broke silence for the first time and stepped forward to defend the ROC's position and image.
Chou said the IAEA has never found in its regular inspections that the ROC has ever violated international requirements or broken its promises on the peaceful use of nuclear energy.
Chou, however, declined to make any comments on the Chang Hsien-yi incident.

According to a recent report in the New York Times, Chang was recruited by the Central Intelligence Agency in the 1960s, when he was a military cadet. In the 1970s, as he rose through the ranks of Taiwan's secret weapons hierarchy, Chang was cultivated as a spy for the United States, the Times quoted US intelligence sources as saying.

Chang helped the Washington obtain information that could not be detected through electronic eavesdropping or spy satellites, the paper said. After taking refuge in the United States, Chang effectively disappeared, and the CIA refuses to discuss the matter.
Since Chang's defection, the paper said, Taipei's official position has been that it will not use its scientific expertise and technical abilities to build a nuclear weapon.

DOC.HEADLINE: TAIPEI MULLING CLOSURE OF MISSION IN LIBYA

TEXT.P: The Ministry of Foreign Affairs (MOFA) is considering the closure of its representative office in Libya, as the north African country has been unfriendly to ROC personnel stationed there, an official with the MOFA said on Tuesday.
Timothy C.T. Yang, director of the African Affairs Department under the MOFA, made the remarks at a public hearing held in the Legislative Yuan.

Yang said that the Libyan government in Tripoli, yielding to pressure from Beijing, has frequently boycotted activities of the ROC representative office there and that the existence of the mission there contributes a great burden to the ROC government.
As mainland China is the only country which supports Libya amid worldwide sanctions against it, it is hard for Tripoli to resist pressure from Beijing, Yang pointed out.

In addition to voicing opposition to the ROC's membership in the United Nations and demanding the ROC representative office refrain from using the nation's official name in local trade exhibitions, the Libyan government has also suspended the office's rights to issue visas. Tripoli has threatened to close the office and no longer grant residence permits to ROC officials, he added.

It is a humiliation for the ROC government that its overseas mission was threatened by the host country, which Yang said has prompted the MOFA to consider closing the office in Libya after a thorough review of its operations, functions and the financial and personnel burden incurred by the ROC government.

Y. F. Chu, deputy director of the Economic and Trade Affairs Department under the MOFA, said that shutting down the office is a painful decision, but that it is unable to operate as it should. Taiwan business interests are important, but the personal safety and property holdings of Taiwan citizens are much more important, she stressed, pointing out that annual bilateral trade between the two countries remains at a modest level of US$27 million.

DOC.HEADLINE: BEIJING TO SUPPORT LAID-OFF WORKERS FOR THREE YEARS: ZHU RONGJI
DOC.DATELINE: Hong Kong, Dec. 23 (CNA) (By Wu Shean-shen & Eva Chen)

TEXT.P: Mainland China's Vice Premier Zhu Rongji recently told an economic conference that the merit of a shareholding system implemented as part of the reform of state-owned enterprises is overstated, stressing that 10 million laid-off workers in the mainland will be supported for three years, Hong Kong's Singtao Jihpao reported on Tuesday.

Zhu, also deputy head of the Central Financial and Economic Leading Group of the Chinese Communist Party (CCP), warned that the most important task facing the mainland economy is to reform the system of state-owned enterprises, emphasizing that failure to do so will lead to disaster.

However, Zhu complained about assertions by some that a shareholding system is the only remedy for the difficulties confronted by the state-owned enterprises. In fact, Zhu remarked, such a system is by no means the sole solution, and it alone cannot resolve the current problems.

According to one of the officials attending the meeting, Zhu was quoted as sternly warning: "Don't take it for granted that the 15th CCP National Congress is a venue for the mobilization of a shareholding system."

The target of resolving problems confronting the state-owned businesses is to make 500 of the country's large and medium-sized enterprises profitable, Zhu stressed. In addition, 10 million laid-off workers will be supported for at least three years by the government, private enterprises and local communities, with each of these sectors providing one-third of their living allowances.

DOC.HEADLINE: PRESIDENT LEE MEETS HONDURAN VICE PRESIDENT

TEXT.P: President Lee Teng-hui on Monday reaffirmed friendly relations between the Republic of China and Honduras when meeting with Honduran Vice President Walter Lopez Reyes.

Lee thanked Lopez for the warm welcome the people and government of Honduras extended to him during his visit to that country in September. He also asked Lopez to convey his personal regards to Honduran President Carlos Roberto Reina.

The ROC president told his visitor that a task force has been formed by the government to study measures aimed at facilitating the implementation of the conclusions reached at a summit between Lee and the leaders of six Central American countries during Lee's Latin American visit in September. The six nations were Costa Rica, El Salvador, Honduras, Guatemala, Nicaragua and Belize.

Lopez expressed gratitude for the long-term assistance the ROC government has provided to his country, adding that he hopes the ROC and Honduras will further strengthen their relations based on the already-close cooperative and friendly ties.

At noon, Vice President Lien Chan hosted a lunch in honor of Lopez with Foreign Minister Jason Hu, Deputy Secretary-General to the President Su Chi and Honduran Ambassador Daniel Edgardo Milla taking part.

Lien said that relations between the ROC and Honduras have been growing closer, as evidenced by the increasing exchange of visits by high-ranking officials, including Honduran President Reina's visit to the ROC last July and Lee's trip to Tegucigalpa in September.

Lien also praised Lopez for the contribution he has made to his country since assuming the vice presidency. Lien said that Lopez has made significant achievements in upgrading cultural and educational development in his country and that the housing policy promoted by Lopez has greatly improved the welfare of the Honduran people.
Earlier in the day, Lopez presided over the opening of the Honduras Golf Charity Invitational, a fund-raising activity aimed at helping poor and handicapped children in the Central American country.

At the tournament, jointly sponsored by the ROC-Honduras Cultural, Economic and Trade Association and the ROC Golf Association, Lopez thanked all the participants for helping make the charity event a success.

The golf tournament will help to further cement long-term friendly relations between the two countries, Lopez said, adding that the proceeds raised at the event will be donated to a social welfare foundation run by the wife of Honduran President Reina.
Lopez arrived in Taipei on Dec. 20 for a six-day visit. He is scheduled to depart on Thursday.

DOC.HEADLINE: NO EVIDENCE OF MECHANICAL FAILURE FOR SILKAIR CRASH

TEXT.P: There is no evidence that mechanical failure caused the crash of SilkAir flight MI-185, as suggested by Indonesian officials on Sunday, SilkAir said Monday.
"There is little evidence to suggest that because it was very well maintained with no known defects," SilkAir spokesman Rick Clements said at a briefing.
"We have to see what evidence we can get from the black box and the wreckage," he added.
He also said that the airline had received no bomb threat and nobody had claimed responsibility for blowing up the plane.
However, the airline had not ruled out these possibilities.
"Nothing has been ruled out. We have to remain open-minded because we have so little information to work with," Clements said.
The aircraft was not carrying any hazardous cargo, he said.

As for sabotage, a spokesman for the Civil Aviation Authority of Singapore (CAAS) said at the briefing that the standard of security was very high at Changi Airport, where the ill-fated flight originated.
"Airports all over the world have to comply with international standards and I'm sure this was so for the Indonesian airport too," he said.
Clements said there was no information that the aircraft had changed its flight path, contrary to some earlier press reports.

Refuting rumors that the plane had been delayed in its takeoff from Jakarta on Friday, the CAAS spokesman said the plane had actually taken off at 3:23 p.m., Jakarta time, some seven minutes earlier than scheduled.

SilkAir flight MI-185, a 10-month-old Boeing 737-300, crashed at the mouth of Musi River, some 35 miles north of Palembang, south Sumatra, Indonesia, last Friday afternoon en route from Jakarta back to Singapore.
All the 104 passengers and crew onboard the aircraft were believed killed in the crash, the first-ever accident for the world-renowned Singapore Airlines and its subsidiary, SilkAir.
Meanwhile, the contingency of hundreds of rescuers widened their search efforts at the crash site by using sophisticated sonar equipment to search for the plane's black box.

Singapore's Communications Minister Mah Bow Tan, who flew to inspect the crash site Monday, told a press conference that workers had found some aircraft parts that came from near the section of the Boeing 737-300 where the flight data and voice recorders are normally located, said reports from Palembang.
"This indicates that they are slightly closer to locating the black box," he was quoted as saying.
He added that search operations would also be widened to include a land search and other parts of the Musi River where the plane crashed.
Rescuers, meanwhile, looking desperately for survivors, saw only body parts floating in various parts of the four-kilometer-wide river.

Brig. Gen. Ryamizard, the chief-of-staff of the South Sumatran Military Command, who is overseeing the search operations, said that villagers found some decomposed body parts near the river bank early Monday.
A C-130 Singapore Air Force plane brought two refrigerated containers to preserve the body parts found at the crash site.
Singapore Airlines chairman S. Dhanabalan, who was also present at the crash site Monday, told the press conference that none of the body parts found so far could not be identified.
He said the present phase of the operation would focus on the recovery of bodies because many relatives of the victims wanted to take their remains back home.

DOC.HEADLINE: U.S. GOLD MINING FIRM BIDS TO BUY AUSSIE COUNTERPART

TEXT.P: The California-based Homestake Mining Co. has made an A$1 billion offer to buy Plutonic Resources of Western Australia, which has been hit hard by falling bullion prices in the world market because of the sales of reserves gold by the Reserve Bank earlier this year.
The bid follows a major sell-off of gold shares owned by Plutonic and other Australian gold mining firms, sparked by the sharp falls in world bullion prices, which now hover below US$290 per ounce.

Homestake, which has a long presence in Australia, said Monday it would offer 34 of its shares for every 100 Plutonic shares, valuing Australia's third largest gold miner at A$5.19 a share or A$970 million.
The offer represents an 86 percent premium to Plutonic's share price before it was suspended on Monday, but is below its 1997 high of A$5.96.
The Homestake-Plutonic group would emerge as North America's third largest gold producer -- and Australia's second largest after Normandy Mining Corp., metal analysts said.

Other Australian gold mining firms, including Newcrest Mining and Australian Resources, are likely to be prime targets for foreign companies because they are having hard times from the recent fall in gold prices, they added.
The Plutonic deal is believed to have been driven by its major shareholder, Malaysian Mining Corporation (MMC), which owns 32 percent of the Australian company.
MMC, like other Asian firms, has been hit hard by the Asian economic crisis, and has no choice but to seal the deal with Homestake, analysts said.
Australia is the world's third largest gold producer and exporter with its output totaling about 290 tons in 1996-97.

DOC.HEADLINE: CANADIAN DOLLAR CONTINUES SLIDE

TEXT.P: The Canadian dollar continued its downward spiral Monday, shedding 0.17 US cents to close at 69.71 US cents.
It slipped as low as 69.66 US cents as Bank of Canada rushed in to buy Canadian dollars to stop its slide.
The loonie (Canadian dollar) reached its record low on Feb. 4, 1986, trading at 69.17 US cents per loonie.
Observers said the Canadian dollar will likely remain stuck below 70 US cents until the new year.
Investors are divided on whether the Bank of Canada will move this week to push up interest rates to protect the currency.
Some analysts expected a hike in the bank rate -- perhaps more than one-third of a percentage point -- this week, while others said the central bank will opt to let the dollar drop even further.

One senior bank economist said: "It seems to have found a trading range here. (But) there's nothing sacred about 70 cents. We may establish an all-time low sometime this winter before the Canadian dollar starts to rebound."

The concern for consumers is that further weakness in the dollar could force the Bank of Canada to raise interest rates, leading the big banks to hike the cost of borrowing for mortgages and consumer, corporate and car loans.
Jeff Rubin, chief economist at the Canadian Imperial Bank of Commerce (CIBC), warned a 0.33 percent increase in the central bank rate could kill 100,000 jobs next year.
A rate hike would also dampen domestic spending and economic growth, he pointed out.

Still, the fallout from another rate increase probably wouldn't cripple the Canadian economy because interest rates remain close to 30-year lows and the economy is much stronger today than it was three years ago.
Speculators started "testing" the loonie Friday after the latest inflation figures showed prices rose only 0.9 percent in November -- the lowest inflation rate since January 1995.
Part of the problem for Canada is that the ongoing currency crisis in Southeast Asia has led to slack demand for Canadian exports, particularly for commodities such as coal, lumber and gold.
It is a widely held perception that Canada's economy remains rather dependent on exports from its mines, mills and forests.
As a matter of fact, seventy percent of the goods Canada exports are manufacturing-based and 30 percent are commodity-based.

DOC.HEADLINE: S'PORE MANUFACTURING INVESTMENTS TO EXCEED 1996 RECORD

TEXT.P: Manufacturing investments in Singapore this year are set to exceed the record S$8.1 billion registered last year, Singapore's Trade and Industry Minister Lee Yock Suan said Monday night.

Speaking at the first anniversary dinner of the Singapore Confederation of Industries (SCI), Lee disclosed that manufacturing investment commitments in the first 11 months of this year already total S$8.1 billion, the same amount as that recorded for the whole of last year.
He stressed that "manufacturing and services will remain our twin engines of growth."
In 1996, manufacturing contributed 24 percent of Singapore's gross domestic product (GDP) and 23 percent of employment, making it the largest sector in Singapore's economy.
"Our aim is to maintain manufacturing's share of GDP at about 25 percent and its share of employment at about 20 percent," Lee told the nation's industrial leaders who attended the dinner.
This is comparable to advanced economies such as Japan, Britain and Switzerland which are placing increased emphasis on strengthening their manufacturing sectors, he added.
Turning to the currency turmoil sweeping through Asia, Lee said recent events were throwing up new threats as well as opportunities.
"Our strong economic fundamentals are helping us to weather the storm and we are in a position to build on our strength," he said.
However, Singapore could not avoid being affected by events in neighboring countries which were among its main trading partners as well as competitors in certain fields.
Lee said he remained optimistic that Singapore would emerge stronger after the crisis and that the region would continue to grow more rapidly compared to other regions.

He said the government on its part was committed to support industries by helping to build world-class capabilities, enhancing competitiveness, providing tax and other incentives to industries for upgrading, and by helping companies to capitalize on the competitive advantages of regional countries for mutual benefit.
As Singapore moves up the value chain towards a knowledge-based
economy, it will need to build up capabilities in marketing, design, research and development and software development, he said.
He pointed out that the private sector has a critical role to play in Singapore's next phase of development.
"The SCI can contribute to this by acting as a two-way bridge between industry and government and by helping members to enhance their competitiveness," he said.

DOC.HEADLINE: AUSSIE SCIENTISTS DISCOVER COWS ABLE TO JOIN SHARKS IN WAR ON CANCER

TEXT.P: Australian scientists have discovered cattle cartilage containing substances similar to those with cancer-fighting properties in shark cartilage.

The scientists now working for the Commonwealth Scientific and Industrial Research Organization (CSIRO) hope that an anti-cancer extract from cattle cartilage will provide a significant financial boost to the depressed cattle industry in Australia and relieve the heavy pressure on the shark population.
The Australian daily on Tuesday quoted team leader Greg Harper as saying that the work began with the interest of Brisbane-based companies in commercializing shark cartilage.

"Sharks are in short supply. Our concern is that it is not a sustainable resource with the number of sharks being taken, and the sheer magnitude of this market in the United States. It is already big in Asia. We are looking to take advantage of cattle cartilage, which is already there in large amounts, and to try and commercialize that," Harper said.
He said there was "enough evidence in the United States, China and Europe of the efficacy of cartilage" in combating cancer.
Cartilage, which is found on the tips of ribs and the sternum, in joints and the ears and nose, has neither nerves, blood vessels or a lymphatic system. It inhibits the growth of blood vessels.
"It stops the supply of nutrients through to a tumor and inhibits migration of that tumor back out," Harper said.
He said overseas research had demonstrated that certain extracts of shark cartilage, injected into tumors, caused them to regress.
"It appears from international research that those activities exist in bovine cartilage but they need to be extracted and enriched," he said.

Harper and a Chinese colleague are working to find the active components, the glycosaminoglycans or GAGs, "to identify what the best bovine sources are, and what process we need to go through to enrich but not destroy the activity."

He said the discovery will benefit Australia because the market for shark cartilage in the United States alone is worth more than A$1 billion a year. The shark cartilage sells for up to A$500 per kilogram in the United States.
He said in Australia, cattle cartilage is virtually thrown away, used in the manufacture of blood-and-bone fertilizer.
CSIRO Tropical Agriculture chief Elizabeth Heij said the research has the potential to turn a common, low-value product into a "very high-value product. The human benefits are quite large."

DOC.HEADLINE: REPUBLICANS GAINING UPPER HAND IN AUSTRALIA

TEXT.P: Australians have voted overwhelmingly to break traditional ties with the British monarchy when it comes to choosing representatives to the Constitutional Convention in February 1998.

The Australian Electoral Commission on Monday released final results of a poll which showed 47 of the 76 elected delegates to the Constitutional Convention would urge the government to break the traditional ties with the British monarchy and opt for a republic for the country.
The Australian Republican Movement (ARM) is confident that Australia will become a republic and the problem is now one of good timing for the country to break its ties with the United Kingdom.

ARM chairman Malcolm Turnbull, a convention delegate, said: "I think the major focus must be to reach consensus. I think the Australian people will be very unsympathetic with delegates who go to the convention in a very doctrinaire, narrow-minded way.

"We would like to see the convention, before it talks about mode of election, actually talk about what it wants its head of state to do. If your answer is you want someone impartial and above party politics, then it becomes harder to justify direct election," he added.
The 76 elected delegates will join 40 politicians from the federal, state and territorial parliaments and 35 appointed by the federal Parliament to take part in the 10-day convention in February.

If the convention reaches consensus on the preferred model for a republic, a referendum will be held on this model by the end of the year 2000. If not, Australians will vote on constitutional options through a plebiscite.
Australia, one of the Commonwealth member countries, currently recognizes the British monarch has as its titular head of state.

DOC.HEADLINE: ROC, S. AFRICA REACH AGREEMENT ON FRAMEWORK FOR NEW RELATIONS

TEXT.P: The Republic of China and South Africa have reached agreement on the framework for new relations after Jan. 1, 1998, according to a statement of the ROC government.

The statement, issued by the ROC Embassy in Pretoria late Monday afternoon, said that as from Jan. 1, 1998, an office known as the Taipei Liaison Office in the Republic of South Africa will be established in Pretoria.
There will also be established in Johannesburg, Cape Town and Durban offices known as the Taipei Liaison Office, it said.
The ROC has also agreed to the establishment of a Liaison Office of South Africa in Taipei as from Jan. 1 next year.

The statement said both sides agreed that the new offices should be given necessary functions for the continuation of economic, trade, educational, cultural, scientific, technical, financial and other exchanges and cooperation, in order to maintain substantive relations on a mutually beneficial basis.
Their personnel should also be given the necessary conveniences, enabling them to perform their duties on an equal and reciprocal footing, it said.

Since the South African government announced on Nov. 27, 1996, that it would end diplomatic relations with the Republic of China, the two sides have held three high-level talks and 11 working-level sessions.

In the course of the negotiations, the statement said, the ROC government has maintained a frank and realistic attitude, seeking to achieve the best possible arrangement on the basis of equality and reciprocity.

The statement said that, with a view toward the future, the ROC government hopes the South African government will, mindful of the long historical ties and mutual respect between the two countries, continue to develop constructive relations in conformity with the interests of both countries and their peoples.

DOC.HEADLINE: US DOLLAR DOWN

TEXT.P: The US dollar dropped NT$0.083 against the New Taiwan dollar on the Taipei foreign exchange market Tuesday, closing at the day's low of NT$32.52.
The greenback opened at 32.9, and experienced a high of 32.93.
Interbank US dollar trading reached US$341.5 million.

DOC.HEADLINE: TAIWAN-SOUTH AFRICA TRADE TIES TO REMAIN UNCHANGED

TEXT.P: The planned suspension of diplomatic relations between the Republic of China and South Africa by year's end is not expected to affect the existing economic ties between the two countries, the Ministry of Economic Affairs (MOEA) said on Tuesday.

But how to protect Taiwan business interests there remains a pressing question, as the two countries have yet to sign a bilateral investment guarantee agreement, the MOEA noted, adding that pushing for the inking of the accord will be its top priority after the two countries sever diplomatic ties.
There are currently more than 300 Taiwan businesses and 30,000 Taiwan citizens based in South Africa, but the numbers are declining as the change in bilateral ties approaches, according to the MOEA.

Lin Chen-kuo, chairman of the semi-official China External Trade Development Council, said the two economies are complementary and mutually-beneficial and that both sides should continue their economic exchanges despite the cutting of formal ties.

Bilateral economic relations have traditionally been close, with two-way trade reaching more than US$180 million in 1995, and Taiwan investment in South Africa amounting to over US$1 billion, he pointed out.
Meanwhile, the ROC Tourism Bureau said the number of Taiwan tourists visiting South Africa in the first ten months of the year posted a decline of 90 percent from the same period of last year.
Only 1,387 Taiwan tourists visited South Africa in the January-October period, a far cry from 13,899 recorded in the same period of 1996, according to travel business sources.
The visa division of the South African embassy here confirmed that the number of visa applications by Taiwan travelers declined significantly this year.

DOC.HEADLINE: DPP WIN IN LOCAL ELECTIONS VOTED TOP DOMESTIC NEWS STORY OF 1997

TEXT.P: The resounding win by the opposition Democratic Progressive Party (DPP) in the Nov. 29 mayoral and county chief elections was overwhelmingly voted the top domestic news event of 1997 in an opinion poll of local media professionals.

The pro-Taiwan independence DPP won 12 top local government posts in the nationwide elections, while the ruling Kuomintang won in only eight constituencies and the remaining three seats went to independents.
Editors-in-chief and news department heads of major news organizations in the Taiwan area as well as CNA editors jointly selected the top 10 domestic news stories of 1997.
Other events comprising the top 10 list in descending order are:
-- An outbreak of foot-and-mouth disease at hog ranches around the island in mid-March. The epidemic cost Taiwan an estimated NT$160 billion (US$4.92 billion) in economic losses.

-- The passage of a package of constitutional amendments by the National Assembly, which provided for suspension of provincial-level elections, redefinition of relations between central and local governments and establishment of a dual-leadership system at the central government.

-- The suicides of Lin Chun-sheng and Kao Tien-ming, two key suspects in the Pai Hsiao-yen kidnap-murder case, following two separate shootouts with police, and the surrender of Chen Chin-hsing, a third mastermind in the Pai case, after a 24-hour standoff with police. The standoff began with Chen taking hostage South African military attache Col. McGill Alexander and his family of four.

-- The kidnap-murder of Pai Hsiao-yen, the teenage daughter of popular entertainer Pai Ping-ping, in April. The crime shocked local society and sparked a public outcry over the government's inability to curb the crime rate. Tens of thousands of ordinary citizens took to the streets to vent their discontent at worsening social order.

-- Typhoon Winnie which pounded Taiwan with strong winds and heavy rains and left 40 dead and 81 injured. The most serious was the collapse of the Lincoln Vila in Hsichi, Taipei County, in which 28 people were killed and 47 others injured.

-- The announcement by the Ministry of Civil Service under the Examination Yuan of the enforcement of a five-day work week scheme in two stages for government employees. Starting on Jan. 1, 1998, all public agencies will implement a five-day work week every other week, which will be expanded to every week from Jan. 1, 2001.

-- President Lee Teng-hui's four-country Latin American tour in September, which took him to Panama, Honduras, El Salvador and Paraguay. During his two-week visit, Lee attended the World Congress on the Panama Canal and a summit meeting of top leaders from six Central American countries.

-- The depreciation of the New Taiwan dollar against the US dollar after the Central Bank of China stopped intervention in market operations. The NT dollar has fallen below the NT$30 vs. US$1 level to a 10-year low of NT$33 for the greenback.

-- Taiwan Governor James Soong's announcement that he was to resign to express his opposition to the government's proposal to suspend provincial-level elections. Soong later decided to stay in his post until his tenure expires in late 1998.

DOC.HEADLINE: TAIWAN TO STRENGTHEN FOREIGN TRADE

TEXT.P: Economics Minister Wang Chih-kang said here on Tuesday that Taiwan has mapped out suitable measures for dealing with Japan's planned suspension of preferential taxation on imports from Taiwan.
Wang confirmed that Japan has decided to cease its policy of favorable duty on Taiwan imports by 2000, a decision which he said is bound to enlarge Taiwan's already huge trade deficit with Japan.

In order to minimize the expected impact of the Japanese move, and to reduce the island's reliance on the Japanese market, the Ministry of Economic Affairs (MOEA) has formulated new strategies to further promote trade with other countries and to enhance the competitiveness of Taiwan products, Wang said.

The minister expanded on this statement, saying such plans include the semi-official China External Trade Development Council's (CETRA) series of "market-offensives," which are aimed at opening more trade markets in countries such as Japan, Turkey, Poland and India.

The so-called "market-offensives" refers to a plan under which CETRA will help local businesses make direct contact with foreign buyers through the opening of trade fairs and workshops in the targeted countries.

The MOEA said that the Japanese government last Friday reviewed its favorable duty system, and concluded that some countries and areas, including Taiwan, South Korea, Hong Kong and Singapore, should be taken off Japan's favorable status list because the gross national products (GNPs) of all four countries have reached over US$9,000.
Japan will gradually implement its decision from April, 1998, with the objective of suspending all preferential treatment for the countries and areas on the list by April 2000, the MOEA said.

According to MOEA statistics, Taiwan's exports to Japan which enjoyed favorable duty hit 253.6 billion Japanese yen (US$1.9 billion) in the period from April 1996 to March 1997. Most of these exports were industrial and mineral products.
Other Taiwan products which will feel the impact of the new measures include chemical goods, agricultural products and synthetic fibers.
The MOEA's Board of Foreign Trade estimated that the new tariffs will cost Taiwan at least an additional 2 billion yen (US$15 million) every year.

DOC.HEADLINE: NO ZERO-SUM GAME IN US RELATIONS WITH TAIPEI, BEIJING: ROTH
DOC.DATELINE: Washington, Dec. 22 (CNA) (By Herman Pan and Sofia Wu)

TEXT.P: A senior Clinton Administration official said on Monday that he sees no "zero-sum" game in US relations with Taiwan and mainland China.

Stanley Roth, assistant secretary of state for East Asian and Pacific Affairs, said at a year-end press conference that the US consistently believes it can simultaneously promote relations with both sides of the Taiwan Strait.

"If you look, ever since 1979 the better US-PRC relations have been, the better US-Taiwan relations -- unofficial though they may be -- have been, and the better that Taiwan-PRC relations have been," Roth said in his first news briefing for Asian media since he assumed office more than five months ago.
Roth claimed that the three sets of bilateral relationships -- Washington-Taipei, Washington-Beijing and Taipei-Beijing -- can advance simultaneously.

Noting that a summit meeting between President Bill Clinton and mainland Chinese President Jiang Zemin at the White House in late October had contributed much to the improvement in overall Washington-Beijing relations, Roth stressed that nothing happened at the summit to in any way diminish or otherwise change the nature of the unofficial US-Taiwan relationship.

He went on to say that the United States remains optimistic that the two sides of the Taiwan Strait will in fact work out their differences and get their dialogue restarted. "We've seen indications and statements on both sides that they would like to see this happen, and it is not for the United States to try to propose a fix. I think it is up to the parties themselves."

DOC.HEADLINE: TAIWAN'S TRADE DEFICIT WITH JAPAN TO HIT NEW HIGH

TEXT.P: Taiwan's trade deficit with Japan is likely to break the US$20 billion mark next year as Japan is scheduled to cancel preferential tariff rates on one-fifth of Taiwan products from April 1998, the Ministry of Economic Affairs (MOEA) said on Tuesday.

According to ministry statistics, Taiwan already incurred a trade deficit of US$15.57 billion in the first 11 months of this year. The amount already exceeded the US$13.83 trade deficit recorded for entire last year.

As continued depreciation of the Japanese yen against the US dollar has made Japanese products even more competitive, MOEA officials worry that Taiwan's trade imbalance with Japan would soar further in the months ahead.
Chang Yao-tsung, director-general of the MOEA's statistics department, predicted that this year's trade deficit with Japan would break the previous high of US$17.11 billion set in 1995.

If Japan really suspends its preferential tariff rates for Taiwan's steel, petrochemical, synthetic fibers and other related products from next April, Chang said the island's trade gap with Japan would widen further. The new tariff rates for those products will nearly double the current figures.

Taiwan has relied heavily on Japan's supply of electronics parts and components. With the world demand for Taiwan's information-technology products increasing, its imports of Japanese parts and components would continue to rise.

On the other hand, Taiwan has found it hard to expand its sales to the recession-hit Japan. Since an outbreak of foot-and-mouth disease at local hog ranches in mid-March, Taiwan has been forced to suspended port exports to Japan. The ban has cut Taiwan exports to that country by an estimated NT$48 billion (US$1.48 billion).
Against this background, the semi-official China External Trade Development Council (CETRA) has decided to step up promotional efforts to help local companies tap the Japanese market.
CETRA has so far organized three trade promotion missions to visit Japan, with regional hypermarkets in western and southern Japan as their priority targets.

CETRA said it will john forces with government agencies and its offices in Tokyo, Osaka and Fukuoka to conduct 80 promotional programs in the first half of next year. The planned programs are expected to bring about US$800 million in additional Taiwan exports to Japan.

Meanwhile, CETRA will continue to lobby major Japanese conglomerates to set up key components and parts production facilities in Taiwan and to increase purchases from Taiwan. Under CETRA's efforts, large Japanese enterprises, including Hitachi, Fujitsu, Itochu, Mitsubishi, Sharp and Kyoto Ceramics, have struck more than US$100 million worth of purchase deals with local companies over the past year.

DOC.HEADLINE: TAIPEI ANNOUNCES SEVERANCE OF TIES WITH PRETORIA

TEXT.P: The Republic of China Foreign Affairs Ministry announced on Tuesday afternoon the severance of diplomatic relations with South Africa from Dec. 31.

"Substantial Taipei-Pretoria relations, however, will continue under a new framework agreed upon by the two sides," said Foreign Ministry Spokesman Roy Y.Y. Wu and Timothy C.T. Yang, director of the ministry's African Affairs Department.
Under the framework, the ROC will operate Taipei Liaison Offices in Pretoria, Cape Town, Johannesburg and Durban, while a Liaison Office of South Africa will be established in Taipei.

The new arrangement, worked out in three rounds of high-level negotiations and 12 rounds of working-level talks, "is acceptable to the Foreign Affairs Ministry, although it's not totally satisfactory," Yang said.

South African President Nelson Mandela announced on Nov. 27 last year that Pretoria will shift its diplomatic recognition from Taipei to Beijing from the beginning of next year. Since then, both sides have been negotiating grounds for maintaining substantial ties between them.

He said that the title "Taipei Liaison Office" was decided upon by the ROC itself after South Africa rejected an earlier ROC suggestion that its national name continue to be used following the suspension of formal ties.
He said that Taiwan's property holdings in South Africa will remain secured, since "South Africa has never questioned or challenged us on this issue."

Refusing to say whether ROC personnel stationed in South Africa will be able to enjoy diplomatic immunity, Yang said only that they will be given due treatment and conveniences to perform their duties.

Saying Beijing has never ceased its attempts to blockade Taiwan's international presence or downgrade its stature, Yang also called on Pretoria not to do anything that might undermine Taiwan's interests once it establishes official ties with Beijing.
Mainland Chinese Vice Premier and Foreign Affairs Minister Qian Qichen will arrive in Pretoria on Dec. 28 to sign a communique to formally open bilateral diplomatic ties.
According to foreign wire service reports, Beijing has even tried to press Pretoria into cutting ties with Taipei earlier than scheduled.
Yang said that his ministry has yet to name the new representative and other officials to South Africa.

DOC.HEADLINE: LARGE MAINLAND MISSION TO ATTEND APEC TECHNOMART IN TAIWAN

TEXT.P: A 220-strong mainland Chinese delegation will attend a technology fair to be held in Taiwan under the framework of the Asia-Pacific Economic Cooperation (APEC) forum, marking a significant exchange of technology between Taiwan and the mainland.

The 2nd APEC Technomart will be held on Jan. 19-24 at Taipei's World Trade Center, with over 1,000 representatives from 18 APEC economies taking part. A number of booths will be set up at the venue, exhibiting a variety of advanced high-technology items.

Vice Premier Liu Chao-shiuan said on Tuesday at a coordinating meeting in connection with the technology fair that the APEC Technomart will present the latest developments of high-tech industries in the Asia-Pacific area. In addition, the fair will be conductive to the further exchange of technology between APEC members, Liu noted.

The vice premier said that Taiwan welcomes the opportunity to host the 2nd APEC Technomart, the first of which was held in South Korea in 1995, and will make every effort to ensure its success. At a time when Taiwan faces difficulties in expanding its role in the international community, hosting exhibitions of this type is very important for Taiwan, Liu added.

APEC encompasses Taiwan, the United States, Australia, New Zealand, Canada, mainland China, Hong Kong, Indonesia, Japan, South Korea, Malaysia, the Philippines, Russia, Singapore, Brunei and Papua New Guinea.

DOC.HEADLINE: LEE MEETS HIGH-LEVEL OFFICIALS ON CROSS-STRAIT, DIPLOMATIC ISSUES

TEXT.P: ROC President Lee Teng-hui, who concurrently serves as chairman of the ruling Kuomintang (KMT), on Tuesday convened a meeting of high-level government and party officials to discuss important national affairs, presidential sources said.

The meeting was called against the backdrop of the financial crisis that has embroiled many of the countries of Southeast and Northeast Asia, the imminent termination of diplomatic relations between Taiwan and South Africa, and the third anniversary of the release of mainland Chinese President Jiang Zemin's eight-point statement on ties with Taiwan, the sources said.
Topics pondered at the two-hour meeting were related mainly to cross-strait exchanges and relations with foreign countries, but no details were available.

Participants in the meeting included Vice President Lien Chan, Premier Vincent Siew, Presidential Secretary General Huang Kun-huei, National Security Council Secretary General Ding Mou-shih, Foreign Affairs Minister Jason Hu, Mainland Affairs Council Chairman Chang King-yuh and KMT Secretary General John Chang.

DOC.HEADLINE: TAIWAN'S SHORTEST MAN LOOKS FORWARD MOST TO TRAVEL ABROAD

TEXT.P: After finding Taiwan's shortest woman, the Taiwan Museum of the Guinness World of Records on Tuesday located the shortest man on the island.
Lin Yu-chih, 26, a resident of Taipei County, is just 67.5 centimeters tall.

Lin, who suffers from brittle bones, is confined to a electrically powered wheelchair, but doctors have attributed his small stature to gene mutation caused by inbreeding between his parents, who are cousins. However, Lin's older brother and younger sister have not been affected.

Although short in stature, Lin has been very agile and strong since childhood, and Lin's mother said he attended an ordinary school until fifth-grade, when his family moved out of the school district.
His life changed dramatically seven years ago when he got his electric wheelchair, which gave him the mobility to visit friends and go out on his own.
As a clerk and a computer operator in his father's company, Lin is able to live on his own and enjoys the music of Beethoven, drawing comics and striking up friendships on the Internet.
He describes his most cherished dream as one day having the opportunity to travel abroad on his own, and hopefully to meet the girl of his dreams.

He is to meet with Taiwan's two shortest women -- Tsai Mei-ling and Tsai Shu-hui -- at a Christmas Party organized by the Guinness museum located in central Taichung City. The two Tsais, standing at 78 centimeters and 86 centimeters respectively, are sisters.

DOC.HEADLINE: SEF HEAD CALLS FOR RESUMPTION OF CROSS-STRAIT DIALOGUE

TEXT.P: Koo Chen-fu, chairman of Taiwan's Straits Exchange Foundation (SEF), on Tuesday called again on Beijing to resume unconditional dialogue with Taipei on an equal footing and said he looked forward to an exchange of visits between SEF directors and their mainland counterparts when the time is ripe.

At a joint meeting of the directors and supervisors of the SEF, which was set up by the government in 1992 to handle relations with mainland China in the absence of official ties, Taiwan's point-man in dealing with mainland China recounted with regret Beijing's unilateral termination of cross-strait contact in 1995.

Institutionalized contacts between the SEF and its mainland counterpart, the Association for Relations Across the Taiwan Strait (ARATS), were established during a meeting between Koo and ARATS Chairman Wang Daohan in 1993, but were suspended indefinitely by Beijing in 1995 in retaliation for ROC President Lee Teng-hui's landmark US trip, which Beijing claimed was an attempt to promote Taiwan independence.

Noting that Beijing's move not only breached the accord between Wang and himself but also undermined the fragile trust between the two sides of Taiwan Strait, Koo called on Beijing to reopen the regular channel of contact without preconditions.

Many bilateral issues, such as the fight against crime and the protection of intellectual property rights, require cross-strait cooperation in order to be resolved, said Koo, urging Beijing to respond to these problems in a responsible way.

Referring to an exchange of visits between SEF and ARATS directors which was proposed by the SEF in June, Koo said the plan hit snags because ARATS demanded that the SEF delegation, to be headed by SEF Vice Chairman Chiao Jen-ho, should take part in an ARATS-sponsored seminar in Xiamen in November to promote cross-strait trade, as a precondition to any exchange visits.

Taiwan rejected this conditional invitation on the grounds that Taipei's current policy is actually to cool down cross-strait trade, saying that any visit should be carried out exclusively for the exchange of views between the SEF and ARATS.

Instead, the SEF suggested postponement of the exchange visit to December or later, when Koo himself will head an SEF delegation to mainland China. This proposal has so far gone unanswered, according to Koo.
Nonetheless, he said he still hopes the exchange of visits between the SEF and ARATS can be realized someday when the time is ripe.

DOC.HEADLINE: EDITOR'S NOTE

TEXT.P: CNA will suspend CEP services on Dec. 25 (Thursday), which is the ROC's Constitution Day and also Christmas Day. We wish all our subscribers a Merry Christmas. Tks.

DOC.HEADLINE: FINANCIAL TURMOIL IN SOUTHEAST ASIA SAID TO HAVE LITTLE IMPACT ON TAIWAN EXPORTS

TEXT.P: The financial turmoil in Southeast Asia has had little impact on Taiwan exports to that region, officials from the Board of Foreign Trade (BOFT) said on Wednesday, adding that in fact Taiwan's exports to Northeast Asian countries have suffered more.

They said that from January to November this year, Taiwan's exports to five nations in Southeast Asia accounted for 12.34 of the nation's total exports, up 0.08 percent from the same period of last year, an indication that Taiwan's exports have not been affected by the financial crisis in the region.

The officials said that with the exception of textiles, Taiwan's levels of expertise and technology, especially in the fields of electronics and information products, are generally much more advanced than those of most Southeast Asian nations.

They also said that Southeast Asian nations rely heavily on Taiwan machinery equipment, pointing out that Taiwan businesses in the region have often imported equipment from Taiwan to make products to export overseas.

They noted that in contrast, exports to Northeast Asia have not been so optimistic, citing as examples the fact that Taiwan exports to Japan between January and November accounted for 9.74 percent of its total exports, down nearly 2 percentage points from the same period of last year. At the same time, exports to South Korea were down nearly 0.3 percentage points, setting a new high for trade deficits in Japan's and South Korea's favor.
The exchange rate between the Taiwan dollar and the Korean won have registered an increase of 35 percent since the beginning of the year, prompting Japan purchase from South Korea rather than Taiwan.

The additional impact of March's outbreak of foot-and-mouth disease in Taiwan and the opening of the market to compact cars from Japan are estimated to increase Taiwan's trade deficit with Japan to US$17 billion this year.

Because South Korean products tend to overlap those of Taiwan, causing a lot of South Korean products to flow into the domestic market, it is estimated that Taiwan's trade deficit with South Korea will reach US$2.6 billion this year.

DOC.HEADLINE: ROC'S FOREIGN TRADE HITS NEW RECORD, TRADE SURPLUS DECLINES

TEXT.P: Taiwan's foreign trade will hit a new high this year, but its trade surplus will fall below the 1996 record, the Ministry of Finance said on Wednesday.

According to customs tallies, two-way trade had reached US$230.54 billion as of Dec. 20, up 8.6 percent from the same period of last year, a trend which finance officials said would see this year's foreign trade surpassing the 1996 level to set a new record.

Customs statistics show that Taiwan exported US$119.12 billion worth of goods between Jan. 1 and Dec. 20, marking a 5 percent year-on-year increase, while imports advanced more than 10 percent to reach US$111.42 billion.
As a result, Taiwan posted a trade surplus of US$7.7 billion during the Jan. 1-Dec. 20 period, down nearly 40 percent from a year ago.
Trade officials attributed this plunge in trade surplus mainly to dwindling exports to Japan and South Korea.
Taiwan registered a trade surplus of US$13.57 billion in 1996, the highest since 1989, when the trade surplus topped US$14 billion.

The officials said although Taiwan has so far managed to avoid the brunt of the recent economic turmoil in Asia, its exports to Japan and South Korea have been seriously affected by the financial woes of the two countries.

Government tallies show that Taiwan shipments to Japan declined 13.6 percent in the first 11 months of this year, while imports from that country rose 4.6 percent. Against this backdrop, Taiwan's trade deficit with Japan surged 22.5 percent to US$15.57 billion for the 11-month period. The suspension of pork exports and a more-than-20-percent drop in machinery sales were major reasons behind Taiwan's shrinking shipments to Japan, BOFT officials said.

Meanwhile, Taiwan's exports to South Korea also slid 9.2 percent during the January-November period, but imports of Korean products jumped 20.8 percent during the same period. As a result, Taiwan's trade deficit with South Korea soared 74 percent to reach US$2.39 billion.
Taiwan has seen negative growth in its shipments to South Korea since April, when the South Korean currency began to depreciate substantially against the US greenback, the officials noted.

In November alone, Taiwan's exports to South Korea plunged 14.9 percent, while imports from that country climbed 16.5 percent. The two countries compete fiercely in many industries, but the depreciation of the Korean won has hindered the entry of Taiwan products into the South Korean market. As South Korea's financial crisis has continued to worsen, the officials said Taiwan-South Korea trade is not expected to return to normal in the near future.
