DOC.HEADLINE: KAOHSIUNG HARBOR BENEFITS FROM OFFSHORE TRANSSHIPMENT CENTER

TEXT.P: A total of 29,860 vessels, with a total weight of more than 500 billion tons, used Kaohsiung Harbor in southern Taiwan as a transshipment center in the first 11 months of this year, according to statistics released on Tuesday by the Kaohsiung Harbor Administration.

The figures represent an increase of 11 percent and 8 percent on terms of vessel number and cargo volume, respectively, from the same period of 1996, the administration said, attributing the growth to Taiwan's opening of cross-strait offshore transshipment services in Kaohsiung Harbor in connection with Xiamen and Fuzhou ports in mainland China's Fujian province in April.

Kaohsiung Harbor handled a record-high level of more than 5.18 million containers of transshipment cargo in the January-November period, up 126,500 containers from a year ago, 107,700 units of which were handled by the cross-strait offshore transshipment center, the administration said.

The shipping sector on both sides of the Taiwan Strait have repeatedly called for Taiwan to permit the island's Taichung and Keelung harbors, and for the mainland to allow Guanzhou, Dalian, Shanghai, Tianjin and Qingdao ports, to be opened to cross-strait shipping.

Meanwhile, it was reported that an office under the Ministry of Economic Affairs (MOEA)'s Export Processing Zone Administration (EPZA) will become operational on Friday. The office has been charged with promoting the Chengkung-Hsiaokang area in Kaohsiung, a government-run special warehousing zone which is currently in the planning stage.

In line with the government's plan to build Taiwan into an Asia-Pacific manufacturing center, the EPZA is also studying the feasibility of setting up special warehousing zones in central Taichung Harbor and in Keelung Harbor and Chiang Kai-shek International Airport in northern Taiwan, in order to introduce high-tech and high value-added industries into those areas.

According to the EPZA, construction of the Chengkung-Hsiaokang special warehousing zone will be completed in 2006. The zone is expected to create 100,000 job opportunities and will have an annual output worth more than US$100 billion.

DOC.HEADLINE: TAIWAN COMPLETES DRAFT ACT FOR SPECIAL ECONOMIC AND TRADE ZONE

TEXT.P: Taiwan has drafted a legal framework for the management of proposed special economic and trade operation zones, ruling that such areas can be opened for direct cargo transshipment, maritime transportation and other trade and economic activities between the two sides of the Taiwan Strait.
A task force formed by the Executive Yuan for the establishment of this type of zone completed the draft on Tuesday.

The task force, led by P.K. Chiang, chairman of the Council for Economic Planning and Development (CEPD), is made up of high-ranking officials from the Ministry of Economic Affairs, the Ministry of Transportation and Communications, and the Mainland Affairs Council, as well as several ministers without portfolio.

Chiang said the draft sets out several concrete directions for the formation of special zones for the free flow of capital, cargo and personnel, which includes devising special laws to remove investment barriers and to allow the gradual opening of economic and trade activities between Taiwan and mainland China based on the development of cross-strait relations and national security.

The draft also includes provisions for setting up an administrative unit capable of providing efficient executive management and services, and building an investment environment for the free flow of cargo, along with the construction of special trade areas complete with the most up-to-date infrastructure.

The CEPD chief said the new draft represents the government's determination to promote trade liberalization, adding that the planned special economic and trade zones will also provide the so-called "single window" services, which means that the proposed administrative unit will take charge of every operation in each zone.

The government will also encourage investors to take part in the zone's public construction works, the minister noted, adding that although the free flow of cargo will be permitted and encouraged, cargo entering other Taiwan regions will still have to be considered as foreign imports.

DOC.HEADLINE: CROSS-STRAIT TALKS TO RESUME NEXT SPRING: ASSESSMENT

TEXT.P: Taiwan has assessed that both sides of the Taiwan Strait could resume talks next spring, but cannot pinpoint the exact time, the top official in chart of the nation's mainland policy said on Wednesday.
Chang King-yuh, chairman of the Mainland Affairs Council (MAC), made the remarks after returning home from a trip to Spain, Germany, France and Belgium.

During his visit to the four European countries from Dec. 11-22, he had extensive discussions and exchanges of views on the development of cross-strait relations with local scholars, think-tanks, overseas Chinese and media.

He said that in view of the return of Hong Kong to mainland Chinese rule in July, the upcoming return visit of US President Bill Clinton to mainland China next spring following the October US visit of mainland Chinese President Jiang Zemin, and the reshuffle of Beijing's State Council during the 9th National People's Congress next March, scholars have assessed that cross-strait talks could be resumed next spring.

Stressing that Taiwan has long stopped challenging mainland China and has not attempted to engage in zero-sum competition with the mainland internationally, Chang expressed the hope that mainland China will resume cross-strait talks without preconditions as soon as possible.

DOC.HEADLINE: SEF CHAIRMAN MIGHT INVITE MAINLAND COUNTERPART TO TAIWAN

TEXT.P: Koo Chen-fu, chairman of Taiwan's Straits Exchange Foundation (SEF), remarked on Tuesday that if Beijing has not responded by early 1998 regarding the resumption of cross-strait negotiations, he does not rule out the possibility of inviting Wang Daohan, his mainland counterpart, to Taiwan.

The SEF is the quasi-official body set up to handle contact with mainland China in the absence of official ties; its counterpart is the Beijing-based Association for Relations Across the Taiwan Strait (ARATS) with Wang Daohan as its chairman and Tang Shubei as its deputy director.

The SEF is ready to resume talks at any time, Koo stressed at the annual SEF joint meeting of directors and supervisors. He called for Beijing to resume unconditional dialogue with Taipei on an equal footing and said he looks forward to an exchange of visits between the directors of the SEF and ARATS when the time is ripe.

In order to resolve the differences and misunderstandings between the two sides, Koo noted, Beijing and Taipei should resume dialogue on matters of protocol, including the protection of Taiwan businessmen's interests and rights, the fight against crime and the protection of intellectual property rights.

Institutionalized contacts between the SEF and ARATS were established during a meeting between Koo and Wang in Singapore in 1993, but were suspended unilaterally by Beijing on June 16, 1995 in retaliation for ROC President Lee Teng-hui's US trip.

DOC.HEADLINE: SHARE PRICES UP ON TAIEX

TEXT.P: Share prices closed 0.5 percent higher on the local stock market on Wednesday following rebound buying for low-price electrical engineering stocks, according to dealers.
The Taiwan Stock Exchange (TAIEX) weighted price index rose 36.74 points to finish at 8,075.05.
The bourse opened at the day's low of 7,925.1, and had a high of 8,080.81
Losers outnumbered gainers 218 to 193, with 61 shares unchanged.
A total of 1.7 billion shares changed hands on a market turnover of NT$89.81 billion (US$2.8 billion).
Seven of the eight major stocks categories suffered losses, with paper and pulp issues posting the largest fall of 1 percent.

Financial stocks followed, with a 0.9 percent drop; textile shares fell 0.6 percent; cement issues decreased 0.5 percent; plastic and chemical shares lost 0.2 percent; and foodstuff issues declined 0.1 percent.
However, electrical engineering stocks gained 2.7 percent.

The 10 companies with the largest turnovers were: Mosel Vitelic; Picvue Electronics; ACER; Taiwan Styrene Monomer; Union Petrochemical; Holtek Microelectronics; Taiwan Semiconductor Manufacturing; Compal Electronic; Mitac International; and Taita Chemical.

DOC.HEADLINE: TZU CHI FOUNDATION DONATES CLOTHES TO NORTH KOREA

TEXT.P: The Buddhist Compassionate Relief Tzu Chi Foundation will begin delivery on Friday of 4,400 packages of clothes to North Korea to help the starving victims of crop failures and natural disasters there, the Hualien-based religious and charitable organization said on Wednesday.
The North Korean International Trade Promotion Board here received the clothes, donated by Taiwan people from all walks of life, on behalf of the North Korean people, the Tzu Chi foundation said.

The winter clothes donation campaign was initiated by a group of officials of the President Group who visited North Korea in October, saw the condition in which people there were living, and sought the help of the Tzu Chi Foundation to provide assistance to them.
The Tzu Chi foundation said the clothes have been collected in the cities of Taipei, Taoyuan and Taichung by volunteers since the beginning of the month.

DOC.HEADLINE: DEFENSE SPENDING TO INCREASE DUE TO CURRENCY DEPRECIATION

TEXT.P: Defense spending will increase by about NT$6 billion (US$184.62 million) during the current fiscal year because of a significant drop in the New Taiwan dollar's value, the Ministry of National Defense (MND) said on Wednesday.

Testifying before the Legislative Yuan's National Defense Committee, Vice Defense Minister Wang Wen-hsien said the ministry will incur an estimated shortfall of NT$5.95 billion in foreign exchange for weaponry purchases in fiscal 1998, which ends on June 30, 1998, because of the NT dollar's 15 percent depreciation against the US dollar so far this year.

Wang said the ministry will use its surplus from other programs to cover the shortfall, but added that if this still cannot balance the books, the ministry will seek the assistance of the Executive Yuan.
He said the country's overall military spending for next fiscal year will increase by some NT$11 billion to reach NT$285.86 billion (US$8.8 billion).

The increased budget is to cover pay raises for military personnel, repair and maintenance of the nation's new generation of warplanes and warships, compensation for civilians accidentally killed or injured as a result of military maneuvers over past years, and other related items, Wang said.

The MND-proposed preliminary budget bill also sets aside NT$84.8 billion, or 29.68 percent of total military budget for the coming fiscal year, for classified defense projects. The amount marks a 2 percent decline from the current fiscal year.
Speaking on the same occasion, Defense Minister Chiang Chung-ling voiced the Defense Ministry's strong opposition to plans to open Tungsha Island in the South China Sea to tourism.

"Anybody who has visited Tungsha Island understands that the islet doesn't have any tourism value," Chiang claimed, adding that the tiny islet in the strategic Pratas archipelago has no fresh water and that living conditions there are primitive.
The Republic of China currently stations troops on the island, and Chiang claimed that the opening of the island to sightseeing will affect national defense and security.

For similar reasons, Chiang said the Defense Ministry also objects to opening Kueishan Island off Taiwan's northeastern coast for sightseeing as has been advocated by some tourism promoters and county government officials.

DOC.HEADLINE: US DOLLAR UP

TEXT.P: The US dollar rose NT$0.117 against the New Taiwan dollar on the Taipei foreign exchange market on Wednesday, closing at NT$32.637.
The greenback opened at the day's low of 32.55, and experienced a high of 32.685.
Interbank US dollar trading reached US$207.5 million.

DOC.HEADLINE: CANADIAN DOLLAR DRIFT CONTINUES UNABATED

TEXT.P: The Canadian dollar closed on Tuesday at 69.57 US cents, down 0.14 US cents from Monday's close.
It opened 0.06 US cents lower, at 69.65 US cents, and continued to drift ever-closer to the historic low of 69.17 cents set in February 1986.
But despite falling through the psychologically significant 70-cent barrier and threatening to challenge the low, commodity traders and economists weren't too jittery.

The concern for Canadians is that further weakness in their dollar could force the Bank of Canada to hike interest rates, leading the big banks to raise the cost of borrowing for mortgages and consumer, corporate and car loans.
Most analysts said it's unlikely the central bank -- which has raised rates a total of 1.25 percentage points since June -- will make another such move before the new year.
The dollar isn't likely to level off until the interest rate gap between Canada and the US is closed off, a banker said.
In spite of recent hikes, the Canadian prime rate, now standing at 6 percent, is still 2.5 percent lower than its US counterpart.

DOC.HEADLINE: CANADA ISSUES SILVER COIN FOR CHINESE YEAR OF TIGER

TEXT.P: The Royal Canadian Mint said on Tuesday that it has issued a sterling silver coin to mark the Chinese Year of the Tiger.
The new coin will go on sale in early January in Toronto and Vancouver, just in time for people shopping for gifts for the Chinese New Year, which falls on Jan. 28, 1998.
The new fifteen-dollar sterling silver coin with a gold cameo is the first coin in a new twelve-year series based on the symbols of the Chinese lunar calendar.
"Our Chinese customers have been asking for coins with Chinese themes, so we worked closely with the Chinese community to develop this coin," said Royal Canadian Mint President Danielle Wetherup.
The center of the Year of the Tiger coin features an octagonal 24-carat gold-covered cameo depicting a tiger. It weighs 34 grams.

The Canadian Mint will produce 68,888 of the Year of the Tiger coins. They cost C$68.88 (US$51.38) each and can be purchased through the Royal Canadian Mint's global network of dealers and distributors.

DOC.HEADLINE: US ASSISTS DROUGHT VICTIMS IN IRIAN JAYA

TEXT.P: The United States government has contributed three grants totaling US$500,000 to assist the people of Irian Jaya who are suffering from the effects of a drought.

A press release from the US Embassy, made available to Antara here on Tuesday, said that the first grant provides approximately US$250,000 to World Vision to distribute seeds to the people of Jayawijaya District.

The statement said that the delay in the onset of this year's rainy season meant that many people were unable to plant enough sweet potatoes, their dietary staple, to ensure a steady food supply for 1998.
It said World Vision and Indonesian experts will provide rapidly maturing seeds to help alleviate the suffering.

This program will provide more than 16l,000 families with seeds for foods already familiar to the area: corn, beans, carrots and cabbage, foods that will be ready to harvest before the next crop of sweet potatoes matures.

USAID is also donating US$100,000 to Mission Aviation Fellowship (MAF). MAF has been flying food and other relief supplies to the highland areas of Irian Jaya. The grant will allow MAF to deliver an additional 50,000 kg of food and supplies to affected villages.
USAID's Office of Disaster Assistance has pledged US$150,000 to the International Committee of the Red Cross for the purchase of medical and relief supplies for Irian Jaya.

DOC.HEADLINE: MAINLAND CHINA-MADE CANDLES RULED UNSAFE

TEXT.P: The Canadian health authorities on Tuesday warned Canadians not to use or buy silver-colored candles imported from mainland China.

Health Canada issued the warning after identifying the product as a fire hazard. The department said the candles have the potential to reignite after they have been extinguished. Lit pieces of the burning wick can fall off and set the side of the candle on fire or ignite nearby materials.
One incident has already been reported of a Christmas decoration catching fire. There were no injuries.

DOC.HEADLINE: MONTREAL CHINESE URGE LANGUAGE POLICE TO LEAVE THEM ALONE

TEXT.P: Quebec's language inspectors are chipping away at the Chinese face of Chinatown in Montreal, and Chinese-Canadians want the "language police" to leave them alone.
The Montreal Gazette reported on Tuesday that the Commission de Protection de la Langue Francaise has held meetings with Chinatown merchants to get them to comply with sign laws.
Restaurateurs and store-owners were told this fall they must make the French characters on their outside signs twice the size of the Chinese ones.
The crackdown angered some merchants and community leaders, according to the Gazette. They feel Chinatown will lose its charm and any changes will bring bad luck.
Merchants say their downtown area should be given tourist status so they can keep their predominantly Chinese signs.

"In the Chinese culture, people don't like to change signs because it is bad luck," said one restaurateur who didn't want his name used. "To pull down a sign, it's like you went bankrupt. That aspect is very important because most Chinese are very superstitious."
The language law is the same for Chinese signs as it is for English ones. French must predominate.
That usually means French must be double the size of other languages. There are no special exemptions in the French Language Charter for ethnic businesses.

DOC.HEADLINE: CANADIAN DAILY SEES RISING TENSIONS AS DPP GAINS CLOUT IN TAIWAN

TEXT.P: A major Canadian newspaper sees "an escalation in regional tensions" across the Taiwan Strait in the coming years as politicians of Taiwan's ruling Kuomintang (KMT) and opposition Democratic Progressive Party (DPP) battle over voter support.

The Globe and Mail said on Tuesday that anyone who makes a living at predicting the world's potential hot-spots puts Taiwan high on the list, according to an editorial entitled "Taiwan becomes democratic China."

Since the beginning of December, Taiwan has been adjusting to a new political reality, in which there are more elected municipal leaders from the DPP, which favors independence, than from the veteran Nationalists, or KMT, it pointed out.
The shift in voter preferences is made all the more significant by the lead-up to a parliamentary election in 1998, the article said.

The local results may not signal an irreversible trend toward endorsement of Taiwan independence, but they reveal far more political boldness than the Taiwan electorate has ever manifested. Moreover, where there are wayward glances in Taiwan, there's mainland-Chinese anger and muscle-flexing. And where there's Chinese muscle-flexing, there's agitation in the United States' pro-Taiwan resolve, according to the paper.

Since 1949, both Taiwan and mainland China have called for a reunified China, the KMT on their model of evolving democratic capitalism, the communists on Beijing's current one-party, state-capitalism terms, it said.

As both have spoken of peaceful reunification, they have armed themselves heavily and prepared for war, it pointed out. The US has weighed in periodically, by facilitating weapons sales and showing force on Taiwan's behalf, it noted.

Against this tense and competitive backdrop, Taiwan has prospered mightily, and mainland China, too, has been reforming and rising economically in recent years. But the two political visions of how to govern Chinese people -- democratically or by authoritarianism -- couldn't be more different.

Of late, it's perhaps this disparity that has led Beijing to contemplate Taiwan-mainland cohabitation. Indeed, Beijing officials have recently proposed Taiwan quasi-autonomy, under which the island of 21 million would have its own army, economic policies and political appointments to Beijing. At the end of the day, though, the unity of China from Tibet to Taiwan, is an essential pillar of the Chinese world view, it said.

The Mail said the KMT has stayed engaged in decades-old talk of eventual reunification, possibly because its members still harbor hope of retaking the mantle of power in Beijing. The problem is that back at home, the Taiwan-firsters in the opposition DPP are gaining clout, and they're far more interested in their island than in one China, it said.

The vast majority of Taiwan's residents are islanders, not mainland Chinese emigres like the ones who dominate the KMT government, said the Mail. Reflecting demographics, the DPP party chairman says Taiwan will "never" reunite with mainland China, and the party's top thinkers advocate less dependency on the possibly unreliable Yankees and more reliance on national defense and a nuclear bomb, it pointed out.

Ironically, an inward-looking Taiwan led by the nativist DPP might well be less of a threat to mainland China than would be a strong KMT with mainland ambitions -- especially if the DPP soft-pedals its agenda, as it is learning to do, the editorial said.

But that's not how the KMT or Beijing are thinking, the article stated. It added that the DPP has the ruling party worrying about losing power. It's no surprise that the local election campaigns saw lots of pro-independence commentary from the KMT, and even some sovereigntist remarks by Taiwan-born President Lee Teng-hui, it commented.
The remarks, of course, prompted Beijing to repeat its old threat of using force against Taiwan, it noted.
Add to the KMT talk the rise of the DPP, and the result is agitation, not only for Beijing but also for the ambivalent United States, it said.

The Mail said that despite last year's possibly aberrant show of force in the Taiwan Strait by the US Navy, the State Department doesn't like it when Taiwan gets strident on independence. Senior US officials quietly lecture them to play the agenda down, it added.

DOC.HEADLINE: ROC FORMS SPECIAL PANEL TO COPE WITH ASIAN FINANCIAL TURMOIL

TEXT.P: The Republic of China government has set up an inter-ministerial contingency task force to cope with possible fallout from the recent Asian financial turmoil, Minister of Finance Paul Chiu said on Wednesday.

Fielding questions at a Legislative Yuan committee meeting, Chiu said the special panel will hammer out concrete measures to address the possible adverse impact on Taiwan of the financial woes afflicting several Southeast Asian countries and South Korea.

The minister, however, would not elaborate on the contingency group's members or working procedures. He said only that all relevant financial and economic units can meet whenever necessary to discuss problems facing the country.

Chiu said the panel is closely monitoring the financial market trends in mainland China and Hong Kong. He declined to predict whether the mainland currency and the Hong Kong dollar would depreciate in the near future. He instead quoted mainland President Jiang Zemin as saying recently that the yuan would not be devalued for the time being.

Chiu went on to say that local industries have not yet been seriously affected by the recent nose-dive in the South Korean currency's value. He urged local entrepreneurs to learn a lesson from their South Korean counterparts' current woes and take precautionary steps.

The minister further said the Finance Ministry will adopt anti-dumping measures to curb unfair trade practices if evidence surfaces that South Korea has sold goods to Taiwan at prices below fair market value.

Chiu said Taiwan's electronics and information-technology industries are not expected to be weakened by the tumble of the Korean won because they are highly competitive. Nevertheless, he admitted that local textile, steel and petrochemcial industries are likely to be affected.

Chiu also said optimistically that Taiwan is unlikely to incur a Korean-style financial crisis because of the combination of brisk sales of high-tech products, large foreign exchange reserves, low debts, a healthy trade surplus and relatively low bad-debt ratios at local banks.

DOC.HEADLINE: SINGAPORE'S CHEMICAL INDUSTRY WILL RECORD 12 PERCENT GROWTH IN 1997

TEXT.P: Singapore's chemical industry will grow by about 12 percent to an output of S$27 billion this year, due mainly to strong growth in petrochemicals and specialty chemicals, according to the Singapore Economic Development Board (EDB).
Growth is also expected to remain stronger over the next few years, it predicted.

The chemical industry -- the second largest manufacturing sector in Singapore after electronics -- comprises more than 300 foreign and local companies engaged in petroleum; petrochemicals; specialty chemicals; and pharmaceuticals, biotechnology and healthcare products. Of these, the first three account for about 80 percent of the chemical industry's output.

The EDB said on Tuesday that following a 5.4 percent contraction last year, petrochemicals output this year is expected to grow by 6.4 percent, despite softer prices of its products worldwide during the past year.

The strong growth was due mainly to the successful start-up of the S$3.4 billion second petrochemical complex on Jurong Island which includes the Petrochemical Corporation of Singapore's second cracker and related downstream projects.
The EDB said investments in these projects have enhanced the integration of the local petrochemical industry and Singapore's development as the leading petrochemical hub in the region.

Specialty chemicals are also estimated to have grown at a double-digit rate. The 12 percent projected growth this year will be backed by strong growth in paints and coatings, industrial gases and chemicals, flavors and fragrances, and water treatment chemicals.
Meanwhile, single-digit growth rates are expected for both the petroleum and pharmaceuticals, biotechnology and healthcare products industries -- at 5.5 percent and 3.3 percent, respectively.

The EDB said the investment outlook for the industry was "encouraging," with growth expected from new projects in the petrochemical, specialty chemical and pharmaceutical industries due to come on stream in the next two years.
The chemical industry contributed 18 percent to the manufacturing sector's output last year, and the figure could rise to about 35 percent by 2003, the EDB said.

DOC.HEADLINE: CASINO BOSS CONSULTS FENG SHUI EXPERTS TO ATTRACT ASIAN HIGH-ROLLERS

TEXT.P: Crown Casino in Melbourne, the biggest casino in the Southern Hemisphere and one of the largest in the world, has consulted feng shui experts in a bid to attract high-rollers from Hong Kong, Indonesia, Singapore, Thailand, mainland China and Taiwan.
Crown's chairman Lloyd Williams believed feng shui experts could provide good advice on the design and layout of his gambling empire and its hotel tower while it was under construction.
Many of the casino's cars also bear the number eight -- on their number plates.
The purpose is to attract Asian high-rollers to the casino, analysts said.
Crown flies in high-rolling gamblers from Asia in its own Lear jet, promoting the exclusive use of its own private golf course in Melbourne's bayside suburbs as an added incentive.

In late 1995 -- about 18 months before the casino opened at its new A$1.6 billion permanent site near the Yarra River, Williams revealed that Asian high-rollers contributed about A$50 million towards the company's first-year earnings.
Earlier this year, while still at its temporary home, the casino was flying in about 30 Asian gambling kings each week with an estimated A$7.5 billion in bets changing hands in 18 months.
In fiscal 1995-96, high rollers contributed A$160 million of the casino's total gaming revenue of A$490 million.
Williams predicted that visiting high-rollers would account for about A$360 million in gaming revenue at the casino, but the figure was estimated before the Asian economic crisis, the analysts said.
They believe the figure could be lower than the estimated one.
In the past six weeks, Crown has lost about A$55 million to Asian high-rollers, resulting in total business losses of A$40 million in the past five months.

DOC.HEADLINE: AUSTRALIAN WINE EXPORTS HIT RECORD HIGH IN 1996-97

TEXT.P: Australia's wine exports in fiscal 1996-97 hit a record high of more than A$603 million, up 28 percent from the previous year, according to the Australian Bureau of Statistics (ABS).
The ABS figures show that one quarter of Australia's wine exports went mainly to the United Kingdom, with the United States and New Zealand coming second and third.
Taiwan, mainland China and other Asian countries are becoming new frontiers for Australian wine, and winemakers believe there is much room for expansion in sales to these countries.
Domestic wine sales were also very brisk. In 1996-97, sales totaled 333.6 million liters, up 1 percent from the record sales of 1994-95.

Australian red wine has become a popular item for export. Of the 333.6 million liters sold in the domestic market, whites accounted for about 185 million liters, reds accounted for 78 million liters and rose just 4.7 million liters.
Australian wine is becoming more and more popular in the world market, and winemakers believe their exports could reach A$1 billion in the next two years.

DOC.HEADLINE: DEMAND IN ASIA FOR AUSTRALIAN PRAWNS SEEN FALLING

TEXT.P: Taiwan, Hong Kong and Japan are expected to reduce imports of Australian prawns because of the recent Asian economic meltdown, according to the Australian Bureau of Agriculture and Resource Economics (ABARE).
An ABARE spokesman said he believes the Asian crisis will force major importers of Australian prawns to reduce their purchases.
Nick Ruello, a Sydney-based independent seafood marketing consultant, has also predicted "a weakening in demand for Australian prawns as a result of the Asian economic crisis."
"This is good news for Australian consumers, as it should result in cheaper prawns at home," he said.
Australian seafood exporters believe export prices of Australian prawns will weaken as a result of the Asian crisis.
Prawn prices in recent years have continued to rise dramatically in the domestic market because of rising demand for the seafood from Taiwan, Hong Kong and Japan, they said.
But the economic crisis is expected to cause a fall or at least slow the rise in domestic prices, they added.

DOC.HEADLINE: TAIWAN FOREX RESERVES RANK FOURTH IN WORLD

TEXT.P: Taiwan's foreign exchange reserves increased US$215 million to US$83.135 billion in November from October, marking the first rise since June, according to the Central Bank of China.
The impact of the Southeast Asian financial crises forced the ROC government to spend some of its foreign exchange reserves to preserve the New Taiwan dollar's value.
As a result, the total amount of reserves has plunged from June's registered US$90.025 billion, the bank said.
According to unofficial statistics, the new figure ranked fourth in the world, following Japan's US$228.15 billion, mainland China's US$120.9 billion, and Hong Kong's US$96.5 billion.
Meanwhile, although the recent financial storm is still expanding and has devastated the economies of South Korea and several Southeast Asian countries, Taiwan's foreign trade still grew.

The Board of Foreign Trade (BOFT) revealed that the amount of Taiwan exports totaled US$111.57 billion during the period from January to November, up 5.6 percent from the year-earlier level. Imports hit US$103.84 billion, representing a 11.5 percent rise.

The BOFT forecast that in the coming year, Taiwan will still enjoy growing development in foreign trade due to stable foreign orders and Taiwan's unstoppable efforts to promote large public construction projects and remove investment barriers to stimulate domestic demand.

DOC.HEADLINE: WALL STREET WAR GAMES

TEXT.P: The next Pearl Harbor-style sneak attack may well be aimed at the United States' economic and information infrastructure rather than a fleet of ships, The Journal of Commerce reported on Tuesday, citing security experts.

Because of that threat, the US Navy has begun conducting war-game exercises on Wall Street to prepare for possible "cyber sabotage," or physical attacks on such major financial venues as the World Trade Center or the New York Stock Exchange, the journal said.

"The worlds of international politics, national security and financial markets are tightly linked," Rear Adm. James Stark, president of the US National War College in Newport, R.I., was quoted as saying.
War games have been used by the military for more than 100 years, but this is the first time the Naval War College has included an economic security component.

Six months ago, Stark came to Cantor Fitzgerald, a Wall Street brokerage firm that has become one of the world's leading electronic marketplaces, to discuss possible threats to the integrity of the global economy.
Last week, the War College and Cantor Fitzgerald led a meeting of government and private-sector officials to evaluate results of an economic-security planning exercise.
The exercise was structured around two related scenarios in February and March of 2000 in the midst of the US presidential primary season.
The first scenario involved an escalating crisis in which US access to Persian Gulf oil supplies were threatened.
In the second, information warfare attacks were launched against critical infrastructures related to the US business and financial community.

Both scenarios dealt with the potential vulnerability of the US to asymmetric warfare, what one participant called the "David effect," when "a little guy with the right technology can confront the big giant in a devastating way."
The exercise showed that the Dow Jones Industrial Average would drop about 25 percent in reaction to the conflict and would not fully rebound to the pre-crash level.
That scenario would place the sell-off as one of the worst in history, approximating that of 1929 and greater than the crash in 1987.

DOC.HEADLINE: DOH TO SEND OFFICIALS TO HK TO STUDY 'BIRD FLU'

TEXT.P: The Department of Health (DOH) will send officials to Hong Kong next week to look into the spread of the deadly H5N1A influenza strain, also dubbed "bird flu," which is believed to have claimed four lives there and has sparked a ban on all chicken imports from mainland China.
DOH officials said although there is still no definite sign of human-to-human transmission of the virus, there are already 10 confirmed cases of "bird flu" in Hong Kong.
"We must learn more about how the virus is transmitted and how Hong Kong authorities are coping with the situation," said an official with the National Quarantine Service under the DOH.

Preventive medicine experts said the H5N1A is carried by migrant birds and can spread directly to birds, poultry or swine, and that there is still no evidence that the virus can directly spread to humans. It takes six months or more time to determine the possibility of human-to-human spread of the virus, they noted.
DOH officials further said as migrant birds seen in Taiwan travel in a different direction from those seen in Hong Kong, local people do not need to worry too much about the new influenza strain.
Still, they advised local people not to make unnecessary visits to Hong Kong in short term to avoid contracting the virus.
Meanwhile, a high-powered mission of Hong Kong travel executives arrived in Taipei on Wednesday to attract Taiwan tourists.

Hong Kong travel service executives said Hong Kong has banned chicken imports from mainland China and has sterilized all chicken ranches in the territory. No chicken in Hong Kong has infected the virus so far, they asserted.
According to Hong Kong tallies, tourist arrivals from Taiwan and Southeast Asian countries have declined substantially since July 1.

Local tour agents said the bird flu is not a main reason behind the delcine in the number of Taiwan tour groups to Hong Kong. The key reason is the appreciation of the Hong Kong dollar against the New Taiwan dollar.

The Hong Kong dollar is pegged to the greenback against which the NT dollar has depreciated about 15 percent in recent months. As a result, the NT dollar has also depreciated against the Hong Kong currency.

DOC.HEADLINE: ASEAN ANTI-HAZE ACTION PLAN SET IN MOTION

TEXT.P: ASEAN environment ministers and officials vowed Tuesday to put in place by next June an action plan to prevent, monitor and fight forest fires, in the hope of sparing the region another episode of the haze which has choked large areas of Southeast Asia this year.
The action plan was endorsed by the ASEAN environment ministers at the end of a two-day meeting in Singapore.
Singapore, Malaysia and Indonesia will take the lead in implementing the strategies.
A technical assistance package -- expected to be worth over US$1.2 million -- from the Asian Development Bank will supplement funds from each individual ASEAN member to finance the plan.

Speaking at the end of the ministerial meeting, Singapore's Environment Minister Yeo Cheow Tong said: "We must send a clear signal to the outside world that we are serious about preventing a recurrence of the haze problem.
"Our clear endorsement of a concrete regional haze action plan, and prompt implementation of the measures spelled out in the plan, will be a clear demonstration of our firm commitment to this end."
The action plan calls for specific measures to:
-- Prevent land and forest fires through better land management policies and enforcement, and intensified public education programs. Malaysia will spearhead activities in this area.
-- Establish operational mechanisms to monitor land and foreign fires. This will be coordinated by Singapore.
-- Strengthen regional land and forest fire-fighting capabilities. Indonesia is in charge of this.

Unlike previous regional cooperation efforts to battle the haze, this action plan spells out concrete steps which have to be taken by specific deadlines, which stretch from February to June next year.
For example, by March, computer links should be set up between meteorological stations in ASEAN member-countries to share satellite images, wind charts, visibility and air quality data.
By then, an inventory of regional fire-fighting capabilities should be drawn up and, if need be, outside help should be formally enlisted, for fire-fighting equipment, aircraft and experts.

The tight deadlines are the biggest challenge faced in implementing the plan, said Yeo. "We expect the three lead countries to do their utmost to ensure that the tight time-frames specified in the plan are being complied with... We are allowing only a few months for all this work to be done."
For Indonesia, State Minister for the Environment, Sarwono Kusumasstmadja, said the challenge would be in bringing about a change in perception and behavior.
He said the Indonesian government will mount an intensive public awareness campaign, with the private sector as a main target, as their land-clearing practices triggered the disaster this year.

Asked if sanctions would be imposed on ASEAN members if the plan's deadlines are not met, Yeo said: "The ASEAN tradition is one where we assist each other as quietly as possible, and not try to get brownie points for helping each other. It is one of quiet assistance and discussion to enable the problem to be solved effectively.
"We do not believe that sanctions are the answer to the problem. We believe that cooperation and mutual assistance are the answer."

DOC.HEADLINE: FEW JAPANESE BELIEVE ECONOMY WILL RECOVER

TEXT.P: Three-fourths of Japanese people polled do not believe the country's economy will recover next year, despite announcements earlier this month of a two trillion-yen tax cut and a ten trillion-yen bond issue to stabilize the financial system, according to a Kyodo News Service survey released here Wednesday.

The nationwide survey, conducted by telephone over the weekend, covers 1,000 eligible voters -- 485 men and 515 women. Only eight percent of those polled expect an economic recovery in 1998, while as many as 75 percent expressed a negative opinion.
Results of the poll indicate that an overwhelming majority claim plans for the tax cut and bond issue are not sufficient to boost the economy.
Prime Minister Ryutaro Hashimoto announced the two-trillion tax reduction plan on Dec. 17 in a bid to boost consumer sentiment and revive the stalled economy.

On the previous day, the ruling Liberal Democratic Party adopted a plan to give ten trillion-yen worth of government bonds to the Deposit Insurance Corp., paying the way for the use of public funds to stabilize the financial system.
Regarding the public funds, 57 percent of the survey respondents oppose their use to stabilize the financial system, while only 19 percent support such a move.
The announcements followed the recent failures of such major financial institutions as Hokkaido Takushoku Bank and the Yamaichi Securities Co.

DOC.HEADLINE: 1997 TOP TEN MAINLAND-RELATED NEWS ITEMS

TEXT.P: Mainland Chinese paramount leader Deng Xiaoping's death in February at the age of 93 was listed as the top mainland-related news story for 1997 by Taiwan mass media.
The top 10 mainland-related news items for this year, as chosen by chief editors and senior writers of Taiwan-based media organizations, including the CNA, are as follows:
1. Deng Xiaoping died in Beijing from pneumonia caused by Parkinson's disease.
2. Work on the mammoth Three Gorges Dam project began after workers diverted the main flow of the Yangtze River.
3. The Chinese Communist Party held its 15th National Congress in September.
4. Hong Kong was handed over to Beijing's sovereignty after 156 years of British colonial rule.

5. The mainland-owned, Panama-registered cargo ship Lian Feng arrived in Kaohsiung on March 2 from Xiamen, mainland China, via Hong Kong. It was the first mainland ship to call at a Taiwan harbor in five decades.
6. Mainland Chinese President Jiang Zemin visited the United States, vowing to strike a "constructive strategic alliance" with Washington.
7. Renowned mainland dissident Wei Jingsheng was exiled to the United States after being released by Beijing authorities on medical parole.

8. During a visit to mainland China with US Vice President Al Gore, House of Representatives Speaker Newt Gingrich warned that the United States would defend Taiwan in the event of a military attack from Beijing.
9. A mainland-registered cargo ship, "Sheng Da," called at Kaohsiung Harbor on April 19 after sailing from Xiamen, south China. The voyage marked the opening of cross-strait transshipment services.
10. Liu Shan-chung, a hijacker who commandeered a Taiwan domestic airliner to Xiamen on the mainland earlier in the year, was extradited to Taiwan on May 14 to stand trial.

DOC.HEADLINE: MAC HEAD QUESTIONS 'ONE NATION, TWO SYSTEMS' IN HK

TEXT.P: Taiwan's top mainland affairs official on Wednesday questioned the long-term feasibility of the "one nation, two systems" formula in Hong Kong.
Chang King-yuh, chairman of the Mainland Affairs Council said that six months after its reversion to Beijing's rule, Hong Kong has generally maintained its own social and economic systems.
However, he said it is questionable whether Hong Kong will be able to maintain its status quo in the longer term, adding that it may take three to five years to have an answer.

Chang noted that many Hong Kong columnists have stopped writing articles in Hong Kong papers, and that several of them have even emigrated abroad. He said this is an indication that even veteran observers of Hong Kong affairs have no confidence in Beijing's administrative formula.

The scheduled legislative polls in Hong Kong next year will be another indicator of the effectiveness of that system, Chang said, adding that the confidence of the general populace will plummet if Beijing seeks to intervene in the election process.

He also warned that Beijing's continued blockade of Taipei's international presence will only create unnecessary barriers to the resumption of cross-strait negotiations, which were suspended by Beijing following ROC President Lee Teng-hui's visit to the United States in June 1995.

Chang was commenting on remarks made recently by MAC officials at the Legislative Yuan that negotiations between Taiwan's Straits Exchange Foundation (SEF) and the mainland's Association for Relations Across the Taiwan Strait (ARATS), may be reopened in May or June.

The officials made the comments on the presumption that Beijing will be able to devote more attention to Taiwan affairs at that time, after concluding a series of political events, including a visit by US President Bill Clinton, the convening of a new National People's Congress and an expected reshuffle of the State Council, or Cabinet.

DOC.HEADLINE: SEMICONDUCTOR SECTOR SHOWS RAPID GROWTH

TEXT.P: Taiwan's semiconductor sector has grown rapidly in the past six years, and now accounts for half of the island's electronics products, the Board of Foreign Trade (BOFT) said on Wednesday.

BOFT officials said that what is even more noteworthy is that the semiconductor exports as a percentage of the nation's total exports has increased to 8.1 percent in the first 10 months of this year, up from 3 percent in 1992.

The officials said that Taiwan's semiconductor manufacturing sector has been affected by the financial crisis sweeping Southeast and Northeast Asia, but pointed out that at least two Taiwan semiconductor giants believe the industry can weather the storm.

Both Taiwan Semiconductor Manufacturing and United Micro Electronics said that South Korea is no longer capable of investment, and that Taiwan's semiconductor sector should seize this chance for business opportunities.

Although the semiconductor sector has developed rapidly, the officials said that the balanced development of industry could pose a potential problem, adding that the government should also develop new industries such as sophisticated machinery, biochemical and telecommunications, as well as aviation industries, to create balanced industrial development.
They noted that since November, the five largest export products were machinery and engineering equipment, textiles, basic metal products, rubber and plastic products, and transportation equipment.

DOC.HEADLINE: SCIENCE BUDGET TO GROW BY 10 PERCENT

TEXT.P: The National Science Council (NSC) has formally adopted a NT$52.31 billion (US$1.63 billion) budget for the nation's science development during the next fiscal year.

The budget, including NT$45.17 billion (US$1.41 billion) for non-military scientific expenditures and NT$7.14 billion (US$216 million) for defense-related research, was approved at a meeting of the NSC on Wednesday. The non-military outlay represents a growth of 10 percent, or NT$4.16 billion (US$130 million), from the level of a year ago.
All of the military funding, with the exception of some NT$476.52 million for projects deemed nonsensitive, was listed as classified.

Vice Premier Liu Chao-shiuan, who concurrently serves as the NSC chairman, said that the budget was worked out after full consultation with the Executive Yuan. He expects it to pass through screening by the Cabinet without any difficulties.

This year is the first time the NSC has been empowered to review scientific research projects proposed by the Ministry of National Defense (MND). It is also the first time that the allocations for MND-sponsored research have been incorporated into the national science budget.

A total of 14 ministries and councils, including the Ministry of National Defense, proposed 58 major science-based research projects for next year. After being cleared by the Cabinet, the budget will be sent to the Legislative Yuan for final approval.

DOC.HEADLINE: REMAINS OF VENEZUELAN PILOTS CREMATED, ASHES TO BE SENT HOME

TEXT.P: The remains of two Venezuelan pilots who worked for the Taiwan-based EVA airlines were cremated Wednesday afternoon in Taoyuan, about 25 miles south of Taipei. Their ashes will be taken back to their homes by their widows.

Rueda Cesar Alberto, 43, and Cegara Marco Tulio, 47, were determined after an autopsy to have died from carbon monoxide poisoning caused by an oven in their apartment. The wives of the two men did not challenge the coroner's conclusion.

Rueda and Tulio were found dead on Sunday in an EVA dormitory they shared in Luchu, Taoyuan County. Police who were called in discovered Rueda lying on his bed with bubbles formed around his mouth, while Cegara was lying in the living room. Their bodies bore no injuries and there was no sign of foul play.

Rueda was scheduled to fly an EVA passenger plane from Taoyuan to London earlier Sunday but failed to report to his job at the CKS International Airport. The plane left on schedule with a standby pilot at the controls.
Concerned EVA staff members went to the dormitory to check on Rueda after failing to reach him by phone and discovered the tragedy.

DOC.HEADLINE: OVERSEAS TAIPEI DESIGN CENTERS SEE SUCCESSFUL OPERATIONS

TEXT.P: Three overseas design centers built by the Industrial Development Bureau (IDB) under the Ministry of Economic Affairs earned a total of NT$52.62 million (US$1.64 million) from business operations this year, according to the IDB.

The IDB first established three Taipei Design Centers in 1992 -- in Milan, Italy; Duesseldorf, Germany; and Osaka, Japan -- for the purpose of enhancing the international competitiveness of Taiwan products.

IDB officials pointed out that the centers have employed several experienced designers and market analysts in those three modern cities to provide the most up-to-date and efficient services, including product development, market survey, and design personnel training.

Since 1993, orders received by the centers for product design, packaging and marketing have steadily increased, with the value of this year's orders reaching the highest-ever total of US$1.64 million, the officials said.

They noted that the IDB is also planning to set up new design centers in the United States, Taiwan's largest trade partner, and mainland China. However, plans for the mainland facility will remain on hold until the two sides of the Taiwan Strait resolve some of their current political differences.

DOC.HEADLINE: ROC TO HELP FINANCE ANIMAL DISEASE RESEARCH LAB IN BANGKOK

TEXT.P: The Republic of China will help fund an animal contagious diseases research laboratory in Bangkok, Thailand, to study foot-and-mouth disease and other animal ailments prevailing in Asia, a Council of Agriculture (COA) official said on Friday.

Chen Pao-chi, director of the COA's Animal Industry Department, said Asian member states of the Paris-based International Office of Epizootics, also known by its French acronym OIE, have long planned to establish an animal contagious diseases research institution in Bangkok. As many Southeast Asian countries are facing a host of financial woes, they have sought financial assistance from other nations, including the ROC.
Japan, the United States, Switzerland have agreed to contribute funds to the proposed laboratory, Chen said, adding that the ROC will also offer financial aid for the program.

Chen, who represented the ROC at an OIE-sponsored meeting on Asian animal diseases in India earlier this month, said India, Thailand, Malaysia and Singapore have strongly advocated the establishment of a regional research laboratory to help eradicate several infectious animal diseases in the region.

Chen said participants at the just-concluded OIE meeting agreed that the new research laboratory should given top priority to studies on foot-and-mouth disease (FMD) and poultry influenza, which have afflicted many Asian countries. The FMD, for example, has swept hog farms in all Asian countries except Japan and South Korea, and the deadly H5N1A influenza strain, which is spread by migratory birds, has been found in Hong Kong recently.
If all goes well, Chen said, the new research facility may be inaugurated next year.

Chen said the OIE, an affiliate of the United Nations, is one of the few government-to-government international organizations in which the ROC can participate. "We should play a more active role in OIE-affiliated animal disease research projects," he added.
