DOC.HEADLINE: 1997 AN UNHAPPY YEAR FOR MOST OF TAIWAN RESIDENTS: POLL

TEXT.P: People in Taiwan feel that 1997 was not a joyous year, with concerns over deteriorating social order being the top source of unhappiness, a recent opinion poll shows.

As the year 1997 will be wrapping up in a few days, the telephone poll, conducted by The China Times daily newspaper, found that most Taiwan residents have been dissatisfied with Taiwan's international status, economic development, public order, and government performance during the last year.

Residents were found to be only somewhat satisfied with the course of the island's democratic development and of relations across the Taiwan Strait, which received an approval rating of 42 percent and 28.6 percent, respectively.

The poll, conducted on Dec. 24 and 25 among more than 700 adults islandwide, found that people are most dissatisfied with public order conditions, with 86 percent of the respondents saying the law and order situation has deteriorated, while only 3.2 percent feel social order has improved.

A high of 45.8 percent of the respondents said Taiwan's international status has taken a turn for the worse, while 22.3 percent saw the situation as unchanged, and only 11.6 percent said the island's international status has improved.
Furthermore, 59 percent of the respondents said Taiwan's overall economic development has faltered, while 16.9 percent said the economy has improved and 14.6 percent saw no change.
About 43 percent of Taiwanese say they are dissatisfied with the government's administrative performance, as compared with 21.2 percent who feel it has improved over the past year.
Furthermore, 57.4 percent of residents believe the island's living environment has taken a turn for the worse, while 17.3 percent see a turn for the better, and 16.6 percent perceive no difference.

On the issue of cross-strait relations, 28.6 percent of the survey respondents cited "no change," while 25.5 percent said the situation has "become more worrisome," and 19.9 percent said mainland ties have "improved."
Regarding Taiwan's democratic development, a high of 42.1 percent said the democratization process has advanced during the past year, while 27.8 percent said it has regressed.

Finally, 33.6 percent of the respondents said they have been satisfied with their personal quality of life during the past year, as compared with 30.8 percent who are "dissatisfied," and 32.4 percent who see their lives as "more or less unchanged."

The China Times conducted the poll on Dec. 24 and 25 and received 741 valid responses, with approximately equal numbers of men and women. The daily noted the survey has a margin of error of plus or minus 3.7 percentage points.

DOC.HEADLINE: FIRST SHIPMENT OF MAINLAND CHINESE GRAVEL ARRIVES

TEXT.P: The Panamanian-registered Li Ning cargo ship anchored at the southern Taiwan port city of Kaohsiung Friday morning, delivering 22,000 metric tons of gravel from mainland China's Fujian Province.
The Li Ning delivery marked the first shipment of such cargo ever allowed from mainland China by Taiwan authorities.

The Republic of China government allowed the mainland gravel to be imported into Taiwan amid outcries from the domestic construction sector over the chronic and increasing shortage of gravel and other related materials.

Due to an impasse over the establishment of direct transport links between Taiwan and mainland China, the Li Ning cargo was transshipped from Fujian to Kaohsiung via Hong Kong, according to sources from the Kaohsiung Harbor Administration.
To accommodate the 17,300-ton vessel, the Kaohsiung Harbor needed weeks of preparation since the international port has no facilities for loading and unloading of gravel.

DOC.HEADLINE: MIDI HOTEL GIVEN 1ST PRIVATE HELIPORT OPERATING LICENSE

TEXT.P: Le Midi Hotel in the central Taiwan mountain resort of Chitou was granted an operating license for its new heliport on Friday.
This was the first time that the Civil Aeronautics Administration (CAA) has issued an operating permit for a privately owned heliport in Taiwan.

CAA Director-General Tsai Tuei said after presenting the license to a senior Midi executive that he hopes more private enterprises or local governments will build heliports at places where regular airport services are unavailable.

Midi Hotel spent more than NT$30 million (US$923,077) building a three-story heliport in its vicinity. The second and third floors of the terminal accommodate waiting lounges, a passenger service center, restaurants and shops, while the roof will be used as a chopper apron.

Midi Hotel has decided to cooperate with Daily Air Corp. in offering chartered flight services from major domestic airports to the hotel starting next month. Scheduled flight services between Taichung's Shuinan Airport and Midi Hotel will begin in February.
The Taiwan Tourist Association will introduce the new chopper services at the 1998 Europe Trade Fair to let foreign travel agencies know that Taiwan's travel market is undergoing significant changes.

Daily Air, which currently operates flight services between Taipei and the offshore frontline island of Matsu, said it will use eight-seat Bell-430 and 13-seat Bell-412 helicopters to operate flights between major domestic airport and Midi Hotel.

Starting in January, the airline will operate chartered flights to the hotel from Taipei's Sungshan Airport, Taoyuan's Chiang Kai-shek International Airport, Taichung's Shuinan Airport, eastern Taiwan's Hualien Airport and Kaohsiung's Hsiaokang International Airport.
The carrier will also offer three daily flights between Shuinan Airport and Midi Hotel starting in February. The ticket price for each flight is NT$2,000 (US$61.54) per person.

Midi and Daily executives said they hope the five-day workweek scheme will help attract more holidaymakers to the scenic Chitou forestry resort. Starting on Jan. 1, all government agencies and educational institutions will implement a five-day workweek on alternating weeks. Midi will offer special tour packages at discount prices between January and March to promote the newly opened chopper services.

DOC.HEADLINE: SHARE PRICES UP ON TAIEX

TEXT.P: Share prices closed 0.7 percent higher on the local stock market on Friday as purchases of low-price technology, plastic and chemical stocks continued where they left off on Wednesday following a one-day holiday, dealers said.
The brokers forecasted, however, that the positive trading pattern might see a reversal in the near future due to lower market turnovers.
The Taiwan Stock Exchange (TAIEX) weighted price index increased 57.45 points to close at 8,132.5, while the bourse opened at 8,135.45.
The TAIEX index reached a high of 8,205.7 on the day, and saw a low of 8,113.23.
Advancing issues overwhelmed falling stocks 347 to 71, with 57 shares unchanged.
A total of 2.01 billion shares changed hands on a market turnover of NT$97.43 billion (US$3.05 billion).
Seven of the eight major stocks categories enjoyed gains.

Textile shares rose the most at 2.3 percent, followed by plastic and chemical stocks at 2.1 percent, cement issues at 1.4 percent, foodstuff and construction shares at 1.2 percent each and paper-making and financial stocks at 0.8 percent each.
Electrical engineering issues dropped 0.5 percent.

The 10 companies with the largest turnovers were: Picvue Electronics, Pacific Electronic Wire, China Development, Far East Textile, Taiwan Styrene Monomer, Ever Fortune, Mosel Vitelic, AGV Products, Mitac International, and Union Petrochemical.

Meanwhile, as a result of active and steady stock trading, which has been cited as a contributing factor for Taiwan's continued economic vitality despite a slump in other Asian nations, the island's bad-check ratio dropped to 53 percent over the period from January to November 1997 in comparison with the year-earlier level, according to the Central Bank of China (CBC).
CBC officials assessed that the figure might be the lowest since 1992.
CBC statistics showed the amount of returned checks accounted for 0.5 percent of the total in November, down from the 0.52 percent recorded in October.

DOC.HEADLINE: DAILY AIR TO OPEN MATSU-OFFSHORE ISLETS CHOPPER SERVICES

TEXT.P: Daily Air Corp., which currently operates flight services between Taipei and the frontline island of Matsu, said on Friday it will start to offer chopper services between Matsu and its nearby islets from February next year.

The government has spent millions of dollars building heliports on the three isles off Matsu's coast -- Tungyin, Tungchu and Hsichu. The three heliports are scheduled to be completed before the Chinese New Year holiday which falls in late January.

Daily Air said it is confident in the market potential of the new chopper services between Matsu, which lies just off the mainland Chinese coast, and adjacent islets. In addition to an anticipated increase in holidaymakers following the implementation of a five-day workweek scheme next year, the carrier said military servicemen stationed on the islets were also potential customers.

The ticket price for each flight from Matsu's Peikan airfield to the three new heliports will be about NT$2,000 (US$61.54). The current price for a single Taipei-Matsu flight is NT$4,800. Thus, a Taipei-Matsu-Tungyin round trip will cost more than NT$10,000.
Daily Air has reached an agreement with Le Midi Hotel in the central Taiwan mountain resort of Chitou to operate chartered chopper services between major domestic airports and the hotel from January.

Starting in February, the airline will also offer three daily flights between Taichung's Shuinan Airport and Midi Hotel. The hotel is the first local private enterprise to build a heliport on its own. The Civil Aeronautics Administration issued a heliport operating license to Midi Hotel on Friday. The heliport costs more than NT$30 million (US$923,077).

The carrier said it will open chopper services to other major domestic tourist destinations, including Ilan and the Kenting National Park, and the Hsinchu Science-based Industrial Park, once heliports in those regions are completed.

DOC.HEADLINE: TAIPEI RESIDENTS LIVE LONGER

TEXT.P: Taipei residents live nearly four years longer on average than inhabitants of other cities and counties, the Ministry of the Interior reported Friday.

Ministry officials said that residents in cities with a high level of urbanization tend to have longer life spans. The average life span of residents in Taipei was 78.41 years last year, compared with 74.49 in Kaohsiung, and 74.14 in Taiwan Province.

The average life span of men in Taipei was also higher at 76.37 compared with 71.48 in Taiwan Province. The average life span of women in Taipei was 81.14 compared with 77.42 in Taiwan Province. Taipei and Kaohsiung are two special areas that do not fall under the administration of the Taiwan Provincial Government.

Residents of the five major cities within Taiwan Province -- Keelung, Hsinchu, Taichung, Chiayi and Tainan -- also recorded higher life expectancies than inhabitants of the 16 counties in the province.
The average life span for males in those five cities was 73.17 years last year, and 77.86 among females, higher by 1.69 and 0.44 years respectively than for men and women in the 16 counties.

The striking gap between city and county dwellers underscores an urgent need for Taiwan to attain a more evenly balanced development, a more equitable distribution of medical resources, and upgraded health standards in remote regions.

Average life expectancies also showed differences in terms of geographic regions. Residents in northern Taiwan live an average of 75.71 years, topping the 74.31 average life span found in central Taiwan, 73.65 in southern Taiwan and 69.59 in eastern Taiwan.
However, Taiwan residents in general live 1.25 years longer than they did a decade ago in 1987, with the average increase among females outpacing the increased life expectancy for males.
Compared with neighboring counties, the average life span of 74.55 in Taiwan is higher than in the Philippines (65) and South Korea (72), but lower than in Japan (80) and Singapore (76).
Taiwan's overall figure was also lower than that for United States (76), Canada (78), Britain (77), France (78) and Germany (76).

DOC.HEADLINE: US OFFICIALS URGE RESTRAIN ON TAIWAN INDEPENDENCE
DOC.DATELINE: Tokyo, Dec. 26 (CNA) (By Victor Lai and Lilian Wu)

TEXT.P: Senior officials from the US State Department urged Hsu Hsin-liang, chairman of Taiwan's main opposition Democratic Progressive Party, to show restraint on the issue of "Taiwan independence" during closed-door talks earlier this month, a major Japanese newspaper said here Friday.

The Sankei Shimbun reported from Washington, DC, that it is "odd" for senior State Department officials to have contact with the DDP, as occurred in the wake of the DPP's stunning victory in local elections held across Taiwan in late November.
The DPP won 12 seats of the 23 seats being contested, while the ruling Kuomintang managed only eight. The remaining three seats went to independents.

The talks with Hsu might have been prompted by worries on the US side that friction between mainland China and Taiwan could be heightened after the win by the DPP, which has in the past advocated the severance of Taiwan's ties to the mainland.
The reports said that during a meeting on Dec. 8, Hsu asked whether the US government had changed its policy toward Taiwan after the visit of mainland President Jiang Zemin.

The US officials replied that the policy has not changed, adding that the US will continue to adhere to the Taiwan Relations Act and to three communiques governing the Taiwan issue signed between the United States and mainland China.
Hsu said that advocacy of "Taiwan independence" is incorporated into the DPP platform, and that the party has no intention of changing that historical document, the reports said.

The US officials reportedly said the US guidelines have been beneficial to Taiwan, and the US policy will continue to be that the leaders on both sides of the Taiwan Strait should not take any "provocative action."
The US also reiterated its stance that it would not support Taiwan independence or the Republic of China's bid to join the United Nations.
The reports said that the meeting with Hsu was arranged after the DPP's election victory last month amid alarm in Washington that the DPP might step up its independence campaign.

DOC.HEADLINE: CREDIT CRISIS HAS BECOME BIGGEST RISK TO REFORM IN M'LAND CHINA
DOC.DATELINE: Beijing, Dec. 26 (CNA) (By Wang Hsin-chung & Eva Chen)

TEXT.P: With the huge debt accumulated by state-owned enterprises in mainland China's banking system, the credit crisis has become the biggest risk to the reform now underway in the Chinese mainland, a Beijing economic expert remarked on Thursday.
In addition, he said, since there is little left in the mainland banking system to allow people to buy consumer goods on credit, this in turn forms an impediment to economic growth.
Speculators with financial privileges use national credit for personal profit by engaging in stock and real estate speculation, he said.

Whenever there is a deficit, it is transferred to the bank, the expert stressed, adding that whenever there is a profit, the money goes into the pocket of the speculator. Stories of enormous bad loans are common. In addition, he said, many financial activities -- including those involving futures, securities, insurance and joint ventures -- are rife with serious fraud, mainly aimed at using public funds and the deposits of ordinary people for personal gain.

The expert was further quoted as saying that a basic law of market economies is "pay back the money you borrow." If this rule is breached, a credit crisis will arise, which will in turn affect normal economic activities and the lives of people in society as a whole.
This situation is unfortunately the biggest risk now confronting the reform process underway in the Chinese mainland, the expert complained.

DOC.HEADLINE: TAIWAN STUDENT DROWNS IN THE US
DOC.DATELINE: Washington, Dec. 25 (CNA) (By Herman Pan & Elizabeth Hsu)

TEXT.P: A Taiwan man studying at a technical college in Virginia drowned earlier this week at a ski resort in West Virginia, eastern United States, according to a newspaper report here.

The report, released Thursday by the mass-circulation Washington Post, cited local police as saying that the student, identified as Chen Jia-ben, 27, was found dead Monday in an indoor swimming pool at the Snowshoes mountain resort.
Medical staff and lifeguards at the resort tried unsuccessfully to revive Chen through artificial respiration.
The police said no eyewitnesses to the death have been located.

The report said the police are now investigating why there were no eyewitnesses, not even a lifeguard, on the scene when the accident occurred, despite firm assurances from a spokesman of the Snowshoes resort that qualified lifeguards are always on duty at the pool.
An autopsy will be performed on Chen's body to verify the cause of his death, the report noted.

DOC.HEADLINE: COA UNVEILS ANTI-FMD PACKAGE

TEXT.P: The Council of Agriculture (COA) has crafted a package of measures to eradicate the food-and-mouth disease (FMD) in two stages.
The council invited health officials, academics and hog industry representatives to review its draft anti-FMD package on Friday.
According to the package, the COA expects to completely stem recurrence of any FMD infection within a year.
The COA is also scheduled to finalize marking of all healthy pigs with ear-tags before the end of May next year.
COA officials said all pigs raised at ranches around the island must be vaccinated against the deadly disease and marked with ear-tags before next May.
The officials said the COA will join forces with local infectious disease control units and hog farmers associations to form joint inspection panels.

Such joint task forces will intensify spot checks at hog ranches, pork wholesale markets and meat processing facilities to ensure that local pig farmers properly and regularly vaccinate their swine in order to fend off the recurrence of an FMD epidemic on the island. The COA will aslo establish a national pig industry databank to facilitate monitoring of hog ranches.

The COA will compensate pig farmers who have had their swine vaccinated regularly but their pigs are still infected the virus again. According to government regulations, all FMD-infected pigs must be slaughtered.

Taiwan's hog ranches were hit by an FMD epidemic in mid-March, the first time in nearly five decades. Since them, all local swine have been vaccinated, but several FMD cases were reported againt early this month. COA officials said a large-scale FMD epidemic is unlikely to outbreak here again. It will take at least a year to prevent recurrence of sporadic FMD cases, and it will need three to four years for Taiwan to be drop from the list of FMD-stricken areas.

DOC.HEADLINE: SOMETHING ROTTEN IN THE STATE OF ASIA

TEXT.P: A senior Canadian journalist witnessing the Asian debt crisis firsthand last week found that while each country's problems are different, they share a common cause: "Their political and business establishments have grown corrupt and must be overthrown."
Peter Newman, a columnist for Maclean's magazine, pointed out, "Revolution is in the air." He made the observation in an article in the weekly's yearend double issue.

The "Pacific Century," hailed only last month by Canada's Prime Minister Jean Chretien at the Asia-Pacific Economic Cooperation summit in Vancouver, has turned to mush, as country leaders plead for more funds from the International Monetary Fund (IMF), he said. At least South Korea, Thailand and Indonesia will soon be forced to declare a debt moratorium as several Latin American countries did in 1982, he noted.

Newman stressed that the crisis flows out of cronyism that pervades these and other nearby countries. "Patronage inevitably trumps patriotism. Heads of governments use their national treasuries as personal kitties, with scarce resources allocated to retainers and relatives," he pointed out.

The family of Indonesia's President Suharto has created a mess of overdue bank loans in the region of more than US$300 billion, with little chance of payback, according to Newman. He added that the toughest job for the IMF is to "drastically alter the area's fiscal culture."
"The monopolies must be broken up, corruption eliminated," he emphasized.

The situation in Indonesia is so fragile, resentment against the Suharto family so intense, "there is bound to be violence in any takeover" when the 76-year-old dictator drops out of sight, Newman said in the article titled "Something rotten in the state of Asia."

Least touched by the meltdown have been "Hong Kong, Singapore and Taiwan," the columnist said. While they are far from enlightened democracies, these islands of fiscal sanity have moved far beyond their neighbors, which are run as personal money machines for their rulers, he noted.

What happens now, not just to the stricken regional economies, but to the world at large, will depend on the short- and long-term stability of Japan and mainland China, "Asia's twin anchors of relative fiscal stability," he predicted.

So far, mainland China has been protected because its yuan is not convertible and its stocks are not subject to foreign speculation, he opined. The mainland's business potential is so huge that nothing much can hurt it, though its stunning growth rate is bound to slow and some of its banks are shaky, he added.

"Similarly," he continued, "despite its troubles with failing investment houses and overextended banks, Japan still holds huge foreign reserves and remains the world's second largest economy." "But public confidence is fading," he warned.
To him, "As usual, Asia is full of contradictions."

DOC.HEADLINE: AUSTRALIA DOUBLES PENALTY ON SPEEDING, DRUNK DRIVING DURING HOLIDAYS

TEXT.P: Australia is imposing severe penalties and fines for speeding and drunk driving after 29 people were killed and several others injured in the past week and more police are sent to major cities and roads to crack down on offenders.

A federal police spokesman told reporters that people found driving in excess of over 30 kilometers above the speed limit will lose their driving licenses and even face jail terms if they cause serious accidents.

Regularly drivers found guilty of driving in excess of more than 10 kilometers above the speed limit will lose three points as a demerit and face a fine of between A$130 and A$170. But now they will face a double penalty if they are caught in either speeding or drunk driving, the spokesman said.
The purpose is to alert motorists to drive carefully so that the number of accidents will drop.
Even before the Christmas holiday began Thursday, the death toll resulting from car accidents over the past week had already reached 29, the spokesman said.

DOC.HEADLINE: UNITED STATES, JAPAN SIGN LIQUOR AGREEMENT

TEXT.P: The United States and Japan signed an agreement to phase out disparities in Japan's tax rates between Japanese and imported distilled spirits earlier than planned, according to reports of the Geneva-based World Trade Organization (WTO) on Thursday.
Under the agreement, Tokyo will raise taxes on Japanese "shochu" spirits in May 1998 and October 2000, instead of October 1998 and 2001 as planned earlier.
Japan will raise taxes on "ko" shochu and cut those on whiskeys in May next year, and will then increase the taxes on "otsu" shochu in October 2000.
There are two basic varieties of shochu -- the otsu type characterized by a strong flavor and the ko type which is clear and has no smell.
Japan will also reduce tariffs on bourbon and whiskeys and eventually abolish them in April 2002.
The Japanese government earlier decided to raise taxes on shochu by maximum 140 percent while cutting the levy on whiskeys by 58 percent by October 2001 through three stages.
But Tokyo and Washington have been negotiating Japan's plan since the WTO issued a ruling in February upholding US insistence that Japan must narrow the gaps in taxes by Feb. 1, 1998.

The ruling came after Japan earlier lost a WTO dispute settlement case filed by the United States and European Union against Japan's discriminatory tax system on imported spirits, the WTO report said.

DOC.HEADLINE: TAIWAN TAKING STEPS TO REDUCE TRADE DEFICIT WITH S. KOREA

TEXT.P: The Board of Foreign Trade (BOFT) will take several steps to help reduce Taiwan's increasing trade deficits with South Korea, a BOFT official said Friday.

Major trading companies doing business with South Korea will be invited by the BOFT to a meeting on Dec. 30 to exchange views on S. Korea's trade barriers and on how to increase exports to that country, the official said. S. Korea has become Taiwan's second biggest source of trade deficit, next only to Japan.

The BOFT will organize in May a trade mission to S. Korea to promote the sales of Taiwan products. The trade mission will visit S. Korean enterprises and hold seminars on trade between the two countries.

The official said that next year the BOFT will also organize trade missions to take part in S. Korea's international trade exhibitions of foods processing technologies, porcelain, fiber machinery, and communications equipment.

DOC.HEADLINE: PRES. LEE SAYS PEACEFUL EVOLUTION WILL CONTINUE ON CHINA MAINLAND

TEXT.P: President Lee Teng-hui said Friday that mainland China will continue to undergo peaceful evolution because of the democratization of Taiwan, the Republic of China.
Speaking at a seminar on national affairs, Lee said in his capacity as chairman of the ruling Kuomintang that the Beijing regime is very sensitive about Taiwan's democratization.
"What Communist China fears most is the democratization of Taiwan," he told the 160 KMT youths participating in the seminar.
The Beijing regime is also very sensitive about his foreign trips, Lee said, because "Communist China feels threatened by the democratization on Taiwan."
He said the government will simultaneously promote formal diplomacy and pragmatic diplomacy. "We must broaden our international activities," he stressed.
Lee also said Beijing's rhetoric that "The People's Republic of China is the only legal government of China" must be refuted as a false claim.
The Republic of China on Taiwan is also doing very well economically and is getting more important in the world, Lee pointed out.
Lee said Taiwan will be able to weather the financial storms in Asia, and predicted that mainland China and Hong Kong will have more severe economic difficulties next year. (by Ed Hsieh)

DOC.HEADLINE: MAINLAND CHINESE ENGINEERS SEEK ADVICE FROM AUSSIE COUNTERPARTS

TEXT.P: Hit by the communist-controlled system, mainland Chinese engineers are now seeking advice from Australian counterparts so that they can remove barriers to their free movement and keep pace with international standards.
The Institution of Engineers, Australia (IEA) reported that the Beijing government is keen for mainland engineers to become better integrated with the global scene.

IEA President Barry Grear told mass circulation newspaper The Australian this week that his institution had recently held a series of seminars in Beijing, Guangzhou and Xian on better global standards and participation.

He said the mainland engineers are "aware Western countries are developing agreements that work toward removing barriers to the free movement and practice of professional engineers between countries."

"They are trying to work out ways in which they can have more peer review of standards. At the moment, there are many standards that are set by government-related organizations. But they are wanting to change so that instead of having different standards for every city, they want to open it up for much greater mobility within China and between China and other countries," he said.
He said: "Australia has been recognized as a leader in the area of global recognition of engineering standards and professional experience within the world market."

He said the organizer of the seminars -- the China Association for Science and Technology -- plans to send a delegation to Australia next year to gain first-hand knowledge of Australian standards and practices. He did not mention the timing of the visit by the mainland Chinese delegation.

DOC.HEADLINE: GRAND JUSTICES SAY CONSCRIPTION RESTRICTION UNCONSTITUTIONAL

TEXT.P: The Council of Grand Justices on Friday interpreted the eighth article of the Military Service Law as unconstitutional, saying that the statute violates the people's freedom of movement enshrined in the Constitution.
Referring to the 10th Article of the Constitution, the grand justices said the people are entitled to freedom of abode, movement and emigration.
The grand justices said that therefore regulations restricting a portion of the island's male population from going abroad should be removed once and for all.

The new interpretation made by the Council of Grand Justices is tantamount to liberalized exit regulations for the island's young men, said Chen Ting-chung, director of the Department of Conscription of the Ministry of the Interior (MOI).

Until this decision, young men were banned from leaving the country as soon as they reached 18 because they could be conscripted at any time. The ban remained in force until they completed their required military service, which lasts two to three years.

These youths could go abroad only if invited to attend academic activities or competitions, or to attend relatives' funeral services and other special occasions, and only then with written guarantees from their parents or legal guardians.
In response to the grand justices' announcement, the MOI said on Friday that it will see to it that related regulations are revised in line with the decision.
The Ministry of National Defense, meanwhile, will revise its own relevant regulations so as to accommodate the new development.

DOC.HEADLINE: TAISUGAR TO MAKE INVESTMENTS OVERSEAS

TEXT.P: The Taiwan Sugar Company is carrying out plans to make investments in four foreign countries, Taisugar Board Chairman P. T. Chien said Friday.

He said Taisugar's joint venture in Vietnam, which became operational in May, produces 10,000 tons of sugar per year. It's annual production capacity will increase to 100,000 tons, when the development plan is completed in the near future.
In addition, Taisugar will relocate its sugar mill in Pingtung, southern Taiwan, to northern Vietnam. It will have an annual production capacity of 2,000 tons.
Taisugar also plans to develop a pig farm in Vietnam, which will be big enough to raise 60,000 pigs at a time.
Chien said Taisugar also plans to raise 30,000 pigs and 30,000 cattle at a time in the Philippines and Australia respectively. It also plans to grow orchids in Costa Rica, he added.
Being unable to compete with other countries in producing sugar, the company has diversified into real estate, eatable oils, health foods, housing construction, and other businesses, he added.

DOC.HEADLINE: MOST TAIWAN PEOPLE OPPOSE BEIJING'S UNIFICATION FORMULA: POLL

TEXT.P: Up to 64.5 percent of the people of Taiwan are opposed to unification with mainland China under Beijing's "one country, two systems" formula, while only 13.4 percent said they could accept this framework, according to the results of a public opinion survey released on Friday.

The survey, made public by Kuomintang (KMT) Legislator Daniel K.Y. Han at the Legislative Yuan, shows that 68.2 percent of the respondents said that they do not believe in Beijing's "one country, two systems" policy, nor in its promise that "Hong Kong people rule Hong Kong." Only 9.3 percent said they have confidence in Beijing's promise.

The survey reveals that 70.3 percent of those polled said that they fully or partially understand Beijing's "one country, two systems" formula, while 29.4 percent said that they don't understand it at all or understand it only a little.

Responding to questions on Hong Kong's overall situation and its future after its return to Beijing's rule in July 1997, 44.7 percent opined that Hong Kong will remain unchanged, in contrast to 4.9 percent who said it will be better off, while 16.1 percent said they think the situation there will worsen in the long run.

Asked about the impression they have of Hong Kong and mainland China, 44.5 percent and 13.5 percent of the respondents gave a positive appraisal of Hong Kong and mainland China, respectively, while 25.1 percent and 64.3 percent, respectively, said they have a negative impression of the former British colony and the Chinese mainland.

The poll also indicates that the people of Taiwan are most concerned about the government's policy toward public order, economic development, improvement in education and democracy, upgrading of national defense and environmental protection, as well as civic and social education and promotion of artistic activities.
The telephone poll, carried out by Shihhsin University on Dec. 10-12, covered 1,075 people aged 18 or over and has a margin of error of 3.05 percentage points.

DOC.HEADLINE: FINANCIAL CRISIS WILL COMPROMISE TAIWAN'S ECONOMIC RECOVERY

TEXT.P: Taiwan's economic growth is losing steam against the background of Southeast Asia's financial crisis and the sharp devaluation of the South Korean won, which, if not halted soon, will cast a shadow on Taiwan's economic prospects for the first quarter of next year, a local economic institute reported on Friday.

The Taiwan Institute of Economic Research, a non-profit civil think-tank, said in an analysis that Taiwan, with its sound financial system and ample foreign reserves, has ridden the economic crisis sweeping its Asian neighbors almost unscathed.
However, the institute said that the bankruptcies of many Japanese and South Korean business conglomerates have cast uncertainty on global economic prospects.

Taiwan's exports to Japan, South Korea and Thailand shrank in November, while textile orders from Hong Kong also posted a decline, a fact reflecting the fizzling out of Taiwan's economic momentum, said the analysis.

It predicted a slack business season for the island's economic backbone -- the electronic industry -- in light of the sharp devaluation of South Korea's currency, which has lost half of its value against the US dollar, coupled with the poor performance of the Hong Kong and Japan bourses.
Unless the Asian financial crisis is halted soon, Taiwan's economy is unlikely to post excellent growth next year.

In view of the Central Bank of China's pledges to maintain a sufficient supply of money during the year end, and the markdown of interest rates by local banks, the institute ruled out a tight financial market during the Chinese Lunar New Year, which will in turn help stabilize the value of the New Taiwan dollar, currently standing at about 32 against the greenback.

DOC.HEADLINE: CSBC TO DELIVER VESSEL TO GERMAN SHIPPING COMPANY

TEXT.P: The first of nine cargo ships the Kaohsiung headquarters of the China Shipbuilding Corp. (CSBC) is building for the German-based Rickmers shipping company will soon be delivered, the state-run CSBC announced on Friday.
As the German shipper attaches great importance to its cooperative ties with the CSBC, the president of Rickmers will come to Taiwan to personally preside over the takeover ceremony.

The cargo vessel, to be named "Alexandra Rickmers," is 187 meters long and 32 meters wide, with a capacity of 2,226 containers. It will be equipped with the most advanced shipping facilities and fully meets the standards set by the German shipping association.

Rickmers' decision to place the order for nine cargo ships with the CSBC aroused widespread attention in Europe and the completion of the "Alexandra Rickmers" is proof that the CSBC's efforts to explore the European market has paid off.

DOC.HEADLINE: EDUCATION MINISTER FAVORS CONSTITUTIONAL INTERPRETATION

TEXT.P: Education Minister Wu Jin said on Friday that the removal of restrictions that ban young men who haven't completed military service from going abroad will greatly help the plans his ministry is advocating aimed at encouraging university students to study abroad.

Wu said that his ministry has been pushing for a system of academic exchange and cooperation programs between local and foreign universities, under which university students will study abroad for one semester or one school year.

According to a "sandwich system" proposed by Wu on Wednesday, students would study locally for their first year, pursue their studies in foreign countries in their second year, and come back to Taiwan to continue their studies in their third year.

Many universities in Taiwan already allow their students to study abroad for a short period of time, usually in the field of foreign language study. However, male university students do not have the chance to go abroad because of the restrictions imposed on them by regulations governing the exit of young men.

The article promulgated by the Ministry of the Interior (MOI) bans young males who haven't completed their military service from going abroad lest they fail to return to Taiwan to meet their obligation stipulated in the constitution. All ROC males are obliged to serve for two or three years in the military when they reach the age of 18. If they are still at school at that age, they can delay their military service until they finish their studies.

The Council of Grand Justices on Friday ruled the article unconstitutional on the grounds that the statute runs counter to the constitutional guarantee of the right to freedom of movement, and was not enacted in line with the required legislative process.
The grand justices ruled that the unconstitutional article should become invalid within six months.

The ruling, however, doesn't necessarily mean that young men can go abroad freely when the article becomes invalid, since the MOI said it will seek to legislate a new law governing the exit of young men.

DOC.HEADLINE: TAIPEI MAYOR CONFIRMS INTEREST IN TOP DPP POSITION
DOC.DATELINE: Tokyo, Dec. 26 (CNA) (By Victor Lai and Lin Wen-fen)

TEXT.P: Taipei Mayor Chen Shui-bian on Friday for the first time said that he will think seriously about running for the head of the Democratic Progressive Party (DPP).

Chen said that whether he will be a candidate in the election for DPP chairman to be held in May is not a personal matter, so he will consider the opinions of DPP grassroots members, DPP heavyweights and other social leaders before making a decision.

At a press conference held in Tokyo, Chen told Japanese reporters that the idea of running for DPP chairman didn't occur to him until his arrival in Japan, explaining that his arrival in a foreign country allowed him to cool down and think about the question.
Chen is regarded as a potential powerful challenger for the top DPP position, but he had so far refrained from showing any interest in the post, saying that he hasn't even thought of the possibility.

Asked if the DPP will win the 2000 presidential election, Chen said that the DPP's victory is certain, as it corresponds with current trends. The recent victory of South Korean opposition leader Kim Dae-jung in the presidential election in that country has inspired his party a lot, Chen noted.

However, the popular mayor refused to confirm whether or not he will run for the next presidential election, saying that he cannot predict what will happen in the next two years. The most important thing at present is to be a good mayor, Chen told the reporters.

Stressing that the DPP is a democratic and united party, Chen said that in spite of the factions in the party, DPP members always reach consensus at the critical moment. The DPP will not and cannot afford to split, he added.
Chen arrived in Tokyo on Thursday to attend the opening ceremony of the "Taiwan Film Exhibition." He is scheduled to return to Taipei on Saturday.

DOC.HEADLINE: NEW TAXATION SCHEME BENEFICIAL TO ALL

TEXT.P: A new taxation scheme slated to take effect on Jan. 1, 1998 will benefit both small and large businesses and the general public, Finance Minister Paul Chiu said on Friday.

Speaking at a news conference at the Ministry of Finance, Chiu said the new taxation system will reduce the tax burden by as much as 0.35 percent of Taiwan's gross domestic product and will help stir up economic growth of 0.25-0.35 percent.

Chiu made the remarks after the Legislative Yuan passed the third reading of the two-in-one new taxation bill, which incorporates business income tax and individual consolidated income tax, thus putting an end to the unfair system of double taxation which exists under the current regulations.
The measure, Chiu said, is expected to bring about immediate benefits of a lower tax burden to a total of 480,000 self-employed and joint-venture businesses.

Under the new regulations, a company can deduct its business income tax from the personal consolidated income tax of its shareholders, while the maximum integrated tax rate will be slashed from the present 55 percent to 40 percent.
These measures will help to increase the public's actual disposable income and will create stronger purchasing power, which will stimulate the nation's economic growth, according to Chiu.
A low-tax environment will greatly improve Taiwan's investment climate and help sharpen Taiwan industries' competitive edge in the international community, he added.

DOC.HEADLINE: INTERNATIONAL BUSINESS JOURNALS HAIL TAIWAN'S HEALTHY ECONOMY

TEXT.P: Surprised by Taiwan's ability to remain nearly unscathed in the current financial crisis, two of the world's most renowned business journals hailed Taiwan's marvelous economic performance this week.

Quoting a foreign investor who called Taiwan "the Switzerland of the Orient," the London-based Financial Times attributed the island's relative immunity to the financial firestorm that has blitzed many of its neighbors to the fact that its economic fundamentals are stronger than those of many of its neighbors.

In an article published on Wednesday, the newspaper said Taiwan's economy reached its nadir in 1996 and is at a different phase of its economic cycle than other countries. It is also more closely tied to the "China triangle" -- Taiwan, Hong Kong and mainland China -- than to the rest of the region.

The island's burgeoning democracy has also played a role, according to the Financial Times, because the close watch on the government and banks by the opposition parties and the media have kept the cronyism rampant in financial circles to a minimum.

However, the article, submitted by the Financial Times' correspondent in Taipei, Laura Tyson, warned that markets are not always rational, and financial crisis may still strike, no matter how well-run Taiwan's economy might be.

Meanwhile, the Hong Kong-based Asian Wall Street Journal put Taiwan's resistance to the financial turmoil to the responsiveness and adaptability to market fluctuations of its many small- and medium-sized enterprises.

In a story by Dow Jones Newswires Taipei chief Russell Flannery, which was published on Tuesday, the newspaper also held out bright prospects for the island's economy by predicting that the island's competitors will usurp Korea Inc.'s place in the global marketplace.

DOC.HEADLINE: TAX CONSOLIDATION TO AID ECONOMIC GROWTH

TEXT.P: The taxation reform passed Friday by the Legislature is expected to contribute the national economic growth by more than 0.25 percent in the first year after its implement, said the Finance Minister Paul Chiu Friday.

In a press conference called after the enactment of the new rules, Chiu said that the new system, which makes business income deductible from personal income to avoid double taxation, will improve both the fairness and efficiency of taxation.

Under the new system, income from business operation will taxed only once as part of personal income at a rate between 10 percent to 40 percent, rather than the zero to 55 percent under the current system.

It will cost the government NT28 billion in lost revenue, according to Chiu. Of that windfall, Chiu said, about NT$8 billion to NT$9 billion will go to the individual business operators and their partners, the other NT$19 billion to NT$20 billion will be enjoyed by enterprises of various size.

The two-in-one tax reform, to some extent, is a tax reduction similar in impact to that of the tax reduction package unveiled by Japan two weeks ago with the purpose to reinvigorate its economy. The increase in personal disposable income resulted from the new system will stimulate consumption which in turn will increase the domestic demand and promote the economic expansion.

The NT$28 billion lost tax income, accounting for 0.355 percent of gross national production, is expected to fuel the economic growth by an extra 0.25-0.35 percent and increase national income by 1.5-2 percent, said Chiu.

Meanwhile, the Chinese National Federation of Industries Chairman Kao Ching-yen said Friday night that the federation as well as the two other national business groups, the Chinese National Association of Industry & Commerce and the General Chamber of Commerce of the Republic of China, all support the new tax scheme.

DOC.HEADLINE: EVA AIR TO OPEN TAIPEI-CHICAGO ALL-CARGO SERVICES
DOC.DATELINE: Los Angeles, Dec. 26 (CNA) (By Philip Liu and Flor Wang)

TEXT.P: The US headquarters of the Taipei-based EVA Airways Corporation (EVA AIR) announced here on Friday that it will open three weekly all-cargo services between Taipei and Chicago beginning on Jan. 8, 1998.

Coupled with its current all-cargo flights to other cities in the United States, the opening of the new route will help the company provide a more comprehensive service network between Asia and North America and help it expand its transshipment services to Columbus, Detroit, Dallas, Miami, Atlanta and Minneapolis, EVA AIR said.

Taiwan's second-largest carrier said that it will use two brand new MD-11 aircraft to serve the Taipei-Chicago route and that the addition of the two planes will expand its all-cargo fleet to five units.

In addition to six weekly all-cargo flights between Taipei and Los Angeles, EVA AIR currently also operates two weekly all-cargo flights to New York and one weekly flight to San Francisco. The airline also operates all-cargo flights to Amsterdam, Brussels, Singapore, Kuala Lumpur, Penang and Manila.

EVA AIR said its revenues in its all-cargo operation reached NT$10.9 billion (about US$330 million) in 1996 and that the figure is expected to increase by 20 percent for 1997, accounting for about one-third of its total annual turnover.
