DOC.HEADLINE: ABSCONDING ALIEN WORKERS STILL A COMMON PROBLEM

TEXT.P: One-quarter of Taiwan employers who have hired workers from abroad have encountered the problem of their running away, according to a recent poll conducted by the cabinet-level Council of Labor Affairs (CLA).
Although the number of runaways decreased slightly in 1997 compared with 1996, the percentage of absconding alien workers, mostly from Southeast Asian countries, remains high, CLA officials said.
The poll of 3,702 local companies found that 24.36 percent of the respondents hired foreign workers last year who later ran away, compared with 30.1 percent recorded in 1996.
Local employers attributed the high rate of absconding to peer pressure among the workers, and the expiry of their work contracts, according to the poll.

The poll also found that 73.8 percent of local employers impose compulsory saving plans on their foreign workers to try to prevent them fleeing, whereby workers are forced to deposit part of their monthly salaries in time savings accounts which cannot be drawn upon within a certain period of time. The money plus interest is paid when the workers legally finish their contracts.

According to CLA tallies, as of the end of November this year, the government had approved the entry to Taiwan of 334,082 foreign laborers from overseas. Of this total, 254,261 have actually entered the country for employment, mostly in the manufacturing and construction sectors, which absorbed 212,339, while household helpers accounted for most of the remainder.
These 254,261 foreign workers constitute about 2.78 percent of Taiwan's overall workforce, CLA officials said.

DOC.HEADLINE: TRADE DEFICIT WITH EUROPE SKYROCKETS

TEXT.P: Taiwan incurred a trade deficit of US$2.62 billion with Europe in the first 11 months of this year, marking a 23 percent year-on-year rise, the Board of Foreign Trade (BOFT) reported on Saturday.

Two-way trade between Taiwan and the Old Continent topped US$36.02 billion during the 11-month period. Of this amount, Taiwan exports accounted for US$16.7 billion, up 8.6 percent from the year-earlier level, while imports from countries in the region as a whole posted an even more impressive gain of 10.4 percent, to reach US$19.32 billion.

BOFT officials said the Commonwealth of Independent States (CIS), the European Free Trade Association (EFTA) and the European Union (EU) were the main sources of Taiwan's trade deficit with the region.

Among EU countries, Taiwan registered a trade deficit of US$2.6 billion with France alone for the January-November period, mainly because of its purchases of French-made weaponry systems and military equipment.

During the same period, Taiwan incurred a deficit of US$720 million in its trade with Switzerland, an EFTA member state. The amount represented a substantial 27 percent decline from the year-earlier level, partly because of drops in Taiwan's imports of Swiss gold bullion, wristwatches and cigarettes.

As Taiwan has imported large quantities of raw materials, including steel, iron ore, aluminum, nickel and cotton from Russia and other former Soviet republics, its trade deficit with the CIS as a whole reached US$1.29 billion during the January-November period, up 25.7 percent from a year ago.

BOFT officials said the board will join forces with other local trade promoting agencies, including the semi-official China External Trade Development Council, to help local entrepreneurs expand their sales to Europe in order to narrow the widening trade gap.

DOC.HEADLINE: PRESIDENT LEE SAID HIGHLY KNOWLEDGEABLE AND EAGER TO LEARN

TEXT.P: President Lee Teng-hui is a very learned man with an insatiable thirst for knowledge, particularly in the fields of molecular medicine, molecular genetics, and neurology, said the president's chief medical advisor on Saturday.

Dr. Lien Wen-pin, a leading cardiologist with the National Taiwan University Hospital and head of the presidential medical team, said President Lee is a model patient who is very medically perceptive.

An insatiable reader, the president shows a keen interest, particularly in books and reports related to the working of the brain, the sympathetic nervous system, hormones, molecular medicine and molecular genetics, Lien noted.

In addition, he said, Lee has a photographic memory. The president memorizes every line and chapter he reads about medical instruments and biological materials. In his mind, he has a clear picture of Taiwan's medical service development and its problems, Lien added.
Lien made the remarks during a ceremony marking the establishment of a turn-of-the-century medicare promotion foundation, to which President Lee was the first fund donor.
Lien himself gave his entire retirement pension to the foundation to help finance its establishment, aiming at raising medicare standards and improving medical research in Taiwan.
Lien, who has lectured at the National Taiwan University School of Medicine for 43 years, retired this summer to work on the foundation's establishment.
His cause has received enthusiastic response, with cash donors ranging from the president to business entrepreneurs. In September alone, NT$10 million (US$312,000) was raised.

The main function of the foundation is to provide financial support for young medical talent engaged in medical research, and to establish chair professorships which will allow veteran medical professors, both local and overseas, to give lectures to young students and professionals in Taiwan.

To begin the professorship program, the foundation has decided to invite two leading cardiological specialists in Japan -- Prof. Yuichiro Goto from Tokai University and Prof. Motokazu Hori from Tsukuba University -- to give lectures at Taiwan's medical schools on a five-year academic contract.

DOC.HEADLINE: NO TAX INCREASE NEXT YEAR: FINANCE MINISTER

TEXT.P: Finance Minister Paul Chiu said on Saturday that his ministry will not increase taxes next year to make up for losses from a new taxation scheme which was passed by the legislature on Friday.
Chiu made the remarks in a year-end conference during which he also unveiled white papers on national tariffs, securities and futures, customs services, insurance, national property and banking.

The Legislative Yuan on Friday passed the third reading of the new two-in-one taxation bill, which incorporates business income tax and individual consolidated income tax, thus putting an end to the unfair system of double taxation which exists under the current regulations. The new scheme is scheduled to go into effect on Jan. 1, 1998.

The new scheme is expected to cost the government an estimated NT$31.5 billion (US$969.23 million) in lost revenue, and Chiu was asked if the government plans to increase taxes to make up for the shortfall, which he denied.

Under the new system, income from business operations will be taxed only once, as part of personal income, at a rate between 10 percent to 40 percent, rather than the zero to 55 percent under the current system.
The new system will help lessen the tax burden on the individual, help promote stable employment and stimulate consumption after making business income deductible from personal income.

Most legislators are in favor of scrapping the present tax-free status for military personnel and schoolteachers, but Chiu said these issues need further consultation and that his ministry will submit a report on the issue before June next year.

DOC.HEADLINE: HONDURAS INVITES ROC TO ATTEND ITS PRESIDENTIAL INAUGURATION

TEXT.P: Honduras has extended an invitation to the Republic of China to send representatives to the inauguration of President-elect Carlos Flores on Jan. 27, Jason Hu, minister of Foreign Affairs, said Saturday.
On whether Vice President Lien Chan will lead the ROC delegation to the inauguration, Hu said the ministry is still working on related matters and that this will be decided soon.
Hu said overseas trips of some top government officials are still on the drawing board, and that he preferred not to comment on them before they are finalized.

On reports that President Lee Teng-hui will visit three or four allies in Africa, Hu said that it is better not to play up the trip before it happens. "Otherwise, it will only bring trouble to the ministry," he added.
Honduras is one of the staunchest supporters of the ROC in Central America.

DOC.HEADLINE: ELECTABILITY FOREMOST CRITERIA IN CHOOSING KMT CANDIDATES: CHANG

TEXT.P: Although personal willingness and credentials are vital in selecting the party's candidates for the mayoral races in Taipei and Kaohsiung, the candidates' chances of winning come first, said John Chang, the ruling Kuomintang's secretary-general, on Saturday.

Responding to questions on the sidelines of a symposium for young KMT leaders, Chang said it is not yet appropriate to discuss publicly the probable KMT candidates for the two municipalities' elections next year, noting that the party will thoroughly consult with its potential standard bearers before drafting them.

As a well-organized political group with many excellent members, the KMT has an established procedure for choosing its candidates, Chang said, adding that this procedure has not yet been launched in the case of the next municipal elections.
While the KMT has not yet revealed its candidates for the two cities' top spots, the major opposition group, the Democratic Progressive Party, is set to field two political heavyweights.
The mayors of Taipei and Kaohsiung are the Republic of China's most important elected officials after the president.

Taiwan Governor James Soong, former State Minister Ma Ying-jeou and Foreign Minister Jason Hu, among others, are reported as the favorites for the KMT nomination in Taipei, while Justice Minister Liao Cheng-hao and incumbent Kaohsiung Mayor Wu Den-yih are tapped as possible party candidates in Kaohsiung. All of the figures, however, have dodged questions about their possible runs.
Jason Hu, at the same symposium, denied that he had ever been consulted about running in Taipei, but said he would abide by the party's order if called.

Meanwhile, James Soong, encountering reporters at an inspection of the Taipei Railroad Station on Saturday, brushed off questions by repeating what has become his typical response: "As governor of Taiwan Province, I would rather devote my full energy to serving my constituents."

DOC.HEADLINE: PROSECUTED JUDGE SUSPENDED FROM DUTY

TEXT.P: A high court section chief judge who was prosecuted for influence-peddling on Saturday was suspended immediately from the bench by the Judicial Yuan President Shih Chi-yang.

In a gesture underscoring the government's determination to wipe out corruption in the island's judiciary, Shih stressed that integrity is the foundation on which the judiciary is built, and that Huang Tien-hua, a judge in the Taiwan High Court, will be punished to the full extent of law.
Earlier on Saturday, Huang was suspended from his job as a section chief by an internal disciplinary committee, before a prosecutor unsealed his own charges against him.

The prosecutor accused Huang of fraudulently obtaining NT$6 million from a defendant in a criminal suit before the Taiwan High Court, by falsely promising to bribe the presiding judges into handing down a not guilty verdict or a probationary sentence.
He was exposed after failing to honor his promise, said the prosecutor.

Although Huang denied the accusation in a statement following his suspension, he described himself as no longer suitable for his position and said he would like to be transferred after his prosecution.

DOC.HEADLINE: TAIWAN, SOUTH KOREA SEEN CAPABLE OF RESISTING POLITICAL STRAIN
DOC.DATELINE: Ottawa, Dec. 26 (CNA) (By S.C. Chang and Flor Wang)

TEXT.P: Among all the Asian "tiger" economies, Taiwan and South Korea, the two most remarkable democracies in the region, will take the political strain best in 1998, a Canadian magazine forecast in its latest issue.

The special report made in conjunction with the Economist publications forecast that the once-powerful Asian tiger economies will cure their wounds in "the intensive care unit" in 1998, and that those who can swallow the bitter medicine will be released from hospital earliest.

The report said that the financial morass which occurred in Southeast Asia in August will last until next year, and that the crisis will put to test the ability of the "wounded tigers" to put their troubled financial systems in order.

The report by Paul Markillie, an editor for the Economist magazine's Asian edition, said Southeast Asian countries, such as Malaysia, will push for expanded trade and investment activities among ASEAN countries to fend off the economic invasion by mainland China and India.

Although the economic growth of Asian nations will slow down next year, Markillie said the figures will still be higher than those estimated for developed countries. He said optimistically that the 1997 financial crisis will cause the Asian tiger economies to change "in the right direction," but that they are expected to take two years to rise again.

DOC.HEADLINE: OUTGOING ENVOY OPTIMISTIC ABOUT FUTURE ROC-SOUTH AFRICA TIES
DOC.DATELINE: Tokyo, Dec. 27 (CNA) (By Mike Chang and Flor Wang)

TEXT.P: Loh I-cheng, the outgoing ROC ambassador to South Africa, said on Thursday that he is optimistic about the future of relations between the ROC and South Africa after the two countries sever their diplomatic ties on Dec. 31, 1997. Speaking in an interview with the Japanese daily Mainichi Shimbun at Johannesburg international airport, Loh said he regrets having to leave South Africa and that he is planning to retire from politics after returning to Taipei. He also expressed sorrow for the isolation that Taiwan has encountered in the international community, but voiced confidence in Taiwan's continued economic development.

Loh criticized mainland China's investment in South Africa as being aimed solely at seeking profits for Beijing, pointing out that the ROC's past assistance to South Africa has been for the purpose of helping the host country.

According to Loh, there are currently about 30,000 Chinese people residing in South Africa, 15,000 of whom are immigrants who arrived from Taiwan in the 1980s. He expressed optimism that the business interests and human rights of these Taiwan immigrants will be fully protected in South Africa after the closure of the ROC embassy, as the country has a sound and just legal system.
He also predicted that there will be no big changes in future bilateral ties, despite the upcoming suspension of official diplomatic relations between the two countries.

DOC.HEADLINE: ROC MISSION TO VISIT FOUR FINANCIAL CRISIS-HIT COUNTRIES

TEXT.P: P.K. Chiang, chairman of the cabinet-level Council for Economic Planning and Development (CEPD), will head a delegation of economics and financial officials on a visit to four neighboring Southeast Asian countries next month to study the impact of the recent financial turmoil in the region.

The delegation, to be composed of officials from the economics, banking and financial sectors, as well as senior executives of major industry associations and business groups, will visit Thailand, Indonesia, Malaysia and the Philippines, the countries which have been hardest-hit by the recent region-wide financial fiasco.
The group is scheduled to leave on Jan. 11 and will return to Taipei around Jan. 20.

Thomas Yeh, director of the CEPD's Economic Research Department, said President Lee Teng-hui directed relevant government agencies at a high-level economic meeting on Dec. 19 to study the impact of the financial turbulence on the economic fundamentals of the four countries. Premier Vincent Siew then asked Chiang to organize a delegation to carry out the mission.

The four countries are major overseas investment destinations for Taiwan entrepreneurs and maintain close trade ties with Taiwan, Yeh said, adding that it is necessary for Taiwan to keep a close watch on the general economic climate in those countries.

Although South Korea is also being plagued by a financial crisis, it has not been included in Chiang's list of destinations. "This is because South Korea accounts for less than 5 percent of Taiwan's total foreign trade and the amount of mutual investment is also limited," Yeh noted.

DOC.HEADLINE: US DOLLAR UP

TEXT.P: The US dollar closed at 32.708 against the New Taiwan dollar Saturday at the Taipei foreign exchange market, up NT$0.047 from Friday's finish.
The greenback opened at the day's low of 32.691 and had a high of 32.760.
Interbank transactions totaled US$82 million.

DOC.HEADLINE: TAIWAN ECONOMY CONTINUES STEADY GROWTH

TEXT.P: Despite the recent Asian financial turmoil, Taiwan's economy continued to flash a safe "green light" in November, indicating that the domestic economy remains on the track of steady growth, the Council for Economic Planning and Development (CEPD) reported on Saturday.
It was the 13th straight month that the country's overall economic performance has received a "green" rating on the CEPD-designed five-color scale for stable growth.

Much to some observers' surprise, the composite index of overall economic performance received a score of 28 points in November, up two points from the September. The observers originally expected the score to drop because of fallout from the regional financial fiasco.

Thomas Yeh, director of the CEPD's Economic Research Department, attributed November's better-than-expected performance mainly to significant gains in new orders and export value as a result of the New Taiwan dollar's depreciation against the US dollar.

The CEPD uses a five-color rating system to measure the country's monthly economic performance. A red light means the economy is overheated; a yellow-red light indicates the economy is heating up; a green light reflects steady growth; a yellow-blue rating signals an economic slowdown; and a blue light represents an economic recession.

Ratings are determined according to nine major economic indicators: export value, new export orders, industrial production, manufacturing inventories, total employment outside the agricultural sector, money supply, stock prices, the check default rate and bank lending to the private sector. The minumum score for a healthy "green" rating is 23 points.

During the month of November, the nine indicators showed mixed performances. Three indicators -- new orders, export value and bank lending to the private sector showed marked improvement, driving up the overall performance score. The ratings for industrial output, stock prices and the check default rate declined, while the remaining three indicators remained at the same levels as the previous month.

Yeh said bank lending to the private sector has continued to increase for nearly six months, indicating that local enterprises' demand for capital has risen and herals a rebound in investment willingness.

Touching on Taiwan's economic prospects for the coming year, Yeh expressed cautious optimism, saying the economic performance for the first quarter of next year will at least receive a "green" rating.

Noting that next year's global trade will grow at a slower pace because of the recent Southeast Asian financial crisis and South Korea's economic woes, Yeh said Taiwan will rely on increases in public and private investment to bolster its economic gorwth in 1998. As long as the private investment can grow 14 percent as projected, he said, Taiwan will be able to maintain a 6.7 percent economic growth next year.

The results of a monthly survey of local manufacturers, conducted by the CEPD in October, echoed Yeh's optimistic forecast of Taiwan's economic outlook. A majority 84 percent of those surveyed predicted that the economy will either improve or remains at the current level for the next three months, while only 16 percent siad they expects the business climate to get worse in the coming months.
Yeh cautioned that Taiwan must devote more energy to expand exports to such emerging markets as East Europe and Latin America in order to sustain its economic growth.

Yeh pointed out that the recent Asian financial crisis is expected to cut demand in the Asian market and that South Korea would certainly lower its prices to promote exports and maintain its niches in the world market. As Asia accounts for more than 50 percent of Taiwan's total exports, Yeh said, the above-mentioned two factors would hinder Taiwan's export growth in the coming year.

Taiwan's exports to Asian coutnries rose a mere 2.2 percent in the first 11 months of this year due to the region-wide financial woes, and its exports to Japan, South Korea and Thailand even registered negative growth.
Yeh said Taiwan must step up efforts to boost sales to south Korea and Japan as well as to tap rapidly growing East European and Latin American markets in order to sustain its economic vitality.

DOC.HEADLINE: MAINLAND CHINA TO REFRAIN FROM BULLYING TAIWAN IN 1998

TEXT.P: Mainland China is discovering the pleasures of a better reputation, having behaved well over Hong Kong and pulled back from bullyboy tactics over Taiwan, a Canadian magazine said.

The Report on Business monthly, in its joint annual edition on global trends with The Economist Publications, predicted that Beijing, acutely aware of how it is viewed by the rest of the world, "will not throw that prize away in 1998."

The magazine pointed out that although preserving Hong Kong's stability will continue to be a high priority for mainland China, pursuing economic reform on the mainland itself "will be even more pressing" in the coming year.
That means mainland China has to tackle the real economic issue of reforming its state-run enterprises, the biggest shake-up of the state-owned industrial sector since the communist takeover in 1949.
As long as President Jiang Zemin can maintain an economic balance, "his position is likely to remain secure," according to the report.
In a profile of Jiang as one of the newsmakers in the spotlight, the Report on Business predicted Jiang's actions will differ greatly from those of his predecessors Mao Zedong and Deng Xiaoping.
To make his reforms stick, the report pointed out, Jiang desperately needs to attract more Western capital.

As mainland China is no longer needed as a counterweight to the now-defunct Soviet Union, Jiang will face "increasingly blatant Western demands for concessions" on issues of human rights and the sale of nuclear technology to Iran and Pakistan in exchange for favorable trading status, said the magazine.

DOC.HEADLINE: INDONESIAN PROVINCE EXPORTS SHRIMP TO TAIWAN

TEXT.P: Indonesia's Lampung province exported 12,786 tons of black tiger shrimp, worth US$151.5 million to six countries -- Japan, Taiwan, the US, Hong Kong, the United Kingdom and Australia -- from January through October, 1997, Antara reported on Thursday.
The province also exported 122 tons of leed shrimp, worth US$1.07 million, from January through October, 1997, down to 65 percent of the total volume compared to the same period of last year.
Japan is the biggest importer of shrimp from the province, followed by the US.
According to the Central Bureau of Statistics, Indonesia in 1996 exported 56 million tons of frozen shrimp and prawn worth US$650 million to Japan, and 6 million tons, worth US$76 million to the US.
Taiwan imported 1.9 million tons, worth US$11.16 million, during the same period.

DOC.HEADLINE: TAIWAN STOCK MARKET CLOSES LOWER

TEXT.P: Share prices closed 0.3 percent lower on the Taiwan Stock Exchange (TAIEX) on Saturday as late selling wiped out early gains amid uncertainty over the general financial situation in Asia in the coming year.

Stock experts said trading has dwindled steadily in recent days as the Year of Ox is running out and investors have become more conservative and wary. "Uncertainty about the domestic and international economic climate has dampened sentiment for making new stock purchases," said a market insider.
The TAIEX weighted price index lost 27.86 points to close at 8,104.64.

The market opened higher at 8,221.92 and rose steadily in early training. However, the rally halted around mid-session amid light trading. The index dropped to a low of 8,096.72 at one point, but managed to regain some grounds shortly before closing.
A total of 1.54 billion shares changed hands during the two-hour weekend trading session on a market turnover of NT$70.39 billion (US$2.17 billion).

Losers outnumbered gainers 221 to 190, with 62 stocks remaining unchanged. Six of the eight major categories suffered losses, with financial, plastics and chemical sectors registering the lagest losses.

DOC.HEADLINE: AUSTRALIA DEVELOPS NEW DRUG TO FIGHT `BIRD FLU' IN HONG KONG

TEXT.P: Australian scientists have developed a new drug capable of fighting the "bird flu" that has so far killed four people in Hong Kong.

Dr. Peter Colman, director of the Biomolecular Research Institute and a former scientist at the Commonwealth Scientific and Industrial Research Organization (CSIRO), said the new drug -- Zanamavir -- attacks different strains of the flu virus, including the new strain known as H5N1 which is currently plaguing Hong Kong.

"The new drug will hit the central region of the virus, stopping the spread of the virus," he told reporters on Wednesday. "We are cautiously optimistic (because) the drug has cleared major clinical hurdles and should be available towards the end of next year," he said.
Colman, who led the 12-member CSIRO team which had been working on the project for more than a decade, said conclusive clinical trials were being carried out in North America and Europe.
He said new pandemics of flu arise from major changes or mutations to which our immune system has little or no resistance.
The new influenza drug was developed by the CSIRO in collaboration with the Melbourne-based pharmaceutical company Biota, he said.

Mass-circulation newspaper The Australian on Friday quoted Biota chairman Dr. Hugh Niall as saying: "This is a major advance in the treatment of one of the world's important diseases. It will have great potential in the pharmaceutical market."

Reports said 13 people are known or suspected to have contracted "bird flu" in Hong Kong. Apart from the four who have died, two remain in critical condition, five are satisfactory and two have made a full recovery.
Hong Kong health authorities have suspended all imports of chickens from mainland China -- thought to be the source of the flu.

DOC.HEADLINE: SINGAPOREANS TO MOURN SILKAIR CRASH VICTIMS DEC. 30

TEXT.P: Singaporeans will hold a mass memorial service Dec. 30 to mourn as a nation for the 104 people who died in the SilkAir plane crash on Dec. 19.

The public condolence service, which will start at 6 p.m. at the Singapore Indoor Stadium, is being organized by a committee headed by former Singapore President Wee Kim Wee and made up of community leaders, the Inter-Religious Organization, SilkAir, Singapore Airlines and the media.
The move to hold the service was first announced Thursday by Singapore Prime Minister Goh Chok Tong after he toured the crisis management center in Changi Airport.

Friday marked exactly one week since the 10-month-old Boeing 737-300 crashed into the Musi River near Palembang, South Sumatra, Indonesia, less than an hour after taking off from Jakarta for Singapore.

All 104 people on board the ill-fated MI-185 flight, including 97 passengers, one of them from Taiwan, and seven crew members, died instantly in the mysterious crash. Only small body parts of the victims have so far been recovered, SilkAir confirmed.

Recovery operations are still continuing and Vice Admiral Rosihan Arsyad, commander of the Indonesian naval western fleet, who has been overseeing Indonesia's rescue operations, told reporters on Friday that naval divers had found parts of the black box's casing.

This gave hope that the flight data recorder and cabin voice recorder, which would give vital clues on the cause of the crash, might not have been swept away by the fast water-flow. "The black box is still out there and we would not stop our operations until we find it," he was quoted as saying.
The recovery mission also discovered a crater measuring 60 meters by 25 meters at the bottom of the river, believed to have been caused by the impact of the crash, reports from Palembang said.
On Saturday, rescuers will dredge the big hole with a giant clamshell excavator, weighing more than 40 tons and with 35-meter cables, reports said.

DOC.HEADLINE: AUSTRALIAN UNIVERSITIES TRYING TO LURE OVERSEAS STUDENTS

TEXT.P: The eight most prestigious universities in Australia have launched an ambitious promotional blitz in the Asia Pacific region to lure overseas students from Taiwan, Japan, South Korea, Indonesia, Malaysia, Singapore and elsewhere.

The eight universities -- University of Sydney, University of Melbourne, Monash University, University of New South Wales, Australian National University, University of Queensland, University of Adelaide and University of Western Australia -- are promoting themselves in major newspapers and magazines in the region, as the cream of Australian higher education, offering "quality academic programs and extensive student support."

Overseas students are also promised a "safe environment," a reference aimed at countering negative media publicity in several Asian countries following the comments of Independent Member of Parliament Pauline Hanson, who last year demanded that the government stop Asian immigration to Australia.

In their campaign, the universities also stress that the depreciation of the Australian dollar against the US dollar has made Australia a much more affordable place for study compared to the United States and Britain, which are the country's major rivals in this area.

The number of overseas students enrolled in Australian schools and universities and private colleges has increased dramatically, rising to more than 143,000 last year from about 8,000 in the mid-1980s.
Nearly 85 percent of these students come from Asia.

DOC.HEADLINE: S'PORE ECONOMIC GROWTH FORECAST FOR 1998 CUT TO 4.4 PERCENT

TEXT.P: Many economists and analysts in Singapore have reduced their forecast of Singapore's economic growth for 1998 down to an average of 4.4 percent -- well below the official forecast of 5 to 7 percent, which the Singapore government is reviewing.
The latest 1998 consensus forecast is down from 5.3 percent in a previous survey just a few weeks ago.

Ten of those polled now think that the Singapore economy will grow at less than the government's forecast. Of these, the most bullish was J.P. Morgan with 4.7 percent, while Vickers Ballas was the most pessimistic with 1.8 percent, according to The Straits Times.
Seven others said they were in the process of revising their numbers downwards, implying that the average growth forecast for next year could dip further in the next few weeks.

Most economists and analysts here were becoming more bearish. Key factors for their sentiments were the longer than expected saga of the regional financial turmoil, concerns over the scope and depth of the global electronics industry's recovery, the slowdown in the local financial sector and rising interest rates in Singapore.

Other dampening factors were the probable slowdown in the world's major economies, by as much as one percentage point, due to the Asian financial crisis; cutbacks in domestic spending arising from the plunge in asset prices; and reduced tourist arrivals, which will aggravate the already sluggish retail and real estate sectors here.

Analysts also said that weak overseas demand for goods from Singapore would affect its manufacturing output. They noted that Singapore's exports could also become less price competitive relative to other Asian countries whose currencies had depreciated more against the US dollar.

Singapore's official 1998 economic growth forecast is currently 5 to 7 percent. But Trade and Industry Minister Lee Yock Suan said recently that the government was reviewing its forecast to take into account the financial crisis in South Korea.
He had noted then that the ongoing regional financial crisis was bound to have some impact on the Singapore economy, although it was difficult to say how big the impact would be.

Despite a less rosy outlook for Singapore's economy next year, however, sentiment among economists and analysts here remains upbeat for this year, with their recent growth forecasts averaging around 7.1 percent.

DOC.HEADLINE: TIME NOT RIPE FOR TAIWAN BANKS TO OPEN BRANCHES ON MAINLAND

TEXT.P: The question of allowing Taiwan banks to open branches in mainland China should be dealt with carefully, Finance Minister Paul Chiu said Saturday.

Speaking at a year-end press conference, Chiu said Taiwan investors are bringing more money to the mainland for investment than they send back to Taiwan. This phenomenon deserves special care, he said, adding that the question of whether allowing Taiwan banks to set up branches on the mainland should therefore be dealt with carefully.
This question is related to the development of cross-strait relations and the implementation of the Guidelines for National Unification, and therefore should be dealt with flexibly, he added.
In an answer to a question about the establishment of offshore banking units (OBU), Chiu said the question of whether Taiwan banks can set up more than two OBUs in Taiwan is now under consideration.

Meanwhile, Lu Ying-tung, chairman of the Securities and Exchange Commission of the Ministry of Finance, said the ceiling of foreign investment in Taiwan's stock market will be raised from 25 to 30 percent next month. He did not elaborate. (by Ed Hsieh)

DOC.HEADLINE: PLA TRYING TO DEVELOP CAPABILITY FOR COMPUTER-VIRUS WARFARE

TEXT.P: The People's Liberation Army (PLA) of mainland China is trying to develop its capability for computer-virus warfare, according to information from Beijing.

Two divisions of the Shengyang Military Region held the first exercise of computer-virus warfare of the PLA on Oct. 10. The exercise was observed by many electronics experts from various military units.

The information from Beijing pointed out that the PLA's electronics equipment was highlighted in a series of articles carried by the Liberation Army newspaper just before the 15th Congress of the Chinese Communist Party opened in mid-September.
High-ranking military officers from various military regions have also attended several seminars on high technology since the beginning of this year.
These activities indicate that the PLA has made the development of its capability in waging electronics warfare a priority, the information from Beijing pointed out.

DOC.HEADLINE: LIEN CHAN TO ATTEND INAUGURATION OF HONDURAN PRESIDENT

TEXT.P: Vice President Lien Chan of the Republic of China confirmed on Sunday that he will lead a delegation to Honduras in January to attend the inauguration of Honduran President Carlos Flores.
Lien, however, refused to disclose whether he will travel to other countries in the region after his visit to Honduras.

It was previously expected that ROC President Lee Teng-hui would attend Flores' inauguration in Honduras. After that plan was canceled, Lee decided to delegate Lien to represent him at the inauguration ceremony, slated for late January.
President-elect Flores of Honduras' ruling Liberal Party is currently speaker of Congress. He won that country's presidential election held on Dec. 1.

Honduras and the ROC have maintained close and friendly relations for several decades. President Lee visited Honduras in September during his four-nation Latin American visit, which took him to Panama, Honduras and El Salvador in Central America as well as to Paraguay in South America.

DOC.HEADLINE: LOW STRESS, CLEAN AIR HELP QUEBECERS LIVE LONGER

TEXT.P: Low-stress lifestyle, clean air and simple living are cited to explain why a small Quebec town has more residents than elsewhere who make it to the "Century Club."

Usually, about one in 10,000 Canadians can expect to live to age 100. The town of St. Narcisse, Quebec, has defied those odds. The farming community of only 2,000 population is home to six people who are 100 years or older, according to figures compiled by Health Canada.
Local residents attribute the record to their low-stress lifestyle, plus the clean air and simple living.
Statistics Canada reports that the average life span has increased by five years in the past quarter-century. The average Canadian male now lives to 76, the average female to 81.

DOC.HEADLINE: CLOUD GATE DANCE THEATER TO PERFORM IN CALIFORNIA

TEXT.P: Cloud Gate Dance Theater of Taiwan Republic of China will present the United States premiere of Artistic Director Lin Hwai-min's "Songs of the Wanderers" at the Cerritos Center for the Performing Arts on Feb. 18-21.
"Songs of the Wanderers" is a dance spectacle of beautiful pictures.
Lin drew inspiration from the wealth of religious practices found in Asia.
"Song of the Wanderers" premiered at the Chinese Dance Festival in Hong Kong in November 1995.
Cloud Gate Dance Theater is a dance company in Taiwan. There are 24 dancers in the company.

DOC.HEADLINE: SILKAIR CONFIRMS FLIGHT DATA RECORDER FOUND

TEXT.P: The Civil Aviation Authority of Singapore (CAAS) and SilkAir officials said late Sunday afternoon they could confirm Indonesian Transportation Minister Haryanto Dhanutirto's report that the flight data recorder of the crashed SilkAir flight MI-185 has been found.
No further information was available at that time, they said in a joint statement.

Reports from Palembang, Indonesia, said Haryanto told a press conference Sunday that the flight data recorder, popularly known as the "black box," was recovered that morning by naval divers from the muddy riverbed of the Musi River, 35 miles north of Palembang, where the plane crashed on Dec. 19.

But, another "black box," the cabin voice recorder, which records conversations between the pilot and co-pilot in the cabin and between the pilot and air traffic controllers at airports, has not been found yet.
The recovered flight data recorded had already been sent to the United States for decoding, the reports said. That process normally takes about two to three months, aviation officials said.

DOC.HEADLINE: US PLANS CRACKDOWN ON VIOLATIONS OF TRADE AGREEMENT

TEXT.P: The United States plans to crack down on violations of the more than 200 trade agreements signed in the past five years and will mobilize new resources to open the mainland Chinese market, according to reports from World Trade Organization (WTO) Saturday.

With the US trade deficit climbing to new heights, David Aaron, US undersecretary of commerce for international trade, describes himself as less concerned about imports but determined to overcome barriers blocking US exports, the WTO report said.

"If you look at the major economies -- Japan, China and some of the big emerging markets -- our market share is going down," Aaron was quoted as saying. "In some cases it's significant; others, marginal."

Mainland China is of particular concern. "It's clear that the Japanese and Europeans are getting through those trade barriers better than we are," he was quoted as saying. "We have to find out why that's so, and what we can do about it."

DOC.HEADLINE: DAILIES RAP QUEBEC MOVE AGAINST CHINATOWN SIGNS

TEXT.P: Two Canadian newspapers have fired critical salvos at Quebec's "tongue troopers" for trying to commit "Chinese sign torture" in Montreal's Chinatown.

In an editorial Friday, The Ottawa Citizen lashed out against Quebec's "testy ethnics" who were at it again this week, making hay out of the intrepid and noble initiatives of so-called tongue troopers to put Chinese characters in their place.

The issue this time was oversize Chinese lettering on signs in the Chinatown of Canada's second largest city, which has the bad luck of being Quebec nationalists' holy town for keeping their language "pure."

For generations, the Citizen pointed out, the Chinese community in Montreal has had the temerity to flaunt its ethnicity, "but recently the troopers have been in a take-no-prisoners mood." They have been demanding that the Chinese shopowners mount new signs to comply with Quebec's language law -- an expensive proposition for small-business owners, the daily noted.

DOC.HEADLINE: SINGAPOREANS URGED NOT TO LOSE CONFIDENCE IN ECONOMY

TEXT.P: Singaporeans and foreigners must not lose confidence in Singapore's economy and government, because once it is shaken, it takes a very long time to recover, Singapore's Deputy Prime Minister Lee Hsien Loong said Sunday night.
Speaking at a grassroots function, he warned, "The most important thing for us is to maintain this confidence which takes years to build up, but if shaken, can be destroyed in a few days.
"All it will take are a few reckless policies, a few foolish speeches, a few riots and demonstrations, and it will take a long time to recover, even with International Monetary Fund help."
Lee, who will take over concurrently as chairman of the Monetary Authority of Singapore (MAS) from Thursday, singled out Indonesia as one country facing a loss of confidence.
"If they don't like it, then in one day the rupiah can fall by as much as 15 percent," he said.

And that, he added, was just the start of the problem. The investors might take the money out of the country, convert it into US dollars or yen and the exchange rate would suffer even more, he warned.
"And it is a contagious problem. As the situation gets worse, even those who had confidence in the country initially will follow those moving out of the economy, to protect themselves," he said.
"And it is not just foreigners who make these calculations, but also the local companies and the citizens.
"If they lose confidence, then it is very hard to restore it, even with the help of the IMF."
He stressed that any loss of confidence would lead to a whole host of other economic problems.
Initially, inflation would set in and the people's purchasing power would be eroded. Then, if the government borrowed heavily to defend the exchange rate, the interest rate would be pushed up.

Companies which had borrowed heavily from the banks, might then be unable to repay their loans, forcing banks into financial difficulty, and then the country would be "really in a deep hole," he said.
Singapore, however, had been spared the worse -- partly because it was lucky and partly because it had followed sound economic policies which had not shaken investors' confidence, he said.
He noted that when the ongoing economic turmoil began, foreign newspapers had written many articles about the region's problems, but "Singapore did not appear on their map of troubled nations."
Instead, now there were articles about how Singapore had done the right thing, how it had avoided the brunt of the economic turmoil and how it stood to gain when the region eventually recovered.

Complementing the government for having adopted the right economic policies, he said that economic growth would be affected by the regional currency crisis, but not severely, and continued sound policies would help retain confidence.

DOC.HEADLINE: CEPD ANALYZES TAIWAN'S SUCCESSFUL ESCAPE FROM FINANCIAL STORM

TEXT.P: Although the destructive regionwide financial turmoil has left scars upon most Asian countries, Taiwan's economy, while unable to entirely escape the assault, is relatively unscathed, much like Switzerland during and after World War Two.

Officials with the Council for Economic Planning and Development (CEPD) on Sunday reasoned that Taiwan's healthy economic fundamentals and a well-established monetary structure have put up a solid front in fending off the financial onslaught against Asian economies.

Citing a pair of articles appearing in the mass-circulation Financial Times of London and the Asian Wall Street Journal, the officials noted that Taiwan has been described as the "Switzerland of the Orient." This is due to its emergence as one of the world's most insulated economies now that East Asia has lost its reputation as a "crisis-free haven" for global investors after financial storm clouds gathered over in Thailand in July.

The CEPD said Taiwan's economic development remains on a stable track, adding that it has outpaced other Asian competitors after efficiently solving financial problems arising from the depreciation of the New Taiwan dollar and a declining stock market.
As of Christmas Day, the New Taiwan dollar had depreciated 14 percent against the US currency since the end of June.

However, according to CEPD statistics, that figure pales in comparison with the registered 57.7 percent drop of the Indonesian rupiah, 51.6 percent devaluation of the South Korean won, 45 percent loss of the Thailand baht, the 34 percent fall of the Malaysian dollar and the 34 percent depreciation of the Philippine peso over the same six-month period.

Analyzing the reasons for Taiwan's ability to weather the regional financial storm, the CEPD officials said that in addition to sound economic fundamentals, including abundant foreign exchange reserves and surpluses in current account balance, the government's earlier financial reforms also played an important role in helping the country survive the crisis.

Those reforms, which encouraged unhealthy local financial institutions to merge with larger banking conglomerates and introduced an insurance system for banks to strengthen the nation's financial infrastructure, were undertaken in 1996 after mainland China launched a series of provocative military threats against Taiwan that caused a severe economic recession on the island.

Meanwhile, the fact that small and medium enterprises play a leading role in guiding Taiwan's economic development also provides the nation maneuverability in dealing with financial fluctuations, the CEPD analysts said.

They added that Taiwan's efforts in promoting liberalization and democratization also proved beneficial in managing the financial and economic challenges, saying that political openness in the society had helped ease problems between the government and banks arising from overextended loans, which are considered a major culprit in sparking the recent financial crises in other countries.

DOC.HEADLINE: HSU HAS NO INTENTION TO SEEK RE-ELECTION AS DPP CHAIRMAN

TEXT.P: Hsu Hsin-liang, chairman of the Democratic Progressive Party (DPP), announced on Sunday that he will not seek re-election to the party's top position.

Hsu, who returned from a trip to South Korea and Japan on Saturday morning, also made it clear in a press conference that he will not be a candidate in the legislative elections slated for late next year.

Hsu stressed his decision not to seek re-election has nothing to do with the possibility that Taipei Mayor Chen Shui-bian might seek the DPP chairmanship. He said the decision had been made prior to the local elections for city mayors and country magistrates held on Nov. 29.

Being a party leader means heavy responsibilities, be not necessarily power, Hsu said, adding that if Chen can succeed him in leading the DPP, it would be advantageous for the popular Taipei mayor as well as for the party.

Hsu pointed out that the DPP's overwhelming victory in November's local elections has successfully put an end to one-party rule by the Kuomintang (KMT) in Taiwan. As the DPP's power has developed onto a par with that of the KMT, Hsu claimed that his first-stage "historical mission" has been achieved.

Hsu went on to say that his decision not to seek re-election as DPP chairman or to run for public office does not imply that he will retreat from the political arena. Instead, he asserted that his second-stage mission is to lead Taiwan to face the challenges of the 21st century.

Hsu said that Taiwan can expect numerous challenges in the coming century, including the question of its relations with mainland China, and that he will make his own contributions in leading the island to play a crucial role in the international community.

Hsu, however, refused to confirm whether he will contest the presidential election in the year 2000, saying only that he will not give up his idealism easily. In the 1996 election, Hsu failed to win his party's nomination to run for office as Taiwan's first popularly elected president.

Hsu said that during the remainder of his tenure as DPP chairman, he will continue his efforts to transform the party, adding that he would promote further discussions to determine the DPP's stance on various policy matters.

Hsu also thanked the public for its support of the DPP. He said the landslide victory in the elections for city mayors and county chiefs meant a great deal to him personally, as he had resigned from the DPP top position four years ago to take responsibility for a setback suffered by the party in local elections at that time.

DOC.HEADLINE: TAIPEI MAYOR CONSIDERS RUNNING FOR TOP DPP POSITION

TEXT.P: Taipei Mayor Chen Shui-bian on Sunday said he will seriously consider a bid to become the head of the Democratic Progressive Party (DPP).

Chen, who returned from a three-day trip to Japan on Saturday night, said that he will weigh the opinions of grassroots DPP members, party heavyweights and other civic leaders before making any decision.
Chen, however, also stressed his intention to seek re-election as Taipei mayor, saying that he is determined to achieve that goal.

Asked to comment upon reports that DPP Chairman Hsu Hsin-liang will not seek re-election to his post, Chen said he believes Hsu's decision was made after careful consideration and should be respected.
Chen said that whether he will seek to become the next DPP chairman will not be influenced by Hsu's decision.

Chen is regarded as a powerful potential challenger for the top DPP position, but he has previously refrained from showing any interest in the post, saying that he hasn't even entertained the possibility.
During his just-concluded visit to Japan, Chen for the first time hinted at his interest in the DPP chairmanship and said that he will consider his options.

DOC.HEADLINE: TAIWAN TO GROW MORE TREES

TEXT.P: The Council of Agriculture of the Executive Yuan will continue to carry out its plan to grow more trees and take better care of trees in Taiwan to comply with the Kyoto Protocol for the reduction of carbon dioxide in the atmosphere, an official of the council said here Sunday.

The council is implementing the 1992 Taiwan Forestry Program, which encourages the planting of trees wherever possible by the general public, and limits the cutting of natural forests and the production of lumber, he said.

Under the plan, 60.24 percent of the slopeland on Taiwan will be covered by trees by the year 2001, compared with the current 58.53 percent. Taiwan has 2,100,000 hectares of forests now. By the end of 2000 the program will increase 61,000 hectares of forests, he added. The new forests will be able to reduce 8,270,000 tons of carbon dioxide per year, he added. (by Ed Hsieh)

DOC.HEADLINE: SURVEY SHOWS STUNNING FIGURE OF ABORTION CASES OF TEENAGERS

TEXT.P: Every gynecologist in Taiwan has on the average conducted 17 abortion operations for teenage girls in the past year, according to a survey made public on Sunday by the China Medical Association.

Ninety-four percent of the 238 gynecologists that sent back the questionnaires to the association said that they have been asked for treatment by pregnant teenagers. There are 2,176 gynecologists in Taiwan.

According to the 103 gynecologists that answered the questions relating to abortion cases, a total of 1,775 abortion operations were conducted by them between October 1996 and September 1997. That means every one of them conducted 17 such operations in the past year.

The survey also saw a drastic increase in the number of abortion cases in August, September and October. The abortion cases in the three months accounted for half of the total abortion operations for junior high school girls.

DOC.HEADLINE: CETRA EYES INDIA, POLAND

TEXT.P: The semi-official China External Trade Development Council (CETRA) has aimed at India and Poland as 1998 investment target for Taiwan businesses wishing to expand into overseas.

The economic reforms adopted by India and Poland in recent years have gained worldwide recognition, helping the two countries transform into attractive investment targets for foreign investors, CETRA said.

CETRA said it plans to organize a trade-promotion delegation to India in the fourth quarter of next year in a bid to seek investment opportunities for Taiwan's textile-related sector and other traditional industries.

CETRA also said it schedules to inaugurate a trade office -- the Taiwan World Trade Center -- in Warsaw on Sept. 1, 1998 as a stronghold to explore the potential East European market, adding that an interim office will be first opened on Jan. 1 in Warsaw to provide services to Taiwan businesses there before the official inauguration of the trade office.
