DOC.HEADLINE: 1997 'PEOPLE IN THE NEWS' SELECTED BY VARSITY STUDENTS

TEXT.P: Television hostess and entertainer Pai Ping-ping topped the list of the People in the News in the World Chinese Communities in 1997, chosen by college and university students in Taiwan, which was published Sunday.

Pai Ping-ping received the largest number of ballots cast by the varsity students in a poll for her cheerful role on the TV screen and her bravery as a mother in the wake of a heart-rending tragedy involving the kidnap and murder of her 17-year-old daughter, Pai Hsiao-yen.

The kidnap/murder of Pai Hsiao-yen, one of the most high-profile crimes in Taiwan in 1997, developed into an islandwide episode from April to November because of the cunning and trickery of Pai's kidnappers.

Steven Chu, a Chinese-American physicist who won this year's Nobel Prize in Physics together with two other scientists, was selected the No. 2 figure in the People in the News list for his outstanding achievement in his research field, and his being a source of pride for all Chinese in the world.

Following was Taiwan Governor James Soong, who has attracted high attention during the past year as a "very special" politician who is the first popularly elected Taiwan governor as well as the last such administrator because of the island's changing political map.
Despite Soong being the last governor of Taiwan, his popularity has continued to soar islandwide, according to the China Cultural Congress, which conducted the poll.

Number four on the list of 1997 newsmakers was President Lee Teng-hui, the first popularly elected president of the Republic of China, who is described as a statesman that is both highly popular and highly controversial.

Hou You-yi, Taipei's chief criminal police, grabbed the fifth place in the poll by demonstrating commendable courage during a hostage crisis masterminded by Pai Hsiao-yen's kidnapper Chen Chin-hsing. Chen took the entire family of South Africa's military attache in Taiwan as hostage during a 24-hour standoff with police.

Ma Ying-jeou, former justice minister who left the political spotlight for two years, took sixth place. Ma, who has a clean image and is particularly popular among women voters and professional and white-collar workers, is considered the ruling Kuomintang's only trump card capable of overcoming the Democratic Progressive Party's powerful influence in next year's Taipei mayoral election.

Following Ma to round out the top 10 list of 1997 People in the News were Taipei Mayor Chen Shui-bian, Premier Vincent Siew, Lawyer Hsieh Chang-ting and former Taipei City Information Director Lo Wen-chia, in that order.

Communist Chinese President Jiang Zemin, Hong Kong's first administrator after the July 1 turnover Tung Chee-hwa, leading mainland Chinese dissident Wei Jingsheng, ROC Education Minister Wu Jin and Ang Lee, renowned Taiwanese-American movie director, also made the 1997 popularity list, ranking between 11th and 20th places.

DOC.HEADLINE: IDF COMPLETES AIR-TO-GROUND COMBAT PREPAREDNESS

TEXT.P: The locally built indigenous defense fighters (IDFs) have completed air-to-ground combat preparedness and will replace aging F-5E jetfighters as the mainstay of the Republic of China's air defense fleet, military sources said on Monday.
"The completion of IDF airborne interception and air-to-ground combat preparedness has contributed much to fortifying our air defenses," said an official with the Air Force General Headquarters.

The official, who spoke on condition of anonymity, said the IDFs had also undergone anti-ship combat training. As the Chungshan Institute for Science and Technology-developed air-launched Hsiungfeng II missiles were originally intended for use by AT-3 trainers, they were not fully compatible with the demands of the IDFs.
"The Air Force has asked the institute to extend the length of the Hsiungfeng II missiles in order to increase their shooting range and meet IDF requirements," the official said.

Commenting on reports that F5-E fighters had succeeded in shooting down IDFs on many occasions during simulated war games, the official said this was partly caused by inexperience on the part of pilots in operating IDFs, which remain relatively new to Air Force pilots.

The Air Force has organized a hypothetical enemy squadron to assist IDFs in airborne combat training, the official said, adding that Air Force pilots are seeking to determine the most suitable "airspace" for the new aircraft in order to enhance survivability during engagement.

The official further said the Air Force has formed several F-16 and Mirage 2000-5 squadrons, but they are still undergoing intensive training and cannot perform airborne interception or combat missions.

As part of its second-generation arsenal buildup plan, the ROC has ordered 60 French-made Mirage 2000-5s and 150 American-made F-16 jetfighters. Some of those planes have already been shipped to Taiwan.

Meanwhile, Army Commander-in-Chief Gen. Tang Yao-ming said over the weekend that the Army will phase out all of its aging 250-kilogram jeeps over the next six years in order to ensure traffic safety for officers and enlisted men.
Tang said relevant Army units are working on a new jeep purchase plan. "We have yet to decide on the model we'll use in the future."
He further said the Army will also gradually replace its aging medium- and heavy-duty trucks with locally produced models in the coming years.
The military began to implement a four-year troop reduction plan in July, under which the Republic of China will cut the number of armed forces personnel from 453,000 to 400,000 by the year 2001.
The government said 400,000 troops are sufficient because the country's military policy now gives top priority to safeguarding the security of Taiwan instead of seeking to reconquer mainland China.

DOC.HEADLINE: BEIJING TO LOWER TARIFFS AGAIN NEXT YEAR

TEXT.P: Beijing will reduce its tariffs again in 1998, with high-technology products and advanced equipment at the core of its rate cuts, a prestigious mainland Chinese magazine has indicated.

Mainland China has lowered its tariff rates seven times since 1992, with an accumulated reduction up to 60 percent, involving almost 5,000 items. The average tariff rate has been lowered from 43.2 percent before 1992 to the current 17 percent, the latest issue of Beijing-based Outlook magazine revealed, adding that the average tariff rate is anticipated to drop to 10 percent by the year 2005.

Mainland business circles by and large welcome the tariff-cutting moves, believing they will spark consumer demand and in turn will provide a lively injection to the recessed economy, the magazine pointed out.

But on the other hand, Outlook stressed, the cost advantage enjoyed by mainland products will be weakened due to price-cutting on imports. Therefore, the mainland's state-owned enterprises, which are already under considerable pressure, will suffer more as a result of reduced tariffs, the magazine commented.

DOC.HEADLINE: COA ACTS TO PREVENT SPREAD OF BIRD FLU

TEXT.P: The Cabinet-level Council of Agriculture (COA) on Monday ordered health authorities to closely monitor all chicken farms in Taiwan in order to prevent the outbreak of bird flu on this island.

The COA issued the order in a special meeting in the morning after the Hong Kong government on Sunday ordered the slaughter of up to 1.3 million chickens in farms and markets throughout the territory in an effort to prevent the spread of the deadly disease, which has killed four people since its outbreak in early December.

COA Vice Chairman Lee Chien-chuan said that the provincial-level Taiwan Research Institute for Animal Health has been examining serum collected from islandwide chicken farms and that no virus has been found to date, adding that any chickens found infected with the virus will be immediately wiped out by health authorities.
Lee said the COA has prepared a manual with which trained health officials will use in promoting their mission to combat bird flu at farms islandwide within the next two weeks.

In addition, the COA also has dispatched officials to Hong Kong to gain a first-hand understanding of the Hong Kong government's measures to stop the bug, Lee noted. He added that a Japanese expert had arrived in Taiwan earlier in the day at the invitation of the COA to help local health officials examine chicken serum and virus.
As Taiwan maintains close exchanges with Hong Kong, Lee said the bird flu, which is caused by the H5N1 virus, could easily be passed on to Taiwan by infected poultry.

DOC.HEADLINE: MND PLANNING TO INCREASE NUMBER OF GI JANES

TEXT.P: While the number of men in uniform is being gradually reduced under a policy of developing elite fighting units, the number of female officers and GIs will be increased, a spokesman for the Ministry of National Defense (MND) said on Monday.

In a report at the Legislative Yuan Committee on National Defense, Chen Chin-sheng, an MND vice minister in charge of personnel affairs, said the MND has recently revised the military recruitment policy in an effort to raise the number of women to between 5 percent and 8 percent of the entire ROC armed forces.
The armed forces began to receive women in officers' and soldiers' training camps in 1991, and opened the doors of military academies to female students in 1994, said Chen.

However, those initiatives were insufficient to recruit enough females into the military, Chen noted, adding that by the end of this year, the number of female officers and enlisted women totals only about 6,000, constituting only a small percentage of the overall ROC armed forces.
The MND is also considering recruiting women into combat units on the provision that the GI Janes are equal to their male counterparts in physical capacity and military skills.

Another major factor prompting the MND to consider opening combat units to women is that most women in uniform, about 85 percent, are reluctant to be transferred or shifted to other positions, which has caused an overconcentration of female personnel in certain job areas, according to Chen.

In addition, Chen said that under the newly revised military recruitment policy, there will be female generals in the ROC armed forces before long, although currently there is no woman whose academic background and military record are sufficient enough to qualify her to become a general.

Meanwhile, the revised regulations have also removed age restrictions on servicewomen, allowing them to serve as long as their male counterparts, Chen added. In the past, servicewomen were asked to retire when they reached the age of 45.

During the report at the Legislative Yuan, two female officers -- Navy Lt. Huang Yi-fang and Air Force pilot Mi Shu-chen -- were also present for the legislators' interpellation. Both of them testified that they have no problems in coping with military careers as women, and that they enjoy the same opportunities as do men.

DOC.HEADLINE: OUTGOING SOUTH AFRICAN DIPLOMAT BIDS FAREWELL TO POLICE OFFICER

TEXT.P: Outgoing South African Military Attache Col. McGill Alexander paid a visit to Hou You-yi, director of the Taipei City Police Headquarters' criminal investigation department, on Monday to express his gratitude for Hou's assistance to his family.

Alexander praised Hou for his bravery in rescuing him and his family members, who were held hostage by Taiwan's most-wanted fugitive, Chen Chin-hsing, on Nov. 19. Chen was one of the three masterminds in the kidnap-murder of Pai Hsiao-yen, the 17-year-old daughter of popular entertainer Pai Ping-ping, in April.

During the 24-hour standoff between Chen and police at the Alexander residence in Taipei's suburban Tienmu district, Hou, who has long been reputed for his integrity and sense of justice, was the only police officer with whom Chen was willing to engage.

It was Hou who entered Alexander's home to escort out the diplomat and his 22-year-old daughter after they were accidentally shot by Chen during the standoff. Alexander sustained a wound to his right leg, while his daughter was struck in the wrist and hip. Alexander's wife and youngest daughter as well as a baby boy in the family's care were released unhurt before Chen surrendered to police.

Alexander credited the peaceful settlement of the incident to Hou's calm, wit and courage. "Hou's performance was beyond the public's expectations of a bureaucrat or civil servant," the South African diplomat said.

For his part, Hou said rescuing hostages was part of his duty. "I just did what I was obliged to do. You and your family do not need to care too much about my role in resolving the crisis," Hou told Alexander.

Hou also lauded Alexander and his family for their calm and rationality in facing the ordeal. "You and your family have set a model for crisis response by crime victims," he said, adding that their business-as-usual performance had helped police accurately assess Chen's situation and his frame of mind.
Alexander and his family will leave for home on Wednesday as South Africa will switch diplomatic recognition from Taipei to Beijing at the end of this year.

Hou said that although formal diplomatic ties between the Republic of China and South Africa will soon be terminated, substantive relations can still be strengthened for mutual benefit. "I hope you'll help reinforce friendship and civilian exchanges between our two countries in years ahead," he added.
Alexander presented a plaque to Hou to express his appreciation, while Hou gave a necktie to Alexander as a souvenir.

DOC.HEADLINE: TRADITIONAL CHINESE MEDICINE DEALERS WANT LEGAL PRESCRIPTION RIGHTS

TEXT.P: Nearly 10,000 owners and operators of traditional Chinese medicine stores around the island took it to the streets on Monday to demand legitimate prescription rights and the establishment of a national university of traditional Chinese medicine.

The protesters, who marched from Chiang Kai-shek Memorial Hall to the Legislative Yuan, argued that although the government rules that medical prescription is a profession requiring certification and approval by a national examination, there is no department of traditional Chinese medicine in any university in Taiwan, and no national university of traditional Chinese medicine to provide professional training for potential traditional Chinese medicine pharmacists.

In addition, they said, the government has ceased related national examinations for traditional Chinese medicine dealers since 1970, depriving them of rights and relevant privileges, including the right to prescribe.
Currently, only doctors of traditional Chinese medicine or stores selling traditional Chinese medicines which have at least one pharmacist on their payrolls are legally allowed to prescribe.

At the Legislative Yuan, Democratic Progressive Party Legislator Chiu Chuei-chen suggested that the government revise the Pharmaceuticals Law to enable owners and operators of traditional Chinese medicine stores who have engaged in the trade during the last five years to receive a certain period of pharmaceutical-related training to allow them the right of prescription.

Meanwhile, Chan Chi-hsien, director general of the cabinet-level Department of Health, asserted that medical prescription requires professional expertise and education and that he does not think the rash awarding of prescription rights to traditional Chinese medicine dealers is beneficial to the long-term interests of consumers.

DOC.HEADLINE: LEE HOPES 1998 WILL BE BETTER FOR SINGAPORE

TEXT.P: Singapore Deputy Prime Minister Lee Hsien Loong hopes 1998 will be better than 1997 for Singapore, despite the economic problems in the region which will spill over into the new year.
Speaking to reporters after a scholarship awards ceremony on Sunday, he said, the Chinese always say next year will be better.
"We certainly hope so, but the regional problems are not going to go away in a hurry. That is not necessarily a bad thing because it will remind Singaporeans of what sort of environment we live in.
"It will help us pull together and have the right instincts, not just cruise, but to fly straight and level for some time to come."
Lee also hoped that the events of 1997 had taught Singaporeans some important lessons.
"It has been a very eventful year. Many things have happened -- events which I think we will remember for a very long time," he said.
One of these events was the impact on Singapore-Malaysia relations after Senior Minister Lee Kuan Yew made his comments on Johor being "notorious for shootings, muggings and car-jackings."
The remarks sparked an onslaught of condemnations in Malaysia against Singapore, which continued even after Lee apologized publicly for what he had said in a court document.
The episode showed how delicate relations with neighbors could be.
The deputy prime minister also cited the haze from uncontrollable wildfires as an event that was "not just a one-off problem but shows how interrelated the regional communities are."
He singled out the regional currency crisis as bearing the most important lessons for Singapore, even though Singaporeans did not feel the impact directly.
The currency meltdown, he said, showed once again "how vulnerable we are, and how fragile prosperity is."
"People think that prosperity is solid and lasts forever, but actually things can go wrong really quickly. And even when it goes wrong elsewhere it can also affect us," he said.
He also cited the crash of SilkAir flight MI-185 as one of this year's sobering events.
Singaporeans would remember these events for a long time, he said. (Conrad Lu)

DOC.HEADLINE: LATIN AMERICA ENDING 1997 IN GOOD HEALTH

TEXT.P: The economies of Latin American and Caribbean countries are ending 1997 with their best results in 30 years, with growth near 5.5 percent and 11 percent inflation, according to reports of the Geneva-based World Trade Organization (WTO) on Sunday.
Though turbulence in Asia will almost certainly lower growth by several percentage points next year, the region as a whole is now much better equipped to deal with external shocks.

"Latin America went up a steep learning curve in the 1980s; in the 1990s its policymakers have shown they can react quickly and effectively. No one was sitting around watching as the impact of the Asian situation rolled toward them," Gert Rosenthal, executive secretary of the UN Economic Commission for Latin America and the Caribbean (ECLAC), was quoted by the WTO report as saying.
The most evident effect of market turbulence would be a drop in the flow of foreign capital to Latin America and deteriorating terms of trade.

This year, the region sucked in US$73.5 billion in foreign investment, accumulating reserves of US$13 billion. But unlike the early 1990s, most was in direct investment, bonds and medium-term bank loans. Foreign direct investment was an unprecedented US$44 billion; Brazil, Mexico, Venezuela and the Dominican Republic each attracted record sums.
The regional current account deteriorated sharply. For 1997, the deficit was US$60 billion, an average 3 percent of gross domestic product, up from US$35 billion last year.
The main factor, the WTO report noted, was the return to the usual pattern of trade, with imports growing faster at 18 percent, than exports, up 11 percent.

Export growth was well above the 7 percent growth forecast for world trade. But Latin America's overall trade deficit soared from US$8 billion last year to US$28 billion for 1997, with "spectacular" increases in the deficits of Brazil, Mexico and Argentina.
Brazil was the only one of the three with a deficit in the current account above 4 percent, but seven other countries, including Chile and Peru, were also running deficits in that region.

DOC.HEADLINE: AUSTRALIAN FIRMS FACE HIGHER COSTS WITH EXODUS OF JAPANESE LENDERS

TEXT.P: Major companies in Australia are facing the prospects of higher funding costs in 1998 as they gear up to refinance A$12 billion in corporate debt because of the exodus of Japanese lenders from the country, according to a survey by the Australian Financial Review released on Monday.

The survey, compiled by respected Hong Kong-based debt markets newsletter Basis Point, shows banks are predicting that loan margins on syndicated debt facilities will rise for the first time in four years because of the impact of the exodus of Japanese lenders from the Australian market.
The Japanese lenders, which have traditionally bailed out Australian companies, are pulling out from Australia due to their own financial problems at home.
The prospect of higher funding costs will create a double bind for Australian companies already bracing for slower economic growth as a result of the Asian financial crisis.
For some Australian companies, the recent depreciation of the Australian dollar against the US currency will cause additional difficulties, according to the survey.
The Australian dollar has now dropped to less than 66 US cents from 75 US cents in the past few months.
The Australian corporate borrowers are preparing to refinance about A$12 billion of debt next year, much of it denominated in the US dollar, according to the survey.

DOC.HEADLINE: TAIWAN COMPETING WITH EUROPE, US TO BUY DISTRESSED ASIAN COMPANIES

TEXT.P: Big corporations from Taiwan are expected to compete with those from Europe and the United States in bargain hunting for distressed Asian firms in the wake of the regional economic crisis, according to the Australian Financial Review.

In a dispatch from Taipei, Bruce Cheesman reported that European and US investors face tough competition from Taiwan in the hunt for bargains in Southeast Asia, Japan and Korea in the wake of the currency meltdown.

"Asia's sale of the century is perfect timing for a government seeking to boost its regional investment. Taiwan's 'go south' policy, aimed at forcing local companies to break their growing dependence on China, is a key economic goal for 1998 following fears in Taipei of a devaluation in China's currency," Australia's leading financial daily reported.

The daily reported that Taiwan firms have a head start in Southeast Asia over US and European companies and potential rivals from Singapore and Hong Kong because Taiwan is already the second biggest investor in Association of Southeast Asian Nations member countries, behind Japan, with a total investment of about US$28 billion.
In another article, the daily reported US and European companies are queuing in a buying spree for distressed firms in Japan, Korea, and Southeast Asia.

The daily reported Australian companies are not joining the rush because it would be very costly for them to buy these distressed companies after the Australian currency depreciated sharply against the US dollar.

DOC.HEADLINE: SEVERAL THEORIES ON WHAT CAUSED SILKAIR MI-185 CRASH

TEXT.P: Ten days after the SilkAir flight MI-185 crash near Palembang, Indonesia, the cause is still a mystery.
There have been conflicting reports which have given rise to several theories on what happened moments before the crash on the afternoon of Dec. 19.
Here are a few:
-- The plane was heading back towards Palembang before it crashed.
Indonesian officials said eyewitnesses on the ground saw it turning back. They also believed that a change in course had been picked up by radar. But no evidence was found to support this.
SilkAir said the plane was on course when it disappeared from the radar screens.
-- A catastrophic mechanical problem or engine failure:
Chief Indonesian investigator Prof. Oetarjo Diran said the evidence showed this could have been the cause.
But SilkAir officials said nothing, even sabotage, could be ruled out.

Brig. Gen. Ryamizard, the chief-of-staff of the South Sumatra Military Command, who is overseeing search operations, believes the pilot sensed something was wrong and decided to turn back to land in Palembang.
Interviews with villagers who witnessed the crash backed this up, he said.
But last week, Singapore Airlines (SIA) Chairman S. Dhanabalan said the Indonesian authorities had denied that there was any evidence to conclude there was mechanical failure.
-- An explosion or explosions:

None of the officials has ruled out this possibility, because of the state of the mangled aircraft pieces found, and the fact that not only has no intact body been found, but most body parts picked up were little more than fragments.
A source quoted a Singapore team member as saying, "It looked like it had rained flesh and debris."
Villagers near the crash site also said they had heard explosions.

And the three senior pilots interviewed said that a bomb, rather than engine problems, would be a more likely cause of such explosions. They believe sabotage is involved although Indonesian officials have ruled out this possibility.
The pilots pointed out that, even if one jet engine explodes or drops off, an aircraft can still fly on the other engine and land.
And if a whole wing drops off or if the plane is ripped into two, the aircraft goes down fast but, even then, a pilot can still send out a distress signal.
-- A hijacking:
A hijacker could also have prevented a distress signal being sent out, according to some official reports.
In the midst of the speculation, SIA senior public affairs manager Rick Clements said that nothing could be ascertained until the investigation into the crash was completed.
This could take weeks, and possibly months, he said.
Technically, the 10-month-old Boeing 737-300 jet was in top condition. It had passed a thorough check only 10 days earlier, SilkAir said.
Its after-flight reports by pilots showed it had an enviable record, with no blemishes.
The Singapore authorities have also described the crash as puzzling -- as there was no distress signal, no bad weather or mountainous terrain.
There is also another discrepancy between reports from Indonesia and Singapore.
At least one report has said that at 5:13 p.m., just before flight MI-185 lost radio contact, it had asked Jakarta for permission to switch to Singapore air traffic control.
But Singapore authorities said the aircraft was still under Indonesian air traffic control when it disappeared from their radar.
The key could lie in the black boxes. But only the flight data recorder, which tracks such things as altitude, speed and direction, has been found.
Still missing is the other box, the cockpit voice recorder which records radio transmissions and sounds in the cockpit, such as pilots' voices and engine noises.

DOC.HEADLINE: EXPERTS SAY MAINLAND CHINA WILL BE AFFECTED BY ASIAN FINANCIAL STORM
DOC.DATELINE: Beijing, Dec. 29 (CNA) (By Wang Hsin-chung & Eva Chen)

TEXT.P: Mainland China will eventually be affected by the financial turmoil that is sweeping East Asia, and the country's exports will suffer most, a recent survey has disclosed.

The survey sponsored by the China Information Press and conducted in Shanghai, Shenzhen, Tianjin, Beijing and some other major cities in mainland China, showed that up to 55 percent of the 100 stock market commentators questioned believe the mainland will eventually be affected by the East Asian monetary crisis -- 10 percent more than those who think the country will remain unaffected.
The main points of the survey are as follows:

* Fifty-four percent of the interviewees believe the mainland's economic condition in 1998 will be somewhat the same as this year; 34 percent think it will improve, while 12 percent think it will be worse.
* Fifty-five percent believe the monetary circulation in 1998 will be similar to that of this year, with 42 percent holding that it will be looser and 3 percent predicting it will be tighter.

* Fifty-nine percent forecast the mainland's stock markets in 1998 will be slow and bullish; 19 percent think it will be slow and bearish; while 5 percent and 1 percent, respectively, think it will be a fast bear or bull market.

* The majority of the respondents said they think business performance will be the same this year, with a slightly smaller number forecasting better performance and only a few predicting it will be worse.
* Seventy percent speculated that the difference in performance levels of mainland enterprises with securities on the stock markets will be wider than in 1997.

DOC.HEADLINE: BEIJING TO PREVENT DISSIDENTS FROM STIRRING UP TURMOIL

TEXT.P: Beijing has called on officials of all regions in mainland China to be wary of dissidents as millions of workers in state-owned enterprises are expected to lose their jobs in the new year, the Hong Kong Standard reported Monday.

The report quoted mainland Chinese sources as saying that officials attending the national conference on law enforcement over the weekend wanted to prevent dissidents from stirring up turmoil among the laid-off workers and in society.
Mainland Chinese President Jiang Zemin said in the conference that "Stability is the prerequisite for reform and development."

Senior provincial officials have been urged to prevent protests by laid-off workers from becoming some sort of organized movement, the report said. They have also been urged to pay close attention to possible illegal activities of non-authorized trade unions.
Beijing feared that the now occasional demonstrations by laid-off workers might become more politically oriented, it added.

DOC.HEADLINE: US DOLLAR DOWN

TEXT.P: The US dollar dropped NT$0.022 against the New Taiwan dollar on the Taipei foreign exchange market on Monday, finishing at NT$32.686.
The greenback opened at 32.725, and was traded between 32.68 and 32.769.
Interbank US dollar trading reached US$292 million.

DOC.HEADLINE: SHARE PRICES DOWN ON TAIEX

TEXT.P: Share prices finished 0.3 percent lower on the local stock market on Monday due to thin trading ahead of the New Year holiday.
Dealers said most investors stayed on the sidelines during the approach of the New Year, and this low atmosphere has resulted in one of the lowest turnovers of this year.
The Taiwan Stock Exchange (TAIEX) weighted price index slid 27.99 points to close at 8,076.65, while the bourse opened at 8,111.77.
The market experienced a high of 8,113.23 and a low of 8,073.69.

A total of 1.32 billion shares changed hands on a market turnover of NT$57.58 billion (US$1.77 billion), the lowest amount since Jan. 29, when a record low of NT$52.2 billion (US$1.6 billion) was registered.
Losers outnumbered gainers 221 to 190, with 62 shares unchanged.

Both papermaking and financial issues posted the largest drop -- 0.9 percent -- and textile stocks followed with a 0.6 percent decline, plastic and chemical shares with a 0.4 percent fall, cement stocks with a modest 0.3 percent loss, and electrical engineering issues with a slight 0.2 percent drop.
Foodstuffs and construction shares both registered 0.6 percent gains.

The 10 companies with the largest turnovers were: Ever Fortune; Mosel Vitelic; Yue Loong; Pao Shiang; Picvue Electronics; China Steel; AGV Products; Pacific Construction; Master Home Furniture; and Yue Phui Enterprise.

DOC.HEADLINE: ROC MULLING MEASURES TO COPE WITH CHANGES IN SOUTH KOREA

TEXT.P: Premier Vincent Siew called a closed-door high-level meeting on Monday to discuss measures to cope with the changing political and economic climate in South Korea.

It was the first time senior government officials had met to mull the future of relations between the Republic of China and South Korea since veteran opposition leader Kim Dae-jung was elected the next South Korean president on Dec. 19.

Taipei-Seoul relations have remained at a low ebb since the two countries cut diplomatic ties in August 1992. Kim is the first opposition leader to win a South Korean presidential election in more than 40 years, and South Korea is being plagued by a financial crisis, prompting Siew to direct relevant government agencies to forecast possible developments in future Taipei-Seoul relations and to hammer out effective measures to protect Taiwan from being hit by fallout from South Korea's current financial and economic woes.

Monday's meeting was attended by Ding Mou-shih, secretary general of the National Security Council, who once served as the ROC ambassador to South Korea; Ying Chung-wen, director of the National Security Bureau; Minister of Foreign Affairs Jason Hu; Minister of Transportation and Communications Tsay Jaw-yang; Peng Tsoy-kuei, chairman of the Council of Agriculture; Hu Chin-piao, chairman of the Atomic Energy Council; and finance and economics officials.

During the meeting, the participants exchanged views on a range of issues, including bilateral governmental and trade ties, as well as air links, a Taiwan Power Co. (Taipower) plan to ship low-grade nuclear waste to North Korea for permanent disposal, and other related topics.

Finance and economics officials are worried that the drastic depreciation of the Korean won will further widen Taiwan's trade deficit with South Korea, which reached US$2.39 billion in the first 11 months of this year. The officials fret that the current trade imbalance between the two countries may worsen to become structural or permanent, in much the same way as the Taiwan-Japan trade deficit has become over the years.

The Board of Foreign Trade and the semi-official China External Trade Development Council have drafted comprehensive plans to help local business people promote sales to South Korea. But trade promoters say these measures may not be enough to bring about favorable results, as the new South Korean president will not assume office until next February, and many Korean people will be reluctant to enter into new business contracts until the new government has been sworn in.

The ROC cut direct air links with South Korea shortly after Seoul switched diplomatic recognition from Taipei to Beijing in August, 1992. South Korea has repeatedly called for the resumption of such links, but the ROC government has made it clear that direct air links will be resumed only on an equal and reciprocal basis. "South Korea must respect our national dignity and sovereignty," a Foreign Ministry official stressed.

Meanwhile, observers have said the prospects for Taipower shipping its low-grade nuclear waste to North Korea for permanent disposal have become gloomier following Kim Dae-jung's election. Kim is known to have strongly opposed the Taipower-Pyongyang deal. Another hurdle is that cash-hungry North Korea cannot afford to build a special dump to accommodate the radioactive waste.

Premier Siew has ordered the Atomic Energy Council and state-owned Taipower to strictly abide by international regulations in handling the issue. Before Taipower confirms that North Korea has built the specialized nuclear dump, the council is unlikely to begin screening the cross-border nuclear waste shipment application.

DOC.HEADLINE: TEENAGER CRIME RATE DOWN IN TAIPEI

TEXT.P: Efforts by the Taipei City government to protect teenagers have been effective, as can be seen from statistics released by the Taipei City Police Headquarters which show that the number of teenage criminals prosecuted for violent crimes fell to 520 in the February-November period of this year, down 153 from the same period of 1996.

The tallies show that the number of teenagers prosecuted for burglary also declined to 1,395 in the same period, down 678 from a year ago, while the number of prosecutions for drug use remained at 485, the same level as the ten-month period of last year.

The 14 police precincts in Taipei launched a collective campaign in February to persuade teenagers to stay away from late-night attractions such as pubs, tea houses, bowling allies and pool halls, conducting late-night raids and detaining youths at police stations.

In the ten-month period, a total of 22,405 youths were detained by police authorities in this manner, 14,828 of whom were found to be innocent, 7,493 of whom were recorded as being delinquents and 84 of whom were fined or sent to local district youth courts for violating the Statute for the Maintenance of Social Order.

In addition, a total of 584 business owners were prosecuted or investigated for running unlicensed businesses or providing illegal services targeted towards youths, while an additional 67 shops were punished by having their water and electricity supplies cut in the 10-month campaign, the tallies indicate.

DOC.HEADLINE: TAIWAN TO HELP SE ASIAN COUNTRIES OVERCOME DIFFICULTIES

TEXT.P: A Taiwan trade mission, led by Chiang Pin-kung, chairman of the Council for Economic Planning and Development (CEPD), will visit four Southeast Asian countries next month.

The trade mission will study the business and investment climates in Thailand, Malaysia, the Philippines, and Indonesia. They will find out feasible ways to increase Taiwan investment in the four countries so as to help them overcome financial difficulties, Chiang said, adding that the financial conditions of neighboring countries may affect the economic development in Taiwan.
The trade mission, which will return to Taipei on Jan. 20, will consist of economic officials and business leaders.
Japan will also try to help Southeast Asian countries tide over their difficulties, he added. (by Ed Hsieh)

DOC.HEADLINE: AIG RAISES FUND TO INVEST IN ASIA

TEXT.P: The American International Group (AIG), the largest US insurer, has raised US$1.53 billion for an infrastructure fund to invest in Asia, according to reports of the Geneva-based World Trade Organization (WTO) Monday.

The announcement follows increased efforts by AIG, which has extensive international operations, to sustain its activities in Malaysia, where Prime Minister Mahathir Mohamad is resisting demands by trade negotiators that foreign insurers be allowed to keep all their investments in the country.
The announcement appears to signal that the company, based in New York but with its roots in mainland China, wants to emphasize its support for Asian economies.

AIG is sponsoring the fund, while GIC Infrastructure, an investment affiliate of the government of Singapore, will be the principal investor. It will be managed by a Bermuda partnership owned by subsidiaries of AIG and GIC.

AIG said a total of 17 institutional investors had made commitments to the fund. "There is continuing appreciation that the future growth of the Asian economies will depend to a significant degree on infrastructure development," Hank Greenberg, chairman of AIG, was quoted as saying.
He added that the "substantial" commitment reaffirmed the confidence of AIG and other institutional investors in Asia's long-term growth prospects, the WTO report added.

The fund will be put into equity and convertible debt infrastructure investments, with more than half of the fund invested in mainland China and India. The balance will go to some of the countries that have been worst hit by the recent currency turmoil, including Indonesia, Malaysia and Pakistan.

AIG launched a similar Asian infrastructure fund three years ago that raised US$1.1 billion and is now nearly fully invested. Many of the investors in the first fund are repeating their commitment in the new venture.

The Emerging Markets Partnership, an asset manager based in Washington, will be the main investment adviser. It is chaired by Moeen Qureshi, a former prime minister of Pakistan, while the managing partner is Donald Roth, a former treasurer of the World Bank and chairman of Merrill Lynch Europe.

DOC.HEADLINE: MULTI-FUNCTION IC CARDS TO PREVAIL BY 1999

TEXT.P: A three-in-one card that will combine the functions of the national identification card, driver's license and health insurance card will replace the three separate items by 1999.

The Task Force on Information Development under the Executive Yuan has assigned the responsibility for convening the meetings on the design and functions of the cards, which will feature a tiny integrated circuit, to the Research, Development and Evaluation Commission.
Present at the meetings will be representatives from the Ministry of the Interior, Department of Health, National Health Insurance Bureau and Institute for Information Industry.
The task force also said in its report to the Executive Yuan that the card's functions might be expanded so it could be used for cash withdrawals.
The first IC cards are scheduled to make their debut next year for a trial period of six months to one year. If they work well, the multi-function cards should be prevalent around the island by 1999.

The task force said the reason for switching to IC cards is to take advantage of new information and communications technology and that the new cards will also help the establishment of computerized government services, thus promoting efficiency.

DOC.HEADLINE: PRESIDENT LEE MEETS WITH AUSTRIAN FRIEND OF ROC

TEXT.P: President Lee Teng-hui met here on Monday with Gunther Winkler, the first president of the Vienna-based Institute of Chinese Culture, extending a warm welcome to the Austrian visitor.
Lee said during the meeting that Winkler is one of the Republic of China's best friends, noting that the professor has been helping promote Taipei-Vienna relations for more than a decade.
The expert in Chinese affair has made frequent visits to Taiwan since the 1980s. Winkler said he is very impressed with the ROC's development in many fields such as politics and the economy.

Winkler said that since the ROC has always been able to settle the problems that it -- like every other nation in the world -- has been beset with, there's every reason to believe that the island will be able to cope with the challenges it will encounter in the coming century.
Lee told the Austrian scholar that the ROC's existence and development in the international community are at all times his primary concerns as a leader of state.

"The ROC is a sovereign country, a fact that should not be neglected by the international community," Lee said, adding that, as a part of this community, "the ROC is also willing to contribute its experiences in development."

DOC.HEADLINE: KMT KEEPS OPPOSITION GUESSING ON ENDING TOWNSHIP ELECTIONS

TEXT.P: The ruling Kuomintang's Secretary-General John Chang dodged an opposition leader's request Monday to stand by a bipartisan agreement to discontinue elections for the heads of Taiwan's townships.

In a courtesy call at the headquarters of the Democratic Progressive Party (DPP), the newly-appointed KMT secretary-general told DPP Chairman Hsu Hsin-liang that the KMT will "respect public opinion and act in accordance with legal due process."

Hsu had asked Chang to reconfirm the KMT's commitment to carry out a bipartisan decision at the National Development Conference to reduce the number of elections by having the heads of townships -- which exist below the county level -- appointed rather than elected.

The KMT, after being trounced by the DPP in the mayoral and county magistrate elections in November, has hinted it would backpedal on freezing the low-level elections, which it has traditionally dominated.
Arguing that ending those local elections is not necessarily to the KMT's disadvantage, Hsu urged the ruling party to "stick to the commitment and carry it out."
Chang said the proposed freeze is a controversial matter among local politicians and the public at large and that the KMT will respect public opinion and act in accordance with the law.
The two, however, agreed to cooperate to revise the existing rules with the purpose of upgrading the legal status of county governments and enriching county coffers.

DOC.HEADLINE: TAIWAN TO PERSUADE BAYER TO PRESERVE ITS TAIWAN INVESTMENT PLAN

TEXT.P: The government is making more moves to urge the chemical giant Bayer AG not to abandon its planned large investment project in Taiwan.

P.K. Chiang, chairman of the Council for Economic Planning and Development (CEPD), said Monday that Premier Vincent Siew is sending a personal appeal to Bayer headquarters in Germany, expressing his warm welcome to the toluene di-isocyanate (TDI) plant Bayer had planned to establish in central Taiwan's Taichung County before suspending the project due to opposition from area residents and environmentalists.

Chiang made the remarks in a press conference here, noting that CEPD Vice Chairman Y.S. Liu plans to visit Taichung Magistrate Liao Yung-lai, hoping that the county government will send a delegation to Germany to learn of Bayer's environmental protection record.

Chiang said that according to figures from the Ministry of Economic Affairs the Bayer plant would be the fourth largest investment project on the island, and that it would be not only a capital-concentrated investment but also one that would transfer a variety of advanced technologies and expertise in the chemical industry to Taiwan.

Bayer is one of only five companies in the world capable of producing TDI. The chemical giant had planned to invest NT$50 billion (US$1.5 billion) to build a TDI plant in the vicinity of Taichung Harbor as a part of its effort to make inroads into Asian markets.

The CEPD leader told the press that the premier has in his letter expressed his regret over Bayer's decision to suspend its Taiwan investment and the government's determination that the plan will be realized on the island.

DOC.HEADLINE: FOREIGN TRIPS FOR GOV'T LEADERS NEXT YEAR

TEXT.P: President Lee Teng-hui and other government leaders are expected to visit a number of foreign countries in an effort to increase the nation's international presence, according to an informed government source.

The source said that Lee is expected to pay a state visit to the Republic of China's diplomatic allies in Africa, especially those in western Africa. Senegal, one of the countries in the region maintaining official ties with the ROC, has extended an invitation to the president.
Meanwhile, Lee is expected to name either Vice President Lien Chan or Premier Vincent Siew to lead a delegation to the inauguration on Jan. 27 of Honduran President Carlos Roberto Flores.
Foreign Affairs Minister Jason Hu, on the other hand, is scheduled to visit Senegal, where he will preside over a conference in mid-January of ROC diplomats stationed in Africa.
Hu may also visit such ROC allies as Burkina Faso, the Gambia and Guinea Bissau during his eight-day trip.

In related news, a close aide to the vice president, who asked not to be named, said that there may be changes in Lien's private visit to Singapore during the New Year holidays now that the plan has been exposed prematurely by local media.
Local papers and TV stations reported that Lien plans to make a trip to the city-state and meet ranking Singaporean officials on matters of mutual concern.
Lee and Lien visited Singapore in March 1989 and December 1993, respectively.

Singapore Prime Minster Goh Chok Tong met Premier Siew Nov. 28 during his transit at Chiang Kai-shek Intentional Airport after attending the summit meeting of the Asian Pacific Economic Cooperation forum in Vancouver.

DOC.HEADLINE: 1998 ECONOMIC GROWTH FOR TAIWAN SHOULD BE ADJUSTED DOWNWARD

TEXT.P: Government agency and private sector projections for Taiwan's 1998 economic growth are too optimistic, two university professors said in a seminar on Monday.

Chengchi University Professor Yin Nai-ping and Taiwan University Professor Liu Yi-lu said that influenced by the worldwide financial shakeup, Taiwan's economic growth in 1998 will be one or two percentage points lower than government projections.

At the seminar, titled "Prospects for the Taiwan Economy Amid Asian Financial Turmoil" and sponsored by the Chung-Hua Institution for Economic Research, Yin said that the government's Council for Economic Planning and Development predicted that the Taiwan economy will grow by 6.72 percent next year, while the Taiwan Institute of Economic Research predicted 6.46 percent growth and the Chung-Hua Institution for Economic Research predicted 6.37 percent growth.

Forecasts for Taiwan's economy made by foreign organizations, however, are not as optimistic, he said, citing that the United Nations predicted 5.25 percent growth and the Organization for Economic Cooperation and Development predicted 5.6 percent growth.

Yin said that with its sound fundamentals, Taiwan has the ability to weather the regional financial storm. However, Taiwan's exports, which account for 80 percent of its Gross National Product, will be buffeted by the worldwide economic slowdown. Yin gave this as the reason for his evaluation that economic growth predictions for Taiwan should be adjusted one or two percentage points downward for next year.

Liu said that most international economic research organizations have adjusted downward their economic growth forecasts for countries around the world. As Taiwan's economy cannot survive the global economic sluggishness undamaged, the island will post at best a 5 percent economic growth for next year, he said.

DOC.HEADLINE: VICE PRESIDENT LIEN TO VISIT SINGAPORE

TEXT.P: Vice President Lien Chan will pay a four-day private visit to Singapore during the New Year holidays, the Ministry of Foreign Affairs announced on Tuesday.
Foreign Ministry spokesman Roy Wu said that Lien and his wife will leave for Singapore on Thursday for a vacation there and are scheduled to return to Taipei on Jan. 4.

Foreign Minister Jason Hu said that his ministry has helped arrange Lien's trip, but that no special itinerary or meetings have been arranged. "Don't make too many political connotations out of Lien's trip," Hu said.
Asked if the vice president will proceed to other countries following his visit to Singapore, Hu replied that no such plan is under consideration for the time being.
Local papers reported on Tuesday that while staying in Singapore, Lien is to meet with the country's Senior Minister Lee Kuan Yew to exchange views on matters of mutual concern.

The last time Lien visited Singapore was in January 1994 when the then premier took a vacation in Malaysia and Singapore. During his visit to Singapore, Lien met with Singaporean Prime Minister Goh Chok Tong and Senior Minister Lee Kuan Yew.
Lien is also expected to lead a delegation to Honduras in late January to attend the inauguration of Honduran President Carlos Flores.

DOC.HEADLINE: AVIATION RIGHTS NO BARGAINING CHIP WITH SEOUL

TEXT.P: Foreign Minister Jason Hu said on Tuesday that the Republic of China government will not use the resumption of aviation exchanges as a bargaining chip with South Korea in future negotiations.

Hu said the basic stance of the ROC government toward the issue is to protect national interests and that it is hard to assess the matter at present, as the two countries have not yet even started negotiations.
Hu said the Ministry of Transportation and Communications will cooperate closely with the Ministry of Foreign Affairs on the issue.

The ROC suspended a bilateral aviation agreement with South Korea on Sept. 15, 1992, banning South Korean airlines from landing in or flying over Taiwan after that country decided to switch diplomatic recognition from Taipei to Beijing.

Meanwhile, Chen Ruey-long, director-general of the Board of Foreign Trade (BOFT), said on Monday that the BOFT is planning to organize a trade promotion delegation to visit South Korea in a bid to boost bilateral trade and commerce ties and help Taiwan businesses to explore the South Korean market.

The current financial crisis plaguing South Korea, Chen said, has also had a serious impact on Taiwan export and import traders. The sharp depreciation of the South Korean won has caused a shortage of foreign currencies among South Korean companies, imposing greater business risks for Taiwan enterprises, he added.

Chen also revealed that he may lead a high-ranking trade delegation to visit South Korea shortly after newly elected President Kim Dae Jung's inauguration, slated for late February, to discuss a new framework on future bilateral economic relations.
