DOC.HEADLINE: LAW ENFORCEMENT AUTHORITIES LAUNCH NEW ANTI-CRIME CRACKDOWN

TEXT.P: Law enforcement authorities launched a new nationwide crackdown on crime on Tuesday as part of the government's efforts to stem the crime rate and improve social order in the run-up to the Jan. 24 elections for township chiefs and city and county councilors.

It was the ninth round of the ongoing anti-crime campaign since mid-1996 aimed at creating a safe, crime-free living environment. This was also the first large-scale crackdown since the nation's courts reclaimed the right to detain criminal suspects.
Minister of Justice Liao Cheng-hao said he hopes local judges will prudently handle applications by prosecutors to detain criminal suspects so as not to impede the anti-crime operations.

Liao said although returning the right of detention to the courts may present increased difficulties for anti-crime operations, Liao encouraged prosecutors and police officers not to be daunted by such hurdles.

The minister said the latest crackdown indicates that the anti-crime drive is comprehensive and incessant. "There is no deadline, no bottom line and no ceiling for our anti-crime campaign," Liao said, adding that as long as law enforcement officers have collected sufficient evidence, they can take actions in accordance with the law.
As of Tuesday noon, three gang leaders targeted for arrest under "Operation Chihping" and nine others targeted by "Operation Lightning Speed" had been arrested.
Liao said he is convinced that relevant judges will make the right decision on whether any of them should be kept in custody or even sent to the offshore Green Island jail for detention.
The minister said Tuesday's crackdown is also aimed at deterring gangsters from trying to use money or violence to influence the Jan. 24 grassroots elections.
Liao said the last islandwide crackdown on Nov. 14 had helped make the Nov. 29 mayoral and county magistrate elections the least violent balloting in the past decade.

Liao further said the government is determined to eradicate organized crime and wipe out illegal firearms. Any person who turns in his or her illegal firearms before Feb. 25 will be exempted from any penalties under an amnesty.

Under the newly revised firearms control law, people who illegally possess guns, knives or ammunition will receive far harsher sentences than before. Liao urged those who illegally possess firearms to voluntarily turn in their weapons to law enforcement authorities before the deadline. "Firearms are a priority target of the current anti-crime campaign," he added.

Liao further said the Ministry of Justice is likely to direct law enforcement units to launch another nationwide crackdown on violent or organized crime and illegal firearms before the Lunar New Year holiday in late January.

Among the arrested gangsters were Cheng Jen-kun, head of the Shihwufen Gang; Chen Chung-hsien, head of the Ta-An Club under the Providence Gang; and Lai Tze-tung, head of the Wenlin Gang. All were accused of having engaged in firearms trafficking, extortion, intimidation and other criminal activities.
A total of 4,000 police officers, 400 military police officers and 100 Bureau of Investigation agents joined Tuesday's anti-crime campaign.

DOC.HEADLINE: TAIPEI EVALUATES NEW EFFECTS ON CROSS STRAITS RELATIONSHIP

TEXT.P: Beijing's "big nation" maneuvering is putting heavy pressure on Taipei's pragmatic diplomacy, said Sheu Ke-sheng, vice chairman and spokesman of the Taipei-based Mainland Affairs Council (MAC), on Monday.
Sheu added that Taipei is evaluating the potential effect of this situation upon future talks across the Taiwan Strait.

As witnessed by the impending establishment of formal diplomatic relations between mainland China and South Africa, set for Jan. 1, 1998, Beijing is using its strategic advantages to mount an offensive against Taiwan, including attempts to constrict Taipei's presence in the international community and forcing Taipei to accept the "one China" principle, Sheu remarked.
Sheu also noted that this situation is worthy of close attention, and that Taipei will assess its effect upon political negotiations between the two sides when such talks get under way.

Pointing out that Taipei recognizes the Beijing government has been a political entity since 1949, Sheu expressed hope that mainland officials will treat Taiwan pragmatically and understand that Taipei's actions in the international community do not arise out of hostility toward Beijing.

DOC.HEADLINE: TAIWAN NOT JUST ASIAN PAPER TIGER

TEXT.P: An investment newsletter said in its latest issue that while almost all Asian tigers are in turmoil, one is still kicking.

That is Taiwan, whose economy remains bullish, Strategic Investment said in its December 1997 issue. In fact, it noted, prospects in Taiwan look so good that the government has had to revise its GDP growth forecasts for 1997 upward for the third time last month.
Taiwan said its growth will reach 6.72 percent for this year, and slow only slightly to 6.4 percent in 1998, the monthly newsletter added.
Continued domestic consumer demand, coupled with growing industrial output and wise management of the economy means that "this Asian Tiger isn't just a paper one," Strategic Investment said.

In another report, the monthly pointed out that the most uncorrupt and economically free countries are the ones least affected by the regional crisis, with Singapore being the best model, followed by Hong Kong.
Taiwan is most likely to move toward the Singapore model and flourish, Dr. Jack Wheeler said in a "Behind the Lines" report for the newsletter.

Meanwhile, The Globe and Mail reported Monday that Taiwan's index of leading economic indicators posted its biggest gain this year in November, suggesting the economy will keep chugging along even as other Asian nations teeter on the edge of recession.
Taiwan's high-tech industry and US$83 billion in foreign reserves are helping insulate the island from the region's financial crisis, the major daily said.

DOC.HEADLINE: ASIAN FINANCIAL CRISIS

TEXT.P: US economists are split on how the current Asian financial crisis will affect the US economy in 1998, according to The Wall Street Journal on Monday.

Optimists, who prevail among mainstream economists, argue that Asia's problems are a well-timed piece of bad news, a much needed brake-tapping to America's economic juggernaut. By cooling demand for US exports, they say, the Asian turmoil reduces the odds of a new burst of inflation or a recession induced by a Federal Reserve interest-rate boost. Much like the 1987 stock market crash, it could turn out to be a pause that refreshes.

But, the Journal said in a frontpage story, a growing minority of economists -- and, privately, some US government officials -- are beginning to worry that the rosy forecasts rely too heavily on old equations that miss new realities of the global marketplace. The economy is acting in ways never before seen by economists trained in postwar America.

The very fact that inflation is falling despite an unemployment rate below 5 percent suggests that the old models are old hat. So does the fact that the bursting of a real estate bubble in Bangkok, Thailand, was able to trigger a chain reaction that temporarily shook the US stock market.

The upbeat consensus forecast certainly has its logic, the Journal said. Despite the rhetoric about globalization, the US still has a highly insular economy. Just 11 percent of gross domestic product comes from exports, and less than 10 percent of exports go to the most troubled Asian nations.

While overseas business is bound to slip a bit as Asian growth slows, demand at home -- from both consumer spending and corporate investment -- remains surprisingly strong. The consensus: Inflation-adjusted GDP growth next year will be a healthy 2.5 percent, even though held down about half a percentage point, mostly by lost export sales.
Absent the Asian crisis, these forecasters contend, the Federal Reserve would have raised interest rates and probably caused the same slowing of the economy anyway.

But the pessimists note that even in normal times, forecasters are lousy at predicting economic turning points and are likely to do even worse when the old rules are in flux. Moreover, forecasting models tend to be built on assumptions that people behave rationally, but actual events are often driven by waves of irrationality. And such waves worry the pessimists.

Still-unknown pieces of the story: how long the crisis will last and how far it will spread among developing countries. It raced from Thailand to Indonesia to South Korea. And nervous speculation has, in recent weeks, circled Hong Kong, Taiwan, China, Russia, Ukraine and Brazil.

A year ago, the Journal said, investors in the United States and elsewhere viewed "emerging" markets as a hot place to invest. Now, many are getting out, causing currencies to fall and interest rates to rise in those markets.

Another shock, such as a Korean default, could cause more currency drops and rate increases, pushing up capital costs and slowing growth in much of the developing world. The US economy would be much more powerfully affected because developing countries together absorb about one-fourth of American exports.

Worsening matters still more could be a turn toward protectionism and isolationism in the United States and economists predict that a flood of cheaper Asian imports will widen the US trade deficit by more than a third over the next couple of years to as much as US$300 billion.

DOC.HEADLINE: STUDY OF ENDANGERED SOCOTRA CORMORANT

TEXT.P: A team of bird experts from the National Commission for Wildlife Conservation and Development of Saudi Arabia (NCWCE) and animal research groups are currently undertaking a field study of the bird species Socotra cormorant which are threatened with extinction.

A spokesman for the commission said the study group, which also includes experts from the Taif-based National Wildlife Research Center and the Jubail Wildlife Sanctuary , will try to find out more about the current state of the rare birds and evolve a mechanism for protecting them.
The team will collect information about the reproduction habits of the birds and identify factors that pose a threat to them.

He said the Socotra cormorants, which were quite common in the Gulf of Aden, the Arabian Sea and the Arabian Gulf, in recent years became very rare, and only nine pairs were registered in the world. He said as a result of their sudden disappearance, the birds were put on the red list of endangered species.

The spokesman recalled that the commission, in collaboration with other national organizations and European wildlife protection groups, did much to save this type of bird from the dangers of Gulf oil pollution in the past. The birds were rehabilitated and were released. On these occasions, about 120 pairs of the birds were counted on Kreen Island in the northern Arabian Gulf.

DOC.HEADLINE: S'PORE MOURNS SILKAIR VICTIMS TODAY

TEXT.P: The memorial service for the 104 victims of SilkAir Flight MI-185, which crashed near Palembang, Indonesia, on Dec. 19, will be held at the Singapore Indoor Stadium at 6:00 p.m. Tuesday.

Among those attending are the next-of-kin and relatives of the passengers and crew onboard the ill-fated aircraft, ambassadors of the foreign nationals who were onboard the flight, members of Parliament whose constituents were the victims, Singapore's acting President Tan Soo Khoon, Prime Minister Goh Chok Tong, Senior Minister Lee Kuan Yew and his wife, and Deputy Prime Minister Lee Hsien Loong.
The service is open to all members of the public.
Some 10,000 people from all walks of life are expected to participate in the public memorial.

Former President Wong Kim Wee, who chairs the organizing committee for the memorial service, said Monday that the national event is one way that Singaporeans can show that they want to share the sorrow and grief.
"I have always believed that as a people we should always feel and act as one big, happy family," he said.
"And, in this case, instead of 'happy' we are all devastated by the tragedy," he added.

DOC.HEADLINE: THAI PROSTITUTE TESTED HIV POSITIVE

TEXT.P: A prostitute from Thailand who was arrested in Yungho, Taipei County, earlier this month, has been tested HIV positive, police reported on Tuesday.

Samphoa Anchacee, 26, arrived in Taipei on Oct. 7 with a tourist visa for the stated purpose of visiting relatives in Taiwan, police said, adding that Anchacee began to engage in prostitution on Dec. 1.
She provided sexual services to more than 60 local men before she was nabbed at a hostel in Yungho on Dec. 13, police said.
Anchacee, who managed to acquire her visa through a fallacious marriage with a local man, told police that she received five to six clients a day at two hostels in Yungho.

Police urged local men who had solicited sexual services in the Yungho area in recent weeks to undergo blood tests in order to determine whether they have contracted HIV, the virus that causes the deadly AIDS. Police suspect that the Thai prostitute had been infected with HIV before she came to Taiwan.
Anchacee will be repatriated early next month together with 14 other foreign prostitutes arrested in late November and early December in the greater Taipei area.
The 14 prostitutes were all connected with the now disbanded Lily sex ring. Police confirmed on Monday that one of those prostitutes has also been tested HIV positive.

The Lily sex ring collapsed after two large-scale crackdowns by law enforcement authorities. Scores of people involved in the Lily operations, including hostel operators, taxi drivers, bodyguards, restaurant owners and other sex brokers, have been arrested.
Police said the recently busted Yungho sex joint was not part of the Lily ring. They said further investigations will be made so that all accomplices may be brought to justice.

DOC.HEADLINE: TAIPEI OFFERS MORE HELP TO SEXUAL ASSAULT VICTIMS

TEXT.P: Taipei Mayor Chen Shui-bian on Tuesday presided over the opening of the Taipei Sexual Assault Prevention Center in the Chung-Hsing Hospital.
Chen said that the center will offer around-the-clock emergency aid, medical treatment, legal advice and accommodations to those who are victims of sexual attacks.
The mayor expressed the hope that women who suffer sexual assaults will make use of the center.
Statistics compiled by the Taipei City Police Headquarters show that a total of 219 rape cases were reported in 1996 and that 247 such cases were resolved during the same period, Chen said.

Chen noted that since many of the women who suffer sexual assaults choose not to report the attacks, the real number of rapes in Taipei might reach 2,500 per year. The city government and related agencies will make more efforts to reduce the incidence of rape, he asserted.

DOC.HEADLINE: MOST ENTERPRISES SHOW LITTLE FAITH IN APROC PROJECT: SURVEY

TEXT.P: Most local and foreign enterprises have little faith in the government's project to build Taiwan into an Asia-Pacific Regional Operations Center (APROC), the Strategic Advancement Alliance said on Tuesday, citing the results of a recent survey.

The Strategic Advancement Alliance said that it sent 1,000 questionnaires to enterprises in the Hsinchu Science-based Industrial Park, the air cargo carriers and shipping companies in Taipei, the Taiwan offices of foreign banks and the members of the Council for Industrial and Commercial Development between Sept. 15 and Oct. 30 to learn their opinions on the government's ambitious project. A total of 384 answered copies were mailed back, it said.

Among the respondents, 40 percent are manufacturers, while air cargo carriers account for 30 percent of the total. Shipping companies make up 18.8 percent of the total respondents, and financial organizations account for 12.5 percent.

More than 66 percent of the respondents said they don't have any faith in the government's APROC project. As high as 84 percent of those polled expressed dissatisfaction with the overall efficiency of the government, while 65.4 percent said that they were not satisfied with the pace the government has taken in revising or updating regulations to facilitate the project.

In addition, half of the respondents felt that the overall investment climate of Taiwan is not good enough to attract foreign investors. For the respondents, the island's geographical position, technological level and workforce quality are the only advantages it has, while the tax and tariff systems, social order, quality of the living environment, traffic and telecommunications, and infrastructure in Taiwan were rated "poor" for wooing foreign investment.

The Economics Ministry is the only government agency that won over a 50 percent approval rating from the respondents in its efforts to help the APROC project. The Council for Economic Planning and Development, Transportation and Telecommunications Ministry, Finance Ministry, Government Information Office and Central Bank of China all received less than 50 percent approval ratings for their roles in pushing the project.

DOC.HEADLINE: BEIJING MAY PROMOTE RESUMPTION OF CROSS-STRAIT TALKS FLEXIBLY
DOC.DATELINE: Beijing, Dec. 30 (CNA) (By Wang Hsin-chung & Eva Chen)

TEXT.P: The stalemate between the Taipei-based Straits Exchange Foundation (SEF) and the Beijing-based Association for Relations Across the Taiwan Strait (ARATS) should not be allowed to continue, a Beijing official concerned with Taiwan affairs remarked Monday.
Beijing authorities "have made many efforts" and "are still making efforts with good will" to promote the resumption of talks between the two sides, the official said.
The official, wishing to remain anonymous, declined to disclose when and how will ARATS will again approach the goal.

The atmosphere between Taipei and Beijing will almost inevitably worsen in the short term since South Africa is set to transfer its formal diplomatic relations from the former to the latter on Jan. 1. Thus Beijing's initiatives are not likely to occur until after the Pretoria factor gets diluted.
A more auspicious time for talks between the two side to resume would be around the Chinese lunar New Year, which in 1998 falls on Jan. 28.

Beijing's brain trust on Taiwan affairs is not ducking the problems confronting political negotiations for the termination of hostilities across the Taiwan Strait, the official said, stressing the official line that such talks will be approached step by step.

DOC.HEADLINE: US DOLLAR DOWN

TEXT.P: The US dollar dropped NT$0.086 against the New Taiwan dollar on the Taipei foreign exchange market on Tuesday, closing at NT$32.6.
The greenback opened at the day's high of 32.735, and experienced a low of 32.56.
Interbank US dollar trading reached US$320 million.

DOC.HEADLINE: SHARE PRICES UP ON TAIEX

TEXT.P: Share prices closed 0.9 percent higher on the local stock market on Tuesday.
The rise was prompted in large part by active trading on Wall Street, dealers said, adding that market turnover here nonetheless remained low.
The Taiwan Stock Exchange (TAIEX) weighted price index grew 90.69 points to finish at 8,167.34.
The bourse opened at the day's high of 8,145.77 and experienced a low of 8,116.15.
A total of 1.76 billion shares changed hands on a market turnover of NT$74.7 billion (US$2.29 billion).
Gainers overwhelmed losers 311 to 91, with 73 shares unchanged.
All eight major stock categories recorded gains, with plastic and chemical shares surging the most at 1.4 percent.

Electrical engineering and construction issues followed with 1 percent wins apiece, while foodstuff stocks grew 0.8 percent, cement and financial shares rose 0.7 percent each, textile issues gained 0.6 percent, and paper-making stocks posted a modest 0.2 percent gain.

The 10 companies with the largest turnovers were Mosel Vitelic, ADI, Yue Loong, Picvue Electronics, Pao Shiang, ACER, Microelectronics Technology, China Steel, Da-Cin Construction and Pacific Electric Wire.

DOC.HEADLINE: SHARE PRICES UP

TEXT.P: Share prices in the Taiwan Stock Exchange ended higher on Tuesday, with the weighted index, the local bourse's major indicator, rising by 69.12 points to finish at 8,145.77.
Plastic and chemical issues posted by the largest increase of 1.4 percent, followed by electrical engineering and construction issues each with 1 percent, and foodstuff issues with 0.8 percent.
Gainers outnumbered losers 311 to 91, with 73 issues remained stable.
A total of 1.75 billion shares changed hands on a sluggish market turnover of NT$74.8 billion (about US$2.3 billion).

The 10 most heavily traded issues were Mosel Vitelic, A. D. I., Yieh Loong, Picvue Electronics, Pao Shiang, Macronix International, Microelectronics Technology, China Steel, Tah Shin Industrial, and Pacific Electric Wire and Cable.

DOC.HEADLINE: TAIWAN CHICKEN FARMERS SEEK BUSINESS OPPORTUNITIES IN HONG KONG

TEXT.P: Taiwan chicken farmers are preparing to break into the potentially lucrative Hong Kong market, following an announcement by the Hong Kong government that it will exterminate up to 1.3 million chickens throughout the territory to stop the spread of the "bird flu" which has killed four people there.

Share prices related to the chicken raising industry surged on the local stock market on Monday at the prospect that Taiwan's chicken exports to Hong Kong will increase significantly as a result of the Hong Kong government move.

Charoen Pok Phand Enterprises (Taiwan), Taiwan's largest chicken raiser and Asia's largest chicken processor, announced on Monday that it will start exports of frozen chicken to Hong Kong within one week, hoping to use Hong Kong as the base for a worldwide sales network.
The Taiwan Chicken Raising Industry Association also said that it is planning to encourage local raisers to export frozen and processed chicken to Hong Kong.

A report by the cabinet-level Council of Agriculture (COA) shows that there are currently about 120 million chickens in Taiwan, while around 350 million are killed each year to meet domestic demand, an average annual per-capita consumption of 16 chickens.

According to the COA, chicken and hog raising are the two major sectors of Taiwan's animal husbandry industry. However, the hog raising industry has been hard-hit by an epidemic of foot-and-mouth disease which swept the island in March, underscoring the importance of the chicken raising industry, it noted.

The COA report indicates that the annual output of the chicken raising industry totals around NT$41.3 billion (about US$1.3 billion), accounting for 13 percent of the overall production value of the animal husbandry sector, second only to the 28 percent attributable to hog raising.
The COA said it has already taken measures to prevent the spread of any type of bird flu which might break out in Taiwan, in order to avert another disaster in the local animal husbandry sector.

DOC.HEADLINE: 1997 TOP 10 CONSUMER NEWS STORIES

TEXT.P: The ROC Consumers Foundation on Tuesday selected the epidemic of foot-and-mouth (FMD) disease at local hog ranches and a series of food poisoning cases reported around the island as the top domestic consumer news events of 1997.
The foundation said 1997 saw many natural calamities, as well as disasters caused by human error or negligence. As a result, it said, consumer confidence has often been jittery over the past year.

During the year, the foundation said, consumer confidence in food hygiene has been challenged many times. The outbreak of an FMD epidemic in mid-March, the recent recurrence of FMD cases in some counties, the discovery of contaminated Dreyer's ice cream products and the repeated occurrence of mass food poisoning cases have exposed the shortcomings in the government's animal disease control and food administration systems.
Other major consumer news events rounding out the top 10 list selected by the foundation's directors and supervisors include:

-- The collapse of Lincoln Villas in Hsichi, Taipei County in August amid heavy rains and strong winds brought by Typhoon Winnie. A total of 80 houses in the complex were either completely or partially destroyed and 28 people were killed in the incident. The tragedy also toppled local consumer confidence in houses built on hillsides.

-- Problems related to illegal remodeling inside residential houses. The safety of those residences, the legality of such structures and the legitimate rights of house owners have attracted much attention and caused heated debate.
-- Frequent squabbling and disputes among cable television operators, which have seriously affected consumer's rights.
-- Repeated air accidents, raising concern about flight safety.
-- Disputes over a children's life insurance program marketed by the Hung Fu Life Insurance Co., which unilaterally asked all of its policy buyers to cancel their purchase contracts.
-- The explosion of gas pipelines in Kaohsiung and the lax safety inspection procedures for liquefied petroleum gas cylinders.
-- Large amounts of pesticide residues on fruits and vegetables sold for human consumption.
-- A sharp increase in the number of cases of legionnaires disease.
-- Deaths suspected to have been caused by the misuse of anti-fungal drugs such as Lamisil and Sporanox.

DOC.HEADLINE: ROC UMBILICAL CORD BLOOD BANK ESTABLISHED

TEXT.P: The ROC Umbilical Cord Blood Bank, the first of its kind in Asia, was officially established Tuesday to serve as a salvation to blood disease patients and anemia sufferers, enabling them to get blood more quickly and cheaply.

The umbilical cord blood bank, organized by the non-profit Chinese Blood Services Foundation, will first gather birth cords from maternity wards in Taipei's leading general hospitals so as to collect fresh umbilical cord blood, which is rich in the "stem cells" that can be used to cultivate more blood, according to a senior researcher from the foundation.

Once umbilical cords are collected, their blood will be individually tested in the blood bank so as to sort the product according to its type of human lymphocyte antigen and ready it for service, said the researcher.
The specialized blood bank will eventually cultivate its own stem cells, using a system that will grow them from original stem cells collected from fresh umbilical cord blood.
The birth cords to be used for umbilical cord blood collection will all be obtained from mothers, who will be asked to sign a donation agreement before they give birth, the researcher said.
In the past, umbilical cords were normally discarded.

DOC.HEADLINE: EX-HK, NZ COPS PROTECT STUDENTS FROM TAIWAN, HK FROM TRIADS

TEXT.P: Asian students studying in Auckland from Taiwan, Hong Kong, South Korea, Thailand and other countries are paying fees to retired police officers from Hong Kong and New Zealand for round-the-clock protection from triads.

In a dispatch from Auckland, the Australian Associated Press (AAP) reported the trouble-shooting scheme run by Campus Services is based on a Canadian university scheme designed to stop unaccompanied or overseas students from being preyed on by organized crime, particularly the Hong Kong-based 14K triad.
For a payment of NZ$58 (US$34) a week, the service provides regular visits and 24-hour contact for students throughout New Zealand, according to the AAP.

One founding member, identified as Yuet Heung Che, who served with the former Royal Hong Kong Police for more than 10 years, said the service helps in such areas as disputes, assaults and victimization.
Che said recent incidents that resulted in some students being sent back to Asia for gang-related misconduct had prompted the establishment of the service.
He said the service has just been launched and advertised in Auckland, the biggest city in New Zealand, a popular destination for people emigrating from Taiwan, Hong Kong and mainland China.
He said his company will launch marketing promotions in Taiwan and Hong Kong to attract business.
Another founding member, a New Zealander who did not want to be named, said the service would act as a "go-between" troubleshooter.
"The service starts by picking students up at the airport and helping them settle down. Whenever trouble occurs, we will be on the scene," the AAP quoted him as saying.
"If required, regular written reports will be provided for parents residing in other countries," he added.
Overseas students will be encouraged to take part in outdoor activities such as fishing rather than hanging around in karaoke bars, the New Zealand police officer said.

The AAP reported thousands of secondary and tertiary students come to New Zealand each year without their parents to study, and that hundreds of the children of immigrants are left at home when their parents travel overseas for business.

DOC.HEADLINE: AUSTRALIA FIGHTING SEX SLAVE TRADE BETWEEN ASIA AND DOWN UNDER

TEXT.P: The Australian government will soon introduce tough laws to prevent the burgeoning sex slave trade between Asia and the Down Under, the Department of Justice said.
Justice Minister Amanda Vanstone said there were between 200 and 300 sex slaves brought into Australia from Asian countries.
She said Australia's proximity to Southeast Asia has made it a key destination for young women procured to work in the sex industry.

She said the new laws are necessary because the current legislation in place deals with people who have been kidnapped and forced into the sex industry but does not cover those who come to Australia voluntarily and turn to prostitution.
The new laws will be submitted to parliament in the next few months, Vanstone said.

"Girls as young as 13 and teenagers are being brought to Australia under the ruse of paying off a family debt and getting here, finding their passports taken and working for a pittance and not being free to leave when they choose," she said.
Vanstone said there is also "strong evidence" of links between the sex slave trade and organized crime.
Contracts demand that a woman's brothel earnings go directly to the brothel owner until her debt is paid.
In September alone, the Australian government arrested 19 illegal immigrants in Sydney who were working in prostitution.

DOC.HEADLINE: FOREIGN MINISTRY PROBING JAPANESE RAMMING OF TAIWAN FISHING BOAT

TEXT.P: The ROC Ministry of Foreign Affairs (MOFA) is looking into allegations that a Taiwan fishing boat was cornered and rammed by a Japanese patrol boat while it was operating in waters near the Tiaoyutai Islands on Sunday night.

The Suao-based fishing vessel, the Yungsheng No. 106, was reportedly rammed by a 500-ton Japanese patrol boat and had its radar and lighting systems damaged while it was fishing in waters near the Chihwei Islet, one of the Tiaoyutai archipelago group in the East China Sea. None of the boat's crew were injured.
MOFA spokesman Roy Wu said if the allegations are found to be true, the ROC government will register a stern protest with the Japanese authorities for severely infringing the ROC's sovereignty.

Wu said the MOFA immediately contacted its liaison offices in Japan and the Ryukyu islands upon hearing the report on Monday morning, to try to gain a better understanding of the incident, but added that as of Tuesday evening, the MOFA had still not heard from the Japanese authorities.
Meanwhile, he reiterated Taipei's sovereignty claim over the Tiaoyutai islands, and the ROC government's determination to safeguard the interests of Taiwan's fishermen.

Wu called for Japan to exercise restraint over fishing in waters near the Tiaoyutais, since Taiwan and Japan are currently engaged in talks aimed at a peaceful resolution to fishing disputes in the region.

The Tiaoyutais, known as the Senkakus in Japan, are located roughly halfway between Taiwan and the Japanese island of Okinawa, and are the subject of conflicting territorial claims by Taiwan, Japan and mainland China.

DOC.HEADLINE: ROC BECOMES WORLD'S 4TH LARGEST SPONSOR FOR POOR CHILDREN

TEXT.P: The Republic of China has emerged as the world's fourth largest sponsor for poor children through the promotion of the World Vision of Taiwan (WVT), Minister of Foreign Affairs Jason Hu said on Tuesday.
Taiwan only trails the United States, Canada and Australia in adopting or sponsoring poor children around the world, Hu said at a year-end tea party sponsored by the World Vision of Taiwan.
Hu said the World Vision's global poor children adoption and sponsorship program has helped the international community understand that Taiwan is willing to share care and love with needy families.

Speaking on the same occasion, WVT President Rev. Chow Lien-hwa said the WVT is a worldwide humanitarian organization. Its Thirty Hour Famine and Love Loaf fund-raising campaigns have become well-known in the international community.

Rev. Chow said the WVT originally gave its top priority to helping needy children and has now expanded its concern to the well-being of a whole community. To help boost community development, the WVT has organized a W.V. Youth Ambassadors Program to promote peace and love as well as to prevent conflicts.

In addition to helping overseas needy children and families, the WVT has also devoted much energy and financial resources to help local children and indigenous people, including educational, medical and vocational counseling.

Rev. Chow expressed his gratitude for donations given by local enterprises or ordinary citizens over past years. "Without their contributions, the WVT couldn't have undertaken so many relief or humanitarian programs," he added.

DOC.HEADLINE: AUSTRALIA OFFERS INCENTIVES TO MIGRANTS NOT TO GO TO BIG CITIES

TEXT.P: The Australian government will give incentives to wealthy migrants by allowing them in with less than the A$300,000 (US$196,000) normally required to qualify for a business visa if they agree not to live in large cities like Sydney, Melbourne or Brisbane.

Under a revamped plan to push migrants into regional areas, Immigration Minister Philip Ruddock said the government was reviewing the cut-off point for net assets but said it would not fall below half the present amount.
"There is an intense degree of interest in furthering business migration to regional areas and lots of support from state governments to facilitate this," he told reporters Monday.

"But the federal government is conscious that these people must have the financial capacity to succeed; that they must be able to afford adequate accommodation and have the funds to get a business up off the ground," he said.

In addition to encouraging business migrants, Australia will continue giving priority to skilled migrants by "making adjustments elsewhere because ... business skills are the most beneficial part of the immigration program," Ruddock said.

Tasmania, South Australia and the Northern Territory welcome skilled migrants to choose their places for the settlement in Australia. But most business migrants have settled in Sydney, Brisbane, Gold Coast and Melbourne in recent years, he said.

Official figures released this month by the Department of Immigration show that on average, business migrants transfer about A$447,000 from their country of origin to Australia one year after their arrival. The amount doubles in the second year and rises to A$1.1 million after three years.
On average, business migrants employ at least four staff two years after their arrival.

Business skills intake grew to more than 5,800 in fiscal 1996-97 from 4,900 in 1995-96, while figures for the family reunion category dropped to 37,240 from 48,700 during the same period, according to the department.
In 1996-97, Australia's migrant intake was set at 72,000, sharply down from 99,000 in 1995-96.

DOC.HEADLINE: TOYOTA RECEIVES BLUE SKY AWARD FOR ITS ELECTRIC CAR

TEXT.P: Toyota Motor Corp. has won CALSTART's 1997 Blue Sky Award for the market launch of its innovative, clean and fuel-efficient Prius hybrid-electric car.

The award is presented each year by CALSTART, a California-based advanced transportation organization, to recognize outstanding marketplace contributions to advanced, sustainable transportation that cleans the air, improves energy efficiency and helps reduce greenhouse emissions.

Toyota was recognized in particular for its Prius model, which is now selling in Japan. This, combined with the company's commitments to three other clean fuel vehicles -- the Coaster hybrid electric bus, the RAV4-EV electric vehicle and the announcement of the "e-com" electric commuter car -- led to its selection as the top award winner for 1997.

"Toyota's actions are currently setting the trend globally in clean, efficient vehicles," said CALSTART President Michael J. Gage. "Their efforts, highlighted by their innovative hybrid system, are redefining passenger transportation and efficiency, which are crucial for both air pollution and global warming. We are proud to honor these solid market commitments with our second annual award."

"We are honored to accept this prestigious award from CALSTART and its participants," said Dave Illingworth, senior vice president and general manager of the Toyota Division of Toyota Sales USA. "We have received much recognition lately for the innovation in our vehicle, but this award recognizes their value to the environment as well."
Illingworth also said that the company will sell a hybrid-powered vehicle in the United States before the end of the century.

CALSTART also presented four 1997 Merit Awards to the Ballard Power System of Vancouver, Canada; James Worden, founder of the Massachusetts-based Solectria Corp.; SunLine Transit of Thousand Palms, California; and the Regional Transit District of Sacramento, California.

The Blue Sky Award is specifically designed to recognize not just leadership and innovation in technology for clean transportation but also a significant commitment to its use. The award can go to companies, organizations or individuals worldwide fitting the criteria.
Last year, CALSTART presented its first Blue Sky Award to General Motors for the automaker's EVI electric vehicle launch in the marketplace.

DOC.HEADLINE: NEW TERRITORIAL WATERS BILL PASSES SECOND READING

TEXT.P: The Legislative Yuan on Tuesday completed the second reading of the Territorial Waters Bill, defining the Republic of China's territorial waters as the area within a 12-mile radius of the coast.
The bill, which was submitted by the cabinet in 1992, also stipulates that waters beyond 12 miles but within 24 miles of the coast are designated the "adjacent area."
Any person or subject (vessel) will be subject to arrest or detention if they violate ROC territorial laws by illegally entering ROC territorial waters or the adjacent area.
A middle line will be drawn to demarcate any overlapping territorial claims between the ROC and foreign countries.

The bill, which will become law after passing a third reading, falls short of including the "U-shaped waters" in the South China Sea in the nation's territorial waters, because lawmakers deemed the area to be "historically Chinese waters."

But this doesn't necessarily mean that the ROC is giving up its sovereignty claims over the Spratly islands in the South China Sea, which are also claimed totally or in part by Malaysia, the Philippines, Vietnam, Brunei and mainland China.

Under the new bill, foreign ships will be allowed to pass through ROC territorial waters so long as they pose no threat to aviation safety, traffic, marine resources or the environment within the waters.

DOC.HEADLINE: TAIWAN REDUCES INVESTMENTS IN SOUTHEAST ASIA

TEXT.P: A total of 74 local applications to invest in overseas, valued at US$281.76 million, were approved by the Republic of China government in November, according to statistics released on Tuesday by the Investment Commission under the Ministry of Economic Affairs.
The commission pointed out that the recent financial storm which has swept most of Southeast Asia has prompted many local business people to reduce their investments in that region.
Instead, the commission said, local enterprises are now investing in Europe, the United States, Japan, Hong Kong, and Singapore, along with the Virgin Islands.

The statistics also show that during the period from January to November, a total of 662 overseas investment applications with a total value of over US$2.6 billion were given the green light, up 52.53 percent from the same period of last year.
These figures suggest that local businesses are using overseas investment as a means to globalize their operations, in order to sharpen their competitiveness.

DOC.HEADLINE: TAIPEI PROTESTS SOUTH AFRICAN DIPLOMATIC SWITCH

TEXT.P: The Republic of China on Tuesday registered a stern protest against South Africa over Pretoria's switching of diplomatic recognition from Taipei to Beijing from Wednesday.

The protests are against Pretoria's acknowledgment of Beijing's "one China" assertion, which hegemonically claims that mainland China is the only legitimate government of China, and Taiwan is an inseparable part of the mainland Chinese territory -- lies that will never be acceptable to the Republic of China on Taiwan, said the Ministry of Foreign Affairs (MOFA).

MOFA spokesman Roy Wu said Taipei has given Pretoria a good dressing-down over the diplomatic switch, a move showing Pretoria's disregard for the long-term friendship between the ROC and South Africa, and for the fact that Taiwan and mainland China are different political entities under separate ruling systems.

During a press conference at the Ministry of Foreign Affairs on Tuesday evening, Wu announced that the ROC is severing its formal diplomatic relations with South Africa, effective at midnight on Dec. 31.
Since Nov. 27, 1996, Taipei has repeatedly expressed grave concerns over Pretoria's planned diplomatic switch before the end of 1997.
The concerns, however, have fallen on deaf ears over the past year, and Pretoria on Tuesday was going ahead with its plan to establish formal ties with Beijing.

The move has not only harmed the ROC's national dignity and hurt the feelings of the people of Taiwan, it has also severely impaired the traditional cordial relations between the two countries, for which Taipei feels inexpressibly regretful, Wu added.

He stressed that despite the severing of diplomatic ties with South Africa, the ROC remains undaunted in seeking wider horizons in the international community, and will continue striving to expand substantive ties with more countries around the world.

DOC.HEADLINE: TAIWAN'S MAJOR INVESTMENTS INCREASING IN VOLUME

TEXT.P: The volume of major investment projects, defined as projects valued at over NT$200 million (US$6.13 million), in Taiwan grew 19.7 percent this year over 1996, according to statistics released on Tuesday by the Industrial Development Bureau (IDB).

The official figures show that Taiwan's major investment projects in 1997 had a total value of NT$257.157 billion (US$7.89 billion), mostly in the textile industry, with an value of NT$83.746 billion (US$2.57 billion) for 50 cases.
The electronics and electrical sector, as well as the basic metal and chemical material industries, also registered a series of significant investments on the island this year, the IDB said.

In September, 1992, the government formed a task force to promote investment on the island, since then the group has provided assistance to private businesses wishing to make major investments worth more than NT$200 million.

DOC.HEADLINE: ROC EMBASSY IN SOUTH AFRICA TO LOWER ITS FLAG ON WEDNESDAY NIGHT

TEXT.P: The Republic of China Embassy in South Africa and its three consulates will lower their ROC national flags on Wednesday evening and assume their new status as Taiwan liaison offices.

As Pretoria has decided to switch its diplomatic recognition from Taipei to Beijing from the beginning of 1998, the ROC Embassy and its consulates will be downgraded into liaison offices after that time, according to an arrangement reached between the two countries.

Timothy Yang, Directior of Foreign Ministry's African Affairs Department, said here on Monday that the ROC Embassy in Pretoria and its general consulates in Johannesburg, Durban and Cape Town will lower their flags at 5:00 p.m. local time (11:00 p.m. Taipei time) and change their name plaques after midnight (6:00 a.m. Thursday Taipei time).

The new ROC representative to South Africa is expected to be named and to assume his post in January, while the three ROC general consuls will remain in their positions after Wednesday, although their job titles will change in line with their new status.

Touching on the new relationship between Taipei and Beijing, Yang said Taipei was unaware, and regretted that Pretoria had agreed to use the word "recognizes" rather than "acknowledges" to indicate its consent to Beijing's claim to Taiwan in its joint communique with Beijing on setting up diplomatic relations.

While denying that the defection of South Africa to the mainland China camp will cause a domino effect among the island's other allies on the African continent, Yang nevertheless warned that Beijing's attempts to isolate the ROC will not stop.

DOC.HEADLINE: TAIWAN ATTRACTING FOREIGN INVESTMENT AMID REGIONAL FINANCIAL WOES

TEXT.P: Foreign funds fleeing from financial woes in South Korea and Southeast Asia are pouring into Taiwan, with the number of approved investment projects surging to 62, for a total of US$209.47 million in November, according to statistics released by the government on Tuesday.
That figure doesn't include the 935 projects still pending approval, said the Investment Commission under the Ministry of Economic Affairs, which compiled the figures.

In an analysis accompanying the statistics, the Investment Commission described them as a preliminary sign of the government's success in building the island into a regional business operations hub, and further attributed the positive figures to Taiwan's seeming immunity to the regional crisis, its healthy economic system and the liberalization measures taken by the government.

There were 611 foreign investment projects approved in the first eleven months of 1997, with an accumulated volume of US$3.69 billion, representing a 38.55 percent year-on-year increase in terms of number and a 62.42 percent rise in volume.

Electronic and electrical appliances, the basic metal industry and its products, the service industry, the finance and insurance industry, and international trade are the top five favorite sectors for foreign investors, accounting for 72.12 percent of the total foreign investment.

DOC.HEADLINE: ASIAN CRISIS WILL AFFECT REST OF WORLD

TEXT.P: With Japan in the grip of powerful deflationary forces, and South Korea at the IMF's door, the rest of the world can have no doubt now that the Asian crisis will affect them, an influential European newspaper predicted on Tuesday.

Forecasters are suggesting that Western economies are in good shape to weather the storm, and will suffer only a marginal reduction in growth. This is probably true. But there are now significant downside risks to this central forecast. If more countries fall victim to the crisis, or if Japan mishandles the shakeout in its financial sector, things could get a lot worse, the Financial Times warned.
Events in Asia affect the rest of the world through a number of different channels. Probably the most important are financial market contagion and the impact on trade.

Little needs to be said about how financial market turbulence in one country can trigger reactions around the world. It is worth emphasizing, though, that while the most dramatic effects were seen in Western markets, the more damaging and lasting effect has been to scare investors away from the emerging markets at a time when many of these countries need to raise foreign capital.
On the trade side, weak growth will depress Asia's imports, and devaluations will make them more competitive. Both will work to the disadvantage of other exporters.

However, in the developed Western economies at least, this effect might not be too serious. European Union exports to Asia excluding Japan are 7 percent of total EU exports, or 2 percent of gross domestic product. US exports to the region are nearly 20 percent of total US exports, but since exports make up a smaller proportion of total GDP, their share in US GDP is roughly the same as in Europe.

A cut in Asian imports would therefore only have a relatively small effect, of the order of less than half a percentage point of US and European GDP growth. Including Japan in the figures does not make too much difference. There will also be a substitution effect: Cheaper goods from Asia will encourage people to switch from domestic to imported goods. But still, the impact on GDP is not huge.

But don't relax just yet, the Financial Times said. Though the most likely scenario is that developed world growth continues at a healthy pace, there is now a significant risk attached to this forecast. Events could turn nasty in two years.

First, the Financial Times said, contagion could spread to other countries. Brazil and Russia remain possible targets. There is also a question of whether communist China will devalue in order to maintain its position against its Asian competitors.

Second, and more worrying, things could go wrong in Japan. The collapse of Yamaichi and subsequent hints that public money might be available to recapitalize some banks, signaled that at last, a shakeout in the financial system may be underway. At the same time, though, the economy is teetering on the brink of recession. The situation is delicate, the Financial Times pointed out.

"The damage to global confidence from such a scenario would dwarf the effects of the Asian crisis so far. It might not only trigger the long-awaited correction in Western equity markets, it could also destroy confidence in developing country markets and in their financial institutions. This would spread contagion far and wide, and lead to very real effects in these economies as their financial systems came under strain," the Financial Times added.

DOC.HEADLINE: TAIWAN WOULD HAVE TO DETER MILITARY ATTACK ALONE FOR TWO WEEKS

TEXT.P: Legislator Parris Chang of the opposition Democratic Progressive Party (DPP) said on Tuesday that Taiwan must be able to deter military attacks from mainland China by itself for at least for two weeks in order to give enough time for support from the United States or Japan to reach the island.
Chang made the remarks in a speech on Taiwan's future at a fund-raising dinner at a local hotel.

The "three no" policies of the United States toward Taiwan that were made public following the meeting between US President Bill Clinton and mainland Chinese President Jiang Zemin in late October have actually imposed restrictions on Taiwan's future, he said.
The "three nos" are that the United States will not support Taiwan's efforts to join the United Nations, Taiwan's independence or "one China, one Taiwan," nor "two Chinas."

But the DPP lawmaker added that the US side also responded positively to his stance, conveyed during a recent visit to the United States with DPP Chairman Hsu Shin-liang, that "Taiwan's future should be decided by Taiwan people, not by mainland China or the United States."

Although the inclusion of the Taiwan Strait into the new security agreement reached earlier this year between the United States and Japan provides a great deal of protection to Taiwan, Chang stressed that the island must be able by itself to counter military attacks from mainland China for at least two weeks before the United States or Japan can reach it with help.

Chang said that to the best of his knowledge, the US government does not intend to force Taipei to conduct negotiations with Beijing, so that rumors that Washington hopes the two sides of the Taiwan Strait can reopen negotiations in spring are not correct.
Also present at the fund-raising activity were former DPP Chairman Huang Hsin-chieh, Taoyuan County Magistrate Annette Hsiu-lien Lu and officials of the American Institute in Taiwan.
