DOC.HEADLINE: ROC SEVERS FORMAL TIES WITH RSA
DOC.DATELINE: Johannesburg, Dec. 31 (CNA) (By J.S. Chang & Deborah Kuo)

TEXT.P: The Republic of China severed formal relations with the Republic of South Africa on the last day of 1997, officially terminating 22 years of diplomatic ties between the two countries.

Relations between the two date back to 1905, when the predecessor of the ROC government set up its first general consulate in South Africa in Johannesburg. The office was upgraded to an embassy in April 1976, when the two countries established formal diplomatic relations.
During the 22 years of formal ties, four ROC ambassadors served as head of the embassy in Pretoria: Kuan Yung, Yang Hsi-kun, Steven Wang and Loh I-cheng.

Loh, who began serving as the last ROC ambassador in South Africa in late 1990, experienced the most trying diplomatic era in the African country, including turbulent changes in domestic politics, black nationalist leader Nelson Mandela's release after 27 years in prison, and Mandela's election in 1994 to be South Africa's first black president.

Loh helped make it possible for Mandela, in his former capacity as leader of the black nationalist African National Congress, to visit Taiwan in 1993, and for President Lee Teng-hui to attend Mandela's inauguration in Pretoria the following year.
After becoming president, Mandela often stressed that South Africa would not establish formal ties with communist China at the expense of the ROC's interests.

His vow, however, was finally broken under the strain of internal opposition, which, apparently envisaging a big slice of the business in mainland China, pushed for Pretoria to switch diplomatic recognition from Taipei to Beijing.
As a result, Mandela informed Taipei late last year that Pretoria would establish formal ties with Beijing on Jan. 1, 1998.

After 13 months of negotiations, Taipei and Pretoria reached a consensus over future ties between the two states under a new framework. The two sides agreed that except in matters such as national names and flags, substantive relations between the ROC and South Africa will remain unchanged.

Commenting on Pretoria's sealing of formal ties with Beijing, ROC Consul General in Pretoria Feng Tai pointed out that the ROC government and private sector have channeled some US$1.5 billion into South Africa for various investment projects during the last two decades. He doubted that mainland China will be capable of investing an equivalent amount in that African country over the next 20 years.

DOC.HEADLINE: SOUTH AFRICAN DIPLOMAT AND HIS FAMILY LEAVE TAIWAN

TEXT.P: A South African diplomat and his family, who were suddenly cast into the national spotlight after being taken hostage by Taiwan's most wanted fugitive last month, left Taiwan for South Africa on Wednesday.

McGill Alexander, military attache of the South African embassy to the Republic of China, said at northern Taiwan's CKS International Airport that they will never forget the people of Taiwan and the friends they have here and that they will return to the island someday.

The South African diplomat, his wife Anne and their 12-year-old daughter Christine are returning to their homeland as diplomatic relations between Taipei and Pretoria will be severed from Jan. 1, 1998, following Pretoria's move to switch diplomatic recognition to Beijing. Another daughter, Melanie, left Taiwan earlier.

Alexander said that being held hostage was an unpleasant experience, but that the many letters and phone calls they received after the ordeal have comforted them. They wanted to express appreciation for the love and care the Taiwan people extended to them following the hostage incident.
Alexander said that Taiwan is a place they will never forget, adding that he is sure they will come back to see their old friends again, though he doesn't know when.

Alexander, his wife, two daughters and a seven-month old baby in their care were held at gunpoint in their Taipei residence on Nov. 18 by fugitive Chen Chin-hsing, wanted for a series of violent crimes, including the kidnap and murder of a high school student. Alexander and his elder daughter Melanie were shot and wounded during the 24-hour standoff, while his wife, Christine and the baby were eventually released unharmed.

DOC.HEADLINE: LIEN'S SINGAPORE TRIP PURELY RECREATIONAL: SU

TEXT.P: Vice Presidential Secretary-General Su Chih said on Wednesday that Vice President Lien Chan's visit to Singapore is purely private, calling on outsiders not to speculate over the trip.

Lien's trip to Singapore is aimed mainly at meeting with friends, playing golf and seeing points of interest, Su said, adding that the outside world should not complicate or politicize the matter, since no political meetings or special itinerary have been included in his trip.
Accompanied by his wife, daughter and Su, Lien is scheduled to depart for Singapore on Thursday for a four-day vacation.

Foreign Minister Jason Hu also said on Tuesday that Lien's trip to Singapore during the New Year holidays is purely private. He denied that the purpose of Lien's Singapore trip is to clear the way for the resumption of negotiations between Taiwan and mainland China.

Regarding reports that Lien is scheduled to lead a delegation to Honduras in late January to attend the inauguration of President-elect Carlos Flores, Hu said a formal announcement on the issue will be made public soon and added that Lien has no plans to travel to other countries following his visit to Honduras.

Hu also revealed that he will travel to Africa in late January to preside over a meeting with representatives of the Republic of China's diplomatic missions stationed in the region and to pave the way for a planned visit by President Lee Teng-hui there next year.
It will be Hu's first visit abroad since he assumed the post in October.

DOC.HEADLINE: FOREIGN MINISTER MAPS MAJOR TASKS FOR 1998

TEXT.P: With 1997 bowing out in a few hours to make way for 1998, Foreign Affairs Minister Jason Hu spelled out the government's major tasks on the diplomatic front in the new year, which include a new fence-mending approach to Southeast Asian countries and introducing the concept of "BOT -- build, operate, transfer -- diplomacy."

In a year-end press conference, Hu said the Ministry of Foreign Affairs (MOFA) intends to continue consolidating relations with its diplomatic allies in the new year, while strengthening substantive ties with countries which maintain no formal relations with the ROC.

The MOFA will also consolidate resources and influences from the private sector to intensify the ROC's role in the international community, and will bolster cross-Taiwan Strait diplomatic communications.

In the face of new situations in Southeast Asia as a result of the region-wide financial upheaval, Taipei will launch a fence-mending initiative to better ties with its Southeast Asian neighbors, Hu said, adding that the initiative will be rich in humanitarian, rather than political, color.

Commenting on the ROC's severing of formal diplomatic relations with South Africa on Wednesday, Hu said he does not think Pretoria's defection to the mainland Chinese camp will cause a domino effect among the island's other allies on the African continent or in other regions of the globe.

Hu pointed to the ROC's "blue chips" on the diplomatic front, including Taiwan's solid economic prowess, a commendable democracy, a strong national defensive buildup, and a hard-working and high-caliber diplomatic corps.

On Beijing's continuing attempts to contain and sabotage Taiwan diplomatically, Hu stressed that the ROC people and government should arm themselves with a higher-degree of confidence, saying that Taiwan is by no means inferior to communist China in almost any aspect. For example, he noted, Taiwan imported some US$20 billion-worth of products from America in recent years, 1.6 times mainland China's imports from the same source.

With regard to Beijing's scheme to use business incentives to lure Panama -- the ROC's long-time ally -- into its camp, Hu admitted that his ministry has prepared psychologically for the worst while making the best of the current situation.

Meanwhile, Hu noted that in the coming year, private resources and influences will be needed, adding that he hoped a concept of "BOT diplomacy" will be introduced to allow private sector access to diplomatic work through private moves such as procurement missions, and international charity-oriented programs.

The foreign minister also announced that he will leave on Jan. 5 for Senegal, where he will attend a regional ROC diplomats conference in Africa. Fourteen ROC ambassadors and representatives in the region are expected to take part in the meeting.
Owing to a tight schedule, Hu will not visit any other allied countries on the African continent in his upcoming trip.

DOC.HEADLINE: AUSSIE CURRENCY SEEN UNLIKELY TO RECOVER IN 1998

TEXT.P: The Australian dollar has suffered its worst year since the currency was floated in 1983, and foreign exchange dealers have forecast a full recovery in 1998 is not in sight.
The Australian dollar plunged 18 percent against the US dollar in 1997, the biggest yearly fall against greenback on record.
The Australian dollar was worth 79.58 US cents at the start of 1997 and reached a high of 80 US cents in March, but it slid to 65 US cents this month and settled at 65.48 US cents Tuesday.
The Australian dollar was mainly hit by the recent financial crisis in Asia.
A worsening current account and depressed commodity prices also have helped the local currency to drop quite dramatically, dealers said.
They are divided on the outlook of the currency in 1998, but few of them are tipping a significant bounce back.
"I don't think the outlook will improve that much next year," Tim Moloney, currency strategist at Deutche Morgan Grenfell, said.

"Asia will take a while to recover, commodity prices won't pick up strongly and Japan is facing a recession. We see the Australian dollar troughing at 64 US cents by March and peaking at around 68 US cents," he said.
Mark Tierney of Bankers Trust Australia is more optimistic, saying the Australian dollar could hover between 70 and 75 US cents.
"It will totally depend on how long this Asian thing hangs over the market's head," he said.
Other analysts are also divided, predicting the currency at between 65 and 75 US cents in 1998.
Australia relies heavily on commodity exports, and Japan is its biggest trading partner.

DOC.HEADLINE: JIANG ZEMIN AGREES TO VISIT AUSTRALIA IN 1998

TEXT.P: Mainland Chinese President Jiang Zemin has in principle agreed to visit Australia some time in 1998, reflecting a large improvement in bilateral relations between Beijing and Canberra following strained ties in 1996.
Jiang has accepted an invitation of Australia's Prime Minister John Howard, but the timing of his visit has yet to be decided, according to the mass circulation newspaper The Australian.
Officials of the two sides are now actively negotiating about both the timing and the substance of the visit, with expectations in Canberra that it will occur in 1998.
Jiang's visit would be the icing on the cake of a massive repair job undertaken by the Howard government after Australia supported the US naval deployment near Taiwan in 1996.

This and other incidents -- including the visit of the Dalai Lama to Australia, the renewed military ties between Washington and Canberra, and the sending of a senior minister to Taipei -- strained ties between mainland China and Australia.
Howard went to visit Beijing in late March this year and his senior ministers, including Foreign Minister Alexander Downer and Trade Minister Tim Fischer, followed suit.

These visits paved the way for improving ties with mainland China, and Beijing reciprocated by the visits of Li Ruihuan, who ranked fourth in the mainland hierarchy, Vice Premier Chu Rongji and other ministers.
Another factor contributing to the improvement of the ties was that Australia abandoned co-sponsorship of the human rights resolution at the UN Human Rights Commission conference in Geneva this year.
Previously, Hu Yaobang visited Australia in 1985 when he was general secretary of the Chinese Communist Party, and Zhao Ziyang also visited here earlier.

DOC.HEADLINE: S'PORE STOCK MARKET VALUE PLUNGES S$4B

TEXT.P: The regional financial turmoil has wiped S$4.15 billion (US$2.49 billion), or 4.6 percent, off the total market value of the 30 blue chips making up the Straits Times Industrials Index (STII) over the last six months.
Their total market capitalization on Monday was S$86.41 billion, compared to S$90.56 billion on July 1, according to the Stock Exchange of Singapore.

However, if Singapore Telecom (SingTel) and Singapore Technologies Engineering (ST Engg) were excluded from the computation, total market capitalization would have slumped 25.5 percent to S$35.34 billion from S$47.43 billion, analysts said.
The STII lost 463.34 points, or 23.4 percent, to 1,517.94 points over the six-month period.

Only SingTel, ST Engg, Avimo and DelGro Corp. traded higher on Monday than their closing prices on July 1, the day before the Thai baht was devalued, sparking months of speculative attacks on regional currencies.
Most of the 30 component stocks were not spared the onslaught of selling in Singapore shares in the past few months, analysts said.
Computer maker IPC Corp. was the top loser in terms of market capitalization. Its share price slumped 67 percent from 45.5 cents to 12.5 cents.
Other counters whose share prices had fallen by more than half were WBL Corp., Singapore Technologies Industrial Corp. and Intraco.
Blue chips fell further Tuesday, with the STII dropping 3.11 points to 1,514.83.

DOC.HEADLINE: MILLENNIUM BUG SEEN DAMAGING COMPUTER SYSTEMS GLOBALLY

TEXT.P: Australia is on heightened alert in preparation for the millennium bug, which will bite computer systems precisely two years from now, and the stock exchange is standing ready to force listed companies to reveal how they will protect themselves from the expected damage.
The Australian Stock Exchange (ASX) warned Tuesday that failure to prepare for the bug would hurt the country's economy and could cost lives.
International focus on the problem, known as Y2K for "Year 2000," is intensifying as the crunch date -- Dec. 31, 1999 -- draws nearer and the implications of unreadiness sink in.

The bug was born from a ploy by 1960s computer programmers to save memory, when programs recorded only the last two digits of years. This will freeze some computers when their internal clocks change from "99" to read "00."
The early programmers had not expected their work would still be in use, and the problem could now strike mainframe computers as well as small chips used in elevators, cars and factories.

ASX Chairman Maurice Newman, who chairs the Australian government's Y2K Taskforce, said he would formally discuss debugging disclosure with the chairman of the Australian Securities Commission Chairman Alan Cameron, early in 1998.
He said the ASX is trying to persuade the world's financial markets to close before and after Jan. 1, 2000 for the final testing of trading technology.
"The surveys I have seen are showing 30 to 40 percent of people have heard of the problem but are not doing anything to fix it -- that is scary," Newman said.

He said global financial markets should rule off their books and close a day early before New Year's Eve 1999 and then close for another 24 hours just a few days into 2000 to see if their computer systems function.
The proposal would cover all transactions, such as foreign exchange and bond trading, share markets and all derivatives trading.

DOC.HEADLINE: CABLE TV VIEWERS IN TAIPEI MIGHT LOSE 28 CHANNELS AT MIDNIGHT

TEXT.P: Taipei's cable TV viewers might see many of their favorite channels unavailable from midnight on Wednesday, as negotiations have collapsed between the country's two largest cable TV operators.

Rebar Eastern TV and Koo's Group are likely to stop transmitting channels affiliated with each other as they have failed to reach consensus on terms for renewing their cooperation contract, which expires on Thursday.

The two groups have a contract to purchase each other's channels for broadcast on their respective cable TV systems, but when renewing the contract, serious disputes erupted over the channel purchase fees and whether each side has to buy a bundle of channels in a package or can just buy the channels they want.
The dispute is almost certain to affect the interests of more than 400,000 cable TV subscribers in the greater Taipei area, with some 28 channels expected to be cut as the new year begins.

President of the Rebar Group Wang You-theng said on Wednesday that if the two sides cannot reach an agreement by Thursday, one more month shall be given for them to work out the dispute. The patriarch of the Koo group, Koo Chen-fu, pointed out that it is therefore possible that paying cable TV subscribers in Taipei will find some channels missing.

Although he claimed that the two groups should be able to solve the dispute by Thursday, Koo added that subscribers who find that they have lost their favorite channels can refuse to pay the subscription fees or switch their cable TV operator.

David Lee, director general of the Government Information Office, on Wednesday reiterated the government's determination to protect the rights of the cable TV subscribers and to mediate in the dispute.

Lee's earlier efforts to mediate at a previous round of talks on Dec. 27. resulted in the two sides agreeing to continue their negotiations based on three principles -- securing the rights of the viewers, competing instead of confronting each other, and purchasing each other's channels -- but events since that meeting seem to suggest that his mediation has been ignored.

DOC.HEADLINE: SHARE PRICES UP ON TAIEX

TEXT.P: Share prices grew 0.5 percent on the local stock market on Wednesday before the market closed for 1997.
Local dealers attributed the rise to purchases by institutional investors seeking to increase the net worth of their funds for year-end rankings.
The Taiwan Stock Exchange (TAIEX) weighted price index rose 41.5 points to close at 8,187.27.

According to TAIEX statistics, the index soared a total of 1,253.33 points this year, with total turnover for the whole the year surging NT$24.6 trillion (US$754.6 billion) to NT$37.7 trillion (US$1.16 trillion) from last year.
The bourse opened at 8,226.33, and experienced a high of 8,243.19 and low of 8,176.7.
A total of 1.8 billion shares changed hands on a market turnover of NT$88.06 billion (US$2.7 billion).
Gainers outnumbered losers 255 to 143, with 74 shares unchanged.
Seven of the eight major stock categories registered gains.
Both technology and paper-making shares recorded the largest gains, at 0.9 percent, followed by foodstuffs and textile stocks, each with a rise of 0.7 percent.
Plastic, chemical and construction issues all posted growth of 0.3 percent, while financial stocks advanced 0.2 percent.
Cement shares dropped 0.4 percent.

The 10 companies with the largest turnovers were: Mosel Vitelic; ADI; Tai Fang Foods Industry; Picvue Electronics; Pao Shiang; China Steel; Winbond Electronics; Da-Cin Construction; Yieh Loong; and Taiwan Tea Corp.
The stock market will not reopen until Jan. 3, 1998.

DOC.HEADLINE: US DOLLAR DOWN

TEXT.P: The US dollar rose NT$0.038 against the New Taiwan dollar on the Taipei foreign exchange market on Wednesday, closing at NT$32.638.
The greenback opened at the day's low of 32.556, and experienced a high of 32.699.
Interbank US dollar trading reached US$265.5 million.

DOC.HEADLINE: MAINLAND INVESTMENT POLICY TO REMAIN IN PLACE

TEXT.P: Economic Affairs Minister Wang Chih-kang said on Wednesday that the government has no plans to change its "no haste, be patient" policy on mainland China investment, but added that it will review the policy if Beijing renounces the use of force against Taiwan.
Wang said the government is willing to revise its policy regulating Taiwan investment on the mainland if the overall situation across the Taiwan Strait and in the region changes.

Speaking at a year-end news conference, Wang stressed that the policy does not ban all Taiwan businesses from investing in mainland China, rather it is aimed at preventing large-scale investment projects worth more than US$50 million or high-tech and infrastructure industries from investing there.

Although Taiwan's economic performance has been brilliant in 1997, with all major economic indexes posting record highs, Wang voiced caution that the local economy will encounter three big challenges in 1998 amid a region-wide financial crisis and a delicate international economy.

According to Wang, the three challenges are a slowing world economy, pressure brought about by the recent global climate conference in Kyoto, Japan, and the pressing issue of entry into the World Trade Organization (WTO).

As the World Monetary Fund has adjusted the growth rate of the world economy from 4.3 percent to 3.5 percent for 1998, Wang said his ministry will closely monitor any effect this might have on Taiwan's export sector and investment willingness.

In line with the agreement reached at the global climate conference on cutting greenhouse gas emissions, Wang said the government will step up its efforts to upgrade Taiwan's industrial sector to reduce the percentage of heavy energy-consuming industries.

The economic affairs minister said a national energy meeting will be held in March to thoroughly overhaul the nation's current energy policy and work out measures to encourage the development of high-tech and high value-added industries.

In addition, he said, the government must accelerate the pace of its efforts to enter the WTO by fully implementing its trade liberalization and globalization policies and taking countermeasures to reduce any possible adverse impact on local industries.

Wang went on to say that the top priority of his ministry next year is to expand domestic demand to sustain continued economic growth and to create an unfettered investment climate to boost investment at home and strengthen the structure of the small business sector.

In anticipation of the ROC gaining WTO entry within the next year, Wang also said his ministry is helping relevant sectors set up a special task force to cope with the possible impact of WTO membership on local industries.

DOC.HEADLINE: TAIWAN'S 1998 ECONOMIC GROWTH TO BE 6.2 PERCENT

TEXT.P: The Central Bank of China (CBC) Wednesday forecast 6.2 percent economic growth for Taiwan in the coming year, along with estimated inflation of 3.5 percent, up from the 3 percent predicted for 1997.
CBC Governor Y.D. Sheu revealed the assessment during the bank's year-end news conference, adding that the CBC will do its best to keep the island's 1998 inflation within the predicted range.
He explained that the 3.5 percent index for consumer price growth was calculated based on a New Taiwan dollar exchange rate of 32 to the US dollar.

The governor said that the Taiwan unit should maintain a value of between 31 and 32 against the greenback in the near future, stressing that his bank will take steps to stem any abnormal trading of the currency which might result in the NT dollar's over-devaluation.

DOC.HEADLINE: MAC HEAD URGES FORMAL NOTICE FOR CROSS-STRAIT TALKS

TEXT.P: Mainland Affairs Council (MAC) Chairman Chang King-yuh on Wednesday urged the mainland Chinese authorities to give Taiwan formal notice of their intention to resume cross-Taiwan Strait dialogue, if indeed they intend to do so.

Chang made the call in response to a report carried in the Hong Kong-based Wen Wei Po newspaper on Wednesday in which Wang Daohan, chairman of the Beijing-based Association for Relations Across the Taiwan Strait (ARATS) was quoted as saying that Taiwan should respond to mainland calls for reopening cross-strait dialogue on political, economic and other issues can be resumed as soon as possible.

Chang said he hopes that Beijing will give Taipei formal notice if decision-makers there indeed want the cross-strait dialogue to be resumed, rather than expressing the desire through informal channels.
Regarding the future of the cross-strait talks, Chang noted that there should be no prerequisites for any new round of talks between the two sides.

DOC.HEADLINE: HSINCHU AVIATION TERMINAL TO OPEN

TEXT.P: Inhabitants of Hsinchu, northern Taiwan, can soon enjoy air services to and from their home area, as the newly constructed Hsinchu aviation terminal will formally open Thursday, the first day of 1998.

Two daily flights to southern Taiwan's largest city, Kaohsiung, along with one flight to Kinmen, a Republic of China-controlled isl;ld lying off the mainland Chinese coast, will become the first regular routes as the terminal opens for domestic air passenger and cargo services.

By March, a total of five additional routes are expected to be gradually added to the flight schedule at the new facility. Eight airliners have been approved to operate the routes, according to authorities at the Hsinchu airfield.

DOC.HEADLINE: GOH CALLS ON SINGAPOREANS TO MAINTAIN CONFIDENCE

TEXT.P: Singapore Prime Minister Goh Chok Tong, in his New Year's message on Wednesday, called on Singaporeans to maintain their confidence in Singapore's economy and government, which he said, is "critical to our growth and prosperity."
"We have won the confidence of the international financial community through 32 years of hardheaded economic policies, prudent financial management and consistent rational behavior," he said.

"If we lose this hard-won confidence, it will take us years to win it back, if ever," he warned. "We must stick to rational policies, and never weaken the sound economic fundamentals which have served us well. This is the key lesson from the regional currency crisis."

He pointed out that the most important development in 1997 has been the continuing regional economic crisis. Thailand's economy was the first to run into problems when the Thai baht was floated on July 2, and dropped immediately. Loss of confidence in Thailand triggered off the financial turmoil in Asia. Regional currencies and stock markets fell sharply.
Goh said, however, that amidst these difficulties, the Singapore economy grew by 7.6 percent in 1997, "better than we had expected."

But, 1998 will be a more difficult year, he cautioned. Slower growth in neighboring countries will affect Singapore and trade with the region will fall. Banks will see less financial activities, and make fewer loans to the region. Fewer tourists from regional nations will visit Singapore, he said.

"Our economies and interests are interlinked. When our partners grow, we grow. When they catch the flu, we will feel unwell. We cannot isolate ourselves from events in the region. But we can minimize their impact on us by strengthening our immune system," he added.

"Our economic fundamentals are sound," Goh stressed. "The Singapore dollar should remain strong. We have large foreign reserves, and no foreign debt. We run substantial budget surpluses. Our banks are strong. We have political stability."
Despite the current gloom, the prime minister told the nation, the medium- and long-term prospects of the region are promising.

Provided the countries in the region undertake necessary but painful adjustments, robust growth should resume after two to three years, he said. The countries will then be "leaner, fitter and more competitive," he added.
He urged Singaporeans to "use the next few years to consolidate and sharpen our competitive edge."
"Let us upgrade our skills, develop our talent, and top up with foreign talent. Let us continue to 'add value' to the economies in the region, help them overcome their difficulties and grow.
"Then we can ride the next wave and surge ahead when the region picks up again," he concluded.

DOC.HEADLINE: 'BIRD FLU' VIRUS NOT DETECTED IN SINGAPORE

TEXT.P: The "bird flu" that has killed four people in Hong Kong has not been detected in people or poultry in Singapore, according to the Singapore Ministry of Health and the Primary Production Department (PPD).

The official assurance was made known in the wake of the mass slaughter of about 1.3 million chickens in Hong Kong in the past two days to rid the former British colony of the influenza strain H5N1, commonly known as bird flu because it had earlier been found only in birds.
The Hong Kong government said that all the chickens in the territory were expected to be destroyed by midnight Tuesday, according to reports from Hong Kong.
The PPD, which monitors all poultry from local farms as well as imported poultry, said Tuesday that Singapore was free from bird flu.
Singapore does not import any poultry from Hong Kong.
Local supplies of frozen or chilled chicken are imported from Brazil, Denmark, the Netherlands and Britain, while live chickens are imported mainly from Malaysia and slaughtered in local abattoirs.

There are about 10 local poultry farms left. The PPD monitors all of them, and only those with "proper infrastructure, good management and sound poultry health and hygiene practices" can supply poultry for consumption in Singapore, said a PPD spokesman.
The spokesman said the PPD has an integrated program to ensure that poultry sold here is free from infectious diseases and is safe for human consumption.
Farms overseas wishing to export poultry to Singapore must first be accredited by the veterinary authority of the exporting country as well as by the PPD.
Also, birds from local and overseas farms are sent routinely to the PPD veterinary laboratory to be tested for a range of diseases, including bird flu, he said.
Live birds slaughtered at local abattoirs are also inspected and tested for drug residues and micro-organisms that cause food poisoning.

DOC.HEADLINE: ROC VICE PRESIDENT TO VISIT SINGAPORE

TEXT.P: Republic of China Vice President Lien Chan and his wife will arrive in Singapore on New Year's Day for a three-day private visit.

While in Singapore, he is expected to play some golf and to reunite with several of his old friends, Ouyang Jui-hsiung, representative of the Taipei Representative Office in Singapore, told several Chinese TV reporters from Taipei on Wednesday.
Staff officials at the Taipei Representative Office disclosed that the Singapore authorities, while making the relevant arrangements, had asked repeatedly that the visit be kept very low-profile.

Informed sources said that although Lien's visit is strictly unofficial, he is nevertheless expected to meet informally with Singapore government leaders, including Prime Minister Goh Chok Tong, to exchange views on topics such as the ongoing regional financial turmoil, prospects for regional economic development and trade liberalization, and other matters of mutual interest.

DOC.HEADLINE: PRESIDENT LEE OUTLINES FIVE GOALS FOR NATION IN NEW YEAR'S MESSAGE

TEXT.P: On the eve of the beginning of his 10th year at the nation's helm, President Lee Teng-hui on Wednesday reviewed the Republic of China's achievements in the past decade and outlined five new goals for his fellow countrymen.

In his New Year's message, Lee listed the ROC's solid democracy, prosperous economy, enhanced national security and pragmatic mainland policy as being among the country's outstanding achievements over the past ten years.
He also held out five objectives for his countrymen to strive for in the future. They are:
First, to enhance the country's competitiveness by consolidating financial policies and initiatives, increasing domestic demand and sustaining the thriving economy.
Second, to cultivate a spirit of diligence and honesty by embarking on a campaign of spiritual reformation and by implementing educational reforms.
Third, to foster a law-abiding spirit by carrying out thorough judicial reform, upholding social justice, combating crime and removing other deficiencies.

Fourth, to establish a responsible and efficient government. This objective, the president said, will require government at all levels to administer in accordance with the laws and regulations, to take greater responsibility for their actions, to develop new ideas and to take the initiative to implement necessary reforms.

Fifth, to establish a society with a rich cultural content by attaching equal importance to humanitarian concerns and culture as the country does to economic development, and by advancing the two goals simultaneously.

DOC.HEADLINE: PRESIDENT LEE TENG-HUI'S NEW YEAR'S DAY MESSAGE (I)

TEXT.P: The following is the full text of President Lee Teng-hui's New Year's Day message:

This New Year's Day marks the beginning of the eighty-seventh year of the Republic of China; It also opens a new chapter for national development. While the new year undoubtedly brings many new tests, it is nevertheless filled with new hopes and opportunities. As long as all of our compatriots work together to set goals, remain steadfastly confident, and continuously strive forward, we can overcome all challenges, meet our responsibilities and usher in an even grander and more prosperous future for our country. It is our firm belief that the eighty-seventh year of the Republic of China shall be a year in which we see a fresh start, achieve new successes and scale new heights in national development.

During the past half century, we have labored under a poor resource base at home and incessant challenges and threats from abroad. Only with our people's "esprit de corps" and hard work could we have generated a vigorous developmental momentum and established a solid foundation for national development. In particular, during the last ten years our compatriots have time and again relied on their outstanding intellect and resolute determination to overcome adversities, to surpass challenges, to open a brand-new historical era of freedom, democracy and prosperity, and to garner the following unprecedented glorious accomplishments: 1. A Solid and Mature Democracy

In the past ten years, we have adhered strongly to the principles of popular sovereignty and continued to pursue democratic reforms. Last year we completed the fourth round of constitutional revisions to further balance the functioning of the central government system. We also downsized government organizations, bringing the democratization process to its concluding stages, and thereby, proudly joining the ranks of the world's modernized countries. 2. A Stable and Prosperous Economy

Over the past few decades, our forward-looking economic policy has produced substantial results by simultaneously restructuring the economy successfully and maintaining a high degree of economic growth. Recently, many East Asian countries are being hit hard by a financial crisis. Our government has been paying constant and close attention to the situation and has dealt with it in a proper manner. As a result, Taiwan has been relatively unscathed by the financial crisis. We estimate our economic growth rate for this year to continue to exceed 6 percent. This proves that our economic policies are correct, our economic structure sound, and prospects rosy. 3. Enhanced National Security

Our remarkable achievements in promoting democratization have added new strength to the world's democratic camp. The fact that the Republic of China exists and has flourished on Taiwan has gained widespread recognition and respect throughout the world. As a result, the world has gradually revised its policies toward the Republic of China. At the same time, we have strengthened and consolidated the combat readiness of our national defense. This has upgraded our national security to a higher level, safeguarding the stable and peaceful environment in which our people live and work. Furthermore, it has allowed the Republic of China to make its own concrete contributions to world peace. (more)

DOC.HEADLINE: NEW YEAR'S DAY MESSAGE (II)

TEXT.P: It was ten years ago when the ROC government first allowed people in Taiwan to visit their relatives on the Chinese mainland. since then, we have taken the initiative to adopt a series of pragmatic and flexible mainland policies and measures, changing the character of cross-strait relations from that of total estrangement and no contacts to the present one of frequent exchanges and close interactions. This development not only serves to promote mutual understanding, but also helps to maintain peace and stability across the Taiwan Strait. As such, it holds great significance to the well-being of the people on both sides of the strait, as well as to long-term national development.

Ladies and gentlemen: While our past accomplishments are worthy of our pride and joy, every day is a new one and there is no end to national development. This is especially true for what we face today. As a thoroughly democratized polity and a new, highly prosperous society, we must arm ourselves with fresh ideas and new methods in order to counter new problems and create new opportunities. Furthermore, as the interdependence between countries deepens day by day, international competition will grow keener and the external environment will become more severe than before. The recent financial crisis that has engulfed countries in East Asia is a more salient example. Although its impact on our country has not been very significant to date, nevertheless, it is not something that should be ignored or taken lightly. Instead, we must raise our vigilance and prepare effective countermeasures.

Therefore, as we face the new year, we have carefully weighted and considered the new circumstances. In the hope of bringing national development to a new height, we must strive toward five objectives:

First, we must enhance our economic competitiveness. The recent Asian financial crisis has proved that our economic system can withstand such a trial. It has also demonstrated the importance of maintaining a sound economic system. In the coming year, we must closely monitor both internal and external changes. We must consolidate financial policies and measures, increase domestic demand, and dedicate our efforts toward sustaining a thriving economy. At the same time, we must plan cautiously and comprehensively for reforming our tax system to integrate business and personal income taxes. We must also make appropriate adjustments for the agricultural sector after our accession to the World Trade Organization. Only thus, can we improve our overall economic environment and strengthen our ability to deal with future challenges and competition.

Second, we must cultivate a spirit of diligence and honesty. Being a poorly endowed country, we have achieved our economic success by relying mainly on the strength of the hardworking and industrious character that our citizens possess. This character also includes a strong determination to always try one's best, a willingness to bear hardships, a perseverance in one's pursuit and a preference for a simple lifestyle. However, the rise in the economic prosperity and affluence of the people has been accompanied by a gradual deterioration of social values. Hedonism and indolence have emerged. Should such trends continue unabated, our economic growth would be jeopardized, and seeds of social malaise would take root, adversely affecting our national strength and competitiveness. Therefore, we must embark on spiritual reformation and awaken those traditional qualities of diligence and honesty. We must also implement educational reform to allow our citizens to reestablish a healthy, simple and positive outlook. Only so can our society shine with vigor and vitality, and forge ahead toward greater progress. (more)

DOC.HEADLINE: NEW YEAR'S DAY MESSAGE (III)

TEXT.P: Third, we must foster a law-abiding spirit. Democracy and rule of law are two sides of the some coin. Once democracy is developed, the strengthening of rule of law must follow. Only in this way can group harmony coexist with respect for individual's freedom. Democracy can then proceed smoothly and unhindered, producing all the functions and values that come naturally with it. Therefore, we must carry out through judicial reforms, uphold social justice, combat crime, and remove deficiencies, so as to maintain social stability and build a democratic, orderly and civilized society.

Fourth, we must establish a responsible and efficient government. We have entered a democratic era where sovereign power resides in the people. We are also part of a pluralistic and rapidly changing society. As such, the people have placed higher expectations for and heavier responsibilities on their government. The fourth constitutional reform completed last year will serve to balance the functioning of the central government and streamline its structure. This will establish a more responsible and efficient government, one that is capable of meeting the needs and expectations of its people. Henceforth, governments of all levels--in particular, local governments which must deal directly with the people's livelihood and welfare--must administer in accordance with the laws and regulations, must take greater responsibility for their actions, must develop new ideas and must take the initiative to implement necessary reforms. Only in this way can the government expand its administrative functions, increase its services, and build a democratic government that is truly "of the people."

Fifth, we must establish a society with a rich cultural content. We must not pursue economic progress at the expense of cultural development. Only by pursuing both will we be able to maintain a balance between material civilization and spiritual values. Today, in contrast with our prosperous economic life, the spiritual life for a majority of the general populace has become somewhat barren. This has resulted in a lack of profound cultural refinement and broad-mindedness in our society, which in turn has caused alienation amongst the people and a growing intensity in conflicts. Therefore, we must enrich our cultural content, lay a solid foundation for spiritual cultivation, and attach equal importance to humanity and culture as we do to economic development. Both must be advanced simultaneously in order to attain a harmonious, honest and culture-rich society.

Ladies and gentlemen: During the past half century, the Republic of China on Taiwan has weathered many epochal storms, and yet has managed to stand from and unwavering through it all. This is due to the fact that at each stage of its development, the Republic of China has been able to set up new goals and formulate new priorities based on an existing foundation and, with the people and the government working hand in hand, to gradually propel the nation to new heights of success, In the coming new year, as long as the entire population of the Republic of China continues to work in unison, greater confidence will be rekindled and greater power amassed to open a bright and glorious era for the Republic of China in 1998!
I wish great prosperity to the Republic of China and a Happy New Year, good health and happiness to all! Thank you!

DOC.HEADLINE: SINGAPOREANS MOURN 104 SILKAIR VICTIMS

TEXT.P: About 8,000 Singaporeans and foreigners mourned the 104 passengers and crew on board SilkAir flight MI-185, which crashed near Palembang, Indonesia on Dec. 19, in a solemn condolence service Tuesday.

The public condolence service, held in the Singapore Indoor Stadium, started at 6 p.m. with a recital of the names of the 104 victims of the ill-fated SilkAir flight, 97 passengers of various nationalities, including Wang Li-ming from Taiwan, and seven crew members. Among the total were 46 Singaporeans.
Former Singapore President Dr. Wee Kim Wee, chairman of the organizing committee for the condolence service, first addressed the packed audience of friends, family and other mourners of the victims.

"We are gathered here today in a sad and painful moment in our history to share in the sorrow and grief of those who have lost their loved ones in the SilkAir crash on Dec. 19 in Palembang, Indonesia," he said.

Singapore Prime Minister Goh Chok Tong stressed in his address: "We have to be strong. Life must go on from here, however difficult it may be. The families (of the victims) must over time step out from the sudden darkness in their lives, SilkAir must fly again with confidence, and the country must emerge with fortitude from this shared grief."
He called on Singaporeans to "give meaning to the lives of those who had gone."

"Our grief for them has brought us closer as a community and a nation. They have, in our remembrance of them, given us the collective strength to face life's challenges. Let us live tomorrow bravely," he continued.
After prayers by representatives from Singapore's nine religions, all mourners stood up in observance of one minute of silence for the 104 SilkAir victims, concluding the 45-minute service.

Also attending Tuesday's service were Singapore's Senior Minister Lee Kuan Yew, Deputy Prime Minister Lee Hsien Loong, cabinet ministers, members of Parliament and representatives of foreign countries whose nationals were among the 58 foreign passengers on board the plane.
Ouyang Jui-hsiung, representative of the Taipei Representative Office in Singapore, was among those present at the service.
